column2: Wednesday was a big day for flip-flops. First Facebook, then Tumblr. From our colleagues at The Lede:

After five days of round-the-clock wrangling, the California Legislature finally agreed on a budget plan to close a huge $40 billion deficit. While the plunging economy has been cited as the cause of the bitter standoff, the state is famous for its perennial eleventh-hour budget dramas and crises.

The Kodak Theater will be alive with awards on Sunday, but the one picking up most of the loot will likely be "Slumdog Millionaire," which was shot digitally. Still, all films end up on film (at least for now), regardless of how they are shot, and Kodak is not above thinking about a hybrid future. On its Web site, Kodak has a really funny take from the National Film & Television School in Britain, which created "Mr. Pixel Mrs. Grain: A Never-Ending Love Story." Turns out a marriage between these December/May technologies is not out of the question. There is even a sequel, or two.

The end of the regular season is less than a month away for teams in the Canadian Hockey League, which means we will be able to see just how the weekly rankings translate into good fortune in the playoffs.
The fury over the executive compensation caps in the recently passed American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, also known as the stimulus bill, misses the point.

A posting in the housing section of the Chicago Craigslist trumpets the availability of one- and two-bedroom condos in an "Eco-Friendly, LEED Certified Building!" The promotional Web site for the building lists "LEED-Certified" as one of the "eco-features."
Bollywood-style dance classes, based on the lavish dance numbers found in some films from India, have become a popular attraction among American exercisers, the Associated Press reports.
The winner of Beliefnet's most spiritual film of the year contest (definitely not to be confused with the Spirit Awards, which will be given out by godless, indie heathens on Satuday), is "Wall-E:"
In today's paper, Paul Boutin wrote about some unconventional solutions for fixing misbehaving gadgets. (Dropped your phone in the toilet? Stick it in a jar of dry rice.)

For the first time anyone could remember -- or even comprehend -- the sight of Joe Cuba brought people to tears. For more than half a century, this conga-playing son of El Barrio fronted bands whose music was relentless, hip and happy.
There it is, on page 14 of General Motors' 117-page viability plan. It was a paragraph on Saab, under the plan's foreign operations summary:

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- Funny scene from Field 4 here at the Mets' facility where the infielders are warming up: Luis Castillo, playing catch with Alex Cora, just plunked Cora with one of his first throws. Cora stayed down on one knee for a few seconds pretending to be hurt before getting up and laughing it off.

Morgan Stanley has tapped William Wicker, the former head of Goldman Sachs's investment bank in China, as a vice-chairman of investment banking in its natural resources group, The Financial Times reported, citing a person close to the company.

Thirty years ago, I was a business writer and editor at The Associated Press who got the dollar numbers each afternoon. One day I announced to my colleagues that the dollar was down more than 1 percent again. (It had been a brutal stretch for the currency.)

After making discreet inquiries to studios around town, the Baquette has discovered that the pre-Oscar party scene has been scaled way back this year. Yes, they are taking place, but they are smaller, some in the form of intimate dinners rather than gigantic parties poolside at some luxury hotel.
On Thursday, a British soldier killed in Afghanistan is to be repatriated at the Royal Air Force base in Lyneham, England. Two more British war dead are scheduled for ceremonies next week.

Updated, 2:36 p.m. | President Obama on Thursday announced the appointments of two New York officials to his administration, naming Adolfo Carrión Jr. as the White House director of urban affairs and Derek R. B. Douglas as a special assistant to the president for urban affairs, The Caucus blog reports.
Scenes from the photographer Eric Ray Davidson's exclusive fashion week diary.
Catching up on some links from the past few days:
Danny Meyer has announced some more plans for food concessions at Citi Field, the new Mets stadium.
Vindu Goel from The Lede's blog cousin, Bits, draws our attention to a development in a story we discussed yesterday.
Updated at 2:20 p.m. with IMG reiterating its denial

Seven moments you aren't likely to see at this year's Oscars, but might want to: Cinematical's got them lined up in a row, including a crash by Bruce Springsteen, a best actress win by Anne Hathaway and Hugh Jackman getting his inner Ellen DeGeneres on.
In this interview from 2009, Oscar de la Renta, the social set’s favorite dressmaker, holds nothing back.
Mayor Gavin Newsom of San Francisco took to blogging Wednesday at Gas 2.0 -- on the occasion of his city's installation of electric-vehicle charging stations in front of San Francisco City Hall.

President Obama on Thursday announced the appointments of two New York officials to his administration, naming Adolfo Carrión Jr. as the White House Director of Urban Affairs and Derek Douglas as a special assistant to the president for urban affairs.
I bought my first Brompton a few months ago and as I wrote here in October, the bike gave me immediate joy.
Updated 12:35 p.m.

Much has been written about the lack of box office this year's nominees have generated, turning the so-called Oscar bump into a bit of a pothole. But according to Bloomberg News, "Slumdog Millionaire" has been surprisingly buoyant since being named and may end up topping $100 million:
Health news from around the Web.

For the first foreign trip of his presidency, President Obama has chosen our neighbor to the north, and Thursday morning he will be in Ottawa for meetings with Canadian leaders, including Prime Minister Stephen Harper.

When you're 64 years you feel the chill a bit more than the younger folks. So if the economy doesn't warm up, said Michael Miele, the chef and one of the owners of Gino on the Upper East Side, the restaurant will close.

On the way down to the Kodak Theater, the Bagger drove along Melrose and noticed that this shiny piece of retail was missing a few teeth. There were fancy places with grates on the front, lots of signs about space for lease and many vacant fronts. In case you hadn't heard, the country has lost some steam since the last Oscars and California is feeling it. Right now, legislators are camping out in Sacramento with sleeping bags and tooth brushes to close a nearly $42 billion budget gap. The state's woes might cheer a few people who have always hoped that California might slide off into the ocean, but for the rest of us, it is a grim portent of what might be coming down the pike. California has always been a bit of trendsetter, and it will probably be no different this time around.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has denounced political parties as a "swamp of dysfunction," he has bankrolled a campaign to eliminate them from the New York City elections, and he has dismissively cast off his own party affiliations like ill-fitting garments. (Democrat? Been there. Republican? Done that.)
Video | To you, it's an annoying infomercial for the "blanket with sleeves." But might it not also be a monkish cult? Move away from the Kool-Aid!
View Larger Map

The Western Climate Initiative began as an agreement between Western governors (and a few Canadian provinces) to place a cap on greenhouse gas emissions and develop a regional market for trading in emissions permits.
Your Jokes | Send via the comment link below:

With $7 billion of government money on the line, it's no surprise that all kinds of companies are claiming they can wire the most isolated ranchers and mountaintop recluses with broadband Internet service.
Say all the grocery stores shut down. Do you have enough food in the pantry to last a week? The fine folks at eGullet believe you do.

Roche Holding of Switzerland sold $16 billion of bonds to finance its $42.1 billion takeover of the United States-based biotech company Genentech. The bond offering, the second-largest company bond offering in history, was a sign of thawing credit markets, Bloomberg News said, citing its own data.

The board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which meets later today, is expected to approve a $300 million plan to replace the longest runway at Kennedy International Airport. The plan would require shutting Runway 13R-31L for about four months, which will lead to delays at the airport. Airlines will have to adjust their schedules and use the airport's three remaining runways.The 14,572-foot runway handles about one-third of the airport's flights, including more than half of all departures. In all, the airport handled about 440,000 flights in 2008.

Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, expressed skepticism Wednesday about the prospect of nationalizing troubled banks and suggested that President Obama's administration would much prefer to keep financial institutions in private hands.
BNP Paribas said Thursday it lost 1.37 billion euros ($1.72 billion) in the fourth quarter as the global financial crisis caught up with France's largest bank.

History | Andrew Jackson, the original Democrat but a small-government Jeffersonian, was the last President to get the country out of hock, John Steele Gordon writes in a "short history of the national debt." Historically the debt was taken quite seriously and there were only two reasons to add to it: war and recession. In recent years there's been a third: profligacy. Wait, make that bipartisanship, in a way, "because Democrats and Republicans alike never said no to any significant interest group." [Wall Street Journal]
In the hush-hush world of Swiss banking, the unthinkable is happening: secrets are spilling into the open.

General Motors, which is seeking $30 billion from United States taxpayers to restructure its ailing business, may sell a stake in its German carmaker, Adam Opel, and could abandon its sporty Swedish brand, Saab, as it seeks ways to cut costs and raise funds.

The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, the agency that polices Wall Street for the Securities and Exchange Commission, plans to name Richard G. Ketchum, a longtime regulator, as its new chief executive. Mr. Ketchum is currently the chief executive of NYSE Regulation Inc., which regulates the New York Stock Exchange.
The Carlyle Group has offered to pay $36 million to keep control of IMO Carwash, in return for the company's creditors writing off debt, The Financial Times reported.

J. Christopher Flowers, the private equity financier, said that ill-timed investments in financial firms in the United States and Europe have caused problems for Shinsei Bank, the Japanese lender that he partly owns.
The stimulus package, while welcome, may not be a quick fix for the struggling wind and solar industries, experts say.
Venture investing may have ground to a halt these days, amid the uncertainty in the markets, but there are still a few lucky start-ups that appear to be beating the odds.
Chef Tom Colicchio is known in the culinary world for his Craft restaurants, but many people recognize him as the head judge on the popular cooking show "Top Chef."
Nancy Folbre is a professor of economics at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

Internet | The future of Web journalism as seen by a Google senior vice president (in an e-mail originally meant for internal consumption): "We won't (and shouldn't) try to stop the faceless scribes of drivel, but we can move them to the back row of the arena." But not "high-quality" content: "We need to make it easier for the experts, journalists, and editors that we actually trust to publish their work under an authorship model that is authenticated and extensible, and then to monetize in a meaningful way." [GoogleBlog]

GroSolar, a New England solar installer, said Wednesday that it was buying the residential-installation business of Borrego Solar Systems, making the combined company the fourth-largest residential solar installer in the United States.
Businesses filing for bankruptcy need loans to work out their troubles, or face liquidation.

Chancellor Angela Merkel's cabinet agreed Wednesday to support a plan to give the government the right to seize control of a private bank whose failure would pose a risk to the stability of the financial system.

Goldman Sachs said several partners must cover margin calls generated by the depressed value of Goldman stock and many of the firm's hedge funds, but the bank denied a report that it's lending money to its executives.
In 2005, foreign investors were growing nervous about Venezuela as President Hugo Chávez began asserting greater control of the economy, but Stanford Group decided it was time to put down stakes.

Technology | Video games have infiltrated the everyday by encouraging players to "cook dinner, get in shape, learn French, rediscover the greatness of Beethoven or keep their wits sharp." A writer asks: "That can't be all bad, can it?" Are we approaching "a time in which nearly every experience offers the possibility, if not the requirement, for play"? [More Intelligent Life]
Is Carl C. Icahn looking to engineer a sale of Lions Gate Entertainment?

Years before the Stanford Group was accused in a worldwide fraud, American financial regulators found significant securities violations at the company that some experts say were telltale signs of deeper problems.
In the unlikely event that Barack Obama has some free time during his first trip to a foreign country as president on Thursday, he can take in Ottawa's first Tar Sands Film Festival.
Cellphones are growing up, and they just might pose a new threat to the Intel-Microsoft based personal computers.

Confession it seems is good for the share price. At least that seemed to be the case for UBS, whose stock rose 3 percent on Thursday after the Swiss bank agreed to divulge the names of well-heeled Americans whom the authorities suspect of using offshore accounts at the bank to evade taxes.
Billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn may be rolling the dice again on an Atlantic City casino.
General Motors vowed on Wednesday that its latest request for federal aid would be the last it would need to carry it through the biggest reorganization in its history.

Literature | The philanthropic Charles Dickens founded a home for misfit women, a "chaste little harem" that was Dickensian if not sometimes Chaucerian -- as when one ward was found was found "carrying on in the kitchen with the police constable employed to watch the place." Were Dickens's lost interviews with these women his "ur-text, the book behind his other books"? More likely, a review says, they were a catharsis for a novelist "quietly exploring his own escape from childhood poverty and the street life of 19th century London." [Times Literary Supplement]

It is not just Wall Street executives who banked on receiving year-end bonuses to support their lifestyles when the economy was booming. A more muted form of the bonus culture extends across the United States, The New York Times's Matt Richtel writes.

A top U.S. regulator on Wednesday backed the idea of giving public company shareholders a so-called say on pay on executive compensation, a concept gaining momentum among investors and lawmakers amid the financial crisis.

Dwayne De Rosario has played on four Major League Soccer championship teams and has been a league all-star three times since joining the league in 2001. After successful stints in San Jose and Houston, De Rosario is back in his native Ontario, playing his first season for Toronto F.C. He won back-to-back goal of the year award in M.L.S. (2004 and 2005), so perhaps it should not be a surprise that De Rosario went with a tantalizing, offensive-oriented Ultimate XI.
It may seem counterintuitive that in the midst of this global economic crisis a substantial number of entrepreneurs, investors and venture capital financiers are interested in starting a company.

I know Word keeps a list of recently opened documents. I don't even use Word that much and Windows XP Start menu has its own list of My Recent Documents I've had open on the PC. Is there a way to erase this list when I want to?

India's highest-level investigative agency agreed Wednesday to open an inquiry into the software outsourcing company Satyam Computer Services, a move that might complicate a quick sale of the company, The New York Times's Heather Timmons reports.
From Claire Cain Miller at Bits:
A property with heavenly connections is on the market in San Francisco.

Wells Fargo shares fell on Wednesday to their lowest level in almost 12 years before recovering amid fears the fourth-largest U.S. bank could cut its dividend and post higher losses after its purchase of Wachovia.

The headlines generated by President Obama's speech on housing and separate comments from the Federal Reserve about the deteriorating economy did little to move stock markets on Wednesday, The New York Times's Jack Healy writes.

Much has been written about how the market for initial public offerings froze out biotech companies in 2008, but it looks like times are also tough for those who went public before the economy soured, VentureBeat says.

State and local governments and the investors who buy their bonds got a bit of welcome news on Wednesday as the leading bond insurer took steps to restore its credibility, The New York Times's Mary Williams Walsh writes.

Charles Barkley called his arrest for drunk driving “unacceptable” as he prepared to return to his television job after a six-week leave of absence. Barkley, 45, had a blood-alcohol level of .149 percent, nearly twice the legal limit of .08 percent in Arizona, after he was arrested Dec. 31 in Scottsdale. He will resume his role as a studio analyst for TNT on Thursday.

Baltimore used the franchise tag on the Pro Bowl linebacker Terrell Suggs for the second consecutive year, which costs the team $10.2 million against the 2009 salary cap. Suggs, a three-time Pro Bowl selection who led the team with eight sacks while recording a career-high 102 tackles last season, was scheduled to become an unrestricted free agent. He played last season under an $8.5 million franchise tag. The Ravens have been negotiating with Suggs’s agent for the last few seasons in hopes of striking a long-term deal. ¶The San Diego Chargers have placed the nonexclusive franchise tag on Darren Sproles, a running back and kick returner who had a huge playoff game against the Indianapolis Colts. Sproles can still negotiate with other teams. If he receives an offer, the Chargers can either match it or receive two first-round draft choices as compensation. chargers ¶New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady said his recovery from knee surgery remained on schedule and he did not see any reason he would not be ready for the 2009 opener. brady.
Mike Whitmarsh, a 1996 Olympic silver medalist in beach volleyball, killed himself through carbon monoxide poisoning in the garage of a friend’s home, officials said. He was 46.

Times are tough all around these days, but the interrelated fields of fashion, media and art in particular are suffering a collective meltdown as galleries shutter, retail sales buckle and publishers now pine for the good old days when "flat" was the new "up." It is, however, a great time to be in the bar business. Pop-up watering holes are poised to be the next big thing. Take, for example, the O.H.W.O.W. space during Art Basel Miami or Le Baron at the Bowery Hotel in New York this fashion week, both of which catered to the escapist urges of an increasingly anxious customer base. Add to that list the 032C Ever Ever Altar Bar, newly opened in Berlin. A collaboration between Berlin's "It" publication and the French designer-artist Item Idem, the space was inaugurated during Berlin Fashion Week with a small reception for the sound stylist Michel Gaubert, and for the following three weekends played high-concept host to a series of get-togethers complete with custom vodka cocktails and fresh dim sum.
President Obama unveiled his ambitious plan to help up to nine million American homeowners. It's an issue that has resisted easy answers in the two years since the housing crisis began.
Mr. McGlinn was a conductor and musical historian who delved deep into neglected archives to recreate musicals in their original form.
Mr. Bond was the most influential African-American architect in New York and one of a few black architects of national prominence.
Reviews of the Michael Kors, Narciso Rodriguez, Sophie Theallet and Rodarte fall collections.
Reviews of the Chris Benz, Coventry, Marc by Marc Jacobs, Peter Som and Thakoon fall 2009 shows.
New York Times correspondent Robert F. Worth reports from Dubai where luxury cars — once the treasured spoils of economic success — are now being sold at auction as foreign workers lose their jobs.
Gov. Sarah Palin must pay back taxes on nearly $18,000 in expenses she charged the state for living in her home instead of in the state capital, officials said.
After 17 years behind bars for a murder that a judge says he did not commit, a Missouri inmate, Joshua Kezer, walked out of a prison a free man.
A lack of communication between crew members played a critical role in the crash of a container ship, causing an oil spill in the San Francisco Bay in 2007, federal officials said.
A survey of nonprofit groups has identified at least $10.6 billion in “shovel ready” infrastructure projects, many of which have been postponed because of credit constraints.
Among today's headlines:
Ken Griffey Jr. has decided to return to the Seattle Mariners, General Manager Jack Zduriencik confirmed on Wednesday night.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Jason Kidd and Antoine Wright celebrated the first anniversary of their trade from the Nets, leading the Dallas Mavericks to a victory over their former team.
Maya Moore scored 16 points and Tiffany Hayes added 15 as top-ranked Connecticut cruised to a 75-39 victory Wednesday night at Providence (9-16, 3-9 Big East).
Alex Ovechkin scored another spectacular, how-did-he-do-that goal while sliding on the ice, helping the host Washington Capitals to a shootout win over the Montreal Canadiens.
Investigators would like to ask Alex Rodriguez who provided him with performance-enhancing drugs, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.
The State of Pennsylvania will let the carp of Pymatuning Lake continue to eat bread thrown by visitors, who number in the hundreds of thousands every year.
Once viewed as trading pawns, Nate Robinson and David Lee now look like indispensable parts of the Knicks’ future.
Several dozen students occupied a cafeteria at New York University barricading themselves inside with tables and chairs and chanting a list of demands.
After a decline in Harvard University’s endowment, it is reviewing plans for a four-building science center in the Allston neighborhood of Boston.

The Department of Defense has identified 4,239 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 644 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
Instead of continuing to cling to the theory of “freedom of action” in space, all space-faring countries would be well advised to sit down and talk about mutual restraint and coordination.
If the White House wants to resuscitate talks with Russia about nuclear-arms reduction, it will need to break free from cold war thinking.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
A Sunday ban of beer sales is more a triumph of special interests than the lingering spirit of the Puritans.
Now that it appears that Roland Burris finessed some of his testimony about his connection to Rod Blagojevich, the disgraced former governor of Illinois, he should consider resigning.
An inquiry is long overdue into whether Sharon Keller, an Texas appellate court judge, closed the court clerk’s office before a death-row inmate could file an emergency appeal.
President Obama’s anti-foreclosure plan does not do enough to help the some 13.6 million homeowners who have mortgage balances higher than the value of their properties.
The central Iranian political fact of recent years has been the reinforcement of Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. How to engage with Iran begins and ends with him.
Lately I am beginning to wonder if, in our current troubled times, being in a Senate — any Senate — actually is hell.
Prosecutors portrayed the ringleader of the Miami men, who are accused of planning to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago, as obsessed with overthrowing the government.

Jim Ochse won the Empire State Building Run-Up in 1980 and 1982. Now 54, he finished in 16:18 this year. He is a fitness trainer in Allentown, Pa. Andrew Femia, 35, a New York triathlete and lawyer, finished in 16:49. Here are their climbing tips:.
Mr. Ndiaye was the veteran curator of Senegal’s historic House of Slaves, whose famous visitors included Nelson Mandela and Bill Clinton.
Do President Obama’s visits to states that turned from red to blue signal that he is already eyeing re-election?
Scott Gomez’s power-play goal in the second period snapped a tie and gave the Rangers and Coach Tom Renney a much-needed win.
The struggling search engine is trying to win business back from its big rival, Google, by improving click-through rates.
The case of a W. R. Grace & Company mine affected miners but also a Montana town at large, where many became ill.
Ken Griffey Jr. has decided to return to the Seattle Mariners, General Manager Jack Zduriencik confirmed on Wednesday night.

An article on Feb. 10 about efforts to create complete evolutionary trees misspelled the name of a computer program that can navigate through a three-dimensional evolutionary tree. It is Paloverde, not Paleoverde. The article also misspelled a type of tree that researchers have studied. It is the baobab, not baobob.

A Sports of The Times column on Monday, about the plight of Shahar Peer, the Israeli tennis player who was denied a visa to play in an event in Dubai, misspelled, in some copies, the name of the city in New Zealand where she faced a small protest last month because of Israel’s Gaza incursion. It is Auckland, not Aukland.
General Motors and Chrysler have threatened that they will need $125 billion to finance bankruptcy if they do not receive the additional federal aid they are requesting.
An article on Feb. 11 previewing the World Cup qualifying match between the United States and Mexico misstated the year that Bob Bradley became the United States coach. It was 2006, not 2003.

An article on Wednesday about the cyclist Floyd Landis, who is competing at the Tour of California in his first professional road race since being stripped of his 2006 Tour de France title, misstated the given name of a teammate in some editions. He is Brad White, not Mike. The article and a picture caption also misidentified, in some editions, the home country of Thor Hushovd, who won Tuesday’s stage of the Tour of California. It is Norway, not Sweden.
Antony Hegarty, the ethereal torch singer of Antony and the Johnsons, has a solo art exhibition in London. A case could be made that he is following some uncharted lines.

A daybook listing in the City Room column in some editions on Monday about a talk by Daniel Libeskind, the architect, on his latest book misstated his nationality. He was born in Poland and became an American citizen in 1965; he is not German.

An article on Feb. 7 about complaints by the city teachers’ union that administrators at KIPP AMP, a charter school in Brooklyn, were intimidating teachers seeking to organize misstated the number of teachers who had signed a petition supporting the union. The number of signers was 16, not 15. The article also gave an erroneous figure from the union for the total number of teachers at the school. At the time, there were 20, not 22; one has since quit.
Jurors in the trial of a Queens woman accused of hiring a hit man to kill her husband were shown a video that prosecutors said foreshadowed the man’s death.

An article on Friday about Britain’s refusing entry to Geert Wilders, a member of the Dutch Parliament whose film, “Fitna,” caused outrage in the Muslim world after it appeared on the Internet, misstated the number of seats in the parliament. There are 225 seats, not 120. (Mr. Wilders’ party holds nine seats in the 150-member lower house.).
INTERNATIONAL.
The Obama administration’s housing plan aims to help homeowners who fall into two categories: those struggling to pay their mortgages and those shut out of the refinancing market.
The excavation for a parking garage near the La Brea tar pits also has yielded a trove of other bones from the last ice age.
For the second time this month, a small earthquake, magnitude 2.4, struck northern New Jersey.
The federal ruling could affect President Obama’s efforts to close the detention site at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
The Darfur conflict has now lasted longer than World War II, and the international community has remained monumentally feckless. Can George Clooney get the world to take action?
A hospital spokesman called the woman’s improved vital signs “a huge positive.”
Historically black institutions have disadvantages when it comes to weathering hard times: smaller endowments and a higher proportion of students who are facing a credit crunch.
The top American commander in Afghanistan said Wednesday that the heightened troop levels that President Obama ordered for Afghanistan could remain in place for as long as five years.
As much as 30 percent of Stanford International Bank’s $8 billion in reported assets last year came from Venezuelans.
José Reyes and Luis Castillo, the Mets’ double-play combination, will play central roles in Manager Jerry Manuel’s lineup machinations.
Mark Cavendish’s hands were already raised in celebration as he crossed the line Wednesday. He should not have been so sure.
Some mortgage companies view foreclosure as more profitable and expedient than loan modifications.
Mr. Van Pelt was a stalwart linebacker for the Giants who was perhaps the best player on the woeful squads fielded by the team in the 1970s.
A 43-year-old man is making a second attempt at rowing a boat 8,000 miles from Senegal to Brooklyn to raise awareness about AIDS prevention.
Cash-starved states will probably continue to face large budget gaps once the temporary federal aid stops flowing, according to a report.
The Boston Red Sox owner John Henry renewed his call for a salary cap to improve competitive balance.
Without its mercurial free-agent slugger, Manny Ramírez, a young team is at a crossroads.
The Walt Disney Company said that it would lay off an unspecified number of workers as it revamped its theme parks after declines in attendance and revenue.
Confronting consumer anxiety over the economy, the giant insurer Geico is for the first time rolling out a secret ingredient of its own: Warren E. Buffett.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is pleading with political party leaders to put his name on their ballot lines this fall.
Officials have significantly increased security forces across Tibet in the face of a grass-roots movement to boycott festivities during the coming Tibetan New Year.
Crime laboratories around the country are grossly underfunded and lack a scientific foundation, according to a study by the National Academy of Sciences.
The United Arab Emirates will issue an entry visa to Andy Ram of Israel for the Barclays Dubai Tennis Championships, said Representative Anthony D. Weiner.
Alex Rodriguez’s vapid answers regarding his flirtation with steroids continued to haunt other Yankees on the first full day of spring training.
In San Francisco, a city supervisor wants to preserve the spirit of the Bay to Breakers footrace, known for runners in various stages of inebriation and undress.
The Russians are hoping Asian governments can compensate for the vast sums Western investors have pulled out of Russia in recent months.
Years before it was accused of fraud, regulators found violations but let the Stanford Group off with modest fines.
U.S. debt could rise from 41 percent of G.D.P. in September 2008 to about 70 percent in 2011.
In his home state of Illinois, Roland W. Burris faced increasingly harsh criticism over how he was named to President Obama’s former Senate seat.
People in a wide range of jobs, accustomed to year-end bonuses to meet their expenses, are trimming back.
Rescuers plucked 18 people from the icy, dark waters of the North Sea on Wednesday after a helicopter ditched close to an oil and gas platform off the east coast of Scotland.
Authorities say they see the hidden hand of drug traffickers in a recent wave of demonstrations protesting the presence of army troops across northern Mexico.
Pope Benedict XVI spoke with Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a Roman Catholic who supports abortion rights and the highest-ranking Democrat to meet with him since the election of President Obama.
A jury ordered Philip Morris to pay $8 million in damages to the widow of a smoker who died of lung cancer in a case that could set a standard for roughly 8,000 similar lawsuits in Florida.
Without hoped-for aid from Washington, the bond insurer MBIA is restructuring itself to regain a triple A rating.
An 81-year-old retired doctor is working to continue to offer free medical care to the poor after his clinic was shut down due to state budget cuts.
As Barack Obama embarks on his first foreign trip as president to Canada, he is no longer emphasizing the idea of renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement.
Papers from New York, Albany, Buffalo, Newark and Hackensack, N.J., are forming an alliance.
The U.S. and Europe had long pressed for the release of Ayman Nour, a one-time presidential candidate.
An after-action review of the military’s last 15-month rotation in northern Iraq offers lessons to the Obama administration as it prepares for further reductions of American troops.
Militias have sprung up in isolated villages in Congo in an attempt to defend against the Lord’s Resistance Army rebels.
Fire officials are investigating whether four car fires near Central Park in the past two weeks were related.
Ecuador expelled Mark Sullivan, United States diplomat, accusing him of trying to handpick local police officers.
Government artillery attacks and air raids in Sri Lanka’s northern war zone killed at least 38 civilians on Wednesday and wounded 140 others.
Foreign Minister Grigol Vashadze said in a continued effort to court NATO that Georgia planned to send a company of troops to join the NATO-led force in Afghanistan.
The judge in a trial of eight men accused of plotting to blow up several trans-Atlantic airliners discharged the jury after only one full day of testimony.
The name, I Choose Hell Productions, was turned down because state law restricts names that include blasphemy, cursing or “that profane the Lord’s name.”
Does force-quitting a program hurt it?
What does it mean when iTunes music is “D.R.M.-free”? Does that mean I can play the files on other types of players?
If your Firefox bookmarks menu is full of old pages you bookmarked to read later, the Read It Later extension might help clean things up.

Should Heath Ledger be named best supporting actor at the Oscars on Sunday, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said the statuette would eventually become the possession of Matilda Rose Ledger, daughter of Ledger and the actress Michelle Williams, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Ledger, who died in January 2008 of an accidental drug overdose, is nominated for his performance in “The Dark Knight.” Posthumous Oscars usually go to a winner’s spouse or oldest child. Mr. Ledger was not married to Ms. Williams, but Matilda, 3, is legally ineligible to sign the contract the academy mandates for all Oscar recipients, which limits their ability to resell the statuette. So, if Mr. Ledger wins, the award will go to Ms. Williams, in trust for Matilda until she turns 18.

The coming Broadway transfer of “Rock of Ages,” the improbably successful musical pieced together from power-chord ballads by Journey, Bon Jovi and other ’80s-era bands, has announced its complete cast. Constantine Maroulis, the “American Idol” finalist who starred in the show’s Off Broadway run at New World Stages, will return in the lead role of Drew, the aspiring Los Angeles rock star. He’ll be joined by Amy Spanger (of Broadway’s “Wedding Singer”) and James Carpinello (Broadway’s “Saturday Night Fever”). Previews for “Rock of Ages” are scheduled to begin on March 17 at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, and the show is to open on April 7.

An article on Feb. 5 about Domino magazine referred incorrectly to a decline in its advertising. For 2008, ad pages were down 4.5 percent compared with 2007; for the December-January 2008 issue, they were down 26 percent compared with the same issue in 2007. Ad pages were not down 26 percent for all of 2008.

A vodka named for Jimi Hendrix will probably never be experienced by consumers after a judge ruled that the product infringes on his trademarks. Experience Hendrix and Authentic Hendrix, which own and license Hendrix’s likeness and music, said in a statement that they had won a $3.2 million judgment against Craig Dieffenbach and his Electric Hendrix Spirits, maker of Hendrix Electric Vodka, right. Electric Hendrix Spirits had described the liquor as inspired “by the innovative spirit of legendary musician Jimi Hendrix,” but the judge, Thomas S. Zilly of Federal District Court in western Washington State, prohibited the company from using Hendrix products for commercial purposes and ordered that the vodka and any related advertising be withdrawn.

An article on Feb. 5 about Plant-O-Rama, an annual gathering of gardeners at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, referred incorrectly to Heronswood Nursery. It was bought in 2000 by W. Atlee Burpee & Company and its operations were moved from Kingston, Wash., to Doylestown, Pa. It is not defunct.

At a hearing in Los Angeles, Superior Court Judge Peter Espinoza rejected Roman Polanski’s request that the 32-year-old case against him for having unlawful sexual relations with a minor be dropped because of alleged wrongdoing by a judge and prosecutor. Judge Espinoza based his decision on Mr. Polanski’s fugitive status, but said the order would not become final until May 7, giving Mr. Polanski time to consider an appearance to plead his case. If Mr. Polanski, who lives in France, were to return to the United States, evidence that “substantial misconduct occurred” during the case would be considered, the judge said.

BOND--J. Max, Jr. The partners and staff of Davis Brody Bond deeply mourn the passing of J. Max Bond, Jr. Through a lifetime of work, Max forged his way through the barriers of discrimination to become one of the country's leading architects and educators. He was a colleague and mentor to many from his early days as a co-founder of the Architects Renewal Committee of Harlem to the staffs at Bond Ryder and Associates and Davis Brody Bond. Social responsibility was a fundamental goal that guided Max's work. His portfolio was diverse and included the Bolgatanga Library in Ghana, the Birmingham Civil Rights Museum, The Martin Luther King, Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change in Atlanta, the Studio Museum of Harlem, and buildings at Harvard, Columbia, Northwestern and Dillard Universities. Max's leadership went beyond those who worked with him. He served as the Chairman of Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture and Planning, and the Dean of the School of Architecture and Environmental Studies at City College of New York. He was devoted to the Harlem community where he lived with his family for many years. His contributions were honored through awards from professional, cultural and public institutions including the 2005 President's Award from the AIA New York Chapter for his commitment to design excellence, activism and diversity in the profession, an Honorary Doctorate of Fine Arts from the University of Michigan and the AIA New York Chapter's 2008 Medal of Honor. Max carved the path for so many in our profession. His determination, wisdom and guidance will continue to inspire all of us who knew him. Davis Brody Bond LLP Architects and Planners

A memorial tribute to the folk singer Odetta will be held on Tuesday at 7 p.m. at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive, at 122nd Street, in Morningside Heights. Odetta, whose voice was a resonant force throughout the civil-rights movement and for decades afterward, died on Dec. 2 at 77. The memorial is open to the public and free of charge. Bernice Johnson Reagon and Tom Chapin are to serve as hosts of the event, which is scheduled to include music and readings by David Amram, Maya Angelou, Harry Belafonte, Oscar Brand, Ruby Dee, Geoffrey Holder, Pete Seeger, Sweet Honey in the Rock, Wavy Gravy, Peter Yarrow and others. Doors open at 6 p.m.

FREESKIING has been credited with making skiing cool again -- particularly among the junior set, which had been lured by the snowboard's renegade appeal. Thanks to twin-tip skis, which are rounded and upturned on both ends, freeskiers can land on the snow facing forward or backward, making it possible to do the flashy jumps and daring tricks of the snowboard on ungroomed backcountry snow, as well as on the pipes and jumps of terrain parks. Overall sales of skis are in decline but freeskis are ''a very hot category right now,'' said Kelly Davis, research director for the trade group SnowSports Industries America. Freeski sales as a percentage of Alpine ski sales have doubled in the last three years, to 28 percent. Like adult twin-tips, children's versions have wood or fiberglass cores and are wider than other Alpine skis to better handle abrupt landings and a range of snow conditions.

KAHN--Alfred J. The entire Columbia University School of Social Work community notes with sadness the death of Professor Emeritus Alfred J. Kahn on February 13. A world-renowned social policy scholar and educator, he was a professor at the school for 57 years. In the early 1980s, Dr. Kahn chaired the influential Committee on Child Development Research and Public Policy of The National Academy of Science. During his career he was the recipient of awards and honors from various universities and professional associations. He will be long remembered as a social work pioneer, author, consultant, teacher and advocate. Sincerest condolences are extended to his daughter, Nancy Valerie Kahn, and his family. Dr. Jeanette C. Takamura, Dean

LICATA--Robert. The Hofstra community is deeply saddened by the passing of Robert Licata, assistant professor of Journalism, Media Studies, and Public Relations. Professor Licata, who first came to Hofstra as an adjunct instructor of Journalism and Mass Media Studies in 1997, was appointed assistant professor of Journalism, Media Studies, and Public Relations in 2005. He served as temporary chair for the Journalism, Mass Media, and Public Relations department for July and August of 2006. As a highly regarded professional, he was respected by his colleagues in the media industry and in Hofstra's faculty. A beloved classroom teacher, he received the University's prestigious Teacher of the Year award in 2007. He received his master's degree from the university in 2004 and is a 25-year veteran of broadcast news. Professor Licata was one of the pioneers in the development of News 12 Long Island. Professor Licata is the recipient of several awards from the Press Club of Long Island and the Fair Media Council (Folio Awards) and has been an Emmy nominee. Professor Licata has also produced promotional videos showcasing musical artists, worked and developed the foundation that became The American Museum of the Moving Image at Kaufman Astoria Studios, and has participated on several diverse media panels. He is survived by his wife, Paula Ganzi Licata. In tribute to the memory of Professor Licata, all Hofstra University flags were lowered to half staff. Marilyn Monter Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President Hofstra University

An accomplished woman of valor, her value was far beyond pearls. Her husband's heart relied on her. Always there was a ready smile and a kind word for all employees of the company. She will be deeply missed and mourned by those whose souls and hearts she touched and will forever be in their hearts. May her loving and devoted husband and fabulous children, grandchildren, nephews, nieces and her entire family be comforted.

WOODGER--Cynthia Lake, January 31, of ALS. A life devoted to music and artistic performance, with unwavering support for others. She cared so much. She loved, she laughed. Daughter of H. Ridgely and Marian Batterman Bullock, she grew up in Glen Cove, LI and Haverford, PA. Adored by her husband, Bruce Woodger; son, Whitney Lake; daughter, Amanda Lake; three grandchildren; sister, Sheila Tucker and cousin, Edith Bouriez of this city. Memorial service: April 25, 10:30am; Trinity Church, Princeton.

NEWSON--Linda Suzanne, age 65, passed away February 14, 2009 after a long, valiant struggle with cancer. She was a longstanding resident of the New York metropolitan area. She was a professional psychotherapist for 30 years. A warm, generous, compassionate soul she will be lovingly missed by her many family, friends, and patients. She was widely traveled and involved in a number of charitable volunteer activities; including going to Tanzania, Africa with her nephew Tony and working as a teacher. Recently, she has volunteered with the "Woman to Woman", women's cancer support group at Mount Sinai Hospital. Linda wished donations be made in her memory to: "Woman to Woman", c/o the Mount Sinai Hospital, One Gustave Levy Place, New York, New York 10029. A spring memorial service in the NYC area is planned.
SPIEGEL--Emily. You will be in our hearts forever. Rob, Jason, Jennifer Stone

NEWMAN--Augusta, on February 18, 2009. Beloved wife of the late Arnold. Devoted mother of Eric and David. Cherished grandmother of Mark, Sarah, Daniel and Emma. Services Friday, 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

FAIRCHILD--Robert F.,of New York and Quogue died suddenly on February 16th, after enjoying a wonderful weekend fishing on his boat, The Grand Cru. Beloved father of Stephanie and Roger Griswold, Suzie and Bruce Kovner, Samantha and Chris Storkerson, Serena and Tyler Sheldon; cherished grandfather of Caroline, Olivia, Liam, Oscar, Roger, and Margaux. Born and raised in New York City, Bob graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and went to work for the family's firm, Fairchild Publications. Bob joined The House of Burgundy in 1971, and is the President and Chief Executive Officer. In May of 1994, he founded the Maison des Grands Crus, in Santenay, France. On July 16, 1987 in recognition of his efforts on behalf of French wines, Bob was made a Chevalier of the Ordre du Merite Agicole, by the French Parliament. Bob is a member of the Board of Overseers of the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, and the Board of Trustees of the Avon Old Farms School. A former member of the Board of Governors of the Union League Club of New York, he also belongs to the Leash Club of New York, Bath and Tennis Club of Palm Beach, Quogue Field Club and Quogue Beach Club and the Long Island Wyandanch Club. Family will receive friends on Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service will be held on Saturday at 10:30am at St. Thomas More, 89th Street (between Madison and Park Avenues). In lie of flowers, please make donations to The University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine of Avon Old Farms School.

KOVEN--Joan. The Brooklyn Law School Community mourns the passing of our beloved friend and colleague, Joan C. Koven. A distinguished graduate of the Class of 1974, she returned to the school, a decade later to teach family law and serve as Associate Dean for Alumni Affairs until her retirement in 1995. Generations of students, faculty, graduates, and staff benefited from her style, grace, wit, professionalism and wise counsel. Although her presence will be missed, her legacy will be long enduring. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Joan G. Wexler, Dean

BOND--J. Max, Jr.,trailblazing architect, died February 18, 2009. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends, colleagues and students whom he inspired by his gracious regard for humanity and his commitment to social justice. He is survived by his loving wife Jean, son Carey, daughter Ruth, three grandchildren, sister Jane Clement Bond and brother George Clement Bond. In lieu of flowers, a fund in his memory will be announced. A memorial service is planned for a future date.

SELIGSOHN--Selma, died February 18, 2009, age 85, after a long and brave battle against cancer. Loving mother of Gerald White (Penny Arnold) and Diane Seligsohn. Devoted grandmother of Juliet LePuil and Isabelle LePuil. Cherished aunt of Eleanor Herman and Fred Herman. Dear friend, great-aunt and cousin. Graduate of NYU Stern School of Business, Pratt Institute and CUNY. Retired librarian, lover and supporter of the arts. Services today, 12pm at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St., New York City.

SPIEGEL--Emily, 80. The loss of a person who gave herself unconditionally with pure love will greatly be missed by our family. We share in this loss and mourn this caring wonderful individual. Goodbye Aunt Emily. Rob Stone

KNOPF--Alfred, Jr.,on February 14, loved beyond measure by his wife of 56 years, Alice, his children Alison Insinger and her husband Thomas Christopher, Susan Knopf, David A. Knopf, and his grandchildren, Patrick and Susan. Memorial service at noon on Friday, February 20, at The Mercantile Library Center for Fiction, 17 East 47th Street, New York. Donations may be made to the ACLU, 125 Broad St., 18th Floor, New York, NY 10024.

BODOFF--Etta Scheinberg Greenfield. Over 100 years, Schvintzan, Eldridge Street, Boro Park, L.A., she saw the best in everyone. Her three daughters, 13 grandchildren, 49 great-grandchildren, great-great-grandson and everyone she touched will love her always.
Health researchers typically focus on improving the quality of foods served in school cafeterias. But what about improving a child’s whole dining experience?

LAS VEGAS – LittleBigPlanet, the quirky and innovative jumping-and-climbing game published by Sony for that company’s PlayStation 3 console, was the top winner Thursday night at the 12th annual Interactive Achievement Awards here, taking eight awards including Overall Game of the Year for 2008.

Updated | 6:00 p.m. The Los Angeles Police Department has opened an internal investigation following the publication of a photograph taken during an inquiry into an incident involving the R&B performer Chris Brown, the LAPD said in a news release. On Thursday, the celebrity Web site TMZ.com posted a photograph that depicted a woman with bruising on her lips and forehead. TMZ identified the woman in the photograph as Rihanna, the pop star and companion of Mr. Brown. Mr. Brown was arrested on Feb. 8 and charged with making criminal threats after fighting with a woman in his car; the name of the woman has not been released. In a statement, the LAPD said it “takes seriously its duty to maintain the confidentiality of victims of domestic violence,” adding that penalties for a leak of evidence could include termination.

He may not particularly need the money, but the tenor Plácido Domingo has been named the winner of the first Birgit Nilsson Prize, which bestows its recipient with a $1 million award for outstanding achievement in classical music, the Birgit Nilsson Foundation said in a release on Friday. The foundation, established by Nilsson, the Swedish soprano who died in 2005, plans to award the prize every two to three years; subsequent winners will be nominated by a jury and selected by the foundation’s board, though Mr. Domingo was chosen by Nilsson herself before her death. In a statement, Mr. Domingo expressed his gratitude, adding: “My greatest regret was that Birgit and I never performed together in ‘Die Walküre’ or ‘Tristan und Isolde.’ I remember telling her this many years ago, to which she replied, ‘Well then, you better hurry up.’”

These have been difficult days for performers associated with 1980s-vintage Australian rock bands. J.D. Fortune, the singer chosen to replace Michael Hutchence in the band INXS, said that he had been fired from the group, Reuters reported. Mr. Fortune, a Canadian performer, was named the replacement for Mr. Hutchence on the CBS reality series “Rock Star:INXS.” Mr. Hutchence died in 1997. Mr. Fortune said he had been let go by the band at a Hong Kong airport; the status of a current tour and a planned new album are unclear.

A California law that would have banned the sale or rental of violent video games to minors was struck down Friday by a federal appeals court, The Associated Press reported. The ruling, by a three-judge panel from the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, reaffirmed an earlier decision by a federal judge in San Jose that declared unconstitutional a 2005 law prohibiting the sale of “patently offensive” games to players under 18. State Senator Leland Yee, Democrat of San Francisco, had sought to reinstate the law, which would have imposed strict labeling requirements on video game publishers. But Judge Consuelo M. Callahan said in an opinion that there were less restrictive ways to protect children from “unquestionably violent” video games. Mr. Yee said he would ask the state’s attorney general, Jerry Brown, to appeal the decision to the United States Supreme Court.

Hollywood studios made what they called a “last, best and final” offer to the Screen Actors Guild late Thursday after three days of contract negotiations broke down. The Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents the studios, rescinded some earlier proposals that the actors’ union had opposed, but the two sides failed to agree on start and stop dates for a new contract. The actors are seeking a three-year contract that would be retroactive to the June 2008 expiration of the earlier contract, which would then align it with the expiration dates of contracts between the studios and other unions, including the Writers Guild. The studios want the new deal to begin on ratification and last for three years, which the actors believe would give them less leverage in bargaining on future deals. The board of the actors union will consider the offer at a meeting on Saturday.

Standing behind a bar for much of my early adulthood, I wasn't a big reader. My literary inclinations were limited to the New York Post's sports section and the Daily Racing Form when a friend handed me a Raymond Chandler novel. "Go ahead," he said. "It won't kill you." I read just the one, put it down, and really didn't give it much thought.

Mike Nothnagel and Byron Walden split the check in this unusual Saturday crossword. It has a theme. That's odd but not unheard of. After all, we had a sex, drugs, rock and roll theme on a Saturday just two weeks ago. Today, though, the theme is discernible, or at least hinted at, even before you read the first clue. The shape of the grid doesn't follow standard symmetry rules. If you're a math geek, the block arrangement might remind you of something. If you're not, you can still solve the puzzle.

Morgan Stanley wants to make sure it keeps the best-performing brokers after it forms a joint-venture brokerage firm with Citigroup's Smith Barney unit, so it plans to pay them a total of $2 billion to $3 billion to encourage them to stay with firm for up to nine years.

The Russian K.H.L. had the big game in Europe on Friday, as No. 2 Atlant and No. 1 Salavat Yulaev clashed for the fourth and final time this season. If Salavat won, they'd go six points ahead of Atlant and claim the K.H.L. regular-season crown. But Atlant had taken two of the three previous meetings.

Despite a slumping economy, New York City Transit recorded a total of 2.37 billion rides across the city's subways and buses in 2008, a 3.1 percent increase from 2007 and the highest figure since 1965. Transit officials attributed the increase to higher gasoline prices, increased tourism and continued residential growth in city neighborhoods -- though all of those indicators have changed course as the recession has deepened.

Hundreds of stylishly dressed job seekers line up for interviews in a downsized fashion job fair on Friday.

It was could be called the most stylish set of job seekers that New York City has seen in recent months. Stiletto heels. Suede thigh-high boots. Carefully manicured eyebrows. Louis Vuitton, Coach and Chanel logos. (Hm. Were they real?) They flipped their black portfolios, clutched their fabric samples and eagerly distributed their résumés.If Fashion Week is where the fantasies are born, the hundreds at the WWD Fashion Career Expo are the ones who actualize those visions for the masses. They are the technical designers, the fabric specialists, the retail associates, and they were willing to pay $10 apiece to talk to recruiters on Friday. But only those with five years or more of fashion education and experience were allowed in.

So, with all due respect to Ikram Goldman, the Chicago retailer who has become Michelle Obama's de facto stylist, here are the looks the T Magazine style department wouldn't mind seeing around Pennsylvania Avenue next fall.

Where to start. This week saw the Environmental Protection Agency give definitive signs it was moving to regulate new sources of CO2, the gas contained in the bubbles in beer. So far, all of the criteria air pollutants under the agency's purview -- substances from lead to sulfur dioxide -- have a direct impact on human health and welfare, while risks from the carbon dioxide's buildup remain indirect, through the rising influence on climate. Can the agency avoid years, if not decades, of litigation over details not dealt with in the Supreme Court decision on carbon dioxide? Stay tuned.

TAMPA, Fla. - The Yankees were nine games out of a playoff spot, with two weeks left last season, before Manager Joe Girardi finally confronted Robinson Cano in a public way. When Cano showed an alarming lack of hustle in the field on Sept. 14, Girardi pulled him from the game and benched him the next day.

A $42 million green housing project broke ground in Harlem this week, joining David and Joyce Dinkins Gardens in the growing trend of environmentally progressive budget housing projects that are being planned and built around the city.The 110-unit project, at 625 West 140th Street, will split its units roughly between formerly incarcerated homeless people and moderate-income families. Among the features the building will offer: free Wi-Fi, roof gardens that will channel rain water, and aluminum solar shades for temperature control. It is to be ready by mid-2010.

Advocates of renewable energy got the stimulus package of their dreams, packed with tax credits and grants and loan programs intended to restart their industry. Now they are turning their attention to the next item on their wish list: a national renewable portfolio standard. President Obama has called for 10 percent of the nation's electricity to come from renewable sources by 2012, and 25 percent by 2025.

"Today is the beginning of a new chapter in Saab's history," said Jan-Ake Jonsson, Saab's managing director, in a statement after a Swedish court approved Saab's request to begin a reorganization process.

Less than two weeks after the Beanpot, the eyes of the college hockey world are back on Boston, where No. 1 Boston University and No. 4 Northeastern square off in a home-and-away this weekend. The Terriers knocked off the Huskies by 5-2 to win the Beanpot title on Feb. 9, and there's no question that they're the best team going in college hockey. B.U. has lost just once since Thanksgiving, and that was more than a month ago.

Forget about the old lemon-peel garnish. Buddha's hand is in the air. Twice in the last week, friends have mentioned cocktails that use the obscure citrus. The West Coast friend makes her own simple syrup from the many-fingered citron, which is grown on a small scale in California and harvested in the winter, and keeps it on hand to splash into vodka. The East Coast friend was raving about a cocktail she'd had in the "secret" back bar of Frankies Spuntino in Brooklyn - which will open as Prime Meats in the coming week or so - that used "this thing I'd never heard of: Buddha budd "Frank Castronovo, one of the two Frankies behind the burgeoning Brooklyn empire, said that when he saw that the citrus could be ordered through his purveyor, Jim & Andy grocery on Court Street, "We grabbed everything we could." (He noted that the fruit's shape is a bit of a Rorschach test; he thinks it looks like a goat's udder.) After making a batch of limoncello from the citrus, the Prime Meats bartender Damon Boelte created a recipe for Buddha's hand bitters, combining the citron with Quassia amara wood chips, juniper berries and Devil's Spring overproof vodka, letting it sit for several weeks before pouring it into antique apothecary bottles.

The fashion world is uniformly swaying to the drumbeat of Africa, and so are we. In the new Women's Spring 2009 issue of T, we spotlight Josephine Baker, a perennial muse who is once again shorthand for Africanesque glamour, having inspired the influential Louis Vuitton show; Camilla Akrans photographs, and Suzy Menkes writes about, the many African motifs dominating the runways; and we meet El Anatsui, the Nigerian sculptor who has emerged as an art-world name to watch and to drop. Elsewhere in the issue, we look at people who are generating as much cultural traction as the mother continent, including the stylist and editor du jour Katie Grand, the designers Oscar de la Renta and Giambattista Valli, and our cover star, Rosario Dawson. What are you waiting for? Take a walk on the wildlife side.
Binyam Mohamed, a British resident detained by the U.S. since 2002 will return to Britain soon, but may not stay permanently.

There has just been a development in the case of Binyam Mohamed, the detainee at Guantánamo Bay whose case we discussed on The Lede last week. The British Foreign Office released a statement today saying that Mr. Mohamed, who was born in Ethiopia but had been granted British residency before he was arrested in Pakistan in 2002, will be allowed to return to Britain.

One theme running through Ralph Lauren's show this morning was discreet luxury: layering a cozy, casual-looking coat or sweater over an incredibly expensive-looking dress. Some people were tickled when a model came out wearing a patchwork coat that made her look like a hobo, except she was wearing crocodile heels. But what really caught my eye was the number of shearling coats and vests Mr. Lauren showed, about seven in total.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: President Obama made his first trip abroad today. He visited Canada, and let me tell you something: If Obama can finally mend our relationship with Canada, well then we'll know this guy really is on to something.

Monologue | Aired Thursday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: There's a new study that says that in America, rich people are ruder than poor people. This is shocking because I didn't know America had any rich people left.

Updated | 4:00 p.m. No one ever said $787 billion isn't a big number, but in a new television ad going on the air on Friday a conservative advocacy group, puts the price tag of the stimulus bill in biblical proportions.

Two reports out today on conflict and the environment mesh in a disturbing way. One, from the United Nations Environment Program, asserts that persistent conflicts within states most often relapse when the root cause is scarce natural resources and environmental issues are not incorporated into efforts to forge peace. The other study, "Warfare in Biodiversity Hotspots," has been published in the journal Conservation Biology. The authors find that "more than 80 percent of the world's major armed conflicts from 1950 to 2000 occurred in regions identified as the most biologically diverse and threatened places on Earth." More on conflict and ecology from Conservation International.

I live in a Bronxville co-op, and we have had our maintenance fees increased twice in the past two years to account for the drastic increase in energy costs. With energy costs having recently reached five-year lows, shouldn't my board decrease the maintenance obligations? It seems as though boards rarely ever consider decreasing maintenance fees, and that doesn't seem fair, particularly during a recession.

As if the luminaries on the red carpet did not feel hunted enough, E! has come up with a way to put them in some kind of stalker/tractor beam called Star Tracker. The brilliant invention will provide, according to the celebrity-obsessed network, "real-time tracking of celebrities strolling down the Oscars' Red Carpet:"

One of our co-op owners has sent the board, through a lawyer, a laundry list of items she wants fixed in our building and is refusing to pay maintenance until all items are addressed. What is her - and the board's - legal responsibility?

Ours is a generation of parents obsessed with parenting - devouring books about it, blogging about it, turning it into a competitive sport. So it's not surprising that President Obama's time in the White House looks like some kind of public experiment in child-rearing. We are intrigued by the first family not only because their children are adorable and so excited about getting a puppy and meeting the Jonas Brothers but also because our president seems to be such a good father - loving but not a pushover, thrilled that he now has a job where he can be with the girls for breakfast and dinner, strict about their chores, slightly cranky when their school is canceled "because of what? Some ice?"

Updated 4:10 p.m. | A protest by New York University students seeking to negotiate with school officials over a variety of issues ended after nearly 40 hours on Friday afternoon, with students leaving a barricaded dining room and a spokesman for the school announcing that 18 participants had been suspended pending a disciplinary review.About two dozen students were still involved in the protest when school security guards removed barricades made of tables and chairs and swept into a third floor dining room inside the Kimmel student center, said Banu Quadir, a 21-year-old N.Y.U. senior, who participated in the demonstration.
Could the recent rant broadcast from the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade spark a rebellion against the government’s rescue plan?

Yesterday Rick Santelli, who reports from the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade the for CNBC, unleashed a rant against Obama's newly announced housing bailout plan, intended to help some homeowners refinance mortgages and avoid foreclosure. The clip was quickly linked to and embedded in Web sites everywhere, and provoked intense reaction that pretty much broke along partisan lines.

Each time I travel to the cabin, I pass the Shaker community in New Gloucester, Maine. The hilltop collection of houses, workshops and barns affords a view east to Sabbathday Lake and west to the community's big apple orchards. Last week, I stopped by once again to admire the barns and buildings. Wrapped in white clapboards, they are wonders of joinery and geometry -- a pure and simple statement of early American architecture.

The wine writers' symposium is winding to a close, and I'm getting ready to visit some wineries in other parts of California. While the main business here is meeting and talking to a lot of dedicated writers, bloggers and others, young and old, who write about wine, the symposium has its side benefits: the opportunity to sample a whole bunch of wines.

Six weeks after salmonella-tainted peanuts were traced to a Georgia processing plant, companies nationwide are still announcing recalls of potentially dangerous products. The Food and Drug Administration's list of recalled peanut products is now more than 2,100 items long. (The agency has a searchable database of recalled products on its Web site.) This week the alerts included Grandpa's Oven Santa Fe Snack Mix, three kinds of Slim-Fast bars, and four snack trays sold by 1-800-Flowers.com.

When Robert Allen Stanford began planting the seeds of his multibillion-dollar financial empire decades ago, he turned to a family friend in his hometown, Mexia, Tex., population 6,600, to fill a seat on the board, The New York Times's Gretel C. Kovach writes.

Some of you may know that the Academy has booked Robert Pattinson to do some presenting on Sunday night. The star of "Twilight," Mr. Pattinson has no special business being at the Oscars, except that his presence on screen or especially in person gives perfectly healthy young women the vapors. The Bagger spent some quality time watching the intersect between Mr. Pattison and his fan base and he can attest that the Oscar producers just took care of a broad swath of the young teen demographic. Young women would pay big money to watch Mr. Pattinson read the phone book, which is sort of what presenting an Oscar actually is.

Wall Street's woes, complete with bankers toting boxes out of their old offices, are well known and even well televised. But away from the spotlight, more insidious departures are under way in Queens and other boroughs. A census by Representative Anthony D. Weiner shows a troubling list of avenues in Queens with a growing number of empty storefronts.According to the survey of 1,730 stores in Queens, 211 are closed or about to close. In all, 12 percent of what Mr. Weiner calls "community stores" are vacant in Queens, twice the rate of a year ago.

Traditionally, the term ''meuniere'' refers to fillets of sole that are floured and sauteed quickly, then finished with lemon juice, parsley and browned butter. But there's no reason to be parochial about it. This is a fast, surprisingly elegant approach to boneless, skinless chicken breasts, or cutlets of pork, turkey or veal.

Film | Marisa Tomei, up for an Oscar for playing a stripper in "The Wrestler," joins a long line of actresses who won acclaim playing women in the sex trade: Charlize Theron, Julia Roberts, Nicole Kidman, Kim Basinger, Natalie Portman, Jodie Foster, Elisabeth Shue, Jane Fonda, Greta Garbo -- the list stretches back to the first woman Oscar winner. Why? Such roles are "a natural corollary to another time-tested role, the male criminal. Another reason: Inherently flawed characters, who possess what some might see as mental, moral or physical imperfections, make for more courageous acting performances." Oh, yeah, and then there's sex. [Wall Street Journal]

Forget aboutAlex Rodriguez for a moment. The issue of the day is this: who was the bigger disappointment in New York  Carl Pavano or Jerome James? Was it Pavano, who was paid $39.95 million over four seasons by the Yankees and, in return, started only 26 games  fewer than one season's worth  thanks to a shocking number of injuries that included his buttocks, ribs and elbow? In all, he won nine games  or about $4.4 million a victory. There will be no "Yankeeography."

The most valuable lesson I learned from the year I spent in Washington (1982-1983, on the staff of the Council of Economic advisers -- I was the senior intl economist, the senior domestic economist was a guy named Larry Summers. What ever happened to him?) was the extent to which senior government figures have absolutely no idea what they're talking about.
Matthew Yglesias catches the WSJ publishing an op-ed urging macroeconomics to build a bridge to the 19th century -- to go back to the good old days when recessions were left to heal themselves.

Law | It's not so much the judiciary but the popular will that makes the Constitution a living, flexible document, the legal scholar (and Obama appointee) Cass Sunstein argues in the introduction to his new book. Take the vastly expanded power of the president in national security: It's "hardly a judicial creation. It is a product of judgments of a variety of persons and institutions and, in an important sense, of We the People." Further, he adds, when judges do weigh in, "the Court's role has been largely to ratify what citizens and their representatives have done." ["A Constitution of Many Minds," Princeton University Press]
Long a staple of European roads, diesel-powered passenger cars have seen a resurgence of late in the United States.

I went to pick up my dog from his haircut last week and the groomer took me aside for "an important question." I was expecting him to ask what the heck Riley had been rolling in lately, or why I thought the pooch was compulsively licking his paws, but what Joey had on his mind was Facebook. His children are in elementary school, and he has twins on the way, so he is thinking he'd better start figuring this mystery out now. I'd written about it on my blog, he said. What advice did I have? (I told him that by the time his kids were old enough to use Facebook there would be something new for him to worry about.)

As she meets with Chinese leaders this weekend, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton is expected to begin a more vigorous engagement with China on issues ranging from climate change to the global financial crisis.
Dramatic footage of running gun battles in the streets of a Mexican town on the U.S. border gives a sense of what Mexico's war on drugs is like with 40,000 troops engaged in the fight.

As Marc Lacey reported in The Times, Mexico has been struck this week by "a wave of demonstrations protesting the presence of army troops" in towns near the border with the United States, where the authorities have been involved in often heavy fighting with drug traffickers from the powerful Gulf Cartel.

Citigroup is planning to sell a part of its minority stake in Brazilian credit-card company Redecard, as the banking behemoth seeks to shore up its balance sheet, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter.

With a pair of fourth-anniversary parties on consecutive Tuesdays, February was shaping up to be a busy month for Brooklyn's Sixpoint Craft Ales even before the microbrewery's brush with media notoriety last week. But for one day, Feb. 12, the level of activity at the business, in Red Hook, Brooklyn, got truly crazy. That morning, word trickled out from Sixpoint's Facebook page that the federal government had ordered an end to production of Hop Obama, a beer named after Barack Obama last year when he was an underdog presidential candidate.

If your Firefox bookmarks menu is full of old pages you bookmarked to read later and then forgot about, the Read It Later extension from Idea Shower might help clean things up. Once Read It Later is installed, just click the checkmark in the Firefox address bar to mark a page for later reading. Click on the Reading List icon in the corner of the Firefox window to see the collection of links accumulated throughout the surfing day. Read It Later can also save links for offline consumption for when no Internet connection is available and can also synchronize between different computers.

Music | Meet the real Peggy Sue of the hit by Buddy Holly, who died 50 years ago this month. Beauty Call reporter Joshua David Stein goes where no man has gone before: to beauty press events. This week, he kisses and tells about a lip gloss kissing wall.By the time I arrived at "XOXO," a strange event celebrating love and the launch of four new shades of Kiehl's lip gloss, the lip gloss was gone. "These women," said a beleaguered PR flack, "they've got no self-control." But one can hardly blame the assembled crowd of fashionable girls and their gay boyfriends from rushing to begloss their lips in shades like East Village Vibe, a milk-chocolate hue, and Lights on Broadway, a slightly rosier gradation. The party had promised a "kissing wall" and a "D.J. from France." This was, after all, fashion week, when parties must sell themselves hard. Lip gloss isn't enough. But, sighed Joanna Virello, a PR rep for IC LAB, the host of the evening, the idea of a kissing wall was nixed: "They said it was unsanitary." Instead there were pictures of puckering models on the walls. But there was a D.J. from France. His name was Edouard, and he had just flown in from Bordeaux, where he works as a banker. A lonely pucker mark - in New York Nude, a medium "sand dune" tone - on the wall proved the existence of at least one woman who wouldn't let hygiene ruin her night.

Dunkirk, the favorite, beat a field of Triple Crown hopefuls in a $42,000 allowance feature at Gulfstream Park. A Kentucky-bred $3.7 million yearling purchase, Dunkirk was fifth going to the far turn but won the 1 1/8-mile race by four and three-quarter lengths. Seven of the 10 3-year-olds in the field are nominated for the Triple Crown. The trainer Todd Pletcher said Dunkirk’s next start would be in the Florida Derby at Gulfstream on March 28.

Because of an editing error, a picture caption in some editions on Wednesday with the Sports of The Times column, about the potential for Alex Rodriguez to work with a foundation that educates youth about the dangers of performance-enhancing drugs, misstated the surname of the group’s president, shown with Rodriguez. He is Don Hooton, not Hooten. (His group, the Taylor Hooton Foundation, is named after his son, who committed suicide shortly after he stopped using steroids.).

An article on Thursday about an exhibition in Paris on the history of French advertising misspelled the surname of a French president who used an ad executive to oversee his public relations campaign. He was François Mitterrand, not Mitterand.

An article on Monday about Carlos Slim Helú, who has become a major shareholder in and lender to The New York Times, referred incorrectly to the size of the newspaper’s editorial staff.
