GOLDSTEIN--Leon, ninety-two, of Brooklyn, NY and Winchester and Woburn, MA. Beloved and devoted husband of the late Helen, his wife of almost 60 years. Devoted father of Marc Goldstein and Judy Blaine, father-in-law of Jerry Blaine: dear brother of the late Esther and Pat. Proud and much loved grandfather of Heather, Brandon, Russell, Amanda and Joshua. Born September 15th, 1916 in Brooklyn, NY, Leon graduated with a Bachelor of Science Degree from City College of the City University of New York. He served his country for 5 years in the Army Air Corps in World War II in the Pacific as a Staff Sergeant, arriving in Iwo Jima on the 3rd day of the invasion. He married Helen soon after his discharge and raised his family in Brooklyn where he obtained his Masters in Education Degree from Long Island University and went on to become a much beloved high school chemistry teacher. He was an inspiration to generations of students, to his family and his friends. He will be missed. Funeral service will take place on Friday, February 20th at 11:30am at: Gutterman and Musicant/Wien & Wien Memorial Chapels 402 Park Street Hackensack, NJ.

Forget about Alex Rodriguez for a moment. The issue of the day is this: who was the bigger disappointment in New York -- Carl Pavano, top right, or Jerome James? Was it Pavano, who was paid $39.95 million over four seasons by the Yankees and, in return, started only 26 games -- fewer than one season's worth -- thanks to a shocking number of injuries that included his buttocks, ribs and elbow? In all, he won nine games -- or about $4.4 million a victory. There will be no ''Yankeeography.'' Or was it James, who made roughly $21 million in three-plus seasons with the Knicks while missing far more games than he played? In all, he averaged 2.5 points and 1.8 rebounds a game in 90 contests while sustaining an assortment of knee and foot injuries. Over the last two seasons, he played exactly 15 minutes and scored 10 points. That comes out to ... well, you do the math. It is not pretty.

SPIEGEL--Emily Joy, 80, of Kings Point, New York, passed away on February 16, 2009. Our extraordinary mother lived every moment of her life to the fullest. Charming, graceful and beautiful in every way, her boundless energy and spirit touched everyone she knew. Her passion for the simple wonders of life, art and music enriched us all. She shared a profound and special love with our father. Her selfless devotion to him and to our family will forever remain in our hearts and minds and will serve as an inspiration. We, her children and grandchildren, will miss her deeply, and we will live our lives with her love, kindness and generosity as our guiding spirit. She is survived by husband Jerry Spiegel, daughters Pamela Sanders and Lise Wilks, sons-in-law Arthur Sanders and Jeffrey Wilks, grandchildren Jordan, Remy, Erin, David, Andrew and Jack. Services will be held on Wednesday, February 18, 1:15pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at West 76th Street. The family will be sitting shiva from Wednesday, 5:30 to 9:00pm, Thursday 2:00 to 8:00pm and Friday from 2:00 to 5:00pm at the home of Jerry Spiegel. Donations in her memory may be made to: Parkinsons Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, New York, 10018.

Once a crutch for the most needy, food pantries have responded to the deepening recession by opening their doors to what Rosemary Gilmartin, who runs the Interfaith Food Pantry here, described as ''the next layer of people'' -- a rapidly expanding roster of child-care workers, nurse's aides, real estate agents and secretaries facing a financial crisis for the first time. Demand at food banks across the country increased by 30 percent in 2008 from the previous year, according to a survey by Feeding America, which distributes more than two billion pounds of food every year. And instead of their usual drop in customers after the holidays, many pantries in upscale suburbs this year are seeing the opposite.

GATES--Philomene Asher, 90, of New York City and Westhampton Beach, died suddenly February 17, 2009. Born and raised in Florida, Phil graduated from Florida State University and from George Washington University Law School. Phil was the beloved wife of the late Samuel E. Gates and adored mother of Gilda Gates Wray, Sharon Gates Stearns and Kathe Gates Williamson. She was "Goggi", the "electric grandmother" to eight grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. Phil was an accomplished attorney, author and valued community leader. She was Chairman of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York and served on the Boards of the New York Infirmary Beekman Downtown and Southampton Hospitals, The Florida State University Foundation, the Legal Aid Society, Grosvenor Neighborhood House, Les Amis de Blerancourt and numerous other community organizations. Phil was an ebullient presence, always there for those who needed her providing love and wisdom. She loved books, dancing, travel and above all, friends and family. She leaves a big hole in our lives. Memorial service to be announced later. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Philomene Gates Award for Excellence in Communications at the FSU Foundation, 2010 Levy Ave, Bldg B Ste 300, P.O. Box 3062739, Tallahassee, FL 32306-2739 or to one of the organizations listed above on whose Board she served.

A senior Communist Party official has warned monks and nuns in Tibet to refrain from carrying out any political activity in the run-up to the first anniversary of the anti-Chinese uprising last March, according to an article published on Thursday in the Tibet Daily, an official newspaper. The official, Lobsang Gyaincain, a member of the standing committee of the regional Communist Party, said the clergy must not take part in activities aimed at ''splitting the motherland.'' The Tibet Daily also reported that senior leaders, in a conference held on Wednesday, called on security forces to crush any signs of support for the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of the Tibetans. Security forces have fanned out across the Tibetan region of China even as many Tibetans have been calling for a boycott of festivities during Losar, the Tibetan New Year, which begins Wednesday.
CHARLES LONG Tanya Bonakdar

Before television shined its warped light on her, Jade Goody was surely destined for a life of hardship and obscurity. Crude-talking, hard-drinking, overweight, barely educated, in debt, the child of drug addicts, she appeared on the reality show ''Big Brother'' in 2002 as a kind of token lowlife. But something about Ms. Goody, then 21, struck a chord -- even if it was a patronizing one -- in a restless nation searching for ways to allay its millennial boredom. She became a bona fide media star, a working-class Paris Hilton. Britons eagerly devoured every detail of her life, no matter how banal. They worked out to her exercise videos, bought her perfume, read her autobiography and, when she made racist remarks about an Indian actress on ''Celebrity Big Brother'' in 2007, angrily turned against her.

New Yorkers have been understandably impatient about the slow pace of Lincoln Center's renovation plans. While musical institutions from Los Angeles to Copenhagen whipped out dazzling new concert halls, New York's vast cultural complex seemed mired in indecision. An ill-conceived proposal by Frank Gehry to cover Lincoln Center's central plaza with a gigantic glass canopy stirred such outrage among constituents that it was shelved in 2001.

ONCE again, people are talking about Bretton Woods. Not just the cross-country and downhill skiers who zoom and whoosh over its snow at this time of year, but thinkers around the world for whom the name signifies not a resort, but a grand economic agreement -- the blueprint that gave a broken world a path to financial stability after World War II. For some, that Bretton Woods seems like the sort of thing it might be time to think about again. In 1944, less than a month after D-Day, delegates from 44 nations met at the Mount Washington Hotel, which still sits grandly against the forested flanks and majestic peaks of the Presidential Range, welcoming guests. Germany and Japan were not invited, and the subject was money. The Allies were winning the war, but everyone knew that most countries -- even the winners -- would emerge as economic wrecks. It was time to invent new systems of finance and trade.

FAIRCHILD--Robert F.,of New York and Quogue died suddenly on February 16th, after enjoying a wonderful weekend fishing on his boat, The Grand Cru. Beloved father of Stephanie and Roger Griswold, Suzie and Bruce Kovner, Samantha and Chris Storkerson, Serena and Tyler Sheldon; cherished grandfather of Caroline, Olivia, Liam, Oscar, Roger, and Margaux. Born and raised in New York City, Bob graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and went to work for the family's firm, Fairchild Publications. Bob joined The House of Burgundy in 1971, and is the President and Chief Executive Officer. In May of 1994, he founded the Maison des Grands Crus, in Santenay, France. On July 16, 1987 in recognition of his efforts on behalf of French wines, Bob was made a Chevalier of the Ordre du Merite Agicole, by the French Parliament. Bob is a member of the Board of Overseers of the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, and the Board of Trustees of the Avon Old Farms School. A former member of the Board of Governors of the Union League Club of New York, he also belongs to the Leash Club of New York, Bath and Tennis Club of Palm Beach, Quogue Field Club and Quogue Beach Club and the Long Island Wyandanch Club. Family will receive friends on Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service will be held on Saturday at 10:30am at St. Thomas More, 89th Street (between Madison and Park Avenues). In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine or Avon Old Farms School.

In their first appraisal of Iran's nuclear program since President Obama took office, atomic inspectors have found that Iran recently understated by a third how much uranium it has enriched, United Nations officials said Thursday. The officials also declared for the first time that the amount of uranium that Tehran had now amassed -- more than a ton -- was sufficient, with added purification, to make an atom bomb.

SPIEGEL--Emily. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art deeply mourn the loss of Honorary Trustee Emily Spiegel. A longtime and beloved friend of the Museum, Emily was an avid art collector and patron of the arts, as well as a generous friend to artists, curators, and collectors. At MoMA she provided important support to the capital campaign, painting and sculpture collection, and to many other areas of the Museum. She was wonderfully caring and truly committed to the arts, and she will be missed deeply. We extend our most heartfelt sympathies to her husband, Jerry Spiegel, and to her daughters Pam Sanders and Lise Wilkes and their families. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art

SPIEGEL--Emily Joy, 80, of Kings Point, New York, passed away on February 16, 2009. Our extraordinary mother lived every moment of her life to the fullest. Charming, graceful and beautiful in every way, her boundless energy and spirit touched everyone she knew. Her passion for the simple wonders of life, art and music enriched us all. She shared a profound and special love with our father. Her selfless devotion to him and to our family will forever remain in our hearts and minds and will serve as an inspiration. We, her children and grandchildren, will miss her deeply, and we will live our lives with her love, kindness and generosity as our guiding spirit. She is survived by husband Jerry Spiegel, grandchildren Jordon, Remy, Erin, David, Andrew and Jack. The family will be sitting shiva Friday from 2-5 pm at the home of Jerry Spiegel. Donations in her memory may be made to: Parkinsons Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, New York, 10018.

A lobbyist's lawsuit against The New York Times over the newspaper's account of her ties to Senator John McCain has been settled, both sides announced on Thursday. The suit, filed by Vicki L. Iseman, the Washington lobbyist, was settled without payment and The Times did not retract the article. In an unusual agreement, however, The Times is letting Ms. Iseman's lawyers give their views on the suit on the paper's Web site.

Cease and desist is the advice I give university administrators toying with thoughts of closing their campus museums and peddling the art, as Brandeis recently threatened to do. Just stop. Period. Bad way to go. If it helps, consider your museum and its collection in purely materialistic terms, as a big chunk of capital, slowly and fortuitously accumulated. Once spent, it is irrecoverable. Your university can never be that rich in that way again. Or view the art in your care as something that doesn't belong to you. Like any legacy it belongs to the future.

WAGNER--H. Bridger, M.D.,passed away on February 10, 2009 after a long illness in Fountain Hills, AZ. He was 81. A research pioneer in the fields of Biological Psychiatry, Psychopharmacology and Neonatology, he was a Professor of Psychiatry and Neuroscience and Acting Chairman of the Dept. of Psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York before moving to Philadelphia, PA in 1982. There he became Chairman of the Dept. of Psychiatry at the Medical College of Pennsylvania at the Eastern Pennsylvania Psychiatric Institute, which later became part of Drexel University. With over 180 publications, he was a founder of the Society of Biological Psychiatry and appointed President of the Society in 1988 along with being Editor Emeriti of its journal 1992-1997. A committed social activist, he helped found the Medical Committee for Human Rights in 1964. Civil rights, peace and justice were causes that occupied his entire life. A devoted husband, father and grandfather, he was a lover of life's pleasures including Cuban cigars, Cape Cod, Wellfleet oysters and martinis. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Rita Hayes Bridger, his seven children, Eric Bridger, Cindy Bridger, Laurie Bridger, Colleen Jacobson, Mary Jane Sanacore, Colo Hayes III, Christopher Hayes and 11 grandchildren.

TOOKER Audrey, a lady of fierce determination and extraordinary passions, passed away on January 29 in New York City at age 81. A descendant of the earliest Dutch settlers of Staten Island, her ancestors included Evert Bancker, Mayor of Albany (1694 to 1695/1707 to 1709), and the famous Colonial silversmith Adrian Bancker, Audrey was born on November 27, 1927 in Mineola, LI, New York to Jean (nee Monahan) and Adrian Bancker. She was raised in an old farm house in Plandome, New York and eduacted at a number of girls' boarding schools and Finch College. She lived for many years in Locust Valley, NY while married to Bill Tooker, an entertaining cross between Cary Grant and Jackie Gleason. Upon the dissolution of her first marriage, Audrey moved to Aspen, Colorado where she met and married Jim Snobble, Vice President of the Aspen Ski Corporation and first Mountain Manager of Snowmass Ski Area. Together they camped and skied in beautiful off the grid locations in Canada and Alaska. At the conclusion of that relationship, Audrey became a "Roads Scholar," moving to Whitefish, MT; Dorset, and Burlington, VT; Cold Spring, NY and eventually Boulder, Colorado. She loved a good argument and a great ski run in that order. She is survived by her daughters Tracey, Holly, Paige and Robin, all of New York metropolitan area, and her sister Patricia Duane of Boynton Beach, FL.

It may be the longest train delay in history: more than 40 years after the first bullet trains zipped through Japan, the United States still lacks true high-speed rail. And despite the record $8 billion investment in high-speed rail added at the last minute to the new economic stimulus package, that may not change any time soon. That money will not be enough to pay for a single bullet train, transportation experts say. And by the time the $8 billion gets divided among the 11 regions across the country that the government has designated as high-speed rail corridors, they say, it is unlikely to do much beyond paying for long-delayed improvements to passenger lines, and making a modest investment in California's plan for a true bullet train.

KAHN--Alfred J. The entire Columbia University School of Social Work community notes with sadness the death of Professor Emeritus Alfred J. Kahn on February 13. A world-renowned social policy scholar and educator, he was a professor at the school for 57 years. In the early 1980s, Dr. Kahn chaired the influential Committee on Child Development Research and Public Policy of The National Academy of Science. During his career he was the recipient of awards and honors from various universities and professional associations. He will be long remembered as a social work pioneer, author, consultant, teacher and advocate. Sincerest condolences are extended to his daughter, Nancy Valerie Kahn, and his family. Dr. Jeanette C. Takamura, Dean

NOBACK--Charles Robert PhD Age 92, of Cresskill, NJ, Professor Emeritus of Columbia University, died peacefully February 4, 2009. Beloved husband of the late Eleanor (nee Loomis), father of Charles (Pete), Peggy, Ted, and Elizabeth. Father-in- Law to Norma Noback and Dr. James Barton and devoted Grandfather to Peter Charles Noback and Lindsay Barton. Proud Brother of Joe and Beatrice, cousin Dick, and numerous nephews and nieces. Dr. Noback received his BS at Cornell University, MS at New York University, and PhD at the University of Minnesota. He worked as Professor of Anatomy at the University of Georgia, Long Island College of Medicine, and proudly aspired to Professor of anatomy and cell biology at Columbia University excelling to the level of Chairman of the anatomy Department and later Professor Emeritus over a span of 33 years. His accomplishments include co-authorship of "The Human Nervous System", research of the nervous system, editor, reviewer, and most proudly scholar and mentor to thousands of students. "In effect I enjoy contacts with students and teaching" Charles R. Noback. He was honored with many awards most recently the "Physicians and Surgeons Distinguished Service Award". A memorial service at The College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University is being planned. Date to be announced. In lieu of flowers donations can be made in his name to his cherished Bronx Zoo through the Wildlife Conservation Society 2300 Southern Blvd Bronx, NY 10460. He grew up witnessing his father's loving care of animals as the Veterinarian of the Bronx Zoo 1926-1936.

With its banks tottering under a mountain of bad debt, many of its best-known stores shuttering their doors and joblessness soaring by tens of thousands every month, Britain has been struggling to cope with a tidal wave of bad news. Now, the blight has touched cricket, and that, for traditionalists, is an indignity too far. Worse, for those who have always regarded baseball as a vulgar derivative of the ''gentlemen's game,'' as cricket has long held itself to be, the source of the game's new woes is an American, indeed a Texan, Robert Allen Stanford, who helicoptered himself -- literally -- into the heart of the English game last year.

FOR many years, anyone who didn't rent or own a house in the Hamptons had two main lodging options in the East End: a rundown motel or a B&B that was most likely showing its age. In any case, guests often paid a fortune for less than luxurious accommodations. But in recent seasons, the quality and range of options have been getting much better, as new owners renovate tired properties for guests accustomed to Frette linens, in-room Wi-Fi and flat-screen TVs.

Chase Utley of the Phillies hammered a baseball off a batting tee, waited, readied himself and then hit another. Utley took a careful approach to this simple hitting drill Thursday because he is recovering from hip surgery and needs to be cautious. His goal is to play in the season opener on April 5. After Utley had surgery to trim the labrum and a bony lesion in his right hip on Nov. 24, doctors told him he would need four to six months to recover. As Utley's rehabilitation continued accelerating at training camp in Clearwater, Fla., he said that playing in the first game for the Phillies, the defending World Series champions, was realistic.

Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Thursday that the United States might consider increasing payments to Kyrgyzstan for access to a crucial air base, just hours after the Kyrgyz Parliament voted to terminate the lease and require the Americans to vacate the base within six months. ''We have not resigned ourselves to this being the last word,'' Mr. Gates said at a meeting here of NATO defense ministers to discuss the need for more combat forces and reconstruction teams in Afghanistan.

It was the declaration heard around the golf world. ''I'm now ready to play again,'' Tiger Woods wrote on his Web site Thursday while announcing his much-anticipated return to competitive golf next week at the World Golf Championships, a match-play event in Tucson. Woods, the defending champion, has been sidelined since June 16, when he defeated Rocco Mediate in a 19th-hole playoff to win the United States Open. It was Woods's 14th victory in a major and his 65th on the PGA Tour. After the playoff, Woods had surgery to repair a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his left knee. He revealed that he had played the event not only on a bad knee, but with a fractured left tibia.

In behaving like Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, State Senator Abel Maldonado surpassed him, for the moment, as Sacramento's powerhouse. Mr. Maldonado, a 41-year-old Republican from the Central Coast, provided the essential last vote needed early Thursday morning on a series of budget bills intended to close California's $41 billion budget gap.

THE country club has long been an American archetype of upscale social networking, white-glove amenities and, oh, yes, golf. Enter the ski club, in which a growing number of winter resorts are using the club model to attract members who prefer first tracks to tee times at sunrise. Think of them as country clubs with vast stretches of white powder instead of putting greens. When Andy Unanue began his Colorado ski vacation earlier this month, for example, he drove to a parking garage right next to the lifts at Vail in the heart of the resort village, picked up his freshly sharpened skis and, with just a few more steps, boarded the lift.

An article published on February 21, 2008, about Senator John McCain and his record as an ethics reformer who was at times blind to potential conflicts of interest included references to Vicki Iseman, a Washington lobbyist. The article did not state, and The Times did not intend to conclude, that Ms. Iseman had engaged in a romantic affair with Senator McCain or an unethical relationship on behalf of her clients in breach of the public trust.

BRAINWAVE The idea of reading what's on other people's minds has always held some allure, particularly for the sci-fi set. But a feat even more challenging than telepathy is reading your own mind -- in essence figuring out how it works. The Rubin Museum of Art has volunteered to act as tour guide for our unknowable inner world by organizing Brainwave, a festival devoted to the way we think.

The 2009 race for the Tony Awards has a late entry: the Goodman Theater's production of Eugene O'Neill's ''Desire Under the Elms,'' starring Brian Dennehyand Carla Gugino, will be transferring from Chicago to the St. James Theater. Previews are scheduled to start April 14, with opening night set for April 27. The cutoff date for Tony eligibility is April 30. The lead producer, Jeffrey Richards -- who also has ''Hair,'' ''Reasons to Be Pretty,'' ''Blithe Spirit'' and Will Ferrell's one-man show on his plate right now -- said it would be a limited 13-week engagement with a budget of $1.9 million. Robert Falls, the director, said that Ms. Gugino -- who recently left the Goodman production to promote film projects -- would return for the Broadway run.

Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof updates the story of Suad, a refugee from Darfur now living in Eastern Chad, who saved her little sister, Halima, from a Janjaweed attack.

My Sunday column is about one of my Darfuri heroes, Suad Ahmed, and her extraordinary (and possibly dead) sister, Halima. I admire them so much because for year after year in covering Darfur, I've met with presidents and prime ministers and foreign ministers and ambassadors, and mostly I've heard excuses. And then you find real moral leadership coming from two unknown sisters in a refugee camp.

A cruciverbalist constructs crossword puzzles. For any artist, the creative process starts by staring at a blank canvas. Nothing happens for a while. Time slows down. The ticking of the clock gets louder. "Write what you know" -- that's always the advice. Tick, tick, tick. Every production begins with a sense that this time, a significant or lovely or amusing or somehow wonderful contribution to the world is waiting to be unlocked. Tick, tick, tick.

Anne Hathaway, coolly sipping a glass of Perrier-Jouet champagne on Friday night, looked much too calm and much too rested for this stage of the awards-season rat race. How was it possible for her to be so Zen while trooping from fete to fete just days before the Oscars? "Easy, I'm not winning," she said, flashing that trademark smile. "I honestly feel no pressure." But wasn't the party circuit alone exhausting? "Oh fine," she said, leaning in close to whisper in our ear, "I did get a massage a little earlier."

The U.N. says it is looking into my statement, in Thursday's column, that officials cut off security for George Clooney for fear that he would criticize genocide. For example, officials apparently are trying to find out which U.N. official called me to say that they were pulling Clooney's security escort; evidently they're not trying very hard, since no one asked me. A listing of credits on Tuesday with a theater review of “In the Next Room (or the vibrator play),” about a 19th century doctor and a magic treatment, misidentified the actor playing Leo Irving, a patient. The Practically Speaking column on Friday, about benefits for small businesses in the federal stimulus package, described incorrectly a provision that gives companies a 50 percent bonus deduction on capital investments. That provision was extended to investments made in 2009; it is not just for investments made in 2008. The article also misstated the production schedule of MCM Composites, whose president commented on the legislation. Wednesday was its last production day of the week, not the month.

An article last Saturday about an adviser to the money manager J. Ezra Merkin, who invested $2 billion of his clients’ money with Bernard L. Madoff, overstated action taken by the Securities and Exchange Commission in the early 1990s against the adviser. Although the adviser, Victor Teicher, who provided investment advice to Mr. Merkin while Mr. Teicher was in prison for securities fraud, was barred by the S.E.C. from providing investment advice to registered securities advisers, he was not barred from advising unregistered advisers like Mr. Merkin.

FLYNN--Johanna C.,February 13. Beloved Mother, Sister, Aunt, and devoted Grandmother. A vibrant and dynamic member of her Carnegie Hill community, she worked tirelessly on numerous social and political causes including Tenant's Advocacy and the Parks Department. She was a loving and generous soul who will live on in our hearts and memories. Her family and friends will miss her dearly. A memorial service honoring her life and legacy will take place on Saturday, February 21st at The Brick Presbyterian Church at 91st St. and Park Ave. at 2:00pm.

GREENBERG--Frances. With deep regret we note the passing of Frances Greenberg on February 19th from complications of a stroke. Family leader and bedrock, Frances was known to all as the "glue" of her extended family which spanned three continents. Born in China in 1917, she came to New York with her late husband, Jack Greenberg, and two daughters before WWII. Always dedicated to her people, she volunteered for several Jewish organizations, was President of the American Far Eastern Society, and also an active member of Congregation B'nai Jeshrun for over fifty years. The youngest of eight, she saw many loved ones off to the next life including, sadly, her two daughters Rosalie and Anne. We strove in your model to bring dignity and peace to your final hour, Grandma. Survived by her son-in-law Dr. Nicholas Koffler, grandchildren Stephen, Pamela, Richard Koffler and Kenny, Andrea, and Jennifer Linsky, as well as ten great- grandchildren. You showed us how to live with strength, common sense, and humor. We'll miss you. Gifts to Cong. BJ Rabbi Discretionary Fund, 2109 Broadway, Suite 203, NY NY 10023. Funeral Sunday February 22nd, 9:30am at Plaza Memorial, 91st and Amsterdam.

Alex Rodriguez was mostly mute as he signed autographs along the left-field fence on a satellite field at the Yankees' spring training facility Friday. He signed a baseball and moved a few inches, signed another ball and then moved again. But one vocal fan finally snagged his attention. ''Hey, Alex, just win and all of this stuff goes away,'' the man said.

The former United States Fed Cup captain Zina Garrison is suing the United States Tennis Association for racial discrimination, according to legal documents filed in federal court Thursday. In the suit, Garrison, who served from 2004 to 2008 and was the first African-American United States Fed Cup captain, accused the U.S.T.A. of refusing to pay her an equivalent salary to that of her counterpart, Patrick McEnroe, the United States Davis Cup captain, who is white.

HIGGINS--Elysabeth Cochran Barbour, known as "Lys", died on Thursday, February 19th at her home following a long illness. She will be remembered for her love of language, her compassion towards animals and her generosity towards her friends. She was the widow of James Henry Higgins II, former chairman of Mellon Bank, NA. Born in New York City on September 7, 1922, she was the daughter of Elysabeth Carrere Barbour Welsh whose uncle was the architect John Carrere of Carrere & Hastings, designers of The New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at 42nd St. Her father was Senator William Warren Barbour from New Jersey who, as a passionate supporter of racial and religious non-discrimination, introduced early anti-lynching legislation and was honored for promoting US aid and refuge to Jewish victims of the holocaust during World War II. A graduate of Westover School and Sarah Lawrence College, Lys served on the Board of Westover School, the New England Historic Genealogical Society, and The Sewickley Historical Society. She was a professional breeder of champion Pembroke Welsh Corgis under the kennel name Hilden and was on the board of the American Kennel Club and the board of overseers at The University of Pennsylvania's School of Veterinary Medicine. As a philanthropist, Lys supported wildlife and environmental preservation, education and the arts. Lys is survived by her brother, Warren Barbour of Bronxville, NY, her three children; Elysabeth H. Miller of New York City, James H. Higgins III of Morristown, New Jersey, and Hilary B.H. Parker of Woodberry Forest, Virginia. She is also survived by three grandchildren James H.B. Higgins, Palmer R. Higgins, and T. Warren Parker. A funeral service will be held at The Presbyterian Church of Sewickley on Sunday, February 22 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, friends are asked to donate to Westover School, P.O. Box 847, Middlebury, CT. 06762 or to the World Wildlife Fund (www.worldwildlife.org click on donate, then memorial donations.)

WHIPPLE--The Rev. Dr. Charles E.,age 95, died on February 20, 2009. Sometime Rector, Church of St. Mary the Virgin, Falmouth Foreside, Maine, sometime Canon of St. Luke's Cathedral, Portland. Professor Emeritus and Director Emeritus of the Student Center at Brooklyn College. Administrator of the Cherry Grove Dune Fund, President of the Cherry Grove Memorial Fund, Chaplain Cherry Grove Fire Department. Member of the Society of St. Charles, K.M., the Confraternity of the Blessed Sacrament, and the Guild of All Souls. Reposing Sunday from 2pm to 4pm at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 145 West 46th Street, Manhattan. A Solemn Mass of Requiem will be held at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin on Monday at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, or to the Cherry Grove Memorial Fund, New York 11782. Interment at a later date.

GATES--Philomene A. The East End Hospice Board of Directors, staff and volunteers note with sadness the death of Philomene Gates, loyal patron and friend. Bernard Ashley, who with his wife Laura founded Laura Ashley, the international company that fashioned tasteful, mostly floral-print women's clothing and an array of housewares that evoked the genteel aspects of the 19th-century English countryside, died Feb. 14 at his home in Wales. He was 82. Mr. Ashley's family confirmed the death to The Times of London, but did not announce the cause.

Tiger Woods said Friday that he did not know what to expect next week in his return to competition at the Accenture Match Play Championship in Tucson -- except that he still expected to win. ''That's my intent, to go in there and win,'' Woods, who has not played since winning the United States Open last June, said on a conference call. ''Nothing has ever changed.''

FAIRCHILD--Robert F. The Avon Old Farms School mourns the passing of our esteemed alumnus, director, and friend, Robert F. Fairchild. A member of the Class of 1960, Bob Fairchild represented the highest ideals of Avon Old Farms School to a generation of our students, alumni, faculty, staff and families. Bob served as an active member of the Board of Directors from 1990 until his death, and provided extraordinary vision, leadership, and support for every aspect of the school. He was instrumental in creating and implementing the comprehensive strategic building plan that has resulted in dramatic improvements to our campus. His extraordinary generosity was directly responsible for several important programs and facilities at school. Bob's energy and positive spirit were truly inspirational to his fellow board members and to all members of the Avon Old Farms School community who had the pleasure of knowing him. His remarkable contributions and deep passion for the school were instrumental in positioning Avon Old Farms as one of America's great secondary schools. The Board of Directors and the entire Avon Old Farms School family wish to extend our heartfelt condolences to Bob's entire family. Dean C. Graham '84, Chairman Kenneth H. LaRocque, Headmaster

HUSSEY--Susan Elaine, co-founder of Tampa's Gorilla Theatre, passed away on February 18, 2009. She is survived by her husband, Aubrey Hampton, their son Trevor, her sister Bo-gardt and her stepson Mitch Hampton. Family and friends join the theater community in mourning her passing. Born June 1, 1954, in Martinsville, IN, Susan led a spirited and colorful life filled with friends, literature, art, and a love of all things natural. After high school, a series of odd jobs included a five-year stint with a small Canadian circus, working as a magician's assistant. A graduate of Indiana University, she received an MA in English from the University of South Florida. In 1983, Susan joined natural cosmetics manufacturer Aubrey Organics and worked her way to Vice President of Marketing and Advertising, as well as Editor-in-Chief of Organica magazine. A playwright and poet, Susan wrote and co-produced a number of award-winning plays, including Plutography in the Slave Trade, A Christmas Memory, The Toxic Wave, and The Dressing Room, which was singled out by the St. Petersburg Times as one of the best 10 shows of 1993, and was later produced off-Broadway in New York. In 1990, Susan and her husband Aubrey co-founded Gorilla Theatre, Tampa's only equity theater. In 1999, she received the Weekly Planet's Best of the Bay award for best playwright. Her two-play collection, The Toxic Wave & The Dressing Room, was published by the University of Tampa Press in 2002. The family requests that, in place of flowers, Susan's bright spirit be honored with donations to her favorite charity, Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS, CareCard Donations, 165 West 46th Street, #

President Obama told the nation's mayors on Friday that he would hold them accountable for how they spend the money in the $787 billion economic stimulus package, which he described as ''a true partnership'' between the federal government and cities that have been too long neglected by Washington. ''I want to be clear about this: We cannot tolerate business as usual -- not in Washington, not in our state capitals, not in America's cities and towns,'' Mr. Obama told a gathering of the United States Conference of Mayors. If mayors propose a wasteful project, he added, ''I will call them out on it.''

HIGGINS--Elysabeth Cochran Barbour, known as "Lys," died on Thursday, February 19 at her home following a long illness. She will be remembered for her love of language, her compassion towards animals and her generosity towards her friends. She was the widow of James Henry Higgins II, former chairman of Mellon Bank, NA. Born in New York City on September 7, 1922, she was the daughter of Elysabeth Carrere Barbour Welsh whose uncle was the architect John Carrere of Carrere & Hastings, designers of The New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at 42nd St. Her father was Senator William Warren Barbour from New Jersey who, as a passionate supporter of racial and religious non-discrimination, introduced early anti-lynching legislation and was honored for promoting US aid and refuge to Jewish victims of the holocaust during World War II. A graduate of Westover School and Sarah Lawrence College, Lys served on the Board of Westover School, the New England Historic Genealogical Society, and The Sewickley Historical Society. She was a professional breeder of champion Pembroke Welsh Corgis under kennel name Hilden and was on the board of the American Kennel Club. As a philanthropist, Lys supported wildlife and environmental preservation, education and the arts. Lys is survived by her brother , Warren Barbour of Bronxville, NY, her three children; Elysabeth H. Miller of New York City, James H. Higgins III of Morristown, New Jersey, and Hilary B.H. Parker of Woodberry Forest, Virginia. She is also survived by three grandchildren James H.B. Higgins, Palmer R. Higgins, and T. Warren Parker. A funeral service will be held at The Presbyterian Church of Sewickley on Sunday, February 22 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers friends are asked to donate to Westover School, PO Box 847, Middlebury, CT 06762 or to the World Wildlife Fund (www.worldwildwife.org - click on donate, then memorial donations.)

A day before the celebratory Academy Awards, the national board of directors of the Screen Actors Guild on Saturday rejected what studios termed a “last, best and final offer” in the negotiations between the actors’ union and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents the studios. Last week, the two sides seemed close to an agreement, but the latest offer from the producers included what SAG called a “surprise demand.” The actors are seeking a three-year contract retroactive to June 2008, when its previous agreement expired. That would mean the new contract would expire at the same time as the studios’ agreements with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists and the writers’ and directors’ guilds. Concurrent expiration dates would, of course, allow the unions to join forces in 2011 negotiations. The studios’ latest offer, presented on Feb. 19, proposed that the new agreement begin upon ratification and last for three years. “The AMPTPs last-minute, surprise demand for a new term of agreement extending to 2012 is regressive and damaging,” the Guild said in a statement released on Saturday. “By attempting to extend our contract expiration one year beyond the other entertainment unions, the AMPTP intends to deleverage our bargaining position from this point forward.” The producers also released a statement defending their offer as “strong and fair,” and pointing out that they have consistently sought a three year agreement and “have offered SAG a way to achieve an earlier expiration date without contributing to further labor uncertainty.”

Crown Publishers, an imprint of Random House, has acquired the North American publishing rights for two forthcoming books by the former secretary of state Condoleezza Rice, Crown’s vice president and publisher Tina Constable announced on Sunday. The first book, tentatively scheduled for publication in the Fall of 2011, will be a memoir of Ms. Rice’s years working in the administration of George W. Bush, first as the national security advisor and later as the secretary of state. The second book will be about her upbringing in Birmingham, Ala., where she was born in 1954, attended a segregated school and grew up against the backdrop of the civil rights movement. Publication of the second book is tentatively scheduled for fall 2012; neither book has a title at this point.

After 18 previews and just five regular performances, “The Story of My Life,” the two-character Broadway musical starring Malcolm Gets and Will Chase, will close after the matinee performance at the Booth Theater on Sunday. The show, about a writer who returns to his hometown to give a eulogy for a lifelong friend, was directed by Richard Maltby, Jr. and featured a book by Brian Hill and music and lyrics by Neil Bartram. The reviews were generally weak and theatergoers were not helping: For the week ending Feb. 15, the show filled 42 percent of seats and the week before that, just 33 percent, according to figures provided by the Broadway League.

It looks like they might bring this one in at under three hours, so I'll curb my complaining. And I'll close by noting that this seemed not only like a relatively brief Oscar ceremony, but a small one. Maybe this is a harbinger of things to come. Like it or not, the movies have lost their pop-cultural supremacy, and the fate of the Oscars may either be to go after a vanished mass appeal or to scale down, acknowledge the shrinking of the audience and turn into something like the Tonys. More of a coterie affair, appealing to the aficionados and the curious. It would be an honorable outcome.

First big surprise of the night! I haven't seen "Departures," but I was sure, like everyone else, that it would be "Waltz With Bashir" or "The Class" -- two of the biggest sensations in Cannes last May -- taking the best foreign language film Oscar. This is a bit of a puzzler to me, but since this is one of those categories where a voter has to have seen every nominee, maybe "Departures" is a great picture. I have to say I'm a bit disappointed that neither the social curiosity or "The Class" nor the political seriousness of "Bashir" moved the Academy. And of course, like my pal the Bagger, I can't believe that "Gomorrah" didn't merit a nomination. Another one of many boats missed by the Academy this year.

Danny Boyle wins the Oscar for best director for "Slumdog Millionaire."

The wins that "Slumdog" has racked up in some of the less glamorous categories--- editing, cinematography and score -- may be the most significant, since they recognize some of the film's novelty. Its look, its pacing and its sound are not like the competition, and indeed not like a lot of commercial American movies. And yet it is an entirely accessible movie, not so much self-consciously exotic as effortlessly, eagerly eclectic. So the fast editing, the eye-popping colors and textures, the songs and the music may be, to some audiences and Academy voters, a bit unfamiliar, but they obviously work, extending the vocabulary of what we sometimes parochially think of as mainstream moviemaking in some exciting new directions.

"I haven't been looking at the red carpet, I've been looking above and thinking of what it would be like to be on a wire above all this."

A cool thing about the order of the non-acting awards is that the procession follows the sequence of the movie-making process. So we started with writing, then went to aspects of production like makeup and cinematography, and now we're in "post," with effects and then, presumably, to editing, musical score, etc. This is a nice innovation, I think.

Brother Bagger, I'm as far beyond that Room as can be -- in a darkened bedroom in Brooklyn, a dog snoring at the foot of the bed, the rest of my family similarly if less noisily deep in slumber -and I have to say that it's a pretty dull night all around. No big surprises, and also a weirdly desperate, jumpy, uncertain energy to the show. But I don't necessarily mind this. The problem with the Oscars, as I wrote not long ago, is that they've taken on an aura of cultural importance that they can't possibly live up to. This broadcast feels trivial, which is as it should be. It matters, that is, to the people in that room and their colleagues, but not necessarily to any of the rest of us.

This is a film about watching the person you love while they sleep. When the eyes are closed, the "windows to the soul" are shuttered. There is no self-consciousness; in fact, consciousness is by definition absent. There is a surrender of the body to gravity and blankets and pillows that creates a kind of intimate landscape. The only visual evidence of life is breathing. It is the finest of motions; a slow rising and sinking. It's the the primordial rhythm of life.

Mariano Rivera is a mentor to several of the young, Latino players in the Yankees' organization. He takes them to dinner, he counsels them and he treats them like his little brothers. Sometimes, Rivera, the older brother, gets to be a playful bully, too. As Rivera interacted with his fellow reliever Edwar Ramirez in the clubhouse on Saturday, their behavior fit the mold of the older brother dominating the little brother because he can. After Rivera had an analgesic heating lotion applied to his right shoulder, he removed his shirt, rubbed it against the product and then pressed it against Ramirez's ear. Ramirez swiped in the air as if a dozen bees had floated into his ear. Ramirez complained, but it did not stop Rivera. In fact, Rivera was not finished with teasing his little buddy. Rivera took his uniform belt, unfurled it and whacked Ramirez in the back. Ramirez was jolted. While Ramirez grabbed a hanger and acted as if he might retaliate, he did not. After all, this was the mighty and valuable Mariano Rivera. Ramirez was just the little brother.

There's simply not enough Beth Ditto to go around. ''This league is all new to me,'' says the lead singer of the post-punk band Gossip, who's currently in the studio working with the megaproducers Rick Rubin and James Ford (of Simian Mobile Disco fame). But, she assures us, ''I'm not afraid!'' Also a fearless clotheshorse, Ditto will introduce a self-proclaimed ''fat-lady clothing line'' for the British plus-size label Evans this summer. She says her current style obsessions are ''Sarah Jessica Parker from 1993, Madonna from her 'Cherish' music video and Missy Elliott's trash-bag look'' - not to mention Jeremy Scott, Vivienne Westwood and ''those amazing designers who make clothes to fit me.'' But whether it is music or fashion, Ditto has just one rule: ''Absolutely no shame.''

You can print out and use to impugn the Bagger's competence on Monday, or use it as a guide to triumph or dispossession tonight. If you are going to vote in all categories, you could do worse. Otherwise you might want to spend your day catching up on, say, the animated shorts.

Two days after a 9-year-old Arizona boy pleaded guilty to the 2008 murder of his father and another man, police in Pennsylvania charged 11-year-old Jordon Brown yesterday in the shooting death of his father's girlfriend. The woman, identified as 26-year-old Kenzie Marie Houk, was eight months pregnant. As The Associated Press reported:

Writing in The Los Angeles Times, John Horn runs deep, revealing historical analytics on how "Slumdog Millionaire," a film that seemed dead more than once, now sits poised to take home the biggest award in the entertainment business:

Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: Are you like me in that because of the recession, you have no money? I mean, at first it was kind of funny, right? But now, it's not funny. Knock it off. We're tired of kidding around. We would like our money back.

Monologue | Aired Friday night on "The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson" on CBS: Arnold Schwarzenegger is taking time off as the Governor of California to shoot a part in an upcoming movie. The movie's about a terrible disaster. And it's called, "Arnold Schwarzenegger Is the Governor of California."

The nation's governors, Republicans and Democrats alike, have descended on Washington, with their worries about the economy set alongside their own ambitions. Several of them appeared on the the news shows today, as Republican governors raised concerns about aspects of the stimulus money that might lock their states into longer-term spending and Democratic governors looking forward to trying to create jobs with the infusion of federal funds. The governors are uncertain about exactly when the stimulus will kick in.
A short documentary profiling an 11-year-old Pakistani girl on the last day before the Taliban closed down her school.

The Bagger, along with a bunch of other ninnies, has been very excited to see what Bill Condon and Laurence Mark are going to come up with to shake the Oscar show out of its torpor. And then he saw a leaked video and it left him feeling just the smallest bit terrified.

John Patrick Shanley, the writer and director of "Doubt," was standing on the rooftop of the London West Hollywood hotel Saturday night, and he was joined one by one by four actors nominated for an Academy Award - Meryl Streep, Viola Davis, Amy Adams, and Philip Seymour Hoffman. Some people complained that the Mr. Shanley, the man who gave them such juicy roles, was not among the nominated.

Sports | Why, an article asks, are so many former Texas Rangers along with A-Rod accused of using banned substances? Could it be the team's proximity to Mexico, where steroids are easily obtained? Or the team's penchant for signing sluggers for its smaller park, which became a launching pad for home runs? Everything's bigger in Texas, indeed. [Wall Street Journal]

The Bagger had a good, ol' time at the Spirit Awards yesterday, spending most of his time outside kibitzing with pals and sources. He chatted up Darren Aronofsky, director of "The Wrestler, whom he once spent some time with on set, as well as a certain song-and-dance man. He said hello to Anne Hathaway, whom he profiled earlier in the season. He had a chance to chat with Philip Seymour Hoffman, who starred in "Synecdoche, New York," a film that the Bagger struggled to make heads or tails of. He even renewed his acquaintance with Misty Upham and Melissa Leo - Ms. Leo gave a flat-out whoop when she won best actress for "Frozen River" later - who showed up in his coverage of movies worth rooting for.

Religion | A new history of the Virgin Mary shows that her cult is "absolutely central to the narrative of European and Christian civilization," a review says. "Her absence was a defining feature of the colder, more rational world that emerged in the Protestant north. And in the colonial era, above all in Latin America, she metamorphosed seamlessly from conquerors' champion to helper of the oppressed." And she was a powerful buttress to faith, for to doubt her son's dual nature was to insult his mother. [Economist]

There was brown liquor, along with flutes of champagne, for the talent coming down the red carpet at the Spirit Awards in Santa Monica on Saturday. Most attendees demurred until they got inside the big tent and were confronted anew by giant bottles of whiskey. The Bagger spent some time on the carpet, but his pal Tricia Romano from Hollywood Life picked up some quotes while he was inside comparing his Oscar picks with some of the people inside:

Mickey Rourke brought down the house (or tent, actually) at Saturday's Spirit Awards with an acceptance speech for best actor that was an exquisite, meandering, profane ramble. It's not often a winner will kiss his director on the lips (in this case Darren Aronofsky), urge Hollywood to give a friend another shot (Eric Roberts) and offer a shout-out to his recently deceased dog (Loki). As Tom McCarthy "The Visitor") joked upon receiving being named best director for "The Visitor": "I think they should have stopped the show after Mickey; who can follow that?"

Culture | In this crisis, it's a good thing we have the Depression's generation of artists and intellectuals -- the likes of Sherwood Anderson, Edmund Wilson and John Dos Passos -- "to help us imagine our way past confusion," an essay says. "The road novels, documentary books and gangster films of the 1930's depicted the myth of social mobility as a bitter cheat. The era's screwball comedies viewed it merely as delightfully laughable." Will our era produce a new "Gatsby"? [Wall Street Journal]

Race | If Attorney General Eric Holder wants a "frank" conversation about race, Heather Mac Donald is happy to oblige. Among her points: Recent history suggests Holder means "a one-sided litany of white injustices." We "actually didn't talk a lot about Barack Obama's race during the election, thank heavens, because most Americans were more interested in the candidate's ideas than in his skin color" -- for racism is fading with the passing of generations. Now, how about "a full airing of the facts" about black crime, educational underperformance and family breakdown? [City Journal]
The Screen Actors Guild’s board of directors on Saturday rejected the “last, best and final offer” by Hollywood producers for a new contract.

Miguel Cotto became the World Boxing Organization welterweight champion when he stopped Michael Jennings 2 minutes 36 seconds into the fifth round at Madison Square Garden. Cotto (33-1, 27 knockouts) landed a steady barrage of head and body shots to drop Jennings twice in the fourth round and once in the fifth before the fight was stopped.

Jo-Wilfried Tsonga defeated third-ranked Novak Djokovic, 6-4, 7-6 (1), to reach the final of the Open 13 in Marseille, France. Tsonga took a 5-0 lead in the tie breaker and had two forehand winners to clinch the match. Tsonga will face Michael Llodra in the final Sunday. Llodra defeated Gilles Simon, 7-6 (5), 6-2, in their semifinal.

Venus Williams defeated unseeded Virginie Razzano, 6-4, 6-2, to win the Dubai Tennis Championships. The victory gave Williams her 40th career singles title and was her seventh win in her last eight finals. Her previous title came in November, at the WTA Championships in Doha, Qatar.

Gina Stechert of Germany captured her first World Cup victory Saturday in a downhill at Tarvisio, Italy, edging Lindsay Vonn by one hundredth of a second and denying Vonn a chance to set a United States women’s record of 19 Cup victories. Stechert completed the Prampero course in 1 minute 59.94 seconds. Anja Paerson of Sweden was 0.39 back in third.

The vice president of A.C. Milan, Adriano Galliani, said the club’s offer of $3 million for David Beckham was the market rate and it would not be increased. The Los Angeles Galaxy recently turned down the offer, calling it “ridiculous.” The Italian newspaper La Gazzetta dello Sport reported Saturday that Galliani said Milan would not make another offer. Beckham, who is on loan to Milan until March 8, has a clause in his Galaxy contract that allows him to leave at the end of the 2009 season.

The right-hander Kris Benson, the first pick in the 1996 draft by the Pittsburgh Pirates, signed a minor league contract with the Texas Rangers. Benson reported to camp as a nonroster invitee. Benson, 34, last pitched in the majors in 2006, going 11-12 with a 4.82 earned run average for Baltimore. He has a career record of 68-73 with a 4.34 E.R.A. with the Pirates, Orioles and Mets. He missed the 2007 season after having surgery to repair a torn right rotator cuff.

The Columbus Blue Jackets placed defenseman Ole-Kristian Tollefsen on injured reserve. Tollefsen is expected to be sidelined for four to six weeks with a lower body injury, General Manager Scott Howson said. He has 1 assist and 37 penalty minutes in 19 games this season.

Competing in her first major international meet, Jordyn Wieber, the reigning United States junior champion, won the American Cup in Hoffman Estates, Ill. Wieber, 13, finished with 60.2 points to finish six-tenths ahead of Bridget Sloan, who helped the United States women win a silver medal at the Beijing Olympics. Wieber will not be eligible for the world championships until 2011.

The Red Sox slugger David Ortiz said he had worked out with the controversial trainer Angel Presinal in the Dominican Republic, but he never saw anyone use performance-enhancing drugs there. Ortiz said he was not worried his name would be linked with others accused of steroid use.

The men’s Dubai Tennis Championships will start next week without five of the top seven players who were scheduled to compete, mostly because of injuries. Top-ranked Rafael Nadal (knee) and No. 2 Roger Federer (back) withdrew early last week.

The Boston Celtics said forward Kevin Garnett would miss two to three weeks because of a strained muscle behind his right knee. Garnett injured his knee Thursday, when he went up for an alley-oop late in the first half of Boston’s 90-85 loss to the Utah Jazz.

Pittsburgh picked up Manager John Russell’s contract option for 2010 despite the Pirates’ 67-95 record in his first season. “J. R. met or exceeded expectations in his first year as the Pirates’ manager,” General Manager Neal Huntington said. “His club worked hard to play the game properly and battled from the first out until the last.”.

Dwyane Wade had 25 points and 9 assists and the Miami Heat moved a step from its closest pursuers in the Eastern Conference playoff race on Saturday by beating the visiting Philadelphia 76ers, 97-91. Jermaine O’Neal finished with 17 points and 10 rebounds in his second game withMiami; Udonis Haslem added 13 points and 10 rebounds and Jamario Moon had 12 points. Andre Miller had 30 points for Philadelphia, which has lost three in a row for the first time since December.
Photos of performances by Oliver Platt.

An article last Sunday about the opening of Jollibee, a Filipino fast-food restaurant, in Woodside, Queens, erroneously included an item on the menu. The restaurant will not serve smoked bangus, a seafood dish offered at Jollibee restaurants in the Philippines.
Julie Ann Galluzzo and Jeffrey Roman Krish met in 2002 at Columbia Business School. After two years of school and a year  after graduation, their friendship finally blossomed into romance.
A retail and entertainment pleasure dome that sprawls over two million square feet may or may not open in August at the Meadowlands in New Jersey.
An interview with Ma Ying-jeou.
Among today's headlines:
The No. 2 Sooners squandered a 15-point first-half lead but clamped down on defense in the second half, beating No. 5 Oklahoma, 66-58.
At the Tour of California, it will not be any easier for riders to run down the leader, Levi Leipheimer, than it will be for Floyd Landis to ride away from his past.
Roger Mason had 25 points and 5 assists against his old team Saturday as he helped the San Antonio Spurs beat the Washington Wizards, 98-67.
Federal authorities interviewed Senator Roland W. Burris as they continued their corruption investigation of former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich, according to reports in the Chicago news media.
At this year’s four tournaments, witty names and clever costumes proved to be winning strategies.
Lottery numbers for Feb. 21, 2009.
Derek Roy had a goal and two assists and the Buffalo Sabres extended the Rangers’ road woes with a 4-2 victory Saturday night.
Oklahoma’s 13-game winning streak is over, and so is North Carolina’s 10-game run.

An obituary last Sunday about the travel writer Leila Hadley misstated the surname and title she used in private life. After her 1990 marriage to Henry Luce III, she went by Mrs. Luce, not Mrs. Hadley. The obituary also misidentified a school where she was a classmate of Gloria Vanderbilt. It is the Green Vale School in Old Brookville, N.Y. — not St. Timothy’s School in Stevenson, Md., which she later attended.

After sitting idle since losing to the Chicago White Sox in a one-game playoff for the American League Central title, the Minnesota Twins agreed to terms with the free-agent third baseman Joe Crede on a one-year deal Saturday.
Some academic researchers and education leaders say that small reductions in the number of students in a room often have little effect on their performance.
The Week Ahead listings on Page 4 this weekend carry an erroneous date. All events listed are for Sunday through Saturday, Feb. 22 to Feb. 28.
When contradictory verdicts are handed down, the discrepancy points to an uncomfortable reality: jurors sometimes follow their hearts as much as the law.
Mr. Upward was the last living link to writers like Isherwood, W. H. Auden and Stephen Spender who shaped English literature in the 1930s.
Two Manhattanites will be the only New Yorkers among eight finalists in Sunday’s Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions Grand Finals Concert.

An article in some editions last Sunday about the many links between the victims of the crash of Continental Connection Flight 3407 and residents of the Buffalo suburbs surrounding the site of the crash misstated, in some copies, the surname of an event planner who gathered with others to mourn Susan Wehle, a local cantor who died in the crash. She is Bonnie Gersh, not Stern. The article also referred incorrectly in some copies to Leon Komm, a funeral director who also knew Ms. Wehle. It is a friend of Mr. Komm’s — not Mr. Komm himself — who lives several hundred feet from the crash site, in Clarence Center.
Mr. Kahn was a social-policy scholar and an educator who turned a critical eye on failures of local and state governments in child development and family support.
Yankees Johnny Damon and Xavier Nady are among the investors whose accounts were caught in a freeze of a company affiliated with Robert Allen Stanford.
Local police officers can offer drivers a reduced charge on moving violations, but the State Police banned the practice in 2006. Now some are fighting the ban.
A pleasure dome is rising in the Meadowlands, a monument to what now seems like a truly impossible dream: commercial merriment.
Before he entered the minor leagues and earned an invitation to major league camp, Josh Thole’s batting practice took place in a converted hayloft in southern Illinois.
To change the debate on the culture wars, President Obama will have to address two truths: that morality has to be practical, and that practicality requires morals.
A federal compromise on the issue of gay marriage that could satisfy both sides in the short run.
We need leaders to help us through our crises, not provide us with crude evaluations of our character.
Precious public money should focus on investing in a new generation of innovative companies, not on bailing out the losers.
No one knows when there will be an end to the economic crisis, of course, but a bigger question may be whether we really want to know.

Anthony Casso, who is serving 455 years, is hoping to exchange information on the drug case for a reduced term.
The Journal Register Company filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors on Saturday, saying a slump in advertising revenue and circulation were to blame.
Charles J. O’Byrne, who resigned amid a tax scandal last year, will return to help oversee Gov. David A. Paterson’s 2010 re-election campaign.
Two suicides and two suicide attempts among cadets, as well as two suicides by staff members, have stirred concern at the renowned military academy.
A Katyusha rocket fired from southern Lebanon hit a village in northern Israel early Saturday, wounding a woman.
NEW YORK.
After a morning session with his swing coach, Phil Mickelson built a four-shot lead going into the final round of the Northern Trust Open in Los Angeles.
A look at some movie title sequences, from the past and present, that are Oscar-worthy.
A top Taliban leader indicated the truce entered with Islamabad in exchange for Islamic law may be temporary.
The Turkish prime minister, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, took his message of inclusion to the Kurdish heartland on Saturday, calling its people “first-class citizens.”
Georgia has taken the fight with its northern neighbor to the disco floor, with plans to present a tune that jabs at Vladimir V. Putin at Europe’s premier song contest.
World leaders will have to summon some of the same moral courage that Darfuris show all the time if the slaughter in the region is to end.
A 62-year-old woman will be the first of 10 people from the industrial city of Liuzhou to come to trial for planned protests in September.
The far-left group Sect of Rebels claimed responsibility for opening fire on a private television network in Athens last week, vowing additional attacks against journalists, the police said Saturday.
The lawsuit is the latest step in an effort to prosecute the exiled former president of Chad on charges of war crimes, torture and crimes against humanity.
One segment of the real estate market is actually booming these days: the auction business.
The taint of a company under suspicion can affect the profile of its former workers.
Small plants in England are being used to collect and refine used cooking oil into biodiesel for vehicles.
Chris DeWolfe is the chief executive of MySpace in Beverly Hills, Calif.
The oil in Gabon is running out, putting the future of the lush Edenic landscapes at Ivindo National Park at risk.
In harder times like these, self-employment can seem a tempting option for many laid-off workers.
A new study provides evidence to invest in simple, plain-vanilla index funds, whose low fees often lead to better net returns.
Gauging the Future of Coal.
How do the oil companies manage to keep going when the price of their basic source product changes so much?
Within an industry, fatigue has set in with the Oscar process as well as its expense.
The concept of the loyal opposition in Congress has seen better days.
Antitrust scrutiny is a growing worry at Google as its market share gains accelerate.
The governors said that the stimulus bill might help them avert draconian budget cuts, but that they did not expect to see signs of an economic recovery until late this year or early 2010.
A Houston program works with men incarcerated in Texas and trains them to become entrepreneurs.
Meg Whitman is trying to define her legacy as eBay’s leader as she explores a run for governor in California.
By comparing the current economic situation to the Depression, we risk it affecting our expectations.
While U.S. troop supplies ride the Kremlin’s rails, a key air base in Kyrgyzstan may be shut to America.
Fewer employees are putting in their notice these days — no doubt because they feel grateful to have a job at all.

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about financial stress tests for banks, referred incorrectly to a measure of soundness called “tangible equity to assets.” In the column’s hypothetical example, it would have been 1.2 percent, not a ratio of 1.2.

Because of a transcription error, the Boss column last Sunday, about William Hawkins, the chief executive of Medtronic, misidentified the company for which he worked that pioneered brachytherapy, which tries to prevent a narrowing of heart vessels after a stent is inserted. It is Novoste, not Medtronic.
Federal authorities say they have arrested four animal rights activists in connection with incidents involving University of California researchers.
An article last Sunday about the future of coal-fired power plants misidentified a company that has developed a technology to capture carbon dioxide. It is Alstom, not Alstrom.
Changing jobs out of fear or desperation can ruin many careers.
Rights groups have begun a campaign to improve the treatment of foreign sheepherders in the American West.
Total’s experience in Yemen shows how far an oil company will go to unearth new energy supplies.
With the N.F.L. scouting combine launching the run-up to the draft and the start of free agency, the next few weeks will be as important to success in 2009 as any nail-biting victory in November.
Marion Barry, the former mayor of Washington and current District of Columbia Council member, has undergone a kidney transplant at Howard University Hospital.
Some of the upgrades to the nation’s tsunami warning systems are temporary and have not been made to the highest standard.
Notre Dame thumped the Friars on Saturday in a game that epitomized the desperation emanating from teams outside the Big East’s top echelon.
What would a government investigation of Bush administration antiterrorism policies look like? Some past inquiries offer models.

Elliot Sadler had a fifth-place finish in the Daytona 500 after losing the lead in the rain.
It was not an easy decision for Monmouth Coach Stephanie Gaitley to leave Long Island University for a rival program in the conference.
Byron Scott attempted to put on a brave face when one of his key players was traded to cut payroll, just as Mike D’Antoni did two years ago.
For now, and at least until the end of the season, Vince Carter will remain with the Nets, a team with a waning shot at the playoffs.
A growing chorus is demanding that executive compensation snared shortly before problems emerged be given back.
The Philadelphia Flyers have been kicking a soccer ball back and forth as part of their pregame routine.
President Obama will set a goal this week to cut the annual deficit at least in half by the end of his term, according to officials.
Financial types say pay caps might spur the smartest bankers to jump ship. But there are few places to go.
Is the Big East the strongest conference in the country? It may not be this season.
Chelsea beat Aston Villa, 1-0, in the English Premier League on Saturday to give Guus Hiddink a victory in his first game as manager.
Didier Cuche completed two runs on the one-mile Kandahar Banchetta course in a combined 2 minutes 49.57 seconds to beat Stephan Görgl of Austria by 0.66.
There is a fresh buzz around the Washington Capitals as demand for tickets has reached franchise-record levels.
Pentagon officials reconsidering the ban on news coverage of coffins arriving from Iraq and Afghanistan are studying the media policies of other countries.
Iraq’s Ministry of Justice allowed reporters rare access to the Abu Ghraib prison, which has been partly renovated.
Toes curled in Britain as Kate Winslet blubbered at the Golden Globes.
An airstrike by the United States-led military coalition killed 13 civilians and 3 militants on Tuesday, military officials said.
Japan offers a peek at how thrift can take lasting hold of a consumer society, to disastrous effect.
The president signals that this is no time for lecturing other countries, but not everyone in his camp agrees.
These days, America is menaced by zombie banks and zombie computers. What’s next, a zombie Jane Austen? In fact, yes.

We share DNA with chimps and other primates, and are tempted to overshare more of ourselves.
The Sports Museum of America, which opened near Wall Street in May, shut down after business Friday.
The Dodgers left-hander Randy Wolf is thinking positively even after a $28.5 million deal with Houston fell through.

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Soviet economist Nikolai Kondratieff and his theory of business cycles referred incorrectly to the presidential candidacy last year of Representative Ron Paul of Texas, who was advised by Peter Schiff of Euro Pacific Capital, whose views, like Kondratieff’s, are considered outside mainstream economics. Mr. Paul, who takes libertarian positions on issues, is a Republican who sought his party’s nomination; he was not the Libertarian Party’s candidate.
The notion that detainees have no right to dispute their imprisonment was a key argument of the Bush administration.
Sophie Anne Jensen and Robert Jeffrey Lalley were married Saturday evening at the Mansion Inn of Saratoga, in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. Robert A. Rybak, a town justice of Clifton Park, N.Y., officiated.
Vicky Hallett and Jeffrey Archer Miller were married last evening in Washington. Rabbi Mindy Portnoy officiated at the Washington Club, a private events space.

Johanna Maria Katherine Bayly, a daughter of Katherine K. Bayly and Judge John H. Bayly Jr. of Washington, was married Saturday to Barclay Gardner Howe Jr., a son of Judith D. Howe and Mr. Howe of Simsbury, Conn. Msgr. John J. Enzler, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington, where he is pastor.
Julie Galluzzo and Jeffrey Karish were married Saturday evening at the Hyatt Regency in Old Greenwich, Conn.
As he endures grueling cancer treatments, Senator Edward M. Kennedy is intent on racing time rather than looking back.
Tali Vardi and Sach Sokol were married Saturday evening at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Jeremy K. Boyd, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

Kimberly DiVita and David James Smith were married Saturday evening at Twenty Four Fifth, an event space in Manhattan. The Rev. Kim Kirkley, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, an interfaith ministry, officiated.
Lisa Ann Rosenthal and Eric Jason Bader were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan. Cantor Morris Wolk officiated.

Lisa Alexandra Hunt and Edward Ives Stevens were married Saturday at Torrey Pines Christian Church in La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Ken D. Huff, a Disciples of Christ minister, officiated, with the Rev. Matthew T. Gamber, a Roman Catholic priest, assisting in a ceremony with Protestant and Catholic traditions.

Alison Jean Becker and Adam Joseph Messinger were married Tuesday at their home in Berkeley, Calif. The bride’s father, Howard S. Becker of San Francisco, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.
The couple is facing new challenges together after both deciding to leave their jobs.
Gillian Margaret Deutch and Daniel Michael Solinsky were married Monday at Dix Hills Jewish Center in Dix Hills, N.Y. Rabbi Howard Buechler performed the ceremony.
Lauren Muzinich and Robert Dickinson were married Saturday evening at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.
A seed of love planted in the hearts of two teenagers blossoms after 47 years.

Matt Kenseth will try to become the first driver since Jeff Gordon in 1997 to win the first two races of the year when he competes at the Auto Club 500 in Fontana, Calif.

CAPITOL, Laura Vinroot Poole’s 6,000-square-foot style emporium, is ground zero for chic Charlotteans, whether they’re looking for a drop-dead evening dress or the perfect cotton T-shirt. “We have an incredibly sophisticated population,” Poole says. “Our clients opt for quality and integrity over fads, so I question every single piece in the store and try to figure out how it fits into their lives.” (4010 Sharon Road, Charlotte, N.C.; 704-366-0388).

Can fashion anticipate the future? Did it hype padded shoulders in advance of feminism? Were miniskirts a precursor of the contraceptive pill? Could hemlines have dropped last summer as a warning of woes on Wall Street? And is the current design passion for Africa a recognition of Barack Obama’s roots?.

From the moment she arrived in Paris in 1925, toward the end of the seminal Art Deco exhibition that led to a collective embrace of all things African, Josephine Baker was a muse among muses, inspiring the likes of Picasso, Alexander Calder, Gertrude Stein, Colette and Adolf Loos. The embodiment of the Harlem Renaissance and the Jazz Age, she was modernism made flesh — the athletic, long-limbed analogue of Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring.”.

If Louise de Vilmorin knew how adoringly she would be remembered — and what an industry would be made of her life and oeuvre — she might not have been so heartsick. How desolate was this French femme de lettres and saloniste, legendary clotheshorse and tastemaker, brilliant hostess and home-wrecking man slayer? Casting about for a title for her new life of Vilmorin, Françoise Wagener, a biographer of Empress Joséphine, settled nicely on “I Was Born Inconsolable” (Les Éditions Albin Michel).
