Since Adam and Eve first used fig leaves to make “aprons,” these garments have weathered mixed fashion fortunes. But at the spring collections, they leapt from the kitchen to the catwalk. At Miu Miu, they were slung over silky skirts; Junya Watanabe’s models swayed with tribal-motif aprons over patchwork denim skirts; and at Marc Jacobs, a 1940s-style apron was cinched with a Lurex-shot sash. Up to the early 20th century, aprons were predominantly worn by servants. But in 1917, according to Elda Danese’s book “The House Dress,” Herbert Hoover, then the director of the Food Administration, developed a plan for civilians to supply food to the military; housewives were issued a beret and coveralls that became known as the Hoover Apron. During World War II, Diana Vreeland, working at Harper’s Bazaar, challenged the designer Claire McCardell to create an attractive garment to meet the needs of women “who faced the facts of life.” McCardell’s “popover,” a tie-fastened denim shift with patch pockets and a quilted oven mitt, sold in the hundreds of thousands. Soon aprons became associated with apple-pie moms, but across the Atlantic stars like Sophia Loren were using them to emphasize their swaying hips. With the advent of women’s liberation, though, aprons became passé, and it wasn’t until the ’90s that designers like Helmut Lang and artists like Andrea Zittel began re-examining them. At Zittel’s Smockshop (smockshop.org), artists still produce one-off versions. Lately, the cult of the apron has been gaining ground — witness “Desperate Housewives” and the earthy mamacitas of Pedro Almodóvar’s films. Apronology, a magazine targeting haute-apron fanciers, was introduced this month. In Japan, “hadaka apron” fetishists enjoy imagery of women wearing nothing but an apron — an aesthetic that evokes some of Thakoon Panichgul&#

Paris Hilton, with her cellphone full of pictures of herself, is here. As are Lindsay Lohan, who declared herself a role model to “younger generations as well as generations older than me”; Britney Spears, the teen-queen train wreck; Barry Bonds, the probably-not-all-natural home-run hero; and Bode Miller, the Olympic party boy. Sadly, Jelena Jankovic, the tennis star riveted by her own image during instant replays on the Jumbotron at last year’s U.S. Open, and Madonna, who has parlayed self-absorption and exhibitionism into a multimillion-dollar career, didn’t make the cut. But for Jean M. Twenge and W. Keith Campbell, psychologists and authors of “THE NARCISSISM EPIDEMIC: LIVING IN THE AGE OF ENTITLEMENT” (Free Press), the challenge must have been not finding examples but deciding which ones to leave out.

When Giambattista Valli was 8 years old, his family took him to see Visconti’s “The Leopard.” The youngster assumed he was about to enjoy a Disney-like production featuring cuddly felines, but what he got instead was a fashion revelation. To this day, Valli credits his aesthetic to the scene where Claudia Cardinale, who plays the unsophisticated but ravishing young upstart Angelica, laughs unabashedly at an off-color joke during a formal dinner. Needless to say, it is Angelica and not a prim principessa who winds up with the aristocrat Tancredi Falconeri, played by Alain Delon. “At that age, you notice things but you don’t know why,” Valli says. “Years later you realize their importance.”.

Thinking of using the abysmal economic situation to justify greasy locks and sagging hems? Planning to trade your favorite five syllables — Saks Fifth Avenue — for the pithier Old Navy? Oh, no! The way to face down hard times is “to express your courage by not letting down on your looks! To keep a dash of lipstick on the stiff upper lip and put your best foot forward in a good shoe! To give up the fatal vice of cheap clothes! In fact . . . be sufficiently grande dame to stop talking about money altogether!”.

One day 10 years ago in the countryside of southern Nigeria, a slim middle-aged man drove past a bag of garbage. Garbage is not an unusual sight in West Africa; village roads are often lined with a parallel hillock of trash — dusty bottles, spoiled food, tin cans, car parts — out of which small trees sometimes grow. But this solitary bag looked promising. It was a quiet, sunny late afternoon in the dry season. The man stopped the car and walked over to look inside.

Katie Grand has never met a handbag she didn’t love. Grand, the putative stylist’s stylist, sounding board for the likes of Marc and Miuccia, and former editor of the achingly hip Pop, uses them on the runway and in fashion shoots as liberally as Georgia O’Keeffe sprinkled her paintings with cattle skulls.

Christian Niessen and Nicole Lachelle, two German designers based in New York, are taking the concept of “one-of-a-kind dressing” to a new level with their No Editions label. Niessen trawls through online newspapers and magazines for striking images (music videos, daily headlines, NASA landscapes), manipulates them on his computer until they’re completely unrecognizable and then transfers them onto clothes. The prints are all unique, which means that no two No Editions garments are ever the same. “Complete individualization is the only weapon that small designers have in the fight against big retailers and chains,” says Niessen, who worked with Helmut Lang as his head designer. The couple makes sure that the prints are always the focus of attention by keeping their silhouettes clean and straightforward: there are shawl-collared felt wraps, ultrathin silk camisole dresses, hooded windbreakers and straight-leg jeans that gradate from dark navy to black. “We work with customized printers and a special blend of inks,” Niessen says. “They are low-cost, low-tech elements that have allowed us to obtain high-tech results that are very difficult to copy.” In other words, don’t try it at home. [?][?][?] MARKUS EBNER.

The first thing you should know about olfactory works of art — scents made by artists who work not in paint or clay but in the medium of scent — is their rare, visceral beauty. Art scents are the Lucian Freuds, Mirós and, at times, Damien Hirsts of the trade. The raw materials used by the luxury fragrance brands to concoct perfumes are harnessed here by artists to construct serious aesthetic work, work that conveys vision and emotion on an invisible canvas. The inventiveness poured into these creations reverberates not against our retinas or eardrums but our nasal epithelia. Which is the second most astonishing thing about scent art — the degree to which museums essentially ignore it.

Around the world, members of our species are celebrating the 200th birthday of Charles Darwin. Because November is also the 150th anniversary of Darwin’s controversial book “The Origin of Species,” the festivities will be quite frolicsome. Have fun, but please, when attending the many lectures, exhibits, symposia and other lofty events in evolution’s honor, choose carefully which of this spring’s insane shoes you wear, because one look at your feet and every hot geek knows which brand or twig of Darwinism you favor.

The work of the Amsterdam-based designer Ted Noten comes with a manifesto: “Jewelry should be famously curious.” His pieces — a brooch cast from chewed gum, shattered porcelain cups hanging from a gold chain — are not your standard charm bracelet. A few years ago, when Noten, a former psychiatric nurse, was invited to create a piece with pearls for an exhibition, he dressed a dead mouse in pearls and encased it in an acrylic pendant. He recently expanded into handbags with gold-plated guns, pills and designer logos. This April you can see his creations at the Ornamentum Gallery at the SOFA fair (sofaexpo.com) in New York City. [?][?][?] MAURA EGAN.

“Valentino: The Last Emperor” (in theaters this spring) seems at first like pure escapist fun — the cinematic version of a lipstick-red party dress that you wear once and remember a thousand times. Valentino, the spectacularly famous fashion designer, jets from fitting to lunch to party, from his Versailles chateau to his Gstaad chalet to his 152-foot yacht, his entourage and five pugs faithfully en suite. But the film’s potent, bittersweet undertow makes it one for the ages. It reveals one of the past century’s most elegantly lived lives — and a world that is slipping away even as the cameras roll. The director, Matt Tyrnauer, followed Valentino and his longtime partner, Giancarlo Giammetti, through tense dealings with Marzotto (which had bought Valentino’s fashion house in 2002; he remained the designer until last year), his penultimate couture show and finally a goodbye party in the Roman Forum, with the Colosseum as a backdrop. Paradoxically, while the film chronicles Valentino’s stepping down, it has enthroned him in a new, different role. Last year, at the Venice and Toronto film festivals, the screenings ended with standing ovations — and not just from fashion fans. Still, Valentino is playing it cool. “I cannot judge the movie,” he says. “But we are not worried that sometimes we look a bit ridiculous or a bit extravagant. We are what we are.” No doubt about that. [?][?][?] DAVID COLMAN.

THE ROYAL SHE.

Maybe it’s a reaction to the distressing economy, but I’ve been consumed with the urge to release my inner diva. And what better role model for fantasies of excess than the art collector and style eccentric Peggy Guggenheim? She had a nose job in 1920, when such procedures were decidedly dangerous; surrounded herself with divine artists, husbands and lovers and an even more divine gaggle of Lhasa apsos; presided over a gallery with curved walls and a turquoise floor; and wore custom earrings by Alexander Calder and Yves Tanguy. Did I mention that her Dunhill lighter had a phallic engraving, also by Tanguy? But Guggenheim’s most recognizable accessories were her batwing, butterfly-shaped, gilded and bejeweled eyeglass frames, courtesy of the artist Edward Melcarth, a friend and fellow Venice resident in the 1950s. It’s unclear whether I’ll be able to discover the next Jackson Pollock within my lifetime, but this season I can at least channel Peggy’s spirit with fabulously decadent shades by David Yurman, Lanvin and Pucci (left, from top). Who knows? If all else fails, I may pack them up, move to Miami, dye my hair blue and pursue a career as a fabulous old lady. Not a bad option, all things considered.[?][?][?] REBECCA VOIGHT.

There’s simply not enough Beth Ditto to go around. “This league is all new to me,” says the lead singer of the post-punk band Gossip, who’s currently in the studio working with the megaproducers Rick Rubin and James Ford (of Simian Mobile Disco fame). But, she assures us, “I’m not afraid!” Also a fearless clotheshorse, Ditto will introduce a self-proclaimed “fat-lady clothing line” for the British plus-size label Evans this summer. She says her current style obsessions are “Sarah Jessica Parker from 1993, Madonna from her ‘Cherish’ music video and Missy Elliott’s trash-bag look” — not to mention Jeremy Scott, Vivienne Westwood and “those amazing designers who make clothes to fit me.” But whether it is music or fashion, Ditto has just one rule: “Absolutely no shame.” [?][?][?] ALEX HAWGOOD.

As Peggy Orenstein points out (The Way We Live Now, Feb. 8), there’s nothing like the suggestion of a cancer risk to freak out a parent. Can we really blame parents for overprotecting when those in charge are negligent? This negligence becomes even more obvious in cases where there isn’t just a suggestion of risk, but clear evidence. Take formaldehyde. Just this month the E.P.A. was reportedly “considering” regulating formaldehyde as a toxic substance, which would be momentous except that the World Health Organization declared it as “carcinogenic to humans” back in 2004, and the E.P.A. itself listed formaldehyde as a “probable human carcinogen” back in the 1980s. If being concerned about a more-than-20-year delay in regulating a carcinogenic substance that is ubiquitous in clothing, carpeting, furniture and paint marks me as a helicopter parent, then watch your head. We can’t raise kids in a bubble, but going out of our way to protect them is the only intelligent choice, because there’s no one else looking out for their well-being.

The 36 Hours column on Feb. 8 about Dallas noted that the Gerald Peters Gallery on Dragon Street was a top draw in the city’s Design District. An essay on Feb. 1 about “Reborn,” an edition of Susan Sontag’s journals, described the abrupt sequence of events surrounding Sontag’s marriage. It cited three journal entries, the first introducing her future husband and the others referring to her engagement and to her marriage, all under date headings between November 1949 and Jan. 3, 1950, as the essay noted.

ASSUME VIVID ASTRO FOCUS The hyperkinetic world of Assume Vivid Astro Focus -- an ''art collective'' that is actually the professional moniker of Eli Sudbrack and Christophe Hamaide Pierson -- knows no perimeters. Melding digital technology, performance art, neon, balloons and graffiti with a whole lot of glitter, the international duo -- Sudbrack is Brazilian; Pierson was born in France -- are pop-culture mixologists. (Right now they're into art made by the Maoris of New Zealand and ''electronic dancing beats from Chicago,'' to name just two interests.) For this issue, they created the ''T'' seen on Page 137 out of African-inspired textiles. As with most of their kaleidoscopic work, they admit that their interpretation of the world's second-largest continent is ''secondhand and purely imaginary.'' The two recently took part in the São Paulo biennial in Brazil (center and far right), and Rizzoli will release a monograph on them next year.

STOLBERG--Irving. A Friend Remembered. Describing another person through titles and labels can be an innocent form of short-hand, or a form of criticism and judgment. During his life, Irving Stolberg earned many titles and attracted many labels. Stolberg, who died on February 13, was most famously known as the two-term Speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives and a 22-year member of that body. To some he was that "liberal Democrat from New Haven." To me he was a former neighbor and a dear friend of 40 years. Through that wonderful association, I was able to gather a deeper understanding of Irv Stolberg, one that transcended titles and labels. Irv Stolberg held, espoused, and vigorously defended some very strong views. He was for peace, opposed to the Vietnam War, for progressive taxation including the income tax, opposed to the death penalty, supportive of the United Nations, opposed to the war in Iraq, for the global spread of democratic institutions, opposed to racism, and respectful of foreign cultures. To some his views were controversial, disloyal, or wrong. To some they were principled, moral, and right. With the hindsight of passed years, it now seems that his views held much truth and will carry well into the future. Irv Stolberg did not simply pluck his views from the shelves of some ideologically driven bookstore, nor borrow them from some talking head. They came, instead, from study and deep contemplation. They came from constant observation and evaluation, applied with the discipline of a lifelong professional academic. Through his travels and work in almost 100 countries, he was informed by the common threads of humanity that he observed; of the common need for peace and the absence of violence, for adequate sustenance, for health care, for the education of children, and protection of the aged. It was with profound respect for all citizens of our globe, and with constant support for their fundamental needs and rights -- through endless public service -- that Irv Stolberg led his life; a good life of a good friend. Irv wished in lieu of flowers that donations in his memory be made to the United Nations Association CT or to the American Friends Service Committee. Edward J. Mazur Richmond, Virginia

LANSDALE--Bruce M.,beloved former President of the American Farm School in Thessaloniki, Greece, on February 2nd at his daughter's home near the School he led for 35 years until his retirement in 1990. He was surrounded by family and friends. Under his leadership, the American Farm School grew from a small school devoted to improving the lives of rural youths from Greece and the Balkans to a major institution known throughout the region and the world as a leader in agricultural education and leadership training. Mr. Lansdale's books, Master Farmer and Cultivating Inspired Leaders, translated into several languages, are recognized tools for global work in sustainable development. Former U.S. Ambassador to Greece, Thomas M.T. Niles, said, "Bruce Landale's work as President of the American Farm School did more for Greece, and Greek-American relations, than all the American ambassadors combined, myself included." Born in 1925 in Worcester, Massachusetts, he was raised in Thessaloniki where his father was an early director of the YMCA. He earned degrees from Rochester University and Cornell. Mr. Lansdale's many honors included three successive Fulbright Scholar grants; Rockefeller and Ford Foundation Fellowships; and an honorary Ph.D. from Aristotle University of Thessaloniki. He was an honorary citizen of Greece and of the City of Thessaloniki. The Greek Government awarded him the Commander of the Order of Honor, and the Royal Order of King George. Besides his wife, Tad, Mr. Lansdale leaves four children: David, Jeffrey and Michael Lansdale, Christine Willis and eleven grandchildren. Memorial gifts may be made the American Farm School (Lansdale Leadership Fund). Contact: 212-463-8434 or e-mail amahee@amerfarm.org.

SELLERS and buyers are not the only jittery players in today's housing market. Real estate offices along Main Streets throughout Westchester County, N.Y., are struggling to stay in business during one of the worst markets in decades, and at the same time shift away from their traditional job description to become more competitive players on the Internet. Reflecting the grave state of the market, Houlihan Lawrence, a family-owned real estate company dating from the 1950s, announced on Feb. 13 that it was laying off 10 percent of its employees -- although not its sales agents, who work as independent contractors.

BRIDGER--Wagner H.,M.D., passed away on February 10, 2009 after a long illness in Fountain Hills, AZ. He was 81. A research pioneer in the fields of Biological Psychiatry, Psychopharmacology and Neonatology, he was a Professor of Psychiatry and Neuroscience and Acting Chairman of the Dept. of Psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York before moving to Philadelphia, PA in 1982. There he became Chairman of the Dept. of Psychiatry at the Medical College of Pennsylvania at the Eastern Pennsylvania Psychiatric Institute, which later became part of Drexel University. With over 180 publications, he was a founder of the Society of Biological Psychiatry and appointed President of the Society in 1988 along with being Editor Emeriti of its journal 1992-1997. A committed social activist, he helped found the Medical Committee for Human Rights in 1964. Civil rights, peace and justice were causes that occupied his entire life. A devoted husband, father and grandfather, he was a lover of life's pleasures including Cuban cigars, Cape Cod, Wellfleet oysters and martinis. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Rita Hayes Bridger, his seven children, Eric Bridger, Cindy Bridger, Laurie Bridger, Colleen Jacobson, Mary Jane Sanacore, Colo Hayes III, Christopher Hayes and 11 grandchildren.

BAILEY--Katharine Palmer, 64, of Millerton, NY, and Lakeville, CT, died peacefully on February 14, 2009 of cancer, after years during which she displayed such courage and composure that few knew she was ill. She was the deeply loved wife of Albert Francke, of Millerton, NY, and sister of Charles Bailey, of Sidney, VA, and Robert Bailey, of Oak Park, IL. Ms. Bailey graduated from Miss Porter's School in 1961, and, after years of adventurous travel through Latin America, Africa and Southeast Asia, received her BA in nursing at Boston University School of Nursing. Then, in 1979, she received her MS in psychiatric nursing at Boston College. She spent 25 years in psychiatric nursing practice, published several monographs and articles on psychopharmacology, and ended her career as an assistant professor at Yale University School of Nursing. She spent her last four years in a joyful marriage to Albert Francke. She was deeply loved by many, and will be missed by all who knew her high intelligence, deep sympathy and caring for others. A memorial service will be held for her at a later date. In her memory please make donations to the Katharine P. Bailey Memorial Fund at Health and Empowerment for African Lives (HEAL) attn. Martha Schnell, 1603 W. Taylor MC 923, Chicago, IL 60612 or www.Healpartners.org.

JERUSALEM -- A Katyusha rocket fired from southern Lebanon hit a village in northern Israel early Saturday, lightly wounding one woman. The Israeli military responded with artillery shells aimed at the source of the fire, according to an army spokeswoman. No injuries were reported on the Lebanese side. Hezbollah, a militant Shiite group, denied involvement in the attack. Two rockets were launched, though only one landed in Israel.

THE NEWS Taiwan said that its economic output shrank by 8.36 percent in the last quarter of 2008, its sharpest fall on record. Combined with a revised figure of minus 1.05 percent for the third quarter, the latest contraction plunged the country officially into recession. BEHIND THE NEWS The slump has now rippled far down a chain of causes and effects: The credit crisis dried up spending by American consumers, which undercut growth in China, whose manufacturers sell them goods; that, in turn, clobbered Taiwan, which depends heavily on trade with the once-booming mainland. Taiwanese exports fell about 43 percent in January compared with a year ago, the steepest plunge in Asia.

GREENBERG--Frances. With deep regret we note the passing of Frances Greenberg on February 19th from complications of a stroke. Family leader and bedrock, Frances was known to all as the "glue" of her extended family which spanned three continents. Born in China in 1917, she came to New York with her late husband, Jack Greenberg, and two daughters before WWII. Always dedicated to her people, she volunteered for several Jewish organizations, was President of the American Far Eastern Society, and also an active member of Congregation B'nai Jeshrun for over fifty years. The youngest of eight, she saw many loved ones off to the next life including, sadly, her two daughters Rosalie and Anne. We strove in your model to bring dignity and peace to your final hour, Grandma. Survived by her son-in-law Dr. Nicholas Koffler, grandchildren Stephen, Pamela, Richard Koffler and Kenny, Andrea, and Jennifer Linsky, as well as ten great- grandchildren. You showed us how to live with strength, common sense, and humor. We'll miss you. Gifts to Cong. BJ Rabbi Discretionary Fund, 2109 Broadway, Suite 203, NY NY 10023. Funeral Sunday February 22nd, 9:30am at Plaza Memorial, 91st and Amsterdam.

Milacci of Bridgeville, PA, and Beteena (Marlowe) Marburger of Sewickley, PA. Robb loved his family, cherished his friends, enjoyed traveling, read comics, ran marathons, watched films avidly, scuba dived, and dreamt of his family's future. He was a member of Delta Upsilon fraternity, the CFA Institute, and the New York Society of Securities Analysts. CAUGHT IN A WHIRLWIND BY THE EIFFEL TOWER, PARIS, OCT. 10, 2008 Stephanie Corrigan, 41, a homemaker from Atherton, Calif., with her daughters Ingrid, 8, and Mila, 4. ''We were just coming off a 21-day trip, and were going to take a train from Paris to London and fly home. My husband is up in the Eiffel Tower with the other two kids, Claudia, 11, and Drake, 6. We take them on trips every single summer. They each have their suitcases, their backpacks. We're like a spectacle in the airport, but they get it, they know exactly what to do. My husband goes in front, then Claudia (the oldest), then Ingrid, then Drake, then Mila, and I'm in the back. People look at you like 'Wow, how are you doing that?' But we've never traveled as a couple by ourselves -- we've never even gone to Vegas for two nights without them. For our next vacation, we're off to Norway for 19 days. We don't really think that it's not doable -- we just book the trip and go.'' As told to Seth Kugel

GONZALEZ--Jay M.,a Scion of International Tax Operations, dies at 75. Jay M. Gonzalez, an international tax partner with Coopers & Lybrand who had an instrumental role in expanding that company's international tax operations, died peacefully in his home in Hillsborough, California, on Saturday, February 7, 2009. Mr. Gonzalez was born in Laredo, Texas and graduated from Texas A & M University. He received an MBA from the University of North Texas. He served his country in Korea in the U.S. Army. Later in his career, Mr. Gonzalez completed Harvard University's Program for Management Development, an intensive course in business management geared for high-performing executives. In 1960 he started a career with Price Waterhouse in New York. In 1965 he joined International Basic Economy Corporation (IBEC) as Vice President of Tax. IBEC was created by Nelson A. Rockefeller with the aim of promoting economic development-such as supermarkets, housing, poultry and mutual funds--in Latin America. IBEC later expanded its activities into 33 other underdeveloped countries on 4 continents. He joined Coopers & Lybrand in 1974 and retired as an International Tax Partner from the San Francisco office in 1996. He excelled in mergers and acquisitions of multinational corporations. A close friend from Atlanta once said to him, "Jay, you are the most brilliant financial architect we shall ever see." Throughout his career Mr. Gonzalez was an active member of the International Fiscal Association (IFA). The membership of IFA includes over 12,000 professionals residing in 100 countries who specialize in international taxation. From 1994 to 1996, he was the President of the USA Branch of IFA which comprises over 1,100 members. He served as a member of the USA IFA Executive Committee for 10 years. After retiring, he spent much of his time working on Palemi Ranch, his ranch in Northern California, for which he oversaw operations and enjoyed spending time. He is survived by his wife, Lilia G. Gonzalez, of Hillsborough; two daughters, Patricia G. Lange of Culver City, and Leah Jarlsberg of San Mateo, one son Michael of Castro Valley, and two grandchildren, Catherine and Alexander Lange. A celebration of Life Mass will be celebrated at 2:00pm, Saturday, March 7, 2009 at St. Bartholomew Parish, San Mateo, California (300 Alameda de las Pulgas), followed by a reception to be held at the Peninsula Golf and Country Club in San Mateo, CA (701 Madera Drive). In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Bartholomew Parish. Sneider & Sullivan & O'Connell's Funeral Home (650)343-1804 www.ssofunerals.com.

EVEN before the economy took a spill, Carlos Quirarte, a marketing director for brands like Earnest Sewn and Freemans Sporting Club, and his business partner, Matt Kliegman, were rethinking the retail concept. ''We always wanted to do a multiuse space, something that had a family vibe to it,'' Mr. Quirarte said. ''Now it feels even more appropriate.'' The Smile, which opened unofficially on Friday, is a conceptual mash-up, housed in a rustic two-floor space designed by Luke Scarola, owner of the Brooklyn antiques store Luddite. There is a cafe, with a Mediterranean-inspired menu created by Melia Marden; a tattoo parlor, run by Scott Campbell of Saved Tattoo; a gallery curated by Mr. Quirarte (Nate Lowman's smiley-face work is now on display); and a wall of shelves filled with exclusive or custom-made products from Adam Kimmel, Sol Moscot, the Brooklyn-based lingerie line the Lake & Stars, the Parisian knitwear label Wool and the Gang, House of Waris, White's Boots and the candle maker Cire Trudon, which dates to the 17th century and designed a candle inspired by the scent of the salvaged-wood interior. ''So many stores just chase trends,'' Mr. Quirarte (right) said. ''We're trying to do something different.''

BETWEEN the seemingly endless winter and the fall fashion shows (best described, at least from the looks on the New York runways, as ''black''), we could use a little spring fever. Lest anyone forget, the approaching season is all about big earrings and body-con dresses and colors that recall the Southwest. Jean Paul Gaultier's jangly turquoise earrings are just the thing to put you in the right state of mind. Wear them with hair pulled back, a bit of bronzer -- and anything but black. Jean Paul Gaultier turquoise earrings, $855 at Emphatics in Pittsburgh; (412) 471-4773.

THROUGHOUT its sad decades-long decline, General Motors kept the faith of a relatively small but highly influential constituency: high-performance enthusiasts with a genetic predisposition for American muscle cars. But on Wednesday, it seemed the company was throwing these true believers under the high-horsepower bus. Automotive News posted an online article that said: ''G.M. today disbanded High Performance Vehicle Operations, which is based at the company's suburban Detroit technical center, and redeployed its engineers.'' A G.M. spokesman, Vince Muniga, was quoted as saying, ''All high-performance projects are on indefinite hold.''

Survivors include daughter Nancy Valerie Kahn. Contributions: "Alfred J. Kahn Doctoral Fellowship Fund at Columbia University School of Social Work," CUSSW, 1255 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY, 10027.

SHEPARDSON--John Whitney, of Denver, Colorado, died at Porter Hospital on February 18, 2009. He was 83. He died of natural causes. John W. Shepardson, the son of Whitney H. and Eleanor C. Shepardson, was born in New York City on March 25, 1925. He was graduated from independent schools in New York City and in New England and entered Harvard College in September 1942. Four months later, he left Harvard to enlist in the U.S. Navy. At the end of World War II, Shepardson was honorably discharged as Quartermaster First Class. He had served in the Atlantic and Pacific theaters aboard LSTs and had participated in the liberation of the Philippines. He returned to Harvard College and took an AB cum laude degree in June 1949. Some years later he earned an M.A. degree from Univerisity of Colorado, Boulder. Shepardson began his business career in June 1949 in New York City. By September 1952 he had redirected his efforts into oil and gas exploration work and was employed successively by Gulf Oil Corporation, American Metal Climax, Inc., Jenney Oil Company, Kelly and Morey, Inc., Northwest Exploration Company; in 1986 he concluded his career as President, Corrida Oils Inc. From time to time, he was self-employed in various aspects of operations and finance of energy companies. Other business activities also included being a director of the Janus family of mutual funds for over twenty-five years. From 1964 to 1968, the entire Shepardson family began the Wellesley Junior Soccer program and so brought soccer to the Boston Suburbs around Rte. 128. He devoted his later years to research in American History, concentrating on the years 1890-1966 and to ranching on a property he owned jointly with his wife at Three Forks, Montana. He was a member of the Cactus Club of Denver. He is survived by his wife of over fifty years, Joan B. Shepardson, his daughter, Elizabeth P. (Betsy) Shepardson of New York City, his son, Daniel C. (Dan) Shepardson, and two grandchildren. Private funeral services will be held following cremation. Contributions may be made to a charity of the donor's choice.

TOMMY TON, the founder of the high-fashion photo blog Jak & Jil (jakandjil.com), admits he can be a bit intrusive with his camera. ''Oh, I'm a stalker,'' the 24-year-old Toronto native joked. He introduced his site in September but has been following the fashion pack for the last two years, shooting street-style photos for Vogue Nippon and Teen Vogue Korea. ''I'm over asking people if I can take their picture,'' he said. ''Now I just wait for the right moment.'' Indeed, for fashion enthusiasts, the results are rather delicious: up-close shots of editors' shoes; models leaving shows in full hair and makeup; the French Vogue team, photographed walking away from the camera (top). And now Mr. Ton's site, which is regularly updated with photos culled from the hundreds he takes each fashion season, has caught the attention of executives at Lane Crawford, the Asian luxury retailer. Last month, he was tapped to shoot its ad campaign, one previously shot by Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin. Undoubtedly it was his enthusiasm for fashion that got him the gig.

FINE--Dr. Harold J.,83, died February 20, 2009, at Chestnut Hill Hospital, PA. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Elsa Honig Fine, devoted daughters Erika Fine of Boston and Amy Fine Collins of NYC, son-in-law Bradley Collins and granddaughter Flora Collins, as well as many nieces and nephews. A psychologist and psychoanalyst, he was a mentor to generations of students as director of clinical training at the University of Tennessee. A clinician devoted to his patients and an author of more than 100 scholarly articles, he helped introduce object relations theory to the United States. With his encyclopedic knowledge, he was everybody's "answer man". He enjoyed jazz, politics, poetry, cars and British tweeds, but his main delight was always his family. He was an adored and doting father. We love him profoundly and miss him deeply. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Harold J. Fine's memory to the GBS/CIDP Foundation, 104 1/2 Forrest Ave., Narberth, PA 19072.

The way stocks skidded, perhaps it was a relief that this was just a four-day trading week. After taking the Presidents' Day holiday off on Monday, the markets got off to a rocky start on Tuesday, when global economic worries pulled stocks lower, and it was mostly downhill from there. A $75 billion plan to aid homeowners barely nudged stocks upward on Wednesday. Thursday and Friday brought steeper declines. Financial stocks were especially battered; Bank of America and Citigroup shares plunged by a third as investors feared that growing losses could lead to government takeovers of troubled banks. At midday Friday, shares in Citi and Bank of America were off almost 50 percent on the week, rising a bit after the Obama administration signaled Friday afternoon that it wanted to avoid nationalizing banks.

OLSON--David Chalmers, died on February 15 of heart failure after a long illness. He was 56 years old. A respected investment banker, David worked for Smith Barney, Credit Suisse/First Boston, and West Merchant Bank. In 1998, he co-founded de Visscher, Olson & Allen to assist private businesses with capital needs. Most recently, he was President of Cantab Advisors, also in family business advisory. He was born on June 11, 1952 in New York City to Jean Stewart Olson and James C. Olson. His father was an early partner of Booz Allen & Hamilton. He went to St. Bernard's School in New York and graduated cum laude from Deerfield Academy, in Deerfield MA in 1970, where he later served as a Trustee. He earned his BA cum laude from Harvard in 1974 and his MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1978. David is survived by his wife, Tara Nicholson Olson, his two daughters, Morgan and Meredith Olson, his brother James S. Olson, his sister Julia Olson Luckenbill, and loving nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, February 24th at 11am at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and 91st Street in New York City. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be made to Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA 01342.

OUTPOSTS Wallace Stegner, the writer who would have turned 100 on Wednesday, has aged well -- everywhere, perhaps, but Manhattan and Stanford, the cradle of the creative writing program he started. For starters, there are rivers undammed, desert vistas unspoiled and forests uncut in the wondrous West because of his pen. He influenced presidents from Kennedy to Clinton to see that ''something will have gone out of us as a people if we ever let the remaining wilderness be destroyed,'' as he wrote. All over the West, Stegner centers, Stegner prizes and Stegner scholars produce work that follows his life theme: an attempt to get Westerners to make peace with their surroundings. His prose was never Hallmark, and he was often blunt.

HIGGINS--Elysabeth Cochran Barbour, known as "Lys," died on Thursday, February 19 at her home following a long illness. She will be remembered for her love of language, her compassion towards animals and her generosity towards her friends. She was the widow of James Henry Higgins II, former chairman of Mellon Bank, NA. Born in New York City on September 7, 1922, she was the daughter of Elysabeth Carrere Barbour Welsh whose uncle was the architect John Carrere of Carrere & Hastings, designers of The New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at 42nd St. Her father was Senator William Warren Barbour from New Jersey who, as a passionate supporter of racial and religious non-discrimination, introduced early anti-lynching legislation and was honored for promoting US aid and refuge to Jewish victims of the holocaust during World War II. A graduate of Westover School and Sarah Lawrence College, Lys served on the Board of Westover School, the New England Historic Genealogical Society, and The Sewickley Historical Society. She was a professional breeder of champion Pembroke Welsh Corgis under kennel name Hilden and was on the board of the American Kennel Club. As a philanthropist, Lys supported wildlife and environmental preservation, education and the arts. Lys is survived by her brother , Warren Barbour of Bronxville, NY, her three children; Elysabeth H. Miller of New York City, James H. Higgins III of Morristown, New Jersey, and Hilary B.H. Parker of Woodberry Forest, Virginia. She is also survived by three grandchildren James H.B. Higgins, Palmer R. Higgins, and T. Warren Parker. A funeral service will be held at The Presbyterian Church of Sewickley on Sunday, February 22 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers friends are asked to donate to Westover School, PO Box 847, Middlebury, CT 06762 or to the World Wildlife Fund (www.worldwildwife.org - click on donate, then memorial donations.)

GATES--Philomene Asher, 90, of New York City and Westhampton Beach, died suddenly February 17, 2009. Born and raised in Florida, Phil graduated from Florida State University and from George Washington University Law School. Phil was the beloved wife of the late Samuel E. Gates and adored mother of Gilda Gates Wray, Sharon Gates Stearns and Kathe Gates Williamson. She was "Goggi", the "electric grandmother" to eight grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. Phil was an accomplished attorney, author and valued community leader. She was Chairman of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York and served on the Boards of the New York Infirmary Beekman Downtown and Southampton Hospitals, The Florida State University Foundation, the Legal Aid Society, Grosvenor Neighborhood House, Les Amis de Blerancourt and numerous other community organizations. Phil was an ebullient presence, always there for those who needed her providing love and wisdom. She loved books, dancing, travel and above all, friends and family. She leaves a big hole in our lives. Memorial service to be announced later. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Philomene Gates Award for Excellence in Communications at the FSU Foundation, 2010 Levy Ave, Bldg B Ste 300, P.O. Box 3062739, Tallahassee, FL 32306-2739 or to one of the organizations listed above on whose Board she served.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended Feb. 7, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount and department stores; and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics; and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Obviously I've been touched and grateful. Beyond that, I don't really plan to go away soon. SENATOR EDWARD M. KENNEDY, on the many tributes he has received since his brain cancer diagnosis. [18]

KENYON--Neal, on December 19, at age 79 after a 2007 stroke. A dancer, singer, director and choreographer for 40 years, he later taught at Florida State University. Cherished for dry wit and Southern charm, he won a 1968 Drama Desk award for "Dames at Sea", which introduced Bernadette Peters. Donations may be made to Broadway Cares or FSU's School of Theatre. 107 S. Wildwood Drive, Tallahassee, FL 32304.

SCHWARZ - Rhoda, of New York and Chicago on February 19. Daughter of Sadye Rieger, beloved wife of the late Mickey Schwarz, mother of Ronald, Barbara, William and Joan, grandmother of Josh, Sam, Anna and Nate, great-grandmother of Vail.

ON May 1, 2007, a very different economic era, Janet Faello put her former marital home on the market for $829,000. She and her husband were divorcing. It seemed like a good price for the house, a six-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath ranch in Dix Hills, in Suffolk County on Long Island. But it didn't sell at that price, or at $750,000, where it landed six months later, or at $699,000, where it stands now.

LIKE many other young suburban families, Pamela and Daniel Greenhall of Aberdeen Township have outgrown their first house. It's a classic ''starter home,'' with three bedrooms and one bath. Last year, when the Greenhalls learned they were expecting a third child, they put the ranch-style house on the market for $279,000. That's when the waiting began.

SHANLEY--John, 65, Footwear and Retail Research Analyst, Susquehanna International Group passed away on February 15, 2009, after battling with bladder cancer for more than four years. During his tenure at Susquehanna International Group, he was recognized by the Wall Street Journal in its annual "Best on the Street" awards in 2004, 2005 and 2007. Prior to joining Susquehanna in 2004, John served as managing director and senior analyst at Wells Fargo Securities, LLC, and managing director at JW Genesis Capital Markets, LLC, in New York. John was the Director of Research and Strategic Planning at The Woolworth Corporation (now Foot Locker, Inc.) and held a similar position at Allied Stores Corporation (now Federated Department Stores) in the past. He was also a member of the Board of Directors for The Retail Marketing Society. He is survived by his wife Patricia; son, Joshua and his fiance, Kristen Johnson; son, Christopher and his wife Jennifer; grandchildren, Dylan John, 12, and Madeline, nine; sisters, Jeanne Comerford and Joan Shanley. John was an avid gardener, sailor and antiques collector, and supporter of the United Way, Soles4Sole, and the Manhattan Rose Society. John was laid to rest on February 19 at the Locust Valley Reform Church. In lieu of flowers, his family requests that donations be made to the American Cancer Society, In Memory of John Shanley, 3893 Adler Place, Bethlehem, PA 18017.
Fathers appear to be playing a bigger role in their daughters’ career choices compared to men of previous generations.
My Well column in Tuesday’s Science Times focuses on the benefits of recess, physical activity and nature in improving a child’s academic life.

He may have been snubbed by the Oscars, but Bruce Springsteen can nonetheless take comfort this summer in the arms of thousands of mud-caked British concertgoers: he has been named one of the headliners of the Glastonbury Festival, the event’s promoters announced on its Web page, www.glastonburyfestivals.co.uk. Mr. Springsteen, whose title track from the Darren Aronofsky film “The Wrestler” wasn’t even nominated in the Academy Awards’ best song category, will receive top billing at the festival on June 27; the full festival runs from June 24 through 28 in England’s Somerset County. Though Glastonbury has traditionally been a showcase for homegrown rock bands like Oasis, Coldplay and Radiohead, the festival has gradually expanded its boundaries; its Saturday night headliner in 2008 was Jay-Z. For stateside fans, Mr. Springsteen will also be appearing at the Bonnaroo festival, which runs from June 11 to 14 in Manchester, Tenn.

The Las Vegas Art Museum has joined the growing roster of cultural institutions that have suspended their operations in the face of a weakening economy; it will close on Saturday, The Las Vegas Sun reported. The museum, which since 1997 has operated from the city’s Sahara West Library, lost its executive director, Libby Lumpkin, in December; she resigned when the museum’s board said that its budget cuts would result in reduced salaries and possible layoffs. Under her tenure the museum has featured exhibitions on Frank Gehry and the Southern California artists Robert Irwin, John McCracken and James Turrell. But the president of the museum’s board, Patrick Duffy, said the museum had seen a substantial decrease in donations amid the financial downturn. “We’ve tried everything to keep this afloat,” Mr. Duffy said, according to The Sun. “It’s just a challenging time.”

Could I throw a couple of glasses of cold water — not as much as a bucket, just a few handfuls, really — on all the euphoria about the new Alice Tully Hall? My problems with it aren’t major, and they’re not particularly musical: it sounds good, and the theater itself is beautiful to behold. But the reopening is being treated as if it were the arrival of another millennium, and I think people are getting carried away.

Neither T-Pain nor his trademark top hat nor his Vocoder device will be at a concert in Guyana after he was threatened with kidnapping or death, The Associated Press reported. T-Pain, the Florida-born hip-hop and R&B performer whose real name is Faheem Najm, was scheduled to perform a concert in that South American nation on Monday night as part of its Mashramani festival, which celebrates Guyana’s independence from the United Kingdom. But the show’s promoter canceled the event after receiving what he said were “credible death and kidnapping threats” against T-Pain via e-mail messages and telephone calls. A police commander for the area told The A.P. that the local authorities were investigating.

This singing competition is too venerable to be called “Metropolitan Idol,” but the consequences for young careers are just as great as with “American Idol”: On Sunday, four winners of the National Council Auditions, sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera, were announced after the final performance round with the Met orchestra. They are Paul Appleby, 25, of South Bend, Ind., a tenor; Anthony Roth Costanzo, 26, of Durham, N.C., a countertenor; Sung Eun Lee, 30, of Seoul, South Korea, a tenor; and Nadine Sierra, 20, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a soprano. Each received $15,000; the four other finalists received $5,000. They were Noah A. Baetge of Seattle; Kiri Dyan Deonarine of Fair Lawn, N.J.; Jessica Julin of Danville, Calif.; and Sarah Mesko of Hot Springs, Ark. Nearly 1,800 young singers entered the competition. Previous honorees include Renée Fleming, Deborah Voigt, Ben Heppner and Samuel Ramey. A first-place finish often leads to selection for the Met’s Lindemann Young Artist Development Program.

The grieving process for The New Group’s production of “Mourning Becomes Electra” will be a brief one. The revival of the Eugene O’Neill drama at the Acorn Theater has moved up the closing date for its limited run by six weeks, a publicist for the show said. The play will now close on Sunday; it was originally scheduled to run through April 18. No reason for the early closing was given, but the play, a 4-hour-10-minute restaging of the “Oresteia” in 19th-century New England, had not been well reviewed, despite a cast that included Lili Taylor and Jena Malone. “Electra,” which first opened in New York at the Guild Theater in 1931, was last revived on Broadway in 1972 with a cast including Colleen Dewhurst and Pamela Payton-Wright. That production played 55 performances.

It’s not confidential: the rock quartet the Killers has filed suit against its former manager Braden Merrick, in response to a 2006 suit that Mr. Merrick filed against the band, Billboard reported. In his claim against the Killers, whose albums include “Hot Fuss” and “Day & Age,” Mr. Merrick said that he had been fired by the group without legal justification and that it owed him royalties from a producing agreement. In its suit against Mr. Merrick, filed Friday in federal court in Las Vegas, the band claims breach of contract, breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment. In a statement, the Killers said that Mr. Merrick’s handling of the group reflected “a pattern of indifference, unavailability, unresponsiveness, and dishonesty” and that his actions resulted in “multi-million-dollar damages in missed concerts and lost touring revenues.”

In response to the global economic crisis, James R. Houghton, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, posted a letter on the institution’s Web site on Friday announcing that the Met had decided to close 15 of its satellite shops around the country. A year ago the Met ran a total of 23 stores but over the last year it has quietly closed 8, including three in California and one at the South Street Seaport Museum in lower Manhattan. It now plans to close an additional seven, and will instead concentrate on its online shop and has recently redesigned its mail order catalog. Mr. Houghton also said that the museum had imposed a hiring freeze and is curtailing staff travel and entertainment as well as the use of temporary employees. It is also in the process of a museum-wide assessment of its expenses to see how it can further reduce costs. Emily Rafferty, the Met’s president, said Monday that “we cannot eliminate the possibility of a head-count reduction.” The museum’s endowment, which provides about 30 percent of its annual operating revenue, has decreased 25 percent since June 30, 2008 to $2.1 billion from $2.8 billion. Membership and attendance is down too, in large part because of falling tourism.

As the Hollywood gossip Web site Defamer.com prepared to cover the Academy Awards on Sunday, its owner, Gawker Media, announced that the site would be folded into its flagship blog, Gawker.com. Defamer, which jabbed at celebrities and industry executives, will become Gawker.com’s entertainment column. Its editor, Seth Abramovitch, and key writers are leaving the company this week. In December, the Gawker founder and president, Nick Denton, said he was in talks to sell Defamer, but those talks fell through, Mr. Abramovitch said. “There are so many other blogs covering what we’d cover,” Mr. Abramovitch noted. Gawker Media has been reorganizing lately, folding the Silicon Valley gossip blog Valleywag into Gawker.com, and selling the sites Consumerist, Wonkette and Gridskipper. In an email message, Mr. Denton wrote, “Gawker is a national title now — and the inclusion of Defamer underlines that our flagship gossip site is as much at home in Hollywood as it is in New York.”

In a red carpet interview before the Oscars on Sunday, the actress Evan Rachel Wood said that she was “definitely going to do” the upcoming Broadway musical “Spider-Man,” which Julie Taymor (“The Lion King”) is on tap to direct for an opening in the 2009-10 season.

Ken Bloom and Frank Vlastnik, authors of the newly revised “Broadway Musicals: The 101 Greatest Shows of All Time,” answered readers’ questions about Broadway seasons past, present and future. Here they discuss the Broadway of today: the economics, the talent and the audience.
It seems fair to say that more than a few Oscar-watchers were caught off-guard by the surprise victory of “Departures” in the foreign-language film category at Sunday’s Academy Awards.

For a second week in a row, the comedian Will Ferrell’s Broadway show, “You’re Welcome America. A Final Night With George W Bush,” has broken the house record at the Cort Theater. The parody of President Bush and his administration, led by Mr. Ferrell as the Bush character he popularized on “Saturday Night Live,” grossed $871,127 for the week ending Feb. 22 -­ an increase of $24,620 over the previous week. The show is scheduled to close on March 15.

The Metropolitan Opera said that Katie Van Kooten will replace Angela Gheorghiu in the role of Magda in Monday evening’s performance of Puccini’s “La Rondine.” In a statement, the Met said that Ms. Gheorghiu is ill. Ms. Van Kooten, who has previously sung the role of Magda at the Royal Opera in London, will be making her debut at the Met in this performance; for the Royal Opera, she has also sung the roles of Pamina in “Die Zauberflöte,” Mimì in “La Bohème,” Marguerite in “Faust” and Antonia in “Les Contes d’Hoffmann.”
“Slumdog Millionaire” won eight Oscars, including the prize for best picture, at the 81st annual Academy Awards on Sunday.
Stars and designers made a statement on the red carpet at the 81st Academy Awards show.
“Slumdog Millionaire” dominated the 81st annual Academy Awards at the Kodak Theater in Hollywood, Calif.
The movie “Slumdog Millionaire” and the actors Sean Penn and Kate Winslet were the big winners at the 2009 Academy Awards.
As the price of gold nears $1,000 per ounce, demand is strong. In Congo, workers mine gold by hand from open pits.
The needs of Iraq's estimated 740,000 war widows now exceed available help, posing a threat to the stability of the country's tenuous social structures.

The Swedish Elitserien offers all the drama of a European soccer league -- that is, there's the race for first over all; the battle to finish high in the league to qualify for post-season action; the struggle to avoid relegation by finishing too low; and the relief of ending up more or less in the middle, where at least you don't have to worry about being subjected to the extended anxiety of the relegation tournament.
Mark Leon Goldberg, left, of UN Dispatch and Kevin Jon Heller of the University of Melbourne Law School debate the International Criminal Court's focus on Africa.

Did you notice that this puzzle isn't square? It has 15 rows, but it had to go to 16 columns to fit the central theme answer. That alone probably makes it harder to fit into the newspaper space, but on top of that, it also has 81 "words" or answers, and that's a lot. Only six daily puzzles in my database have more. I'm guessing all that combines to explain why most of the clues are short. That count of 81 words is not only large, but it's also unusual because it's an odd number. If you like math, you might enjoy coming up with a proof of why standard puzzles have even word counts.

I felt so fortunate to attend a special presentation the other night: William Stout, owner of the eponymous architecture and design bookstore in San Francisco, had been invited to talk about his favorite books at Linden Tree, a casual salon of sorts that aims to foster the design community in the city.
Morgan Stanley's chief executive, John J. Mack, said Monday that his firm would face new regulatory restrictions on some of its businesses since it is now a bank holding company.
The museum whose looting in 2003 became a symbol of the chaos that followed the American invasion officially reopened on Monday.

What kind of advice should scientists give to politicians? I take up that question in my Findings column about Roger Pielke Jr.'s book, "The Honest Broker: Making Sense of Science in Policy and Politics," which argues that too many scientists stealthily pass off their own political views as incontestable scientific truths. As a result, they're tempted to try to win political debates by hyping their own expertise and denigrating their opponents as "unscientific."

Many designers this season showed belted jackets and dresses, often with a mannish leather belt. So the waist is a point of focus for fall. At least two designers, Chris Benz and Vera Wang, showed a high-belted jacket. That 's a different silhouette, whether with a slim skirt or pants.

The Rangers announced Monday evening that they have hired John Tortorella, a one-time Rangers assistant and the fiery former Tampa Bay coach whose seven-year tenure there included a Stanley Cup championship in 2004, to take over from Tom Renney, whom the Rangers fired earlier in the day.
A real-life tale of high-tech Facebook happiness, from reader Debby Joseph:

MSNBC has posted a number of video reports from Nick's recent trip to the Chad-Sudan border near Darfur, where he traveled with NBC journalist Ann Curry and actor George Clooney. You can watch them by following this link (viewing with Explorer seems to work best). You'll have to put up with a commercial at the beginning, but the web-only video diary by Mr. Clooney -- who juggles the roles of Hollywood heartthrob, Darfur advocate and Nick's roommate -- are worth it. In counterpoint to the somber topic of Darfur itself, he makes off-the-cuff jokes, horses around with the refugee kids and pursues his own journalistic ambitions by reporting on Nick in the shower. The bonus prize for Nick's Pulitzers? "To shack up with a two-time Sexiest Man Alive."

Hilco Merchant Resources and Gordon Brothers have withdrawn their bid to run the liquidation of Fortunoff, the bankrupt luxury goods store, a person briefed on the process told DealBook Monday evening.
The credit crisis seems to be permeating every nook and cranny of the world economy -- including the business of sports.

While this was a weekend to honor returning heroes in New York, it looks as if the Devils' franchise goalie will be returning to action this week. Heroes also returned in Toronto and Montreal, and a young rivalry that once seemed manufactured has re-emerged as the real deal.

Last week, we had a wave of panic roll through Facebook users as many realized that the site had changed its terms of service in a way that implied it might soon broadcast their most embarrassing photographs to parents, teachers, and prospective employers.

If the general mood during New York fashion week left everyone secretly wishing that the free supply of Smart Water had only been laced with Xanax, London fashion week, by comparison, is an almost cheery affair. At nearly every presentation, tea and sympathy abound.

Senator John McCain took his seat at the White House on Monday and listened to a briefing from one of his economic advisers. The only hitch is Mr. McCain was sitting in the sixth row, not on stage, and the adviser was now working for President Obama.
How does a digital recorder work? If I get one, can it automatically transcribe the audio files into text?
A. O. Scott reviews William Wyler's epic, 50 years after it won the Academy Award for best picture.
For some months now, my Mac Pro has refused to chime -- to make that unmistakable bong sound only Apple computers make. What's happened?

Updated, 9:51 p.m. | Special elections will be conducted on Tuesday in three City Council districts in Queens and on Staten Island to fill three seats vacated by successful candidates who won other offices in the November election. Polls will be open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Candidates will serve out the remainder of the terms through December 31, 2009.None of the candidates are running under the aegis of established party labels, because the City Charter says that in a special election for municipal office, the candidates may not use any of the names of designated parties that have received more than 50,000 votes in gubernatorial elections. These forbidden party designations include: Democratic, Republican, Independence, Conservative, and Working Families.
It's hard to believe that Microsoft's Windows 7 is still a prototype system; the software giant has taken off both gloves to convince users of the beta that Windows 7 is to be taken very seriously.

The lenses just keep getting wider. Samsung announced on Monday two new 12-megapixel cameras with 24mm ultra-wide-angle lenses, beating the 25mm lens model that Panasonic announced last month. The high-end Samsung TL320 offers a 5X optical zoom and a new type of LCD that is brighter and consumes less power, while the Samsung HZ15W has a 10X optical zoom and mechanical image stabilization.

The stock market has given the Obama team's rescue efforts a Bronx cheer. Today the S.& P. 500 joined the Dow in closing below the lows reached on Nov. 20. It has been more than a decade since those indexes were valued as low as they are now.

JPMorgan Chase slashed its quarterly dividend on Monday afternoon to 5 cents a share from 38 cents, an 87 percent reduction, and the bank said it expected to maintain that dividend "for the time being."

Latin America | Latin America has become more gay-friendly, an article says, as gays have won rights from the region's more globalized, open regimes, and thrive in the more cosmopolitan cities. Chile, Ecuador, Mexico, Brazil, Uruguay and Nicaragua have all liberalized one way or another since the late 1990's. (On the transgender front, Cuba allows free sex-change operations for qualifying citizens.) Buenos Aires illustrates the trend, as the Times and now the Economist have reported. [Foreign Policy, Economist]

An amusing video (or maddening, depending on your feelings about Duke) that highlights the happy feet of the Blue Devils' Elliot Williams in a victory over Wake Forest on Sunday. (We found the video on The Big Lead).

If your neighbor swiped your New York Times this weekend, you missed T's jam-packed women's spring fashion issue. Luckily, we've put it all online - and more. Over the next few days we'll be spotlighting exclusive Web videos, photo spreads and interactive features available at the digital home of T Magazine. Today, we're featuring the magazine's "Screen Test" video interview of Rosario Dawson by Lynn Hirschberg. If you like what you see, there are 25 more "Screen Tests" where that came from.

After "Slumdog Millionaire"'s victory last night (Jai Ho!), there's never been a more fitting time to show one of the world's most dynamic cities some love. (If you're unconvinced of why you might want to, check out T's story from Fall 2007.) When I was in Mumbai recently, I found this supersoft T-shirt at the boutique Bombay Electric, a fashion-crowd favorite behind the Taj Mahal Palace and Tower. The shirts arrived at the shop just a few days after the terrorist attacks in November, so the owners decided to donate all the profits from them to a fund that helps victims of the attacks. They're a huge hit in the shop, and they're also available online, in black or white, for $19.

The best part of poker - I say as someone who doesn't play - are the bad-beat stories. Not because I can follow the ins and outs of why the hero who should have won lost to the villain who shouldn't have even been allowed at the table, but because it's amazing to hear someone recount in so much detail and poker lingo exactly how fate cheated them. And how it was cheating, plain and simple.

President Obama has settled on former Gov. Gary Locke of Washington state as his top choice for commerce secretary, as he tries for a third time to fill a cabinet position that has bedeviled his administration, a White House official said Monday.
Just a few days ago, transit officials were talking about the high bus and subway ridership figures from 2008.
Ontario, Canada's most populous province and the region most severely affected by declining exports to the United States, introduced a sweeping package of energy related legislation on Monday.
One of the joys of the government's efforts to deal with the current crisis is that they keep changing the rules.

The author of "The Black Swan," Nassim Nicholas Taleb, predicts that the global financial crisis will be harder to end than the Great Depression and it may force the United States government to nationalize some banks.

During the stimulus debate, President Obama made several overtures to the Republicans, hoping to bring them on board with his plan, to little avail. Not one House Republican voted for the package, and only three moderate Republicans voted with the Democrats in the Senate.

In 2001, when the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change produced its third set of reports examining the causes and consequences of global warming, it included a fascinating illustration, called the "burning embers" diagram, showing gradients of rising risk with rising temperatures. It was part of the panel's evolving effort to provide policymakers with a clear sense of what was known about potential impacts from various levels of warming and also what was uncertain.
Two more senators added their voice to a chorus of lawmakers and governors who have a response to stimulus naysayers: If you don't want the money, we'll be happy to take it off your hands.
February 23, 2009:  John Harwood and The New York Times correspondents discuss the political battle over President Obama's stimulus plan.

Update | 5:52 p.m. The American International Group, the battered insurance giant that is now effectively majority-owned by the federal government, is in talks to receive more government aid as it prepares to record another giant loss, a person briefed on the talks told DealBook.
Helen Hunt directs an ad for True North, a maker of snack foods, that profiles Inspiration Café, a Chicago restaurant dedicated to serving homeless residents with dignity.

A secret task force of 70 United States soldiers has been helping Pakistan battle Al Qaeda and the Taliban by training commandos and sharing intelligence, officials said. Its efforts have begun to pay big dividends.

A number of fall collections in New York were noteworthy for their specific palette. L'Wren Scott used deep forest green and red, with glints of plum, kelly, chartreuse, dark teal, and ruby amid the black. Sophie Theallet's palette included rusty orange, red, browns and a gray sky blue. Ralph Lauren combined antique shades of cream, silver and woodsy brown with touches lavender. He made a statement with all those double creams.
Citing a strong economy, a "favorable tax regime" and thriving offshore banking businesses, Property Frontiers tabs Panama as its top "hot spot" for 2009.
TARP investments are certainly "troubled." And Washington, it turns out, isn't the best short-term investor.
A new ad for Apple promotes the company's efforts to minimize the environmental impact of its products.

Last month the BBC children's channel, Cbeebies, hired a brand new team of hosts. Cerrie Burnell and her partner Alex Winters are now greeting toddlers in the morning and reading them storybooks every night. Cerrie, an actress and special-needs teaching assistant, was born with only one fully formed arm. The disability is clear on the show, and it is just as clearly making some parents uncomfortable.

For every issue of T, the magazine's art directors commission a contemporary artist or designer to create a distinctive "T." Their work is then used to open the feature well -- that part of the magazine uninterrupted by advertisements. Given only the most general guidelines about the issue's theme (for Women's Fashion Spring 2009, for example, the artists were told that Africa was a dominant trend), the artists are free to produce an original piece that hews to both their own aesthetic and the overarching feel of the season.
The oil-rich emirate of Abu Dhabi may be set to take over where Dubai, its far more glamorous sister state down the the coast, has left off.

The parties and the event itself were plenty fun on Sunday, but as folks who followed along at home know, the Bagger did not have a good night when it came to the Oscar ballot. He got off to a lousy start, blowing the first two awards (damn that Penelope Cruz). And while he stormed back, taking 12 of the next 13 categories, the end game did him in (damn that Sean Penn and "Departures").

The great Sundance beer bottle case is closed, a city attorney for Park City, Utah, said today. Back on Jan. 16, Erik Cooper, a Sundance Film Festival volunteer,was beaned with a half empty bottle of Miller Lite, just as a couple of figures ran past and one, he said, yelled an anti-gay slur. The police ticketed the man for littering. Mr. Cooper objected, and suggested an assault charge was in order.

After years of denying accusations that it's given to frittering, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation acknowledged on Monday that it has begun twittering. The agency invited the public to follow it on Twitter, the microblogging service.

History | Once again, lessons for our own times are being found in the decline of the Roman Empire, a review says, but two new books can't agree on what they are. One cites "increasing and obsessive bureaucratization" of the government and the "self-interest" of political leaders. The other faults Justinian's "unwillingness to negotiate with Persia (that is, modern Iran), an inability to secure peace in the Balkans and a reluctance to tolerate religious diversity in his empire." Hey, maybe they're both right. [Times of London]

ABC's live broadcast Sunday of the 81st Annual Academy Awards was up appreciably in the ratings over last year's telecast, the least watched Oscars on record.

The Rangers' firing of coach Tom Renney on Monday came as absolutely no surprise. As is often the case with coach firings, he ended up taking the fall for problems that hardly started or end with him, but when a team is in total freefall like the Rangers are, management has to do something or risk sending fans the message that they don't care. General manager Glen Sather chose to fire Renney. He was not going to fire himself.

In 1984, I was all set to buy my first computer: a Kaypro 4. It came complete with Wordstar, dBase II, MicroPlan, Microsoft Basic, S-Basic, SuperCalc, and the CP/M operating system.

Like most specialty retailers, Gap had a tumultuous 2008 and a terrible January, exacerbated by enduring weakness in its namesake chain of apparel stores. The company's shares have lost more than a third of their value over the last year, and Motley Fool, the investment advice site, just called the clothing retailer a "deathbed stock."

On Jan. 1, Ivan Gazidis planted himself behind a desk at Arsenal's plush Emirates Stadium in north London, and a bit of culture shock splashed him in the face like a stream of bracing after-shave lotion.

A group of Latin American leaders have called on President Obama to rethink America's campaign against illegal drugs, which they blame for helping to foment crime, corruption and political instability in Latin America while failing to reduce the availability of drugs in America. The criticism appears in a report from the Latin American Commission on Drugs and Democracy.

Despite the huge sums the federal government is spending to aid banks and stimulate the economy, President Obama said on Monday that his administration will slash the federal budget deficit, in part by ending the "casual dishonesty" that has accompanied Washington budgets of late.

Andrews reports from Washington.

Last week, the Iranian state-run broadcaster Press TV reported that seven Iranian followers of the minority Bahai faith, who were arrested last year, will be tried in Tehran as soon as this week on charges of "espionage for Israel, desecrating religious sanctities and propaganda against the Islamic Republic." If convicted, the five men and two women could be sentenced to death.

Academics just can't let go of "The Sopranos." University presses have published a variety of books about the finest television series ever, and now Duke University Press is bringing out "The Sopranos," by Dana Polan, a professor of cinema studies at N.Y.U.

Felix Rohatyn, the veteran financier credited with saving New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s, believes the Unites States government should think bigger if it wants to dig the country out of its current economic hole -- even if it means creating a new government-led bank.

If you have a hard time remembering to change the scene setting on your camera, soon you won't have to. Camera makers are starting to announce new models for next week's PMA show in Las Vegas, and it looks as if intelligent auto mode is becoming smarter in many point-and-shoots.

Barry Ritholtz at The Big Picture has compiled a list of economists, politicians and other interested parties who have come out for or against temporary bank nationalization. There are some heavy hitters on both sides.

Merrill Lynch's former chief executive, John A. Thain, was questioned by the New York State Attorney General's Office last week. In a six-hour session, Mr. Thain answered wide-ranging questions about the bonuses he paid Merrill employees and about his interactions with officials at Bank of America, which acquired Merrill at the end of the year.

Did you see Jim Calhoun's outburst on ESPN the other night? It came during a news conference after a University of Connecticut men's basketball game, when the Connecticut coach was asked what strikes me as a perfectly fair question -- though admittedly not the kind basketball coaches usually face.

Shaking up the national and Big 12 rankings, Texas knocked off No. 2 Oklahoma on Saturday after Blake Griffin sustained a concussion in the first half. As of Sunday night, Griffin's status was uncertain for a Big Monday matchup with No. 15 Kansas. The Sooners and the Jayhawks are both 11-1 in the league, and Monday's battle for Big 12 supremacy is only the beginning of a decisive week in the conference.

A federal prosecutor said Monday that two psychiatrists who have examined Aafia Siddiqui, a Pakistani neuroscientist charged with trying to kill an American soldier and F.B.I. agents while in custody in Afghanistan, said she was not suffering from psychological illness that would render her unfit for trial. That assessment was in contrast to a previous evaluation of Ms. Siddiqui's fitness.

Former Vice President Al Gore is pulling a dramatic slide from his ever-evolving global warming presentation. When Mr. Gore addressed a packed, cheering hall at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science in Chicago earlier this month, his climate slide show contained a startling graph showing a ceiling-high spike in disasters in recent years. The data came from the Center for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters (also called CRED) at the Catholic University of Louvain in Brussels.

Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week is long over and by now the critics are soaking their feet, but some of their biggest reviews are just now hitting newsstands. Today Scorecard tallies the votes for the last round of New York shows: Calvin Klein, Chado Ralph Rucci, Isaac Mizrahi, Ralph Lauren, L'Wren Scott,Tommy Hilfiger, Vera Wang and Zac Posen. In October, the Utility Player tracked down homeowners who signed contracts for delivery of home heating oil during the summer, when prices peaked. By the time they turned on their furnaces, though, fuel costs had plummeted, leaving customers fuming because they were paying far more than market rates.Other homeowners pulled out their furnaces and paid up to $10,000 to install natural gas systems. Because natural gas is delivered continually, consumers do not need to sign contracts that lock in set rates. Newer natural gas boilers also require less maintenance, burn fuel more efficiently than oil furnaces and often take up less space.

Music | Far from epitomizing musical fakery, video games like Rock Band and Guitar Hero foster actual music creation, an article suggests. "You learn about time, you learn about what the parts are," a company executive says. "There's this natural, intuitive knowledge about how songs are composed and arranged that the game totally gives you. My guess is that in five years' time there'll be an explosion of garage bands." [Atlantic]

Politics | Those who see our crisis as simply economic and political are missing the point, Matthew Continetti writes. It's part of a broader societal blight of irresponsibility festering for years, in which "it seems as though every figure who waltzes across the public stage is a cheat, a fraud, a liar, or a failure." Obama seems to grasp the problem, but not what to do about it. "Increased dependence on the state is not a solution to our lack of personal accountability. It will only encourage more of it." Last Wednesday, the Obama administration announced the appointment of Adolfo Carrión Jr., the Bronx borough president, to be the White House's urban affairs chief. On Sunday, the Bronx County Democratic Party stoked the race to replace Mr. Carrión by announcing its endorsement of Assemblyman Rubén Díaz Jr., who will most likely face another well-known Latino political figure in a special election this spring: City Councilman Joel Rivera.The official story is that the party came to its decision at a meeting on Saturday, when numerous Bronx politicians and Democratic operatives voiced their preference for Assemblyman Díaz, who had honored the audience with his presence. Councilman Rivera was invited, but did not attend the event, a party spokesman said.

Nascar: One week after winning the Daytona 500 with the help of a little luck and a lot of rain, Matt Kenseth had to fight Jeff Gordon for the final 38 laps (out of 250) to win the Auto Club 500 in Fontana, Calif. Kenseth was third going into the final pit stop behind Gordon and Greg Biffle, but Kenseth beat the other two back on the track. "The crew got me clean air out front both times, and that's a huge difference," said Kenseth, who is only the second driver since 1977 to win the first two races. Gordon did it in 1997.

"Slumdog Millionaire" nearly ran the table and then filled the stage with a huge group of folks who were part of making the movie. "Jai Ho" indeed. Some surprises indeed, with "Departures" trumping "The Class" and "Waltz with Bashir" in best foreign language film. The rest of the show went according to plan - every plan but the Bagger's - who got killed when Sean Penn won over Mickey Rourke in best actor and Penelope Cruz beat out Viola Davis, one of the the Bagger's longer bets. The show itself was an odd hybrid of dinner theater on steroids and then a huge infusion of global energy from "Slumdog." It was sort of all over the road - there were any numbers of languages being spoken back in the press room - but charming in its own way.
