One of the key insights in Keynes's General Theory -- actually, THE key insight -- was that the loanable funds theory of the interest rate was incomplete. Loanable funds says that the interest rate is determined by the supply of and demand for saving; Keynes pointed out that the supply of saving is endogenous, depending on the level of output. He even illustrated the point with a remarkably ugly diagram (scroll down a bit). Hicks later made things clearer with the concept of the "IS curve", which shows how the equilibrium interest rate from loanable funds varies with the level of GDP.

Economy | Surprise: Even as the economy tanked and shed jobs last year, workers' average hourly pay went up. Reasons, according to James Surowiecki: Wages are traditionally "sticky," since it's important to maintain morale and keep the most productive workers. But what's new is that employers can better afford such workers. In the "just-in-time" economy, companies get more bang for the labor buck by cutting jobs in a timely way, as efficiently as they calibrate supply orders. [New Yorker]

Bode Miller holds the United States men’s record with 31 wins.

On Saturday, a day before the Academy Awards, the national board of directors of the Screen Actors Guild rejected what studios termed a “last, best and final offer” in the negotiations between the actors’ union and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents the studios. (Below, a SAG protester at the Kodak Theater, scene of the Oscars.) Last week the two sides seemed close to an agreement, but the latest offer from the producers included what SAG called a “surprise demand.” The rub lies not so much in the terms of the contract as in its timing. The actors’ union is seeking a three-year contract retroactive to June 2008, when its previous agreement expired. That would mean the new contract would expire at the same time as the studios’ agreements with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists and the writers’ and directors’ guilds. Concurrent expiration dates would, of course, allow the unions to join forces in 2011 negotiations. The studios’ latest offer, presented on Feb. 19, proposed that the new agreement begin upon ratification and last for three years. The “demand for a new term of agreement extending to 2012 is regressive and damaging,” the guild said in a statement released on Saturday. The union accused the studios of trying “to deleverage our bargaining position from this point forward.” The producers also released a statement, defending their offer as “strong and fair.”.

After 18 previews and just 5 regular performances “The Story of My Life,” the two-character Broadway musical starring Malcolm Gets and Will Chase, closed after the matinee performance at the Booth Theater on Sunday. The show, about a writer who returns to his hometown to give a eulogy for a lifelong friend, was directed by Richard Maltby Jr. and featured a book by Brian Hill and music and lyrics by Neil Bartram. The reviews were generally weak, and theatergoers were not enthusiastic: for the week ending Feb. 15, it filled 42 percent of the house and 33 percent the previous week, according to the Broadway League.

LittleBigPlanet, below, the quirky and innovative jumping-and-climbing game published by Sony for the company’s PlayStation 3 console, was the top winner Thursday night at the 12th annual Interactive Achievement Awards in Las Vegas, where it took eight awards, including overall game of the year for 2008. The game beat a slate of heavyweight finalists including Fallout 3, Grand Theft Auto IV, Left 4 Dead and Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots. The acclaim for LittleBigPlanet, which was developed by Media Molecule, could provide a modest boost for the PlayStation 3, which has lagged behind its competitors from Microsoft (the Xbox 360) and Nintendo (the Wii). The Interactive Achievement awards are the video game industry’s equivalent to the Oscars. In addition to the overall game award, LittleBigPlanet took honors for console game of the year, game direction, family game of the year, art direction, visual engineering, character performance and outstanding innovation.

At the Spirit Awards for independent film on Saturday, Mickey Rourke won best male lead for his role in “The Wrestler,” and the film was declared best feature. Mr. Rourke’s rambling acceptance speech, full of expletives and a thank you to his recently deceased dog, was a highlight of the event, held in a tent on the beach in Santa Monica, Calif. “Vicky Cristina Barcelona” won a best screenplay award for Woody Allen, and best supporting actress for Penélope Cruz. A full list of nominees and winners is available at spiritawards.com. ... The 29th annual Golden Raspberry Awards were also presented on Saturday. The awards, better known as the Razzies, are presented annually to honor the worst movies and performances. Paris Hilton was the most decorated, taking home the worst actress award for “The Hottie and the Nottie”; the worst supporting actress nod for “Repo: The Genetic Opera”; and even the worst screen couple prize for “The Hottie and the Nottie” — for her appearance either with Christine Lakin or Joel David Moore: take your choice. Mike Myers was a big “winner” too: “The Love Guru” was voted worst picture and Mr. Myers worst actor for his role in it. The full list of losers is at razzies.com.

Jade Goody, 27, the controversial British reality TV star who is terminally ill with cervical cancer, was married to her fiancé, Jack Twist, 21, on Sunday in a ceremony that was covered by the celebrity magazine OK!, which paid more than $1 million for the rights, the BBC reported. Ms. Goody, who became infamous for her boorishness and vulgarity on the British reality show “Big Brother” several years ago, has become more of a media darling of late. She agreed to publicize her illness and impending death in order to make money to leave behind for her two young sons and has drawn expressions of sympathy across Britain.

Crown Publishers, an imprint of Random House, has acquired the North American publishing rights for two forthcoming books by the former secretary of state Condoleezza Rice, right, Crown’s vice president and publisher, Tina Constable, announced on Sunday. The first book, tentatively scheduled for publication in the fall of 2011, will be a memoir of Ms. Rice’s years working in the administration of George W. Bush, first as the national security advisor and later as the secretary of state. The second book will be about her upbringing in Birmingham, Ala., where she was born in 1954, attended a segregated school and grew up against the backdrop of the civil rights movement. Publication of the second book is tentatively scheduled for fall 2012; neither book has a title yet.

DIILLON--Gregory Russell, retired Vice Chairman of Hilton Hotels Corporation Gregory R. Dillon, retired Vice Chairman and Director Emeritus of Hilton Hotels Corporation, died peacefully February 18 at his home in Los Angeles at age 86. A longtime real estate executive and confidant of retired CEO Barron Hilton, Dillon began his career as an attorney for the company's founder, Conrad Hilton. Reflecting his close ties to the family, he has served as a director of the Conrad N. Hilton Foundation since 1994, providing humanitarian aid for the world's needy, regardless of race, religion, or geography. He is survived by his wife, Jenine, three sons, two daughters and seven grandchildren. "Greg Dillon was a consummate professional in law and hotel development, and was a tremendous ambassador for our company," said Barron Hilton. "His warmth and sincerity, and his irrepressible Irish charm, will long be remembered by our family, and by our extended hotel family around the world. He is an irreplaceable friend that I'll sorely miss." A rosary will be held Sunday, March 1st at 5pm at Gates, Kingsley & Gates Funeral Chapel, 1925 Arizona Avenue in Santa Monica. A memorial mass will be celebrated Monday, March 2nd at 11am at St. Paul the Apostle Church, Ohio and Selby Avenues in Westwood. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions be made to either Saint John's Health Center Foundation, 1328 22nd Street, Santa Monica, CA 90404-2091, or Las Floristas, Inc., c/o Maggie Simms, 10071 Valley Spring Lane, Toluca Lake, CA 91602.

BEBO VALDéS and CHUCHO VALDéS ''Juntos Para Siempre'' (Calle 54/Sony) One of the greatest musicians in Havana during the 1950s, the pianist Bebo Valdés saw his career reignite about 10 years ago. Since then he's made a series of well-conceived records that drew upon his own historical interests: a century of shared musical history between his homeland and the United States. There was a modernized bolero album, a Latin-jazz big-band album, a remarkable through-the-ages solo-piano album, a couple of duet recordings with violin and bass.

JAKE OWEN ''Easy Does It'' (RCA Nashville) The young country star Jake Owen was mostly a rapscallion on ''Startin' With Me,'' his sometimes exquisite 2006 debut album, and nowhere more so than on ''Eight Second Ride,'' a bruiser of a seduction featuring plaintive, muscular, layered guitars that suggested a more thoughtful Black Sabbath. On this song, one of that album's best, he picked up a young woman in a bar, brought her to his truck and encouraged her, with big helpings of verve and internal rhyme, to ''climb on up, and honey, watch the cup/that I'm spitting my dip inside.'' Seriously -- that stuff leaves a stain.

Republican governors split sharply during the weekend over how to respond to the economic crisis, a debate whose outcome will go a long way toward shaping how the national party redefines itself in the wake of its election defeats of recent years. The divisions were evident at the annual winter meeting of the National Governors Association here as the Republicans differed both in their approaches to their own states' budget shortfalls and in their attitudes toward President Obama's $787 billion stimulus package.

In a bracing refresher course on why economics is called the dismal science, a gathering of academics in Washington on Thursday poured cold water on the idea that the new stimulus plan will create lots of jobs and improve the lives of many by wiring rural areas for broadband. Most of the economists at the seminar sponsored by the business schools of Columbia and Georgetown said the ability of broadband to spur economic development in rural areas was difficult to quantify.

WHITWORTH--John H.,Jr., succumbed to cancer after a long illness on February 18, 2009, in Millbrook, NY. He was born in Pontotoc, Mississippi on August 13, 1933. A graduate of the University of Mississippi and the University of Mississippi Law School, he was a retired partner of the law firm of Dewey & LeBoeuf. A member of the Knickerbocker Club, the Millbrook Garden Club and a former member of the Millbrook Hunt, he is survived by his sister, Helen Whitworth Odom, his nieces, Anna Whitworth Schoonover and Virginia Odom McKay and his nephew, Hendon Jerome Whitworth. The service will be held at St. Peters Church, Deep Hollow Road, Millbrook, NY, Friday, February 27th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate gifts to The (Jack) Russell Foundation, Inc. (501c3), PO Box 725, Rhinebeck, NY, 12572 and/or to St. Peters Outreach Programs, PO Box 1502, Millbrook, NY 12545.

MURRAY--John James, Kent, NY, died February 22, 2009. The family of John Murray mourns the loss of a wonderful husband, father of nine children and grandfather of eight. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 62 years, Lillian, his children; Pamela Arenson, Christine Pearson, John Murray, Warren Murray, Mark Murray, Bernadette Murray-Fertel, Joseph Murray, Douglas Murray and Regina Murray. Born August 5, 1921 in Manhattan, a veteran of World War II, he saw duty in the worst of the island fighting in the Pacific theater. He reared his family with his fierce commitment to love and truth. His integrity set a standard for us all. His patrimony will best be remembered for the unwavering love and support of his family, for creating the most magical Christmases ever, and for his hard work to give his family a wonderful life. He was a smart, brave, generous, funny and very loving man, a man of dignity.

K'NAAN ''Troubadour'' (A&M Octone) ''Somalia'' and ''America'' arrive side by side, as adjacent tracks, on ''Troubadour,'' the sophomore album by the wiry rapper K'naan. And that sequencing feels pointed and insistent, like the songs themselves. ''So what you know about the pirates terrorize the ocean?'' he asks in ''Somalia,'' over the stirrings of a children's choir. In ''America'' he follows up a Somali incantation with a boastful disclaimer: ''Not long ago I don't spoke English.''

SAND--Edward A. Former Chairman and CEO of Parents Magazine Enterprises died on Friday, February 13. He was 97 and lived in Sarasota, Florida. The cause of death was complications from a fall in his home. Mr. Sand joined Parents Magazine in 1944 and along with the publication's founder George J. Hecht, built the company into a multi-faceted media and retail operation which included five adult and children's magazines; a children's book business; the FAO Schwartz toy stores; Baker and Taylor, the worlds largest book distributor; and Family Publication Service, which was co-owned with Time Inc. The company remained privately held until Mr. Sand negotiated its sale to the W R Grace Company and to the German publisher Bertelsmann in the late 1970's. After graduating New York University Mr. Sand launched The Literary Workshop where he edited and published the stories of prominent young writers including H. L. Mencken, Sherwood Andersen and Erskine Caldwell. After The Literary Workshop had to be discontinued because of lack of advertising, Mr. Sand worked briefly as a newspaper reporter and a magazine circulation director. After retiring from Parents in 1979, Mr. Sand was a frequent contributor to the Sarasota Tribune where he wrote a periodic column on family issues and to the Longboat Key Observer. He was an active collector of American art and a contributor to numerous charitable causes. Mr. Sand is survived by his son Thomas Sand, daughter-in-law Mary L. Sand and granddaughter Jennifer Robin Sand.

BAIN--Dr. Beverly Mae (Konugres), Bernardsville, NJ passed peacefully on February 20, 2009 at 79. Dr. Bain was an internationally known pioneer in occupational therapy and rehabilitation. A graduate of CO College, voted "Woman of the Future"; she earned her OTR from, USC; MS in Learning Disb, Montclair St. University.; Ed D. Fairleigh Dickinson and FAOTA; after a fellowship at Warm Springs, GA, Dr. Bain was recruited by Dr. Henry Kessler and directed the OT department, '55; she created OT programs at Kean College and Union City Teacher Institute; a member of RESNA, Dr. Bain was an assistant professor for 18 years at NYU graduate OT program, being voted Teacher of the Year She was appointed by President Nixon to Defense Advisory Committee on Women in the Armed Services, integrating women in the military and academies. She was currently a consultant at the Matheny School and Hospital. During her career, she authored numerous papers and 18 chapters in medical textbooks. She lectured widely on rehab in US and abroad. Dr. Bain is survived by her husband John N. Bain of Bernardsville for nearly 50 years; her daughter Karin Bain Kukral and John Z. Kukral of Old Greenwich, CT; grandchildren Jimmy, Johnny and Julie; sisters Kris Ann Vogelpohl and Lyn Coupounas, brother James Konugres and nephew Thomas Bain, his wife and children, Michelle, Tyler and Kylene Bain and many nieces and nephews.

It's probably safe to say that Whopper Sacrifice, Burger King's impish Facebook campaign that offered free burgers to anyone dropping 10 friends, wasn't aimed at retirees. But maybe it should have been. A recent report from Forrester Research indicates that while it might be tempting to categorize all Americans of a certain age as techno-dinosaurs and Luddites, more than 60 percent of baby boomers are avid consumers of social media like blogs, forums, podcasts and online videos. That's up from roughly 40 percent a year ago.

A capsule summary in the ''On the Web'' listings on Friday for an Economix blog article about President Obama's housing proposal misspelled the surname of the author. He is Edward L. Glaeser, not Glaser.

The dream of a free and easy way to watch Internet video on a television set just ran into some harsh reality. Boxee, led by Avner Ronen, below, is a free software package that combines multiple sources of Internet video in a simple interface. One of its most important content sources, the video site Hulu, said on Wednesday that it would stop allowing its programs to be shown through Boxee.

ROBIN--Murray B. Passed away on February 22, 2009 after a three year bout with Multiple Myeloma. He is survived by his devoted wife Dorothy, his three children Helen, Dana and Tracy, their respective spouses Peter, Lucy and Charles, and his five grandsons Dax, Tucker, Asher, Emmett and Max. He will be remembered by them forever with love. He will be missed by cousins and friends. Once he became your friend, it was a lifetime commitment. Funeral services, Tuesday February 24th, 11:15am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street, NYC.

FINE--Dr. Harold J.,83, died February 20, 2009, at Chestnut Hill Hospital, PA. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Elsa Honig Fine, devoted daughters Erika Fine of Boston and Amy Fine Collins of NYC, son-in-law Bradley Collins and granddaughter Flora Collins, as well as many nieces and nephews. A psychologist and psychoanalyst, he was a mentor to generations of students as director of clinical training at the University of Tennessee. A clinician devoted to his patients and an author of more than 100 scholarly articles, he helped introduce object relations theory to the United States. With his encyclopedic knowledge, he was everybody's "answer man". He enjoyed jazz, politics, poetry, cars and British tweeds, but his main delight was always his family. He was an adored and doting father. We love him profoundly and miss him deeply. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Harold J. Fine's memory to the GBS/CIDP Foundation, 104 1/2 Forrest Ave., Narberth, PA 19072.

Gerald E. Myers, a scholarly expert on the philosopher William James who expressed his missionary zeal for modern dance through the highly unusual position of philosopher in residence of the American Dance Festival, died Feb. 11 at his home in New London, Conn. He was 85. The cause was multiple myeloma, said his son, Curt.

You don’t need the F.B.I.’s assistance to deduce the whereabouts of the Fox television series “Fringe,” though a C.P.A. might help. The show, about a federal agent and her unconventional investigative team, will cease filming in New York as the state’s tax credits for movie and television production dry up, and relocate to Vancouver, Variety reported. After its pilot was made in Toronto, “Fringe” (created in part by J.J. Abrams, of “Lost” and “Alias” fame) moved to New York for its first season, hoping to take advantage of production discounts offered by the city and state. But as money for the tax incentives has evaporated — New York state has already spent $515 million toward credits that were supposed to last into 2013 — its producers looked elsewhere. A second season of “Fringe,” while likely, has not yet been announced.

This is why they call him the Boss: Ticketmaster agreed to change its sales policies after more than 2,000 Bruce Springsteen fans and Mr. Springsteen himself complained about Ticketmaster’s practices, the New Jersey Attorney General’s office said in a news release. Earlier this month, many customers said that when they tried to buy tickets from Ticketmaster.com for Mr. Springsteen’s May 21 and 23 concerts in East Rutherford, N.J., they were instead directed to TicketsNow.Com, a resale site owned by Ticketmaster, where tickets were offered at far more than their face value. On his Web site, Mr. Springsteen wrote, “The abuse of our fans and our trust by Ticketmaster” had made him “furious.” As part of its settlement, Ticketmaster will create a wall between its site and TicketsNow.com for one year, and establish a lottery where fans who filed complaints could purchase tickets to Mr. Springsteen’s New Jersey shows.

A legal dispute between Jackson Browne and Senator John McCain over Mr. Browne’s song “Running on Empty” will keep running: In federal district court in California on Friday, a judge denied motions filed by Mr. McCain and the Republican National Committee to halt a lawsuit brought against them by Mr. Browne, according to court documents. In his suit, Mr. Browne said that Mr. McCain and the committee had infringed on his copyrights by using “Running on Empty” in a presidential campaign commercial without Mr. Browne’s permission. Mr. McCain and the R.N.C. had argued that First Amendment and fair-use rules permitted the use of the song because it occurred in a political context, but Judge R. Gary Klausner was unconvinced; Judge Klausner also set a late April date for a hearing to set a schedule for a jury trial.

The Broadway musical that gave us “Ease on Down the Road” and may have inspired a vintage-1980s electronics retail chain is coming back: New York City Center announced that it would stage a revival of “The Wiz” as its Encores! Summer Stars production. The original musical, a modern-day retelling of L. Frank Baum‘s “Wonderful Wizard of Oz” with an African-American cast, featured a book by William F. Brown, music and lyrics by Charlie Smalls and orchestrations by Harold Wheeler, won seven Tony Awards, including best musical in 1975. The Encores! revival will be directed by Thomas Kail and choreographed by Andy Blankenbuehler (who collaborated on “In the Heights”), and is scheduled to run June 12 through July 3. No casting has been announced.

The widely anticipated new musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark,” with music and lyrics by U2’s Bono and the Edge, and directed by Julie Taymor (“The Lion King”), took a big swing toward a Broadway debut on Tuesday as the producers announced that the show was scheduled to begin previews next January at the Hilton Theater.

An omnibus bill for the current fiscal year introduced on Monday by the House Appropriations Committee includes a $10 million increase for the National Endowment for the Arts and for the National Endowment for the Humanities, which would bring each of their annual budgets to $155 million. The allocations, which have yet to be acted on by the House and Senate, follows the approval on Feb. 13 of $50 million in additional funds for the National Endowment for the Arts in Congress’s economic stimulus bill. In the previous fiscal year, the endowment’s budget rose from $124.4 million to $144.7 million.

The coming Broadway transfer of “Next to Normal” is switching homes, moving from the Longacre Theater to the Booth Theater. Its producers said they hoped to create a more intimate feel in the smaller Booth and tap into the heavily trafficked area around Shubert Alley.

Ken Bloom and Frank Vlastnik, authors of the newly revised “Broadway Musicals: The 101 Greatest Shows of All Time,” answered readers’ questions about Broadway seasons past, present and future. Here they take a look at Broadway’s history: the best, the overrated and the overlooked.

Conan O’Brien is bringing a big part of his past to his future role as host of the “Tonight” show: Andy Richter. Mr. Richter, who served as Mr. O’Brien’s sidekick during the first eight years of NBC’s “Late Night with Conan O’Brien,” is coming back as the announcer for “Tonight” when Mr. O’Brien takes over the show in June. Mr. Richter, who will also perform in sketches on “Tonight,” left “Late Night” in 2000 to pursue an acting career and starred in several network comedy series, including one, “Andy Barker, P.I.,” that was produced by Mr. O’Brien’s company. Mr. Richter returned as a final guest on “Late Night with Conan O’Brien” last week. Before the taping of the final show, Mr. Richter said: “The best thing about Conan taking over the ‘Tonight’ show is that he’s coming to Los Angeles, where I already live. So I’m getting my friends back.”

In one of the rare interviews he has granted since commencing his first American tour in more than 15 years, Leonard Cohen spoke to The Times’s Larry Rohter about everything from his religious faith to the music he keeps in his iTunes account.

In an attempt to combat bedbugs, members of the City Council have proposed various pieces of legislation, including the regulation of the sale and disposal of mattresses. One proposal would require that every mattress be sold with a container marked "Used Mattress -- For Disposal Only," which would be used when the mattress is being discarded. Another would prohibit the sale of reconditioned mattresses entirely. In addition, there are more broad-based proposals, including efforts to establish a task force and a training program for exterminating bedbugs in the city.

Archaeology | The Scottish sailor who inspired Daniel Defoe's "Robinson Crusoe" is coming into sharper relief 300 years after his return to human society, thanks to an archaeological investigation into his solitary island life. Alexander Selkirk -- "a pirate, a drinker and a short-tempered ruffian" -- wasn't shipwrecked but rather was left stranded on an island some 400 miles off Chile after quarreling with his captain. Selkirk "had apparently always had trouble getting along with other people, which was perhaps precisely why he endured his solitary confinement on the island so successfully." [Spiegel]

For many years there has been increasing interest in growing and eating organic produce. Consumers cite its health benefits, more robust taste, and its tendency to come from small-scale producers.
The lineups for the Mets' second intrasquad game of the season

Latin America | Expect more "presidents for life" across Latin America, an article says, now that Hugo Chávez of Venezuela has won a constitutional amendment to allow him to run for office indefinitely. Already at least 13 other countries have made it easier for leaders to stay in or return to power. It's "bad news for the region," a democracy advocate says. "Latin America's fragile democracies won't get stronger with charismatic leaders, but with stronger institutions and a solid civic culture." [Real Clear World]

Nationalization, at least a partial one, seems inevitable for Citigroup. As Washington prepares to tighten its grip on the struggling company, the implications - for the troubled financial giant and the rest of the industry - are starting to sink in, The New York Times's Eric Dash writes.

The following is one in a series of articles in which Green Inc.'s editor, Tom Zeller Jr., explores ways to improve the energy efficiency of his home. Green Inc. readers are encouraged to share their own thoughts and experiences in the comments section -- or by emailing us at greeninc@nytimes.com
Celebrity gossip, it seems, will never go out of style. At least, that's what Josh Berman and Colin Digiaro, co-founders of MySpace, are hoping with their latest venture.

Many of the most impressive engineering facets of the new World Trade Center will be invisible to future visitors. But the construction site permits a glimpse of how complex -- and imposing -- structural solutions must be.

The government faced mounting pressure on Monday to put billions more in some of the nation's biggest banks, two of the biggest automakers and the biggest insurance company, despite the billions it has already committed to rescuing them, The New York Times's Edmund L. Andrews, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Mary Williams Walsh reported.
3i Group has launched an offer to buy back one of its listed funds, as the its new chief executive, Muchael Queen, seeks way to reduce the company's 2 billion pound ($2.9 billion) debt burden.

The debt-laden miner Rio Tinto may try to persuade irate shareholders to back a $19.5 billion tie-up with Chinalco by offering them bonds on the same terms as the Chinese company, The Sydney Morning Herald Reported.
Japan's Astellas Pharma isn't giving up on the idea of buying CV Therapeutics, despite having its $1 billion bid rebuffed by the Palo Alto, Calif.-based drugmaker.
Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard.

A fund of hedge funds run by two relatives of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was marketed exclusively by firms controlled by Robert Allen Stanford, the Texas-born financier sued by regulators over what they say was a $8 billion fraud, The Wall Street Journal reported.
The British government is expected to introduce controversial legislation in the House of Lords this week to sell a stake in Royal Mail, a labor union told Reuters on Monday.

Apax Partners, the British private equity group, has sold 7.7 percent of its management company to Singaporean and Australian investors, according to The Financial Times. Apax plans to put the cash raised from the deal into a permanent fund that it will invest in future buyout funds, the report said.

UBS, mounting a legal fight against federal efforts to force it to disclose the names of United States clients suspected of offshore tax evasion, may end up in court in July for a mini-trial on the matter, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.

Updated, 11:39 a.m. | A fire that broke out in a tenement building in Chinatown early Tuesday has killed one resident, and at least one other person is critically injured, a Fire Department official said. The fire started in the six-story building at 22 James Street around 3:47 a.m. and grew to four alarms, said the official, Francis X. Gribbon, who was at the scene.Firefighters discovered a 32-year-old man fatally injured in the building, though it was not immediately clear how he died or on what floor his body was discovered, Mr. Gribbon said. He was transferred to Beekman Downton Hospital. A woman in her 30s was critically injured for smoke inhalation was initially taken to Beth Israel Medical Center, in Manhattan, and then transferred to Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx.
Millions of dollars of Robert Allen Stanford's assets on St. Croix remained unfrozen on Monday, even after a court-appointed receiver was said to have arrived on the Caribbean island.
Carl C. Icahn has once again raised his stake in Lions Gate Entertainment and said he may seek to make changes to the film studio's board.
Is partial nationalization the cure for America's ailing banks?
NRG Energy is providing $10 million to help eSolar, a Pasadena, Calif.-based company, develop lower-cost solar power plants.
John A. Thain, the former chief of Merrill Lynch, faced six hours of questioning last week with the attorney general of New York.

Since the fall of the Berlin Wall, the countries of Eastern Europe have emerged as critical allies of the United States in the region, embracing American-style capitalism and borrowing heavily from Western European banks to finance their rise.

Hedge funds and the rest of the so-called shadow banking system are almost certainly going to face more regulation, Breakingviews says. But governments should not try to supervise them directly; instead, the publication argues, it would be far more productive for governments to monitor how they borrow to leverage their investments.
Abruzzo may be the bargain region of Italy, according to a new study.
Balfour Beatty Construction U.S., the Dallas-based general contractor, said Monday that it has signed a deal for RT Dooley Construction.

Westec Intelligent Surveillance, a video and audio monitoring firm, has raised $20 million in fresh funding in a round led by Argonaut Private Equity and Egis Capital Partners, The Dallas Morning News reported.

Merrill Lynch, which is facing an exodus of senior bankers in Europe, saw the back of yet-another high-profile executive Monday, as veterans of the bank are weighing an uncertain future with new owner Bank of America, The Financial Times reported.
Hewlett-Packard on Monday began a $2.7 billion, three-part sale of notes via Banc of America Securities, Deutsche Bank and RBS Greenwich Capital, according to IFR.
American International Group, rescued twice last year by the U.S. government, is asking for more aid and bracing for a fourth-quarter loss of roughly $60 billion, according to press reports.

Economy | Count the economist Jeffrey Sachs among the naysayers of Obama's economic strategy; he suggests it's simply another of the "unduly large swings in macroeconomic policies" to blame for our current mess. "Massive deficits and zero interest rates might temporarily perk up spending but at the risk of a collapsing currency, loss of confidence in the government and growing anxieties about the government's ability to pay its debts," he writes. "Stop panicking," he counsels. "There is little reason to fear a decade of stagnation, much less a depression. The U.S. economy is technologically dynamic and highly flexible." [Scientific American]

Office real estate investment trust HRPT Properties Trust said that its subsidiary, Government Properties Income Trust, will go public, but HRPT will continue to own a nearly 50 percent stake in the company.

The American International Group, which is reportedly negotiating for tens of billions of dollars in additional assistance amid mounting losses, has received offers from MetLife and Axa for its American Life Insurance unit, Bloomberg News reported, citing three people familiar with the situation.

The wave of selling in European and American stock markets continued in Asia on Tuesday, sending key indexes in several countries down more than 3 percent and toward the lows they hit in October, The New York Times's Bettina Wassener reported.
On a day when two leading stock indexes sank to their lowest point in more than a decade, Wall Street did not need the dire problems of banks to lead the way to the bottom.
As the United States government considers doubling down on its bailouts of major financial institutions, The Deal is offering its rundown of 2008's Deals of the Year in its latest issue.
Genentech urged its shareholders on Monday to reject a hostile takeover offer from the company's majority owner, Roche, The New York Times's Andrew Pollack writes.

War | "How do you program a robot to be an ethical warrior?" an article asks. Not easily, a Navy-commissioned report suggests, because the underlying codes are now so complex and written by so many programmers that "no individual can predict the effect of a given command with absolute certainty." There's also the problem of "behaviors not programmed but arising out of sheer complexity." That's why -- and here the mind begins to reel -- engineers pursue artificial morality for remote-controlled war. [Britannica, Times of London, CalPoly]

I use Microsoft Word 2003, but after working on a really long document one night, I found I couldn't open the file - or any other Word documents - the next day. I also keep getting messages about something called the "Normal.dot" file, which I never got before. What might be causing this and how can I fix it?
Nazi Party posters and views from the exhibition “State of Deception: The Power of Nazi Propaganda” at the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.
The World Anti-Doping Agency president, John Fahey, begins a European tour Tuesday and will face questions about the agency’s revamped whereabouts rule for out-of-competition testing.
Andy Murray got off to a winning start Monday at the Dubai Tennis Championships, a tournament missing many top players who are boycotting or injured.
A preview of the President's address to a joint session of Congress.

Across the city, the starchitect building bubble has burst overnight. Developers from Silverstein to Swig face financial setbacks or even foreclosures, and even the Port Authority is planning on "stumps" in place of towers at Ground Zero. Sans skyscrapers atop them, the plinths of Norman Foster and Richard Rogers may be Manhattan's first low-rise monuments to recession.
Mr. Blau turned his infatuation with the songs of a Belgian-born troubadour into one of Off Broadway’s most enduring hits, “Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris.”
Mr. Nolan, who was mute and quadriplegic since birth, produced a highly praised volume at 15 and later published a prize-winning autobiography, “Under the Eye of the Clock.”
Photos from the new production by Theater for a New Audience.
A 15-year-old boy was shot and killed in the Bronx on Monday night, and two other teenagers were wounded, the police said.
We know that Bits readers are fascinated by Amazon.com's new Kindle 2. Well, it's finally arriving in customers' hands Tuesday, and our colleague David Pogue has reviewed it. Here's an excerpt:

Because of an editing error, an obituary by The Associated Press on Feb. 13 about Shirley Jean Rickert, who starred in several “Our Gang” film comedies as a child, misstated the years in which she played Tomboy Teri Taylor in eight Mickey McGuire comedies alongside Mickey Rooney. It was in 1933 and 1934, not “between 1927 and 1934.”.

A film column on Friday about the Film Comment Selects series at the Walter Reade Theater, which includes “The Hurt Locker,” misidentified the festival where that movie was first shown. It was the Venice Film Festival, not the Toronto International Film Festival. (Its screening in Toronto was its North American premiere.).

MAHMUDIYA-- Inside a tribal guest house near here, shaded by palm trees and surrounded by irrigated fields of barley and wheat, the talk over tea the other day quickly turned to politics. Not Iraq's, America's.
A dance review on Saturday about the Antonio Gades Company, at City Center, misstated the year Mr. Gades died. It was 2004, not 1984.

A listing of credits on Feb. 16 with a theater review of “East 10th Street: Self Portrait With Empty House,” at the Axis Theater in the West Village, referred incorrectly to the play’s director, who is also the artistic director of the Axis Theater Company. The director, Randy Sharp, is a woman.

An article on Monday about the Academy Awards ceremony misstated part of a comment by Danny Boyle, director of “Slumdog Millionaire,” in some editions. Mr. Boyle, saluting the people of Mumbai, where the film is set, said, “You dwarf even this guy,” referring to the Oscar statuette — not “You dwarf even the sky.”.
Guard Stephon Marbury and Coach Mike D’Antoni will face off in a Manhattan law office as an arbitrator considers Marbury’s grievance against the Knicks.

A picture caption in some editions on Friday about the second day of a student protest at New York University misstated the surname of one of two students in the campus cafeteria. The student at right is Colin Dillon, not Dilleen.
Among today's headlines:
While the changes in the new Kindle are fairly minor, they’re exactly what was needed to turn a very good electronic book reader into an even better one.
Dr. Douglas K. Rex on things you need to know about colonoscopy.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

A report in the City Room column in some editions on Monday about “Arguing Jewish Style: An Examination of Texts From the Bible to Modern Literature,” a presentation scheduled for Sunday at the Society for the Advancement of Judaism, gave an erroneous time from organizers for the event. It is at 3:30 p.m., not 1 p.m.
A prosecutor said he had no choice but to file adult charges against an 11-year-old boy accused of killing his father’s pregnant girlfriend, despite questions about how to jail him.
A jury in West Palm Beach convicted Rev. Francis Guinan of stealing from his church, but it found that he had embezzled far less than the $488,000 prosecutors charged.

An article on Monday about the political debate over the long-term solvency of Social Security misstated the age at which new retirees may begin to collect full benefits. Under the current formula, a person born between 1943 and 1954 must be 66 years old — not 65 — to receive full monthly benefits.
Investigators have found evidence that a bird may have struck a helicopter before it crashed into a swamp near Morgan City last month, killing eight people.
The parents accused of killing their 4-year-old daughter with an overdose should be tried for first-degree murder, not less severe charges, the Massachusetts Appeals Court ruled.

A picture caption on Sunday with an article about Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton’s visit to China misidentified the Chinese leader shown meeting with her in Beijing. He is President Hu Jintao, not Prime Minister Wen Jiabao.
A resident of a Phoenix shelter for the homeless shot and killed an employee at the facility, possibly because he had just been told he was being kicked out, the authorities said.
A state panel has approved a settlement of about $500,000 for two women whose sexual harassment claims led to last year’s resignation of Ohio’s attorney general, Marc Dann.
The Supreme Court cleared the way for the Environmental Protection Agency to issue new regulations on emissions of mercury and other pollutants from coal-fired power plants.

What we need now is a Web-based system for measuring our changing society with key national indicators — in a free, public, easy-to-use form.
Since his election, President Obama has been roundly criticized for using “I” instead of “me.” Here is a tip, Mr. President.
The Obama administration sees this economic crisis as an opportunity to expand its reach, but I fear that in trying to do everything at once, it will do nothing well.

This singing competition is too venerable to be called “Metropolitan Idol,” but the consequences for young careers are just as great as with “American Idol”: on Sunday, four winners of the National Council Auditions, sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera, were announced after the final performance round with the Met orchestra. They are Paul Appleby, 25, of South Bend, Ind., a tenor; Anthony Roth Costanzo, 26, of Durham, N.C., a countertenor; Sung Eun Lee, 30, of Seoul, South Korea, a tenor; and Nadine Sierra, 20, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a soprano. Each received $15,000; the four other finalists received $5,000. They were Noah A. Baetge of Seattle; Kiri Dyan Deonarine of Fair Lawn, N.J.; Jessica Julin of Danville, Calif.; and Sarah Mesko of Hot Springs, Ark. Nearly 1,800 young singers entered the competition. Previous honorees include Renée Fleming, Deborah Voigt, Ben Heppner and Samuel Ramey. A first-place finish often leads to selection for the Met’s Lindemann Young Artist Development Program.

The grieving process for The New Group’s production of “Mourning Becomes Electra” will be a brief one. The revival of the Eugene O’Neill drama at the Acorn Theater has moved up the closing date for its limited run by six weeks, a publicist for the show said. The play will now close on Sunday; it was originally scheduled to run through April 18. No reason for the early closing was given, but the play, a 4-hour-10-minute restaging of the “Oresteia” in 19th-century New England, received mostly poor reviews, despite a cast that included Lili Taylor, above with Joseph Cross, and Jena Malone.
The museum joins the growing roster of cultural institutions that have suspended their operations in the face of a weakening economy.

As the Hollywood gossip Web site Defamer.com prepared to cover the Academy Awards on Sunday, its owner, Gawker Media, said it would fold the site into its flagship blog, Gawker.com. Defamer, which jabbed at celebrities and industry executives, will become Gawker.com’s entertainment column. Its editor, Seth Abramovitch, and Defamer’s main writers will leave the company this week. In December Gawker’s founder and president, Nick Denton, said he was in talks to sell Defamer, but those talks fell through, Mr. Abramovitch said. “There are so many other blogs covering what we’d cover,” he noted.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art will close seven more of its satellite shops around the country, bringing to 15 the number it has closed in the last year.

Neither T-Pain, above, nor his trademark top hat nor his Vocoder device will be at a concert in Guyana after he was threatened with kidnapping or death, The Associated Press reported. T-Pain, the Florida-born hip-hop and R&B performer whose real name is Faheem Najm, was scheduled to perform a concert in that South American nation on Monday night as part of its Mashramani festival, which celebrates Guyana’s independence from Britain. But the show’s promoter canceled the event after receiving what he said were “credible death and kidnapping threats” against T-Pain via e-mail messages and telephone calls. A police commander for the area told The A.P. that the local authorities were investigating.

He may have been snubbed by the Oscars, but Bruce Springsteen can take comfort this summer in the arms of thousands of mud-caked British concertgoers: he has been named one of the headliners of the Glastonbury Festival, the event’s promoters announced on its Web page, glastonburyfestivals.co.uk. Mr. Springsteen, whose title track from the film “The Wrestler” was passed over for nomination in the Academy Awards’ best song category, will receive top billing on Saturday, June 27; the full festival runs from June 24 through 28 in Somerset County in England. Though Glastonbury has traditionally been a showcase for homegrown rock bands like Oasis, Coldplay and Radiohead, the festival has gradually expanded its boundaries; its Saturday night headliner in 2008 was Jay-Z. For stateside fans Mr. Springsteen will also be appearing at the Bonnaroo festival, which runs June 11 to 14 in Manchester, Tenn.
Ratings for the 81st Annual Academy Awards on Sunday night were up significantly over last year’s telecast, the least-watched Oscars on record.

The very title of its newest show, ''It Started With a Dream: David Zippel -- Lyrics He Wrote, Lyrics He Wishes He Wrote,'' distills the quandary facing the 92nd Street Y's long-running Lyrics and Lyricists series. On and off Broadway, there may be enough talented younger songwriters to fill up a season of programs. But for the longtime subscribers making nostalgic pilgrimages to the shrines of the old masters, today's descendants of the great tradition, no matter how talented, tend to be viewed with a suspicion that borders on indifference. Thus the ''lyrics he wishes he wrote'' addendum to the title (Mr. Zippel, who hosted Saturday's opening-night show, apologized for the grammar) meant the inclusion of a long medley of song fragments, awkwardly stitched together, saluting Mr. Zippel's influences. They included Coleman and Leigh, Bock and Harnick, Rodgers and Hammerstein, Porter, Sondheim and Comden and Green, as well as Laura Nyro and Joni Mitchell. The audience sing-along, a popular fixture of the series, was Irving Berlin's ''I Got the Sun in the Morning.''

JOHNSON--Lorna Drummond, M.D.,died peacefully in her sleep surrounded by her loving family and cat, Buffers on February 21, 2009. Born in Great Crosby (Liverpool) England, November 26, 1920, she graduated from the: Horace Mann School in New York City, received her BA from Barnard College, and her MD from New York University School of Medicine. She met her husband, Robert E. Johnson MD, at the Bellevue Medical Center in New York City, where they participated in the rescue of victims from the B-25 plane crash into the Empire State Building. They moved to Framingham, MA in 1953, with their four children. In order to spend more time with her children, she went into medical research, where she ran the cervical cancer clinic at the Boston Hospital For Women Lying In Hospital Division for 30 years where she became an expert in cervical cancer. She then moved to the New England Regional Primate Center in Southborough, MA and studied the reproductive behavior of the cotton-topped tamarins as well as other primates and non-primates. She was predeceased by her husband Robert E. Johnson, M.D., who was a well-loved and respected physician in Framingham; her daughter, Laurel "Muffin" Lyons, M.D. of Woodsville, NH; and James Samuel "Sam" Johnson. She leaves behind her family: daughter Amy Johnson, M.D. of Rochester MA, son Robert Johnson Jr. of Framingham MA, grandson Christopher Lyons of Greenland NH, granddaughters Sarah Lyons of Andover MA, and Devon Johnson of Rochester, MA. Relatives and friends are kindly invited to attend her funeral service on Friday, February 27, at 11am at the First Parish in Framingham, 24 Vernon St., (at Framingham Center). Burial will follow at Edgell Grove Cemetery, Framingham. Visiting hours at the Norton Funeral Home, (www.nortonfuneralhome.com) 53 Beech St., Framingham, will be Thursday from 5:30pm 7pm. In lieu of flowers, please send any donations to the James Samuel Johnson Scholarship Fund for Young Artists, c/o Stephen W. Price, Treasurer/Tax Collector, 150 Concord Street, Framingham MA 01702.

Pneumonia is the biggest killer of the world's children -- two million a year, more than AIDS, malaria and measles combined. But pneumonia, which just means fluid in the lungs, has many causes: bacterial, viral, fungal and parasitical. In poor countries, it is often treated without testing for the cause; a health worker will see a child panting for breath and give antibiotics.

ELLIMAN--Edward S.,son of Douglas L. and Katherine Scales Elliman, aged 85, died of cancer on February 20. He was born on March 4, 1923 and raised in New York City. After graduating from St. Paul's School in 1941, he enlisted in the U.S. Navy at the start of World War II, serving as a First Class Signalman on the USS Doyle. He took part in the landings of Salerno, Normandy (D-Day) and southern France, and also saw action in North Africa. After the war, he spent his entire business career in New York City real estate, becoming president of Douglas Gibbons Hollyday and Ives, Douglas L. Elliman and Company, and Elliman and Penn. In his 40+ year business career, he specialized in cooperative conversions, property management, and wholesale brokerage. Married to the former Ann Rockefeller, he lived for most of his adult life in Greenwich, Connecticut and had three sons--Edward H. (Ted), David D., and Christopher J. (Kim)--seven grandchildren--Westyn, Devon, Dascher, Isabel, Henry, Theodore, and Claire--and three daughters-in-law--Alice, Andrea, and Nicole. He pursued racquet sports, sailing, and rowing with a passion, interests which he happily shared with his family. An avid reader, he particularly enjoyed histories of the Civil War, classical Greece and Rome, and World War II. He also loved to sing and recite the poetry of Shakespeare, Kipling, and Sir Walter Scott. He had a lifelong association with St. Paul's School and for 50 years served on the Board of Christodora, a New York City foundation that operates outdoor education programs for city youth. Personable and gregarious, he enjoyed a wide range of friends and colleagues. He was proud of and devoted to his family, as they will always be to him. A Memorial Service will be held at the Christ Church Chapel, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT at 11:30am on Saturday, February 28. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Edward S. Elliman Scholarship Fund, Christodora Foundation, 1 East 53rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10022 or to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH 03301.

This singing competition is too venerable to be called ''Metropolitan Idol,'' but the consequences for young careers are just as great as with ''American Idol'': on Sunday, four winners of the National Council Auditions, sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera, were announced after the final performance round with the Met orchestra. They are Paul Appleby, 25, of South Bend, Ind., a tenor; Anthony Roth Costanzo, 26, of Durham, N.C., a countertenor; Sung Eun Lee, 30, of Seoul, South Korea, a tenor; and Nadine Sierra, 20, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a soprano. Each received $15,000; the four other finalists received $5,000. They were Noah A. Baetge of Seattle; Kiri Dyan Deonarine of Fair Lawn, N.J.; Jessica Julin of Danville, Calif.; and Sarah Mesko of Hot Springs, Ark. Nearly 1,800 young singers entered the competition. Previous honorees includeRenée Fleming,Deborah Voigt,Ben HeppnerandSamuel Ramey. A first-place finish often leads to selection for the Met's Lindemann Young Artist Development Program.

In a surreal moment last Sunday back in London, just as my 17-year-old daughter, Harriet, was showing me a picture of us taken four days earlier at an Egyptian cafe, we learned a bomb had just gone off in Cairo's Hussein Square. The number of people injured was still unclear then, but one thing was certain -- tourists were among them. ''Let me see that picture again,'' I said, grabbing her laptop. I looked closely at the image, our faces lit up not just by the sun, but by the sheer joy of spending a week in Egypt, taking in sights that are thousands of years old and absorbing a culture so completely foreign to our own. I looked past our exuberant expressions, scrutinizing instead the people and things surrounding us -- a man smoking a water pipe, a waiter tallying a bill, and an umbrella over a table bearing the slogan ''Unlimited Refreshments, Zero Alcohol.''

Taught Physics at City College of New York, before settling into a five decade career with IBM, in Scientific Centers and Scientific Marketing. A Life Austrian Chess Master, he enjoyed passing on his love of the game to his grandchildren, with whom he also shared his insights in soccer. Steven Rattner, a financier known in New York society and a counselor to many corporate chieftains, will join the Treasury Department as a lead adviser on the auto industry bailout. Mr. Rattner, 56, will advise Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner and Lawrence H. Summers, the director of the National Economic Council, on reorganization efforts by General Motors and Chrysler, two carmakers that are receiving federal bailout money.

The Pentagon official who inspected the Guantánamo Bay prison at the behest of President Obama and declared its conditions humane described himself Monday as a ''fresh set of eyes'' who had been given free rein to go about his work. But detainees' lawyers and human rights groups ridiculed the 85-page report that the official, Adm. Patrick M. Walsh, sent to the White House this weekend. They called it a public relations gesture by the new administration to try to quiet criticism of the prison while officials work to close it within a year.

The application process opened Thursday for the 40th running of the New York City Marathon on Nov. 1. The first big road races of the year have had record fields, so the marathon's registration, which closes June 1, could increase for 2009. The marathon has already had another significant increase. With the economic outlook uncertain, the organization that directs the race has raised its entry fees.

HART--Sheila Whitestone Cook, departed this world on Wednesday evening, February 18, 2009 in Vero Beach, FL. Mrs. Hart is survived by her husband, James J. Hart of New Fairfield, CT and her children Kenneth B Cook, II of Pleasanton, CA, Robert B. Cook, Jr. (Linda) of Chesapeake, VA, Amy C. Gavin of Los Altos, CA and William W. Cook (Dianne) of Englewood, FL, three grandchildren, two great grandchildren, and Mr. Hart's five children, eleven grandchildren and eight great- grandchildren. Sheila Hart was born December 2, 1927 to the late Henry A. Whitestone and Eileen O'Reilly Whitestone by flashlight in New York City . She attended and graduated from Holy Child Academy in her hometown, and matriculated and graduated from Barnard College in 1948 with a BA in History. Her sister Kathleen W. Burrus predeceased her. She married the late Robert B. Cook, Sr. at the main altar of St. Patrick Cathedral. They raised their four children in towns from North Carolina to Rhode Island, before settling into Princeton, New Jersey in 1962. In 1988, she married James J. Hart in the presence of their nine children and spouses. The Harts wintered in San Juan, PR for 13 winters, and then moved to the mainland of Indian River County, FL for their cold weather sojourns. Mrs. Hart was a resident of Princeton, NJ for 47 years and a parishioner of St. Paul's Catholic Church and a member of the Present Day Club. She was especially proud of being the longest continuously living resident of Candlewood Isle, New Fairfield, CT where she and five generations have spent summers since 1931. At her direction, she will be interred in Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Concord, MA at a future date. Memorial Mass will be offered later at St. Paul's Church, Princeton, NJ and at St. Edward the Confessor's Church, New Fairfield, CT& nbsp; Memorial contributions may be made in her name to The School of the Holy Child, 2225 Westchester Avenue Rye, NY 10580 or the Candlewood Lake Authority, P.O. Box 37, Sherman, CT 06784.

A month into her husband's presidency, Michelle Obama is viewed more positively than were other first ladies in the past 28 years at similar stages, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Over all, 49 percent of Americans have a favorable opinion of Mrs. Obama, 5 percent view her unfavorably and 44 percent do not yet have an opinion.

A widely used heart device recalled two years ago by Medtronic may be failing in patients at a rate significantly higher than previously known, a new report by two prominent cardiac specialists indicated. The Medtronic device, known as the Sprint Fidelis lead, is an electrical cable that connects an implanted defibrillator to a patient's heart.

Gold miners formed a human chain on Monday while digging in an open pit near the village of Kobu, in northeastern Congo. Control over the country's vast natural resources has long been a source of violent conflict. Additional photographs: nytimes.com/world.

President Obama is benefiting from remarkably high levels of optimism and confidence among Americans about his leadership, providing him with substantial political clout as he confronts the nation's economic challenges and opposition from nearly all Republicans in Congress, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. A majority of people surveyed in both parties said Mr. Obama was striving to work in a bipartisan way, but most faulted Republicans for their response to the president, saying the party had objected to the $787 billion economic stimulus plan for political reasons. Most said Mr. Obama should pursue the priorities he campaigned on, the poll found, rather than seek middle ground with Republicans.

Lying side by side on a narrow bed, talking and giggling and poking each other with skinny elbows, they looked like any pair of teenage girls trading jokes and secrets. But the bed was in a crowded hospital ward, and between the moments of laughter, Sarah Jonas, 18, and Mwanaidi Swalehe, 17, had an inescapable air of sadness. Pregnant at 16, both had given birth in 2007 after labor that lasted for days. Their babies had died, and the prolonged labor had inflicted a dreadful injury on the mothers: an internal wound called a fistula, which left them incontinent and soaked in urine.

Ratings for the 81st Annual Academy Awards on Sunday night were up significantly over last year's telecast, the least-watched Oscars on record. Nielsen's preliminary estimates show an average of 36.3 million viewers tuned in to the three- hour-plus awards show on ABC, a 13 percent increase over the 32 million who watched in 2008. Oscar ratings are down considerably from an all-time high of 55 million in 1998, when ''Titanic'' dominated the awards; two years ago 40.2 million viewers tuned in. ABC easily won the night over all, while Fox was runner-up with live Nascar coverage throughout prime time (9.7 million). CBS earned third place with ''60 Minutes'' at 7 (9.2 million) and ''The Amazing Race'' at 8 (7.8 million), followed by repeats of ''Cold Case'' (6.9 million) and ''The Unit'' (5.4 million) at 9 and 10. NBC finished in fourth place.
LEAVING HIS POST At the Front Door

He closed a budget gap, streamlined the payroll, staved off wholesale layoffs, avoided scandal, kept a low profile and occasionally played a Mozart piano sonata for guests at his home. Most chief executives with a record like that would make stockholders swoon. Yet Cardinal Edward M. Egan, who will retire in April as head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, rarely evoked that kind of reaction during his nine years as steward of the church's flagship diocese in the United States.

MILWAUKEE -- For a few deeply unpleasant days, the Rev. David Cooper found himself in the crosshairs of the Roman Catholic hierarchy. It was 2003, and the priest had opined to a reporter that women should be ordained. Faraway bishops rumbled about censure. Then he picked up the telephone and heard the baritone of Milwaukee's archbishop, Timothy M. Dolan. Father Cooper immediately offered to resign.

JAHSS--Melvin H.,M.D. The members of the NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases Department of Orthopaedic Surgery mourn the untimely passing of our friend and colleague, Dr. Melvin H. Jahss. Dr. Jahss was an honored member of the department for more than 60 years. He was an outstanding educator of residents and a world-renowned orthopaedic surgeon who laid the foundation for modern foot and ankle surgery. Dr. Jahss established a premier foot and ankle service at HJD, and was the proud founder of the AOFAS, which celebrated its 40th anniversary this year. He was the founding editor of the Foot and Ankle Journal and editor of the definitive textbook on disorders of the foot. He created a tradition of integrating the clinical and academic elements of foot and ankle disorders that inspired countless colleagues, residents and fellows. He was also an avid collector of Tiffany glass lamps, American and Chinese pottery and Japanese lacquer art, to name only a few. He leaves a saddened hospital community and a profound void, since his many years of dedicated work at the hospital have touched the lives of an infinite number of people during his tenure. We grieve his passing as we celebrate his exemplary life and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Harriet and to the entire family. Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D., Chairman William L. Jaffe, M.D., Vice-Chairman

DUFFY--Peter J.,aged 92 years peacefully at home on February 21, 2009. Loving husband of Marguerite. Beloved father of Peter Jr. (Eleanor). Predeceased by beloved wife Florence and daughter Theresa. Peter was a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre, Knight of St. Patrick and Friendly Son of St. Patrick. Peter started out delivering telegrams for Western Union to the fur district as a teenager. He started Peter Duffy Firs in 1950 and was proud to be the only Irishman in the fur business. Peter had an engaging, charismatic personality and those who knew him recognized his uniqueness. He faced the end of his life with a big smile everyday as well as tremendous strength and courage. He will be dearly missed by all his family, friends and employees whose souls he touched and will forever be in their hearts. Visitation Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9pm at John Krtil Funeral Home, Inc., 1297 1st Avenue, NYC (69-70th Street). Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10am at St. Joseph's Church in Yorkville, 404 East 87th Street. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory preferred to: SNACK for Autistic Children, 220 East 86th Street NYC 10028 or the Francis Pope Foundation, 401 East 81st Street, NYC 10028.

North Korea confirmed Tuesday that it was preparing to launch what outside experts believe is a missile theoretically capable of reaching Alaska and Hawaii. But the North insisted that what it planned to launch was a scientific satellite. The North's announcement came only days after Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and South Korea's foreign minister, Yu Myung-hwan, urged it not to carry out a threatened test-launching, calling such a move ''very unhelpful'' and ''provocative.''

PANTZER--Esther. The Employees of Pantzer Properties and Panco Management Group extend their sincere condolences on the untimely passing of Esther; loving mother and grandmother to Karen, Jessica, Josh, Jack and Mia, and beloved wife of Michael Pantzer, our esteemed COO.

When the original Alice Tully Hall was planned in the late 1960s, its acousticians were concerned mainly with how chamber music, recitals and lieder concerts (the particular passion of the arts patron for whom the hall was named) would sound in the space. Early music, played on period instruments, was probably far down the list of priorities, if it was there at all. The period-instrument movement was still a backwater, at least in the United States, where its main appeal was to college audiences, who heard it mostly in churches with the kind of resonance that not only provides the acoustical support early instruments need but suggests a historical patina as well. The prominence given early music in the reopening festivities at Alice Tully Hall is a sign of how much has changed in 40 years. Now period performance is a growth industry, and the first music heard in the revamped hall on Sunday afternoon was a set of Sephardic pieces performed by Jordi Savall and Hespèrion XXI, one of the most renowned period-instrument groups. Mr. Savall and company were also the first ensemble to perform a concert all their own in the new Starr Theater, as the concert hall itself is now called: a Sunday evening program that took up where their Sephardic set at the opening concert had left off.

PANTZER--Esther. Our lives will never be the same without our beloved Esther. She was the most wonderful, devoted friend anyone could ever ask for. She was beautiful inside and out. She knew what was important and lived her life accordingly. Her family was the center of her life and we feel so fortunate to be part of her family. We will be forever grateful to her beloved Mike for bringing Esther into our lives and will always cherish the too short time we shared. The void in our hearts will never be filled. Our deepest sympathy to Mike and their precious Karen, Jessica, Jack, Mia and Josh. Trish and Ron Sherman

Sooner or later, people who have Alzheimer's disease will have to give up the keys to the car. But figuring out when poses a problem for doctors and families, because the loss of driving privileges also means less freedom and mobility. Now a new study reports that a series of cognitive tests may help doctors determine which early Alzheimer's patients are likely to pose a danger behind the wheel.

He may have been snubbed by the Oscars, but Bruce Springsteen can take comfort this summer in the arms of thousands of mud-caked British concertgoers: he has been named one of the headliners of the Glastonbury Festival, the event's promoters announced on its Web page, glastonburyfestivals.co.uk. Mr. Springsteen, whose title track from the film ''The Wrestler'' was passed over for nomination in the Academy Awards' best song category, will receive top billing on Saturday, June 27; the full festival runs from June 24 through 28 in Somerset County in England. Though Glastonbury has traditionally been a showcase for homegrown rock bands like Oasis, Coldplay and Radiohead, the festival has gradually expanded its boundaries; its Saturday night headliner in 2008 was Jay-Z. For stateside fans Mr. Springsteen will also be appearing at the Bonnaroo festival, which runs June 11 to 14 in Manchester, Tenn.

Three regional museums are cutting staff as the economic downturn takes its toll on attendance and endowments. The Detroit Institute of Arts said it would lay off about 20 percent of its staff, or 63 of its 301 employees, in an effort to cut $6 million from its $34 million annual budget, The Detroit Free Press reported. The layoffs would affect 56 full-time and 7 part-time employees from across the museum’s staff; the museum has already canceled planned exhibitions on the Baroque period and the artwork of Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns and Jim Dine.

It’s not only American politicians who can rankle rock stars by playing their music: MGMT, the Brooklyn-based indie-rock duo, has demanded that France’s Union for a Popular Movement party compensate the band for using its song “Kids,” Agence France-Presse reported. The Union for a Popular Movement, the party of President Nicolas Sarkozy, played the song at its national congress in January, as well as two online videos and at a public function for the party leader, Xavier Bertrand. The party’s public relations firm said the use of the song was an unintentional mistake, and has offered the band one euro (approximately $1.28) in symbolic damages; a lawyer for the band has threatened to sue. Next week, the French parliament will consider a bill that would impose stronger penalties for illegal file-sharing and online piracy.

Ken Bloom and Frank Vlastnik, authors of the newly revised “Broadway Musicals: The 101 Greatest Shows of All Time,” answered readers’ questions about Broadway seasons past, present and future. In the final installment, they look at what’s to come in Broadway’s future.

Fifty years after Neil Klugman first held Brenda Patimkin’s glasses inPhilip Roth‘s first book, “Goodbye, Columbus,” Houghton Mifflin Harcourt has announced that it will release Mr. Roth’s 30th and 31st books, the publisher said in an e-mail message. “The Humbling,” which is scheduled for the fall, is a novel about an aging stage actor whose empty life is altered by “a counterplot of unusual erotic desire,” the publisher said. The company (which awarded its Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship to “Goodbye, Columbus” in 1959) will also release “Nemesis,” a work of fiction set in the summer of 1944 that tells of a polio epidemic and its effects on a closely knit Newark community and its children. That book is scheduled for publication in 2010.

It’s official: Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) has been No. 1 for a total of 10 weeks, longer than any album released this decade.The last album to have so long a run at No. 1 was Santana’s “Supernatural,” with 12 weeks there in 1999 and 2000.

A fresh wind stirred at the Juilliard School on Tuesday afternoon. It was more than the sensuous “cool breeze” of a kiss referred to in Purcell’s “Sweeter Than Roses,” sung by Lei Xu, a Chinese soprano, in Morse Recital Hall. More, too, than the energetic huffing and puffing of Burak Ozdemir, a Turkish bassoonist, in C.P.E. Bach’s Concerto for Bassoon and Strings in A (Wq. 172), which followed.

A California high school production of “Rent: School Edition” that had been canceled this month, over concerns about content and the right of the principal to review the musical’s script, has now been approved for an April 2009 production after the principal reviewed the script, school officials announced late Wednesday.

The Walters Art Museum in Baltimore has become the latest art institution to announce cost-reducing measures that include job cuts. On Thursday, the museum said in a release that it had laid off 7 staff members and eliminated 9 unfilled positions, and would also implement a salary freeze and a selective hiring freeze as well as staff furloughs. It also canceled a coming exhibition it had planned with the Musée d’Orsay in Paris and the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles. Additionally, the museum said it would close its Hackerman House annex on Mount Vernon Place on weekdays. During 2008, the museum said, its endowment declined by 27 percent, and it is facing reductions in city and state funding.

Fun as it may be to stay at the Y.M.C.A., the Village People will not need to reside there any time soon; the band will be allowed to keep performing while a lawsuit filed against them by one of its founding members is resolved. In a news release, a spokesman for the band and its promoters, Sixuvus Ltd., said that a San Diego judge had granted a preliminary injunction in a suit filed by Victor Willis, the original lead singer and police officer of the campy disco group. In his suit, Mr. Willis said that the resuscitated group, which he left in 1979, is using his likeness and voice in its performances; he also named the William Morris Agency and Can’t Stop Productions, which owns the trademark to the band’s name, as defendants.

Days after their visit to the Academy Awards, two child stars of “Slumdog Millionaire” have learned that they will be moved from a desolate section of Mumbai to new government housing, BBC News reported. Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, 10, and Rubina Ali Qureshi, 9, who played young incarnations of the characters Salim and Latika in the Oscar-winning film, will be moved from Mumbai’s Garib Nagar slum to houses allocated by the city’s government. The chairman of the local housing association, Amarjeet Singh Manhas, said, “Since the children have made the nation proud, they must be given free houses,” according to the BBC. The plight of the young actors of “Slumdog Millionaire” had prompted an international outcry; the movie’s producers and its director, Danny Boyle, have said that the children were tutored and paid three times an average Indian adult’s salary while working on the film.
The columnist Nicholas D. Kristof will do anything to get people's attention on the situation in Eastern Chad -- even tagging along with a Hollywood celebrity, George Clooney.
Behind his trademark full-court pressure defense and up-tempo offense, Missouri Coach Mike Anderson has finally hit his stride this season.

In the restaurant, the little tables shimmered under the moody lighting. It was just the kind of lighting, I knew, that after a few drinks would take on a shadowy glow and make our table the only table, a tiny oasis. But here I was: stone cold sober, out of the house for the first time in weeks, and meeting new people - an intimidatingly attractive couple with bright smiles and even brighter careers.

Probably the most influential work on health care spending has been done by Jack Wennberg and his colleagues at Dartmouth. They have found that medical spending varies enormously across the country -- and that the variation cannot be explained by the sickness of patients or by health outcomes. In other words, more health care often is not better health care.

My Thursday column is from Goz Beida, Chad, and attempts to set the stage for the International Criminal Court to issue an arrest warrant for President Bashir of Sudan. Lots of people are worried about what the warrant will mean: Will Bashir kick out aid workers? Will the north-south agreement in Sudan unravel? If Bashir is ousted, will the Islamist leader, Turabi, take over the country?

I mentioned that I made a cauliflower gratin last week for my dinner party alongside pork loin stuffed with dried apricots and prunes; creamy, cheesy but not too thick or heavy, it's a good (if terrifically unhealthy for a vegetable) side for meat that's somewhat dry. There were a few requests for the recipe in the comments section; it follows after the jump.

Barack Obama's online presence drove his campaign's early fund-raising and his primary victory over Hillary Rodham Clinton. His campaign's use of Twitter, Facebook and YouTube proved that he was part of the Web 2.0 generation. In the run-up to November's election, Senator Obama -- or one of his staff members -- typed more than 250 updates to his Twitter account at twitter.com/barackobama.

As the parent of real-estate brokers like Coldwell Banker and Century 21, Realogy is widely expected to suffer mightily throughout the recession. But it said on Wednesday that it will get help from its owner, the private equity firm Apollo Global Management.

Government financial regulators today released details of the long-awaited "stress test" -- that is, the test that officials will apply to the country's biggest banks to see if they have enough capital to survive the downturn.

The Police Department is publicizing a set of proposed internal rules for how it will manage the data it collects in trying to secure Lower Manhattan against a potential terror attack -- everything from the license plate numbers of cars to videotaped images of people walking the streets.Beginning Wednesday evening, the public is invited to read the "Public Security Privacy Guidelines" [pdf] online and send in comments by e-mail or regular mail.

With climate now a high priority issue in Washington, there has been a huge surge in the number of Senate lobbyists working on the issue, according to an online report from the Center for Public Integrity.

Since the last two posts were very down on the administration, let me say that the initial leaks on health care are encouraging. The supposed commitment of $634 billion to health care reform isn't quite enough to pay for the subsidies that are an essential part of a universal-care system, but it's not ridiculously short, either. It's beginning to look as if Obama's really going to go through with this -- and if he gets us to universality, his legacy will be secure.

The Phoenix Coyotes and the N.H.L. have been pressuring the city of Glendale, Ariz., to amend its lease at their Jobbing.com Arena, hoping to eliminate the $2.70 per ticket charge the club pays the city as a parking levy (one report has that fee higher, at $2.85). This would supposedly make the sale of the team (or part of the team) more possible.
For people who are trying to lose weight, it doesn't matter if you are counting carbs, protein or fat. All that matters is that you're counting something.

A humpback whale has become entangled in fishing gear about eight miles offshore in New York waters, the Coast Guard said on Wednesday. Until the team from Provincetown Center for Coastal Studies in New England arrives at the spot, near Sandy Hook, N.J., on Thursday, the Coast Guard has established a 500-yard safety zone around the stranded whale, which it announced via Twitter.

Well, that was fast. Just a few years ago Ireland's booming economy was hailed as the "Celtic Tiger," and people had started to flock to, rather than from, its shores in search of a better standard of living. Now, suffering along with much of the rest of the planet from the world financial system's Wile E. Coyote moment, and the sudden popping of a huge local real-estate bubble, Ireland's economy is plunging back to earth, and its young workers are making travel plans.

An abbreviated hourlong edition of "The Biggest Loser" on Tuesday attracted the series' highest ratings among adults 18 to 49 since its January premiere, helping NBC rank second in that demographic in the 8 p.m. time slot.
