A Quinnipiac poll released on Wednesday said that 55 percent of New York City voters wanted the mayor's control of the public schools to continue, echoing a similar poll last month that said 56 percent would keep the mayor in charge. Both numbers suggest significant change from last summer, when a Quinnipiac poll said 29 percent wanted to retain mayoral control and 55 percent said the mayor should share control of the schools with an independent school board.

Show after show this week in London, the Y.B.D.'s were designing like it was 1995. Topshop's Unique collection, in the hands of the stylist Katie Grand, mined the junkyard-rave aesthetic of the cult classic "Tank Girl" to mixed results. Charles Anastase's "autobiographical" collection paid homage to the unsung icons of grunge -- think the D.I.Y. style of Kelley and Kim Deal, of the alt-rock band the Breeders, and Rayanne Graff, the too-cool-for-school character played by A.J. Langer on the teen drama "My So-Called Life." Chances are that only the hipsters who crash his shows will be savvy enough to appreciate this.

My husband and I were married in July of 2008. He sold the house that he had lived in for six years in August of 2008. I sold the house that I lived in for seven years in February 2009. My question is: do we have to pay tax on capital gains on one of the houses since we will have sold more than one primary residence in two years? And if we do, does it matter which one we pay the gains on? In other words, can we choose which transaction we claim the exemption on?

On this date in 1935, Babe Ruth was released by the Yankees. He didn't finish his career in pinstripes, but he was forever immortalized at Yankee Stadium with a 4,700-pound ceremonial monument dedicated on April 19, 1949.

My friend is renting a house in Queens. She has a signed a lease that ends in about five years. The house went into foreclosure and is now owned by the bank. She came home to find a notice nailed on her front door stating that the house has been given to a company for liquidation. She is wondering what her rights are. Will there be an eviction process? How long does that generally take?

As the traveling fashion circus was preparing to pitch its tent in London, a group of men's-wear students from the city's Royal College of Art headed to the Brioni headquarters in Penne, Italy, for a master class on the art of the jacket. One of the students, Hanna Ter Meulen, shares her thoughts on the first few days. (Check back on Friday - Hanna will bring us up to speed on how the rest of the experience panned out.)

Olympus has added the creative capabilities of its E-30 DSLR camera to the new, more affordable E-620, an entry-level DLSR that will be available in May for a price of $700 (body only) or $800 with a Zuiko 14mm-42mm (equivalent) f3.5/5.6 lens.

After Friday's post on price-earnings ratios, I had a good e-mail exchange with a computer-science graduate student at the University of Iowa named Benton McCune. He agreed that a P/E ratio based on 10 years of prior corporate earnings is a good way to look at stock prices. But he said that when he did the calculation, he got a ratio of 13.5, not the 14.5 that I mentioned.

Federal officials provided new details of its plans to shore up major banks in the event of a sharper economic downturn and convert the government's preferred shares into common bank stock, The New York Times's Jack Healy reports.
Ben Bernanke's testimony over the past two days gives us our best clue yet about where the administration and the Fed are going with bank rescue. And the answer seems to be ... nowhere.

The Cubs are still slated for a sale, but the Tribune Company will not be putting its landmark office buildings in Chicago and Los Angeles on the block this spring as expected, because of the weak real estate market and the media company's bankruptcy filing late last year.

The calls for the government to take urgent and clarifying action on Citigroup are growing louder by the blogpost, and coming from pretty much all sectors of the commentariat. As the Opinionator noted yesterday, the Wall Street Journal has endorsed the idea, telling Obama to "get on with it."

Just wanted to draw your attention to an article in Dining today by Oliver Schwaner-Albright about Brooklyn's artisan food scene, which feels to me like way more than just a scene with each passing season. A fair amount has been written about Brooklyn restaurants (and I could add a few here that are also in the constellation of businesses described in the story: for starters, Diner and Marlow and Sons in Williamsburg, which share owners with the butcher shop Marlow and Daughters, and who produce a literary magazine, Diner Journal), but we haven't seen as much about small producers, the outlets for their output, and above all, the guiding ethos (and aesthetic) of it all. And, I can vouch, the food is very, very good.
Many Tibetans marked Losar, or the Tibetan New Year, on Wednesday by refraining from celebrations and remembering Tibetans who suffered in last year's government crackdown.

Updated | 5:19 p.m. A British court has sentenced a member of the House of Lords to 12 weeks in jail for reckless driving before a crash in which another motorist was killed. The case has attracted attention both because the defendant, Nazir Ahmed, is a peer, and because he has admitted that he was sending text messages while driving, just before being involved in the crash in which Martyn Gombar, a Slovakian living in England, was killed.

Following is the first set of answers from Christopher O. Ward, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. During his first year in the post, Mr. Ward has developed a detailed plan for the rebuilding of the World Trade Center and a $3.3 billion capital improvement plan for 2009. The plan includes starting construction of a new passenger rail tunnel under the Hudson River, improving airports to reduce passenger delays, completing environmental work for a new Goethals Bridge, and finishing the purchase of new PATH cars, which will begin service in a few weeks.

Monologue | Aired Tuesday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: President Obama gave his first speech to a joint session of Congress tonight. Obama focused on the three most critical things he wants Americans to understand: First, that the economy is in a lot of trouble; second, that the road to recovery won't be easy; and third, that it's all President Bush's fault.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- Sean Green, projected to be the Mets' primary set-up reliever, left their game against Baltimore in the first inning with a cut on the nail of his right middle finger. He motioned to the dugout after giving up a run-scoring single to Orioles cleanup hitter Ty Wigginton, a sharp grounder that went through the box but did not hit him. Out came Jerry Manuel and the trainer Ray Ramirez, and Green told them that he had felt discomfort a few pitches earlier. He was removed and replaced by Pedro Feliciano.

There is a vigilante dog-waste graffiti painter in Inwood on the Upper East Side, according to a new YouTube video put up by Stan O'Connor, a local tour guide. The vigilante is apparently going around after hours spray-painting dog droppings that are being left on the sidewalk, apparently in violation of New York's strict scooper laws.

Obviously, she's got style, but can she really sing? Check out Ditto's music video for "Coal to Diamonds" below. President Barack Obama said in his speech to Congress that the nation must address "the crushing cost of health care," with premiums having grown four times faster than wages in the past eight years and one million more Americans having lost health insurance each of those years. Reform won't be easy, he said, but it cannot wait another year.

The existing home sales numbers for January are being interpreted very differently than the December numbers were. A month ago, we heard that the sales rate ticked up and perhaps that was a sign of an improving market. Now we hear the rate hit a new low, and things are horrid again.

Canon has announced a compact snapshot printer that it says pumps out 4-by-6-inch photos in about 47 seconds. The Selphy CP780 looks a lot like its predecessor, the CP760, but Canon also says it will deliver better-quality prints.
Update | 1 p.m. It's official: The newest member of the First Family - the canine one - will move into the White House in April. And it will likely be a Portuguese water dog.
Renewed by the CW on Tuesday: the new series "90210." Also returning next season: "Gossip Girl," "One Tree Hill," "Smallville," "Supernatural" and "America's Next Top Model."
Macquarie, the big Australian investment bank, has recently hired three former Lehman Brothers bankers as it expands its presence in the United States.

This just in: Eddie Alterman has been named vice president and editor in chief of Car and Driver magazine, owned by Hachette Filipacchi Media U.S. Mr. Alterman has been a writer and editor for magazines and has most recently been a regular contributor to The New York Times, which published his review of the new Nissan 370Z last Sunday.
The sustainable crowd is thrilled and buzzing about the appointment of Kathleen Merrigan as Deputy Secretary of Agriculture. Check it out here, here and here.

One side effect of the downturn may well be more parents working from home. For some it will be involuntary - cobbling together a home business after losing an office job. For some it will be a way to save on the expenses of going elsewhere for work - no more office space to lease, no more commuting costs. And for many it will be a way to save on child care. Work during nap time, or play dates, or on wi-fi while watching karate practice. It can be done. Right? RIGHT?

Peter B. Madoff, the younger brother of disgraced financier Bernard L. Madoff, has been sued by Senator Frank R. Lautenberg's family foundation over his role in the vast Ponzi scheme that prosecutors say went on for years at Bernard L. Madoff Investment Securities.

One snowy New Year's Eve, in a cabin by Lake George in upstate New York, Dan Reingold, the 54-year-old C.E.O. of the Hebrew Home for Aged in Riverdale, shared a bottle of single-malt Scotch with a group of friends and asked them to imagine a nursing home that wouldn't make baby boomers like themselves say, "Over my dead body."
Simon Critchley is professor of philosophy at the New School for Social Research in New York. His latest book is "The Book of Dead Philosophers."

A Canadian nuclear facility that produces at least of half of the world's supply of medical isotopes has a long history of leaks and unanticipated maintenance delays. And little wonder. The reactor -- part of the Atomic Energy of Canada's Chalk River Laboratories in Eastern Ontario -- has been in operation for nearly 52 years.

The combination of olives and oranges is about as Mediterranean as it gets, and probably about as old. Fennel seeds and olive oil in this Minimalist column are natural additions -- fennel grows wild throughout the Mediterranean, and the olive yields its oil more easily than any other fruit, vegetable, or seed.

Updated, 3:05 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has finished his meeting with Republican chairmen and left after speaking briefly with reporters. His adviser Howard Wolfson took the lectern, speaking on behalf of the campaign. (Mr. Bloomberg rarely addresses the news media as a candidate, and his aides appear intent on keeping it that way.)

Ma, quale financial crisis? Mere mortals may be thinking of how to cut back expenses, but Roberto Cavalli is plotting new ways to expand his universe. His newest venture zeroes in on just what the world needs now: a Cavalli credit card, conceived in partnership with Mastercard, and embellished with a gold logo and a multihued, iridescent snakeskin print. (No word yet on whether high spenders will be able to upgrade to, say, crocodile or leopard.) The Italian designer will host a dinner this Sunday during Milan fashion week with special guests like Milla Jovovich, who will star with him in an Internet-only ad campaign, and Elizabeth Hurley.

Danny Cepero burst on the scene during the 2008 Major League Soccer season when he found himself starting in goal for the New York Red Bulls late in the season. And it was quite a professional debut when the native of Baldwin, N.Y., became the first M.L.S. goalkeeper to score a goal. Cepero went on to backstop the Red Bulls through two rounds of the playoffs before losing to Columbus in M.L.S. Cup '08.

The Bagger is always amazed when people (especially print journalists) whinge about the menace of bloggers. Finance | The "Gaussian copula function," conceived in 2000 by a math whiz who grew up in rural China, will go down in history as the mathematical formula that was Wall Street's undoing, an article says. It persuaded bankers that hugely complex risks -- all those mortgages bundled into securities -- could be gauged with ease and accuracy. But warnings about its limitations were largely ignored, and then everyone's number was up. [Wired]

The Bagger is in the air, typing on wireless provided by Virgin America. Which is kind of great, and kind of sad. In the past, the airplane seat was the one place he was off the grid and thinking long (and of course, deep) thoughts. Now the Web owns him even when he takes his seat back in steerage. The custom entertainment choices await, but the Bagger is too busy typing. And as long as he is on the grid, he did some extra-special supersonic surfing for your viewing pleasure. Just remember that the closest exit may behind you and should the cabin lose pressure, put on your own mask before assisting others.

Film | Stanley Kubrick's 1968 film "2001: a Space Odyssey" anticipated the space shuttle, stations in orbit and TV screens on the backs of aircraft passengers' seats, a blogger says. But it missed the mark with video phone booths; HAL the computer's human lip-reading, Pan Am product placement and meetings mercifully free of PowerPoint. What a fantasy. [Currybet]

Science | The bad old days are the good old days in our memories because they were something we eventually overcame, the sketchy neuroscience of nostalgia suggests. Updated Feb. 26 | Just last week, for East Siders across the river like me, it was still the forlorn "P____C___" sign. Suddenly it became "PE___C___," then "PE__I_C___." By Tuesday, it was an increasingly recognizable "PE_SI CO__." Soon the scrabbled and half-formed letters should spell out, once again, "PEPSI COLA," the familiar swirly logo emblazoning the Queens sky in ruby neon where it had been beckoning the thirsty since 1936.Like many New Yorkers, I missed the giant landmark after it was taken down during demolition of the longtime Pepsico bottling plant in Hunters Point on the East River in 1999. But the loss really hit home after I moved back to New York last summer and found an apt/w rv vu. The water view across the southern tip of Roosevelt Island would also have taken in the Pepsi sign - if there had still been a Pepsi sign. It had gone up briefly in a temporary location nearby -- then disappeared again.

In addition to his building at 17 East 79th Street, he now owns four of the six apartments at 19 East 79th, a white 1880 neo-Grec co-op town house.

Patrick McEnroe, the captain of the United States Davis Cup team, said that Andy Roddick, James Blake and the doubles team of the twins Bob and Mike Bryan would compete March 6-8 in Birmingham, Ala., in an opening-round match against Switzerland. Ken Anderson and Peter Windsor, the principals behind a new United States-based Formula One team called USF1, announced their intent Tuesday to run the 2010 schedule. An article on Jan. 28 about women who commiserated over dating Wall Street bankers caught in the financial crisis described a group they had formed, Dating a Banker Anonymous, as a support group. That is the name of their blog. Its creators originally told The Times that about 30 women had participated, but since publication, they have said that all involved were friends. Laney Crowell, one of the women who started the blog, said in the article that it was “very tongue in cheek;” she has since described it as a satire that embellishes true experiences for effect. Had the nature of the blog been made clear at the outset, the article would have described it accordingly, not as a support group.

An article on Tuesday about the first mention of penicillin in The New York Times misstated, at one point, the year that occurred. As the article correctly noted, the word first appeared in 1940, not 1922. (Alexander Fleming, the biologist who discovered penicillin, was first mentioned in the newspaper in 1922.).

The Critics’ Choice column on Monday, about new CDs, reversed the channels in which a listener hears the pianists Bebo and Chucho Valdés on the CD “Juntos Para Siempre.” Bebo Valdés is heard in the right channel, and Chucho, his son, in the left. The column also misstated Bebo Valdés’s age at the time of the recording sessions in 2007. He was 88, not 89.
Duke Ellington is the first black American to be prominently featured on a United States coin in circulation with the release of a quarter honoring the District of Columbia.

The TV Watch column in some editions on Monday, about the telecast of the Academy Awards ceremony, referred incorrectly to the movie “Mamma Mia!” in naming some of the films whose songs were used in a medley performed by Hugh Jackman and Beyoncé. It was not nominated for an Academy Award.

A music review on Monday about the pianist Christopher Taylor, at the Miller Theater, misidentified two of the “Goldberg” Variations by Bach in assessing Mr. Taylor’s decision to take an intermission in the work. It is Variation No. 16 — not 15 — that is a French overture and “proclaims a new beginning at the halfway point,” and it is No. 15 — not 14 — that “does not provide conclusion enough to justify a lengthy interruption.”.

The Cândido Godói Journal article on Monday, about the unexplained proliferation of twins born in the farming town of Cândido Godói in southern Brazil, misstated the type of twins usually associated with a genetic tendency of the mother. The Broadway musical that gave us “Ease On Down the Road” and may have inspired a vintage-1980s electronics retail chain is coming back: New York City Center announced that it would stage a revival of “The Wiz” as its Encores! Summer Stars production. The original musical, a modern-day retelling of L. Frank Baum’s “Wonderful Wizard of Oz” with an African-American cast, won seven Tony Awards, including best musical, in 1975. The Encores! revival will be directed by Thomas Kail and choreographed by Andy Blankenbuehler (who collaborated on “In the Heights”), and is scheduled to run from June 12 through July 3. No casting has been announced.

This is why they call him the Boss: Ticketmaster agreed to change its sales policies after more than 2,000 Bruce Springsteen fans and Mr. Springsteen himself complained about Ticketmaster’s practices, the New Jersey attorney general’s office said in a news release. Earlier this month many customers said that when they tried to buy tickets from Ticketmaster.com for Mr. Springsteen’s May 21 and 23 concerts in East Rutherford, N.J., they were instead directed to TicketsNow.Com, a resale site owned by Ticketmaster, where tickets were offered at far more than their face value. In a statement at the time, Mr. Springsteen said he was “furious” about “the abuse of our fans and our trust by Ticketmaster.” As part of its settlement, Ticketmaster will create a wall between its site and TicketsNow.com for one year, and establish a lottery in which fans who filed complaints could buy tickets to Mr. Springsteen’s New Jersey shows.

The widely anticipated new musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark,” below, with music and lyrics by Bono and the Edge and directed by Julie Taymor (“The Lion King”), took a big swing toward a Broadway debut on Tuesday: the producers announced that the show would begin previews on Jan. 16 at the Hilton Theater. The musical, produced by Hello Entertainment/David Garfinkle, Martin McCallum, Marvel Entertainment and Sony Pictures Entertainment, is to open on Feb. 18. The legal dispute between Jackson Browne and Senator John McCain over Mr. Browne’s song “Running on Empty” will keep running: a federal judge in California has denied motions filed by Mr. McCain and the Republican National Committee to halt a lawsuit brought against them by Mr. Browne, according to court documents. Mr. Browne said in his suit that Mr. McCain and the committee had infringed on his copyrights by using “Running on Empty” in a presidential campaign commercial without Mr. Browne’s permission. Mr. McCain and the committee had argued that First Amendment and fair-use rules permitted the use because the song occurred in a political context, but Judge R. Gary Klausner was unconvinced. Judge Klausner also set a late-April date for a hearing to set a schedule for a jury trial.

The National Football League Players Association, locked in a contentious selection process for its next executive director, announced Tuesday that it had hired outside legal counsel to investigate allegations against one of the three finalists for the job. Chip Yablonski, a longtime counsel to the players union and other labor groups, will look into concerns, first reported by SI.com, that Troy Vincent, a former president of the union who played for 15 seasons, might have released confidential information about player agents. The union will select the successor to Gene Upshaw, who died in August, during a mid-March meeting.

FEUERSTEIN--Moses. The Orthodox Union, its lay leadership and staff, its network of member synagogues, and its youth movement, NCSY, extend their condolences to the family of Mr. Moses Feuerstein, of blessed memory, of Brookline, MA. As a former OU president, Mr. Feuerstein was one of the visionary leaders of our organization, who anticipated the needs of Orthodoxy in America, and who foresaw its phenomenal growth. His contributions to that growth are of historic proportions and will be prominently recorded in the annals of American Jewry. We offer our sympathy to his widow, Mrs. Shirley Feuerstein, and to his children, Rabbi Mordechai Feuerstein, Henry Feuerstein, Joanne Greer and Esther Zemelman, and to the extended family, all of whom carry on Mr. Feuerstein's noble tradition. Stephen J. Savitsky, President Rabbi Tzvi Hersh Weinreb, Exec VP

Wall Street bounced back on Tuesday from its lowest levels in nearly 12 years after the chairman of the Federal Reserve tamped down investor fears that the government would nationalize major banks. ''We are committed to ensuring the viability of all major financial institutions,'' the Fed chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, told the Senate Banking Committee. His reassurance on nationalization followed earlier statements from the White House that supported a privately held banking system.

DUFFY--Peter J.,aged 92 years peacefully at home on February 21, 2009. Loving husband of Marguerite. Beloved father of Peter Jr. (Eleanor). Predeceased by beloved wife Florence and daughter Theresa. Grandfather of Maria, Patrick, Tobie and Peter. Great-grandfather of Brittany and Peter. Dear brother of Margaret Cronin and Uncle of Jimmy Smith (Teri) as well as numerous nieces and nephews. Loving brother-in-law of Julie Locascio and Clark Hild (Elly). Longtime member of the NYAC and Atlantic Beach Club. Peter was a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre, Knight of St. Patrick and Friendly Son of St. Patrick. Peter started out delivering telegrams for Western Union to the fur district as a teenager. He started Peter Duffy Furs in 1950 and was proud to be the only Irishman in the fur business. Peter had an engaging, charismatic personality and those who knew him recognized his uniqueness. He faced the end of his life with a big smile everyday as well as tremendous strength and courage. He will be dearly missed by all his family, friends and employees whose souls he touched and will forever be in their hearts. Visitation Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 & 7-9pm at John Krtil Funeral Home, Inc., 1297 1st Avenue, NYC (69-70th Street). Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10am at St. Joseph's of Yorkville Church, 404 East 87th Street. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory preferred to: SNACK for Autistic Children, 220 East 86th Street NYC 10028 or the Frances Pope Foundation, 401 East 81st Street, NYC 10028.

ELLIMAN--Edward S.,son of Douglas L. and Katherine Scales Elliman, aged 85, died of cancer on February 20. He was born on March 4, 1923 and raised in New York City. After graduating from St. Paul's School in 1941, he enlisted in the U.S. Navy at the start of World War II, serving as a First Class Signalman on the USS Doyle. He took part in the landings of Salerno, Normandy (D-Day) and southern France, and also saw action in North Africa. After the war, he spent his entire business career in New York City real estate, becoming president of Douglas Gibbons Hollyday and Ives, Douglas L. Elliman and Company, and Elliman and Penn. In his 40+ year business career, he specialized in cooperative conversions, property management, and wholesale brokerage. Married to the former Ann Rockefeller, he lived for most of his adult life in Greenwich, Connecticut and had three sons--Edward H. (Ted), David D., and Christopher J. (Kim)--seven grandchildren--Westyn, Devon, Dascher, Isabel, Henry, Theodore, and Claire--and three daughters-in-law--Alice, Andrea, and Nicole. He pursued racquet sports, sailing, and rowing with a passion, interests which he happily shared with his family. An avid reader, he particularly enjoyed histories of the Civil War, classical Greece and Rome, and World War II. He also loved to sing and recite the poetry of Shakespeare, Kipling, and Sir Walter Scott. He had a lifelong association with St. Paul's School and for 50 years served on the Board of Christodora, a New York City foundation that operates outdoor education programs for city youth. Personable and gregarious, he enjoyed a wide range of friends and colleagues. He was proud of and devoted to his family, as they will always be to him. A Memorial Service will be held at the Christ Church Chapel, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT at 11:30am on Saturday, February 28. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Edward S. Elliman Scholarship Fund, Christodora Foundation, 1 East 53rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10022 or to St. Paul's School, 325 Pleasant Street, Concord, NH 03301.

SIMMONS--Robert Kurt, co-founder of The Simmons Group of Companies, died peacefully February 20 at his home in New York City at age 65. He is survived by his wife Deborah, son Marc, and mother Dorothy. Robert was educated at NYU and Berkeley, where he graduated with an MBA. As co-founder of The Simmons Group of Companies, he established businesses in Hong Kong, China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Korea, Thailand, Indonesia and the U.S. He was the first American to establish a toy factory in China. His philanthropic work included donating and raising funds for The Children's Brain Tumor Foundation, as well as donating and raising funds for a network of 32 schools in rural areas of China and establishing a scholarship program for minorities in Hong Kong. His devotion to his family, his business acumen and his kindness in charitable endeavors will be remembered by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held on Friday, February 27th at 9:00am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York City with interment immediately following at King David Memorial Gardens, Putnam Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Children's Brain Tumor Foundation, 274 Madison Ave., New York City 10016.

EYRE--Henry Norman "Jim", Jr.,78, of Manhattan and Columbia County, NY, passed with grace and dignity Saturday, February 21, at his home in New York City. Jim was a longtime resident of Farmington, CT, with his late wife Barbara Blount Eyre and their four children. A graduate of Taft ('48) and Yale ('52), Jim held positions in sales, advertising and construction management until 1973, when he acquired the W.T. Whale Co. in Hartford, CT. As President and CEO, he built it into one of the area's premier fine homebuilders and commercial construction companies. Following his wife's death of cancer in 1993, Jim married Ruth Scott von Wiesenthal of New York in 1997. Since 2001, Jim was a board member of the Columbia County Historical Society, founder and editor of the magazine Columbia County History & Heritage, and tireless champion of the capital campaign to restore the Vanderpoel House as a center for Columbia County history. In 2006, Jim was appointed a Trustee of the New York State Archives Partnership Trust. Jim is survived by his beloved wife Ruth Scott Eyre; sisters Elizabeth E. Taylor and Jane E. Repp; sister-in- law Madeleine D. Blount; children Lucy Lindeyer, Leigh Eyre, William Eyre, Melanie Christie and eight grandchildren. A memorial service is scheduled for 11am Saturday, February 28, at the Dutch Reformed Church, 88 Route 9H, Claverack, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Jim Eyre Memorial Fund, Columbia County Historical Society, P.O. Box 311, Kinderhook, NY 12106.

MY pipes froze. I had shoveled 1,350 linear feet of snow in the last five months. I wanted soup. If it's damp, I haul out the soup pot. Usually I prefer water-based vegetable soups, because I think stock muddies the flavor. Besides, no matter how easy it is to simmer a few bones with an onion and a carrot, I hardly ever do it. To me, making stock is a hassle, and antithetical to home cooking. It belongs to the realm of professional kitchens with salaried dishwashers.

The Officers and the Board of Directors of Christodora, Inc. mourn the passing of our esteemed President Emeritus, a colleague and friend whose life personified service to his family, city, and country. His wise leadership and dedicated service to Christodora for over fifty years touched the lives of the youth of this City by introducing them to the glories and challenges of the natural world. Tatiana B. Pouschine, Chair Katrina Cary, Director

Stern-faced and silent, the actor Jeremy Piven entered the Actors’ Equity building at 11:15 a.m. today for the grievance hearing over his sudden departure from the Broadway revival of “Speed-the-Plow,” leaving a bevy of entertainment and theater reporters waiting for his views on this unusual fight with theater producers.

A panel convened by the Writers Guild of America met with Jay Leno on Wednesday as part of a disciplinary process stemming from the guild’s strike, Variety reported. The WGA West is reviewing whether Mr. Leno, the “Tonight” show host and a member of the guild, violated its rules by continuing to deliver his monologues on the show while the guild was on strike. The strike began on Nov. 5, 2007, and concluded on Feb. 12, 2008; “Tonight” was in reruns until Jan. 2, 2008, at which point Mr. Leno resumed performing monologues, which he composed without his writers. Mr. Leno supported the strike, and paid his staff’s salaries out of his out pocket during it. The guild could punish Mr. Leno with a fine, suspension or expulsion if it deems he broke its rules.

On a day when theater observers were largely focused on performers who had exited Broadway, Robin Williams announced that he’d be returning to the Great White Way. Mr. Williams, the frenetic comedian and actor (of “Good Will Hunting” fame and “Patch Adams” infamy) will be bringing his one-man show, “Weapons of Self-Destruction,” which he has been performing around the country, to the Neil Simon Theater, the show’s producers James L. Nederlander and Ron Delsener announced in a news release. The show, which will be performed on April 28 and 29, and from May 1 to 3, marks Mr. Williams’s first appearance on Broadway since 2002; it follows in the footsteps of Will Ferrell‘s one-man show, “You’re Welcome America. A Final Night with George W Bush,” which has been a box-office hit at the Cort Theater.

Joseph O’Neill’s novel “Netherland” was named the winner of the 2009 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction, the PEN/Faulkner Foundation said on Wednesday. The honor for “Netherland,” about a Dutch-born equities analyst, his British wife and their son, who live in New York during the Sept. 11 attack and its aftermath, is something of a comeback for Mr. O’Neill. The novel, though widely praised, was shut out in the National Book Awards and the National Book Critics Circle awards. The PEN/Faulkner Award, which comes with a prize of $15,000, will be given to Mr. O’Neill at a ceremony on May 9. Four finalists, who will receive $5,000 each, were also named. They are Sarah Shun-lien Bynum for “Ms. Hempel Chronicles,” Susan Choi for “A Person of Interest,” Richard Price for “Lush Life” and Ron Rash for “Serena.”

Giving new meaning to long-term commitment, Samuel L. Jackson has signed a deal with Marvel Studios to portray the character Nick Fury, the eye-patch-wearing leader of the fictional espionage agency S.H.I.E.L.D., in as many as nine movies, Variety reported. The films, based around various Marvel Comics superheroes, would include “Iron Man 2,” “Captain America,” “Thor” and the hero team-up movie “The Avengers,” as well as potential sequels. A release date of May 7, 2010, is planned for “Iron Man 2.”
On this week’s Popcast, a focus on Latin music: Ben Ratliff reviews “Juntos Para Siempre” by Bebo and Chucho Valdés and Portuguese Fado singer Mariza performs in our studio.

That old devil moon will soon be rising over Jim Norton, Kate Baldwin and Cheyenne Jackson; they’ve been cast in New York City Center’s coming Encores! production of “Finian’s Rainbow,” City Center said. The revival of the offbeat — to say the least — musical will star Mr. Norton, a Tony Award-winner for “The Seafarer” and Ms. Baldwin (“Wonderful Town”) as Finian and Sharon McLonergan, the father and daughter who bring their stolen pot of leprechaun’s gold to the fictional state of Missitucky. Mr. Jackson (Broadway’s “Xanadu”) will play Sharon’s Missituckian suitor, Woody. The Encores! production will be directed and choreographed by Warren Carlyle with music direction by Rob Berman. It is scheduled to run from March 26 through March 29. A leprechaun has not yet been announced.

Updated By a vote of 61-37, the Senate passed a bill providing full voting representation for the nation's capital in the House of Representatives, nearly ensuring that the measure will become law this time around. While advocates were declaring victory already, a court fight almost definitely looms over the constitutionality of giving the District of Columbia voting privileges in the House that are akin to those of the 50 states.

The developer Bruce C. Ratner chalked up a legal victory for his proposed Atlantic Yards development in Brooklyn on Thursday when a state appellate court ruled against opponents who had challenged the $4 billion project on environmental grounds.In the opinion, the court agreed with a lower State Supreme Court decision that the state had acted properly in reviewing and approving the project, which includes an arena for the Nets and up to 6,000 apartments on 22 acres. Still, the project has a number of other roadblocks to clear, including another lawsuit, before it can break ground.

Several authors of the 2007 report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on the projected effects of global warming now say they regret not pushing harder to include an updated diagram of climate risks in the report. The diagram, known as "burning embers," is an updated version of one that was a central feature of the panel's preceding climate report in 2001. The main opposition to including the diagram in 2007, they say, came from officials representing the United States, China, Russia and Saudi Arabia.

Economy | Never mind F.D.R.; Obama should take a lesson from Germany, a German columnist says -- no, not so much from Weimar's cautionary prewar hyperinflation, but from the handiwork of Ludwig Erhard, father of the country's postwar Wirtschaftswunder ("economic miracle"). Erhard's debt-averse, sacrifice-heavy model "not only functions differently from F.D.R.'s, it also smells different -- namely of sweat." Miracle? As the self-effacing Erhard liked to say, "There are no miracles." [Spiegel]

There's more to Milan coffee than just Cova. In fact, a handful of grand old-school bars have been cranking out flawless cappuccinos on buttercup damask tablecloths for nearly a century. Even the Neapolitans (big-time coffee snobs), who practically get a nosebleed when they come North, agree that Milan boasts some highly decent crushed beans. These traditional bars are the best places to ingest coffee in the city, but they are also great places to pop in for a quick lunch or preshow aperitivo. Here, the coffee is as smooth as silk, and a glass of spumante costs less than a Coca-Cola.

| More than 52 million people watched President Obama's first address to a joint session of Congress in prime time on Tuesday. Ormonde Jayne is a niche London perfume house run by its creator, an attractive, well-presented Englishwoman named Linda Pilkington. Pilkington has a keenly refined sense of visual design - the jewel-box store at 28 Old Bond Street is painfully chic (onyx lacquered surfaces and exquisitely wrapped scents, fragranced lotions and candles) - but she also has business acumen. For one, she has picked the perfumer Geza Schöen to build her scents from the olfactory blueprints she creates, and Schöen is a fragrance wizard operating at the top of his game. For another, the Ormonde Jayne collection has managed to bottle mesmerizing strangeness that stays, just barely at times, this side of unwearable art scents. Isfarkand is a marvelously startling peppery gas, and Champaca, the translucent smell of (this is more literal than metaphorical) the bamboo-ish leaves of emerald-green rice plants in their watery fields. If anyone creates a perfume collection a century from now, it will quite possibly resemble Ormonde Jayne's.

It’s official: Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) has been No. 1 for a total of 10 weeks, longer than any album released this decade has been. The last album to have so long a run at No. 1 was Santana’s “Supernatural,” with 12 weeks there in 1999 and 2000. The biggest debut on this week’s Billboard chart is “Uncle Charlie” (Jive) by Charlie Wilson, the lead singer of the Gap Band (“You Dropped a Bomb on Me”). “Uncle Charlie,” with guest appearances by Snoop Dogg, Jamie Foxx and T-Pain, sold 58,000 copies last week to reach No. 2. The Fray’s self-titled second album, on Epic Records, reached No. 3 with 53,000. Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) reached No. 4 with 43,000 sales, and Beyoncé’s “I Am ... Sasha Fierce” (Columbia) is No. 5 with 41,000. Robert Plant and Alison Krauss’s “Raising Sand” (Rounder), which got a big bump last week thanks to its five Grammy wins, fell seven spots to No. 9 with 32,000 sales, a 58 percent decline from last week.

Fun as it may be to stay at the Y.M.C.A., the Village People will not need to reside there any time soon. The band will be allowed to keep performing while a lawsuit filed against it by one of its founding members is resolved. In a news release a spokesman for the band and its promoters, Sixuvus Ltd., said that a San Diego judge had granted a preliminary injunction in a suit filed by Victor Willis, the original lead singer and police officer of the campy disco group. In his suit Mr. Willis said that the resuscitated group, which he left in 1979, was using his likeness and voice in its performances; he also named the William Morris Agency and Can’t Stop Productions, which owns the trademark to the band’s name, as defendants.

Days after their visit to the Academy Awards, two child stars of “Slumdog Millionaire” have learned they will be moved from a desolate section of Mumbai to new government housing, BBC News reported. Azharuddin Mohammed Ismail, 10, and Rubina Ali Qureshi, 9 (both above with the film’s director, Danny Boyle), who played young incarnations of the characters Salim and Latika in the Oscar-winning film, will be moved from the Garib Nagar slum in Mumbai to houses allocated by the city’s government. The chairman of the local housing association, Amarjeet Singh Manhas, said, “Since the children have made the nation proud, they must be given free houses,” according to the BBC. The plight of the young actors of “Slumdog Millionaire” had prompted an international outcry; the movie’s producers and Mr. Boyle have said that the children were tutored and paid three times an average Indian adult’s salary while working on the film.

Saudi Arabia is notoriously change-averse, but four years after assuming the crown, King Abdullah may finally be ready to fulfill his promise to lead his country toward greater tolerance and modernity. We welcome his decision to name several reformers to top posts in his government -- and his even more surprising decision to oust certain hard-line leaders of the country's powerful religious establishment. We hope it means that Saudi Arabia will soon grant full civil and legal rights to women and all who reside in the kingdom.

Author of works on Boris Vian, Raymond Radiguet, and Jacques Prevert, translator and talented musician, he is remembered for his place in the cultural life of New York City and for his contributions to Franco-American cultural exchange. Francine Goldenhar Director, La Maison Francaise Tom Bishop Director, Center for French Civilization and Culture

An Estonian court convicted a former high-ranking security official of treason on Wednesday for passing delicate information from the Estonian government and NATO to Russia, in a case that has heightened fears of a continued security threat by Russian intelligence networks in Europe. Herman Simm, the former head of the National Security Authority, was sentenced to 12 and a half years in prison ''for passing secret state and foreign state information,'' said Gerrit Maeselu, a spokesman for the Estonian prosecutor's office. ''We think that he started working for Russian intelligence in 1995,'' Mr. Maeselu said in a telephone interview, adding that Mr. Simm, 61, was in a position to hand over intelligence on NATO starting in 2001, when Estonia began accession talks with the alliance in earnest. Estonia joined NATO in 2004.

Only rarely does one solution solve a lot of problems. One that does -- or at least could -- is New York's Bigger Better Bottle Bill. Potentially one of the most productive items on Albany's legislative menu, the bill would expand the list of cans and bottles that could be redeemed for a nickel. It would include bottles used for noncarbonated and nonalcoholic beverages, such as water, sports drinks and juice. The bill would reduce litter in rivers and on highways, encourage recycling, save on natural resources and help replenish environmental programs whose budgets have been cut during the economic downturn.

To the casual eye, the basement of this city's Firehouse 9 looks like a jumble of old hydrants, Dr Pepper cartons, rakes and random gear. To specialists in energy efficiency, the 1960s-era building is a mess of a different sort: wasteful hot water heaters for the firefighters' showers, ancient refrigerators and outdated lights. Wrapping up an elaborate energy audit, Knoxville is about to find out which of 99 city buildings are wasting the most energy. It hopes to begin repairs this summer, just in time to catch a tsunami of federal stimulus money earmarked for such unglamorous tasks as replacing light bulbs and fixing leaky insulation.

Prime Minister Ehud Olmert reinstated Israel's special envoy to Egypt in its mediation efforts for truce talks with Hamas. The envoy, Amos Gilad, left, formally apologized for having criticized Mr. Olmert and the government in a newspaper interview over their insistence that there could be no cease-fire with Hamas until it released a captured Israeli soldier, Gilad Shalit. In Cairo, talks began between the Palestinian rival factions Fatah and Hamas with the aim of forming a national unity government.

Three people apparently using an incendiary device set themselves and their car on fire on Wednesday as police officers approached them at a prominent street crossing in central Beijing. The motive was unclear, but officials said in a written statement that the three had apparently come from outside the Chinese capital ''to appeal for personal issues.'' The statement said two of the three people were hurt in the fire, which tied up an intersection of the Wangfujing shopping street near Tiananmen Square for more than two hours. The statement, from the Beijing Municipal Public Security Bureau, said that police officers stopped a suspicious-looking automobile with ''out of Beijing'' license plates around 2:50 p.m. and that a fire erupted inside the vehicle as they tried to examine it.

A long-term contract announced Wednesday by the Giants and their star running back Brandon Jacobs could keep Jacobs with the team for up to four years and pay him as much as $25 million. At the very least, Jacobs is guaranteed $13 million and is certain to be a Giant in 2009.

Iran tested a reactor at its first nuclear power plant on Wednesday, and said it was planning to expand its uranium enrichment program nearly tenfold, despite intense international pressure over the program. The head of the Atomic Energy Organization, Reza Aghazadeh, said all parts of the reactor at the nuclear power plant in the southern port of Bushehr had worked smoothly. ''We celebrate today and are assured that we are getting closer to making the reactor operational,'' he said, according to the news agency ISNA. Mr. Aghazadeh also brushed off a report by the United Nations nuclear agency last week saying that Iran had slowed down its efforts to expand its enrichment program.

SIMMONS--Robert Kurt, co-founder of The Simmons Group of Companies, died peacefully February 20 at his home in New York City at age 65. He is survived by his wife Deborah, son Marc, and mother Dorothy. Robert was educated at NYU and Berkeley, where he graduated with an MBA. As co-founder of The Simmons Group of Companies, he established businesses in Hong Kong, China, Taiwan, the Philippines, Korea, Thailand, Indonesia and the U.S. He was the first American to establish a toy factory in China. His philanthropic work included donating and raising funds for The Children's Brain Tumor Foundation, as well as donating and raising funds for a network of 32 schools in rural areas of China and establishing a scholarship program for minorities in Hong Kong. His devotion to his family, his business acumen and his kindness in charitable endeavors will be remembered by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held on Friday, February 27th at 9:00am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St., New York City with interment immediately following at King David Memorial Gardens, Putnam Valley, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Children's Brain Tumor Foundation, 274 Madison Ave., New York City 10016.

Calling Mexican drug trafficking organizations ''a national security threat,'' Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. announced Wednesday that federal authorities had mounted their biggest assault against one of Mexico's most powerful drug cartels. DUFFY--Peter J.,aged 92 years peacefully at home on February 21, 2009. Loving husband of Marguerite. Beloved father of Peter Jr. (Eleanor). Predeceased by beloved wife Florence and daughter Theresa. Grandfather of Maria, Patrick, Tobie and Peter. Great-grandfather of Brittany and Peter. Dear brother of Margaret Cronin and Uncle of Jimmy Smith (Teri) as well as numerous nieces and nephews. Loving brother-in-law of Julie Locascio and Clark Hild (Elly). Longtime member of the NYAC and Atlantic Beach Club. Peter was a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre, Knight of St. Patrick and Friendly Son of St. Patrick. Peter started out delivering telegrams for Western Union to the fur district as a teenager. He started Peter Duffy Furs in 1950 and was proud to be the only Irishman in the fur business. Peter had an engaging, charismatic personality and those who knew him recognized his uniqueness. He will be dearly missed by all his family, friends and employees whose souls he touched and will forever be in their hearts. It has been old home week all season on ''ER,'' the long-running NBC series, as former stars have returned to make their final rounds at County General Hospital before its doors close this spring after 15 years. George Clooney, Julianna Margulies, Anthony Edwards, Noah Wyle and others have showed up for star turns in front of the cameras, in episodes already broadcast or leading up to the series finale on April 2. Just as in a real hospital, it is these doctors and nurses who make the dramatic decisions and who have gotten most of the recognition and glory for the success of the series, which has won 22 Emmys.
INTERNATIONAL Memo From Cairo

THE release this week of Amazon's Kindle 2 has put electronic book readers in the spotlight. Its proponents celebrate the ability to store thousands of titles on a single lightweight device; the access to newspapers, magazines and blogs while on the go; and the ability, at the click of a button, to own one of hundreds of thousands of titles in seconds. I'm not sure I buy it. I'm a book person. A real-book person. I like to hold books. Thumb through their pages. I even like the smell of them. So while I appreciate technology in all its forms, I approached the latest crop of e-book readers with no small amount of skepticism.

For the mother of a police officer killed during a traffic stop two years ago, a judge's words on Wednesday finally produced a measure of relief. Inside a courtroom at State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, Justice Plummer E. Lott sentenced Dexter Bostic to life in prison without the possibility of parole for firing two fatal gunshots into the face of Officer Russel Timoshenko.

Two bronze heads originally looted from China were sold Wednesday night for a total of nearly $35.9 million without commissions, after fierce but futile protests from China and a failed legal challenge to the auction. The bronze heads were bought by anonymous bidders on the telephone, but the winning bids on both pieces were taken by the same Christie's employee, Thomas Seydoux, suggesting that the buyer might be the same person. But Mr. Seydoux said later that he did not know who the buyers were.

Representative Barney Frank, the chairman of the powerful House Financial Services Committee, is not a fan of stadium naming-rights deals like the Mets' Citi Field agreement or the corporate hospitality that is a hallmark of sports sponsorships. ''Marketing expenses should be for real marketing, not ego boosts, which is what I think naming rights are,'' Frank, a Democrat from Massachusetts, said Wednesday in a telephone interview. ''Important men, in particular, like to hang out and ingratiate themselves with sports figures, and after the fact try to figure out how to make sense of the sponsorships as marketing or economic development.''

The latest record store to close in New York is a big one: the Virgin Megastore in Union Square. Following its announcement last month that the Times Square Megastore would close down in April, Virgin Entertainment Group North America will shut down the Union Square shop in late May or early June, a spokeswoman said, confirming a report in Billboard. Virgin will also close its Market Street store in San Francisco in April. The New York closures will leave Manhattan without a large-scale record store. Thousands of music retailers have shut down in recent years as CD sales have plunged, and Virgin has been closing most of its locations around the country since it was bought by the real estate companies Vornado and Related in 2007, but its high-traffic New York stores were said to be profitable.

An ambitious mixed-media project intended to pay tribute to Stephen Sondheim and eyed for a possible Broadway run has been canceled before its out-of-town tryout was able to be staged. In a statement, the Alliance Theater of Atlanta said that “iSondheim: aMusical Revue” had been canceled because of difficulties in raising money for the project. The project was to have featured music written by Mr. Sondheim for shows including “Gypsy,” “West Side Story” and “Sweeney Todd”; it was to have been directed by James Lapine, who collaborated with Mr. Sondheim on shows including “Into the Woods” and “Sunday in the Park with George.” In a statement, the Frankel/Viertel/Baruch/Routh group of producers said, “The show’s extensive technical requirements for film and multi-media projection required raising what proved to be an extraordinarily large amount of additional money; millions, actually, which was simply unavailable for a non-commercial production in the current economic climate.”The Times’s interactive feature Listening to Sondheim can be found here.

Given where many baseball players have found assistance, the idea of a professional slugger who needs help from Satan to win the World Series seems almost quaint. Nonetheless, a new movie version of the musical “Damn Yankees” is rounding the bases and heading for theaters, Variety reported. This film will star Jake Gyllenhaal as Joe Boyd, the devoted baseball fan whose Faustian bargain transforms him into the pennant-clinching Joe Hardy; Jim Carrey will play Mr. Applegate, the salesman who also happens to be the devil. No casting for the lost soul Lola has been announced. The original stage production of “Damn Yankees” featured a book by George Abbott and Douglass Wallop and music and lyrics by Richard Adler and Jerry Ross; the 1958 film version starred Tab Hunter, Gwen Verdon and Ray Walston.

Peter Scarlet has stepped down from his role as the artistic director of the Tribeca Film Festival, the festival said. Mr. Scarlet, who was promoted to artistic director in 2007, had previously been director of the San Francisco Film Festival and the Cinémathèque Française in Paris before joining the Tribeca festival, which was founded in 2002 by Robert De Niro, Jane Rosenthal and Craig Hatkoff. Earlier this month, Geoffrey Gilmore, the director of the Sundance Film Festival, left that post to become the creative director of Tribeca Enterprises, the parent company of the Tribeca festival; at that time, Mr. Scarlet was expected to remain in an expanded role. In a statement, Mr. Scarlet said, “I realized simply that it’s time for me to seek new challenges.” The Tribeca Film Festival will announce its 2009 programming lineup on March 9.
Wisdom, insights and random observations from this weekend’s Arts & Leisure section. (Click on links for complete stories.)

Rounding out a week in which art institutions around the country were beset by budget cuts and job losses, the Indianapolis Museum of Art said that it would undergo a restructuring that includes reductions in staff and operating expenses. The museum said that it would cut its personnel by 10 percent, including the elimination of 15 full-time and 6 part-time positions; additionally, it said that 10 senior staff members including its director and chief executive would donate 3 percent of their salaries back to the museum. The museum, which offers free general admission, has seen its endowment decline to $281 million from $382 million since the fall; it receives less than 1 percent of its budget from local and state government.

The real competitive threat to “I Love You, Man,” the male-bonding comedy set for release by Paramount and DreamWorks on March 20, may not be “Duplicity,” the Julia Roberts–Clive Owen caper expected from Universal on the same day. After all, goofy guys and a gal on a con should find plenty of space in the famous four quadrants of the theatrical audience.

After a hearing on Thursday at which the Actors’ Equity Association and the Broadway League did not penalize Jeremy Piven for his abrupt departure from the Broadway show “Speed-the-Plow,” the play’s producers said on Friday that they would file for arbitration. In a statement, Jeffrey Richards, the show’s lead producer said, “The grievance went as expected yesterday. The grievance committee (made up of League and Equity representatives) did not rule for either side and we will be filing for arbitration as provided by our contract.” According to Actors’ Equity rules, an arbitrator from a designated board of nine members will hear the case, with the hearing to commence, if possible, within 30 days of a written demand. Mr. Piven has said that he departed the show while suffering from mercury poisoning, which frequently left him exhausted, and which he said he contracted from eating fish twice a day for 20 years.

Davis, of carrying out a "massive Ponzi scheme" over the last decade, in which they misappropriated funds and made more than $1.6 billion in "bogus" loans to Mr. Stanford.

Heston Blumenthal, one of the most acclaimed chefs in the world, has temporarily closed his restaurant the Fat Duck in Bray, England, after an apparent food poisoning scare.

The United States government could be giving up a big chunk of change by converting its dividend-yielding preferred shares in Citigroup to common stock, which carries no dividend. The lost income to taxpayers could total about $10 billion in today's dollars, or even more.

8020 Media, the innovative publisher behind the reader-generated photography journal JPG Magazine, has found a second life with new owners. Last month, its old backer, Minor Ventures, pulled the plug on the magazine, which solicited photo contributions from its readers and published a bimonthly print edition.

Amazon announced today that it would let publishers decide whether they want the new Kindle e-book device to read their books aloud.

Sumner M. Redstone, the media mogul who controls both Viacom and CBS, reached a deal with banks on Friday that gives him two more years to pay down some $1.46 billion in debt without having to sell more stock in either company, his family holding company, National Amusements, said in a statement.

Fox's "American Idol" and "Hell's Kitchen" lifted the network to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday. According to Nielsen's estimates, "Idol" led its 8 p.m. time slot with 20.7 million viewers, enough to compensate for "Hell's Kitchen" drawing a much smaller audience of 9.9 million at 9 p.m.

For years, sailing enthusiasts from around the country have gathered in the main hall -- known as the model room -- of the New York Yacht Club on West 44th Street in Midtown Manhattan for an awards ceremony to honor the Rolex Yachtsman and Yachtswoman of the year. These awards, given by U.S. Sailing, are among the nation's top sailing distinctions.
Traveling cheaply is one thing. Traveling cheaply, in a foreign country, with an infant in tow is another. But Italy proved surprisingly hospitable to a family of three.

On a cold, damp afternoon in January, from deep within the halls of the Palazzo Ducale, a cry rang out. It echoed through the immense Chamber of the Great Council, where 2,000 Venetian noblemen once directed the course of their empire beneath Tintoretto's immense "Vision of Paradise." It carried up the intricate, gilt-encrusted stucco carvings of the Golden Staircase to the doge's own apartments. It pealed out even into the Piazza San Marco, whose paving stones were slicked a shiny gray from persistent drizzle.

You may remember that I invited Bill O'Reilly to travel to Darfur, to give him something justified to rant about. When he balked, I tried to help him out by holding a sponsorship drive for him. My favorite way to look at photographs is by leafing through homemade albums. The captions are fanciful, the order is significant, the material is diverse. Good albums communicate a private urgency, and occasionally you even hit on something sinister, as when an ex-wife is conspicuously missing or a blacklisted face has been cropped out. For decades, a growing network of scrappers in America has refined and updated English commonplace books and turned scrapbooking into folk art.

The Esquires barbershop manages to be at once high class and down home. Customers can get an old-fashioned trim on the one hand, touched up with warm shaving cream and a straight razor like in any neighborhood shop, and also a manicure.

This week, Dr. John Mulhall, director of the Male Sexual and Reproductive Medicine Program at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, has been taking questions on the Well blog about what to expect following treatment for prostate cancer. Today, Dr. Mulhall, author of Saving Your Sex Life: A Guide for Men With Prostate Cancer, answers questions about exploring treatment options, effects of treatment on erectile function and penile rehabilitation after cancer treatments. Next week, Dr. Mulhall will answer questions about testosterone, alternative remedies and implants, and other treatments to restore sexual function.

Following is the third and final set of answers from Christopher O. Ward, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. During his first year in the post, Mr. Ward has developed a detailed plan for the rebuilding of the World Trade Center and a $3.3 billion capital improvement plan for 2009. The plan includes starting construction of a new passenger rail tunnel under the Hudson River, improving airports to reduce passenger delays, completing environmental work for a new Goethals Bridge, and finishing the purchase of new PATH cars, which will begin service in a few weeks.

Skip right over this if you, like me, endlessly plug city pairs into booking engines and therefore have a pretty good handle of how much it would cost you, at any given time, to get on a plane and fly somewhere divine. But because in this case ignorance is not bliss, I just want to make sure that everyone is aware how amazingly cheap fares are to Europe right now. The other day I bought a round-trip ticket from New York to London on British Airways the base fare of which was $120. That's right, $120. Now, after all the taxes and fees, that ticket ended up costing me $474, quite a bit more but still a pretty good deal. If you've got some flexibility with dates, flying other places in March is even cheaper: New York to Stockholm on SAS for $383 (base fare: $74!). To Barcelona on Continental for $378. To Dublin on Delta for $307.

Shoulders were sharp and wide, with unflattering bubble skirts and lots of dark velvet. Platform shoes had heels that suggested fancy table legs.

Columbia University has named Michele M. Moody-Adams, Cornell University's vice provost for undergraduate education, as dean of Columbia College, the first black person and the first woman to serve in the post.Dr. Moody-Adams, 52, a philosopher, has also run Cornell's program on ethics and public life. Fete Accompli reports on fashion week parties, sampling Champagne and mingling with celebrities so that you don't have to.What: Angela Missoni's surprise 50th birthday partyWhen: Thursday, February 26Where: The new Visionaire theatre in Milan's Piazza CavourWho: The Missoni clan and the usual fashion suspects.Dress code: Authentic old-school Missoni knits plucked from the depths of the closet; orange corduroy pants and ironed pocket squares for men; kimono sleeves, kohl-rimmed eyes and lots of leg for women; one silver fishtail pony, courtesy of the still-working-it-at-70 Rosita Missoni.Music: Who knows? All attention was fixed on the jumbo video slide show that wrapped around the walls showing Angela in her various states of flowing brown-haired glory over the years -- glam and tan and headscarved on the beach; young mother with awkward teen girls (yes even swans like Margherita Missoni often start out as ducks) on the canals in Venice; and up close and snuggly with her dapper boyfriend Bruno.Drinks: Sicilian whites and reds flowed liberally, and refreshingly, in correctly sized stemware.Eats: A buffet longer than a Eurostar topped with generous pools of polenta (the good speckled kind), piles of Parmigiano and sculpted salami.Overheard: "I was asleep on the couch when they woke me and told me to get moving. My birthday was in December, so frankly I was expecting something after men's, not women's." -- Angela Missoni

Economy | Points from a wide-ranging interview with the financial historian Niall Ferguson: 1) "This is a very unfair crisis. The epicenter is the United States, but the rest of the world, and particularly America's trading partners, will get hit harder than the U.S." -- even countries like Canada that acted with probity. 2) The Chinese "want the status quo" (financing American debt) because "they have nowhere else to go." 3) But the real profit potential will be in all the "companies that can't roll their debt over" and "end up being sold at bargain basement prices" to those who still have cash. A headline on a report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about a decline in charitable giving referred incompletely to that drop. As the report correctly noted, the number of all charitable gifts of $1 million or more — not just large bequests — fell in the last half of 2008.

An article on Thursday about a Supreme Court argument in an identity-theft case misattributed a comment from one of the justices, repeating an error in the court transcript. It was Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. — not Justice John Paul Stevens — who said: “There’s a basic problem here. You get an extra two years if it just so happens that the number you picked out of the air belonged to someone else.”.

An article on Feb. 18 about people in their 20s who, unable to afford health insurance, rely on a scattershot network of improvised remedies described incorrectly the operation of an insulin pump used by Robert Voris, 27, a diabetic who works at a restaurant in Brooklyn. The pump administers insulin but does not in fact monitor blood-sugar levels. The insulin is injected through intravenous tubing attached to the pump; the pump itself is not inserted under the skin. The article also misidentified the items Mr. Voris stockpiled in 2007, when he last had insurance. They were tubing and other supplies, not insulin pumps.

While President Obama’s budget outline requests a 4 percent increase in basic military spending, to $534 billion from $513 billion fiscal 2009, the administration has made it clear that it intends to shift some money from huge cold war-style weapons systems to smaller programs focused on fighting insurgents in Iraq and Afghanistan and new threats to the nation’s cybersecurity.
The budget promises what it calls a comprehensive effort to address global warming, slash oil imports and create a “green” economy that produces millions of new jobs.
The new budget offers the first estimate of how much more the president thinks will be needed to save the financial industry.
By indexing student-aid Pell Grants to inflation, the president’s budget attempts to guarantee low-income college students a stable grant amount.

Rather than pay the $7 million roster bonus the starting right guard Brandon Moore was due next week, the Jets released him Thursday. The move continued the Jets' trend of clearing salary cap room since Rex Ryan took over as coach. On Wednesday, the Jets restructured the contract of receiver Laveranues Coles to allow him to become a free agent when free agency begins Friday. Combined, the moves save the Jets more than $13 million in cap space.

BANK SAYS NO DEAL Bank of America announced that it pulled out of negotiations last month to become a top-level sponsor at Yankee Stadium, in part because of the economic crisis. ''But there were a lot of complexities with these negotiations, not just the environment or the tone or mood of the country.''

10 P.M. (Discovery) AMERICAN LOGGERS Fifty years ago Gerald Pelletier began a logging business with $100 and a truck. Now his sons oversee the company, which employs dozens of men who use hundreds of machines to harvest timber on thousands of acres in Maine's rural northwest backcountry. This new series follows the Pelletier brothers and their sons as they climb into their big rigs and follow the logging route known as the Golden Road, the lone passage between civilization and the largest swath of unprotected forest north of the Mississippi. 8 P.M. (ABC) WIFE SWAPSusan Peters, who, with her tiara-wearing husband, teaches yoga and allows their 10-year-old son to rule the household, trades places with Beth Vaughn, the wife of a dairy farmer and a strict disciplinarian who wants her children to know that life is not a barrel of laughs.

SACKS--Harriet Fass. Harriet Sacks, wife, mother, grandmother, died peacefully at her home in Stuart, Florida. She leaves behind her smitten husband of 59 years, Leonard, daughter Amy and her husband Dr. Gary Kalkut, son Cary and his wife Julie Sandler, and son Andrew and his wife Julie Fisher, her grandsons Sam, Jacob, Elliott and Julian, and brother and sister-in-law Paul and Phyllis Sacks and Michael and Patti Sacks Leonard always called Harriet, "The most beautiful woman in the room." And she was. Graced with extraordinary looks, exquisite style, generosity and great confidence, she lit up a room like a star and will be greatly missed by everyone lucky enough to have known her. Harriet attended Hunter College. She worked as a stylist, account executive, advisor and business partner at her husband's advertising agency. Hers was an extraordinary life. After her childhood in the Bronx she lived in Manhattan, Denmark, Tokyo, The Hamptons, South Florida and traveled the world over. She gave us love, strength, conviction and in the end, a very special gift in the time we were able to spend together. On her last Saturday night, she said to her gathered family, "If there has ever been a better weekend, I don't know it." In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The James Lenox Society at New York Presbyterian Hospital. There will be a private funeral service. The family will be receiving visitors at the home of Amy and Gary Kalkut, 161 West 75th Street, on Monday, March 2nd and Tuesday, March 3rd from 6 to 9pm.

ONE of the most memorable, and parodied, of current infomercials is for the Snuggie, a blanket with sleeves whose users resemble converts to a cozy cult. Jay Leno mocked the Snuggie in a monologue (''Why don't you just put your robe on backwards?''), as did Ellen DeGeneres on her syndicated show (''They should throw in a pointed hat so you can look like a wizard.'') On CNN recently, a segment on the Snuggie -- four million of which have sold since it began advertising in October -- said it ''has spawned all sorts of online imitators'' and later mentioned the Slanket as one ''of the other versions of the Snuggie out there.''

FRIOU Robert Edwin, died on Thursday, February 26, 2009 in Tarrytown, NY after a long and valiant battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was born in 1917 in Brooklyn, NY, the eldest son of the late George Dyson and Lillian Ackerman Friou. He lived in Brooklyn, exempt for summers in Friendship. ME, until he married Alice Regina Hoffman in 1940. He attended Columbia College (B.A. 1938) and Columbia Law School (L.L.B. And J.D. 1940). He served as an attorney for the United States Tax Court in Washington DC until war broke out in 1941, when he volunteered for the US Army. He graduated from the Command and General Staff School in Ft. Leavenworth, Kansas, and became a captain in the US Air Force. After the war, he and his wife moved to Brooklyn Heights, and later to Hackensack, NJ, while he worked for Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside and Wolff in New York City as head of their Tax Department. In 1957, the family moved to Bethlehem, PA where he was Tax Attorney for Bethlehem Steel Co., and later to Canton, OH, where he was counsel to Herbert Hoover and the vacuum cleaner company named after him. In the early 60s the family moved to North Tarrytown, NY (now called Sleepy Hollow). Robert did litigation, mostly in the bankruptcy field, in New York City and Westchester County. He and his second wife, Elizabeth Bell Friou, moved to Tarrytown in 1995. Friou's proudest and finest achievement was, however, the pro bono work he did for about 15 years after his retirement, helping the poor tenants of the Tarrytowns to keep their homes, and to enlist the landlords' help in keeping them livable. As he used to say, truthfully, he "never lost a case", and he was much loved in the Tarrytowns and adjoining villages. For this work he was awarded the New York State Bar Association 1991 President's Pro Bono Service Award for the 9th and 10th Judicial Districts of the State of New York, and was Vice Chair of the American Bar Association Senior Lawyers Division Pro Bono Committee. The New York State Bar Association, in its newspaper to all attorneys in New York State, said: "Friou's story provides a model for any attorney who might be finishing up one phase of his or her practice." He himself was quoted as saying about pro bono work: "What I do now gives me the most pleasure of all the work I have done since my admission (to the Bar) in 1940, and is the most immediately effective on people's lives." Robert was a man of uncommon abilities, generosity, humor, integrity, loyalty and tenacity, and his life reflected all those qualities. He is survived by his wife; his daughters Jane Clemens and Elisabeth Mote and their husbands; his grandchildren Rebecca Gauthier, David Jr., and Amy Clemens; his three stepsons, Stephen, Richard and Paul, and their families; three siblings, Kenneth, Lillian and Charles (a fourth one, George, died earlier), and their extended families. They and all those who knew him will miss him sorely. Family will receive friends at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591 Sunday from 3-5pm only. In lieu of flowers, donations to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, NY 10018 would be appreciated.

The so-far fruitless negotiations between Manny Ramírez and the Los Angeles Dodgers stalled again Thursday night when Ramírez and his agent, Scott Boras, rejected the team's offer of a one-year, $25 million contract with a player option for $20 million in the second year. Frank McCourt, the owner of the Dodgers, said that future negotiations with Ramírez would have to ''start from scratch.'' The Dodgers issued a news release that said Boras had rejected four of their offers to Ramírez.

CORSO John Steven, 73, died peacefully Tuesday evening, February 24th, with children and grandchildren at his bedside. Mr. Corso, born in Brooklyn in 1935, was a long time resident of Chappaqua, NY with his late wife Maria, and his three children; more recently he lived in Somers, NY. A graduate of the College of Aeronautics he was a design engineer with the missile division of the Martin Company and a sales engineer with Weatherhead Hydraulic. He later became a co-founder of Power-Draulics-Nielsen where he was a partner for over 30 years. He is survived by two sons, Anthony and Charles; his daughter Joan Ferroni; and his four grandchildren, Charles, Maria, Emily, and John. The family will receive friends and mourners at the Beecher Funeral Home in Pleasantville, NY this Friday afternoon from 2-4pm, and Friday evening from 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday, February 28, at 11:30am at the Church of Saint John and St. Mary (Upper Church) in Chappaqua, NY. Burial will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers kindly make donations in his name to the Church of St. John & St. Mary, 30 Poillon Road, Chappaqua, NY 10514.

G.M. changed the way it calculated projections for the average fuel economy of its fleet in 2012 in a way that made the mileage numbers worse than if the company had been consistent in its methodology.

Thousands of supporters of the opposition leader Nawaz Sharif protested across Punjab Province, a day after the Supreme Court upheld a ruling barring him from holding elected office and removed his brother as the province's head of government. In Rawalpindi, demonstrators waved the green flags of the Pakistan Muslim League-N, the party led by Mr. Sharif, left, and chanted slogans against President Asif Ali Zardari's government. In Punjab's provincial capital, Lahore, the police herded 20 lawmakers from the Sharif brothers' party into police trucks as they gathered for a protest at the Punjab Assembly. The police allowed them to clamber out as the crowd swelled with supporters. Separately, Mr. Sharif addressed a rally in Shekhupura, near Lahore, and called on Pakistanis to reject the court's decision.

The Obama administration outlined a vast overhaul of financial aid programs for college students, one that would end years of federal support to banks and other lenders, in its budget proposal unveiled on Thursday. The proposal would increase grants to the neediest students and allow those grants to rise slightly above the inflation rate, an effort to keep pace with tuition increases.

PRINTZ--Mary Selina (nee) Horn, died February 21, 2009 of congestive heart failure due to post polio syndrome. Born April 8, 1923 in Detroit Michigan to (Wild) Bill Horn, speedboat builder and champion racer and Zelah Mitchell. Told at age five by the doctors that she would never walk again she paid little attention. She and dad got roller skates and bicycles and the latest braces and by 16 she had one of the first high school driver's licenses. She and dad built landing craft for the military in WWII. She had her own apartment in NYC where she answered phones in the lobby of the Sutton Hotel. Mel Torme among others. She married a British Naval officer and jumped on the back of his motorcycle for a European Grand Tour honeymoon. On second though she joined a girlfriend in the West Indies for a six-week divorce and invented "The Mahogany Club" near the airport on St. Thomas. She and the piano player developed into a permanent duo and settled in NYC. She got a job at an answering service to work the same hours as her husband and quickly made a name in the business, opened her own, helped Comden and Green put together "Bells Are Ringing" (her own business being called ("The Belles Celebrity Answering Service") and became kind of an operational central for the live wires on both coasts. The Belles still is known for the individual custom secretarial type service with no buttons to push on East 56th St. in NYC. Mary is survived by her husband Robert J., twin sons William Horn and R. Joseph, daughter in law Pam Wendi and granddaughter Emma Lauren. A memorial is being planned.

Jackson, below, has signed a deal with Marvel Studios to portray Nick Fury, the eye-patch-wearing leader of the fictional espionage agency S.H.I.E.L.D., in as many as nine movies, Variety reported.
