Heath Bell of the Padres said he lost 25 pounds by playing active video games with his children. The Brewers' Prince Fielder, whose father, Cecil, was heavy for his entire career, looks appreciably slimmer, but said he had an aversion to scales and would not reveal his weight. And Travis Hafner of the Indians lost at least 10 pounds, he said, by having a chef deliver special meals every day in a cooler. Examples of baseball players slimming down have been filtering in via spring training sightings, newspaper reports and blog postings from throughout the country.

For the second time in a week, a team of scientists announced it had found an antibody that attacks both seasonal flu virus and the H5N1 pandemic flu strains, a discovery that could lead to new treatments and, possibly, a universal flu vaccine. The new antibody was revealed in the online journal Science by a team from the Scripps Research Institute and Crucell, a Dutch company. It attaches to the neck of the hemagglutinin spike on the virus's shell, as did the antibody revealed on Sunday by a team from the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Harvard and others. But the first team also tested its antibody in mice.

FOR CHILDREN BAMKIDS FILM FESTIVAL (Saturday and Sunday) Just when you thought the movie awards were over, here come the BAMmies. They're the prizes voted by children in this annual film festival, now in its 11th edition at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The fare, for ages 2 through 13, consists of 50 short and feature films from 21 countries, many having New York premieres. Live music, face painting, moviemaking and discussions with filmmakers are also among the draws. Programs start at 10 a.m., 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 777-3456, bam.org; $11 per screening; $5 for ages 13 and under; $8 for 65+; $7 for BAM Cinema Club members; $7 for musical performances only.

WORKS ON PAPER Park Avenue Armory

THE little brown pine cone sat in the snow, looking like a single period on a blank, white sheet of paper. It was enough to arouse the curiosity of my 5-year-old son, Anders, who called a halt to our snowshoe hike. Anders stooped and scooped the cone, about the size of a gumdrop, into his mitten. Then he gawked upward at the evergreen tower beside the trail -- a hundred-foot-tall, old-growth eastern hemlock. And he asked, ''Daddy, how come such a tiny pine cone can make such a big tree?''

WILLIAMSBURG SPELLING BEE True confession time: I'm a spelling nerd. I won my junior high bee, have been known to take a rooting interest in the national finals on television and, as an editor, depend to a certain extent on my ability to spell. Still, even for me, the prospect of spending a night out just, well, spelling didn't sound all that promising.

From the 1930s to at least the 1960s the Apollo was a combination town meetinghouse, ''American Idol'' and La Scala for black American music. It celebrated the democratic impulse and the aristocratic impulse; it was where you could see comedians play the oaf and Duke Ellington play the genius. Since the mid-'70s it hasn't meant what it once did. It remains one of New York's very best theaters: great sound, great sightlines. But there are those who remember it almost as a living organism. People didn't just enter it; it entered them.

TUMBLING into a near-frozen creek on a 6-degree day while skiing the backcountry would typically be a sobering event. But on a cold-snap Saturday last month, just south of Middlebury, Vt., I found myself semi-supine in the snow, laughing as the icy water lapped against my back. The cross-country skiing -- miles and miles of gliding through Green Mountain National Forest -- had made me giddy. But so did knowing that a hot sauna and a four-course meal were waiting back at the Blueberry Hill Inn in Goshen once we reached the car at the trailhead.

SIMONS--Naomi Ruth, originally of Flatbush, Brooklyn, on February 23, 2009, at the age of 87 in Pleasant Hills, California. Beloved wife of the late Harold Simons. Loving mother of Mark Simons, the late David Simons and Bettysue Feuer. Sister of Mildred Feinberg and a friend and brother-in-law to her husband, Frank. A teacher, a student of the language, in love with books and butterflies and, as Nippy Nao, a rider of imaginary horses. You will be missed but not forgotten. We will meet you for a beverage at the 19th Hole. Funeral at Beth David Cemetery, 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY.

She was deeply loved by her husband, daughters and grandchildren Reed, Samantha and Gabriel. Remembered for her zest for life and indomitable spirit, she will be dearly missed.

UNIFORMED SS soldiers were the last thing Alexander Kisse ever expected to see again. Especially in a bucolic corner of southeastern Pennsylvania. But nearly six decades after fighting in Belgium during the Battle of the Bulge -- and being shot in the leg while charging a pillbox encampment with a satchel of explosives -- the Germans were back. ''There I was, helpless, with no gun and this German platoon walking towards us,'' said Mr. Kisse, a 91-year-old former infantryman from Pittsburgh, recalling his encounter in 1999. ''I was shaking, getting flashbacks! Then my son told me, 'It's O.K., they're Americans.' ''

The final score was Tyler Ennis 6, Prince Albert 2 in Western Hockey League play on Friday night as Ennis, the 19-year-old left wing, scored all the goals for his Medicine Hat Tigers, helping his team clinch a playoff berth. Ennis, a first-round draft pick of the Buffalo Sabres last year, scored three goals in the second and third periods to give him 41 this season. He was one away from tying the W.H.L. record for goals in a single game (held by five players) but, according to this article in The Medicine Hat News, the coaching staff did not realize that and held Ennis out late in the third.

Re "Reporting in Real Time" (Feb. 8): You offer a frank and welcome report on the problem you treated. Only one issue remains: Is publishing fast on the Internet exactly the same as beating the competition in a print story?How many people knew of the New York Post story in the nine minutes it took for The Times to go online? How much did The Post gain by getting the story on the Internet nine minutes before The Times? How much more would The Times have benefited by getting the story right the first time?I don't think competition on the Internet can be equated with competition in the daily print wars. Jerome F. WeberUtica, N.Y., Feb. 8, 2009 ● If a person is granted anonymity to tell The Times a story, and the story turns out to be knowingly and clearly untruthful and damaging to the subject of the story, as were the Paterson agents' lies about Caroline Kennedy, why does The Times continue to honor the confidentiality?Wouldn't both truth and fairness be served by identifying the dishonest source?Phil HoltNew Haven, Feb. 8, 2009● As someone who just retired from the newspaper business after more than 30 wonderful years, I'm concerned about something else related to news on the Internet: that it has already deteriorated into a race to see who can post the hour's most outrageous comment first, to be followed by tons of instant analysis.Good newspapers used to put out special editions to publish a story before anyone else, but it seems, in my understanding of newspaper history, that news once focused more on events, on things that happened, not just what someone said. Jim RygelskiSt. Louis, Feb. 9, 2009 ● Of course, opinion and false statements are getting more prevalent and will eventually become the norm because of the pressure of bloggers. It is a natural degradation of news journalism. It will get worse, and it is irreversible.Neither you nor anyone else can stop it, because those who will replace you and the other editors will be have been born and raised in the new medium of news where journalistic integrity in the form of accuracy and objectivity is just not that important.This is no different from the rest of human endeavors where such outdated concepts are ridiculed for the sake of expediency and personal gain.John EllzeyAlexandria, Va., Feb. 8, 2009 ● I read an anecdote in Reader's Digest years ago about a craftsman in New England who posted a sign in his shop. It read (and I'm paraphrasing here), "You can have it good, you can have it cheap, or you can have it fast. You get your choice of two, not all three." I was reminded of that when I read your column.You discuss the question of accuracy regarding Caroline Kennedy's bid for the Senate seat vacated by Hillary Rodham Clinton. And yet at the end of the column, when discussing Web competition, there's no inclusion of accuracy in the criteria, only speed. You write, "The Web has no deadlines, just the anxiety that the guy down the street will beat you to the story, and you have to get yours published first."Accuracy must become a criterion alongside speed, or credibility suffers. The two must be measured simultaneously and have equal status. It matters not one whit if an inaccurate story is later proved false and retracted.Getting a story to print (no matter whether on paper or on screen) solely to be the first to report it does no one any good if the story is later proved false. So please revise the standard to this: Get the accurate story to print first.Dennis M. SteeleMontvale, N.J., Feb. 8, 2009●●Re "They Still Have the Nixon Tapes to Kick Around" (Feb. 22): Thank you for addressing the unfortunate front-page article about Stanley I. Kutler and the Nixon tapes. As an Africanist historian, I could not enter the fray. But I have known Mr. Kutler for almost all of the years he has been a professional scholar, and I (along with countless others) can attest to his integrity as well as his competence.Of course we all make mistakes, although in some cases politics have played a role, as is all too obvious in the form of attacks on Mr. Kutler's "Abuse of Power."I'm glad you undertook to unravel the circumstances behind the attacks, but I do think that the reporter, Patricia Cohen, should be brought to task for practicing "gotcha journalism." The article probably should never have been published, but if making academic arguments more available to the general public is a goal of the weekend editor, then the article should have been refereed in the same way that submissions are reviewed by scholarly journals.Patricia W. RomeroTowson, Md., Feb. 22, 2009The writer, a professor of history at Towson University, is the editor of The Journal of Colonialism and Colonial History.

A front-page article on Jan. 4 about Bruce E. Ivins, the late Army scientist who the Federal Bureau of Investigation says was responsible for the anthrax letter attacks of 2001, reported that F.B.I. scientists had concluded in 2004 that out of 60 domestic and foreign water samples, only water from near Fort Detrick, Md., where Dr. Ivins worked, had the same chemical signature as the water that had been used to grow the mailed anthrax. That information, provided by a former senior law enforcement official who did not want to be named in the article, suggested that the anthrax could not have come from military and intelligence research programs in Utah and Ohio, as some defenders of Dr. Ivins’s innocence had speculated. The F.B.I. declined to answer questions for that article, which said that the evidence against Dr. Ivins was circumstantial and that many of his colleagues believed the F.B.I.’s conclusion was wrong.

Two Canadian fighter jets forced a Russian bomber away from Canadian airspace hours before President Obama's trip to Ottawa last week, Defense Minister Peter MacKay said Friday. The jets intercepted the long-range bomber about 125 miles from Canada over the Beaufort Sea in the Arctic, he said at a news conference. ''I'm not going to stand here and accuse the Russians of deliberately doing this during the presidential visit,'' he said. ''But it was a strong coincidence.'' The Russian Defense Ministry said Friday that Canada had been notified about the flight and that its aircraft had complied with international regulations.

ARMITSTEAD--Reverend Austin Herrick, 84, passed away peacefully February 20, 2009 in his home. Reverend Armitstead was born on December 30, 1924 in Nashua, New Hampshire and spent his childhood and teenage years in New England and Pennsylvania before enlisting in the Army in early 1943. Armitstead fought for freedom as an infantryman in the 12th Armored Division seeing action along the Rhine River near Strausburg, France until taken as a prisoner of war in early 1945. After his liberation in April 1945 he returned to the United States and civilian life. He graduated Dickinson College in Carlisle, PA in 1948 and having decided to dedicate his life to the service of God, worked with migrant farm workers from northern Florida through northern New York before enrolling in Union Theological Seminary in New York City where he was awarded a Masters of Divinity in 1952. He married his wife, Bianca Audrey Potz-Nielsen in 1951 and the couple began a lifetime of ministry together. Reverend Armitstead was an elder in the New York Conference of the United Methodist Church and served pastorates in Hauppauge, Commack and Center Moriches on Long Island, Bay Ridge Methodist Church in Brooklyn, Faith United Methodist Church on Staten Island and Community United Methodist Church in Jackson Heights, Queens where he established a four language church bringing a diverse community together in service to God. Upon his retirement in 1994, he served as a Community Liaison for the Western Queens Gazette and offered his personal ministry through his photographic works. In addition to his pastoral responsibilities Armitstead was also a leader and advocate for social change and justice in each of his stops along life's path. He was an early and vocal advocate for racial integration and equality and also worked tirelessly in the cause of ecumenicalism and community responsibility upon the part of the churches he served. He held positions as President, Vice-President or Chairman on a number of boards in New York including the Salvation Army, American Red Cross, Police Community Relations, Staten Island Council of Churches, Brooklyn United Methodist Church Home, Jackson Heights Community Development, sheltered New York City homeless, served the New York City Police and Fire Departments in a number of ways, and served on numerous task forces of New York City Mayors, improving the lives of thousands. His passion for championing the underdog was also evident in his life-long love of baseball as he was an avid New York Mets fan and attended nearly a thousand ball games at Shea Stadium in Queens. Perhaps fitting, Armitstead died only a few days after the last remaining piece of that ballpark was leveled. He was an honorary lifetime member of the Baseball Hall of Fame. Due to declining health, Armitstead and his wife moved to Suffolk in the summer of 2007 where he lived out his life close to family. Reverend Armitstead is survived by his wife of over 57 years, Bianca Audrey Potz-Nielsen Armitstead; one daughter, Nancy Armitstead of New York City; two sons, Alan Jackson Armitstead (wife, Petra) of Suffolk and John Auman Armitstead (wife, Ima) of Lexington, Kentucky; two brothers, Donald M. Armitstead of Seattle, WA and Dr. Paul T. Armitstead of Waco, TX; and five grandchildren, Christian, Jaclyn, Michael, Steven and Jonathan. A memorial service will be held on Friday, February 27, at 11am in Sturtevant Funeral Home, Bennetts Creek Chapel, Suffolk celebrated by the Reverend Bob Weeks of Aldersgate United Methodist Church. Ground committal will be in the Albert G. Horton, Jr. Memorial Veterans Cemetery also in Suffolk. Contributions in lieu of flowers should be made to your local church, hospice, food bank, the Salvation Army or Red Cross. www.SturtevantFuneralHome. com

Sumner M. Redstone, the media mogul who controls Viacom and CBS, reached a deal with banks that gives him two more years to pay down $1.46 billion in debt without having to sell more stock in either company, the family holding company, National Amusements, said. Mr. Redstone has been under financial strain since October, when he breached the terms of his loans and was forced to sell more than $200 million in stock. The covenants of the bank loans were tied to the value of CBS and Viacom shares, which fell sharply in the fall, causing Mr. Redstone's problems. The deal to restructure the debt is expected to close by the end of March, and at that time, National Amusements, which holds the debt, said it would make a payment of more than $100 million. That will leave National Amusements with about $1.46 billion in debt, which will come due in December 2010. The loans previously came due last December.

CARIBBEAN ROOTS Of a Bronx Sound

A United Nations tribunal sentenced a Roman Catholic priest, a former military chaplain, on Friday to 25 years in prison for genocide in Rwanda. The priest, Emmanuel Rukundo, 50, left, a Hutu extremist, on at least four occasions betrayed Tutsi refugees hiding in a seminary to soldiers, who subsequently killed them, the court said. The tribunal had earlier handed life sentences for genocide to two other Hutu priests. Clergy members were both perpetrators and victims of the 1994 genocide. Ten priests, two bishops and the archbishop of Kigali were held captive and killed by Tutsi rebel soldiers, now part of the Rwandan Army. Members of the Tutsi military have not been prosecuted by the court.

HAZARD--Oliver Cope, of Bedford, New York died February 22nd. Born December 7, 1931 in Providence, RI to Thomas Pierrepont Hazard and Anne Frances Cope Hazard, Ollie grew up in Cambridge, MA and Peace Dale, RI. An alumnus of Yale, he became a noted investment banker, recognized for his expertise in the design, structure, and timing of debt and equity financings. In the 1980s and 90s, as Senior Vice President at Dillon Read & Co. Inc., Ollie's career culminated in the marketing, syndication, and pricing of public offerings totaling $36 billion. With a magnanimous smile and a good sense of humor, Ollie's generosity and care was felt by many of the causes he supported, including the Bridge Fund of New York, the Westchester Land Trust, the Bedford Coalition, and the Bedfor Historic Review Commission. Ollie is survived by his wife of 48 years, Sarah Halsey Hazard, his children Eliza Hazard (Herndon, VA), Peter R. Hazard (Telluride, CO), and Caroline H. Hazard (Silver Spring, MD), his sister, Mary P. Conrad (Albuquerque, NM) and 15 nieces and nephews. A service will be held at St. Matthew's, Church on Monday, March 2nd at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Ollie's name may be sent to The Bridge Fund of New York, Inc., 271 Madison Avenue, Suite 907, New York, NY 10016.

Remember when the Washington Redskins gave fiscal and free-agent restraint a try? Apparently, that model for franchise building was so last year, and last year was not a particularly good one for the Redskins. So early Friday morning, the Redskins' owner, Daniel Snyder, reverted to form, doing a cannonball into the free-agency pool by signing defensive tackle Albert Haynesworth, the top prize of the free agents, to a seven-year contract worth a potential $100 million. The deal is expected to pay Haynesworth $32 million in the first 13 months. The Redskins scooped up the 27-year-old Haynesworth, who spent his first seven seasons with Tennessee, only hours after free agency opened Friday. His signing came not long after Washington signed cornerback DeAngelo Hall to another lavish deal, a six-year contract that includes $22.5 million guaranteed. Hall joined the Redskins in the middle of the 2008 season and boosted their struggling defense.

FRIOU Robert Edwin, died on Thursday, February 26, 2009 in Tarrytown, NY after a long and valiant battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was born in 1917 in Brooklyn, NY, the eldest son of the late George Dyson and Lillian Ackerman Friou. He lived in Brooklyn, exempt for summers in Friendship. ME, until he married Alice Regina Hoffman in 1940. He attended Columbia College (B.A. 1938) and Columbia Law School (L.L.B. And J.D. 1940). He served as an attorney for the United States Tax Court in Washington DC until war broke out in 1941, when he volunteered for the US Army. He graduated from the Command and General Staff School in Ft. Leavenworth, Kansas, and became a captain in the US Air Force. After the war, he and his wife moved to Brooklyn Heights, and later to Hackensack, NJ, while he worked for Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside and Wolff in New York City as head of their Tax Department. In 1957, the family moved to Bethlehem, PA where he was Tax Attorney for Bethlehem Steel Co., and later to Canton, OH, where he was counsel to Herbert Hoover and the vacuum cleaner company named after him. In the early 60s the family moved to North Tarrytown, NY (now called Sleepy Hollow). Robert did litigation, mostly in the bankruptcy field, in New York City and Westchester County. He and his second wife, Elizabeth Bell Friou, moved to Tarrytown in 1995. Friou's proudest and finest achievement was, however, the pro bono work he did for about 15 years after his retirement, helping the poor tenants of the Tarrytowns to keep their homes, and to enlist the landlords' help in keeping them livable. As he used to say, truthfully, he "never lost a case", and he was much loved in the Tarrytowns and adjoining villages. For this work he was awarded the New York State Bar Association 1991 President's Pro Bono Service Award for the 9th and 10th Judicial Districts of the State of New York, and was Vice Chair of the American Bar Association Senior Lawyers Division Pro Bono Committee. The New York State Bar Association, in its newspaper to all attorneys in New York State, said: "Friou's story provides a model for any attorney who might be finishing up one phase of his or her practice." He himself was quoted as saying about pro bono work: "What I do now gives me the most pleasure of all the work I have done since my admission (to the Bar) in 1940, and is the most immediately effective on people's lives." Robert was a man of uncommon abilities, generosity, humor, integrity, loyalty and tenacity, and his life reflected all those qualities. He is survived by his wife; his daughters Jane Clemens and Elisabeth Mote and their husbands; his grandchildren Rebecca Gauthier, David Jr., and Amy Clemens; his three stepsons, Stephen, Richard and Paul, and their families; three siblings, Kenneth, Lillian and Charles (a fourth one, George, died earlier), and their extended families. They and all those who knew him will miss him sorely. Family will receive friends at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591 Sunday from 3-5pm only. In lieu of flowers, donations to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, NY 10018 would be appreciated.

9 P.M. (Starz) REDBELT (2008) In this fight film written and directed by David Mamet, a Los Angeles jujitsu instructor (Chiwetel Ejiofor) with money troubles saves a pampered, slumming action star (Tim Allen, above right) from a beating. After which promises of friendship ensue, and principles are surrendered. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said Mr. Mamet had ''taken a sturdy B-movie conceit -- a good man versus the bad world, plus blood -- tricked it out with his rhythms, his corrosive words and misanthropy, and come up with a satisfying, unexpectedly involving B movie that owes as much to old Hollywood as to Greek tragedy.'' 6:30 P.M. (Fox) AT THE MOVIES Ben Lyons and Ben Mankiewicz offer their opinions of ''Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li,'' starring Kristin Kreuk (''Smallville'') as the video game heroine, and ''Crossing Over,'' Wayne Kramer's drama with Harrison Ford, Ray Liotta and Ashley Judd, about immigrants struggling to achieve legal status in Los Angeles.

Benjamin Netanyahu, the leader of the conservative Likud Party who was chosen to form the next Israeli government, met with Tzipi Livni of the centrist Kadima Party on Friday, in another attempt to join forces in forming a broad coalition. But both said afterward that no agreement had been reached and it seemed unlikely that one would be. Ms. Livni wants a commitment on a two-state solution with the Palestinians, and Mr. Netanyahu is not ready to give one. But neither Ms. Livni nor Mr. Netanyahu closed the door entirely on making another effort.

Two people were killed and 13 were wounded on Friday as security forces broke up an opposition protest in southern Madagascar, the police and protest organizers said. The deaths, in Fianarantsoa, brought to 98 the number of fatalities since political unrest erupted on Jan. 26 when the opposition leader Andry Rajoelina called for antigovernment demonstrations.

FRIOU Robert Edwin, died on Thursday, February 26, 2009 in Tarrytown, NY after a long and valiant battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was born in 1917 in Brooklyn, NY, the eldest son of the late George Dyson and Lillian Ackerman Friou. He lived in Brooklyn, exempt for summers in Friendship. ME, until he married Alice Regina Hoffman in 1940. He attended Columbia College (B.A. 1938) and Columbia Law School (L.L.B. And J.D. 1940). He served as an attorney for the United States Tax Court in Washington DC until war broke out in 1941, when he volunteered for the US Army. He graduated from the Command and General Staff School in Ft. Leavenworth, Kansas, and became a captain in the US Air Force. After the war, he and his wife moved to Brooklyn Heights, and later to Hackensack, NJ, while he worked for Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside and Wolff in New York City as head of their Tax Department. In 1957, the family moved to Bethlehem, PA where he was Tax Attorney for Bethlehem Steel Co., and later to Canton, OH, where he was counsel to Herbert Hoover and the vacuum cleaner company named after him. In the early 60s the family moved to North Tarrytown, NY (now called Sleepy Hollow). Robert did litigation, mostly in the bankruptcy field, in New York City and Westchester County. He and his second wife, Elizabeth Bell Friou, moved to Tarrytown in 1995. Friou's proudest and finest achievement was, however, the pro bono work he did for about 15 years after his retirement, helping the poor tenants of the Tarrytowns to keep their homes, and to enlist the landlords' help in keeping them livable. As he used to say, truthfully, he "never lost a case", and he was much loved in the Tarrytowns and adjoining villages. For this work he was awarded the New York State Bar Association 1991 President's Pro Bono Service Award for the 9th and 10th Judicial Districts of the State of New York, and was Vice Chair of the American Bar Association Senior Lawyers Division Pro Bono Committee. The New York State Bar Association, in its newspaper to all attorneys in New York State, said: "Friou's story provides a model for any attorney who might be finishing up one phase of his or her practice." He himself was quoted as saying about pro bono work: "What I do now gives me the most pleasure of all the work I have done since my admission (to the Bar) in 1940, and is the most immediately effective on people's lives." Robert was a man of uncommon abilities, generosity, humor, integrity, loyalty and tenacity, and his life reflected all those qualities. He is survived by his wife; his daughters Jane Clemens and Elisabeth Mote and their husbands; his grandchildren Rebecca Gauthier, David Jr., and Amy Clemens; his three stepsons, Stephen, Richard and Paul, and their families; three siblings, Kenneth, Lillian and Charles (a fourth one, George, died earlier), and their extended families. They and all those who knew him will miss him sorely. Family will receive friends at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591 Sunday from 3-5pm only. In lieu of flowers, donations to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, NY 10018 would be appreciated.

The United States will not attend the second World Conference Against Racism in Geneva unless the conference's main document improves, according to a State Department official, though the Obama administration sent a delegation to preparatory talks in Geneva. The long, unwieldy document seeks to ban criticism of religion, calls for slave reparations and attacks Israel as racist. Israel and some American Jewish groups urged a boycott of the April conference, and several close American allies, including Canada, said they would not go. The United States walked out of the first Conference Against Racism, in Durban, South Africa, in 2001, as a protest against an effort to compare Zionism to racism.

HAZARD--Oliver Cope, of Bedford, New York died February 22nd. Born December 7, 1931 in Providence, RI to Thomas Pierrepont Hazard and Anne Frances Cope Hazard, Ollie grew up in Cambridge, MA and Peace Dale, RI. An alumnus of Yale, he became a noted investment banker, recognized for his expertise in the design, structure, and timing of debt and equity financings. In the 1980s and 90s, as Senior Vice President at Dillon Read & Co. Inc., Ollie's career culminated in the marketing, syndication, and pricing of public offerings totaling $36 billion. With a magnanimous smile and a good sense of humor, Ollie's generosity and care was felt by many of the causes he supported, including the Bridge Fund of New York, the Westchester Land Trust, the Bedford Coalition, and the Bedfor Historic Review Commission. Ollie is survived by his wife of 48 years, Sarah Halsey Hazard, his children Eliza Hazard (Herndon, VA), Peter R. Hazard (Telluride, CO), and Caroline H. Hazard (Silver Spring, MD), his sister, Mary P. Conrad (Albuquerque, NM) and 15 nieces and nephews. A service will be held at St. Matthew's, Church on Monday, March 2nd at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in Ollie's name may be sent to The Bridge Fund of New York, Inc., 271 Madison Avenue, Suite 907, New York, NY 10016.

Seth Davis, a writer for Sports Illustrated and college basketball analyst for CBS, is the author of "When March Went Mad: The Game That Transformed Basketball." It's a look at the 1979 N.C.A.A. title game that featured Magic Johnson's Michigan State team against Larry Bird's Indiana State squad. In an e-mail interview, Davis discussed both players, the impact the game had on the sport and whether we will ever see anything like it again.

Talk about the economy is everywhere, and the same things are being said. We're in a deep hole. We may not be able to dig ourselves out. We're underwater. Our assets are overwhelmed by our debts, which keep growing. The question is who or what can get us out of this mess? Some answer Obama. Some (a much smaller group) say Geithner. Some (in desperation) say China. But others say Jesus Christ.

Barack Obama - unlike the other five presidents my colleagues and I are discussing on this blog - must contend with a worrisome new feature in American politics: the trivialization of the filibuster in the Senate. A simple majority vote no longer suffices to pass major pieces of legislation. Instead, in almost every case, the Senate must muster at least 60 votes (a "supermajority") to close off debate. And because of a rule the Senate adopted relating to deficit spending, it took another 60 votes to pass the stimulus package last month.

MILAN -- On a day in which the soggy remains of Carnival streamers cling to editors' stilettos, Max Mara's new Atelier line of coats provided an uplift. It just makes good sense for a company known for coats to put its name and craft behind a limited-edition group that is impeccably done-and worth, I think, the price. There are 17 styles in the line, all with a strong sense of fashion (not your humble classic), in fabrics like wool, alpaca, camel's hair and a luscious black and white tweed that has been embroidered in black on the skirt of the coat. There are also evening styles, including one in deep red with three-quarter sleeves and rosettes on the collar. Laura Lusuardi, the company's chief designer, pointed out the hand finishing and silk linings-all done in Max Mara's factories. At a time when many fashion houses are under economic pressures, making something that really employs top skills must have been a source of pride. The coats are quite shapely-barrel-shaped, A-lined, others with a defined waist. Here and there is a whiff of early Balenciaga. Max Mara plans to have the coats, priced from about $1,500 to $3,000, in five of its U.S. stores, including the Madison Avenue shop, Chicago and Beverly Hills. And the company has produced opera-length gloves in different colors to go with the three-quarter sleeve models.

History | Are you sure you want to declare George W. Bush the worst president? That's what Thomas Fleming asks those of his fellow historians who have ranked No. 43 thusly. What about Madison, who let the British burn the White House? Or John Adams, who blanched in the face of war with France and offered his job back to Washington? What about Jefferson's disastrous trade embargo? What about the bigoted Wilson? F.D.R. in his second term? Carter? Harding? "Maybe it's time to suspend the rush to judgment on George W. Bush for 10 or 20 years." [Wall Street Journal]

Economy | A counterintuitive effect of the recession in California is that places with older populations are better off -- because they're spurring growth in the health-care sector and because those areas didn't experience the youthful booms of cities where many jobs are now being lost. Rather than luring hipsters and nightclubs, revitalizing downtowns "might have been better off building retirement homes." [Economist]

Philosophy | In this economy, Keynesianism seems the philosophy of the day as stimulus takes center stage. But actually, an essay says, "so far the 21st century is Schumpeterian" - as in Joseph Schumpeter, the Austrian who propounded the "volatile, wild" benefits of "creative destruction." "Keynes was the guy trying to turn the party down just as Schumpeter was coming in from the kitchen with another bottle of tequila." [Smart Set]

The fine points of a very good Marni show this morning included boxy jackets in black felt and rather cozy-droopy pants balanced somewhere between leggings and sweats. One pair combined a gray knit with a murky plaid fabric. Consuelo Castiglioni's collection had a strong practical streak, with slightly oversized jackets, tunic dresses in grid-like jacquard checks, a felted wool coat with a grid of pockets, and a dark, woodsy, masculine palette. Some of the wool skirts were great: straight, just above the knee, with a same-color panel in a different fabric at the back. She showed tights and knee socks in a muted checkered pattern, and cone-heel pumps or strappy platform sandals in a three-way color mix. The collection worked in part because of the large number of desirable separates and in part because of Castiglioni's sophisticated interpretation of tactile fabrics, shine, and adornment. Barnacles of black sequins and stones appeared on a purple felt coat. Neck pieces were a craft project of felt-encrusted stones and other materials. Where's my glue gun? Pale, round sunglasses had colored mirror lenses.

Books | This week in the Book Review: "When it comes to dysfunction, the Wittgensteins of Vienna could give the Oedipuses a run for their money," says the Times's reviewer. Also, a new biography of Flannery O'Connor -- sickly, cortisone-boosted Southern novelist who died at 39 and is today "a one-woman academic industry." [Book Review podcast]

Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the role of the loyal opposition in politics referred incorrectly to an item in the stimulus bill recently signed into law. The article repeated a frequent but incorrect Republican assertion that the bill directs money specifically to mouse-marsh preservation. It does not.

A report in the Pulse column last Sunday about The Smile, a new store in lower Manhattan, included incorrect information from Carlos Quirarte, one of the store’s owners, about his professional background. He was not a marketing director for Freemans Sporting Club, a clothing brand.

An article last Sunday about restrictions on compensation and whether that might cause talented employees and executives to leave their firms on Wall Street misspelled the name of an investment bank run by John H. Gutfreund in the 1980s. It was Salomon Brothers, not Solomon Brothers.

Because of a transcription error, an article last Sunday about adapting Jane Austen to the horror genre and making her into an action hero quoted incorrectly from a telephone interview with Deidre Lynch, editor of “Janeites.” Ms. Lynch said: “It goes with the muddy petticoats and the rambling across the countryside in this unladylike way. The next step is ninja training.” She did not say “many petticoats.”.

An article last Sunday about Total, the French oil company, referred incorrectly to the location in Saudi Arabia of Jubayl, a port town where Total plans to build a refinery with Aramco. It is on the Persian Gulf, not the Red Sea.

An article on Feb. 15 about the reality television show “Jon & Kate Plus 8,” which chronicles the life of a couple who have twins and sextuplets, misstated the ages of the children. The twin girls — Mady and Cara — are currently 8 years old, not 7; and their sextuplet siblings — Hannah, Leah, Alexis, Aaden, Collin and Joel — are 4, not 3.

An article last Sunday about the misunderstood comic genius of Jerry Lewis misidentified the film that includes a scene with thousands of screaming fans waiting for Mr. Lewis and Dean Martin. It is “The Caddy,” not “The Stooge.” The article also misstated a word in the name of the organization that administers the Oscars. It is the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (not Pictures).

Anyone who has played even some basketball would appreciate Shane Battier’s contributions to the success of every team he has ever played with (Feb. 15). Back in the day, the N.B.A. could point to Jim McMillan of the Lakers (not coincidentally the catalyst for the team that still holds the league’s longest winning streak) and Bill Bradley (arguably the “glue” for two Knicks championship teams) as similar players with less-than-gaudy statistics whose sense of where they were on the court made their teams better. We didn’t have Daryl Morey’s math skills to prove it, so it’s good to see that there are now real tools to measure what our common sense told us then was true.

A picture with a report in the Comings & Goings column on Feb. 15 about an Arctic cruise on a schooner in honor of Capt. Bob Bartlett, who helped Robert Peary reach the North Pole, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph was by Dylan Clark/Maine Maritime Academy — not Maine Marine Academy.

To the Editor: Jennifer Conlin’s article “Cruise Lines Urged to Shrink Their Footprints” (Feb. 15) may leave the wrong impression about the industry’s environmental commitment. While Ms. Conlin accurately described some of the efforts visible to cruisers, she veered off course when it came to environmental initiatives below deck. Ms. Conlin failed to report, among other things, that air emissions are regulated and that our industry is exploring new technologies to further reduce emissions; that our ships treat all blackwater; and that advanced wastewater purification systems discharge water cleaner than most municipal water treatment plants. Environmental stewardship is a top priority for us. Terry Dale.

To the Editor: Regarding, “Cruise Issue; Voyage to the Top of the Continent” (Feb. 15), I have been on the Hurtigruten cruise, below, albeit in September, and I laughed all the way through Paul Schneider’s story. The detail about how “we huddled against the warmth of the smokestack up on the aft deck” in order to watch the aurora borealis was exactly as I experienced it. Too bad we didn’t think about acquiring some aquavit, though. Susan Shields.

To the Editor: Regarding “Frugal Traveler: Vegas”: I recently bought a round-trip ticket flying Delta to Las Vegas from Baltimore for $141 including taxes. My husband and I stayed at Planet Hollywood using Priceline for $60 a night. Our Ford Mustang was $9 a day at Avis. We ate at Firefly and Egg Works, both reasonably priced places on the Strip. We had a great time and can’t wait to go back. Nathalie Pierre.

To the Editor: I loved reading your Surfacing column, “Bright Spot in the Big Easy” (Feb. 15) about Magazine Street in New Orleans where I just spent time in an apartment above a pizza parlor and lingerie store. But down the street in the 4000 block is a bar not to be missed. It is Ms. Mae’s, open 24/7 365 days a year ... well drinks are $1 and strong, and the video poker machines are hot! If your guilt gets the best of you, head down the street to Whole Foods to do penance.

100 DAYS In early March 1969, after aides complained they had not yet met the new president, the national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, arranged for Richard Nixon to talk to his National Security Council staff, of which I was a holdover from the Johnson administration. There were only 20 or so of us there, less than a quarter the size of the mini-foreign ministry the council would become under Kissinger and later administrations. We gathered expectantly in the Cabinet Room, hoping for some personal impression of the man now in the Oval Office. We were not disappointed. Nixon walked in, tanned and smiling after a weekend in Florida, though typically ill at ease as he moved through quick handshake introductions. He began brief remarks with self-conscious ingratiation, commiserating with the staff for having to deal with what he called ''all those impossible fags'' in the State Department, oblivious that most in the room were Foreign Service officers on temporary assignment. ''Ignore the bureaucrats,'' he told them after a swift, fluent rundown of international trouble spots. ''I want you to handle the rest of the world.'' Turning to Kissinger, he added softly, in what seemed as much an intimacy as a boast, ''And you and I will end the war.''

TAKING IN THE VIEW, MAMMOTH LAKES, CALIF., NOV. 22, 2008 Colin Paterson, 57, British Ministry of Defense engineer from Bristol, England, prepares to descend Mammoth Mountain in the Sierra Nevada. it was his first time skiing in the United States. ''Obviously, the U.K. government has quite a few dealings with the U.S. government. I had a series of meetings, which were in back-to-back weeks. So I ended up staying for a weekend. Rather than sitting in a hotel room, giving the government another day of free overtime, I took an invitation to go skiing at Mammoth Mountain. It makes a big difference -- particularly in such a beautiful part of the United States -- to be able to take the opportunity to get out into the mountains. I really love skiing. My wife and I try to go twice during the winter, usually to the Alps, in France. Obviously it was November, early in the season. The snow wasn't the best -- to be honest, it was a bit icy and scraped in areas. But you can't complain in November if you can ski from the top to the bottom of a mountain.'' As told to Austin Considine

PRESS--Billie Kallick, died February 12, 2009, in Washington, DC, of heart failure after a long illness. An educator, Billie Press was an early post-Sputnik visitor to the USSR, accompanying her husband, geophysicist Frank Press (later science adviser to President Jimmy Carter and President of the National Academy of Sciences) during International Geophysical Year 1957-8 to Moscow when such visits were still quite rare. Returning home to Pasadena, CA, she argued successfully for one of the first ''Gifted Child'' programs that became a part of the public response to Sputnik. She founded and directed such a program in the Pasadena City Schools 1962-65, which involved training 250 teachers. At the same time that Sputnik was galvanizing a broad response in the US, universal education in the Soviet Union under Khrushchev had been cut from 10 years to 8, with only 10% going on to higher education. Billie appreciated the irony of this, publishing an article quoting her interview with a high Soviet official, ''It is bad policy to educate so many people beyond the stations they will occupy in life.'' Of course Billie didn't agree with this one bit! Obtaining her doctorate in 1968, she went on to found the HomeBased Early Childhood Education program in the Cambridge, MA, public schools, a kind of ''each one teach one'' in which economically disadvantaged mothers themselves became trained and employed as home visitors to other disadvantaged families, bringing books and educational materials into the homes of toddlers. She later taught at Salem State College and Lesley College, and was, in Washington, DC, a specialist in HEW's Bureau of Elementary and Secondary Education (1978-79). Born October 15, 1925, in St. Louis, MO, Billie grew up in Brooklyn, NY, the daughter of New York Times compositor and proofreader William Kallick and Mary Enders Kallick. Attending Samuel J. Tilden High School, she qualified for a full scholarship to NYU, where she graduated in 1946, marrying Frank Press (her highschool sweetheart) the same month. She is survived by her husband, her children William Press of Austin, TX, and Paula Press of Chapel Hill, NC, 2 grandchildren and 2 greatgrandchildren.

ON a cold, damp afternoon in January, from deep within the halls of the Palazzo Ducale, a cry rang out. It echoed through the immense Chamber of the Great Council, where 2,000 Venetian noblemen once directed the course of their empire beneath Tintoretto's immense ''Vision of Paradise.'' It carried up the intricate, gilt-encrusted stucco carvings of the Golden Staircase to the doge's own apartments. It pealed out even into the Piazza San Marco, whose paving stones were slicked a shiny gray from persistent drizzle. The cry disturbed visitors and guards alike, perhaps reminding them of the days when prisoners, denounced in secret and tried without mercy, were dragged across the Bridge of Sighs to meet sour, inescapable fates. In La Serenissima -- the Most Serene Republic -- it sounded a most discordant note.

FRIOU Robert Edwin, died on Thursday, February 26, 2009 in Tarrytown, NY after a long and valiant battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was born in 1917 in Brooklyn, NY, the eldest son of the late George Dyson and Lillian Ackerman Friou. He lived in Brooklyn, exempt for summers in Friendship. ME, until he married Alice Regina Hoffman in 1940. He attended Columbia College (B.A. 1938) and Columbia Law School (L.L.B. And J.D. 1940). He served as an attorney for the United States Tax Court in Washington DC until war broke out in 1941, when he volunteered for the US Army. He graduated from the Command and General Staff School in Ft. Leavenworth, Kansas, and became a captain in the US Air Force. After the war, he and his wife moved to Brooklyn Heights, and later to Hackensack, NJ, while he worked for Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside and Wolff in New York City as head of their Tax Department. In 1957, the family moved to Bethlehem, PA where he was Tax Attorney for Bethlehem Steel Co., and later to Canton, OH, where he was counsel to Herbert Hoover and the vacuum cleaner company named after him. In the early 60s the family moved to North Tarrytown, NY (now called Sleepy Hollow). Robert did litigation, mostly in the bankruptcy field, in New York City and Westchester County. He and his second wife, Elizabeth Bell Friou, moved to Tarrytown in 1995. Friou's proudest and finest achievement was, however, the pro bono work he did for about 15 years after his retirement, helping the poor tenants of the Tarrytowns to keep their homes, and to enlist the landlords' help in keeping them livable. As he used to say, truthfully, he "never lost a case", and he was much loved in the Tarrytowns and adjoining villages. For this work he was awarded the New York State Bar Association 1991 President's Pro Bono Service Award for the 9th and 10th Judicial Districts of the State of New York, and was Vice Chair of the American Bar Association Senior Lawyers Division Pro Bono Committee. The New York State Bar Association, in its newspaper to all attorneys in New York State, said: "Friou's story provides a model for any attorney who might be finishing up one phase of his or her practice." He himself was quoted as saying about pro bono work: "What I do now gives me the most pleasure of all the work I have done since my admission (to the Bar) in 1940, and is the most immediately effective on people's lives." Robert was a man of uncommon abilities, generosity, humor, integrity, loyalty and tenacity, and his life reflected all those qualities. He is survived by his wife; his daughters Jane Clemens and Elisabeth Mote and their husbands; his grandchildren Rebecca Gauthier, David Jr., and Amy Clemens; his three stepsons, Stephen, Richard and Paul, and their families; three siblings, Kenneth, Lillian and Charles (a fourth one, George, died earlier), and their extended families. They and all those who knew him will miss him sorely. Family will receive friends at Coffey Funeral Home, 91 N. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY 10591 Sunday from 3-5pm only. In lieu of flowers, donations to Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 1359 Broadway, Suite 1509, New York, NY 10018 would be appreciated.

THE Irish police force recently released details of how it tracked down one of the worst drivers on the country's roads. His name was Prawo Jazdy, and he had racked up more than 50 tickets for speeding and parking violations. Each time he was caught, he would give a different address.

VIDEO After years of traveling solo, the Frugal Traveler does Venice on the cheap with his wife and 6-week-old daughter. SLIDE SHOWS Get a taste of utopia at a 25-acre organic farm in Palmetto, Ga. Go vegetarian in Thailand, below, at an inventive cooking school and a playful restaurant that serves up delicate dishes. Visit the lost city of the Incas.

CORSELLO Dr. Serafina, 75, died Friday, February 20 in her New York City home. She was deeply loved and respected by her family, friends, colleagues and patients. She will be remembered for her boundless energy, her devotion to the art of healing, and her generous ability to love. Born in Palermo, Italy on May 13, 1933, she was raised and educated in Rome. She was an early practitioner of medical care that integrated mainstream and complementary and alternative treatments, which the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM), within the National Institutes of Health (NIH), began to study only in 1997. Dr. Corsello was among 25 physicians in the US selected to serve on an advisory committee to the Office of Alternative Medicine, created by Congress in 1992 (expanded by Congress in 1997 into NCCAM). She was an internatonally respected clinician, lecturer and the co-founder of the Foundation for the Advancement of Innovative Medicine (FAIM). Her book, The Ageless Woman, published in 1999, focused on anti-aging medicine and bio-identical hormone replacement. She is survived by her daughter Paola, son-in-law Robert, and adored granddaughter, Sofia Grazia. She leaves also her brother Piero and her extended family in Rome and Palmero. Family will receive Friday from 5:00 to 8:00pm at Frank E. Campbell (Madison at 81st Street). Funeral Mass, Saturday 10:00am, The Church of Saint Paul the Apostle.

This page: At Christian Dior Couture, John Galliano concocted his own New Look inspired by Dutch portraiture and a trip through the Dior archives. Opposite: At Armani Privé, the silhouette was poured on and heavily lacquered. For their first outing at the Haute Couture, the new Valentino creative directors Maria Grazia Chiuri and Pier Paolo Piccioli turned out a ladylike collection (this page) best described as, well, ver y Valentino. Opposite, clockwise from top left: At Dior, as the show carried on, the dresses became increasingly enormous. The show stopper at Atelier Versace was a pleated organza column that seemed to hold together by sheer force of will. At Givenchy Haute Couture, the designer Riccardo Tisci ricocheted between shapes that were part Edwardian, part 1980s. At Gaultier Paris, Jean Paul Gaultier likes his tailoring sharp but his genders blurred.

KENYON--Neal, on December 19, at age 79 after a 2007 stroke. A dancer, singer, director and choreographer for 40 years, he later taught at Florida State University. Cherished for dry wit and Southern charm, he won a 1968 Drama Desk award for "Dames at Sea", which introduced Bernadette Peters. Donations may be made to Broadway Cares or FSU's School of Theatre. 107 S. Wildwood Drive, Tallahassee, FL 32304.

The Science of Slam Clemson civil-engineering students have devised a way to rate slam dunks. To the frame of the backboard they mounted a small box housing two accelerometers, which measure nongravitational acceleration and force. The results are broadcast on the scoreboard within 15 seconds.

APPARENTLY, the dark cloud of the economy has a silver lining: less traffic congestion. A study released last week by Inrix, a supplier of live and historic traffic information for navigation devices and radio stations, shows that compared with 2007 there was a 30 percent decline in traffic congestion across major metropolitan areas of the United States last year. Inrix based its second annual report, called the National Traffic Scorecard, on an analysis of nearly 50,000 miles of primary roads, culled from information it collects on more than 800,000 miles of highways.

SUTTON--Clifton "Chuck" Rolet. Clifton "Chuck" Sutton was born October 31, 1950, heir to a family legacy of leadership; social justice champion recieved an award at age 12 after a major department store boycott. Chuck was Co-Executive Producer and writer for "It's Showtime at the Apollo" and contributed to the launching of Uptight magazine. Mourning his passing are wife Patricia Moore Sutton; children, Yusef Fanon, Amina Mae Hedmann, Clifton Rolet II, and Patrick Wesley; cousin, Jemin Sargeant, Uncle, Percy Ellis Sutton, Aunt, Essie Sutton, brother and sister Dr. Alexander C. Sutton, Jr. and Lura M. Sutton Sims, nine other siblings and numerous relatives, family and friends. Services: 10am, March 2, 2009, Riverside Church, the Nave, New York, New York. Interment: March 14, 2009, 1:00 pm Eastview Cemetery, San Antonio, Texas. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the scholarship: Grandvel Jackson Trust c/o Robert Mann Accounting Firm, 400 Montgomery Street, Suite 1110, San Francisco, CA 94104.

By the time the Knicks waived him last week, Stephon Marbury had collected about $150,000 a day to sit in exile, according to an analysis by CNBC's Darren Rovell. But the Knicks are not done paying for Marbury. The final bill comes due in June 2010, when the Utah Jazz will claim the Knicks' first-round draft pick, which is unprotected and could be in the lottery. The pick was part of the package the Knicks sent to Phoenix for Marbury in January 2004. (Utah later acquired it from Phoenix.)

KRESCH--Bessie R. P. died peacefully at home February 27, 2009. She was predeceased by her husband Nathan and son Arnold. She is survived by sons Richard (Jane) and Charles (Nora), grandchildren Jodie, Rebecca, Jennifer, Matthew, Stephanie and Jonathan as well as nine great-grandchildren. Bess was a dedicated socially conscious teacher and was active in Hadassah, The Sisterhood of Temple Israel in the City of New York and Temple Emanuel of Bayonne, NJ. Services private.

SIMONS--Naomi Ruth, originally of Flatbush, Brooklyn, on February 23, 2009, at the age of 87 in Pleasant Hills, California. Beloved wife of the late Harold Simons. Loving mother of Mark Simons, the late David Simons and Bettysue Feuer. Sister of Mildred Feinberg and a friend and brother-in-law to her husband, Frank. A teacher, a student of the language, in love with books and butterflies and, as Nippy Nao, a rider of imaginary horses. You will be missed but not forgotten. We will meet you for a beverage at the 19th Hole. Funeral at Beth David Cemetery, 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY.

A good dose of color lifts the spirits, which may explain why many people on the avenues are mixing colors with the abandon of the painters known as Les Fauves (the Wild Beasts), or the German Expressionists, who dashed the sweet-pea palette of the Victorians to pieces in the early 20th century. At the opening last week of a show of works by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner at the Neue Galerie on Fifth Avenue, a few of the guests appeared ready to step into the paintings.

THE NEWSPresident Obama's budget plan reflected the full costs of four major items that were never counted in the Bush administration's budgets: the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan; disaster relief; Medicare reimbursements to doctors; and relief from the alternative minimum tax for some taxpayers. BEHIND THE NEWS Adding in those costs would swell projected federal deficits over the next 10 years by some $2.7 trillion, but the president told Congress in his speech on Tuesday that he was ''committed to restoring a sense of honesty and accountability to our budget.'' He added: ''For seven years we've been a nation at war. No longer will we hide its price.''

SACKS--Harriet Fass. Harriet Sacks, wife, mother, grandmother, died peacefully at her home in Stuart, Florida. She leaves behind her smitten husband of 59 years, Leonard, daughter Amy and her husband Dr. Gary Kalkut, son Cary and his wife Julie Sandler, and son Andrew and his wife Julie Fisher, her grandsons Sam, Jacob, Elliott and Julian, and brother and sister-in-law Paul and Phyllis Sacks and Michael and Patti Sacks Leonard always called Harriet, "The most beautiful woman in the room." And she was. Graced with extraordinary looks, exquisite style, generosity and great confidence, she lit up a room like a star and will be greatly missed by everyone lucky enough to have known her. Harriet attended Hunter College. She worked as a stylist, account executive, advisor and business partner at her husband's advertising agency. Hers was an extraordinary life. After her childhood in the Bronx she lived in Manhattan, Denmark, Tokyo, The Hamptons, South Florida and traveled the world over. She gave us love, strength, conviction and in the end, a very special gift in the time we were able to spend together. On her last Saturday night, she said to her gathered family, "If there has ever been a better weekend, I don't know it." In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The James Lenox Society at New York Presbyterian Hospital. There will be a private funeral service. The family will be receiving visitors at the home of Amy and Gary Kalkut, 161 West 75th Street, on Monday, March 2nd and Tuesday, March 3rd from 6 to 9pm.

SEIFTER--Sam, Ph.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is profoundly saddened by the loss of its much beloved and admired Distinguished University Professor of Biochemistry. As a member of Einstein's founding faculty, Dr. Seifter helped to establish the College of Medicine as a leading institution for medical education and biomedical research both nationally and internationally. During 50 years of devoted service to the medical school he fulfilled a multitude of roles, including 11 years as chairman of biochemistry. He also was instrumental in establishing the College's scientific journal, Einstein Quarterly (now Einstein Journal of Biology and Medicine), for which he was faculty advisor and chairman of the editorial board. A world-renowned biochemist, best known for his studies of collagen and immunology, he set the standards for conscientious scientific exploration, collegial collaboration, and inspirational humanity. Since 1991, an annual lecture on minority issues, named in his honor, has recognized his ''unremitting efforts in the cause of social justice, particularly as it relates to medical education and scientific research.'' A teacher par excellence, he was a mentor to countless students and colleagues who remember him most fondly for his indefatigable curiosity and his great warmth and kindness in helping others in their quests for greater knowledge. His merit as a mentor was widely celebrated, including a Life Teaching Award from Einstein. His example as the finest of scientists, teachers, and human beings will be his legacy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Eleanor and the entire Seifter family. Allen M. Spiegel, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

THOMPSON--Hugh W.,Professor of Chemistry at Rutgers, Newark, an art collector and a man of sardonic wit, died Saturday, February 21st of injuries sustained in a head-on collision with a wrong-way bus while on his way to work.Professorial at all times, down to tweed jackets and sandals in most weathers, Hugh was revered by family and friends for both his idiosyncratic erudition and his puckish humor, as well as for his restless curiosity, intellectual reach and the breadth of his interests. He often managed to teach something, even in casual conversations, and it was likely to be an obscure but surprisingly interesting lesson delivered with wry wit. Hating hypocrisy, he was a passionate scientist, firmly dedicated to that which could be proven. He was wary of religion and politics, and he delighted in extracting the weird from both real and pseudo news sources. He would send the "news" items around, and then thoroughly enjoy any debate he stirred up. He was a man of cultivated tastes, with a love of foreign cuisines, a keen ear for music and an equally keen eye for art. Briefly, he was not only a collector, but also a dealer in graphics, during which time he turned his wife Elizabeth's childhood nickname, Tizbo, into the lofty sounding "Gallerie Tizbeau" for business dealings. He abandoned the gallery idea, but remained a connoisseur, amassing over many years a stunning collection of 19th and 20th century European and American graphics. Born December 7, 1936 in New York City, he grew up in Washington, DC and Kent, Ohio, where his father was Head of the Chemistry Department at Kent State University. His mother, Myra Waterman Thompson, was once a reporter for The New York Times. Hugh graduated from Cornell University with Honors in 1958, and received his Ph.D. from M.I.T. in 1963. An N.I.H. postdoctoral fellowship at Columbia University followed, and in 1964 he married Elizabeth Anne Barnes on the terrace of her aunt's villa on the French Riviera. Hugh's entire professional career was in the Chemistry Department at Rutgers, Newark, where he was variously Chair of the department, Director of the graduate program, mentor to countless graduate and undergraduate Chemistry students, and author of over 130 research papers in the areas of synthetic, structural, and dynamic organic chemistry and on hydrogen-bonding in the crystalline state. He was a member of the American Chemical Society. He is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Barnes Thompson of Manhattan, his daughter, Victoria Thompson of Washington, D.C., and his brother, Geoffrey Thompson of Mountain View, CA. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date. Hugh's family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Rutgers University c/o Chemistry Dept., 73 Warren St., Newark, NJ 07102.

MONA T. KANCIPER scanned the pastures that ring her blue and white barn, now at close to capacity and crammed with four-legged creatures temporarily, and in some instances permanently, residing here for lack of anywhere else to go. As the hard-driving president of New York Horse Rescue, a nonprofit organization that had its origins in the rehabilitation of racetrack castoffs but now copes with all breeds in all manner of predicaments, she is more interested in rescuing horses than whispering to them. But, like most horse-lovers, she occasionally does that as well.

The New England Patriots are apparently so confident that Tom Brady will return to form from a serious knee injury for the start of the 2009 season that they traded their safety net. The Patriots sent Matt Cassel, Brady's backup and their surprising star of last season, to the Kansas City Chiefs on Saturday for a second-round draft pick, No. 34 over all. The Chiefs also acquired the veteran linebacker Mike Vrabel in the deal.

Whether she’s singing of an illicit affair with Matt Damon or facetiously intimidating Jewish grandparents who don’t vote for Barack Obama, Sarah Silverman has never been constrained by propriety or good taste. But a dispute over money has at least temporarily brought a halt to her Comedy Central series, “The Sarah Silverman Program,” The Hollywood Reporter said. Ms. Silverman and her fellow executive producers on the show, Dan Sterling and Rob Schrab, have threatened to quit the program over proposed budget cuts. Comedy Central, which has not yet given an official order for a third season of the show, wants to reduce its budget to $850,000 an episode, down from $1.1 million an episode, amid cost-cutting at the network and throughout the entertainment business; Ms. Silverman and her producers would obviously prefer the larger figure. The Hollywood Reporter said that a resolution to the standoff was expected as soon as Monday.

As Monty Python fans will gleefully remind you, nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition, and for nearly 30 years, nobody in the Welsh town of Aberystwyth expected that the troupe’s 1979 film “Life of Brian” would be screened in the village. The movie, a satire on the life of Jesus, had been banned there for so long that residents forgot that the ban existed. But like an ex-parrot, the prohibition on “Life of Brian” has since been allowed to expire, and the movie will be shown for the first time at a screening on March 28, Agence France-Presse reported. Python members Terry Jones (who directed the film) and Michael Palin (who played Pontius Pilate) are both expected to attend the screening at the invitation of Aberystwyth’s mayor, Sue Jones-Davies, who also appeared in the film. “We decided that we might as well go on with it,” Ms. Jones-Davies said, according to Agence France-Presse.

A third and final novel by David Foster Wallace will be released posthumously by his longtime publisher, Little, Brown & Company, The Associated Press reported. The novel, called “The Pale King,” is expected to be released in 2010; according to The New Yorker, which published excerpts of its manuscript on Monday, it focuses on a group of I.R.S. agents working in a Midwestern office, and was about one-third complete in 2007. The novel was still unfinished when Mr. Wallace committed suicide in September; Little, Brown said that it will release the book, which runs “several hundred thousand words,” along with “notes, outlines and other material,” according to the A.P. Little, Brown previously announced that it would publish in April a graduation speech given by Mr. Wallace at Kenyon College in 2005 as a book called “This is Water.”

A production of a new play by Richard Bean at the National Theater in London provoked a protest in the theater on Friday, BBC News reported. The play, a comedy called “England People Very Nice,” chronicles 300 years of immigration patterns in the London neighborhood of Bethnal Green, as the area is inhabited by French Huguenots, Irish, Jews and Bangladeshis. During a talk at the theater given by Mr. Bean, Hussain Ismail, a playwright, and Keith Kinsella, a teacher, took to the stage carrying placards, objecting to what they said were racist depictions of ethnic groups in the play. “Richard Bean is making it seem like all Bangladeshis are drug dealers or users, muggers and marry their cousins,” Mr. Ismail said, according to the BBC. Nicholas Hytner, the director of the National Theater, told the BBC that the play “clearly sets out to demonstrate that all forms of racism are equally ridiculous.”

Your calendar may say 2009, but in concert arenas around the country, the 1980s will be going strong for months to come. The vintage British metal band Def Leppard announced that it would commence a 40-city tour with its like-minded American cousins Poison and Cheap Trick. In a release, Def Leppard said the tour would begin June 23 in Camden, N.J., and conclude Sept. 6 in San Bernardino, Calif. Mötley Crüe will begin its own summer tour, “Crüe Fest 2: The White Trash Circus,” on July 19. That tour, which includes latter-day acts like Buckcherry and Papa Roach, continues through Sept. 5, the group said in a release. And the bands REO Speedwagon, Styx and .38 Special will tour together May 13 through July 11, Billboard reported. A new song by Styx and REO Speedwagon, called “Can’t Stop Rockin’,” is planned for release later this month.

The Metropolitan Opera announced that the title role in its production of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly” would be performed by Patricia Racette on Tuesday night and Saturday afternoon, the final performances. She is replacing Cristina Gallardo-Domâs, who is ill, the Met said in a release. Ms. Racette previously sang the role at the Met in October and November. Saturday’s performance will be broadcast to movie theaters around the world as part of the opera house’s “The Met: Live in HD” series.

Nebbishy misanthropes, your ship has come in: The Tribeca Film Festival announced that its opening-night film would be the world premiere of Woody Allen‘s “Whatever Works,” which was written and directed by Mr. Allen and stars another great bespectacled pessimist, Larry David of “Seinfeld” and “Curb Your Enthusiasm” fame. The film, which will screen April 22, also stars Evan Rachel Wood (“The Wrestler”), Patricia Clarkson and Ed Begley Jr. The Tribeca Film Festival runs through May 3, and is to announce its full schedule next week.

“In a way it was like having the encores before the main offering,” Allan Kozinn wrote in The New York Times on Friday. Reviewing a benefit concert of the Vienna Philharmonic conducted by Zubin Mehta at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, he was referring to the waltzes and other light works by Johann Strauss Jr. that made up fully half of the program. The “main offering” to come during Mr. Mehta and the orchestra’s visit last week was three concerts including meatier fare over the weekend.

Updated | 5:54 p.m. After the Broadway revival of “Guys and Dolls” opened on Sunday night to widespread negative reviews, the producers held discussions today about the show’s future and decided to keep it running, according to several theater industry sources familiar with the talks.

Orient-Express Hotels Ltd. has told the New York Public Library that it is unable to complete the purchase of the Donnell branch in Midtown for $59 million, the library said Monday. “We are now evaluating various alternatives to ensure that Orient Express honors its commitment to the library,” said Herb Scher, a library spokesman. Under the original agreement, announced in November 2007, the five-story building on West 53rd Street was to be replaced by an 11-story hotel. The library would own and occupy space on the first floor and underground, and five floors of the hotel would connect to the “21” Club on 52nd Street, also owned by Orient-Express. The hotel company said in a statement: “The global financial crisis and the lack of availability of credit for construction and real estate development means that progress cannot be made on the project at the present time.”

Kepler is designed to measure tiny brightness variations in stars that might indicate orbiting planets. NASA hopes to find Earth-like planets orbiting stars at a distance that would permit liquid water, potentially allowing them to support life. Kepler will be placed in an orbit around the Sun, surveying more than 100,000 stars for three years.

Prosecutors of the prostitution case that exposed Eliot Spitzer as a client while he was governor are appealing a court order directing them to unseal records that may shed light on the origins of the investigation. The case led to Mr. Spitzer's resignation as governor of New York in March 2008. The Feb. 19 ruling by Jed S. Rakoff of United States District Court in Manhattan ordered the federal prosecutors to provide the records -- including sworn affidavits that were part of wiretap applications in the case -- to The New York Times, which in December filed a motion to unseal the material.

It is a simple enough question: who bought the credit-default swaps that American International Group sold during the housing bubble? And at this point -- after Bailout No. 4, with the government handing A.I.G. another $30 billion to go with the previous $150 billion -- you would think that the taxpayers would have the right to know that information. Is it Goldman? Royal Bank of Scotland? The Irish banks that are on the verge of collapse? What happened to all that transparency the new administration keeps talking about?

The film and television industry, one of the few fields generating profits in the deep throes of this recession, is fighting to extend the incentive programs that has created film jobs here in the past few years. At a news conference at Kaufman Astoria Studios in Queens, dozens of film and television workers gathered to ask politicians to make the New York State Film Production credit program a permanent measure.The program, which offers studios tax credits from the city and state for up to 35 percent of the production costs, has been so successful that the state has already paid out the $690 million that was to last through 2013.

WASHINGTON -- In the weeks after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, some Justice Department officials asserted that the American military could assume a major role in hunting terrorists in the United States and would not be subject to traditional Fourth Amendment curbs on unreasonable searches and seizures. The arguments that the military could take on the role of a super police force were ultimately discounted by the Justice Department's Office of Legal Counsel in the waning months of the Bush administration. The legal counsel's office stated on Oct. 6, 2008, for instance, that several assertions made by Justice officials in 2001 were "either incorrect or highly questionable."

So, Robert Samuelson writes, why not "bribe" them to buy now? Give them a 10 percent tax credit, up to $15,000, on the purchase of a new home -- with the bribe offer lasting only a year so that "waiting would be costly." [Newsweek]

Politics | Why libertarians don't fit well within the conservative movement: It's difficult to support economic freedom while opposing cultural change, an article says. "Markets foster technological innovation" -- cars, TVs, computers -- "and this constantly upends established ways of life." And as the Bush years showed, "limited government never has been a social conservative principle." With free-market economics on the outs in the meltdown, "even the conservative Heritage Foundation is calling for more government involvement in the economy." [Policy]

The Semi-Automatic was designed not by Wanders but by Ito Partnership for the Morgans Hotel Group, to conquer the cliché of the gift shop.

I've often written about Mukhtar Mai, the Pakistani woman who used compensation money from a gang-rape to start schools and a women's shelter. She's one of my heroes, and lately there are some signs of funny business concerning the legal case against her attackers. Mukhtar has deeply offended the local feudal elites by championing the poor and pointing out the degree to which corruption protects the elites when they rape or abuse poor women. It's no secret that some of those feudal families would like to see Mukhtar put in her place, even killed, and I hope the latest burst of activity doesn't reflect that. Mukhtar's aide, Samson Salamat, send around this note earlier today, and then Mukhtar just sent another note saying she's deeply concerned. Here's Samson's note.

What: A 150-person dinner to toast the new Roberto Cavalli Mastercard.Where: Milan's Teatro Franco Parenti, a bilevel multiplex with an outdoor Olympic-size pool.Dress Code: Cleavage galore. Bustiers, push-ups, underwires -- whatever it took to get that Italian showgirl silhouette. Lots of ruching, draping, beading and plenty of lip liner, tinted eyewear and python skin as second skin. Clothing coverage diminished as the night wore on and the unclad masses infiltrated the exclusive dinner.Drinks: The evening began with Mumm's champagne served on silver platters by white-gloved waiters. Later, Cavalli's own Tenuta dei Dei (2006) was served.Décor: Huge lanterns and massive banquettes blanketed with Cavalli's own floral printed silks and more roses than the gardens of Valentino's French chateau.Music: Opera during the cocktail hour; the British singer Malde May backed up by a live five-piece jazz band during dinner. The Italian journalist Jo Squillo was so taken that she parked her dinner chair in the middle of the dance floor and tapped the evening away alone. Cavalli acted as house paparazzo and snapped everyone in sight.Food: Bacon-wrapped shrimp, pici pasta with thyme, fennel-crusted branzino. Then they stopped serving because no one could take the fourth lamb course.Gift: Iridescent python credit card holder.Perks: White-coated waiters outnumbered guests. At 11 p.m. the dinner turned into a multilevel rager with hundreds of hotties dancing in the dark.Overheard:"The best thing about the credit card is that you get to be friends with me. Good clients will get access to me online where we can chat. I love Facebook!" -- Roberto Cavalli

After three weeks absorbing and analyzing the results of the Jan. 31 provincial elections, in the corridors and meeting rooms of the Iraqi parliament, it seems that all the political blocs are terrified for their future. There was a sequence early in the third period of Sunday's Flyers-Devils game where Martin Brodeur was at his classic, amazing best, as he made a juggling stop off Scott Hartnell. "The hard shot popped into the air off Martin Brodeur's glove," writes Dave Caldwell in Monday's Times, "and he swatted the puck backward into the corner with his stick. Brendan Shanahan tracked it down and started a rush." Two quick passes and 10 seconds later, Johnny Oduya gave the Devils a 3-0 lead. It was, as Dave writes, "as if the play had been designed that way."

The poison pill forever changed the hostile deal. It allows a board to "just say no" and forces a hostile bidder to run a proxy contest to remove and replace the board to eliminate the pill impediment. If a target is well-defended and prohibits shareholder action by written consent or the calling of a special meeting, then the proxy contest is confined to the annual meeting.

A major snowstorm swirled into the New York region late Sunday night, closing schools in New York City and throughout the region. Flight travel essentially ground to a halt with the cancellation of thousands of flights and morning commuting on buses and trains was delayed.As of 8 a.m., most city subways were operating on or close to schedule, but there were significant delays on the A, G and L lines, and all New York City buses were delayed, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported. New Jersey Transit commuter trains were running up to 25 minutes late, with some cancellations, and New Jersey Transit buses were running 20 minutes late. The Long Island Railroad also reported scattered delays. In addition to the flight cancellations, major bus carriers, including Greyhound and Peter Pan, canceled all trips after midnight.
