Tuesday, 9 a.m. If you're the sort of person who mourns the loss of grit in New York City, then the third item on the agenda of the Landmarks Preservation Commission will come as a relief. The fact is, few care if a wealthy lawyer builds a porch on his colonial revival, but the installation of a public toilet at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn is important beyond dispute. The application to construct the public privy will weigh the merits of convenience against the damage that it might cause to Prospect Park. The actual decision is more or less beside the point. Our public servants are talking about the simple things again. 1 Centre Street, ninth floor, Manhattan.Ah, the Grade School Flashbacks

The Looking Ahead column last Monday, about financial events scheduled this week, erroneously included one company among those that will report quarterly earnings. The company, Smithfield Foods, will report its earnings on Thursday, March 12; it did not report them last Thursday.

An article in some editions last Monday about the arrest of a Bronx woman on murder charges in the death of her 4-year-old grandson referred incorrectly, using information from the police, to another child found in the woman’s apartment, an 18-month-old, who was unharmed. The child is a girl.

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Thursday about the trial of a New York police officer, Rafael Lora, in the shooting death of a Bronx man, Fermin Arzu, referred incorrectly to a spectator, Disairy Arzu, who spoke about the case outside the courtroom. She is a niece of the victim, not of the officer. The article also paraphrased one of her comments incorrectly. She said she did not believe the defense’s version of events — not the prosecution’s.

An article on Friday about reaction to a proposal by the Obama administration that would limit the value of deductions for charitable gifts misstated the name of a fund-raising expert in Memphis. He is Robert F. Sharpe Jr., not Robert J. Sharpe.

BAUMRIN--Steve N.,56, unexpectedly on February 28th. He graduated from Great Neck North and attended the School of Art at Washington University is St. Louis. He loved painting in his studio and chronicling his life through his art and poetry. He was the next generation to run The Delancy Tool Company. He was deeply loved by his family and friends. He was there for everyone and didn't know the word "no" when it came to being kind, generous and compassionate. He will be missed by all who knew him. Beloved son of Phyllis B. Davis and Leonard Baumrin, step-son of Sherman Davis. Loving husband to Melanie. Devoted father to Julien and Chloe. Big brother to Michael (Sara) and Gail (Ira). Services Monday, March 2nd, 2009 at 12:45. "Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Two missiles fired Sunday from American remotely piloted aircraft killed at least eight militants in a Taliban stronghold on the Afghan border, according to a local intelligence official and news reports. The attack, in the Sora Rogha area of South Waziristan, a tribal region controlled by the Pakistani Taliban leader Baitullah Mehsud, hit a militant base, the official said. The dead included four Arab militants, the intelligence official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity because he was not authorized to speak to reporters.

BERNSTEIN--Sidney, of Coconut Creek, FL died on February 28, 2009, at the age of 70. Beloved of his Beverly. Proud father of Michael and Jamie (Grobman) Bernstein of North Bethesda, MD and Evan and Sherry (Bernstein) Schwartz of New City, NY. Adoring "Grandpa Shalom" of Joshua and Jacob Bernstein and Hailey and Alexa Schwartz. A graduate of Columbia College and The Cornell Law School, he had a distinguished career in legal and professional publishing spanning more than 40 years. He volunteered in Israel for Sar-El. He is a past president of Congregation Beth El of La Jolla, CA, a member of the board of directors of Temple Beth Am, Margate FL, a member of Congregation Shalhevet Hamaccabim in Israel, and was Executive Vice President of the Golda Meier Association. His life was dedicated to his children, his grandchildren, the law, and Israel.

SILVERSTEIN--Jeanette (Jean), 95, died peacefully on February 28, 2009. Survived by her adoring children Naomi (Strauss) and Baruch Silverstein, son-in-law Sidney F. Strauss and daughter-in-law Michal Silverstein, cherished grandchildren, Michael and David Strauss and Ayraham Mordechai Silverstein. This was a truly beautiful woman in every sense of the word whose life touched everyone who ever came in contact with her. She was admired by everyone and was "dear" to the entire world around her.

KORENGOLD Edna Gerler. With great sadness the family and friends of Edna Gerler Korengold mourn her loss. Born December 5, 1919 in New York City. Edna died in Naples, Florida on February 22, 2009 of cardiac failure. She is survived by her devoted husband, Marvin Korengold, sons, George Korengold, Danny Korengold and Tommy Korengold, and daughter, Karen Twible. "Grandma" of 10 grandchildren, Adam, Erin, Maddy, Kara, Lizey, Maggie, Meredith, Will, Kendall and Greer, and great-grandmother of four, Maeve, Sam, Dylan and Benjamin. Educated at Wadleigh High School and New York University, Edna was an avid reader who provided numerous recordings for the blind. Her sweetness and warmth were well known to her family and resulted in a large circle of friends over the course of a long life. She will be remembered with the greatest of love and admiration. Services will be held at the Washington Hebrew Congregation, 3935 Macomb Street, Washington, DC on Friday, February 27 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to programs for the visually impaired or to the charity of one's choice.

WOOLNER--William R.,MD, formerly of Westchester, died January 27 in Damariscotta, ME. Born in 1917 in Peoria, IL, he lived in the metropolitan New York area from 1923 to 1999 when he moved to Maine. He is survived by his wife Joan of Jefferson, ME, his daughters Victoria Woolner Samuels, Cate Woolner, and Justine Woolner Wise, his sister Mary Kaufman, his stepdaughters Theresa Stevens, Patricia Adams, Claire Adams and ten grandchildren. Dr. Woolner attended Yale University and Medical College of Virginia. His long-time practice was in White Plains and he served on the Board of White Plains Hospital. He was a member of Westchester Reform Temple. Contributions can be sent to Westchester Jewish Community Services, on whose Board he served for many years.

LANDES--Phyllis Markman. Mommy, you are in our hearts and minds forever. With all our love always, Lu and Harry

DWIGHT--George H.P.,81, died of cancer on February 27. Born on August 6, 1927, a life-long New Yorker, he worked passionately to make the city a better place. After graduating from Groton School in 1945, he attended Harvard and then Columbia Law School, graduating in 1952, the articles editor of the Law Review. As a young lawyer, George was Special Assistant Corporation Counsel under Mayor Robert Wagner. A passionate Democrat, he joined the Lexington Democratic Club, a reform club, in the 1950s, eventually becoming president. On the boards of the United Neighborhood Houses of New York and Union Settlement for many years, he most recently crusaded to prevent the Washburn Wire Factory site on the East River from becoming a mall and to create Vision Harlem, a plan to highlight Harlem's landmarks, relink its neighborhoods and connect the entire community to the rest of the City. He was a partner at the firm of Richards & O'Neil and most recently of counsel at McLaughlin & Stern. An ardent gardener, George grew wild flowers on the rocks of Mount Desert Island, Maine. Married for 34 years to Eleanor Collier Dwight, he is survived by his five children Lucinda Dwight, George Dwight, Margaret Dwight, Bradley Dwight and Susannah Prout his three step-children- Daphne Trotter, Willard Gardiner and Sargent Gardiner, seven grandchildren, and seven step-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 4pm on Thursday, March 12 at St. Michael's Church, 225 West 99th Street, New York, NY. Donations to Union Settlement and the Groton School, Groton, MA are welcome.

BéLA FLECK ''Throw Down Your Heart: Tales From the Acoustic Planet Vol. 3, Africa Sessions'' (Rounder) Four years ago the banjoist Béla Fleck went to Africa with an agenda. He had long been intrigued by his instrument's ancestral history there; he had also been gripped by the transcendent voice of Oumou Sangare, the queen of Malian Wassoulou music. His journey resembled fieldwork in the sense that he was traveling with a recording engineer and film crew. But he also had his banjo and an urge to bridge musical divides.

Landmarks and Toilets Tuesday 9 a.m. If you're the sort of person who mourns the loss of grit in New York City, then the third item on today's agenda of the Landmarks Preservation Commission will come as a relief. The fact is, few care if a wealthy lawyer builds a porch on his colonial revival, but the installation of a public toilet at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn is important beyond dispute. The application to build the public privy will weigh the merits of convenience against the aesthetic damage it might cause to the plaza and Prospect Park. The actual decision is more or less beside the point. Our public servants are talking about the simple things again. 1 Centre Street, Ninth floor, Manhattan.

TATUM--Wilbert. The Board and staff of the Community Service Society of New York mourn the loss of a close friend and innovator. His pioneering work in journalism, activism and community service leaves a genuine legacy in New York City, particularly for communities of color. His leadership and his visceral outrage at injustice remain an inspiration to the people whose lives he touched. I'll personally miss his wonderful sense of humor and his role as a mentor and advisor to a generation of African American leadership. Our deepest sympathy goes to his wife, Susan, daughter Elinor and the entire Tatum family. David R. Jones, Esq., President & CEO Community Service Society

PRINTZ--Mary Selina (nee) Horn, died February 21, 2009 of congestive heart failure due to post polio syndrome. Born April 8, 1923 in Detroit Michigan to (Wild) Bill Horn, speedboat builder and champion racer and Zelah Mitchell. Told at age five by the doctors that she would never walk again she paid little attention. She and dad got roller skates and bicycles and the latest braces and by 16 she had one of the first high school driver's licenses. She and dad built landing craft for the military in WWII. She had her own apartment in NYC where she answered phones in the lobby of the Sutton Hotel. Mel Torme among others. She married a British Naval officer and jumped on the back of his motorcycle for a European Grand Tour honeymoon. On second though she joined a girlfriend in the West Indies for a six-week divorce and invented "The Mahogany Club" near the airport on St. Thomas. She and the piano player developed into a permanent duo and settled in NYC. She got a job at an answering service to work the same hours as her husband and quickly made a name in the business, opened her own, helped Comden and Green put together "Bells Are Ringing" (her own business being called ("The Belles Celebrity Answering Service") and became kind of an operational central for the live wires on both coasts. The Belles still is known for the individual custom secretarial type service with no buttons to push on East 56th St. in NYC. Mary is survived by her husband Robert J., twin sons William Horn and R. Joseph, daughter in law Pam Wendi and granddaughter Emma Lauren. A memorial is being planned.

MILLER--Seymour 90, of Wellington, FL formerly of Brookville, NY on February 27, 2009. Born February 18, 1919. Sy grew up in Brooklyn. One of the original Darby's Rangers, he served in North Africa, Sicily, and Italy. He is survived by his wife of 63 years Rosalyn; sons Marc (Stephanie deSibour) of Washington, D.C., and Peter (Catherine Tambini) of New York City, granddaughters Jamie and Emily; brother Robert, sister-in-law Phyllis Hildebrand and loving nieces and nephews. Funeral Services Wednesday, March 4, 11am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. Donations may be made to U.S. Army Ranger Association, P.O.Box 52126, Fort Benning, GA, 31995-2126.

KELLER--Jacqueline. Long Beach Island will never be the same. Goodbye dear friend. Susan and Joel Simon

NEKO CASE ''Middle Cyclone'' (Anti-) ''The next time you say 'forever' I will punch you in your face,'' Neko Case vows on ''Middle Cyclone,'' an album filled with cataclysmic love songs. It's Ms. Case's sixth studio album on her own, in a career that also includes her on-and-off membership in the New Pornographers. In her latest songs nothing is constant: not romance, not life, not memory, not even the rhythm or the shape of a melody. Putting her big, torchy voice behind larger-than-life imagery, she's fearless through every transformation, merging herself with storms -- one song is titled ''This Tornado Loves You'' -- and seeing herself in animals like a killer whale and a vulture. She's as dangerous as she is devoted.

Why Are iPhone Users Willing to Pay For Content? It may be no surprise that the best-selling computer book this year is ''iPhone: The Missing Manual'' (O'Reilly, 2007), by David Pogue, the technology products reviewer for The New York Times.

The last of the National Guard troops who went to New Orleans to help the police deal with violence in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina ended their time in the city over the weekend. With the state facing a $341 million budget deficit, some lawmakers pressed for an end to the deployment. Above, members of the Guard prepared to depart Sunday. Left, troops ferried storm victims to the Superdome in 2005. Below, troops patrolled the Fifth Ward, making car stops and providing backup to the city police. Troops also handled domestic violence calls and car accidents. Some of the Guard members later signed on with the Police Department.

Recovery.gov, the Web site started by the Obama administration to show the distribution of economic stimulus funds, seems to be the Internet version of a 1960s' Main Street construction sign, ''Your Tax Dollars at Work.'' This being 2009, however, it begins with a short video by President Obama. The site had a surge in traffic last Tuesday, the night of Mr. Obama's address to Congress, although its peak came the day it began, Feb. 17. Traffic to the site last Wednesday came mostly from search engines, as well as the White House and PlentyofFish, a free dating site. SHELLY FREIERMAN
Barcelona's winless skid in the Primera Liga reached three after it lost at Atletico Madrid, 4-3. Barça's 12-point lead going into 2009 is down to 4 over Real Madrid.

At left, Raymond Del Barrio as Damon Runyon in the contemporary revival. ''Guys and Dolls'' was based on Runyon's stories.

10 P.M. (BET) HARLEM HEIGHTS For young and fabulous African-Americans in New York, Harlem is the place to be. This new documentary series offers a glimpse into the lives of eight men and women from different backgrounds as they make the leap from college to adulthood. The cast, above, includes a budding lifestyle magazine editor, a man from a troubled family working to find success while giving back to his community, and the hard-partying son of a Harlem politician who is considering a political career of his own. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Gabrielle Anwar of ''Burn Notice'' is a guest. Segments look at teaching parents to deal with stress and aggression; obesity and the recession; and Australian animals.

The Walt Disney Company has cut the “High School Musical” franchise from its varsity line-up, announcing that a fourth installment –- with all new lead actors — will have its premiere on television instead of the big screen. “High School Musical 4,” set for 2010, will feature a story built around a rivalry with a cross-town school, said Gary Marsh, president of entertainment at Disney Channels Worldwide. Unclear at this stage is whether Kenny Ortega, the director of the first three movies, will return. Zac Efron and Vanessa Hudgens will not reprise their starring roles, although other characters (Ashley Tisdale as Sharpay?) may pop up to add continuity. The writer of the last three movies, Peter Barsocchini, will also write the new screenplay. With “High School Musical 3: Senior Year,” the franchise –- a giant business for Disney with merchandise, theme park and music extensions –- moved from television to theaters. It sold $250 million in tickets worldwide, but the songs had less of a cultural impact than those from No. 2.

Our long national nightmare is over, and a budgetary standoff between Sarah Silverman and Comedy Central has ended without bloodshed, The Hollywood Reporter said. Ms. Silverman, the comedian and star of “The Sarah Silverman Program,” had threatened to leave the series with her fellow executive producers when Comedy Central sought to reduce its budget to $850,000 an episode from $1.1 million. Instead, Comedy Central will produce a new 10-episode season of the show with Logo, the gay-themed cable network; both channels are divisions of MTV Networks, which is owned by Viacom. The series, a satire on Ms. Silverman’s Southern California life, features two gay characters, played by Brian Posehn and Steve Agee. “We’re happy,” Ms. Silverman told The Hollywood Reporter. “All we ever wanted was just to make our show. Nothing fancy just our show.” A new season of the show is planned for 2010.

Ned Rorem, Stephen Sondheim and John Corigliano are starting at $500. Michael Torke, Chester Biscardi and Ricky Ian Gordon are bargains at $100. But they all have 10 weeks to elicit higher prices. The Lotte Lehmann Foundation has persuaded some 30 composers to donate their autographs with a few bars of music in their handwriting for a silent auction to raise money for the organization, which promotes the art song through composition and voice competitions in the name of the German-born soprano. Daron Hagen, a board member who is in charge of the auction, said the group hoped to raise $20,000. The online auction ends May 12 and people can attend a cocktail party the next day for a last round of bidding, according to the foundation’s Web site, lottelehmann.org. Bids can be submitted at the site, which shows each entry. (At a recent glance, the first few measures from Danny Elfman’s theme to “The Simpsons” were fetching $300.) Mr. Hagen said the minimums were based on a review of autograph prices on eBay and elsewhere. Mr. Sondheim’s excerpt is the opening of his song “Send in the Clowns” from the show “A Little Night Music,” with the opening lyrics: “Isn’t it rich?”

While the “Life on Mars” stars Harvey Keitel, Jason O’Mara and Michael Imperioli were joining labor leaders Monday in Astoria, N.Y., urging New York State to extend its tax credits for film and television production, ABC canceled their series, Variety reported. “Life on Mars,” adapted from the British television series of the same name, starred Mr. O’Mara as a New York police detective who is hit by a car and believes that he has awoken in the 1970s. The British series was popular enough to yield a spinoff, called “Ashes to Ashes,” set in the 1980s; the American adaptation never quite took off with viewers, even after it was moved to a time slot following the science-fiction serial “Lost.” Variety said that ABC’s version of “Life on Mars” could end with a finale that would resolve its central time-travel mysteries.

The Tom Hanks–Meg Ryan romance that doesn’t involve its leading man leaping into a volcano or a product placement for AOL is planned for a Broadway adaptation. Variety reported that a musical version of “Sleepless in Seattle,” the 1993 Hanks-Ryan vehicle that followed “Joe Versus the Volcano” and preceded “You’ve Got Mail,” about a pair of lonely hearts who meet via a call-in radio show, is in the works. The composer Leslie Bricusse (“Stop the World – I Want to Get Off,” “Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory”) will write the music and Jeff Arch, who wrote the “Sleepless” screenplay with David S. Ward and Nora Ephron, will write the book; Joel Zwick is slated to direct and David Shor is producing. No theater or casting was announced. Mr. Shor plans on a 2010 opening.BONUS: Vincent Canby’s review of “Sleepless in Seattle” (“a movie you may hate yourself in the morning for having loved the night before”) can be found here.

Feuds are nothing new for the British rock group Oasis, which over the years has engaged in wars of words with rival bands, the media and its own members. But now Oasis, led by brothers Noel and Liam Gallagher, finds itself in a dispute with the Chinese government over two canceled shows the band was scheduled to play on April 3 in Beijing and April 5 in Shanghai, Agence France-Presse reported. The group said the shows, which would have marked its debut in mainland China, were canceled because the Chinese government had discovered that Noel Gallagher performed in 1997 at a benefit concert advocating freedom for Tibet. But a Chinese cultural ministry official denied that the band’s performance licenses had been revoked, and a local promoter told Reuters that the shows had been canceled for financial reasons. “I have no money,” the promoter said, according to Reuters. “It’s normal in an environment of economic crisis.”

Updated | 2:52 p.m. The National Endowment for the Arts on Tuesday announced guidelines for arts groups seeking grants from the $50 million apportioned to the agency in the economic stimulus bill. Some funds will be distributed to state arts agencies and regional arts organizations who will sub-grant it to various cultural groups; funds will also made available directly to nonprofit arts organizations via a competitive process. One-time grants must be used for salaries for positions that are in jeopardy or have been eliminated as a result of the current economic crisis, or for fees for previously engaged artists and/or contractual workers. The distributing organizations may use up to $50,000 for their own jobs and for the administration of funds. Priority will be given to cost-effective programs that maximize the amount of funds distributed, the agency said. The awards will support activities that are scheduled to begin on April 1, or shortly thereafter.

The YouTube Symphony Orchestra, the classical music performance group whose musicians auditioned via the video-sharing Web site YouTube.com, has selected its inaugural lineup, The Associated Press reported. To form the orchestra, Google, which owns YouTube, asked prospective members in December to post videos of themselves on the site; some 3,000 videos were narrowed down to 200 finalists, who were then voted on by YouTube users. The winners include more than 90 performers from 13 states and 29 countries ranging in age from 17 to 55. They will attend master classes and rehearsals, and on April 15 will perform “Internet Symphony No. 1, Eroica,” a new composition by Tan Dun, at Carnegie Hall, where they will be conducted by Michael Tilson Thomas, the music director of the San Francisco Symphony. A video mashup of the concert will be posted on YouTube the following day.

A revival of Tennessee Williams‘s “A Streetcar Named Desire,” starring Cate Blanchett as Blanche DuBois and directed by Liv Ullman, is among the highlights of the 2009-10 season at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The schedule, which the Kennedy Center announced on Tuesday, includes Terrence McNally‘s “Nights at the Opera,” in which his plays “Master Class” and “The Lisbon Traviata,” and a new work called “Golden Age” will be performed in repertory; the 2010 VSA arts International Festival, which features performers with disabilities; and the start of the center’s two-season Focus on Russia series, at which the Mariinsky Ballet, the Mariinsky Opera and Orchestra and the Bolshoi Ballet, among many other groups, will perform. More information about the season can be found online at kennedy-center.org.

Crime | A Penn professor and poverty expert serves as a juror in a Philadelphia murder trial and finds "there is an abstraction in most of the literature and in most of what I have written." The trial leaves him in crisis, with questions about himself, the accused and the victim: "Who were these men, only a piece of whose lives were laid in front of us?" And so he visits the defendant after his acquittal, only to find that still "ambiguities remain unresolved, contradictions abound, ends dangle." [Dissent]

"You can't knock a country that created wallpaper and silk," says Alison Picket, the art consultant for the Opposite House, a new Kengo Kuma-designed boutique hotel in northeast Beijing. Situated in a village in Sanlitum - an area that has become a hub for art, dining and shopping (Dover Street Market, Miu Miu and Fendi boutiques are sprouting next to Uniqlo and Apple outposts) - the hotel sets the mood in its public rooms with Picket's collection of ''wearable'' art linked by ancient techniques and bold materials.

A lawmaker in California wants to force Google Earth and similar services to blur images of so-called "soft targets" like schools, hospitals, churches and government buildings to protect them from terrorists. Oy. No, your income tax doesn't suddenly shoot up if your taxable income rises one penny into a new bracket. To belabor the obvious, the tax code specifies marginal rates: your rate rises from 33 to 35 percent if your taxable income exceeds $372,950, but only the income above $372,950 pays the higher rate.

This week marks the 25th anniversary of the death of Libby Zion, an 18 year-old college freshman who died in a New York Hospital. The fallout from her death led to sweeping reforms in the hours and supervision of doctors-in-training, called "residents.''

Instead of reporting to the laundry or the kitchen or the boiler room, a Washington state prison inmate, Robert Knowles, reports to the compost heap. Mr. Knowles is taking part in a "green work" program at the Cedar Creek Corrections Center. Inmates grow organic produce, compost the prison's food waste, take part in ecological research projects with a nearby university, and even produce honey from the prison's own hives.

History | If Obama becomes a great President he can thank Bush, in one historian's view. For it won't be just because of Obama's own skills, but because the luck of historical timing gave him a foil for greatness: a discredited administration to be repudiated. There have been repeated couplings of "manifest incapacity and towering success": John Adams and Jefferson; John Quincy Adams and Jackson; Buchanan and Lincoln; Hoover and F.D.R.; and, most recently, Carter and Reagan. "Key to the success of the reconstructive or realigning presidents has been the ability to justify their direction and expand their support by indicting the failures of the old order." [Atlantic]

World | Posters reveal the changed nature of anti-Semitism today, a columnist says. In the Nazi era, Jews were personified as hook-nosed, ghoulish and filthy. But "anti-Semitic propagandists of our own age typically omit the Jew's features altogether in favor of a faceless, Star-of-Zion-emblazoned tank or helicopter," he says, reflecting the preoccupations of leftists allied with radical Muslims. "In this left-wing intellectual climate, disparaging any race or religion per se is off limits. The preferred tactic is to disparage the allegedly colonial, imperialist, racist etc. nature of their actions." [National Post]

The Paris ready-to-wear shows start tomorrow, and already there are fresh signs that the fashion crowd is tightening its belts. The new Philippe Starck-designed hotel Mama Shelter, where the rooms start at 79 euros, is the latest favorite address for usually spendthrift editors having to watch their expenses. When I stayed at the hotel during the couture shows in January, it was the no-vacancy hot spot, and for this week only the 299 euro rooms are still available.

Organizers for the Nascar Nationwide series race at Circuit Gilles Villeneuve in Montreal signed a three-year deal to keep the event there. This year’s NAPA Auto Parts 200 will be held Aug. 30, a Sunday, with qualifying a day earlier. In its first two years, the Montreal event was held on Saturday with qualifying on Friday, on the same weekend that the Nascar Sprint Cup series was competing in another city.

East Brunswick (N.J.) High School Coach Marcus Borden used to bow his head and drop to one knee when his football team prayed. But the Supreme Court on Monday ended the practice when it refused to hear his appeal of a school district ban on employees joining a student-led prayer. The decision could add another restriction on prayer in schools, advocates said.

The Reebok Grand Prix, a New York meet that has become one of the best-known events in the country, will become part of the international track federation’s new Diamond League circuit starting in 2010.

Favre said his heart had been set on joining Coach Jon Gruden. He called Tampa Bay's offense a "a perfect fit."

On Feb. 21, Kiril Georgiev of Bulgaria played 360 people simultaneously in Sofia, Bulgaria, breaking the world record for such a feat. His final score was 284 wins, 70 draws and 6 losses. The previous record holder, Andrew Martin, an English international master, had played 321 opponents at Wellington College in Berkshire, England, on Feb. 21, 2004. Susan Polgar of the United States played 326 people simultaneously at a mall in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., in August 2005, but the Guinness Book of World Records did not recognize her record as official.

A capsule summary on Friday for a sports article about the federal judge presiding over the perjury trial of Barry Bonds misstated her surname. As the article correctly noted, she is Susan Illston, not Ellison.

An article on the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about several buildings in New York City that are adding cogeneration systems to create electricity and capture otherwise wasted energy included several errors.

Because of an editing error, an article and a headline last Tuesday about adulterated pig organs that were sold in a southern Chinese livestock market and sickened 70 residents who ate them referred incorrectly to clenbuterol, the suspected contaminant. Clenbuterol is a performance-enhancing drug with steroid-like properties, but it is not a steroid.

An article last Tuesday about Art Capital Group, a company that lends money to artists, collectors and gallery owners using artwork as collateral, misstated the surname of one of the company’s owners at two points. He is Baird Ryan, not “Mr. Baird.”.

Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 6 about the possible lessons the United States could draw from Japan’s attempts to recover from a severe downturn after the bursting of a real estate bubble in the late 1980s referred incorrectly to the steps the country took to try to stimulate its economy. Although the country spent trillions of dollars on infrastructure projects and cleaned up the debt-ridden banking system, it did not reduce consumption taxes to encourage consumer spending. (The government raised the tax in 1997 over the objection of many economists in an attempt to reduce growing budget deficits.).

The Metropolitan Opera announced that the title role in its production of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly” would be performed by Patricia Racette on Tuesday night and Saturday afternoon, the final performances. She is replacing Cristina Gallardo-Domâs, who is ill, the Met said in a release. Ms. Racette previously sang the role at the Met in October and November. Saturday’s performance will be broadcast to movie theaters around the world as part of the opera house’s “Met: Live in HD” series.
Nebbishy misanthropes, your ship has come in: the Tribeca Film Festival’s opening-night film will be the world premiere of Woody Allen’s “Whatever Works.”

Orient-Express Hotels Ltd. has told the New York Public Library that it is unable to complete the purchase of the Donnell branch, right, in Midtown for $59 million, the library said Monday. “We are now evaluating various alternatives to ensure that Orient Express honors its commitment to the library,” said Herb Scher, a library spokesman. Under the original agreement, announced in November 2007, the five-story building on West 53rd Street was to be replaced by an 11-story hotel. The library would own and occupy space on the first floor and underground, and five floors of the hotel would connect to the “21” Club on 52nd Street, also owned by Orient-Express. The hotel company said in a statement: “The global financial crisis and the lack of availability of credit for construction and real estate development means that progress cannot be made on the project at the present time.”.

As Monty Python fans will gleefully remind you, nobody expects the Spanish Inquisition, and for nearly 30 years, nobody in the Welsh town of Aberystwyth expected that the troupe’s 1979 film, “Life of Brian,” would be screened in the village. The movie, a satire on the life of Jesus, had been banned there for so long that residents forgot that the ban existed. But like an ex-parrot, the prohibition on “Life of Brian” has since been allowed to expire, and the movie will be shown for the first time on March 28, Agence France-Presse reported. The Python members Terry Jones (above right, with Graham Chapman), who stars in and directed the film, and Michael Palin, who plays Pontius Pilate (among others), are both expected to attend the screening at the invitation of Aberystwyth’s mayor, Sue Jones-Davies, who also appears in the film. “We decided that we might as well go on with it,” Ms. Jones-Davies said, according to Agence France-Presse.

A production of a new play by Richard Bean at the National Theater in London provoked a protest in the theater on Friday, BBC News reported. The play, a comedy titled “England People Very Nice,” chronicles 300 years of immigration patterns in the London neighborhood of Bethnal Green, as the area is inhabited by French Huguenots, Irish, Jews and Bangladeshis. During a talk at the theater given by Mr. Bean, Hussain Ismail, a playwright, and Keith Kinsella, a teacher, took to the stage carrying placards, objecting to what they said were racist depictions of ethnic groups in the play. “Richard Bean is making it seem like all Bangladeshis are drug dealers or users, muggers and marry their cousins,” Mr. Ismail said, according to the BBC. Nicholas Hytner, the director of the National Theater, told the BBC that the play “clearly sets out to demonstrate that all forms of racism are equally ridiculous.”.

FIELD--Eris M. It is with great sadness that we mark the passing of a gracious and committed friend. In philanthropy, as in life, Eris M. Field was a full partner with her husband, Lawrence N. Field ('52) and together they have been among the most generous of donors to Larry's alma mater, Baruch College, CUNY. The historic Lawrence and Eris Field Building at 17 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan is a physical embodiment of their vision and commitment to the College's academic excellence. The nationally ranked Field Programs in Entrepreneurship at Baruch College are growing and thriving because of Eris and Larry's unwavering support. Married for 49 years to her husband, Larry, and the devoted mother of two accomplished daughters, Eris was a passionate patron of the arts in Los Angeles, her adopted city. The Eris M. Field Plaza at the entrance to the Walt Disney Concert Hall commemorates her devotion to the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Among her other philanthropic efforts, Eris was a "Founder" of the Los Angeles Music Center, and, in 2005, Cedars-Sinai Medical Center dedicated the Eris M. Field Endowed Chair in Diabetes Research, a gift that recognizes Eris's own battle with the disease. Eris Field lived a full and generous life and we extend our most heartfelt condolences to her husband, Larry; her daughters, Lisa and Robyn; Robyn's husband, Anthony O'Carroll; and her two beloved granddaughters, Ibby and Kate. Baruch College and the Baruch College Fund community join Eris and Larry's many, many friends who are saddened by her untimely passing. Kathleen Waldron, President Baruch College and Larry Simon '65, President The Baruch College Fund

BERNSTEIN--Sidney, of Coconut Creek, FL died on February 28, 2009, at the age of 70. Beloved of his Beverly. Proud father of Michael and Jamie (Grobman) Bernstein of North Bethesda, MD and Evan and Sherry (Bernstein) Schwartz of New City, NY. Adoring "Grandpa Shalom" of Joshua and Jacob Bernstein and Hailey and Alexa Schwartz. A graduate of Columbia College and The Cornell Law School, he had a distinguished career in legal and professional publishing spanning more than 40 years. He volunteered in Israel for Sar-El. He is a past president of Congregation Beth El of La Jolla, CA, a member of the board of directors of Temple Beth Am, Margate FL, a member of Congregation Shalhevet Hamaccabim in Israel, and was Executive Vice President of the Golda Meier Association. His life was dedicated to his children, his grandchildren, the law, and Israel.

The Devils' 3-0 victory over Colorado on Sunday assured them of a 17th consecutive winning season. That matches the Detroit Red Wings' current string of winning campaigns, both of which began in 1991-92 (though with a one-year break because of the lockout during the 2004-5 season). They are the longest such streaks going, not just in the N.H.L., but in any of the four major North American sports. The achievement is another in a list of impressive ones for the Devils.

KOZA--John W.,a leader in the real estate capital management industry and a beloved husband and father, died on February 27, 2009 in his home in Calistoga, CA. He was 67. Born in 1941 and raised on the South Shore of Boston, Mr. Koza was the son of John S. and Mary Kennedy Koza of Quincy, MA. After graduating from Archbishop Williams High School, he earned a BS in economics and a MBA from Boston College. After graduation, Mr. Koza served in the U.S. Army from September, 1962 to September, 1965. He was a First Lieutenant in the Quartermaster Corps stationed in Wurzburg, Germany. After a career in mutual funds and banking, Mr. Koza began his real estate career at Fidelity Investments and later served as Senior Vice President of Asset Management at The Boston Company Real Estate Counsel, Inc. With a move to the West Coast, Mr. Koza was the Director of Real Estate Consulting for Frank Russell Company in Tacoma, WA and then Managing Principal of The McMahan Group in San Francisco, CA. In 1998, he formed Koza & Co. of which he was Principal and later formed Koza Partners, which he considered the fruition of his vision for real estate capital management. Mr. Koza served on the advisory boards of the National Council of Real Estate Investment Fiduciaries (NCREIF), the Zell/Lurie Real Estate Center at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania as well as Crosswater Realty Advisors. He was past Chairman of the NCREIF Valuation Committee, the Pension Real Estate Association (PREA) and the PREA Institute Committee. He was a member of Lambda Alpha. Mr. Koza served on numerous boards including Franciscan Children's Hospital in Boston, MA, The Annie Wright School in Tacoma, WA, and Calistoga Affordable Housing, Inc. He is survived by his wife, Linda Marie Koza and her two sons, Richard and John Loeb. In addition, he leaves his six children from his first marriage to Karen Monroe Koza: Gail K. Koza and her husband, Paul Meskell, Karla Koza Evers, her husband Stefan, their sons Ethan and Maxfield, Adele R. Kohler, her husband William, their three children, John, Ella, and Scarlett, Carole Koza Varghese and her husband George, William M. Koza and his wife, Alena, and Thomas J. Koza. Mr. Koza is also survived by his four siblings: Carol Burns and her husband James, Mary Drown, Doris Baldwin and her fiancee Richard Mullowney, and Robert Koza and his wife, Susan. He is also survived by many loving nieces and nephews and their families. Known for his quick wit, his loyalty to his friends and family as well as his belief in the value of education as a conduit to success, John relished his interpersonal relationships and conversations. He took great pleasure in his role as mentor to many in his field and advisor to his children. He will be greatly missed but never forgotten. A public viewing will be held from 5:00-7:00pm on Tuesday, March 3rd at Morrison Funeral Chapel of Napa Valley, 900 Vintage Ave., St. Helena, CA. An additional viewing will be held at 10:00am on Wednesday, March 4th, at Our Lady Of Perpetual Help Church, 901 Washington St., Calistoga, CA. A funeral mass will follow at 11:00am. A gravesite service will follow at the St. Helena Cemetery, 2461 Spring St., St. Helena, CA. A memorial service to honor Mr. Koza's life will be held on Saturday, March 7th at 10:00am at St. Thomas the Apostle Parish, 111 Exchange St., Millis, MA. A reception for friends and family will follow at the home of Adele and Will Kohler, 10 Baker Rd., Medfield, MA. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Hospice of Napa Valley and the American Cancer Society.

WARRING--Renee, 96, died peacefully February 28, 2009 at her family's home. Renee was predeceased by her husband, George. She is survived by her daughter, Wendy, her son-in-law, Troyen Brennan, and her grandchildren, George and Hannah Brennan. Born in Vienna, she escaped the Nazis in 1938. She lived in Queens for fifty years, working in the garment industry until her daughter was born, late in her life. In 1990, she moved to Boston to be with her daughter's family and then to Hartford in 2006. Beloved by and devoted to her family and friends, she was a talented dressmaker, artist, and whiz at Jeopardy; she entertained many with her wit. A memorial service is planned for May in Hartford.

For decades, psychologists have warned against giving children prizes or money for their performance in school. ''Extrinsic'' rewards, they say -- a stuffed animal for a 4-year-old who learns her alphabet, cash for a good report card in middle or high school -- can undermine the joy of learning for its own sake and can even lead to cheating. But many economists and businesspeople disagree, and their views often prevail in the educational marketplace. Reward programs that pay students are under way in many cities. In some places, students can bring home hundreds of dollars for, say, taking an Advanced Placement course and scoring well on the exam.

BERG--Dr. Anne S.,passed peacefully February 28, 2009. Loving wife to Bill and devoted mother to Kathryn Smerling (Robert Smerling) and Lisa Berg. Beloved grandmother to Matthew Smerling and inspiration to her sister, Evelyn Halper. A renaissance woman with a full heart and many passions. Accomplished athlete, a respected educator whose thirst for knowledge kept her young. She will be missed by her many friends and her large extended family who cherished her wisdom and kindness.

VIALOTTI--Dr. Charles P. passed away peacefully after a brief illness in his 100th year. Devoted husband of Rose since 1941. Loving father of Charles, Jr., and the late Lynn Harper. Esteemed physician who retired just three years ago after 70 years of compassionate devotion to his patients. Avid fisherman and skilled artist whose vast collection of sketches delight all who have seen his work. His broad smile and positive life attitude will be missed by all. Services were private followed by interment in a family mausoleum in South Hampton, NY. Donations in his name to Villa Marie Claire Hospice, 12 West Saddle River Road, Saddle River, NJ 07458 are appreciated by the family.

PRODDOW--Penny, passed away peacefully at home in New York, February 28, 2009, following a short illness. Penny's professional worlds included teaching at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, curating at R. Esmerian, Inc., co-writing a monthly column for In Style Magazine. Educated at Bryn Mawr as a classical archaeologist, Penny wrote a series of children's books in the 1970s, bringing to life the world of Greek myths for a young audience: these writings would become the basis of her lecture series "Pause for Pegasus" given at the educational department at the Met in recent years. Applying her knowledge of ancient art, Penny became a jewelry researcher and historian; her pioneer efforts assisted in organizing landmark jewelry exhibitions and co-writing articles and five books. Most important of all, Penny's friends and associates will miss her gutsy creativity, her acute observation enhanced by historical and literary knowledge, and of course her laughter - all together providing for a unique humanity that only Penny Proddow could bring to our lives. Burial in Nantucket will be private. Ralph Esmerian

MARK--Martha W.,70, of Croton on Hudson, NY, died after a long illness, February 27, 2009 at Northern Westchester Hospital Center, Mt. Kisco, NY. Mrs. Mark, known before her marriage as Martha Weinstein, is the daughter of Anne Kruger and Jacob Olshen. She is a graduate of Far Rockaway High School and Hunter College, Class of 1959. At her bedside were her husband, Lawrence H. Mark, Jr., and their two daughters, Katherine A. Mark of Croton on Hudson, a graduate of Williamsville East High School who attended Skidmore College, and Elizabeth (Betsy) Mark Meyerson of Atlantic Beach, NY. Mrs. Meyerson is a graduate of Croton Harmon High School, Mt. Holyoke College and St. John's Law School. Mrs. Mark also leaves two grandchildren, Benjamin Jacob Meyerson, 10, and Hannah Grace Meyerson, nine. She also leaves her godson Glenn M. Smith of New York City and his son, Daniel, 11, as well as her brother-in-law, Richard C. Mark of Purchase, NY, and his children and grandchildren, and cousins Peggy Tirschwell and Richard Gilder of New York City, and their children and grandchildren. An accomplished writer and editor, Mrs. Mark was the author of two books on fashion, edited numerous print articles and scripts for TV documentaries. In 1976, she founded the Victorian Costume Collection at the Theodore Roosevelt National Inaugural Site in Buffalo, NY, and was a founder of the Ringwood, NJ, Cooperative Nursery School in 1965. At her request, there will be no funeral service. Instead, the family asks those who knew and loved her to think of her or say a prayer at 11am EST, on Tuesday, March 10, 2009.

LIEBER--Charles Saul, M.D.,MACP, AGAF, age 78, passed on March 1, 2009. Son of Izak Lieber and Laje Maj. Loving husband of Maria A. Leo-Lieber. His struggle to survive the Holocaust fostered a remarkable strength and determination that led him to become a renowned leader in science and medicine. He had an exceptional love and pride for his family and will forever be remembered for his brilliant mind, passion for life, and gentle spirit. Services are today 10am at Temple Sinai, 1 Engle St., Tenafly, NJ. Memorial donations in his honor can be made to the USC Shoah Foundation Tribute to Charles S. Lieber (213-740-6051) and the AGA Foundation Charles S. Lieber Fund (301-222-4005).

LIEBER--Charles S.,M.D. The Department of Medicine of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourns the passing of Dr. Charles S. Lieber, Professor of Medicine in the Division of Gastroenterology for over 40 years. KATZ--Madelyn. It is with deep regret that the Intrepid Family of Foundations note the passing of Madelyn Katz, who together with Ron and the entire Katz family have been leading supporters of the Intrepid Museum, the Fisher House Foundation and the unique Operation Mend program that they created which is partnered with the Intrepid Relief Fund. Maddie was an outstanding woman whose kindness and generosity touched many, many people. Operation Mend is only the latest example of how she and Ron touched so many lives. On a recent visit to the program in Los Angeles, Intrepid leadership saw first-hand how the program, which provides advanced reconstructive surgery to military personnel with severe facial injuries, gives new hope to dozens of affected troops and their families where there was none and highlights how, when citizens care, nothing can stand in the way of how America shows its gratitude to our troops - something so important to the Katz Family. Maddie and Ron have worked miracles for them and so many others. Her loss is indeed a great loss for the charitable world, but she will remain a wonderful example of how one can answer the call to help others in need. We extend our deepest sympathies to our dear friend Ron, her husband of 52 years, and to their entire Katz family. We ask that you keep them in your prayers. Love to you Ron, Todd and Dana and all of our Katzs. Arnold and Audrey Fisher Marty and Nancy Edelman Ken and Tammy Fisher Charles and Nathalie de Gunzburg Richard and Peggy Santulli Winston and Jessica Fisher Bill White and Bryan Eure And our Entire Board of Trustees family and supporters.

Fears that the world's economies are even weaker than had been thought ricocheted around the globe on Monday as investors from Hong Kong to London to New York bailed out of stocks. Losses cascaded from one market to the next as concern spread that government efforts had not been enough to stabilize troubled financial institutions or broader economies. Only by Tuesday morning did markets show signs of stabilizing, with key indexes in Asia showing more modest declines.

India will hold national elections over four weeks starting next month, election officials said on Monday, as the leading national parties scrambled to join forces with regional and caste-based parties. India has been ruled by coalition governments for over a decade, making the country's national parties increasingly reliant on smaller factions. That trend is only expected to intensify. The economy is likely to dominate at the polls. India's economy grew 5.3 percent in the last quarter, the slowest rate since 2003. SOMINI SENGUPTA

People with bipolar disorder are at risk for an array of fatal illnesses, according to a review of 17 studies involving more than 331,000 patients. The researchers, writing in the February issue of Psychiatric Services, looked at studies of patients whose bipolar illness was severe enough to require hospitalization. Mortality in those patients ranged from 35 percent to 200 percent higher than in comparison groups.

The decision by federal prosecutors to appeal a judge's ruling in the Barry Bonds perjury case will delay his trial at least until July, according to a timeline submitted Monday by the federal clerk of the Northern District of California. Prosecutors must file their appeal with the Ninth District Court of Appeals by June 1, and Bonds's lawyers have until July 1 to register their response, according to the timeline. A three-judge panel of the appellate court will probably hear oral arguments on the case and then must make a decision, further delaying the trial, which was scheduled to begin Monday in United States District Court in San Francisco.

The Rangers should know whether forward Sean Avery, their former agitator, will be headed back to their lineup by noon Tuesday. The Dallas Stars placed him on re-entry waivers at noon Monday and by that time Tuesday, the N.H.L. will announce the lowest-seeded team that put in a claim for him. The Rangers cleared room on their roster Monday by sending forward Mark Bell, whom they claimed off waivers last week from Toronto, to their American Hockey League affiliate in Hartford.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Wednesday morning.

The antiques collector who says he placed the winning bid for two disputed bronze sculptures and refuses to pay for them acted without the support of the Chinese government, Bloomberg News reported. Cai Mingchao, a collector and auctioneer, said he had submitted the two winning $18 million bids for the bronze heads of a rat and a rabbit; the Qing dynasty sculptures were looted in the 1800s from an imperial palace outside Beijing, and were “bought” last week in Paris at a Christie’s auction of the Yves Saint Laurent collection. But Mr. Cai has said he will not pay for the works out of patriotic duty, prompting speculation that the Chinese government, which has demanded that France return the objects to China, had encouraged or pressured him to do so. In a report in China’s state-run Xinhua news service, an official from China’s State Administration of Cultural Heritage said that Mr. Cai had acted alone. At a press conference, Li Zhaoxing, the spokesman of China’s legislature, said, “The auction will not add anything positive to the good tradition of the country in which it was hosted. It will only have the opposite effect,” according to Bloomberg.

Three co-defendants of Anthony Pellicano, the former Los Angeles private investigator who was convicted of wiretapping and charges related to racketeering, were sentenced Tuesday for their roles in his operations, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Pellicano, who in May was found guilty of federal charges for conspiring to wiretap and intimidate celebrities and executives, and in August was convicted of wiretapping the ex-wife of the investor Kirk Kerkorian in a child-support case, was sentenced in December to 15 years in prison. Mark Arneson, a former sergeant in the Los Angeles Police Department, and Rayford Earl Turner, a former telephone technician were each sentenced to 10 years in federal prison, following their convictions for federal racketeering and racketeering conspiracy counts in May. Abner Nicherie, an entrepreneur who had hired Mr. Pellicano, was sentenced to 21 months in prison for aiding and abetting a wiretap.

Having solicited the votes of theatergoers, the creators and producers of the Broadway musical “Avenue Q” said that George W. Bush would stay on — as part of a lyric in the show. In December, the puppet musical announced a contest seeking a replacement lyric for the song “For Now,” in which its protagonists are told that many things in life (including then-President Bush) are “only for now.” After substituting phrases like “recession,” “your mother-in-law,” and “this show” during performances, the show’s writers Robert Lopez, Jeff Marx and Jeff Whitty have changed the lyric to, “George Bush was only for now.” (When the “Avenue Q” tour plays California, the lyric will be changed to “Prop 8 is only for now.”) In a statement, Mr. Whitty said that during the tryout period “we discovered there is nothing like the strong response the Bush line gets from the audience.”

Extending her winning streak on the Billboard album chart, Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) held at No. 1 for an 11th week, with sales of 73,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Only five other solo female artists have had albums with 11 or more weeks at the top spot in the 53-year history of Billboard’s chart: Alanis Morissette, Whitney Houston, Mariah Carey, Carole King and Judy Garland. Also this week, the Virginia metal band Lamb of God‘s new release, “Wrath” (Epic), reached No. 2 with 68,000 sales, and the Jonas Brothers‘ “3D Concert Experience” (Hollywood), the soundtrack to their new concert film, opened at No. 3 with 50,000. As with the film, which opened last weekend, the album fell far short of industry sales expectations. With a boost from eight wins at the Academy Awards, the “Slumdog Millionaire” soundtrack (Interscope) moved 44,000 copies, reaching No. 4, and Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) is No. 5 with 41,000.

While the global economy continues to strike a series of sour notes, a manufacturer of pianos in the Czech Republic has been supplementing its income by making household furniture in addition to uprights and baby grands, Agence France-Presse reported. Petrof, a company founded in 1864, has seen its sales decline from about 7,000 pianos annually to about 2,850 a year; since the fall, it has also been producing furniture made with the same ebonization, polishing and varnishing techniques used in the construction of its pianos. Petrof was started as a cabinet-making workshop, and made everything from grenade boxes to sleepers for railway tracks during World War II. “At the time of a crisis, people think about other things than buying a new piano,” said the company’s president, Zuzana Ceralova-Petrofova, according to Agence France-Presse.

From “Hairspray” to “All Shook Up,” Broadway musicals about the early days of rock ‘n’ roll can be a crapshoot. (These days, even Broadway musicals about crapshoots can be crapshoots.) That hasn’t dissuaded the producers of the musical “Memphis” from announcing that they plan to bring their show to the Great White Way in 2009. The musical, with a book and lyrics by Joe DiPietro (“I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change”) and music and lyrics by David Bryan, a founding member of Bon Jovi, tells the fictional story of a white DJ who falls in love with a black singer in 1950s Tennessee; it has been staged at the La Jolla Playhouse and Seattle’s 5th Avenue Theater. The Broadway production will be directed by Christopher Ashley (“Xanadu”) and choreographed by Sergio Trujillo (“Jersey Boys”). A theater and cast were not announced.

When the American artist Bruce Nauman represents the United States at this summer’s Venice Biennale, his work will not be limited just to the national pavilion. Details of the exhibition, which is being organized by Carlos Basualdo and Michael R. Taylor, curators from the Philadelphia Museum of Art, were announced Wednesday. The show, called “Bruce Nauman: Topological Gardens,” will survey four decades of Mr. Nauman’s work, including video, installation, performance and neon pieces. In addition to the United States pavilion, the Università Iuav di Venezia at Tolentini and two floors of a 15th-century gothic palace that houses the Università Ca’Foscari will show different versions of a sound installation by Mr. Nauman that would not fit in the pavilion. The Biennale opens to the public on June 7 and is on view through Nov. 22.

In Lisa Loomer’s new play “Distracted,” Cynthia Nixon portrays the mother of a child who may or may not have attention deficit disorder. The play, which is running Off Broadway at the Laura Pels Theater in a production of the Roundabout Theater Company, begins as Mama tries to quietly meditate, only to be interrupted by the screeching voice of her demanding child.

Update | 5:20 p.m. Horton Foote, who chronicled America’s wistful odyssey through the 20th century in plays and films mostly set in a small town in Texas and left a literary legacy as one of the country’s foremost storytellers, died in Hartford, Conn., on Wednesday. He was 92, said his daughter, Hallie Foote.

City officials said on Wednesday that the number of homeless people living on the streets in New York has declined by 30 percent in one year, prompting one prominent advocacy group to immediately dismiss the estimate as far-fetched. At a news conference at the Department of Homeless Services, Commissioner Robert V. Hess cheerfully announced the results of the annual Homeless Outreach Population Estimate, which was conducted in January. More than 2,000 volunteers comb some of the city's streets for one night each year, looking for homeless people in parks, bus shelters and subways.

I am looking to buy an apartment in Manhattan. I have the cash and I do not want to get a mortgage loan. Is it better to buy a co-op or a condominium? The co-op pays interest on its mortgage and includes part of that payment in my maintenance charges. If I don't get a loan, can I renegotiate the maintenance charges?

I was a shareholder in a co-op and sold my apartment during 2008. I did not receive a 1098 form for my share of interest paid on the co-op's mortgage. I received the form in each of the four previous years. Since I sold it during the year, am I not entitled to a tax deduction for the maintenance, including interest, for a majority of the year?

Elinor Carucci's latest body of work, "My Children," focuses on - you guessed it - her own brood, in this case her 4-year-old twins, Eden and Emmanuelle. The Israeli-born Carucci takes the viewer through the many stages of raising a child, from pregnancy to bath time. Every image - whether it's capturing the tension of a haircut or a face covered in cherry juice - has a visceral yet beautiful quality, which any parent can relate to. Carucci's photos, along with works by Sunil Gupta, Amy Jenkins and Angelika Sher, will be featured in the show "Intimate Line," which opens tomorrow and runs through April 18 at the Sepia International Gallery in Chelsea.

A detailed survey of the rapid pace of gentrification in Chinatown, including counts of luxury hotels and trendy bars, was released Wednesday by two community organizations, which argued that a special protective zone with tenant protections should be drawn around the historic and densely packed immigrant neighborhood.Over the last few years, new construction in Chinatown -- by both Chinese and non-Chinese investors -- has increased as the neighborhood has felt spillover development pressures from TriBeCa, the Lower East Side and NoLIta. In total, the Community Development Project of the Urban Justice Center and the Chinatown Justice Project of the Committee Against Anti-Asian Violence, which conducted the survey in 2008, counted 25 new hotels, 118 new high-end priced boutiques and cafes and 26 luxury residential buildings in Chinatown, which it defined with borders along Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, Pearl Street, Worth Street, Broadway and a jagged boundary to the north.

Yesterday, when Monsieur Alloux met me at Gare Lyon, he seemed surprised that I had taken the train from Milan to Paris, a seven-hour trip, when normally I would fly. I thought a change would be fun. In truth, I had visions of going to Peck, the food shop in Milan, and loading up on prosciutto and cheese and bread for the ride. I would look out at the mountains-snow-covered, of course-and at noon, open my Tuscan red (instead of buying shoes or a sweater in Milan, I had bought a beautiful corkscrew at Lorenzi) and enjoy the break and the unknown company. Instead, I managed to get food poisoning at La Langhe, one of those iffy fashion hangouts. Suffice it to say I did not see the inside of Peck. I love the advice I got from Hal Rubenstein before the Versace show. He's so sweet, Hal. He said I should take slow magnesium, several Tums and a banana. Or was it apricot juice? I thanked him and wished Donatella would hurry and start the show. I think her collection was a good one, don't you? Everyone else in Milan got in such a spasm about big shoulders and ballooning sleeves, but not Ms. Versace. She has a modern sense of glamour, from a woman's point of view, no nonsense and certainly no freak show.

An article on Saturday about the Qatar Philharmonic Orchestra, which made its American debut last month at the Kennedy Center in Washington and was conducted by Lorin Maazel, misidentified a group Mr. Maazel led in Germany, where he worked with Kurt Meister, who put together the Qatar orchestra. It was the Bavarian Radio Symphony Orchestra, not the Bavarian State Opera.

A capsule summary on Monday for a sports article about goalie Martin Brodeur’s 100th career shutout for the Devils misstated the timing of that accomplishment. It came in his third N.H.L. game after returning from elbow surgery, not his second game.
Documents released Tuesday provide new evidence that the Swiss bank UBS help wealthy Americans evade taxes on billions of dollars in assets.
The Jets continued their extreme defensive makeover on Tuesday, again looking to Baltimore to find free safety Jim Leonhard. He signed a three-year deal.

A film column on Friday about the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series misspelled the name of the director of “Eden Is West,” a movie in the series. He is Costa-Gavras, not Costa-Gravas.
The Devils a had 3-2 victory over the Maple Leafs in Toronto, helping Martin Brodeur improve to 4-0 since returning from an elbow injury.

Jarvis Hayes hit a tie-breaking 3-pointer on a pass from Vince Carter with 18 seconds left to lift the Nets to a 99-95 road win over the Milwaukee Bucks.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Saturday about the cancellation of a production of “iSondheim: aMusical Revue” planned for Atlanta misstated Stephen Sondheim’s contributions to the shows “Gypsy” and “West Side Story.” He wrote the lyrics, not the music. (Jule Styne wrote the music for “Gypsy,” and Leonard Bernstein wrote it for “West Side Story.”).
St. John’s made up a 15-point deficit over the last 10 minutes of regulation to defeat Georgetown, 59-56, in overtime on Tuesday night at Carnesecca Arena.

An article on Monday about Geoff Ogilvy’s victory at the Accenture Match Play Championship in Arizona referred incorrectly to a shot he hit on the 11th hole that landed under a jumping cholla cactus. It was his second shot, not his drive.

An article on Friday about Susan Illston, the federal court judge presiding over the perjury case of Barry Bonds, referred incorrectly to a part of her background on the bench. Another judge, Vaughn Walker — not Illston — oversaw an unrelated phone records case involving AT&T and the federal government.

The Phone Smart column on Thursday, about improvements in the cellphone industry’s prepaid plans, misstated recent changes made to Virgin Mobile USA’s policies and fees. Changes that allowed customers to make free calls after 7 p.m. and make unlimited free calls to other Virgin Mobile users affected customers with contracts, not prepaid ones. (Those features were already available to Virgin’s prepaid customers.).

The State of the Art column on Thursday, about some innovative programs on Google Labs, misstated the number for sending short text messages via cellphone to Google, seeking information. It is 46645, not 46643.

An article on Monday about Senator Charles E. Schumer’s call for $100 million in federal stimulus funds to convert the James A. Farley Post Office, next to Pennsylvania Station, into a transit hub misstated the year that the original, above-ground Penn Station was demolished. It was 1963 — not 1968, which is the year the current Penn Station opened.

A revival of Tennessee Williams’s “Streetcar Named Desire,” starring Cate Blanchett, below, as Blanche DuBois and directed by Liv Ullmann, is among the highlights of the 2009-10 season at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. The schedule also includes Terrence McNally’s “Nights at the Opera,” in which his plays “Master Class” and “The Lisbon Traviata” and a new work called “Golden Age” will be performed in repertory, and the start of the center’s two-season Focus on Russia series, in which the Maryinsky Ballet, the Maryinsky Opera and Orchestra and the Bolshoi Ballet will perform. More information about the season can be found at kennedy-center.org.

The Tom Hanks-Meg Ryan romance that doesn’t involve its leading man leaping into a volcano or a product placement for AOL is planned for a Broadway adaptation. Variety reported that a musical version of “Sleepless in Seattle” — the 1993 Hanks-Ryan vehicle about a pair of lonely hearts who meet via a call-in radio show, which followed “Joe Versus the Volcano” and preceded “You’ve Got Mail” — is in the works. Leslie Bricusse (“Stop the World — I Want to Get Off,” “Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory”) will write the music, and Jeff Arch, who wrote the “Sleepless” screenplay with David S. Ward and Nora Ephron, will write the book; Edward Zwick (of the films “Defiance” and “Glory”) is scheduled to direct; and David Shor is producing. No theater or casting has been announced. Mr. Shor plans on a 2010 opening.

PALY--William, on March 2nd, 2009. Beloved husband of the late Shirley. Devoted father of Bruce and Ann, and father-in-law of Diane and Dennis. Adoring grandfather of Brooke, Jake, and Isabelle. We will miss you.
POLSKY--Gladys P. Congregation Eman-El of the City of New York mourns the death of our cherished member and extends deepest sympathy to her family.

GITELLE--Gene L.,M.D., formerly of New York City, died Monday, March 2, 2009 in Tuscon, AZ after a short illness. A psychiatrist and addictionologist, Dr. Gitelle was an assistant attending physician at the Mount Sinai Medical Center and a 50-Year distinguished Life Fellow of the American Psychiatric Association. He was a diplomate of ASAM, the American Society of Addiction Medicine and a member of many professional societies. Born in New York City in 1923, he served in the Army Air Corps in WWII, and was graduated from the University of British Columbia and the Medical School of the University of Berne, Switzerland. He is survived, and will be sorely missed by: his wife, Tobey Baron Gitelle; Sharon Gitelle (John French) and grandchildren, Emily and Joshua Segal; Betsy Gitelle (Jay Leve) and granddaughter Sarah; and Jeffrey Gitelle (Jennifer Weuve); as well as those who knew him. A memorial service will be scheduled in New York City in the Spring for family and friends. Donations made to the American Macular Degeneration Foundation (AMDF), P.O. Box 515, Northampton, MA 01061-0515 will be welcomed.

HOLSTEIN Dr. Albert of Middletown, New Jersey died Friday, February 27, 2009 at the age of 91. Born September 14, 1917, Dr. Holstein was the son of Sarah Ruskin Holstein and Jacob Holstein, owners of Holstein's Department Store on Jackson Avenue in Jersey City, NJ. Born and raised in Jersey City, Dr. Holstein attended St. Peter's College before continuing on to receive his DDS from Georgetown University Dental School. He practiced dentistry in Jersey City for nearly 50 years. Dr. Holstein is predeceased by his sisters Clara Feldman and Libby Bergen. He is survived by his wife Eleanor Holstein, their sons, Paul Holstein of Delmar, NY and Neil Holstein of Southport, CT; three children from his previous marriage Jeffrey Danneman of New York, David Holstein of Massachusetts and Robyn Holstein-Glass of Maryland and seven grandchildren. A private funeral service was held at Beth Israel memorial Park in Woodbridge, NJ on Sunday, March 1, 2009. Donations in Dr. Holstein's name may be sent to Ms. Ann Craved, St. Peter's College, 2641 Kennedy Blvd., Jersey City, NJ 07306, acraveo@spc.edu. Checks should be mailed to St. Peter's College.

ROSS--Lore. The American Jewish Committee mourns the passing of our beloved friend Lore Ross. In partnership with her devoted husband of 67 years, Eric, Lore was an extraordinarily generous woman who leaves behind an enduring legacy of philanthropy and human kindness. She will be sorely missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Eric, their children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Richard J. Sideman, President David A. Harris, Executive Director

BERNSTEIN--Sidney, of Coconut Creek, FL died on February 28, 2009, at the age of 70. Beloved of his Beverly. Proud father of Michael and Jamie (Grobman) Bernstein of North Bethesda, MD and Evan and Sherry (Bernstein) Schwartz of New City, NY. Adoring "Grandpa Shalom" of Joshua and Jacob Bernstein and Hailey and Alexa Schwartz. A graduate of Columbia College and The Cornell Law School, he had a distinguished career in legal and professional publishing spanning more than 40 years. He volunteered in Israel for Sar-El. He is a past president of Congregation Beth El of La Jolla, CA, a member of the board of directors of Temple Beth Am, Margate FL, a member of Congregation Shalhevet Hamaccabim in Israel, and was Executive Vice President of the Golda Meier Association. His life was dedicated to his children, his grandchildren, the law, and Israel.

GRIMINGER--Dr. Paul. Professor, Rutgers University, is survived by his wife, four children and nine grandchildren. He was a soldier, scholar, mentor, global citizen and most of all dedicated husband and father. Enjoy memories of him, as we will do every day for the rest of our lives.
GROSS--Joan Twenty-six years. We never stop loving you. All of us.

ORKIN--Judah M. Dr. age 90 Father of Bruce and Lawrence, grandfather of Heather, Jared, Jessica and Jocelyn. Brother of Harriet Ehrlich. Husband of Beatrice. Grave side service Riverside Cemetery Saddle Brook, NJ Friday, February 27, 2009 11:30am.

SAND--Edward A.,died on February 13th, 2009 in Sarasota, FL. He was formerly Chairman and CEO of Parents Magazine Enterprises where he guided the company's growth to include magazine and book publishing and the FAO Schwarz stores, until retiring in 1979. After graduating NYU and before joining Parents Magazine, Mr. Sand founded The Literary Workshop magazine which published the stories of H.L. Mencken and other prominent authors. Upon the death of his beloved wife Sarah, Mr. Sand moved from his home in Longboat Key to Sarasota. He was loved and respected by his friends and family for his kindness, intelligence and independence. He is survived by his son Thomas Sand, granddaughter Jennifer Sand and daughter-in-law Mary Sand.

10 P.M. (Science) MANTRACKER With 25 years of experience as a cowboy on a Canadian ranch, and 13 as a trained volunteer with the Search and Rescue Association of Alberta, Terry Grant, left, can find just about anything, anywhere. In this import from Outdoor Life Network Canada, Mr. Grant's mission is to track on horseback and capture two weekend warriors, who are dropped into rough terrain in Alberta, British Columbia, Ontario or the Yukon with little more than water, a compass and sheer instinct -- and who have 36 hours to reach a destination more than 22 miles away without being caught. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Segments look at saving money with coupons; teenagers and trust; and child entrepreneurs.

ARMITSTEAD--Reverend Austin Herrick, 84, passed away peacefully February 20, 2009 in his home. Reverend Armitstead was born on December 30, 1924 in Nashua, New Hampshire and spent his childhood and teenage years in New England and Pennsylvania before enlisting in the Army in early 1943. Armitstead fought for freedom as an infantryman in the 12th Armored Division seeing action along the Rhine River near Strausburg, France until taken as a prisoner of war in early 1945. After his liberation in April 1945 he returned to the United States and civilian life. He graduated Dickinson College in Carlisle, PA in 1948 and having decided to dedicate his life to the service of God, worked with migrant farm workers from northern Florida through northern New York before enrolling in Union Theological Seminary in New York City where he was awarded a Masters of Divinity in 1952. He married his wife, Bianca Audrey Potz-Nielsen in 1951 and the couple began a lifetime of ministry together. Reverend Armitstead was an elder in the New York Conference of the United Methodist Church and served pastorates in Hauppauge, Commack and Center Moriches on Long Island, Bay Ridge Methodist Church in Brooklyn, Faith United Methodist Church on Staten Island and Community United Methodist Church in Jackson Heights, Queens where he established a four language church bringing a diverse community together in service to God. Upon his retirement in 1994, he served as a Community Liaison for the Western Queens Gazette and offered his personal ministry through his photographic works. In addition to his pastoral responsibilities Armitstead was also a leader and advocate for social change and justice in each of his stops along life's path. He was an early and vocal advocate for racial integration and equality and also worked tirelessly in the cause of ecumenicalism and community responsibility upon the part of the churches he served. He held positions as President, Vice-President or Chairman on a number of boards in New York including the Salvation Army, American Red Cross, Police Community Relations, Staten Island Council of Churches, Brooklyn United Methodist Church Home, Jackson Heights Community Development, sheltered New York City homeless, served the New York City Police and Fire Departments in a number of ways, and served on numerous task forces of New York City Mayors, improving the lives of thousands. His passion for championing the underdog was also evident in his life-long love of baseball as he was an avid New York Mets fan and attended nearly a thousand ball games at Shea Stadium in Queens. Perhaps fitting, Armitstead died only a few days after the last remaining piece of that ballpark was leveled. He was an honorary lifetime member of the Baseball Hall of Fame. Due to declining health, Armitstead and his wife moved to Suffolk in the summer of 2007 where he lived out his life close to family. Reverend Armitstead is survived by his wife of over 57 years, Bianca Audrey Potz-Nielsen Armitstead; one daughter, Nancy Armitstead of New York City; two sons, Alan Jackson Armitstead (wife, Petra) of Suffolk and John Auman Armitstead (wife, Ima) of Lexington, Kentucky; two brothers, Donald M. Armitstead of Seattle, WA and Dr. Paul T. Armitstead of Waco, TX; and five grandchildren, Christian, Jaclyn, Michael, Steven and Jonathan. A memorial service will be held on Friday, February 27, at 11am in Sturtevant Funeral Home, Bennetts Creek Chapel, Suffolk celebrated by the Reverend Bob Weeks of Aldersgate United Methodist Church. Ground committal will be in the Albert G. Horton, Jr. Memorial Veterans Cemetery also in Suffolk. Contributions in lieu of flowers should be made to your local church, hospice, food bank, the Salvation Army or Red Cross. www.SturtevantFuneralHome. com

de GIVE--Eleanor Hoguet, age 90, died peacefully at home in Newburyport, MA on March 2. Mrs. de Give was formerly of New York City and Southampton. She was the daughter of Louise and Robert L. TWIN SOULS, Long Lost

After killing and decapitating a fellow passenger on an intercity bus last July, Vince Weiguang Li apologized to the police and urged them to kill him, according to evidence presented Tuesday. Prosecutors offered grisly details of the attack as Mr. Li's murder trial opened in Winnipeg, Manitoba, including an assertion that Mr. Li cannibalized his seatmate, Tim McLean, 22. Mr. Li's lawyer did not dispute his client had killed but said he was mentally ill and not criminally responsible.

ALGER--Ian. His colleagues at Weill Cornell Medical College and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital express condolences to the family of Dr. Alger, an esteemed Clinical Professor in our Department of Psychiatry. The Jets continued their extreme defensive makeover on Tuesday, again looking to Baltimore to find free safety Jim Leonhard. He signed a three-year deal. Leonhard, 26, is also the second projected starter in the secondary the Jets have acquired, joining cornerback Lito Sheppard, who was traded from Philadelphia. A former Ravens assistant, Mike Pettine, will be the defensive coordinator.
