MESS UP, MAKE MILLIONS Former top executives of Countrywide Financial, which made tens of thousands of risky mortgages and helped set off the worldwide financial crisis, now stand to make millions from the mess they created. DUNNING THE DEAD With many people unable to pay their bills, collection agencies are finding fertile ground in relatives of the recently deceased. Unaware that there is no legal obligation, many agree to pay. [A1.]

LIEBER--Charles S. M.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of dear friend and cherished colleague, Charles S. Lieber, M.D., Specialty Chief of Liver Disease at the James J. Peters VA Medical Center in the Bronx and Professor of Medicine in the Division of Gastroenterology and Pathology at The Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Dr. Lieber was internationally renowned for his investigations in to the pathogenesis and treatment of Alcoholic Liver Disease and was the first scientist to show that alcohol itself is toxic to the liver. The Mount Sinai Family extends our heart-felt condolences to Dr. Lieber's family, his wife and co-worker, Dr. Maria Leo-Lieber, and his children. Peter W. May Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center, Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center

Signaling a new direction in Middle East diplomacy, the Obama administration will send two senior officials to Syria this weekend to begin discussions with the government, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said on a visit to Israel on Tuesday. The overture suggests how the Obama administration intends to tackle three interlocking challenges in the Middle East: the nuclear threat posed by Iran; long-simmering tensions between Israel and Syria; and the grinding conflict between Israelis and Palestinians. Syria, regional experts say, could be the key to alleviating all three.

AUDIO: The Fisher Poets Gathering in Astoria, Ore., is a meeting place for the poets of the fishing boat. Listen to audio of poets performing their songs and view a slideshow of photographs of Astoria. Readers are invited to send in their own songs and poems about the economic downturn. They can also explore the relationship of work and a way of life with a geographic location.

EONS ago, I went out with a man who lived near the South Street Seaport. His address was part of his appeal. After the requisite wine drinking and some half-hearted (at least for me) clubbing, we'd get to the part of the date I was really looking forward to: a wee-hours trip to the Fulton Fish Market. There, we'd buy ultra-fresh slabs of slippery seafood for our late-night suppers.

PRODDOW--Penny, passed away peacefully at home in New York, February 28, 2009, following a short illness. Penny's professional worlds included teaching at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, curating at R. Esmerian, Inc., co-writing a monthly column for In Style Magazine. Educated at Bryn Mawr as a classical archaeologist, Penny wrote a series of children's books in the 1970s, bringing to life the world of Greek myths for a young audience: these writings would become the basis of her lecture series "Pause for Pegasus" given at the educational department at the Met in recent years. Applying her knowledge of ancient art, Penny became a jewelry researcher and historian; her pioneer efforts assisted in organizing landmark jewelry exhibitions and co-writing articles and five books. Most important of all, Penny's friends and associates will miss her gutsy creativity, her acute observation enhanced by historical and literary knowledge, and of course her laughter - all together providing for a unique humanity that only Penny Proddow could bring to our lives. Burial in Nantucket will be private. Ralph Esmerian

Likening obesity's risks to those of smoking, a large European study spanning decades has found that young men who were overweight at age 18 were as likely to die by 60 as light smokers, while obese teens, like heavy smokers, were at double the risk of dying early. While obesity is linked to a slew of health problems, the new findings fly in the face of numerous recent studies showing that people who are merely overweight may not be at higher risk of premature death than those of normal weight.

SIRKIN--Jacob, February 3, 1933-February 26, 2009. Born in Mexico City and longtime resident of California. Jacob was a proprietor, a highly respected sales executive in the men's fashion industry, and Vice President of Huaxin International Corp. Jacob was a great source of love, support and joy to his family, friends and associates. He will be deeply missed.

FIELD--Eris M. It is with great sadness that we mark the passing of a gracious and committed friend. In philanthropy, as in life, Eris M. Field was a full partner with her husband, Lawrence N. Field ('52) and together they have been among the most generous of donors to Larry's alma mater, Baruch College, CUNY. The historic Lawrence and Eris Field Building at 17 Lexington Avenue in Manhattan is a physical embodiment of their vision and commitment to the College's academic excellence. The nationally ranked Field Programs in Entrepreneurship at Baruch College are growing and thriving because of Eris and Larry's unwavering support. Married for 49 years to her husband, Larry, and the devoted mother of two accomplished daughters, Eris was a passionate patron of the arts in Los Angeles, her adopted city. The Eris M. Field Plaza at the entrance to the Walt Disney Concert Hall commemorates her devotion to the Los Angeles Philharmonic. Among her other philanthropic efforts, Eris was a "Founder" of the Los Angeles Music Center, and, in 2005, Cedars-Sinai Medical Center dedicated the Eris M. Field Endowed Chair in Diabetes Research, a gift that recognizes Eris's own battle with the disease. Eris Field lived a full and generous life and we extend our most heartfelt condolences to her husband, Larry; her daughters, Lisa and Robyn; Robyn's husband, Anthony O'Carroll; and her two beloved granddaughters, Ibby and Kate. Baruch College and the Baruch College Fund community join Eris and Larry's many, many friends who are saddened by her untimely passing. Kathleen Waldron, President Baruch College and Larry Simon '65, President The Baruch College Fund

Take your pick: lean or buttery? There were arguments for either style at the tasting of Santa Barbara chardonnays. Like every soccer-playing youngster in France, Sébastien Le Toux dreamed of growing up to score goals like Thierry Henry and Nicolas Anelka. But at the first stop on his professional career, Le Toux was shuttled to the back line -- a creative player transformed into a destroyer. ''I was 18 playing in the reserve team of Rennes, and the coach asked me to play right defender,'' Le Toux, 25, said before he left for preseason training in Argentina with Seattle Sounders F.C., a Major League Soccer expansion team. ''When you are young, you just keep the dream to be a pro player and to do things that may not make you happy, but you are happy to play.''

What we’re reading (and watching) on Thursday morning.

If you’re a once-cherubic adolescent star seeking to prove that you can handle grown-up roles, joining the cast of the biopic “The Runaways” is apparently the way to do it. Variety reported that Dakota Fanning, of “Dr. Seuss’ The Cat in the Hat” and “Charlotte’s Web,” has signed on to the film about the all-female rock group famous for pop-punk songs like “Cherry Bomb”; Ms. Fanning, 15, will play the group’s lead singer, Cheri Currie, who was also 15 when she joined the band. Kristen Stewart, the star of the “Twilight” movies, has previously been announced to play the band mate Joan Jett (who went on to solo stardom with “I Love Rock N’ Roll”). The music video director Floria Sigismondi will write and direct the film, and Ms. Jett is serving as an executive producer. Production is expected to start in the spring.

On this week’s Popcast, Jon Pareles reviews “No Line on the Horizon” by U2 and “Middle Cyclone,” the latest solo offering from the New Pornographers vocalist Neko Case. Also, the singer-songwriter Eleni Mandell talks to Ben Sisario and performs the track “Personal” in our studio.

What’s a major opera production without a major cast change? The Metropolitan Opera announced that Christine Brewer and Linda Watson will share the role of Brünnhilde in its coming performances of Wagner’s four-part “Der Ring des Nibelungen.” Ms. Brewer was already scheduled to sing the role in the first cycle (scheduled for March 28, April 11, April 18 and April 25); she will also take over the role for its second cycle (April 27, April 28, April 30 and May 2) as well as a non-cycle performance of “Die Walküre” on April 6. She is replacing Lisa Gasteen, who has withdrawn due to a back injury, the Met said in a release. Linda Watson will replace Ms. Gasteen in the opera’s third and final cycle (May 4, May 5, May 7 and May 9). Ms. Watson sang Brünnhilde at the Bayreuth Festival from 2006 to 2008. In December, she filled in for Katarina Dalayman in the role of Isolde in the Met’s “Tristan und Isolde.”

A popular rock band once said that money can’t buy me love, but $59.99 (plus tax) will get you a copy of the first video game officially modeled on the music of the Beatles. In a news release, the producers of the game, The Beatles: Rock Band, said it would be released for the Microsoft Xbox 360, Sony PlayStation 3 and Nintendo Wii consoles on Sept. 9, and offer an “experiential progression through and celebration of the music and artistry of the Beatles.” Previous entries in the series, produced by Harmonix and MTV Games, have allowed players to jam along to popular songs on plastic controllers shaped like musical instruments. The companies said they would also create new hardware for the game modeled on the instruments used by John Lennon, Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr. A list of the songs in the game was not announced.

Comics have finally joined the mainstream. Anticipation for the live-action film version of “Watchmen,” the dark and violent superhero opus that saw its birth in comic books and arrives in theaters on Friday, has built to a nationwide boil. And today The Times introduces three separate lists of the best-selling graphic books in the country: hardcover, softcover, and manga. We’ll update those lists weekly in this space, and offer a few observations along the way.

Updated | 1:55 p.m. The marquees of Broadway theaters will be dimmed on Thursday for one minute at 8:00pm in tribute to Horton Foote, who died on Wednesday. Mr. Foote’s most recent Broadway play was “Dividing the Estate,” the dysfunctional family portrait that ran at the Booth Theater from Nov. 20 through Jan 4.

The R&B singer Chris Brown has been charged with two felonies, including assault likely to cause bodily injury and making criminal threats, The Associated Press reported, citing court documents. The charges stem from an incident that occurred in Los Angeles early on the morning of Feb. 8 in which Mr. Brown fought with a female passenger in his car. The woman has not been identified by the police. Mr. Brown was arrested that night, booked on suspicion of making a criminal threat and released on bail. The Los Angeles County District Attorney’s office subsequently asked the police to collect more evidence before determining what charges would be filed. Mr. Brown and his companion, the singer Rihanna, have canceled numerous appearances and concerts since the incident; Mr. Brown was expected in court on Thursday.

Proving that this decade really is the 1980s in quotation marks, Michael Jackson announced that he would perform a series of concerts in London this summer, in what the singer called a “final curtain call,” Reuters reported. Mr. Jackson, 50, revealed the details of the concerts at a news conference Thursday in London, where he said he would perform 10 shows at that city’s O2 Arena, beginning July 8. “When I say this is it, I mean this is it,” Mr. Jackson said, according to Reuters. “I’ll be performing the songs my fans want to hear.” The shows would be Mr. Jackson’s first major performances since 2001 and 2002, when he appeared at a pair of 30th anniversary celebrations and two benefit concerts; a brief appearance by Mr. Jackson at the World Music Awards in 2006 was booed by audience members.

Robin Williams has halted the tour of his one-man comedy show, “Weapons of Self-Destruction,” to undergo heart surgery, Reuters reported. The 80-city tour was to have included performances on Broadway at the Neil Simon Theater on April 23 through April 25, April 28 and 29 and May 1-3. Earlier in the week, Mr. Williams postponed four shows in Florida, saying that he was experiencing shortness of breath. In a statement, representatives for Mr. Williams said that he would have surgery for an aortic valve replacement, and that the tour was expected to resume in the fall. The statement said that tickets would be honored for the new performance dates, or that ticketholders can contact their place of purchase for refunds. No new Broadway dates for “Weapons of Self-Destruction” were immediately announced.

On Thursday the Finnish SM-liiga ended its regular season, the last European league to close out its schedule, and that allows us to take a final look at our World Club Top 10 rankings for 2008-9. With that, we get a stark appreciation of just how great the magnitude of Avangard's elimination of Salavat Yulaev, also on Thursday, really was. Not only did Avangard, the No. 16 seed in the K.H.L. playoffs, knock off the No. 1 seed; not only did it oust the defending Russian champions; it also bounced the team that finished atop the World Club rankings and, arguably at least, was the best in the world.

The other night at a dinner party, a friend described how she tried to practice mindfulness meditation to keep herself from losing it during an utterly wretched seven-hour layover in an airport while she was exhausted, ill and desperate to get home to her children.

Updated, Friday, Mar. 6, 9:10 a.m. | The economic news gets worse by the day. On Friday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that the national unemployment rate surged to 8.1 percent in February, its highest in 25 years, with 651,000 jobs lost last month.

Sudan | Sudan's leader may not be arrested anytime soon and hauled before an international tribunal, but America and its allies can still ground his air force. So argues a former Air Force chief of staff (and ex-Obama campaigner) with a colleague. A no-fly zone was opposed by humanitarian groups worried about losing access to Darfur, but the situation there is deteriorating, the authors say. "By taking away the Sudanese government's freedom to use air power to terrorize its population, the West would finally get enough leverage with Khartoum to negotiate the entry of a stronger U.N. ground force." [Washington Post]

Annual e-commerce sales will shrink for the first time this year, according to eMarketer. The research firm issued its revised e-commerce forecast Thursday, predicting that shoppers will spend 0.4 percent less online this year than last year.
Today the government announced that initial unemployment insurance claims fell last week after a couple of weeks of increases -- but that's no reason to celebrate, economists say.

After 13 months without a competitive game, Ronaldo (that is Ronaldo Luís Nazário de Lima) returned from injury Wednesday night, playing 22 minutes in his first game for Corinthians in a 2-0 win at Itumbiara in a Copa Brasil match.

As The Times reported on March 2, Fox's action-packed program "24" has proclaimed itself "carbon neutral." That means not only switching to hybrid cars whenever possible, but burning 20 percent biodiesel in location generators. Since that didn't go nearly far enough, the producers also paid for carbon credits to offset 1,291 tons of carbon dioxide (slightly more than a half season's worth).

With Cornell (9-3), Princeton (7-4), Yale (7-5) and Dartmouth (7-5) still in contention as the Ivy League heads into its final weekend of men's basketball, the league announced the tentative sites and dates of potential playoff games should two or three teams finish tied for the title. The game or games would determine the league's representative for the N.C.A.A. tournament.

The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. This week the hypnotic dance-floor technicians Nancy Whang and Juan MacLean, of the band the Juan MacLean, share their essentials. This installment is a two-parter: here, Whang, also a member of LCD Soundsystem, dishes on her favorite things; tomorrow, MacLean himself will do the honors. Juan will also play a D.J. set at the Eyebeam Art and Technology Center on March 7. Their new album, ''The Future Will Come,'' comes out April 14 from DFA.
Glenn Warciski, a Giants loyalist, Fifth Down commenter and blogger, wants a fair hearing for Kevin Gilbride. Take it away, Glenn.

I like to cook pork. It's not an odd thing, or revolutionary or even news, but it's the truth.
Sony has announced a $500 ultra-zoom camera with a raft of interesting features, including an upgraded image sensor and lens, and the ability to take very wide panoramic shots.

Religion | "It turns out that human beings have a natural inclination for religious belief, especially during hard times," a science article says. One theory is that religion is an evolutionary adaptation: shared belief helped our ancestors form tightly knit groups and survive. Another is that we're hard-wired for belief in the supernatural, as when tots create imaginary friends. But there are some Doubting Thomases. [New Scientist]
"Breaking Bad," starring Bryan Cranston as a terminally ill scientist who sells drugs to secure his family's future, returns for its second season on AMC on March 8.

The artist Christine Hill's makeshift apothecary, "The Volksboutique Armory Apothecary," at the Ronald Feldman Gallery booth perhaps best embodies the mood at this year's Armory Show, the international art fair. Everyone in the art world is in need of a remedy for the current economic malaise. Hill was selling prescriptions for whatever ails you, for $20 each - a tad more reasonable than recent offerings from, say, Damien Hirst - and there was a line of waiting "patients." In fact, you could find lots of quick fixes and one liners all over Piers 92 and 94, where the fair is being held through Sunday, March 8.
Earlier today, ESPN Deportes reported that Alex Rodriguez will have surgery to remove a cyst on his right hip and may require 10 weeks to rehabilitate.

John Maine could pitch a perfect game and find imperfection. That is just his personality. But even by his standards, Maine was disgusted with his two-inning performance against Italy Thursday afternoon. He did not allow a run, but he walked three straight hitters to begin the game, then gave up two singles in his final inning.
CNBC's Bill Griffeth talks to David Pogue about the first 8-megapixel camera phone available in the U.S.
Kim Severson reported that organic inspectors don't necessarily protect us against food poisoning. But neither do food safety inspectors, Michael Moss and Andrew Martin report.

Gareth Pugh's shows are always a cinematic experience, but this time the English designer took the concept quite literally. He teamed up with the filmmaker Ruth Hogben and the model Natasa Vojnovic to create a mesmerizing movie (a preview of which appears above) full of movement, attitude, flowing capes, pin-studded dresses, chain-mail accents and furry square hats. Jean-Paul Goude would be proud.
This week, the Paris food writer Alexander Lobrano, the author of "Hungry for Paris" and the European correspondent for Gourmet magazine, joins the T table to share his thoughts (and tips) on dining.

Latin America | Latin America is going increasingly nuclear in its quest for energy, a scholar writes, for reasons including erratic hydroelectric power and uncertain natural gas supplies from neighboring countries. Argentina and Brazil may seek to double or triple existing nuclear capacity. Mexico, Chile and Uruguay also have big plans. "Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez has sought nuclear cooperation from Brazil, France, Iran, and Russia, but few suppliers appear to be biting." For some reason. [Carnegie Endowment]

Now that Kate Winslet has her Oscar at long last, moviedom must coronate a new most-overdue-to-win actress. The Film Experience, a blog run by a guy who describes himself as an "actressexual and cat lover," has sifted through a list of previous nominees like Sigourney Weaver, Annette Bening and Julianne Moore and declared that the top slot now belongs to Michelle Pfeiffer?

A rocky season for NBC's remake of the 1980s crime show "Knight Rider" drew to a close on Wednesday, showing minor improvement, but improvement nonetheless, in the show's struggling ratings.

With this year's deer hunt completed, County Executive Joseph N. DiVincenzo Jr. already has plans for the upcoming year to start replanting the South Mountain Reservation in the spring - including fenced areas to keep out the deer - and also to expand the deer culling to new reservations for 2010. The Local sat down with the Mr. DiVincenzo Wednesday to discuss his ideas and bring your questions straight to the county executive.

How different is the N.H.L. today -- after the deals and non-deals of trade deadline day -- than it was yesterday? The initial analysis indicates some very significant changes in the business of player acquisition and development.

Breakfast on the road can either be triste or transcendent. Last week in Athens, Ga., I found two things to write home about. Looking forward to a biscuit at the Waffle House chain (love those light fixtures), I was rerouted to The National by Hugh Acheson, the extremely talented (and cool) chef at Five & Ten, who's one of the partners.

So much is unknown at this point about Alex Rodriguez's hip injury. The Yankees are in full lockdown mode about the issue, and we hope to get more information as the day goes on.

On Wednesday night, the Pakistani broadcaster Geo TV aired security-camera video footage from near the cricket stadium in Lahore, which appeared to show the gunmen who had carried out the deadly attack on Tuesday leaving the scene in no great hurry, and under no pressure at all from Pakistani police, who are not seen in the footage.

Government regulators appear to have known all along that a unit of American International Group was busy writing billions of dollars worth of risky credit protection contracts that are now at the center of the insurance group's record-setting losses.
Macquarie, the Australian investment bank, has made three more senior hires over the last week as it seeks to expand its presence in the United States.

Update | 4:09 p.m. The wrap up session: President Obama entered the room with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who said said he looked forward to being a "foot soldier" in the push for health care reform and "this time we will not fail."

The directors of the 10 Formula One teams - that includes the not-defunct Honda team - held a press conference in Geneva today to announce the following list of proposed changes to the regulations to cut costs and improve the show. These changes proposed by the Formula One Teams Association have to be approved by the FIA before they are adopted, so many of them may not be adopted. Having said that, some were already announced by the FIA in its recent cost-cutting proposals, and they are therefore not new - but simply approved by the teams themselves... ie., old news rehashed:

The Phantom Corsair, one of the boldest custom cars of the 1930s, will be making a sojourn from its home at the National Automobile Museum in Reno, Nev., to star at the Amelia Island Concours d'Elegance, to be held March 13-15 at the Golf Club of Amelia Island, Fla.

A reader sends in the following very cool map, which shows home prices in each state each quarter, relative to that state's long-term trend. Red represents housing prices above the long-term trend, and blue represents prices below it. Note how many states were still red by the end of 2008. This may indicate that home prices have further to drop:

Major League Soccer released its 2009 schedule a little more than a month ago, and the new season will start in roughly two weeks when the Red Bulls travel to Seattle to play the expansion Sounders at what will likely be a jammed Qwest Field on March 19.

Hollywood is really getting the hang of those huge, power-gobbling, neighborhood-riling digital billboards that have been lighting up all quarters of Los Angeles. The city council authorized about 850 of them while settling legal disputes with CBS Outdoor and Clear Channel Outdoor a couple years ago.

Employment in New York state climbed to a peak last summer, then tumbled off a cliff, according to the latest analysis of the job market from the State Department of Labor in Albany. In the last four months of 2008, the state lost more than one-fourth as many jobs as it gained during the previous five years, the department reported on Thursday. New York was still losing jobs as the new year began: the state's unemployment rate rose in January to 7 percent from a revised rate of 6.6 percent in December, the report said.

I don't mean to turn this column into All E-Books, All the Time. But Amazon pulled a nice one-two P.R. punch. Two weeks ago, it released its Kindle 2 electronic book reader, and announced that its catalog of electronic books had hit 240,000 titles. You can download them wirelessly to the Kindle, via the Sprint cellular network, whenever it suits your fancy.

Icahn Enterprises, the publicly traded holding company run by billionaire Carl C. Icahn, reported a loss of $468 million in the fourth quarter on Thursday as the performance of the firm's hedge fund and other investments plummeted.
David Pogue looks at Amazon’s new Kindle e-book application for the iPhone and iPod Touch.
There's a big hole in the hedge fund industry, as nearly $1 trillion in assets has disappeared over the last six months of 2008, according to a study.

Seeing Things is a biweekly design column by Brooke Hodge, the curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles.

Mary P. Jones is the mother of two children, one of whom has been diagnosed with autism. She writes about helping her boy navigate through his challenges on her blog, A Room of Mama's Own, and she does so anonymously (Mary Jones is her pseudonym) to protect her son (and the rest of her family, as you will see if you visit her blog.) Her goal is to shield the boy from prying eyes, not subject him to them. Because, as she writes in today's guest blog, Mary knows a lot more than she would like about the stares of strangers.

President Bashir is not only expelling major international aid groups from Darfur (and in some cases from other parts of Sudan as well), as I noted in today's column, but I just got word that he has also ordered the closure of SUDO, the Sudan Development Organization, a highly-regarded Sudanese NGO that has done tremendous work around the country and is a pillar of civil society there. It is run by Dr. Mudawi Ibrahim, a man of enormous courage who has been devoting his life to overcoming poverty in Sudan.
With Vain Glorious, T Magazine's senior editor and beauty guru Sandra Ballentine breaks down the latest spas, salons and products for your aesthetic pleasure.
More than 26 million Americans -- that's one in nine adults -- have kidney disease. Millions more are likely to develop the disease, but most of us don't know we're at risk.
Like his father, Pat Knight, the men's basketball coach at Texas Tech, uses a motion offense.

A news release describes the White House Fellows Program as "the nation's most prestigious program for leadership and public service." Hundreds of young people across the nation submit applications every year, and only 30 or so are ultimately chosen to "spend a year working as full-time, paid special assistants to senior White House Staff, Cabinet Secretaries and other top-ranking government officials."

Bobby Jindal of Louisiana suggested that the federal government's plan to spend "$140 million for something called volcano monitoring" might be wasteful, he wisely did not suggest that the country also cut back on however much we are paying people to keep an eye out for big rocks hurtling towards us through space.

Avangard Omsk pulled off an enormous upset on Thursday with a 4-1 defeat of Salavat Yulaev Ufa, the defending Russian champions and No. 1 team in the regular season just completed, to clinch their Russian K.H.L. octavofinal series, 3 games to 1. The Hawks, embroiled since the second month of the season in coaching crises, lawsuits, the death of a player and the suspension of its directorship, lost Game 1 in overtime, took Game 2 on penalties, then came home and won the next two. In Thursday's Game 4, the Omsk Arena crowd of 10,000 chanted "Avangard" through most of the final period.
Fox is setting up post-"American Idol" previews for two new shows.

A bankruptcy filing by General Motors -- which the automaker said Thursday wasa distinct possibility -- would ripple far and wide.

On March 2, Roche amended its tender offer document and changed the language for how it would deal with a squeeze-out of Genentech's shareholders. Those are the shareholders who do not tender into Roche's offer if the offer succeeds in meeting its minimum tender condition.

Andrew Bacevich is a former U.S. soldier who fought in Vietnam and now teaches International Relations at Boston University. In the National Interest this week he reviews The Accidental Guerrilla: Fighting Small Wars in the Midst of a Big One, a new book by another former solder, David Kilcullen. In his review, Bacevich takes issue with the notion that counterinsurgency is the best way to deal with the jihadist threat, and suggests containment as the better strategy.
From our colleagues over at The Caucus:

For those wondering if the benefits of the increasingly ubiquitous compact fluorescent lightbulb (see our logo above) have been overstated, a report last night from the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation offers a little something to chew on. The report suggested that the energy savings associated with the bulbs -- which use far less electricity than their incandescent predecessors -- may be offset by higher heating bills, and more greenhouse emissions.

Updated, 6:28 p.m. | After intense protests from India's government and the Indian press, Mohandas K. Gandhi's eyeglasses and some of his other belongings were sold on Thursday afternoon for $1.8 million at an auction in Manhattan, after last-minute attempts to halt the sale. [Read the article prepared for Friday editions.]The buyer was identified as Vijay Mallya, an Indian liquor and airline executive who owns the company that makes Kingfisher beer. A representative for Mr. Mallya, Tony Bedi, did the bidding and later announced that the belongings would be returned to India for public display, but it was not clear whether they would be turned over to the government, as some officials have demanded.Indian officials had maintained that the auction -- scheduled to be completed on Thursday afternoon in Manhattan -- was illegal, but also that they were continuing to negotiate with the owner, James Otis, over a possible resolution. Ultimately, the government and Mr. Otis were not successful in halting the auction.

Update | 12:46 p.m. In a 25-minute conference call, Mr. Kundra discussed some of his plans and interests, including his intention to extend the use of "cloud computing" in the federal government and to create a data.gov web site thatwill put vast amounts of government information into the public domain.

GENEVA -- Stuffed with useful information, but often heavier than the anchor on the QE2, bulky media kits are a necessary evil of every auto show. Ignore them, and be prepared to incur the wrath of an editor when it comes time to fact-check. Pick up every single one offered, and you'll walk with a limp for days to follow.

David Pogue tests the Memoir, the first 8-megapixel cellphone in the United States.

The top three teams in the Canadian Hockey League ranking - the Windsor Spitfires, the Calgary Hitmen and the Vancouver Giants - remained unchanged this week. The top five teams in the ranking - the Drummondville Voltigeurs and the Shawinigan Cataractes are fourth and fifth, respectively - each have at least 50 victories.

In a testy statement issued at 7 p.m. on Wednesday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's office slammed state leaders for shortchanging New York City out of at least $200 million in federal stimulus -- a charge the governor's office immediately dismissed.

GENEVA -- Dear President Obama, I have good news. It turns out that mending relations with Iran isn't so hard after all. Just remember to smile, ask intelligent questions, and at the end of the conversation suggest a road trip. Thanks to a little four-wheeled diplomacy, there is now an open invitation to visit Tehran and go cruising in an Iran Khodro sedan.

Three years after his campaign for the United States Senate transformed him into a national Democratic figure, Ned Lamont said he is weighing another electoral adventure: a challenge to Connecticut Republican Gov. M. Jodi Rell.

Good morning tri-town! And what a happy one it is for one lucky person in town though not for those on the early trains running 12 to 25 minutes late.

Throughout the Capitol, from the vaulted Assembly chamber to the first-floor cubicles of the Budget Division, officials are frantically cutting budgets, trimming head counts and freezing salaries to deal with the worst fiscal crisis in decades.

Sport | Suddenly, two disparate events have plunged cricket into global crisis: the fall of the Texas billionaire Robert Allen Stanford and the terrorist attack this week in Pakistan on the Sri Lankan cricket team. In the Caribbean, Stanford had been benefactor of an English version of the speeded-up game of cricket called 20Twenty, which was meant to compete with the new and, until now, hugely successful Indian Premier League. But now fears over security mean Asian cricket "can never be the same again," a columnist says, given the attack in Pakistan and the recent terrorist assault in Mumbai, India. [The Hindu, Wall Street Journal, New Yorker]

Speaking of the rule of two - see Bagger item below about the two upcoming Amelia Earharts - by which cinematic biography keeps trying to occur in pairs: "Watchmen," coming to theaters on Friday, gives the movie world not just another Richard Nixon, played by a putty-faced Robert Wisden , to complement the Nixon played so handily by Frank Langella in "Frost/Nixon," but another unexpected pairing as well.

MGM Mirage, the struggling casino operator, and its Dubai partner failed to reach a deal with Deutsche Bank over $1.2 billion in financing for the ambitious $8.6 billion CityCenter project in Las Vegas, Reuters reported citing unnamed sources.
Facing a precipitous slide in its share price, General Electric is mounting a defense of its financial strength in hopes of reassuring jittery stock and bond investors.

Update | 8:13 a.m. General Motors has substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern if it fails to stem its losses and generate cash, and it may be forced to file for bankruptcy protection, the automaker said Thursday.

Spurred by government incentives, ample sunshine and investments from energy companies eager to turn a profit, a growing number of south-Israel kibbutzim -- those communal-living enterprises that have traditionally emphasized ideals like collective labor, egalitarianism and natural living -- are turning to state-of-the-art energy projects.
American International Group's Asia-Pacific unit, American International Assurance, said Wednesday it was mulling an initial public offering as it continued to review strategic options.

Google's YouTube and the Universal Music Group, the world's largest music label, are in advanced discussions over a licensing agreement that could lead to the creation of a premium site for music videos, The New York Times's Miguel Helft reported, citing a person briefed on the talks.

New York State's attorney general, Andrew Cuomo, issued subpoenas on Wednesday to seven executives who received tens of millions of dollars in 2008 pay from Merrill Lynch before it was taken over by Bank of America, Reuters reported, citing a person familiar with the investigation.

The Blackstone Group wrote down to zero the value of billions of dollars of debt it bought last year from Deutsche Bank, as market value of the loans sank, Bloomberg News reported, citing a person familiar with the decision.
Many New Yorkers will tell you, usually quite loudly, that the town just isn't the same since the Checker cab disappeared from Manhattan's streets in 1999.

Stepping up its battle to oust HudBay Minerals's chief executive, Allen Palmiere, the hedge fund SRM Global Master Fund released details of how the head of the Canadian miner tried to alter the terms of a controversial merger agreement with rival Lundin Mining, after shareholders protested.

The games giant Activision Blizzard, with $3 billion in cash and no debt, is keeping its eye out for deal opportunities as prices of potential targets continue to fall, the company's top publishing executive told Bloomberg News.

The privately held casino operator Harrah's Entertainment wants to exchange an unspecified amount of debt for up to $2.8 billion worth of new notes in order to lower its debt obligations and have more time to pay back lenders, The Associated Press said.

Economy | There's a one-in-five chance of a minor depression (an economic contraction of 10-25 percent) and a 2 percent chance of a major depression (25 percent, like in the 1930's), the economist Robert J. Barro figures. He comes up with these odds after crunching the numbers from more than a century's worth of stock market crashes followed by downturns in countries around the world, from Argentina to Sweden. So look at the bright side, he says; there's an 80 percent chance we'll only have this lousy recession! And as for the government bailouts and spending, he's also chipper -- up to a point: "I think it more likely that the economy will eventually recover despite these policies, rather than because of them." [Wall Street Journal]

Congress needs to create a systemic risk regulator to monitor the safety and soundness of the nation's entire financial system, corporate governance experts told lawmakers on Wednesday, but they disagreed on who should be given that responsibility, Reuters reported.
The bulls drove a relief rally in United States stocks on Wednesday after a precipitous five-day slide, but don't bet the run-up signals a bottom just yet, Reuters says.

Losing your job anywhere is disorienting, but imagine being laid off when you work in a foreign country. Not only is your source of income, and perhaps a good part of your identity, suddenly yanked away, but often you lose your right to remain in the country.

It used to be that people who wanted to solve a social problem - like lack of access to clean water or inadequate housing for the poor - created a charity. Today, many start a company instead, The New York Times's Marci Alboher says.

UBS came under blistering attack on Wednesday from officials and lawmakers amid a growing outcry over Swiss banking secrecy practices that Washington says allow rampant tax evasion, The New York Times's Lynnley Browning reported.
Pharmacies around the country are offering free antibiotics to consumers, but public health officials say the incentives send the wrong message and could worsen the problem of drug resistance.
WellPoint, the second-largest U.S. health insurer by revenue, has put its pharmacy benefits management business up for auction, The Financial Times reported.
Nancy Folbre is a professor of economics at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

Film | Cinema may undergoing "a death" in the way we physically interact with the form, a cinephile laments. It's losing its "necessary exertions" -- "the chasing and the yearning and the never-knowing and the suffering in a broken, smelly, damp-cushioned seat." Now we have "post-cinematic cinema" viewed "through the prism of YouTube" as "reactions to and defenses against distraction and boredom." Lev Glazman, the co-founder of Fresh and the creative director of its perfumes, is responsible for scent works that range from the excellent, daring Cannabis Rose and Cannabis Santal - strong and challenging, as viscerally striking as a Richard Serra sculpture - to the mysterious, marvelous abstraction of Sake to the pretty, if somewhat demotic, literalism of Tangerine Lychee and Pomegranate Anise. Nothing wrong with the last of these; they are breathtakingly lovely. They simply elide into single-accord aromatherapy like a number of Jo Malone scents, and have a similar brief evanescence.

Angie Woznuk scored the first goal for the Americans in the 22nd minute. The United States beat Denmark in the last two finals and has won the title six times in the last eight years. algarve ¶Manchester United goalkeeper Edwin van der Sar had his English league record of not allowing a goal stopped at 1,311 minutes after he failed to hold a shot and Peter Lovenkrands gave Newcastle the lead. An obituary on Feb. 19 about John McGlinn, a conductor and musical historian who recreated old musical comedies in their original forms, erroneously included one recording among those he supervised. An obituary on Feb. 23 about Konrad Dannenberg, who had been one of the last survivingGerman rocket scientists to switch allegiances and help American space and missile programs in the cold war, misstated his relationship with the Nazi Party. He was in fact a member of the party. He joined in 1932, before Hitler came to power, a fact that he revealed to American immigration authorities.

PICCINNINI--John J.,Valued partner and friend, passed away. It is with the most profound sadness that the partners and staff of Citrin Cooperman & Company, LLP mourn the sudden passing of John J. Piccinnini, a valued partner and great friend, at his home on March 2. From his first day at Citrin Cooperman, John made a lasting impression on everyone at the firm, as well as all his clients, which he served with passion and professionalism. To the partners and staff of the firm he became a good friend. His warmth and good humor is remembered even by those who didn't know him that well. John was a genuine, good person who would do anything for the people around him. Warm, giving and caring are words that describe him best. He always contributed to the good of the firm and the partners and staff. He was also a devoted husband and father and his family was what he lived for. John joined Citrin Cooperman & Company, LLP, after serving as the chief financial officer of The Coastal Group, a Manhattan-based advertising agency, for the previous six years. He began his career at a mid-sized regional accounting firm, and later co-founded Saltzer Lassar Piccinnini & Co., LLC, where he was a senior partner. He not only brought accounting acumen to Citrin Cooperman, but he was especially adept at providing strategic planning and business consulting advice to his clients.

This chart, based on data from November 2008 to January 2009, shows how a homeowner's chances of defaulting on a mortgage increase when the amount owed on the loan (or loans) becomes greater than the value of the property itself. The types of loans are broken down as follows: prime loans; ''alternative-A'' loans (loans given to buyers who did not qualify for prime loans but had good enough credit to get loans with more favorable terms than subprime loans); ''option adjustable-rate loans''; and subprime loans. Any loan with a combined current loan-to-value ratio of greater than 100 percent is considered ''underwater'' -- meaning that it exceeds the value of the property it was intended to finance.

From Boston to Atlanta to San Francisco, the economy has gotten worse in the last two months, and in a snapshot of economic conditions released Wednesday, business executives were pessimistic about the chances for a near-term recovery. ''The deterioration was broad based,'' with only a few exceptions, the Federal Reserve said in its beige book, a regular sketch of economic conditions in 12 Fed districts nationwide. Many do not expect a recovery until late 2009 or early next year.

POLSKY--Gladys Preston. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Gladys Polsky, beloved mother of Gail Rudnick and mother-in-law of David Rudnick. The Rudnick family displays an unwavering commitment to philanthropy, strengthening our ability to serve those in need and make an enduring impact on the Jewish community and all New Yorkers. We extend our deepest sympathies to Gail and David; to Gladys's grandson, Jeffrey Rudnick; to her granddaughter, Barbara Murstein; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

KERSTEIN--Ronald J.,69, of Surprise, AZ and Portland, OR, formerly of River Edge, NJ passed away on Wednesday, March 4, 2009. Beloved husband of Naomi for 46 years, devoted father of Steven Kerstein and his wife Cinthia and Jennifer Coury and her husband Robert. Cherished grandfather of Nathan Coury. Dear brother of Nancy Arias and her husband Ricardo. Brother-in-law of Rachelle Liebman and her husband Marc. Prior to his retirement, Ron was a certified public accountant at Anchin, Block, and Anchin, LLP in New York City. He was a member of Temple Sholom in River Edge and Temple Shir Tikvah in Portland. Services will be 11am, Friday, March 6, 2009 at Temple Sholom, 385 Howland Ave., River Edge, NJ. Burial will follow at Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Extending her winning streak on the Billboard album chart, Taylor Swift's ''Fearless'' (Big Machine) held at No. 1 for an 11th week, with sales of 73,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Only five other solo female artists have had albums with 11 or more weeks at the top spot in the five-decade history of Billboard's chart: Alanis Morissette, Whitney Houston, Mariah Carey, Carole King and Judy Garland. Also this week the Virginia metal band Lamb of God's new release, ''Wrath'' (Epic), reached No. 2 with 68,000 sales, and the Jonas Brothers' ''3D Concert Experience'' (Hollywood), the soundtrack to their new concert film, opened at No. 3 with 50,000. As with the film, which opened last weekend, the album fell far short of industry sales expectations. With a boost from eight Oscars, the soundtrack for ''Slumdog Millionaire'' (Interscope) moved 44,000 copies, reaching No. 4, and Nickelback's ''Dark Horse'' (Roadrunner) was No. 5 with 41,000.

ROSS--Lore. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the passing of Lore Ross. A refugee who fled Nazism, Lore was deeply committed to the Museum and the cause of Holocaust remembrance and education. Life partner to her devoted husband, Eric, she was a woman of great determination, strength and dignity. Together, Lore and Eric have been the Museum's largest individual benefactors, and as inaugural members of the Museum's Chairman's Circle, they have inspired countless others with their unparalleled generosity and leadership. The Museum extends its deepest condolences to Eric, a cherished friend and longstanding member of the Museum's Council, and to their children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Fred S. Zeidman, Chairman Joel M. Geiderman, Vice Chairman Sara J. Bloomfield, Director

BUCHMAN--Irving, died March 4, 2009, in the hospital in New York City, of congestive heart failure and related illnesses. He was born in the Bronx in 1925, the youngest son of the late Benjamin and Ydit Brendzel Buchman. He earned his B.A. at The City College Of New York and his M.F.A. in Theater at "Carnegie Tech" (later, Carnegie Mellon.) After stage managing at The Actors Studio and on Broadway, he followed his brother Herman (later joined by their brother Harry) into the then new medium of television. They all worked as makeup artists, helping to shape their new union, Local 798 of IATSE. Later, Irv was much in demand during a golden age of New York City filmmaking. Among many other feature films, he worked on "A Thousand Clowns", "The Group", "The Producers", "Midnight Cowboy", "Klute", "Taxi Driver", and "Diner". In addition to his loving wife of 58 years, Mariette (Tine) Barkhorn Buchman and his brother Harry, he leaves his four children Timothy, Amie, Andrew, and Mariette, nieces Helaine, Judy, and Caitlin, and six grandchildren: Amelia, Bic, and Celeste Cass; Sage, Tyler, and Phoebe Altenhofen. The funeral service will be private. The family will receive visitors at home on Friday and Saturday, March 6 and 7, from 5pm to 8pm, 415 Central Park West, New York, NY 10025. Contributions can be made to The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, in care of the Friends Office, Room M6, 476 Fifth Avenue, New York NY 10018.

PRODDOW--Penny, passed away peacefully at home in New York, February 28, 2009, following a short illness. Penny's professional worlds included teaching at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, curating at R. Esmerian, Inc., co-writing a monthly column for In Style Magazine. Educated at Bryn Mawr as a classical archaeologist, Penny wrote a series of children's books in the 1970s, bringing to life the world of Greek myths for a young audience: these writings would become the basis of her lecture series "Pause for Pegasus" given at the educational department at the Met in recent years. Applying her knowledge of ancient art, Penny became a jewelry researcher and historian; her pioneer efforts assisted in organizing landmark jewelry exhibitions and co-writing articles and five books. Most important of all, Penny's friends and associates will miss her gutsy creativity, her acute observation enhanced by historical and literary knowledge, and of course her laughter - all together providing for a unique humanity that only Penny Proddow could bring to our lives. Burial in Nantucket will be private. Ralph Esmerian

CODELIA Ernest Joseph Jr.,79, a well known attorney practicing in the New York City Metropolitan area passed away on Saturday night, February 28, 2009. Mr. Codelia is survived by his children: Johnedward and Adriene Codelia of London, England, and Annalies Codelia of Worcester, Massachusetts; predeceased by his ex-wife and mother of his children, Frieda Codelia. Ernest Codelia is also survived by his brother and sister-in-law, Edward and Annette Codelia of Florida; his niece, her husband and daughter, Chrissy, Billy, and Clare Bey; and sisters Gina Codelia and Rosa Williams of New York. Mr. Codelia was predeceased by his parents, Guadalupe and Ernesto Cordelia, Sr. Mr. Codelia is also survived by his loving companion of over 40 years, Mary O. Rivera of Malba, New York; stepson and daughter-in-law, David and Sharon Rivera along with their three children Christopher, Kimberly, and Jason of Clinton, New York. Ernest graduated All Hallows Elementary and High School of the Bronx, City College of the City University of New York as a civil engineer, and Brooklyn Law School receiving his Juris Doctor. Admitted to the New York Bar, Appellate Division, 1st Department in 1957. Mr. Codelia started as a solo practitioner in the 1970s and later founded his firm, Ernest Codelia, P.C., in 1984 which later became Codelia & Socorro. Ernest Codelia has been serving the Bronx community for over 40 years. Ernest, better known to people close to him as "Ernie," truly loved the diversity of the community. Ernie was known for his dedication to his clients. Many have voiced... "this is a great loss to the legal community." Ernie's commitment and motivation reflected in his work as well as in the team he lead: Peter Shipmen, Esq., Myrna Socorro, Esq., Jeannette Ortiz-Hausmann, Esq., Nelly Guzman and Trini Toland. His devotion to his family was exceptional. A man of great talent and peace of mind, loyalty was the quality you would use to describe him. Besides hard work, he believed that through education a person could achieve and accomplish anything. Education gives each person the knowledge and tolls for life and the choices we make. Ernie strongly believed there is always something to be learned. Funeral services are being handled by Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Avenue, New York, with a viewing on Thursday, March 5, 2009, 3:00 to 9:00pm. The funeral mass will be at Holy Family Church, Castle Hill Avenue and Watson Avenue, Bronx, New York on Friday, March 6, 2009, at 10:00am. Interment to follow at St. Raymond's Cemetery: Our Lady of Hope Indoor Crypts, 2600 Lafayette Avenue, Bronx, New York.

DEVOTED skiers who suddenly find themselves answering to ''Mommy'' and ''Daddy'' face a conundrum: they want their tots to start taking steps toward becoming self-sufficient on the snow but they don't want to spend too much money. They are finding that even the shortest of skis and the smallest of boots can be very expensive. But now, there are devices to help teach children to ski as soon as they are able to walk -- without intimidating bank accounts. For a fraction of the cost of Alpine systems that anchor tiny heels to skis with rigid boots and bindings, a new generation of toddler skis slip right over regular boots so children can become familiar with the sliding sensation.

A memorial service will be scheduled in New York City in the Spring for family and friends. Donations made to the American Macular Degeneration Foundation (AMDF), P.O. Box 515, Northampton, MA 01061-0515 will be welcomed.

LIEBER--Charles S.,M.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of dear friend and cherished colleague, Charles S. Lieber, M.D., Specialty Chief of Liver Disease at the James J. Peters VA Medical Center in the Bronx and Professor of Medicine in the Division of Gastroenterology and Pathology at The Mount Sinai School of Medicine. The Mount Sinai Family extends our heart-felt condolences to Dr. Lieber's family, his wife and co-worker, Dr. Maria Leo-Lieber, and his children. Peter W. For the first few days of free agency, the Arizona Cardinals were dangerously close to looking like the pre-2008 Cardinals. They had a running back hoping to be released, a star receiver unhappy with his contract and Kurt Warner, the quarterback who had led them to an out-of-nowhere trip to the Super Bowl, taking a trip to division rival San Francisco in the middle of contract negotiations. On Wednesday, one of those obstacles was overcome. Warner, who had made clear before free agency that he did not want to play elsewhere (a bit of candor that most likely did not help his bargaining position), agreed to a two-year, $23 million contract with the Cardinals. The deal, which will pay Warner $19 million in guaranteed money in 2009, including a $15 million signing bonus, assures that he will be the starting quarterback for at least 2009 and probably 2010 and that he will almost certainly finish his career with the Cardinals.

After only five months of breaking the news, the comedian D.L. Hughley‘s CNN show is concluding at the end of March. “D.L. Hughley Breaks the News” was billed as a Saturday-night talk show tied to the week’s news. The show averaged 750,000 viewers and was taped in front of a studio audience in New York. In a statement Thursday, CNN said Mr. Hughley wanted to be permanently based in California to be closer to his family. “To accommodate this, we agreed upon a new role where he will be a contributor for the network based in Los Angeles,” the network said. CNN isn’t exiting the comedic news business entirely: its international channels will continue to play hour long recaps of “The Daily Show,” the Comedy Central news satire, each weekend.

The singer Chris Brown arrived in a Los Angeles courtroom on Thursday afternoon, hours after he was charged with two felonies stemming from an altercation with his companion, the pop star Rihanna, The Associated Press reported. Earlier in the day, Mr. Brown was charged with assault likely to cause bodily injury and making criminal threats, following a Feb. 8 incident in which he had fought with Rihanna in his car. At that time, he was arrested and released on bail. The felony complaint against Mr. Brown identifies his alleged victim as “Robyn F.”; Rihanna’s full name is Robyn Rihanna Fenty. With lawyers for both Mr. Brown and Rihanna in the courtroom, Mr. Brown answered a few questions from a court commissioner, who ordered him not to harass, threaten or harm anyone, according to The A.P. Mr. Brown’s arraignment has been postponed until April 6.

The last time most of us saw all four principal members of the “Seinfeld” cast together they were sharing a jail cell in that sitcom’s self-referential, un-sponge-worthy 1998 series finale. A decade later, Jerry Seinfeld, Jason Alexander, Michael Richards and Julia Louis-Dreyfus will be reunited in the slightly less oppressive environs of “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” the HBO comedy that stars the “Seinfeld” co-creator Larry David, The Associated Press reported. A representative for HBO said that the “Seinfeld” stars would be part of a multi-episode story line in the coming season of “Curb Your Enthusiasm.” The new season, which will be 10 episodes, is scheduled to start in the fall.

Illustrating Karl Marx’s lesser-known maxim that history repeats itself first as a chick flick and second as a stage musical, the 1990 romance “Ghost” will become the latest cinematic weepie to be translated to the stage. The creative team of “Ghost: The Musical” announced that they would be adapting the supernatural film, in which Patrick Swayze and Demi Moore famously got frisky around a pottery wheel, for a production to open in London’s West End in 2010. Bruce Joel Rubin, who won an Academy Award for the original screenplay, will write the book and lyrics, and Dave Stewart and Glen Ballard will write music and lyrics; Matthew Warchus (Broadway’s coming “God of Carnage”) will direct. No casting or theater was announced. A musical version of the romantic comedy “Sleepless in Seattle,” planned for Broadway in 2010, was announced earlier this week.BONUS: Janet Maslin’s Times review of “Ghost” (“Current Hollywood thinking extends into the next world, but not very far”) can be found here.

For the time being, at least, having a day job hasn’t hampered the Roots. On Thursday night, after wrapping their first week as the house band for NBC’s “Late Night with Jimmy Fallon,” the acclaimed hip-hop group played a loose and rambunctious show at the Highline Ballroom, starting shortly before midnight. The show kicked off a residency called “The Jam,” which will repeat on March 19, 23 and 31, and April 14 and 21, with future dates to be scheduled.

Ending a two-month drought in which she apparently had no newsworthy contact with the British legal system, Amy Winehouse appeared in a London court Thursday where she was arrested and charged for an incident in which she is accused of attacking a fan, The Associated Press said. Sherene Flash, a dancer, has said that Ms. Winehouse, the soul singer, hit her in the eye at a charity ball in Berkeley Square on Sept. 26 when she asked to take a picture of Ms. Winehouse. A police spokesman told The A.P. that Ms. Winehouse appeared voluntarily at the station, where she was charged with common assault and released. Ms. Winehouse is scheduled to appear in court on March 17 to answer the charge.

As Haley Jones on Thursday night’s episode of “CSI: Crime Scene Investigation,” Taylor Swift fulfilled an aspiration she’s talked about a lot in the press: to be an object of forensic analysis. The program started and then, a few moments in, there she was, dead in a motel parking lot, a body in search of a plot.

The Broadway play “Impressionism” has postponed its official opening by 12 days, its publicists said. The play, which stars Jeremy Irons (in his first Broadway role since “The Real Thing”) and Joan Allen (her first since “The Heidi Chronicles”), is now scheduled to open at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on March 24; it was previously scheduled to open on March 12, and has been in previews since Feb. 28. Written by Michael Jacobs and and directed by Jack O’Brien, the play has not been previously workshopped or performed elsewhere. In a statement, Bill Haber, a producer of the show,said, “We did not give Jack O’Brien and our extraordinary creative team and company enough time to fully prepare Michael Jacobs’s new play for Broadway.” A preview performance scheduled for Monday has been canceled to permit more time for rehearsals.

In an honor that’s nearly as estimable as achieving Alpha-Plus status, the literary archive of Aldous Huxley, the writer and “Brave New World” novelist, has been acquired by the U.C.L.A. Library, the library announced. Among the materials in the collection are manuscripts and working papers for 12 of his books, as well as 35 essays, articles and speeches; recordings of Huxley reading from his lectures and his 1944 novel, “Time Must Have a Stop”; and love letters he exchanged with his wife Laura, who died in 2007. The archive also includes personal items like a magnifying glass and wallet used by Huxley, as well as his British passport. Though Huxley was born and raised in Britain, he lived in California from 1937 until his death in 1963. The U.C.L.A. Library’s special collections department is already home to the manuscripts for his novels “Time Must Have a Stop” and “The Devils of Loudon.”

How powerful is Rush Limbaugh? Well, powerful enough to make Michael Steele, chairman of the Republican National Committee, apologize for calling the radio host a mere "entertainer." Possibly powerful enough to cost Steele his job. But powerful enough to force President Obama to debate him? You'd think that would be highly unlikely, but as we found out this week, the White House is going to do everything in its power to keep Limbaugh at the forefront of public consciousness.

I had no idea that this was going to be hell week for General Electric when I decided to write about it. What spurred my column this week was the company's decision to cut its dividend last Friday by 66 percent. But hell week it certainly was. Two analysts at a small firm came out with a brutal report essentially predicting the kind of downward spiral that has so badly damaged other big firms, like Citi and Bank of America. Other bears circled. Credit default spreads widened. The stock sank. The chief financial officer went on CNBC to defend the company. And on and on it went, a dance we've seen again and again -- usually with bad results.

Citigroup -- the mega-bank that managed its own finances so badly that it has required three taxpayer bailouts totaling at least $45 billion so far -- is preaching fiscal responsibility to young people.This week, the company began pitching a Visa credit card to MySpace users called Citi Forward, with the slogan, "Actions speak louder than words."

In case you missed it, an asteroid -- 2009 DD45 to be exact -- measuring between 20 and 30 yards in diameter, flew past us on Monday at about 41,000 miles from Earth, which is about twice as high as the orbits of some telecommunications satellites. A more sizable asteroid, 99942 Apophis, which has a 885-foot diameter, will come within 21,000 miles of the Earth in 2029.

A document containing names and Social Security numbers of 3,470 city employees represented by the Organization of Staff Analysts, a 4,600-member municipal union, disappeared after an apparent mix-up in the mail system, prompting the city to send letters to the employees warning that their information might have been compromised.It was the second time in recent weeks that the privacy of some city employees had been compromised. An employee of the Police Pension Fund walked into a data center on Staten Island and took 12 computer backup disks containing personal information, including Social Security numbers. The man was arrested on Feb. 28 and the tapes were recovered, while the city continues to review the security for the facility.

Colette is always an obligatory pit stop for editors during fashion week, but this season the chic boutique might as well have had an official slot on the calendar. On Saturday, the team from Current Elliott will be at Colette customizing their popular "boyfriend jeans" according to clients' wishes; the model Erin Wasson will present her first fashion collection, recently shown in New York; the photographers Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin will sign copies of their new portfolio for Stern magazine; Harri Peccinotti, who just published a book of his sexy fashion work with Damiani, will also be signing away; and for old-school photography aficionados, Lomo will introduce a new version of its classic camera (created in conjunction with Colette) with an exhibition of photos snapped by 10 female artists around the world. That film, which ended up making $70.9 million at the domestic box-office in 2007, holds the record for an opening weekend in March.

When it comes to air pollution in the New York City area, there is no shortage of places to cast blame. The Environmental Protection Agency's definition of the local "nonattainment area" where pollutants regularly exceed federal air quality standards includes the city, northern New Jersey, Long Island and part of Connecticut.

I've heard enough book-group horror stories to doubt the whole notion of communal reading. One of the undercelebrated joys of literature, after all, is precisely that it allows (or demands?) such solitude and intimacy: reading has more in common with the cloisters than it does with the congregation. To my mind, then, programs like the popular "One Community, One Book" - which my hometown has just instituted - feel coercive and dutiful, more promotion than devotion.

In the classic Abbott and Costello routine, Who was on first base, What was on second and I Don't Know was on third. Seventy-one years after that routine was first performed nationally, I Don't Know is still hanging around, waiting to play third for the Yankees ifAlex Rodriguez cannot hold up physically.

Online-poker forums have turned the gambler's time-honored "bad beat" story - a tale of a seemingly surefire victory gone wrong - into a literary art. A timely literary art. When it comes to online poker, bad-beat stories entertain an inevitable, if unspeakable, contemporary worry: the Internet is rigged. And who doesn't brood on that from time to time? Facebook is taking our data; our surfing patterns are being tracked; the bill for all this free info is bound to come due someday.

This technique for preparing mussels is similar to cooking them a la plancha -- on a thick slab of hot metal, much like griddles used by short-order cooks. Here, the mussels are presented in the same skillet in which they cooked, so their juices -- cooked dry and stuck to the pan -- come with them. Dip the mussels in drawn butter, or just season with salt and pepper.

Expanding outward from Thursday's health care summit at the White House, the Obama administration announced today that it planned to hold several regional forums on the subject in key states.

Politics | If, as conservatives argue, tax cuts starve government, making people willing to accept program cutbacks down the line, will massive deficits to pay for health care, green energy and the like do the exact opposite -- i.e., create the appetite later to pay for these programs through higher taxes? That's what's Ross Douthat of The Atlantic thinks Obama's up to with all this money-printing. Another blogger, Jonathan Chait, says Obama's spending is wiser than "cleaning up the Republican mess," as he says Clinton tried to do after the Reagan-Bush era. "Not only did Democrats mostly fail to impose their priorities to anything like the degree Republicans had, voters penalized them in 1994 for imposing fiscal pain." [Atlantic, New Republic]

An early review of the Balenciaga fall collection, which was shown Wednesday morning in Paris, declared that it was strictly "all about Yves." Certainly Saint Laurent, whose worldly possessions were auctioned off at the Grand Palais last week, is on a lot of people's minds. But was Saint Laurent the only thing on Nicolas Ghesquière's mind? We detected a whiff of Emmanuel Ungaro in the air. And for anyone wanting to get a jump on fall (while saving a few euros in the process), here's a shortcut: a pattern from Vogue Patterns (a "Paris Original," no less) for a 1980s Ungaro "High Fashion Dress." When it comes to air pollution in the New York City area, there is no shortage of places to cast blame. The Environmental Protection Agency's definition of the local "nonattainment area" where pollutants regularly exceed federal air quality standards includes the city, northern New Jersey, Long Island and part of Connecticut. In a territory that large, 6.5 tons of particulate matter emissions per year amount to a drop in the bucket. In context, the same goes for 99 tons of sulfur dioxide. Still, the chance to prevent pollution on that level is an exciting one, and two local agencies, the Port Authority and the city's Economic Development Corporation, are hoping to do just that with a new initiative being planned for the Red Hook waterfront.
I think it's time that high-end restaurants team up with the airlines. There is never enough food on airplanes, and too much at fine-dining establishments.

Literature | Sales of "Atlas Shrugged" spiked after Britain bailed out Northern Rock, after TARP took big stakes in American banks and when Obama's stimulus plan passed. "Whenever governments intervene in the market, in short, readers rush to buy Rand's book," an article says. Then again, Marx hasn't been selling too badly either. Come to think of it, how about a "Grapes of Wrath" index? [Economist, BBC]

An important game takes place in the Western Hockey League tonight, when the Calgary Hitmen, ranked No. 2 in the Canadian Hockey League ranking, visit the Vancouver Giants, ranked No. 3. How important? The Vancouver Sun is calling it "junior hockey's game of the year." Two points separate the teams and the over-all lead in the W.H.L. is at stake tonight. In their previous meeting, in Calgary on Jan. 16, the Hitmen pulled away late for a 6-3 victory.

When it comes to employment, this is not like any recession that most Americans can remember. The falloff in jobs over the last six months -- since just before Lehman Brothers went under -- has been greater than in any similar period since the 1970s.

The Mitsubishi Research and Design of America office and design center in Cypress, Calif., are being closed, and 60 employees are being let go, said Moe Durand, a spokesman for Mitsubishi Motors North America on Thursday.

Oops. Now TARP bailouts and luxury skyboxes don't exactly mix. [Wall Street Journal]

The Pakistani newspaper Dawn reports that on Thursday, "the mausoleum of renowned Pashto mystic poet Abdur Rehman Baba was bombed by unidentified miscreants," outside Peshawar, in Pakistan's North West Frontier Province. Dawn calls the bombing of the shrine to "a 17th century poet, revered for his message of love and peace" part of an "attack on Sufism."

Greenhill & Company, the boutique investment bank, is expanding its footprint in the burgeoning restructuring sector by establishing a financing advisory and restructuring practice and hiring two senior bankers.

Wall Street jobs are scarce these days, but here's a rare bright spot: The new chief of Cantor Fitzgerald & Company, a unit of Cantor Fitzgerald LP, says the unit is looking to hire as many as 100 professionals for its fixed-income business this year.

Environment | There might be a simpler way to reduce carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, researchers say: build "air capture" machines to "scrub" it out like they do on submarines and spacecraft. The technology "has been around for decades, but the only people who cared were at NASA, because too much CO2 in a space shuttle means you die," says a researcher. But how to power the air scrubbers without defeating the purpose? And could they discourage efforts to improve energy efficiency? [Economist]
Bernard Madoff and $50 billion.
For his second act, Eliot Spitzer, the former governor and attorney general of New York, is reportedly following in his father's footsteps as an investor in commercial real estate.
One Merrill Lynch trader apparently gambled away more than $120 million in the currency markets. Others seemingly lost hundreds of millions on tricky credit derivatives.

Trying to draw a line in the sand, a Senate panel told the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve to identify all the parties made whole by the bailout of the American International Group or forget about coming back to ask Congress for more rescue money, The New York Times's Mary Williams Walsh reports.

There are times when a corporate takeover has importance far beyond the companies involved.

Exxon Mobil put on a show of strength on Thursday, pledging to increase investments in coming years, chiding rivals for mistimed acquisitions and reminding everyone it had the financial strength to make headway even as other companies pulled back, The New York Times's Jad Mouawad reported.

Citigroup needs superhero directors, Breakingviews says. With its stock dipping for a while below $1 on Thursday, the struggling bank could use help from the corporate equivalent of the Justice League, the band of DC Comics superheroes that included Wonder Woman, Batman and Green Lantern.

The American hedge fund Citadel Investment Group plans to roll out several new funds, including one with lower fees that will aim to make money on currencies, interest rates and other trades based on broad economic trends, The Wall Street Journal reported.
Personal and business bankruptcy filings surged last year as the economy spiraled downward, new data showed Thursday, a trend experts say they expect to continue in 2009.

The Hearst Corporation has given the first concrete sign that it might turn its Seattle newspaper into an Internet-only news outlet, making offers to some of its staff to stay on in such an operation, The New York Times's Richard Perez-Pena rpeorted, citing journalists there.

U.S. private equity firms are reporting substantial write-downs on their portfolios for the year, but investors are already anticipating the next round of cuts if the equity markets continue to fall, Reuters said.

GENEVA -- Volkswagens are built in Mexico. Chevrolets are built in India. Mercedes, BMW and Toyota all build vehicles in, well, the United States. The list goes on and on. But one interesting trend uncovered at this year's Geneva auto show is the globalization of Italy's most prestigious car designers.
The African lender Standard Bank said it had inked a deal to buy a 33 percent stake in Troika Dialog, Russia's second-largest investment bank.
Citigroup plans to sell its 26 percent stake in Japanese online broker Monex Group, to raise cash, The Yomiuri Shimbun reported on Friday.
Terra Industries' board has urged shareholders to rebuff the $2.1 billion hostile bid started by a rival, CF Industries, two weeks ago.

The auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers is overhauling its operations in India two months after starting an investigation into fraud at one of its Indian clients, The New York Times's Heather Timmons reported.

Asian stock markets resumed their downward slide Friday after Wall Street fell to its lowest levels in more than 12 years amid deepening fears about the fate of General Motors and major financial companies, The Associated Press said.

Satyam Computer Services won regulatory approval to sell a majority stake in itself, but suitors said there was still uncertainty about the accounts and liabilities at the Indian company, which has been hit by fraud.

Psychology | The vigilante hero of the comic-book film adaptation "Watchmen" (opening today) is named Rorschach and wears an inkblot mask. But do psychologists still use the Rorschach test? Yes, an article says; it's "second in popularity only to the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory among professionals in the field." But those aren't genuine Rorschach inkblots on the mask in the film; in fact, "the official Rorschach images are still under copyright in some countries." [Slate]

First, a hearty thanks to everyone for the interesting and funny comments over the course of the last few days and shows - Hutton, Miss T (loved the English wedding reference - so true), Barbara Alexander, RC, Marko (for disagreeing so well on Balenciaga), Eric Antos and many others. At least in Paris we are not having a discussion (yet?) about the '80s, etc. I like the debate that Ghesquiere's collection stirred, and I know or sense that many people here on the blog feel he was not up to his game this time. He didn't quite have it, and that lack of, what? - precision? diligence? - is unusual. I'll just add that I love when very talented designers let go of the familiar and swim in a different direction. Ghesquiere has done soft clothes many times before (think of the Balenciaga bride collection), but this time it's with the advantage of everything he's learned and tried since.

Tune in to the Men's Fashion Spring 2009 issue of T, which highlights television's most interesting leading men - the cover star Eric Dane, plus Bill Hader, Gaius Charles, Joshua Jackson and Taylor Kitsch - all of whom are poised to make the jump from the small screen to your local cineplex. We also pay tribute to a handful of visual powerhouses who are no longer with us but who continue to influence the culture in unexpected ways: the provocateur Martin Kippenberger, the photographer George Platt Lynes and the painter Egon Schiele are all enjoying a second coming. Elsewhere in the issue, we meet the artist Samuel Fosso, who has an uncanny ability to transform himself into an assortment of characters; the designer Christopher Bailey, who shares his creative universe; and the musician John Mayer, who takes us on a tour of his world-class watch collection. Look at this installment of T as a celebrity-, artist- and fashion-studded season premiere.
