A music review on Saturday about the “Shuffle Mode” concert at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, featuring the Brooklyn Philharmonic and the indie-rock bands Clogs and Bell Orchestre, misspelled the given name of the bassoon player for Clogs. She is Rachael Elliott, not Rachel.
The Yankees have known for 10 months that Alex Rodriguez had an irregularity in his right hip. Why were they not more aggressive about monitoring him?

A music review last Friday about Thievery Corporation at Terminal 5, using information from a publicist, misidentified the vocalist on the song “Vampires.” It was Arthur Steele, not his brother, Archie.

An article on Wednesday about Google’s efforts to inform authors around the world about a proposed settlement that would allow the company to proceed with part of its plan to digitize all books misidentified the Pacific Ocean region in which the island of Niue, where Google placed a newspaper advertisement, is situated. It is in Polynesia, not Micronesia.
The son of a Dead Sea Scrolls scholar was accused of using stolen identities to harass critics of his father’s theories.

A music review on Thursday about a concert of contemporary music at Alice Tully Hall misstated the history of “For Madeleine” by Michael Gordon. The performance at Alice Tully Hall was its New York premiere, not its world premiere.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about plans to make a musical based on the movie “Sleepless in Seattle” misidentified the director. He is Joel Zwick — not Edward Zwick, also a director. (They are not related.).

An article on Thursday about the risks of giving free antibiotics to consumers misstated a word in the name of an organization studying the issue. It is the Infectious Diseases Society of America (not Disease).
Arriving at the Dodgers’ spring training headquarters on Thursday, Manny Ramírez declared that he was looking forward to his first full season in Los Angeles.

An article on Tuesday about the appointment of Nancy-Ann DeParle to run the White House Office of Health Reform referred incorrectly to the ancestry of Ms. DeParle’s mother. She was a native-born American, not a Chinese immigrant. (Ms. DeParle’s father was from China.).
An article on Thursday about the nomination of W. Craig Fugate to head the Federal Emergency Management Agency misstated his political affiliation. He is a registered Democrat, not a Republican.
For the first time, President Obama indicated that he was open to compromise on details of the health care overhaul he proposed in the 2008 campaign.

STERN--Jean L. The Trustees and staff of The Children's Aid Society of New York mourn the passing of beloved Board member Jean L. Stern. She was one of Children's Aid's most compassionate, dedicated, caring and committed Trustees and one of our most active committee members, co-chairing the City and Country Branches committee and serving on the Health Services, Office of Public Policy & Client Advocacy, Mental Health and Foster Care/Home-Based Services committees. In her 12 years as a member of the Board, she was an extremely generous supporter of the agency's mental health programs, Child Sight, Alvin Ailey summer dance camp and many other programs. In addition, she and her husband Robert established a four-year college scholarship, named for their late son Wick, which is given to eight students each year who have stayed in school and pursued higher education despite great obstacles. Jean was an irreplaceable part of The Children's Aid Society, and she will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Angela Diaz, M.D., M.P.H., President C. Warren Moses, Chief Executive Officer

P'stan The governor of Punjab said on Thursday that the Pakistani police had made a number of arrests in the commando-style attack on the Sri Lanka cricket team in the Punjabi city of Lahore, but he offered no details, saying that a full report would be presented on Friday. The governor, Salmaan Taseer, also said that investigators had found weapons and that the attackers were fully trained. It was unclear from his remarks whether any of the gunmen were among those arrested. The police have been struggling to explain security lapses after the Tuesday attack, in which a dozen gunmen ambushed vans carrying the cricket team and officials as they passed through a central square before an international cricket match at Lahore's central stadium. The attack, which killed six police officers and a driver, has deeply embarrassed Pakistan.

At least five police officers were killed and several wounded on Thursday when a bomb they were trying to defuse exploded in Ingushetia, the restive southern Russian republic close to Chechnya, investigators said. Among the dead were the chief of police for the republic's Nazran region and two officers from the Federal Security Service, according to a statement from the investigative wing of Russia's prosecutor general's office. The bloodshed is a reminder of the volatility in Ingushetia, which is mostly Muslim and has been plagued by attacks and bombings by militants. MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China called Thursday for closer political and economic relations with Taiwan, but he offered few specifics and did not expand on a previous suggestion by President Hu Jintao for improving communication with Taiwan on military issues. In his opening speech to the National People's Congress, Mr. Wen clearly signaled the Chinese leadership's support for a series of economic measures that negotiators from Beijing and Taiwan were already discussing. These include the gradual integration of banking and other financial services across the Taiwan Strait, and the drafting of a ''comprehensive agreement on economic cooperation'' that could eventually become the basis for a free-trade agreement.

PERU: CENTRAL BANK CUTS RATE TO 6% Peru's central bank cut its benchmark lending rate for a second consecutive month to spur economic growth as global demand declines for the country's commodities. The seven-member board, led by its central bank president, Julio Velarde, left, reduced the rate by a quarter percentage point, to 6 percent. Policy makers said in a statement accompanying the decision that the rate cut came after the bank found ''less inflationary pressure and declining inflation expectations.'' Peru's economy expanded 6.6 percent in the fourth quarter, the slowest pace in more than two years, as manufacturing, fishing and electricity output slumped. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

TIBET The British rock band Oasis has said that the Chinese government canceled the band's scheduled debut concerts in China because a band member, Noel Gallagher, had appeared at a Free Tibet concert in New York in 1997. The band said in a posting on its MySpace page this week that the government told the band on Feb. 28 that officials were revoking a performance license and that two shows scheduled for early April in Beijing and Shanghai were being canceled. A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman said at a news conference on Tuesday that organizers of the concert had informed Chinese officials that the concerts were canceled ''because of economic reasons in their business operations.''

BUCHMAN--Irving, died March 4, 2009, in the hospital in New York City, of congestive heart failure and related illnesses. He was born in the Bronx in 1925, the youngest son of the late Benjamin and Ydit Brendzel Buchman. He earned his B.A. at The City College Of New York and his M.F.A. in Theater at "Carnegie Tech" (later, Carnegie Mellon.) After stage managing at The Actors Studio and on Broadway, he followed his brother Herman (later joined by their brother Harry) into the then new medium of television. They all worked as makeup artists, helping to shape their new union, Local 798 of IATSE. Later, Irv was much in demand during a golden age of New York City filmmaking. Among many other feature films, he worked on "A Thousand Clowns", "The Group", "The Producers", "Midnight Cowboy", "Klute", "Taxi Driver", and "Diner". In addition to his loving wife of 58 years, Mariette (Tine) Barkhorn Buchman and his brother Harry, he leaves his four children Timothy, Amie, Andrew, and Mariette, nieces Helaine, Judy, and Caitlin, and six grandchildren: Amelia, Bic, and Celeste Cass; Sage, Tyler, and Phoebe Altenhofen. The funeral service will be private. The family will receive visitors at home on Friday and Saturday, March 6 and 7, from 5pm to 8pm, 415 Central Park West, New York, NY 10025. Contributions can be made to The New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, in care of the Friends Office, Room M6, 476 Fifth Avenue, New York NY 10018.

As he introduced his new choice for secretary of health and human services in the East Room this week, President Obama turned his head from right to left, but he was not looking at the audience. He was reading from two teleprompters strategically set up outside the tight television camera shot. When he was done, the teleprompters quietly began retracting down to the floor. As she stepped forward to make her remarks, the nominee, Gov. Kathleen Sebelius of Kansas, seemed momentarily surprised.

HAHN--Ann Shriver (Nancy), 80, died peacefully in her home in Haverford, PA on February 18, 2009. She was born October 26, 1928 in Manhattan, NY. She was the youngest of three children born to Alfred and Anne (nee Fowler) Shriver. She graduated from Madeira Boarding School in Virginia where she was Class President. She attended Mt. Holyoke College in Massachusetts. She took two years of accounting at the American Institute of Banking, and studied biometrics and calculus at Cornell Medical School. She became a statistical analyst in the Department of Biometrics at New York Hospital. She was also one of the first women admitted to the officers' training program at Chase Manhattan Bank in NY. In 1954 she wed Stephen Hahn in Paris, France. She was a loving and devoted mother to three children Rob, Anne Elizabeth and Tom. While raising her children she was elected president of the Yorkville Youth Council's Board, a non-profit organization supporting after-school centers in the New York public school system. In addition, Nancy was the Assistant Administrative Director of Diller-Quaile School of Music, NY, and was the Administrative Director and Headmaster's assistant at St. Bernard's School, NY. In 1980 she moved near Philadelphia where she became assistant to the director of Performing Arts program at Bryn Mawr College and later a legal secretary for Crawford and Diamond law offices. At the same time, she created ASH Handwovens, her own line of handwoven fabrics. Later in life, her love of animals led her to become a member of the Board of Directors at Women's SPCA of Pennsylvania. She compiled and edited a pioneering book on the human/companion animal bond, "New Perspectives on out Lives with Companion Animals" published by University of Pennsylvania press. She dedicated her last 15 professional years, into her late 70s, as an event planner for St. David's Church, in Wayne, PA, arranging and coordinating weddings. She spent every summer with her children, grandchildren and extended family at her summer home in the woods of Forestburgh, NY as her family has done since the 1880s. Nancy possessed a keen curiosity which led her to engage in many diverse intellectual endeavors. She was kind and generous not only to her family but also to her many friends. Nancy will be deeply missed. Mrs. Hahn is survived by her three children, Rob, Weston CT, Anne Elizabeth Block, Westlake Village, CA, Tom, Piedmont CA, brother Donald Shriver, Maplewood, NJ and eight grandchildren. She is further survived by nieces, nephews, other relatives and dear friends. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her brother Denton Shriver. A Memorial Service will be held at 2pm on Saturday, March 21, 2009 at St. David's Church (old church) 763 South Valley Forge Rd., Wayne, PA 19087. In lieu of flowers contributions in her name may be made to Merriewold Club Memorial Fund, 2674 Route 42, Forestburgh, NY 12777.

MANDELL--Abe, 89, Pioneer of Television Syndication Business, on March 5, 2009. Abe Mandell was President of ITC Entertainment for over 25 years. He is credited with being the man who brought The Muppets to television and movie audiences all over the world through the widely successful "The Muppet Show," and Muppet movies. Mandell enjoyed an incredibly successful and diverse career in the entertainment industry. His company launched over 35 major motion pictures, as well as some of the world's most popular television shows, including such classics as "The Muppet Show," "Space: 1999," "The Prisoner," "The Saint," and "Adventures of the Galaxy Rangers." Born in Covington, KY, October 4th 1919 to Jacob and Ester Mandell, he went on to attend the University of Cincinnati. After serving in the Army in the Pacific Theater of WWII, Mandell returned with his new wife, Bernice, to Manila in 1947, where he opened international markets for the American motion picture industry, and often traveled vast distances with a canister of film under his arm. Moving to New York City in 1957, he became head of international sales for ZIV Television, then hired by Lord Lew Grade to handle sales for ITC Entertainment, and eventually Mandell became the president of the company. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife, Bernice, his three children, Judy, Robert, and Henry, and his three grandchildren, Sarah, Olinde, and Graham. Funeral Service Today 12 noon at Larchmont Temple in Larchmont, NY. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery in Hasting-on-Hudson, NY. For information call Fox Funeral Home (914) 834-0144.

A slide show of the newly renovated galleries of American art at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The museum recently reopened its section of American art after two years spent upgrading wiring, heating, cooling and ventilation. Not yet reinstalled when Roberta Smith, an art critic for The Times, visited was the museum's single gallery devoted to the Garbisch collection (gifts from Edgar William and Bernice Chrysler Garbisch). Nonetheless, she writes, ''I viewed its 11 paintings grouped in a storage room. Even leaning against walls in fluorescent light, they were the strongest works I saw all day.'' The Garbisch collection includes William Matthew Prior's ''Little Miss Fairfield,'' top left. ''The picture's life is quickened by the black lines of shadow defining the child's arms and hands,'' Ms. Smith writes. Winthrop Chandler's detailed portrait of Capt. Samuel Chandler, top right, is also in the Garbisch gallery. nytimes.com/arts

The Dallas Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones, once one of receiver Terrell Owens's biggest boosters, explained -- vaguely -- on Thursday why Owens's latest career stop ended just as his stints in San Francisco and Philadelphia did. He praised his play on the field and voiced concern for the impact he had on the rest of the team. ''Terrell Owens was a very productive player who performed at a very high level for all three of his years here in Dallas,'' Jones said in a statement. ''But we have made a decision to move forward without him.

President Obama on Thursday named Vivek Kundra, a youthful, Indian-born computer expert, as the first federal chief information officer. The White House said Mr. Kundra, 34, who for the past year and a half was the chief technology officer for the District of Columbia, would have wide powers to oversee federal technology spending, improve information sharing between agencies, and expand public access to government information.

In the classic Abbott and Costello routine, Who was on first base, What was on second and I Don't Know was on third. Seventy-one years after that routine was first performed nationally, I Don't Know is still hanging around, waiting to play third for the Yankees if Alex Rodriguez cannot hold up physically. I Don't Know could turn out to be Cody Ransom, a 33-year-old career backup who hit .302 for the Yankees last year, but had only 43 at-bats. Nobody has yet been moved to call him C-Ran.

PRODDOW--Penny, passed away peacefully at home in New York, February 28, 2009, following a short illness. Penny's professional worlds included teaching at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, curating at R. Esmerian, Inc., co-writing a monthly column for In Style Magazine. Educated at Bryn Mawr as a classical archaeologist, Penny wrote a series of children's books in the 1970s, bringing to life the world of Greek myths for a young audience: these writings would become the basis of her lecture series "Pause for Pegasus" given at the educational department at the Met in recent years. Applying her knowledge of ancient art, Penny became a jewelry researcher and historian; her pioneer efforts assisted in organizing landmark jewelry exhibitions and co-writing articles and five books. Most important of all, Penny's friends and associates will miss her gutsy creativity, her acute observation enhanced by historical and literary knowledge, and of course her laughter - all together providing for a unique humanity that only Penny Proddow could bring to our lives. Burial in Nantucket will be private. Ralph Esmerian

KRAM--Harvey, born August 16, 1921 in Bronx, NY, died March 3rd in Boston. Predeceased by parents Abraham and Gertrude Freedman Kram and brother, Leonard, he is survived by wife of 67 years, Elly Kram, children Leonard and Kathy Kram and their respective spouses Nancy Cohen Kram and Peter Yeager, grandchildren Jason Yeager, Nicole Kram Rosen and Brent Kram and spouses Zachary Rosen and Marisol Sewell along with great-grandchildren Bella Kram Rosen and Lisa Gilman Rosen. After graduating M.I.T. in 1942, he served as a Naval Officer during World War II. For most of his career, he worked for Leviton Manufacturing Company. where he rose to Vice President of Operations for more than a decade. A dedicated family man who went out of his way to help others, he was held in high esteem by his inner family circle, his many cousins, peers and lifelong friends but he most adored being "Papa" to his grandkids of all ages. He and wife Elly started the Jason Fund in honor of their grandson to support research to cure diabetes. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Jason Fund, c/o Diabetes Research Institute Foundation, 3440 Hollywood Boulevard, Suite 100, Hollywood, FL 33021-6900 would perpetuate this mission. On Sunday, March 8th, memorial services will be held at 12:30pm in Great Neck, NY, in Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 N. Station Plaza.

FOOTE--Horton, was our colleague, our friend, and our family. The very thought of this world without him in it is beyond comprehension, considering how fully he lived with such grace, integrity, and passion for our shared humanity. We knew him through the stories and characters he created for us, and for some of us, we knew him simply as our "buddy"-- a lover of chocolate, Coca-Cola, rehearsal rooms, performances, and especially family, friends, and his work. He will always be remembered by his words-- his extraordinary words. To Horton's family, we send our love and gratitude for letting us all share the great gift of knowing him. We will miss him more than our words can tell. Jim Houghton and Signature Theatre Company

FOOTE--Horton. The playwrights, board and staff of New Dramatists mourn the death of Horton Foote. We offer our condolences to Hallie, Horton Jr., Walter, Daisy and the entire family on the loss of this extraordinary gentleman. One of New Dramatists' earliest resident playwrights, Horton's life will continue to be a model for generations of writers. He was dedicated, industrious and undaunted as a playwright, generous as a professional colleague and unmatched as a human being. Everyone will miss him profoundly for his unique voice, wisdom, sweetness and humor. We will treasure the memory of Horton through his work, which is so reflectively steeped in truth. Isobel Robins Konecky, President Seth Gelblum, Chairman

GORDON--Michael M. It is with profound sadness that the lawyers and staff of McKee Nelson LLP mourn the loss of our partner, friend and colleague, Michael M. Gordon. A man of great integrity, intelligence, compassion and judgment, Michael was a prominent commercial litigator dedicated to defending the rights of his clients in complex product liability, employment and securities disputes. His body of legal work includes playing a leadership role for more than 30 years in the Agent Orange litigation and representing Exxon Mobil in the New York Harbor oil spill. He was recognized as a leading expert in the developing areas of vicarious liability and federal claims based on the alien torts statute. An integral member of the McKee Nelson family, Michael previously was a partner in King & Spalding and Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. He was a true senior statesman in the legal community, leaving a lasting impression on everyone who had the honor of knowing him. Above all, Michael was devoted to his cherished family. We extend our deepest sympathy and sincere condolences to his wife Linda Lowry Gordon, his daughter Alexandra Lowry Gordon, his son Harrison Lowry Gordon, his parents Gladys Mackin Gordon and Lawrence H. Gordon, his brother Andrew Mackin Gordon and his extended family.

UNANUE DE QUINONES--Mary Ann. The Board and Staff of Ballet Hispanico extend their deepest sympathies to the Unanue family on Mary Ann's untimely passing. The Unanue family have been long standing friends to Ballet Hispanico and our hearts go out to them in this tragic time.

ALBANY -- Manhattan Coach Barry Rohrssen looked a bit dazed in the aftermath of the Jaspers' 68-61 loss to Fairfield on Saturday night in the MAAC tournament. The Jaspers clanged away their shot at the MAAC semifinals at the free-throw line, where nine free throws bounced astray in the second half.

My Sunday column is about the aid workers being expelled from Darfur. Surprisingly, the United Nations reacted with rather more vigor than the Obama administration, especially at first. Ban Ki-moon issued a tough statement and has been busy calling up leaders in the region to try to get this reversed, and the heads of WFP and other agencies made strong statements as well. In contrast, the initial State Department comment was pathetic, although it was strengthened to a condemnation on Friday. Obama, Biden, Clinton were all tough on Darfur when they were in the Senate and when they were running for office, so let's hope they aren't backing down now that they are in office.

Terrell Owens has agreed to a one-year contract with the Bills, bringing his well-documented celebration of himself proven talents to the A.F.C. East. At $6.5 million, Owens seems to have come at a bargain price. And since the Bills only committed to one year, he will have to work quickly if he is going to wear out his welcome in a fourth N.F.L. city.

This morning I headed out early for the Café de Flore. I picked up the new French Vogue (all about Coco Chanel) and some newspapers. I put away some coffee and eggs. Haider Ackermann's show was at 10:30 a.m. on the Quai Malaquais, which is a few steps from Dries van Noten's shop, and by my calculation of such things, I could shop for a few minutes before I went to Ackermann. I rang the shop buzzer at 10:29.

For any number of reasons, many things in fashion look dated. Magazines look dated. Stores look dated. Lots of clothes look dated, including many we saw only yesterday. We've seen talented designers put forward craft and savoir faire, like Alber Elbaz with a super Lanvin collection. And many others have surprised us by moving in a new or more accessible direction, like Nicolas Ghesquiere at Balenciaga with his satin drapery and John Galliano with his Persian motifs at Dior. But while these collections show a great deal of hard work and focus - as you'd expect, given the daunting economic picture - we feel somehow they are not very ambitious. They are almost too easy to understand. The mastery of a particular dressmaking technique, however pleasing the result, is not proof of an extraordinary sensibility. Indeed, after marveling at a technique we gradually come to realize that it's still the same old technique and that really nothing has changed or improved our understanding of fashion. We feel empty, in fact.

Usually, it's President Obama (or one of his aides) who ends the interview, leaving reporters clamoring for more. Indeed, Robert Gibbs, his press secretary, cut off the president's exclusive interview with The Times on Friday after about 35 minutes.

Box Office Mojo has the opening day figures up for "Watchmen," the biggest release of the year, so far, and a movie that prognosticators had been predicting would make anywhere from $50 million to $85 million in its opening weekend. Including midnight shows on Thursday night, the superhero adventure based on the classic graphic novel had made $25.1 million in its first day of release on an estimated 7,500 screens in 3,611 theaters. The midnight shows, which were on a smaller number of screens, accounted for $4.55 million of that.

Vijay Mallya is more than just a familiar face around the paddock these days. As the team principal of the Force India team and a man full of racing passion, the Indian billionaire is accepted amongst the Formula One community as one of the boys. Well, more or less. The team's having a few teething problems, and it has been known more for the poker games that go on amongst the drivers on the second floor of its three-floor motor home than for its results on the track. That may end this year as it starts life anew with the Mercedes engine.

Books | We'd like to acknowledge this acknowledgment of the odd convention of book "acknowledgment" sections: "It is not entirely clear when a dedicaton-to the Queen of England, say-morphed into a forum for flagging second-grade teachers and expired mentors." Yet now some turn to this page first -- "like reading the weddings in the New York Times Sunday Styles section before hitting the news." After all, the social obsession is similar. "Writers bring me their personal problems," grouses a retired book editor and "reluctant arbiter" of acknowledgment etiquette. "'If I thank Ted I have to thank Alice-but I don't like Alice.' I tell them it's like a wedding. You've got to invite everyone." [American Spectator]

An article on the cover this weekend about Joan Allen, who is appearing on Broadway in “Impressionism,” at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, gives an outdated opening date for the play. A picture caption on Feb. 26 with an article about the slow pace of home sales erroneously included information about a drop in value for the home shown for sale in the Pacific Heights area of San Francisco. It is not known whether the value of the home, relative to its peak value, has dropped 40 percent. The caption also overstated the overall decline in value for homes in Pacific Heights. The homes have dropped 21 percent from their peak — not 40 percent, which, as the article noted, is the drop in value for all homes in the San Francisco metropolitan area.

An article on Tuesday about criticism of a federal advisory panel’s review of an Eli Lilly blood-thinning drug paraphrased incorrectly from comments by a Food and Drug Administration official about Dr. Sanjay Kaul, a prominent cardiologist. The official, Dr. Jane Woodcock, said that errors by agency staff members in handling questions about possible intellectual bias had led to Dr. Kaul’s being asked not to attend a meeting of the review panel. She did not say that those errors had been the reason Dr. Kaul was appointed to the panel, or that she or the agency staff members had concluded that Dr. Kaul was intellectually biased.

A chart last Saturday with an article about the race to succeed Robert M. Morgenthau as Manhattan district attorney referred incompletely to the professional experience of Richard J. Condon, one of the well-connected people who worked for Mr. Morgenthau over the years. While Mr. Condon was indeed the first deputy police commissioner for three years in the 1980s, he was also named commissioner in September 1989, and served for four months.

An article on Thursday about complaints by charities that they are not receiving enough help from the federal government referred incorrectly to the tax rate on which Warren Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, takes deductions for charitable gifts. It is 35 percent — not 17 percent, which is his overall tax rate.

An article on Friday about the increasing use of private inspectors to monitor food manufacturers and their suppliers misidentified the operator of the plant that made Veggie Booty, a snack that was the source of a salmonella outbreak in 2007. It is Keystone Food Products of Easton, Pa. — not Keystone Foods, a different company based in West Conshohocken, Pa.

Favorable rattlesnake weather calls for temperatures in the high 70s, with a gentle southerly breeze to float chaparral kisses deep into the tableland of the Balcones Escarpment. Blessed with such conditions on a weekday in late February, Eric Carl Timaeus loaded an assortment of wood crates, canvas sacks and hooked poles into his pickup truck, where a black rosary swung from the rearview mirror, and set off past miles of caliche pits and Border Patrol checkpoints into the short-grass country. ''I'm on the way that way, thought I'd make sure you didn't have a problem with me going out there today,'' Timaeus, 57, said to a rancher on his cellphone.

As he returned to base here after a day patrolling a place once called the Triangle of Death, Capt. Landgrove T. Smith of the First Battalion, 63rd Armor, summarized the war in Iraq in a way that would once have been unthinkable. ''We're in the endgame now,'' he said.

As a newly sobered art world sizes up this weekend's Armory Show, many are wondering about the fates of smaller fairs with catchier names. What prospects do they have in a crippled economy? A winnowing has already occurred: at least three of last year's Armory-week fairs have opted out of the festivities. Those that remain are trying out some new strategies. Volta, which shares a parent company with the Armory, strives to be seen as its younger, hipper sibling (something like the Art Statements section of solo-artist booths at Art Basel and Art Basel Miami Beach). Pulse, in its most diverse incarnation yet, is banking on globalization. And Scope supplements its accessible, pop-kitschy wares with a packed special-events calendar of music, screenings and parties.

If Mazoltuv Borukhova had planned her husband's death, her lawyer, Stephen P. Scaring, told a Queens jury on Friday, she would have talked to the hit man on a disposable cellphone, not on her own phone. She would not have waited, he said, until after a court order forced her to turn over her daughter to her husband -- the event that prosecutors say supplied the motive. She would have had him gunned down, Mr. Scaring said, on a dark night as he left his dental office, not in a park full of witnesses as he brought the 4-year-old girl to meet her mother.

Johan Santana, forging ahead in his quest to start the April 6 opener in Cincinnati, is poised to throw batting practice Saturday morning -- six days ahead of the schedule mapped out by the Mets' pitching coach, Dan Warthen. The Mets have not said when Santana's first Grapefruit League start will be, but it could come earlier than March 18, the original target. ''It means he's getting ready for opening day, what you been talking about?'' Manager Jerry Manuel said, laughing. ''That's what that means.''

Wall Street ended a week of battering sell-offs on an mildly positive note as stock markets closed mostly higher despite a report showing that unemployment had surged to its highest level in 25 years. Underscoring the sweep of economic declines, the government reported Friday morning that the unemployment rate rose to 8.1 percent in February after the economy lost 651,000 jobs. The job losses were not as stark as revised totals from December and January, and stocks initially surged before pulling back during the day and finally recovering at the close.

President Obama will announce Monday that he is reversing Bush administration limits on federal financing for embryonic stem cell research as part of a pledge to separate science and politics, White House officials said Friday. As a presidential candidate, Mr. Obama spoke out in favor of stem cell research, so his intention to undo the curbs put in place by President George W. Bush is not surprising. But the decision is nonetheless of great interest, involving a long-controversial intersection of science and personal moral beliefs.

Vivien Raynor, who wrote wittily and incisively about contemporary art for The New York Times and other publications, died on Feb. 15 at her home in Manhattan. She was 82. The cause was complications of anemia, said Roy Herndon Smith, a friend.

PASKIN--Charlotte, beloved wife of the late Arthur Paskin, died peacefully on March 6, 2009 at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, NY at the age of 84. She was a dedicated and much admired Nursing Instructor at Suffolk County Community College for 25 years before she retired. She was a graduate of Columbia University and the Bellevue School of Nursing. She is survived by her three daughters, sons-in-law, and their families: Judith Paskin and Dan Flerlage, Max, Sam and Lauren Paskin-Flerlage of Ithaca, NY, Carol and Hal Epstein, Anne and Jeremy Epstein of Washington, DC and Amy and Erem Birkan, Leyla and Rebekah Birkan of Sante Fe, NM and her brother-in-law Peter Allen of New York, NY. Funeral Services will be held on Sunday at 10am at O.B. Davis Funeral Home, 4839 Nesconset Highway, Port Jefferson Station, NY.

Monica Bill Barnes's new ''Another Parade,'' the third offering by the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival, begins rather brilliantly. The tall, gangly Deborah Lohse, whose Carol Burnett-like face holds the constant promise of tragic comedy, strides onstage to the sounds of the Sarabande from Bach's glorious Cello Suite No. 4. She proceeds to ignore the music as she performs subtle little hip and shoulder shimmies, arm swings and strange truncated gestures, occasionally baring a shoulder or her abdomen, while smiling and grimacing with equally mysterious arbitrariness. The solo is a tour de force, mostly because of the way Ms. Lohse -- one of those performers who have only to raise an eyebrow to cause an audience to burst out laughing -- is able to infuse Ms. Barnes's material with an almost magical amount of meaning and power.

MACKEN--Daniel Loos, M.D. Columbia University Medical Center celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Dr. Daniel L. Macken, Assistant Clinical Professor of Medicine and Special Lecturer in the Division of Cardiology. We are grateful for his enduring legacy, representative of distinguished careers in medicine and in the military, and for his thoughtful generosity through the Medica Foundation and its support of the Daniel L. Macken Visiting Lectureship in Cardiology. The entire Columbia community offers its condolences to his children, grandchildren and the extended Macken family. Lee Goldman, M.D., Exec. Vice President Columbia University and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Allan Schwartz, M.D., Chief, Division of Cardiology

Senator John McCain is rewriting the part of presidential loser. Unwilling to vanish into retirement like Bob Dole, or retreat into academia like Al Gore, or even quietly convalesce like John Kerry, Mr. McCain has quickly reclaimed a place on center stage in Washington, some days skewering President Obama and the Democratic Party, and on other days standing by their side.
