It is not known whether the value of the home, relative to its peak value, has dropped 40 percent. The caption also overstated the overall decline in value for homes in Pacific Heights. The homes have dropped 21 percent from their peak -- not 40 percent, which, as the article noted, is the drop in value for all homes in the San Francisco metropolitan area.

When the students of the Conserve School in Wisconsin poured into the auditorium on a blustery morning early this year, they had no inkling of what would follow. Stefan Anderson, the headmaster, told them that the trustees were essentially shutting down the prep school because of the dismal economic climate. Its four-year program would be converted to a single semester of study focused on nature and the environment.

After only five months of breaking the news, the comedian D. L. Hughley's CNN show is concluding at the end of March. ''D. L. Hughley Breaks the News'' was billed as a Saturday night talk show tied to the week's news. It averaged 750,000 viewers and was taped in front of a studio audience in New York. In a statement on Thursday, CNN said Mr. Hughley, above, wanted to be permanently based in California to be closer to his family. ''To accommodate this, we agreed upon a new role where he will be a contributor for the network based in Los Angeles,'' the network said. CNN isn't leaving the comedic news business entirely: its international channels will continue to play hourlong recaps of ''The Daily Show,'' the Comedy Central news satire, each weekend.

To the Editor: ''Justice Not for Sale'' (editorial, March 3) says it extremely well. Not only must ''low politics'' be kept as far away as possible from our courts, but even the appearance of political decisions is unacceptable. This is why for decades the American Bar Association has called for merit selection of judges and argued against the proliferation of multimillion-dollar judicial campaigns.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) FORGETTING SARAH MARSHALL (2008) In this breakup comedy produced by Judd Apatow and directed by Nicholas Stoller, a doughy, underachieving musician (Jason Segel, above with Kristen Bell) encounters his ex-girlfriend (Ms. Bell), the star of a television cop series, with her new rock 'n' roll lover (Russell Brand) at a resort in Hawaii. Good thing the pretty receptionist (Mila Kunis) has a soft spot for losers. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott said that the film's ''overall jollity is streaked with some raw emotions, including jealousy, heartache and humiliation.'' 8 P.M. (CMT) GONE COUNTRY Season 3 ends with the contestants -- including Mickey Dolenz, Justin Guarini, Sheila E., George Clinton and Taylor Dayne -- performing their new songs before an audience of thousands, and a winner is chosen.

The numbers in the jobs report for February were bad, but the trends were worse. More than half of the 4.4 million jobs lost since December 2007, when the recession began, vanished in the last four months. The unemployment rate has also surged to 8.1 percent last month from 7.6 percent in January -- and from 5.0 percent when the recession began. The ranks of the unemployed now total 12.5 million people. It's fortunate, then, that the nation's first line of defense against rising joblessness -- unemployment insurance -- was reinforced in the stimulus law that passed last month. The law increases unemployment benefits by $25 a week and allows states to extend those benefits through the end of the year. It also provides $7 billion to the states to cover more than 500,000 workers -- often part-time, low-wage and female -- who are denied jobless benefits under outdated rules that apply in many states. Those states, of course, must reform their systems to specifically include those workers and to bring their programs more in line with federal guidelines.

Was it something in the air? Was it something in the food? Was it some unspeakable organism lurking evilly on a countertop or skulking under a plate? Whatever it was, it has caused hundreds of people in the past month to report becoming violently sick with projectile vomiting, sudden diarrhea and flulike symptoms after eating at the in Bray, Berkshire. The Fat Duck, which has three Michelin stars and is perhaps Britain's most celebrated restaurant, has closed. The outbreak's cause remains a mystery.

As Britain's government prepares to tighten its grip on another bank, pressure is mounting on lenders that have turned down government help to join the British Treasury's latest effort to revive the economy. The Lloyds Banking Group, created in a government-brokered takeover earlier this year, said Friday that it was negotiating with the Treasury over the terms of an asset protection plan. If Lloyds and the Treasury agree, the scheme would insure £250 billion, or $353 billion, of Lloyds' assets and increase the government's stake in the bank beyond the current 43 percent, the BBC reported Friday.

Tel Aviv Israel closed its embassy in Mauritania on Friday at Mauritania's request, an Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman said. Mauritania, an Arab and Muslim country in northwestern Africa, announced in January that it was freezing its diplomatic relations with Israel and closed its embassy in Tel Aviv. The immediate cause of tension was Israel's military offensive in Gaza. But the military junta that took over Mauritania last summer is also said to have been growing closer to Iran and Libya, countries hostile to Israel, after being refused assistance by the West.
Correction Appended IF you're fortunate to still have your job, but aren't sure how much longer that will be the case, lost income may not be your only worry. Your medical insurance is at risk, too.

kyrgyzstan The Kyrgyz Parliament voted 90 to 1 on Friday to end agreements with 11 allies of the United States who use the Manas Air Base as a refueling and transport hub for the war in Afghanistan. Last month, President Kurmanbek Bakiyev announced that the United States' eight-year lease on the base would end, throwing a wrench in the way of President Obama's plan to increase the American presence in Afghanistan. But Mr. Bakiyev's spokesman said that ''the doors for negotiation with the United States are open, and we are prepared top consider a new agreement.'' Once the government of each country is informed of the decision, it has 180 days to withdraw from the base.
'MODERN [DANCE] MUSICALS'

In an honor nearly as estimable as achieving Alpha-Plus status, the U.C.L.A. Library announced that it has acquired the literary archive of Aldous Huxley, the author of ''Brave New World.'' Among the materials in the collection are manuscripts and working papers for 12 of his books, as well as 35 essays, articles and speeches; recordings of Huxley reading from his lectures and his 1944 novel, ''Time Must Have a Stop''; and love letters he exchanged with his wife, Laura, who died in 2007. The archive also includes personal items like a magnifying glass and wallet used by Huxley, as well as his British passport. Though Huxley was born and raised in England, he lived in California from 1937 until his death in 1963. The U.C.L.A. Library's special collections department is already home to the manuscripts for ''Time Must Have a Stop'' and another Huxley novel, ''The Devils of Loudon.''

One day after the Yankees indicated that Alex Rodriguez would try to play the 2009 season with a torn labrum in his right hip, the tone of their outlook shifted unmistakably toward the more grim possibility of surgery sooner rather than later. After a two-hour conference call Friday night that included Rodriguez, his agent, team officials and doctors, General Manager Brian Cashman said: ''Surgery is something that's going to have to happen. The discussion is: when?''

An article on Thursday about complaints by charities that they are not receiving enough help from the federal government referred incorrectly to the tax rate on which Warren Buffett, the Omaha billionaire, takes deductions for charitable gifts. It is 35 percent -- not 17 percent, which is his overall tax rate.

In January, more than two dozen new police recruits in Columbus, Ohio, were sent notices that they would be laid off, even before they were sworn in as officers. The city had spent $1.4 million to train them, but like cities everywhere, Columbus was running out of money. But a few weeks later, the mayor rescinded the layoffs and told the recruits they would be joining the police force after all.

A court-appointed receiver notified 1,000 employees of the Stanford Financial Group on Friday that their jobs were terminated in an effort to preserve the value of whatever resources were left in the company. The company's assets were frozen last month when the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil fraud complaint against Robert Allen Stanford and two other senior executives.

The United States and a senior United Nations official have called for an independent investigation into the murders of two prominent Kenya human rights activists, shot at close range on Thursday while their car was blocked in heavy traffic in Nairobi, the Kenyan capital. ''The United States is gravely concerned and urges the Kenyan government to launch an immediate, comprehensive and transparent investigation into this crime,'' the American ambassador to Kenya, Michael E. Ranneberger, said in a statement on Friday. It urged the authorities to ''prevent Kenya from becoming a place where human rights defenders can be murdered with impunity.''

KRAM--Harvey. The Board of Directors and the associates of Leviton Manufacturing Company mourn the passing of Harvey Kram, our retired Group Vice President, who contributed to our company for over 45 years. We extend our condolences to his wife Elly, his children and his grandchildren.

Ending a two-month drought in which she apparently had no newsworthy contact with the British legal system, Amy Winehouse appeared on Thursday in a London police station where she was arrested on a charge of having attacked a fan, The Associated Press said. Sherene Flash, a dancer, has said that Ms. Winehouse, the British soul singer, hit her in the eye at a charity ball in Berkeley Square on Sept. 26 when she asked to take a picture of Ms. Winehouse. A police spokesman told The A.P. that Ms. Winehouse had appeared voluntarily at the station, where she was charged with common assault and released. She is scheduled to appear in court on March 17 to answer the charge.

There are drawbacks to putting an art gallery in one's living room, among them having to keep the floors spotless and hide dirty socks. But there are definite benefits, too: no overhead, for one, which comes in handy if the art market, in keeping with most other markets these days, happens to sputter to a halt. In Bushwick, Brooklyn, galleries owned and run by artists have sprouted over the past few years in living rooms as well as in storefronts and factory spaces. Unlike gallery owners in Chelsea or SoHo, many of these artists-slash-gallerists have an extra layer of insulation against the spiraling recession. Most have full-time jobs and said their motive for showing art was just that: to show art.

An article on Wednesday about potential threats to the banking industry in Switzerland misstated, in some editions, the size of commercial bank assets in the United States relative to gross domestic product. It is 70 percent, not 0.7 percent.

The prime minister of Zimbabwe, Morgan Tsvangirai, was hurt and his wife, Susan, was killed Friday in a car crash about 45 miles south of the capital, according to officials of Mr. Tsvangirai's political party, the Movement for Democratic Change. Mr. Tsvangirai was heading to his rural home for a Saturday rally when the crash occurred Friday afternoon. From his hospital bed in Harare afterward, he told one of his aides that a large truck driving on the other side of the road had come toward his Land Cruiser, the middle vehicle in a three-car convoy.

Dr. Randeep Singh Mann, a doctor with a history of disputes with the Arkansas Medical Board, was arrested after a large cache of weapons was found at his home. Dr. Mann is accused of possessing unregistered firearms. Federal agents said city employees of London, Ark., about 75 miles northwest of Little Rock, were working near Dr. Mann's home when they uncovered a plastic bag containing 98 grenades. A search of Dr. Mann's property produced 110 machine guns and grenade launchers. Court papers said Dr. Mann had been questioned in ''a special investigation'' on Feb. 4, the day a car bomb critically wounded the president of the medical board, Dr. Trent P. Pierce, in West Memphis. A spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco Firearms and Explosives, Austin Banks, said Dr. Mann's arrest was unrelated to the attack. The medical board twice suspended Dr. Mann's authority to prescribe narcotics. He has sued the board twice without success, claiming violations of his due process rights.

ZAAGER--Ellis, on March 5, 2009. Beloved husband of Paula; devoted father of Dr. Andrew and Amy Zaager and Dr. Susan Dresdner; adoring grandfather of Nicole, Ilana, Joshua, Justin and Toby; brother of Edith. Services Sunday, 1:00pm at "Schwartz Bros" Queens Blvd and 76 Road, Forest Hills, NY

Geovany Soto went to high school in Puerto Rico, has lived in San Juan most of his life, and will play his next significant game this weekend for Puerto Rico in the World Baseball Classic. As for his first significant game, at age 5, Soto remembers it very clearly. It might have been just below the reservoir. Or maybe down near that ice rink. But it was definitely in Manhattan's Central Park.

James G. Bellows, whose insistence on stylish writing and bold, clean graphics promoted the New Journalism movement while he was the editor of three major newspapers, including The New York Herald Tribune, died Friday. He was 86 and lived in Los Angeles. His death, at an assisted-living facility, was caused by Alzheimer's disease, said his wife, Keven.

The Security Council deadlocked on Friday over taking any action on the tempest that erupted over the indictment of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan on war crimes charges and his subsequent expulsion of 13 aid organizations. Mr. Bashir's supporters, led by Libya and China, insisted that any official statement issued by the Council simultaneously address the potential humanitarian crisis and a possible deferral of the charges, while Western nations blasted the idea of linking the two issues and warned of a potential humanitarian catastrophe that could affect millions.

As government data revealed that 651,000 more jobs disappeared in February, a sense took hold that growing joblessness may reflect a wrenching restructuring of the American economy. The unemployment rate surged to 8.1 percent, from 7.6 percent in January, its highest level in a quarter-century. In key industries -- manufacturing, financial services and retail -- layoffs have accelerated so quickly in recent months as to suggest that many companies are abandoning whole areas of business.

The House Judiciary Committee has hammered out what appears to be a good deal to compel Karl Rove and Harriet Miers to testify about the United States attorneys scandal. Although it makes a few unfortunate concessions, the agreement is strong where it matters -- requiring the two former Bush administration officials to testify under oath about the improper politicization of the Justice Department.

FOOTE--Horton. The Dramatists Guild of America mourns the passing of Horton Foote, a legendary playwright and beloved colleague whose humor, compassion and decency gave voice to the folks of Harrison, Texas, and, in so doing, gave voice to us all. John Weidman, President The Dramatists Guild of America

Amid the worst economic downturn of their careers, the chief executives of the nation's retail chains face a dilemma. Legally, they must tell investors the truth about their abysmal sales and eroding profit margins. But to avoid provoking a panic that would send their companies spiraling into bankruptcy, they must also project confidence and inspire the belief that they can outlast the recession.

A new spacecraft, built to hunt the heavens for other Earth-like planets, roared into space from the Kennedy Space Center on top of a Delta 2 rocket at 10:49 p.m. Friday. The craft, Kepler, named after the German astronomer Johannes Kepler, who discovered the planetary laws of motion, is to spend the next three and a half years in an orbit around the Sun, where it will count planets by looking for the tiny blips in starlight caused by planets eclipsing their suns.

As another dismal jobs report was issued in Washington, President Obama traveled here on Friday to salute the hiring of 25 police recruits whose jobs were saved by the $787 billion recovery plan he signed into law last month. ''For those who still doubt the wisdom of our recovery plan, I ask them to talk to the teachers who are still able to teach our children because we passed this plan,'' Mr. Obama said. ''I ask them to talk to the nurses who are still able to care for our sick, and the firefighters and first responders who are still able to keep our communities safe.''

An article on Tuesday about criticism of a federal advisory panel's review of an Eli Lilly blood-thinning drug paraphrased incorrectly from comments by a Food and Drug Administration official about Dr. Sanjay Kaul, a prominent cardiologist. The official, Dr. Jane Woodcock, said that errors by agency staff members in handling questions about possible intellectual bias had led to Dr. Kaul's being asked not to attend a meeting of the review panel. She did not say that those errors had been the reason Dr. Kaul was appointed to the panel, or that she or the agency staff members had concluded that Dr. Kaul was intellectually biased.

The presence of pop stars present and future paid off for two of Thursday night's most-watched programs: according to Nielsen's estimates, the CBS crime drama ''CSI'' delivered 20.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., benefiting from a guest appearance by the country singer Taylor Swift. But the night's top show was, of course, Fox's ''American Idol,'' which attracted 21.2 million viewers at 8 p.m. Fox led the night over all, though its audience for ''Hell's Kitchen'' (10.6 million) at 9 p.m. was more modest. CBS was in second place, with ''Survivor'' (12 million) at 8 and ''Eleventh Hour'' at 10. NBC ranked third over all with ''The Office'' (8.6 million) at 9, ''30 Rock'' (7.4 million) at 9:30 and ''ER'' (8.8 million) at 10. ABC was fourth with ''Ugly Betty'' at 8 (6.4 million).

AnnTaylor Stores, the retailer of women's business attire, said its fourth-quarter loss widened as consumers pared spending on clothes amid the recession and the company took a $286.6 million write-down. Its net loss expanded to $375.6 million, or $6.66 a share, from $6.67 million, or 11 cents, a year earlier. Revenue plunged 20 percent, to $483.4 million, its third consecutive quarterly decline. Excluding $346 million for the write-down and reorganization costs, the loss was $1.03 a share. Analysts estimated a loss of 59 cents. Shares fell $2.13, or 38.5 percent, to close at $3.41.

Nobody on the United States roster for the World Baseball Classic has played for more major league teams than LaTroy Hawkins. Only one player, Chipper Jones, is older. And nobody else was designated for assignment only seven months ago. Hawkins, 36, has played for seven teams, including the Yankees for four dizzying months at the start of last season. When Minnesota Twins closer Joe Nathan backed out of the tournament Sunday because of a sore shoulder, Hawkins, of all people, got an invitation from the pitching coach Marcel Lachemann.

Tehran Deputy Prosecutor Hassan Hadad said Roxana Saberi, the Iranian-American radio reporter who was arrested more than a month ago, would be released within the next few days, the ISNA news agency reported Friday. ''The investigation has taken place, and she will be released in a few days,'' the agency quoted him as saying. An official said last week that Ms. Saberi, left, had been arrested because she had worked for more than two years in the country without press credentials. Ms. Saberi's father, Reza Saberi, who lives in Fargo, N.D., told NPR on Sunday that she phoned on Feb. 10 to tell him that she had been in detention for 10 days.
DANCE BY ALAN DANIELSON Danspace Project

Hispanics will be heavily represented in the World Baseball Classic, with teams from Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Panama, Puerto Rico and Venezuela. Three of those countries have produced an abundance of big leaguers, with 473 players from the Dominican making it to the majors, along with 232 from Venezuela and 226 from Puerto Rico.
International IN A DISPUTED MIDEAST LAND,

With the recession deepening, the Nets said Friday that next year's season-ticket holders would be able to pay for their tickets in 10 monthly installments, with the Nets picking up the last payment. Season-ticket holders who lose their jobs will have their money refunded, the team said. ''At the end of the day, we know we're a want, not a need,'' said Fred Mangione, the Nets' senior vice president for ticket sales and marketing. He said ticket prices would either stay the same or be cut by as much as 10 percent.

Eddy Curry has lumbered back onto the Knicks' radar, just in time perhaps to salvage his season and complicate the team's playoff push. In a move that caught Coach Mike D'Antoni by surprise, Curry declared himself healthy Friday morning and practiced for the first time in two months. He ran, he scrimmaged and he exhaled in deep, heavy bursts, appearing eager, if out of shape.

Fans wanting to know which Australian pitcher retired the side to start a recent World Baseball Classic tuneup against Japan had to be resourceful to find out. While the Japanese players wore their names on the backs of their uniforms, each member of Team Australia had an advertisement for sports undergarments sewn above his number. The bills must be paid, and in a country where baseball is still taking hold, no opportunity can be spared.

The 50-something Manhattan businesswoman stopped before the steel-plated reinforced box on a showroom floor in Midtown. ''In these times, I feel I need something in my home,'' she said. The price tag was $4,000, but she liked the color, Chinese red. ''If you can afford it, it's nice to walk into your house and see something that's not dull steel and gray,'' she said. ''It's gorgeous. It's a beautiful piece.''

The third baseman with a right hip problem decided to play through the pain. After all, there was an American League East title to chase. Surgery could come later. Even when a magnetic resonance imaging scan revealed a torn labrum, the third baseman said he wanted to keep going. If that sounds familiar outside the Yankees' universe, where Alex Rodriguez's hip has become a black hole for attention, it is with good reason. The same situation played out last season in the Boston Red Sox' parallel universe with their own gimpy third baseman, Mike Lowell.
A Spare Times entry on Friday about ''Making Brooklyn Bloom,'' a gardening workshop at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, misstated the day of the event. It is today from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. -- not Sunday.

Chris Pieper began looking for an academic job in sociology about six months ago, sending off about two dozen application packets. The results so far? Two telephone interviews, and no employment offers. ''About half of all the rejection letters I've received mentioned the poor economy as contributing to their decision,'' said Mr. Pieper, 34, who is getting his doctorate from the University of Texas, Austin. ''Some simply canceled the search because they found the funding for the position didn't come through. Others changed their tenure-track jobs to adjunct or instructor positions.''

An article on Friday about the increasing use of private inspectors to monitor food manufacturers and their suppliers misidentified the operator of the plant that made Veggie Booty, a snack that was the source of a salmonella outbreak in 2007. It is Keystone Food Products of Easton, Pa. -- not Keystone Foods, a different company based in West Conshohocken, Pa.

With an array of real estate crimes, ranging from deed forgery to mortgage fraud schemes, adding to foreclosure rates in Brooklyn neighborhoods, the borough's district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, says the time has come for a specialized unit to investigate and prosecute them. The need for such an office has been building, Mr. Hynes said, announcing the new unit on Friday. As foreclosure rates have sharply risen in central Brooklyn neighborhoods like Bedford-Stuyvesant, Mr. Hynes's office, with limited resources, has been forced to turn down real estate investigations, and instead has referred victims to civil court or relied on federal prosecutors, who generally concentrate on larger schemes.

A federal appeals court panel in Atlanta upheld the bribery conviction of former Gov. Don Siegelman of Alabama on Friday, giving new weight to a prosecution that Democrats have contended was an example of political use of the courts during the Bush administration. The three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit was unanimous in ruling that there was enough evidence to convict Mr. Siegelman of bribery for having appointed a campaign contributor to a state hospital licensing board, rejecting his arguments that the testimony of an aide who turned against him was not enough. The judges rejected prosecutors' contentions, however, that Mr. Siegelman had participated in a ''broader self-dealing scheme.''

Twelve of the interrogation videotapes destroyed by the Central Intelligence Agency in 2005 depicted harsh interrogation methods on two Qaeda suspects, according to court documents. The documents reveal for the first time how many of the 92 videotapes, from a secret C.I.A. facility in Thailand, documented aggressive questioning of the two suspects, Abu Zubaydah and Abd al-Rahim al-Nashiri. The documents, heavily edited sections of a 2004 review by the C.I.A. inspector general, were submitted as part of a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit brought by the American Civil Liberties Union. A separate document made public Friday revealed that 90 of the 92 destroyed tapes depicted Mr. Zubaydah's detention and interrogation, and two showed Mr. Nashiri.
I'm the, as I said, loyal opposition. And both words, I think, are operative. SENATOR JOHN MCCAIN, Republican of Arizona. [A1]

After the International Criminal Court this week ordered his arrest on war crimes, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, Sudan's ever-ruthless leader, ordered the expulsion of 13 international aid groups that keep millions of impoverished Sudanese alive with food and medical care. If Mr. Bashir does not reverse the expulsion, it should be considered added proof of his guilt. It is the first time the 7-year-old court has sought to arrest a sitting head of state. The warrant -- for war crimes and crimes against humanity -- is undeniably deserved. The judges said that Sudan's president played an ''essential role'' in the murder, rape, torture and displacement of large numbers of civilians in Darfur.

The Swiss drug giant Roche raised the price of its hostile offer to buy out the biotechnology company Genentech on Friday to $93 a share, from $86.50. Analysts said the new price was likely to entice many more Genentech shareholders to tender their shares. Roche also extended its offer to shareholders by a week, until March 20. Genentech has already urged its shareholders to reject the $86.50-a-share bid, saying Genentech is worth $112 a share.

Doris Cole Abrahams, a theatrical producer who helped bring Peter Shaffer's ''Equus'' and Tom Stoppard's ''Travesties'' to Broadway, died on Feb. 17 in Manhattan, where she lived. She was 88. The cause was heart failure, her daughter Carole Abrahams said.

The minute the two get together in the room, we know where this is going. Or not. ''You've got quite a rap sheet for a best-selling author,'' Detective Kate Beckett says, slapping a thick file on the table. She mentions dropped charges for disorderly conduct and resisting arrest. Richard Castle, the author, fires back: ''What can I say? The mayor's a fan. But if it makes you feel any better, I'd be happy to let you spank me.''

Robin Williams, right, has halted the tour of his one-man comedy show, ''Weapons of Self-Destruction,'' to undergo heart surgery, Reuters reported. The 80-city tour was to have included performances on Broadway at the Neil Simon Theater on April 23 through 25, April 28 and 29, and May 1 to 3. Earlier in the week Mr. Williams postponed four performances in Florida, saying that he was experiencing shortness of breath. Representatives of Mr. Williams said in a statement that he would have surgery for an aortic valve replacement, and that the tour was expected to resume in the fall. The statement said that purchased tickets would be honored for the new performance dates or ticketholders could contact their place of purchase for refunds. No new Broadway dates were announced.

An article on the cover this weekend about Joan Allen, who is appearing on Broadway in ''Impressionism,'' at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, gives an outdated opening date for the play. After the section went to press, the opening was changed to March 24; the play is not opening on Thursday. A theater listing on Friday in the Weekend section also included the outdated date.

The last time most of us saw all four principal members of the ''Seinfeld'' cast together, they were sharing a jail cell in that sitcom's self-referential, un-sponge-worthy 1998 finale. A decade later, Jerry Seinfeld, Jason Alexander, Michael Richards and Julia Louis-Dreyfus will be reunited in the slightly less oppressive environs of ''Curb Your Enthusiasm,'' the HBO comedy that stars the ''Seinfeld'' co-creator Larry David, The Associated Press reported. A representative of HBO said the ''Seinfeld'' stars would be part of a multiepisode story line in the coming season of ''Curb Your Enthusiasm.'' The new season, which will consist of 10 episodes, is to start in the fall.

Lawyers for the Obama administration struggled on Friday to persuade a federal judge here to throw out an unusual civil lawsuit against John C. Yoo, the former government lawyer whose memorandums on torture were used by the Bush administration to justify sweeping policies on detention and interrogation. Despite their efforts, the judge did not seem inclined to dismiss the lawsuit, which was brought by Jose Padilla, an American citizen who spent more than three years in isolation in a military brig as an enemy combatant.

Two labor unions have pulled out of a broad coalition seeking agreement on major changes in the health care system. The action, by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and the Service Employees International Union, shows the seeds of discord behind the optimistic talk at a White House conference on health care this week.

They worried what their friends would say. They dialed up former bosses to seek approval. And they debated it with skeptical spouses -- even with fretful parents. Recruited by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's re-election campaign, some of the nation's top Democratic strategists are finding that even in an era of supposedly postpartisan city politics, a decision to cross party lines can be wrenching.

A move by Gov. David A. Paterson to increase the free allowances for carbon-dioxide emissions that New York gives power plants is unlikely to undermine efforts by nine other states that signed a landmark pact to reduce global warming, officials said on Friday. Last fall, 10 states from Maryland to Maine agreed to cap the emissions from hundreds of power plants and to make them pay for polluting. Under this carbon-trading pact, known as the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, each state issues its own tradable permits, or allowances, for each ton of carbon-dioxide pollution.

FOOTE--Horton. The Lincoln Center Theater Board, Artists and staff are deeply saddened by the death of beloved Horton Foote, whose Dividing The Estate we had the honor of producing earlier this season in association with Primary Stages at the Booth Theater to widespread praise and audience delight. Horton's prodigious body of work in theater, film and television assure him of his honored place in the pantheon of American dramatists. We send our love to Hallie, and the members of his family and to all of us bereaved by the loss of a dearly loved playwright. John Beinecke, Chairman Andre Bishop, Artistic Director Bernard Gersten, Executive Producer

Two hours after the game, Jon Brockman, the endearing engine of an unlikely champion, was among the few still in the arena, as usual. He had yet to take his ritual ice bath because two preschool boys still wanted his autograph, which they received with high-fives. Brockman's University of Washington basketball team had just come from behind to beat Arizona, clinching at least a share of the Pacific-10 Conference championship with U.C.L.A. The height-challenged Huskies, ranked 16th, are not known for their defense or outside shooting. But if they beat Washington State on Saturday, they will win the Pac-10 title outright for the first time since 1953.

PRESIDENT Obama has laid out an ambitious agenda for dealing with our energy needs and climate change: he proposes to double the supply of renewable energy within three years, establish a cap-and-trade program to reduce carbon emissions and use federal stimulus dollars to help homes, businesses and governments use energy more efficiently. This is the right blueprint for increasing the number of green jobs, encouraging economic growth, ensuring that the United States has the energy it needs at reasonable prices, and reducing the risk of global climate change.

The United States and Russia tried to mend their frayed relationship by having their top diplomats sit down to dinner here on Friday. Before the appetizer was served, the diplomatic first date had gotten off to an awkward start because of a gag gift gone awry. Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, in greeting Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, presented him with a red plastic button emblazoned with the English word ''reset'' and the Russian word ''peregruzka.''

What would Mohandas K. Gandhi have thought of Vijay Mallya? Mr. Mallya, an airline and liquor tycoon, bought Gandhi's personal effects in a controversial New York auction on Thursday. He said Friday that he planned to give the items to the government of India.

Alvin Klein, a longtime theater reviewer for the Sunday regional sections of The New York Times and for WNYC radio, died on Feb. 28 at his home in the East Village section of Manhattan. He was 73. The cause was a heart attack, said his son, Gideon, of Las Vegas.
Fans of South Korea watched their team build on a six-run first inning in a 9-0 rout of Taiwan on Friday at Tokyo Dome in the World Baseball Classic. South Korea will face Japan on Saturday.

The N.C.A.A. has ruled that Florida State was guilty of major violations in a widespread academic fraud case uncovered in 2007. It announced Friday that it would strip scholarships from 10 Seminole teams and force them to vacate all of the victories in 2006 and 2007 in which the implicated athletes participated. In addition, the college was placed on probation for four years.
Eric Timaeus has dominated the Sweetwater Jaycees Rattlesnake Round-Up, a competition held each March in West Texas. nytimes.com/sports

HOROWITZ--Jodi Fisher, loving mother of Elizabeth, Jared and Tate, beloved wife of Paul, devoted daughter of Joy Fisher and Jerome and Anne Fisher, sister of Jeffrey and Marc Fisher and a caring aunt and friend passed away after a courageous battle with leukemia on March 4, 2009. Jodi's kindness, selflessness and dedication to her family and friends made her a remarkable woman who brought laughter and life to those who surrounded her. She was a graduate of Boston University's School of Communication. As Vice President of Public Relations and Media Planning for Nine West Group and later Jones Apparel Group for 15 years, Jodi left a legacy of greatness that serves as an inspiration to all. Her compassion for others allowed her to contribute immensely to the world around her. Jodi was honored by the footwear industry as the founder of Shoes on Sale, one of the leading breast cancer events in the country, which has raised over $30 million dollars for breast cancer research and educational programs. But Jodi's greatest passion was her role as a mother. She loved her children and her enthusiasm for their pursuits in life made her their greatest advocate. Her accomplishments are abundant, but above all the unique and special relationships Jodi forged with her children, family and close friends will be forever missed. Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth El in Stamford, CT at 1 pm on Sunday March 8, 2009. The family will be sitting Shiva on Sunday and Monday from 6-9pm at 96 Indian Head Road, Riverside CT. Contributions can be made to Jodi Horowitz Leukemia Research Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY 10065.

South Korea lashed out Friday at a warning from North Korea that appeared to threaten civilian planes traveling through the region. While hectoring comments are routinely made by the North, often in inflammatory language, the threat caused enough uncertainty that three airlines announced that they were rerouting some flights. Singapore Airlines said Friday that it would reroute flights passing through the North's airspace. On Thursday, South Korea's two principal airlines, Korean Air and Asiana Airlines, said that they would adjust the routes of some flights approaching South Korea from the east.

Until a stranger without an appointment showed up one day in late 2001, Stephen L. Ranzini was feeling rather pleased with himself. University Bank here, which he led as president, had just won a national award for community service. The honor attested to Mr. Ranzini's success in working with local black ministers and a nonprofit agency to increase home-ownership in African-American neighborhoods.

Zimbabwe A magistrate in the eastern city of Mutare was arrested late Thursday for ordering the release of Roy Bennett, the treasurer of the Movement for Democratic Change, who is being held on terrorism charges there, according to Mr. Bennett's lawyers. The magistrate had ordered Mr. Bennett's release in response to a High Court ruling approving his bail on Tuesday. The magistrate's orders were not followed by jailers, and Mr. Bennett remains locked up. ''It's an effort to intimidate the people who are presiding in the case,'' said one of the lawyers, Trust Maanda. The government has appealed the High Court's ruling, which will keep Mr. Bennett in jail at least until the Supreme Court considers the bail request.

In March 1929, unaware that the start of the Great Depression was just months away, the Massachusetts Horticultural Society staged a flower show for its centennial with lavish abandon. ''A desert garden valued at $25,000 has been brought all the way from California,'' a New York Times correspondent marveled, noting waterfalls, forests, houses with backyards and a rambling tropical garden. ''Remarkable acacia trees reach from floor to ceiling across one of the wide walls of the Great Hall. It really is magnificent.''

Boulders the size of compact cars are carved out here at a vast quarry near Bethlehem and pushed noisily through grinders, producing gravel and sand that go into apartment buildings in this rapidly growing Israeli settlement and all across Israel itself. The land of the West Bank is, of course, disputed. Israel occupies it, and the Palestinians want it for a future state. But more and more of it is gone -- quarried by Israeli companies and sold for building materials, a practice that is the focus of a new legal challenge.

Representative John B. Larson embarked again this week on his lonely quest to enact a national tax on carbon dioxide emissions. His idea is to set a modest price on a ton of emissions, gradually increasing it each year until the desired reduction in heat-trapping-gas pollution is achieved. Under the bill he introduced this week, virtually all the revenues from the tax would be returned to the public in lower payroll taxes.

Redcorp Ventures, a Canadian gold-and-silver mining company, filed for bankruptcy in the United States and Canada, citing cost overruns and a lack of financing. It listed assets of as much as $100 million and debt of as much as $500 million in Chapter 15 papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Seattle. Redcorp has already sought protection in Canada.

The Broadway play ''Impressionism'' has postponed its official opening by 12 days, its publicists said. The play, which stars Jeremy Irons (in his first Broadway role since ''The Real Thing'') and Joan Allen (in her first since ''The Heidi Chronicles''), is now scheduled to open at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on March 24; it had been scheduled to open on March 12, and has been in previews since Feb. 28. Written by Michael Jacobs and directed by Jack O'Brien, the play has not been in a workshop or a performance elsewhere. In a statement, Bill Haber, a producer of the show, said, ''We did not give Jack O'Brien and our extraordinary creative team and company enough time to fully prepare Michael Jacobs's new play for Broadway.'' A preview performance scheduled for Monday has been canceled to permit more time for rehearsals.

FILNER--Barbara, 67, past President, Association for Women in Science, and Senior Program Officer, Howard Hughes Medical Institute, died of cancer February 24 at home in Bethesda, MD. Dr. Filner earned her Ph.D. in biology at Brandeis in 1968. She was a vigorous advocate for women in science and loving wife of Dr. Harry Rosenberg.

KEENAN--Terrance. The Board, staff, grantees and friends of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation mourn the passing and celebrate the life of legendary grantmaker and our revered colleague, Terrance Keenan. For 50 years, first with the Ford Foundation, the Commonwealth Fund and then with the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, where in 1972 he was in the vanguard of a new venture and a new staff, Terry set the standard for creativity, caring and vision in philanthropy. What made Terry so special is that he never lost sight of the people we are trying to help. His modus operandi was to always remember that the Foundation represents a public trust; to recognize the primacy of new ideas and innovation; and to demand of himself and others the highest standards of ethics and excellence. Born in Philadelphia in 1923 to Peter and Marie Keenan, Terry Keenan was raised in Bucks County, Pennsylvania. He graduated from New Hope Solebury High School and summa cum laude from Yale University, where he was a member of Phi Beta Kappa, after service in the Pacific as a Navy flight navigator during World War II. Upon graduating from Yale, the brilliantly eclectic Terry taught English, Spanish, French, history and art appreciation at Jefferson prep school in St. Louis, Missouri. In 1955, he moved to New York City to work at Merrill Lynch on a biography of the firm's founder, Charles Merrill. His long and distinguished career in philanthropy began the next year, when he joined the Ford Foundation to direct its Office of Reports. In 1965, he became board secretary for the Commonwealth Fund in New York, where he served as the right hand man to Fund president Quigg Newton. In 1972, Terry became Vice-President of the newly established Robert Wood Johnson Foundation (RWJF), then the second largest philanthropy in the U.S. and the largest focusing on health issues. Terry Keenan created many of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation's most enduring and exemplary programs during his 30-year career with us. Considered the Indiana Jones of health philanthropy, Terry ventured to remote rural outposts and blighted urban neighborhoods to bring health care to communities deeply in need. In his first portfolio of what eventually became 940-plus grants at RWJF was a program to train rural nurse practitioners, a network of rural clinics, and a summer study program to prepare minority students to enter the health professions. He always had an endless string of inventive ideas that he effectively championed and led by marvelous, inspiring exampleHis idea to develop a network of foundations to share information and build connections among health philanthropies became Grantmakers in Health, which now brings together more than 300 foundations focused on health. A Keenan-inspired program to improve health care in small communities became, in 1987, the Local Initiatives Funding Partners program to encourage local foundations to support health philanthropy in their communities. One of the U.S.' greatest champions of nursing and nurses, Terry initiated programs to create specialized clinical training for nurses; to restructure hospital-based nursing care; to create clinics led by nurse practitioners; to expand the role of nurses in emergency care in rural areas; to promote the use of school-based clinics, led by nurses, to improve care for students and their families; and to train and promote nurses for executive-level leadership roles in health organizations. A small project in Elmira, New York to see if nurse home visits to economically disadvantaged mothers of newborns could help improve the life outcomes of both children and mothers became the national, thriving Nurse-Family Partnership. A man of great but quiet faith, Terry Keenan pioneered the creation of partnerships between local health and faith-based organizations to improve and expand volunteer care-giving for chronically ill patients, an idea that became the Faith in Action program. Terry's philosophy of what makes a great philanthropy is found in his 1992 monograph, The Promise at Hand: "A great foundation" he wrote, "is informed and animated by moral purpose," "walks humbly," "is deliberate," "accountable," and "self-renewing." Such attributes aptly describe Terry Keenan, a great and humble man, as well. Terry is survived by his loving wife of 30 years, Joette Lehan Keenan, by his sister, Sheila Keeler and her husband, Philip, by his sister-in-law Barbara Rogers, and many nieces and nephews. Relatives and friends are invited to Terry's graveside service on Saturday, March 7, at 2pm at St. Martin of Tours Cemetery, New Hope, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Terrance Keenan's name may be made to the Make-A-Wish Foundation, One Valley Square, 512 Township Line Rd., Suite 133, Blue Bell, PA 19422. www.Lifecelebration.com, 1-800-GIVNISH.

Dow Chemical and Rohm & Haas said Friday that they were in discussions about their disputed $15 billion merger, sending shares of both companies sharply higher as investors bet the two sides would work out a deal over the weekend. Shares of Rohm & Haas closed up 18 percent, to $63.80, after the companies disclosed the talks in a news release. Dow's stock rose nearly 10 percent, to $7.11.

Forty years after ''Juice: A Theater Cantata in 3 Installments'' was performed at the Guggenheim Museum, Meredith Monk is back with a new work, or rather a new-old work. In ''Ascension Variations,'' presented at the museum on Thursday night, Ms. Monk, the heralded composer, director, singer, choreographer and filmmaker, follows the spatial structure of ''Juice.'' Or, as she explained in a WNYC interview, ''Here's the same bottle, but the liquid's different.'' This poignant site-specific work for 120 performers blends selections from Ms. Monk's recent ''Songs of Ascension'' with elements of the 1969 ''Juice.'' The audience members begin on the ground floor of the Guggenheim's majestic rotunda. From the ramps that swirl above their heads, voices waft throughout the space. Four performers, smashed together to resemble a caterpillar and covered in red from head to toe, slowly plod up the ramp.

Bernard L. Madoff is expected to plead guilty on Thursday to charges that he operated a worldwide $50 billion Ponzi scheme, according to court documents filed late Friday. A ''plea proceeding'' on that date was cited in the filings as part of a proposal by federal prosecutors for allowing Mr. Madoff's victims to be heard in court.
To the Editor: Re ''Warrant Issued for Sudanese Leader Over Darfur War Crimes'' (news article, March 5):

The ''For Sale'' signs are just starting to sprout, but already experts worry that this spring home-buying season will be even grimmer than the last. Despite tentative signs of recovery in hard-hit areas like California and Florida, the broader housing market is far from reaching bottom, economists say. Across much of the nation, prices are likely to keep falling into 2010.

At one point last month, LeBron James dazzled the Madison Square Garden crowd for 52 points in a victory against the Knicks. His encore for the Cleveland Cavaliers, four days later, was a 16-point performance in a loss to the Lakers. More recently, he scored 55 points in a win over the Milwaukee Bucks, then 20 in a victory against the Detroit Pistons. In some games, a basketball player seems incapable of making a wrong move. The decisions are quick and decisive. In others, he is errant and ineffectual.

BONETTI--Barbara. A Bronx girl, she was raised in Parkchester, attended Preston High School, 59. She retired from Sherman Sterling. She had a love affair with Manhattan and Neil Diamond. Barbara is survived by her brother Joseph, niece Susan, nephew Joseph, Jr., great-nephew Joseph, III. Barbara made us laugh, she was loved by all and will be missed. Family will receive Sunday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel", Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Mass of Resurrection Monday 11am St. Jean The Baptiste, Lexington Ave. at 76th St. Interment Trinity Mausoleum.

A new spacecraft built to hunt the heavens for Earth-like planets roared into space from the Kennedy Space Center on a Delta II rocket at 10:50 p.m. Friday. The craft, Kepler, named after the German astronomer Johannes Kepler, who discovered the planetary laws of motion, is to spend the next three and a half years in an orbit around the Sun, where it will count planets by looking for the tiny blips in starlight caused by planets' eclipsing their suns. NASA scientists said they would spend the next two months checking out the spacecraft. Kepler is equipped with the largest digital camera ever flown in space.
THINK YOU KNOW The City's Streets?

ROSENFELD--Saundre L.,died March 5, 2009, she was 79. Sister of Gabriel (Louise) Rosenfeld, aunt of Eric (Sally) Rosenfeld, Alison (James) Desmarais and Leslie (Carlyle Wash) Rosenfeld. Funeral Service Monday, 1pm, Temple Beth El, Chappaqua, NY. Burial Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Phelps Hospice, 701 No. Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591 would be appreciated.

Maj. Gen. Tariq Khan, commander of Pakistan's Frontier Corps paramilitary force, got some bad news the other day: The Pakistani Army needed its two helicopters back for a more urgent mission. Trouble was, they were the only two helicopters General Khan had that day -- or any other day -- to combat Al Qaeda and the Taliban in the country's lawless tribal areas. ''If the army needs their assets, we don't get priority,'' General Khan said of the transport and attack aircraft that the army lends him because his forces have none of their own.
To the Editor: Re ''A Promise of Reform in Saudi Arabia'' (editorial, Feb. 26):

The first time Eddie Kunz left a game at Shea Stadium, he began to understand what it meant to be a member of the Mets' bullpen. Pitching against the San Diego Padres on Aug. 6, less than one week removed from Class AA, Kunz, 22, allowed his first major league run before skipping over the first-base line and back to the dugout. He received the same treatment that had rained down on bullpen saboteurs and former All-Stars alike. The boos, peppered with invective, poured out of the stands.

Barack Obama has only been president for six weeks, but there is a surprising amount of ire, anger, even outrage that he hasn't yet solved the problems of the U.S. economy, that he hasn't saved us from the increasingly tragic devastation wrought by the clownish ideas of right-wing conservatives and the many long years of radical Republican misrule. This intense, impatient, often self-righteous, frequently wrongheaded and at times willfully destructive criticism has come in waves, and not just from the right. Mr. Obama is as legitimate a target for criticism as any president. But there is a weird hysterical quality to some of the recent attacks that suggests an underlying fear or barely suppressed rage. It's a quality that seems not just unhelpful but unhealthy.

A chart last Saturday with an article about the race to succeed Robert M. Morgenthau as Manhattan district attorney referred incompletely to the professional experience of Richard J. Condon, one of the well-connected people who worked for Mr. Morgenthau over the years. While Mr. Condon was indeed the first deputy police commissioner for three years in the 1980s, he was also named commissioner in September 1989, and served for four months.
MINDLIN--Michael. Died 5 years ago today. He is greatly missed and remembered with love. F.M.

The singer Chris Brown appeared in a Los Angeles courtroom on Thursday afternoon, hours after he had been charged with two felonies stemming from an altercation with his companion, the pop star Rihanna, The Associated Press reported. Earlier in the day Mr. Brown, left, was charged with assault likely to cause bodily injury and making criminal threats, after a Feb. 8 incident in which he was said to have fought with Rihanna in his car. At that time he was arrested and released on bail. The felony complaint against Mr. Brown stated that he had attacked ''Robyn F.''; Rihanna's full name is Robyn Rihanna Fenty. With lawyers for both performers in court, Mr. Brown answered a few questions from a court commissioner, who ordered him not to harass, threaten or harm anyone, according to The A.P. His arraignment has been postponed until April 6.

JAY--Theodore C.,of Larchmont, NY, died of colon cancer March 5, 2009 at the age of 85. Mr. Jay is survived by his widow, Salomea Kape; his children from his marriage to the late Olga M. Jay, Mark, Jeremy and Leslie Jay, and their spouses; his granddaughter Michelle Jay; and his stepson, John Kape. Also survived by two sisters, Gertrude Lewis and Kaki Levin. Funeral service Sunday, 12 noon at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, Inc. in Larchmont.

WEINBERG--Edith. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of Edith Weinberg, affectionately known as Bunny. Beloved mother of our Director Adam Weinberg, she will be deeply missed. Our most heartfelt condolences go out to her husband Jim and children Jed; Nina, her husband Bruce Doran, and son Danny; and Adam, his wife Lorraine, and children Zoe and Kira; and the entire Weinberg Family. Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Hurst, Co-Chairman Brooke Garber Neidich, Co-Chairman Neil G. Bluhm, President

An armchair psychologist could read volumes into the recital the pianist Evgeny Kissin gave at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night. Half of the program was devoted to music by Prokofiev, an eternal wunderkind whose attempts at maturation were overshadowed by his youthful facility. The other half consisted of works by Chopin, a peerless Romantic whose offerings could be taken for their surface flash, elusive intimations of incalculable depth, or both at once. Beyond its suggestive parallels to a preternaturally gifted, mysterious musician's career, the program featured works well suited to Mr. Kissin's exacting technique and expressive gifts. He revealed an orchestral range of colors and a knack for illuminating character in three arrangements from Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet.''

One of the hottest issues in German politics right now has ''Made in America'' stamped on it. The crisis at General Motors threatens to drag down Opel, a storied German brand that G.M. bought 80 years ago on the eve of the Great Depression. Many in the industry believe Opel has a future only if it can get a temporary helping hand from the German government.

Seven members of a fraternity at New England College in Henniker were arrested this week as part of an investigation into a November fraternity ceremony during which the police say hazing took place. They say the students participated in a ritual that evening, where they were pelted with eggs and coffee grounds, then doused with cold water. They are accused of not reporting the hazing, which is illegal in New Hampshire, as is the hazing itself. The fraternity, Sigma Alpha Beta, has been disbanded. More arrests are expected in connection with another ritual that evening during which the police say pledges were branded.

WAGNER--Rubin, 89. It is with profound sorrow that we announce the passing of Rubin Wagner, for over 66 years the proud husband of the late Sima Wagner, patriarch of our family and mentor to so many. Ruby lived a life devoted to his wife, his children, Harry and Leon, his daughters in law, Myra and Marsha, and his grandchildren Elliot, Lauren, Gabriel and Daniel. For his dedication to his family, to his friends, to those in need; for his jokes, "have you heard my latest?", for his good humor and love of Judaism and Israel, and for the respect with which he treated his fellow man, rich or poor, Ruby was widely loved by the countless people whose lives he had touched. Born Ruvke Wajner (pronounced Viner) in Vilna, Lithuania, Ruby was the older son of Aron and Sore Chana, both of whom perished in the Holocaust, and brother of Mendel who disappeared into the Ponary forest. At the outbreak of World War II Soviet Russia invaded Vilna and ceded it to Lithuania. On February 20, 1940 at the age of 20, Ruby eloped with the love of his life, Sima Benosher. In June 1941, Soviet Russia annexed Lithuania and closed Jewish institutions. Sima, Ruby and baby daughter, Sheyna, lived together with his parents in a life of relative comfort where their baby's 'feet never touched the ground' from the constant love and attention she received from her grandparents. A year later the Germans entered Vilna. Ruby cared for his family in the ghetto. He survived the war in concentration camps often working as a barber, a skill he had learned in his mother's thriving beauty salon. Ruby was liberated in 1945 unaware that his daughter had perished or that his wife survived. Sima and Ruby were reunited to begin life again, lived in Heidenheim, Germany among many friends, had their first son, Aron (Harry) and in May 1949 set sail for America. Beginning in a railroad flat apartment at 1958 Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn, Ruby did what he had to do to support his family eventually becoming a barber in a shop in the basement of the famous Hearst Building near Columbus Circle. A few years later he had the opportunity to go into partnership to build one single-family house in what was then the farmland of Huntington, New York. He asked the advice of one of his successful clients who told him, 'the barber chair will be here if it doesn't work out.' Founding Ripley Associates and Forest Green Ruby and his longtime business partner, Victor Cynamon, built many homes, developed much property, at one time becoming a large landowner in Huntington. Moving to Roslyn, New York then Aventura, Florida Ruby was always active in his community whether planning cantorial concerts, doing what was needed at his synagogues, or participating in Holocaust remembrance. Throughout his life Ruby was a proud 'Vilner', to him a very special identity. Vilna was an important center of Jewish life, a center of Jewish learning, a nexus of Yiddishkeit. Ruby was one of the publishers of 'Vilna in Pictures' a highly regarded pictorial history by Lazar Ran, the longtime editor of 'The Daily Forward', a project on which he and his colleagues worked for many years. From his youth an aficionado of soccer, Ruby came to love the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Mets. He loved his weekly poker games, vacations in the Catskills; he loved happy occasions, Chivas, and any food that starts with the letter 'a' (as in 'a shtikkele cake, a drink', etc.). Finally, Ruby deeply loved the country that gave him and his extended family the opportunity to rebuild their lives and flourish from the horrors that they had survived. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, March 8th at 12:00pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY 11797 P: 516-921-5757. Shiva will be held on Sunday through Wednesday: Sunday and Monday at the home of Harry Wagner 23 Tamara Court, Melville, NY 11747 Sunday: all day, Monday: beginning at 6pm, Tuesday at the home of Leon Wagner, 8 Lincoln Woods Purchase, NY 10577, beginning at 6:00pm, Wednesday at the apartment of Elissa and Great Neck Richman 860 United Nations Plaza, #

Burdened by falling gasoline consumption and excess production capacity, ethanol producers appealed to the government on Friday to raise the 10 percent limit on ethanol in most gasoline blends to as high as 15 percent. Ethanol plants are closing across the country and some ethanol producers are declaring bankruptcy. The appeal will require the Obama administration to decide whether to increase federal support for the industry, which has already benefited from an array of subsidies, tax credits and Congressional production mandates.

A brief article on Thursday about tools for blow-drying hair transposed multiple lines of type. The correct version of the article, ''Tools for Hair-Raising Adventures,'' can be found at http://nytimes.com/styles.

KRAM--Harvey, born August 16, 1921 in Bronx, NY, died March 3rd in Boston. Predeceased by parents Abraham and Gertrude Freedman Kram and brother, Leonard, he is survived by wife of 67 years, Elly Kram, children Leonard and Kathy Kram and their respective spouses Nancy Cohen Kram and Peter Yeager, grandchildren Jason Yeager, Nicole Kram Rosen and Brent Kram and spouses Zachary Rosen and Marisol Sewell along with great-grandchildren Bella Kram Rosen and Lisa Gilman Rosen. After graduating M.I.T. in 1942, he served as a Naval Officer during World War II. For most of his career, he worked for Leviton Manufacturing Company. where he rose to Vice President of Operations for more than a decade. A dedicated family man who went out of his way to help others, he was held in high esteem by his inner family circle, his many cousins, peers and lifelong friends but he most adored being "Papa" to his grandkids of all ages. He and wife Elly started the Jason Fund in honor of their grandson to support research to cure diabetes. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Jason Fund, c/o Diabetes Research Institute Foundation, 3440 Hollywood Boulevard, Suite 100, Hollywood, FL 33021-6900 would perpetuate this mission. On Sunday, March 8th, memorial services will be held at 12:30pm in Great Neck, NY, in Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 N. Station Plaza.

The Supreme Court on Friday erased a lower-court ruling on perhaps the most fundamental national security question of all: Does the president have the power to order the indefinite military detention of legal residents of the United States? The court's action, which had been urged by the Obama administration, wiped away one of the Bush administration's greatest victories in the lower courts, a 2008 ruling that expanded the limits of executive authority to combat terrorism by allowing such detentions.

NASA has set Wednesday at 9:20 p.m. Eastern time as the launching date for the space shuttle Discovery. Its mission to the International Space Station had been planned for mid-February, but was delayed because of concerns over a valve that broke during the shuttle Endeavour's mission in November. There were concerns that a piece of valve breaking off at a crucial point during liftoff could prove catastrophic. The valves are used to regulate the flow of hydrogen gas from the main engines to the external fuel tank. Using a new testing method, engineers were able to identify three valves that are free of cracks for the Discovery's flight. In addition, engineers performed calculations and experiments to be confident that even if a piece broke off, it would not cause significant damage.

WEINBERG--Edith (Bunny). The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of our esteemed Founding Member. We express deepest sympathy to her husband James, her children Adam, Jed and Nina and to the entire family. Aubrey L. Glazer, Rabbi Israel Singer, Cantor Karen Goldstick, President Ken Brown, Chairman

A 77-year-old child prodigy with bushy eyebrows and the heart of an adolescent swooning at his first exposure to Rachmaninoff: that describes the sensibility of Michel Legrand, the French jazz pianist and composer and multiple Oscar winner who is playing a rare New York engagement at Birdland, accompanied by a string quartet, harp, bass and drums. This unwieldy mixture of classical, jazz and Hollywood is built around pianism that suggests a steep mountain brook spilling from level to level on an elaborate series of terraces, as Mr. Legrand tosses off stylistic quotes from masters like Oscar Peterson, Bill Evans and especially Erroll Garner. As both a composer and a pianist, Mr. Legrand favors repeated chromatic sequences, piled onto one another until one wonders if the structure can hold all that weight without collapsing.

An ex-convict with a history of committing violent crimes shot himself in the head Friday afternoon in Cleveland as the authorities were about to arrest him for killing his new wife and four of her relatives, including three children, the night before. The man, Davon Crawford, 33, had been the subject of a 20-hour manhunt. He had been released from prison two years ago, and had married on Monday.

What would Karole Armitage have said 30 years ago if told that France would someday name her a Commander of the Order of Arts and Letters? Would her punk or her ballerina side have come out? Wednesday night at the Kitchen she was all smiles and politeness while receiving the insignia from Kareen Rispal, the cultural counselor of the French Embassy. The brief ceremony followed ''Think Punk!,'' an Armitage Gone! Dance performance celebrating the three decades since Ms. Armitage's first New York season. It's been 23 years since Vanity Fair dubbed her the ''punk ballerina''; how those monikers stick.

The 36-board playoff for third place in the Yeh Bros Cup last weekend in the Gold Coast, Queensland, Australia, was between Bridge i Norge (Geir Brekka, Erik Saelensminde, Boye Brogeland, Espen Lindqvist and Odin Svendsen) and U.S.A. Hampson (Geoff Hampson, Curtis Cheek, Joe Grue, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell). The Americans won by 117 international match points to 65. The players combined well on this deal to earn a sizable swing.

In a blow to environmental groups and a boost for ranchers, the Obama administration announced Friday that it would take the gray wolf off the endangered species list in Montana and Idaho, though it left the predator under federal protection in Wyoming. The delisting allows Montana and Idaho to assume complete management of the animal, which will include a hunting season in both states. The move also delists wolves in the western Great Lakes and parts of Oregon, Utah and Washington.

STERN--Jean. The Big Apple Circus marks with great sorrow the loss of our good and generous friend Jean Stern and extends our condolences to Bob and his family. Jean demonstrated in so many ways a love for children, which was always wonderfully evident when she attended our performances. We will miss her under the Big Top. Paul Binder, Founder & Artistic Advisor Michael Christensen, Co-Founder & Creative Dir. Guillaume Dufresnoy, Artistic Director Gary Dunning, Executive Director
To the Editor: Re ''Matters of Principal'' (Op-Ed, March 5):

Gov. David Paterson of New York, whose list of friends in the political world seems to be growing shorter by the week, could soon be forced to cross off another group: the environmental community. Environmentalists -- and for that matter anyone who worries about climate change -- were disturbed to learn on Friday that Mr. Paterson had agreed in a closed-door meeting with energy executives last fall to reopen rules governing New York's participation in a landmark pact to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

FISHER-HOROWITZ--Jodi. The University of Pennsylvania/PENN Medicine mourn the loss of Jodi Fisher-Horowitz. A founder of FFANY Shoes on Sale, Jodi was instrumental in raising millions of dollars for cancer research and treatment at PENN Medicine, where a new professorship in hematology and oncology will bear her name. Her daughter Elizabeth, College '10, and son Jared, College '13, continue a strong Penn legacy established and nurtured by our dear friends Anne and Jerome Fisher, Wharton '53. We extend our condolences to the entire Fisher and Horowitz families, including Jodi's beloved daughter Tate and husband Paul. James S. Riepe, Chair, Board of Trustees Amy Gutmann, President Arthur H. Rubenstein, Exec. V.P. (for the Health System) and Dean, School of Medicine

“Teza,” an Ethiopian film about the ruthless regime of the former dictator Mengistu Haile Mariam, who was in power in Ethiopia from 1974 until 1991, won the Golden Stallion of Yennenga, the top prize at the Fespaco film festival in Burkina Faso, Reuters reported. The film’s Ethiopian-born director, Haile Gerima, currently lives in the United States and his sister Selome Gerima, who also co-produced the film, accepted in his honor at the event, which plays a similar role in Africa to the Academy Awards in the United States. The second-place prize was awarded to the South African film “Nothing But The Truth,” directed by and starring John Kani as a librarian struggling against racism before and after apartheid. The film is based on Mr. Kani’s play of the same name. “Teza,” about a scientist who returns to Ethiopia after studying in Germany in the 1970s, also won best screenplay and a special jury award at the 2008 Venice film festival in September.

Bobby Cannavale (“Mauritius”) and Jackie Hoffman (“Xanadu”) are among those in the eclectic cast the stageFarm has rounded up for “The Gingerbread House,” a new play by Mark Schultz. The drama, which the company’s artistic director Alex Kilgore calls “a dark fairy tale of upward mobility and inverted priorities,” will also star Sarah Paulson, Jason Butler Harner, and Ben Rappaport. Mr. Kilgore directs. Previews begin April 11 at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater in Manhattan. StageFarm’s previous productions include “Spin,” and “Vengeance,” evenings of commissioned short plays, and “U.S. Drag,” by Gina Gionfriddo (“Becky Shaw”) and “Drug Buddy,” by David Folwell. … “Krapp, 39,” the solo show written and performed by Michael Laurence and directed by George Demas, currently running at the Soho Playhouse (sohoplayhouse.com), has been extended through April 5. … Tovah Feldshuh and Harris Yulin are among the scheduled participants in a series of post-show discussions about issues surrounding the Holocaust that will accompany the Actors Company Theater’s upcoming revival of “Incident at Vichy,” by Arthur Miller. The 1964 drama about a group of detainees being held in France during the German occupation is currently in previews and opens March 16. Mr. Miller’s sister, Joan Copeland, will be featured at another discussion. Details are at tactnyc.org. … The Fire Dept. has announced details for its upcoming Salon Series of staged readings of new plays, beginning with “The Minotaur,” by Anna Ziegler. Mario Cantone, Jill Clayburgh, Campbell Scott and Jeremy Webb will appear in the March 27 event at the Players Club in Gramercy Park. The series will continue with “Dividing Ashes” by Chiori Miyagawa on April 24 and “Exposure Time,” by Kim Merrill, on May 29. Details are at thefiredept.org.

On June 30, U2 will play Barcelona, the first stop on a world tour that the Dublin band will take to promote its most recent album “No Line on the Horizon,” Billboard reported. The band will tour Europe through Aug. 22 and then come to North America on Sept. 12 to play Soldier Field in Chicago. The official announcement of tour dates and cities is expected to be posted at the band’s Web site, U2.com, on Monday. … Also coming soon to Chicago: Kings of Leon, Depeche Mode, the Beastie Boys, and the reunited (again) Jane’s Addiction, who will play at this year’s Lollapalooza festival, scheduled for Aug. 7-9 at the Windy City’s Grant Park, Billboard reported. The official announcement of the Lollapalooza lineup is not expected until next month.

“God of Carnage,” by Yasmina Reza, which is currently in previews at Broadway’s Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, was named the year’s best new comedy at the 33rd annual Laurence Olivier Awards in London on Sunday evening. The awards, London’s equivalent to the Tonys, were presented at the Grosvenor House Hotel. “God of Carnage,” in a translation from the French by Christopher Hampton and directed by Matthew Warchus, will open in New York on March 22 in a production starring Jeff Daniels, Hope Davis, James Gandolfini and Marcia Gay Harden. Other Olivier winners included Margaret Tyzack, who won best actress for “The Chalk Garden,” by Enid Bagnold; and Derek Jacobi, who was named best actor for his performance as Malvolio in Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night.” Both plays were productions of the Donmar Warehouse. The night’s biggest winner was the National Theater of Scotland’s production of “Black Watch,” which has had two runs in New York at St. Ann’s Warehouse. The London production at the Barbican picked up Oliviers for Gregory Burke for best new play; John Tiffany for best director; Steven Hoggett for best theater choreographer and Gareth Fry for best sound design.

The artist and filmmaker Steve McQueen is incapable of playing it safe. His recent film, ''Hunger,'' an unforgiving depiction of the hunger strike staged by the imprisoned Bobby Sands of the Irish Republican Army, won the Caméra d'Or for best first feature at Cannes last year. Despite - or because of - his penchant for provocation, he will represent Britain in June at the 2009 Venice Biennale. ''I feel lucky to be asked,'' he says. McQueen is particularly audacious when it comes to his personal style; here he's wearing a spring kilt from his friend Yohji Yamamoto. The two have an artistic collaboration in the works, and McQueen says he appreciates his pal's ability to deconstruct men's-wear clichés. As for the skirt, he doesn't bat an eyelash. ''It's just clothing, isn't it?''

A quick note (quick because I'm on deadline for the column) on several arguments out there:
View Larger Map

Monologue | Aired Friday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: CNN's Dr. Sanjay Gupta turned down the surgeon general job, because he'd have to take a pay cut. Honestly, you have no idea how much money CNN pays him to keep Larry King alive.

Monologue | Aired Friday night on CBS: Hey, you know what it is this weekend? On Sunday, it is daylight saving time, when you are going to lose an hour of sleep, but so what? You pretty much lost everything else.

Monologue | Aired Friday night on NBC: Here's some exciting news. The Obama family is finally getting their dog. They say they're getting a Portuguese water dog. And today, Rush Limbaugh said he hopes the dog fails.

History | According to a declassified memo, Reagan secretly attempted to persuade Gorbachev of the existence of God at their fourth summit meeting in Moscow in 1988. After previous summits, a book excerpt says, "Reagan sometimes speculated to his aides that Gorbachev's use of phrases such as 'God bless' might be an expression of religious faith." And so Reagan's overture may have embodied his hope that Gorbachev was "secretly devout" and "capable of changing the system." [Wall Street Journal]

History | The predecessor of the footwear giants Adidas and Puma not only made the spikes that carried Jesse Owens to triumph at the '36 Berlin Olympics, but also the Nazi version of the bazooka, an article says. And the Hugo Boss textile factory made ball bearings. How fashions change. [Spiegel]

Politics | Running against liberal type and afoul of PETA, the new Obama dispensation in Washington tends to be more of a fur-wearing crowd, an article says -- as the chilly inaugural attested. It has to do with appointees being Chicagoans or black or both; Chicago "has long embraced fur to fight off the biting cold winter wind" and "fur-industry officials say that black consumers are disproportionately big fur buyers." [Wall Street Journal]

An article on the cover this weekend about Joan Allen, who is appearing on Broadway in “Impressionism,” at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, gives an outdated opening date for the play. Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the winter sports roundup in some editions last Sunday about Ted Ligety’s victory in a World Cup giant slalom ski race in Slovenia misstated the number of men’s giant slalom races completed so far this season. It is 7, not 29.

Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in some editions of the college basketball roundup last Sunday carried an incorrect label. Arizona State defeated Washington State, 76-35, in women’s basketball — not men’s. (On the same day, the Washington State men defeated Arizona State in overtime, 51-49.).

An article last Sunday about military consultations between China and the United States in Beijing misstated the title of the Defense Department official who led the American delegation. The official, David Sedney, is the deputy assistant secretary of defense for East Asia. (There is no under secretary of defense for East Asia.).

An article on Feb. 22 about the austerity of Japanese consumers, a legacy of the economic malaise that plagued Japan from the 1990s until the early 2000s, referred incorrectly to a residential area known as Nakano, the home of one frugal Japanese family whose members talked about their lives. It is part of the city of Tokyo, not a suburb. The article also misspelled, in some editions, part of the name of a research group whose economist, Hideo Kumano, said Japan’s economy may once again be entering a prolonged malaise. It is Dai-ichi Life Research Institute (not Dai-chi).

To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column “With Attendance Off, Disney Is Dealing” (Feb. 22): Having just come back from Disney World for the third time since November, I can tell you the decrease in attendance is a myth. On each of my trips, wait times reached 150 minutes on the popular rides with all the “fast passes” gone shortly after the park’s opening. Given the large influx of South Americans I noted, me thinks the mouse is crying “wolf.”.
