Boychick / (boî chik) / n. / A term of endearment, taken from Yiddish, for a young boy or man; a gender-fluid buzzword for the “oy fey!” man-child looks that slinked their way down Europe’s most influential runways, as in, “Bugle-beaded chinos — boychick or tragic?” or, ”Dude, chicks dig boychicks, but the bro clutch is too much.”.

Where are the men? Or, more specifically, where are the American men? As much as I love actors like Johnny Depp, George Clooney and Denzel Washington, these big-time moviestars have been big-time movie stars for at least a decade. They are undeniably great, but where is the next generation of homegrown talent? While there’s been a new wave of leading men from Australia (Russell Crowe, for one) and England has provided Hollywood with an endless stream of dashing aspirants (like Orlando Bloom, Ben Barnes and Robert Pattinson, the matinee idol/vampire of “Twilight”), America (and I’m even including Canada) has fallen short. Except in comedy, where Seth Rogen has emerged as a new kind of sex symbol, American cinema has been curiously lacking in native testosterone.

Exactly 70 years after it was introduced at the 1939 World’s Fair, nylon is making news again. Back then, women cheered the arrival of sheer hosiery. Now it’s the men’s runways that are filled with shiny nylon (and nylonesque) windbreakers. Prada’s hangs off the shoulders with a strap, Patrik Ervell showed a featherweight poncho in gold and cream, and Dior Homme paraded black and gold versions. Nylon has always been used for both fashion and function, with practicality usually gaining the upper hand. During World War II, nylon production shifted from stockings to parachutes and tents, but with the development of low-cost nylon fabrics, the stage was set for a postwar boom. In 1949, Haspel Clothing promoted nylon suits with the slogan “A crisp and new-as-tomorrow look.” Soon after, men were dressing in basics like the Ike jacket, nicknamed for General Eisenhower. When James Dean wore a red windbreaker in “Rebel Without a Cause” (1955), it became a classic. A decade later, the skiwear company Bogner was dressing James Bond for the slopes, but reality soon trumped make-believe with the nylon-coated aluminumized spacesuit worn by John Glenn and the other Mercury astronauts. The ’70s and ’80s were all about high-tech nylon variations like Cordura: these were embraced by sailors like Dennis Conner, whose team won the 1988 America’s Cup in nylon-bonded uniforms. Today nylon shows up in work wear from old pros like Carhartt and Dickies, mountain-climbing outerwear from Northface, Nike’s windbreakers and the unitard developed by Speedo for Michael Phelps. In fact, this garment, together with the gear worn by bike messengers, was the inspiration for Duckie Brown’s show, where nylon leggings were combined with synthetic shorts and crinkly jackets. Seven decades into nylon’s history, it seems that fashion may finally be trumping function.

We’re not just about selling guys stuff. We want to please them, and we’ll do whatever they want within legal limits.” Go to sidmashburn.com.

William S. Burroughs has always had a toehold in popular culture — from David Bowie’s cut-up lyrics to Gus Van Sant’s “Drugstore Cowboy.” Now, 12 years after his death, the well-born heroin addict’s chilly presence is wafting around like the smoke off a spoonful of China White. London recently hosted “Burroughs Live” at the Royal Academy of Arts. This July, in Paris, nakedlunch.org will host events celebrating the 50th anniversary of “Naked Lunch”; come autumn, New York joins in as well. And then there’s Burroughs’s famously dapper macs, three-piece suits and rakish hats, which are back on the runway. The wide trousers at Dries Van Noten, fedoras at Junya Watanabe, suits at Hermès and heavy-framed glasses almost everywhere confirm that his debauched brand of intellectualism is eternally stylish — shotgun and methadone notwithstanding. [?][?][?] ALEX NEEDHAM.

Shepard Fairey is our nation’s pre-eminent poster boy. He created that rousing image of Barack Obama in looming close-up, an American rebel who gives off the revolutionary ardor of Che Guevara while wearing, in place of a slanted beret, a crisp white shirt and tie. The Obama Hope poster, as it is known, says something about the high-art ambitions of its creator, a 39-year-old street artist who is currently having, at the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, his first-ever museum retrospective. Starting this Thursday, you can also find his work emerging from Saks Fifth Avenue stores. New shopping bags and advertisements designed by Fairey’s crew, Studio Number One, wittily riff on the geometric art of Rodchenko and the Russian Constructivists. With their austere ballet of circles and stripes and their striking red-meets-black palette, the new Saks graphics appropriate the visual language of the Bolsheviks to promote an ideology that was definitely not conceived by Karl Marx. As a new slogan exhorts: Dress Up the Sneaker! Some of Fairey’s critics, particularly of the blogging variety, are already crying sellout. Please, comrades, lighten up. As the Russian artists discovered, utopian movements are bound to end in disappointment — but the populist graphics they leave in their wake amount to their own mini-revolution. [?][?][?] DEBORAH SOLOMON.
THE PARADOX OF PLENTY.

Depending on your point of view, Bernd Eichinger’s film “The Baader Meinhof Complex” is either a biopic about domestic terrorism in the early ’70s or a cautionary tale about sartorial decision making. In Germany, the movie has prompted a sober review of the Baader-Meinhof group, which is still cloaked in romantic notions of left-wing radicalism despite the narcissistic dedication to violence, hashish and LSD-laced hedonism displayed by its founder, Andreas Baader, and his girlfriend, Gudrun Ensslin. What began with plans to throw pudding at the American vice president Hubert Humphrey culminated in bombings and hijackings. Eichinger, who also produced the historical films “We Children From Bahnhof Zoo” and “Downfall,” summarizes the era thus: “It was fun. Then it turned into a nightmare.” Even Ulrike Meinhof, the newspaper columnist turned commando, found it increasingly difficult to present any political justification for the group’s slide into mayhem. Still, Baader-Meinhof and its successor, the Red Army Faction, had its fashionable devotees: the group was an unnamed inspiration for Marianne Faithfull’s 1979 hit “Broken English,” and Joe Strummer took to wearing R.A.F. T-shirts. Vanity — and the need for new disguises — contributed to the ringleaders’ undoing: Ensslin was arrested while shopping for clothes after a shop assistant felt a pistol in her blue-gray leather jacket. Baader, always in Ray-Bans, was an uncooperative student of the Palestinian fedayeen, once insisting that his velvet trousers, not green battle dress, were the correct choice for live-ammunition training. Finally, a tip-off about young people cruising in ostentatious cars led police to a garage near Frankfurt in 1972. And what do you know? Baader and two associates showed up driving a purple Porsche. [?][?][?] EDWARD HELMORE.

Olivier Borde recently introduced Garde Robe, a collection reminiscent of the preppy-but-tattered boys in “Lord of the Flies”: snug jackets are paired with voluminous shorts and polos with unruly stripes and large hand-embroidered roosters on the chest. Borde and his business partner, Heath Callender, an American stylist who used to work for J. Crew, set up their atelier in Carpentras, the small Provençal town where Borde grew up. The duo created Garde Robe soon after they were cited for “reinventing the classics of male fashion” at France’s annual young design and photography competition in Hyères. “We decided to take advantage of the buzz,” says Borde, who has always wanted to do men’s wear, despite a stint with the women’s designer Charles Anastase in London. During a visit to Los Angeles, he fell for skating gear and casual American basics, which he reworks with intricate detailing. “We like the clothes to look handmade,” Borde says, “so there’s lots of patchwork with vintage fabrics like old lining silk, and mother-of-pearl buttons that Heath found at an Amish store in Pennsylvania. Right now, Garde Robe is small enough for us to do that.” Don’t count on its staying that way for long. Available at Maria Luisa in Paris. [?][?][?] REBECCA VOIGHT.

“I have no pictures from my childhood,” the artist Samuel Fosso recalled. We were standing in the Jean Marc Patras / Galerie in Paris; surrounding us were large black-and-white photographs of what appeared to be leaders in the American civil rights and African independence movements, heroic symbols of liberation: Martin Luther King Jr. preaching to the crowds at the March on Washington; Malcolm X in profile, his leather fedora tipped rakishly forward; Aimé Césaire, the great poet of negritude and politician from Martinique, wearing a lambskin hat against the winter chill of Paris; a young Nelson Mandela arrayed as a Zulu chieftain.

The artist and filmmaker Steve McQueen is incapable of playing it safe. His recent film, “Hunger,” an unforgiving depiction of the hunger strike staged by the imprisoned Bobby Sands of the Irish Republican Army, won the Caméra d’Or for best first feature at Cannes last year. Despite — or because of — his penchant for provocation, he will represent Britain in June at the 2009 Venice Biennale. “I feel lucky to be asked,” he says. McQueen is particularly audacious when it comes to his personal style; here he’s wearing a spring kilt from his friend Yohji Yamamoto. The two have an artistic collaboration in the works, and McQueen says he appreciates his pal’s ability to deconstruct men’s-wear clichés. As for the skirt, he doesn’t bat an eyelash. “It’s just clothing, isn’t it?” [?][?][?] ALEX HAWGOOD.

ALL BUSINESS.

RIGHT UP TO HIS PREMATURE death in 1955, the photographer George Platt Lynes had a talent for living. For more than a decade, he maintained a triangular love affair with the curator Monroe Wheeler and the writer Glenway Wescott; he later got cozy with his studio assistant and, after he died in World War II, moved in with the assistant’s younger brother. He photographed the major artistic personalities of his day, including Jean Cocteau, Gertrude Stein and Cecil Beaton, and set a standard in the history of male photography, influencing Robert Mapplethorpe, Herb Ritts and Bruce Weber.

Though he died at the age of 43, Martin Kippenberger was called a lifetime’s worth of names: impresario, provocateur, art-world clown, petit-bourgeois dandy . . . not to mention “the most influential artist of postwar Germany,” according to the New York gallery owner Friedrich Petzel.

As the recession increases the pace of industrial closings in the Rust Belt, one Midwestern manufacturer, Cleveland Art, is actually benefiting from the economic downturn. Its furniture is in numerous Ralph Lauren stores, Steven Spielberg has bought some pieces for his home, and the company recently opened a store in Los Angeles. Yet its design studio is in a dilapidated industrial building in Ohio, surrounded by an acre of land covered with rusting machine parts. That’s because the designer Jason Wein and his 10 or so employees make furniture out of scraps salvaged from shuttered factories, of which there is no shortage. The gears, turbines, pipes and panels — typically from the 1860s to the 1920s — are the objects from which they create dressers, seating, tables and lamps.

Having worked as an art director for Flair, Vanity Fair and Vogue, the artist Harri Peccinotti is one of fashion’s most highly decorated hyphenates. No matter. To this day, he is best known for his two sexually charged Pirelli calendars from 1968 and 1969. Infamous for their mix of gritty realness (think models glistening with sweat beads) and high eroticism (he had a fixation with popsicles), the images from both calendars are now together for the first time in “Harri Peccinotti: H. P.,” a new book from Damiani. “I look back on them with affection,” Peccinotti says of the larger-than-life calendars. “I think they were quite honest photographically.” Now in his 70s, Peccinotti is shooting for publications like French Vogue and 10 Magazine, and working on a book on birds. “The feathered kind,” he says. [?][?][?] ALEX HAWGOOD.

At Bernhard Willhelm’s spring show, there was the usual assortment of men’s-wear oddities — things like feather headpieces and Shakespearean culottes. So it’s understandable that the designer’s new, relatively understated line of footwear sneaked by undetected. His leather sandals and moccasins, inspired by peasant shoes and released under the fledgling Together brand, are a collaboration with the Spanish footwear company Camper. These gladiator sandals, available at Opening Ceremony, consist of ropelike laces tethered to tire-rubber soles; the side-buckle moccasins are hand-stitched from a single piece of leather, one of the oldest shoemaking techniques. Willhelm says they’re meant for “anyone who wants to feel the elements — call him Muhammad Jesus.’ [?][?][?] MONICA KHEMSUROV.

Jon Mooallem’s article (Feb. 22) is yet another poignant and frightening reminder of how immensely destructive a force human overpopulation is, especially when that force is multiplied many times over by modern technology and economic policies bent on perpetual growth. Acknowledging these root causes of our many environmental problems for what they are is an essential first step toward remedying them.

In her interview with Deborah Solomon (Questions for, Feb. 22), Dambisa Moyo was right to say that aid to corrupt African governments has missed the mark and that microfinance — which gives individuals the means to start small businesses — fosters more sustainable economic development. But so does building schools, training teachers and opening clinics, all of which are being done at the local level throughout Africa. Halting all aid in five years is not the answer — directing it correctly is. As we move to aid the U.S. economy through the stimulus package, we should not deny the same tools to our African neighbors.

In Robin Marantz Henig’s fascinating article (Feb. 22) I found myself wanting to read that these very intelligent doctors were able to come up with a diagnosis for this poor, brave patient and have it all wrapped up neat and tidy at the end, like a television drama or the Diagnosis column in The Times magazine. I can only imagine the frustration Stiers and others like her experience when it just doesn’t work out that way, and they suffer for years without knowing what they have. I also realized how much I take for granted good health and how thankful I am that we have a system in place that works hard to unlock the mysteries of diseases that are difficult to diagnose.

The On Poetry column on Feb. 22 referred imprecisely to a distinction John Ashbery earned with the publication of a book of his poetry in October. While he is the first living poet to be honored with a volume in the Library of America series, he is not the first living poet to have a collection published by the Library of America. It previously published a collection of poems by Samuel Menashe in its American Poets Project series.

The stock market plummeted again last week in one of its worst performances in months. Another very bleak Labor Department report on Friday morning highlighted the gravity of the economic decline now under way. The unemployment rate shot up to 8.1 percent in February, the highest level in more than 25 years. Since the start of the recession in December 2007, the economy has lost more than 4.4 million jobs.

Look, I wish I had the luxury of just dealing with a modest recession or just dealing with health care or just dealing with energy or just dealing with Iraq or just dealing with Afghanistan. I don't have that luxury, and I don't think the American people do either. PRESIDENT OBAMA. [A1]

There's nothing like a good snowstorm to halt the mad pace of Manhattan. Snow creates a fantasyland for a few hours before turning to slush. The fashion world has yet to come to grips with snow, judging by the fall fashion shows in Milan and Paris last week. But on Fifth Avenue and in the parks, the hooded coat and waterproof boots were stars. Central Park was a sight to behold before the snow was trampled by admirers.

BEERS--Mark H.,54, physician, researcher, teacher, author, editor, and opera critic, of Miami Beach and Fire Island Pines, NY, died February 28, 2009, in Miami Beach of complications from diabetes, following a short illness. Professor of Clinical Medicine at the University of Miami and Editor-in-Chief, Emeritus, of the Merck Manuals of Medicine, he is survived by his partner of 33 years, Stephen K. Urice, whom he married in Montreal in October, 2008; his mother, Linda Beers, of West Palm Beach; and his sister, Jacqueline Herbsman, and her family. Contributions may be made to the Beers Scholarship Fund, which he established at the University of Vermont College of Medicine, 89 Beaumont Ave., Burlington, VT 05405.

GORDON--Michael M. It is with profound sadness that the lawyers and staff of McKee Nelson LLP mourn the loss of our partner, friend and colleague, Michael M. Gordon. A man of great integrity, intelligence, compassion and judgment, Michael was a prominent commercial litigator dedicated to defending the rights of his clients in complex product liability, employment and securities disputes. His body of legal work includes playing a leadership role for more than 30 years in the Agent Orange litigation and representing Exxon Mobil in the New York Harbor oil spill. He was recognized as a leading expert in the developing areas of vicarious liability and federal claims based on the alien torts statute. An integral member of the McKee Nelson family, Michael previously was a partner in King & Spalding and Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. He was a true senior statesman in the legal community, leaving a lasting impression on everyone who had the honor of knowing him. Above all, Michael was devoted to his cherished family. We extend our deepest sympathy and sincere condolences to his wife Linda Lowry Gordon, his daughter Alexandra Lowry Gordon, his son Harrison Lowry Gordon, his parents Gladys Mackin Gordon and Lawrence H. Gordon, his brother Andrew Mackin Gordon and his extended family.

MACKEN--Daniel Loos, M.D. Columbia-Presbyterian cardiologist, founder of Medica Foundation, and decorated army officer, Dr. Daniel L. Macken died peacefully on March 1st at 75. Dr. Macken was preceded in death by his wife, Maritza Hibbard Macken. He is survived by his children Elizabeth Macken and Diana Nemirovsky, two grandchildren, and his brother Connell Macken. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 14th at 1pm at The Church of Saint Vincent Ferrer, 869 Lexington Avenue, New York City. Donations may be directed to either the Columbia University Division of Cardiology or the Neuro-oncology Research Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

DO newlyweds really need expensive wine glasses that, because of fear of breakage, probably will never leave the cupboard? In fact most couples (and their guests as well), would be better served by inexpensive stemware and tumblers by the dozen. There is plenty of well-priced glassware -- clear and colored -- to set stylish tables and stock bars that will serve a crowd.

HAHN--Anne Shriver (Nancy), 80, died peacefully in her home in Haverford, PA on February 18, 2009. She was born October 26, 1928 in Manhattan, NY. She was the youngest of three children born to Alfred and Anne (nee Fowler) Shriver. She graduated from Madeira Boarding School in Virginia where she was Class President. She attended Mt. Holyoke College in Massachusetts. She took two years of accounting at the American Institute of Banking, and studied biometrics and calculus at Cornell Medical School. She became a statistical analyst in the Department of Biometrics at New York Hospital. She was also one of the first women admitted to the officers' training program at Chase Manhattan Bank in NY. In 1954 she wed Stephen Hahn in Paris, France. She was a loving and devoted mother to three children Rob, Anne Elizabeth and Tom. While raising her children she was elected president of the Yorkville Youth Council's Board, a non-profit organization supporting after-school centers in the New York public school system. In addition, Nancy was the Assistant Administrative Director of Diller-Quaile School of Music, NY, and was the Administrative Director and Headmaster's assistant at St. Bernard's School, NY. In 1980 she moved near Philadelphia where she became assistant to the director of Performing Arts program at Bryn Mawr College and later a legal secretary for Crawford and Diamond law offices. At the same time, she created ASH Handwovens, her own line of handwoven fabrics. Later in life, her love of animals led her to become a member of the Board of Directors at Women's SPCA of Pennsylvania. She compiled and edited a pioneering book on the human/companion animal bond, "New Perspectives on out Lives with Companion Animals" published by University of Pennsylvania press. She dedicated her last 15 professional years, into her late 70s, as an event planner for St. David's Church, in Wayne, PA, arranging and coordinating weddings. She spent every summer with her children, grandchildren and extended family at her summer home in the woods of Forestburgh, NY as her family has done since the 1880s. Nancy possessed a keen curiosity which led her to engage in many diverse intellectual endeavors. She was kind and generous not only to her family but also to her many friends. Nancy will be deeply missed. Mrs. Hahn is survived by her three children, Rob, Weston CT, Anne Elizabeth Block, Westlake Village, CA, Tom, Piedmont CA, brother Donald Shriver, Maplewood, NJ and eight grandchildren. She is further survived by nieces, nephews, other relatives and dear friends. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her brother Denton Shriver. A Memorial Service will be held at 2pm on Saturday, March 21, 2009 at St. David's Church (old church) 763 South Valley Forge Rd., Wayne, PA 19087. In lieu of flowers contributions in her name may be made to Merriewold Club Memorial Fund, 2674 Route 42, Forestburgh, NY 12777.

BLOCH--Joseph. The Juilliard School mourns the death of Joseph Bloch, one of the school's most distinguished and revered faculty members, who taught at the School most years from 1948- 1996. AS all the big shoulders and little bags on both the spring and fall runways tell us, the 1980s are alive and well -- and providing endless inspiration for designers who want to get the party started again. Joy Gryson, a former design director for Marc Jacobs handbags and the woman behind the three-year-old accessories line Gryson, mined that decade's pop colors and punk attitude for her new less-expensive handbag line, called Olivia Harris. ''I wanted to do something young and fun and a little gritty,'' she explained of her spring collection, which just arrived in stores. ''It's very Debbie Harry, the Go-Gos, the girl hanging out on the Lower East Side.'' You could imagine all of the above sporting this strappy acid-yellow pouch, which Ms. Gryson has nicknamed the ''bar bag.'' ''You just throw it on and go out dancing,'' she said.

HAVING spent too much time idling in hotel rooms, Christina Kruse, the hauntingly beautiful German model, decided in the mid-'90s to take up a hobby. So she bought a Mamiya camera and became her own guinea pig, dressing up as different characters and posing for herself. Then she began gluing the photos into travel journals (or ''Reisebuchs,'' as she calls them) and creating intricate collages that elegantly combined gouache and newsprint, colored tape and metallic paper. ''They became like a language I had with myself,'' she said. Nowadays, Ms. Kruse has a studio in Brooklyn and a costume closet the size of a small bedroom. Her photos have been published in Vogue, Harper's Bazaar and Interview; and last week, her first solo show in the United States opened at Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea. On view is a range of evocative, often amusing self-portraits and collages, as well as ''Reisebuch 1-5,'' her limited-edition artist's book, painstakingly self-published in Germany. So much for free time. As she noted, ''It took forever to do them.''

WITNESSING A BREAK IN THE CLOUDS IN THE ADIRONDACKS, OCT. 5, 2008 Berenice Tompkins, 12, right, from Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., takes a breather with her father, Aiken Tompkins, 44, and her mother, Kerry-Jane King, 49, atop Mount Van Hoevenberg, just south of Lake Placid, N.Y. ''I've traveled with my mom and her family because my mom is English, and her family goes to a lot of places around Europe. But with both of my parents, we tend to do stuff like camping. We try to go away for weekends as much as we can, and the Adirondacks is the nearest place. It's a great feeling to hike to the top of a mountain. I love the feeling of looking out, and you can see everything. And it's a great thing to do together as a family. Normally, I don't see my parents that much. Whereas, when we hike, I get to see them. Normally, there's other stuff interfering, whereas, when you're hiking -- it's like it's a good opportunity to just talk to them.'' As told to Austin Considine

BERNSTEIN Jay M.D.,an authority on pediatric renal cystic diseases, passed away February 26 following an extended illness. He was 81 and lived in W. Bloomfield, MI since relocating from New York in 1969. Retired in 1998 as director of the Beaumont Research Institute and associate medical director of Beaumont Hospital in Royal Oak, MI, where from 1969-89 he had been chair of the Department of Anatomic Pathology. He was on the editorial boards of over seven journals, and had co-authored over 285 publications on kidney disease. He lectured frequently and held over 20 visiting professorships. He presented over 300 lectures and workshops at professional seminars around the world, and was most proud of his participation in the WHO Committee on Classification and Nomenclature of Renal Diseases and its follow-up review boards. He traveled extensively as a member of several NIH pediatric research review committees. Past chair of the Renal Pathology Society, and past president of the Society for Pediatric Pathology. He was honored with a number of awards and lectureships, including the Founder's Award from the American Society of Pediatric Nephrology in 1999; the Henry L. Barnett Award from the American Academy of Pediatrics in 1997; and the 19th Morita Lecture at Beaumont Hospital in 1996. Graduate of Stuyvesant High School. After service in the Navy, he received a B.A. from Columbia, and an M.D. from SUNY Downstate. Born in Brooklyn, the son of the late Michael and Frances. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Carol, sons John (Abigail) and Michael (Harriette), and two grandsons.

Gordon, loving brother to Andrew Mackin Gordon. A graduate of Vassar College and Columbia Law School, Michael was a prominent commercial litigator and highly respected partner in the law firm McKee Nelson LLP. Over the course of his exceptional career, he also served as a partner in King & Spalding and Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft. A private funeral service will be held; a memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center for Research into Thymic Cancers, P.O. Box 27106, NY, NY 10087-7106. All donations should be directed to the Thoracic Oncology Service. mskcc.org/mskcc/html/20.cfm

CADILLAC RECORDS Darnell Martin's film tells the story of the Chicago-based rhythm-and-blues label Chess Records. Adrien Brody plays Leonard Chess, the label's co-founder; with Mos Def as Chuck Berry, Jeffrey Wright as Muddy Waters and Beyoncé Knowles as Etta James. In December in The New York Times A. O. Scott called the movie a ''rollicking and insightful celebration of Chicago blues in its hectic golden age.'' (Sony, Blu-ray $39.95, standard definition $27.96, R) Happy-Go-Lucky In an acclaimed performance, Sally Hawkins stars as an unstoppably upbeat primary school teacher in Mike Leigh's comedy. ''Nothing and everything happens in 'Happy-Go-Lucky' '', Manohla Dargis said in October in The Times. (Miramax, $29.99, R)

Her memory lives on in all of us at VISIONS. Nancy T. Jones, President Nancy D. Miller, Executive Director/CEO

In her interview with Deborah Solomon (Questions for, Feb. 22), Dambisa Moyo was right to say that aid to corrupt African governments has missed the mark and that microfinance -- which gives individuals the means to start small businesses -- fosters more sustainable economic development. But so does building schools, training teachers and opening clinics, all of which are being done at the local level throughout Africa. Halting all aid in five years is not the answer -- directing it correctly is. As we move to aid the U.S. economy through the stimulus package, we should not deny the same tools to our African neighbors. BARBARA ALISON ROSE Executive Director Aid for Africa Chevy Chase, Md.

LOWEY--Irving S.,resident of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of New York City, passed away on March 4th, 2009. After graduating from City College, NY, Irving worked as an agent for the Internal Revenue Service. As a Certified Public Accountant he formed and served as principal of his own companies, Irving S. Lowey & Co. as well as Eclipse Energy. He also served terms as president of the East Midwood B'nai Brith Chapter, was honored by the Anti-Defamation League, and was the former President and Treasurer of Boca Greens Country Club. He remained actively engaged in his work until the time of his passing. He loved life and lived every moment. Predeceased by his beloved wife Jayne F. Lowey, he is survived by his sister, Lillian Kirschenberg, daughters Robin Lowey, Marilyn Lowey, Amy Horowitz and Debra Wallinger, grandchildren Matthew, Evan, Jake, Joshua, Hannah and Sam, niece and nephew Meryl and Bruce Kirschenberg. Services were held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel 11115 Jog Road Boynton Beach, FL 33437 at 11am March 6th, 2009. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10065.

Several months ago, William Stewart, a physical education teacher, found a $100 ticket in his mailbox. The charge? The sidewalk in front of his home on East 168th Street was dirty. That day, Mr. Stewart recalled, he looked at the wrappers and paper bags in front of his house, which, he said, had been blown there by the wind. Then he looked across the street: Outside an abandoned house, junk was piled high, including broken furniture, cardboard boxes, pieces of wood, a pair of blue jeans.

THANKS to Marc Jacobs, mom is having the last laugh. Her jeans -- those high-waist, generously pleated denim trousers that have been the saggy brunt of so many jokes, including a ''Saturday Night Live'' skit with the tag line: ''I'm not a woman anymore. I'm a mom'' -- just showed up on Mr. Jacobs's fall runway, looking surprisingly cool. Cut with skinny legs and paired with a metallic peplum jacket, these are not Saturdays at Stop & Shop pants. Rather, they hint of Champagne-fueled nights on the disco floor and, in fact, do not look all that different from the slightly slouchy, peg-legged trousers chic women have been wearing since last season. Come next fall, it could be the new jeans style.

SPANG--Thomas J.G.,avid outdoorsman, died at home in Manchester-by-the-Sea, MA on February 28, 2009. Born in Chicago on January 31, 1929, he and his family moved to Massachusetts in 1938. Tom attended Dexter School and Milton Academy ('47) where he later co-founded the Korean War Memorial Scholarship, given to a student from a developing country, in memory of his classmates who lost their lives. Summers, Tom attended Camp Wabun in Canada, where he discovered his lifelong love: the great outdoors. After Harvard ('51) he took a post at General Motors before moving to France to work for the Paris Review. From there, he hitchhiked around the world as a stringer for the Boston Globe. Tom then took a position at the Gillette Company in London, where he met his wife Caroline, and later with Morgan Guaranty Trust in New York City, which sent him to Madrid. After three years, he returned to New York with his wife, two daughters and 50 cases of wine. They moved to Manchester in 1968, so Tom could pursue his love of writing between posts in Africa and Central America with United Nations Development Programme. He then founded Gametrails Limited, where he was able to combine his love of writing with his love of adventure, exploring the world for the best wing shooting, fly fishing and local eateries. He spent summers at his camp in Quebec, where he and Caroline taught their three children how to do the J stroke, portage a canoe, and cast a fly. Tom is survived by Caroline, daughters Charlotte and Vanessa, son Thomas, five grandchildren, his brother Joseph Peter Spang III, and his dog Binti. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 28, 2009 at 11:30am at Milton Academy's Apthorp Chapel. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Korean War Memorial Scholarship Fund, Milton Academy, 170 Centre St, Milton, MA 02186 or the Essex County Greenbelt, 82 Eastern Avenue, Essex, MA 01929. Services by Campbell Lee, Moody, Russell Funeral Home, 525 Cabot Street, Beverly. Information, directions, condolences at: www.campbellfuneral.com

ESSEX--Winfield Scott Jr.,known to his friends as "Skip", was the first trader to have seats on both the New York and London Stock Exchanges. He was also a professional white hunter in East Africa, a partner in Hunters Africa and had a coffee farm in Rhodesia, before independence. He died suddenly February 20th at his home in Wellington, FL where he lived with his fiancee, Helene Jackson ("Danny") Magill. He was 66. Mr. Essex was an honorary member of the East African Professional Hunters' Association, an organization in Kenya that governs big game hunting and a partner in Philadelphia Investors in Pennsylvania. He was a member of the Brook Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club, and the Holland Lodge all in New York City and also the Racquet Club and Philadelphia Club in Philadelphia, PA. Mr. Essex was admired for his impeccable dress, gourmet cooking, wit, intelligence, and eye for the fairer sex. Mr. Essex grew up in Columbus, Ohio. He attended Washington and Lee University and received his BA degree from the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. Three children survive him from his first marriage to Brenda Teagle Callaway: Lee Essex Doyle of Boston; Amanda Teagle Essex of New York; and Winfield Scott III of Westport, Conn. He has a fourth son, William David Scott Essex, of Dublin, Ireland, from his second marriage to Victoria Thompson Essex. Survivors also include his brother Richard Essex and his daughters Helena and Isabella of London and five grandchildren: India Lee Doyle, Wyatt Addison Doyle, Hunter Scott Essex, Sydney Essex and Campbell Essex. A toast to Mr. Essex will be held at the Brook Club in New York City on April 16th at 6 pm. His ashes will be scattered over the plains of his beloved Botswana by his family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust, PO Box 15555, Nairobi, Kenya.

DOMESTIC DISTURBANCES In the past I sensed a certain sadness, even feelings of betrayal, in the reactions from my husband, Max, to my proselytizing about my Pema Chödrön ''Getting Unstuck'' CD: ''I never thought that you, of all people, would get into that New Age stuff,'' he'd said wistfully. I hadn't realized that when a person gets unstuck the people around her can feel left behind. It has dawned on me lately, meditating on the Metro, thoughts silenced so completely that I can hear every page being turned by passengers up and down the car that being fully in the moment, all senses turned on, feeling your hands in your lap and the ground under your feet, is a very good way of not being there at all.

ANN DEMEULEMEESTER, the dark poetess of Belgian fashion, doesn't do a lot of color. So it came as a surprise when halfway through her spring collection, shades of burnt orange and coral burst through her black and white palette. As she explained, it was a spiritual thing. Reading ''Siddhartha'' had made her crave the colors. Or, there was simply something in the air, as a slew of fashion houses including Chloé, Christopher Kane, Dries Van Noten, Louis Vuitton, Christian Dior and Nina Ricci all showed orange to great effect in their spring collections. Lanvin's tangerine silk dress is one of its best sellers this season.

There are more street fairs in the square bordered by the Hudson River and the Bowery, from Canal Street to West 14th Street, than in any other place in the city. The area has the highest concentration of civic organizations in the five boroughs, and among the highest number of sidewalk cafes. Sixty percent of the buildings here have landmark status, according to Bob Gormley, district manager at the local community board. The neighborhoods within this square -- SoHo, Greenwich Village, the West Village and Little Italy -- are among the city's most visited and photographed, and their names are virtual synonyms for New York.

MARC ANDRÉ ROBINSON The work of the Brooklyn-based multimedia artist Marc André Robinson is based on the yard-sale adage that one person's trash is another's treasure. Robinson is perhaps best known for his assemblage-style sculptures (like the one at near right) made from other people's property. He created the ''T'' on Page 87 entirely out of chairs -- objects he views as ''a kind of point of orientation, like a Platonic reference.'' Robinson (far right) is an expert garbage picker and has made trolling for trash part of his daily routine. ''The rest are donated to me by friends who think I might be able to squeeze some life out of things that have otherwise sort of run their course.'' Robinson, who is the nephew of the iconic photographer Sam Haskins, was one of the artists included in the New Museum's exhibition ''Unmonumental'' in 2007. A new show of his work goes up this fall at the Steve Turner Contemporary gallery in Los Angeles.

WAGNER--Rubin, 89. It is with profound sorrow that we announce the passing of Rubin Wagner, for over 66 years the proud husband of the late Sima Wagner, patriarch of our family and mentor to so many. Ruby lived a life devoted to his wife, his children, Harry and Leon, his daughters in law, Myra and Marsha, and his grandchildren Elliot, Lauren, Gabriel and Daniel. For his dedication to his family, to his friends, to those in need; for his jokes, "have you heard my latest?", for his good humor and love of Judaism and Israel, and for the respect with which he treated his fellow man, rich or poor, Ruby was widely loved by the countless people whose lives he had touched. Born Ruvke Wajner (pronounced Viner) in Vilna, Lithuania, Ruby was the older son of Aron and Sore Chana, both of whom perished in the Holocaust, and brother of Mendel who disappeared into the Ponary forest. At the outbreak of World War II Soviet Russia invaded Vilna and ceded it to Lithuania. On February 20, 1940 at the age of 20, Ruby eloped with the love of his life, Sima Benosher. In June 1941, Soviet Russia annexed Lithuania and closed Jewish institutions. Sima, Ruby and baby daughter, Sheyna, lived together with his parents in a life of relative comfort where their baby's 'feet never touched the ground' from the constant love and attention she received from her grandparents. A year later the Germans entered Vilna. Ruby cared for his family in the ghetto. He survived the war in concentration camps often working as a barber, a skill he had learned in his mother's thriving beauty salon. Ruby was liberated in 1945 unaware that his daughter had perished or that his wife survived. Sima and Ruby were reunited to begin life again, lived in Heidenheim, Germany among many friends, had their first son, Aron (Harry) and in May 1949 set sail for America. Beginning in a railroad flat apartment at 1958 Coney Island Avenue in Brooklyn, Ruby did what he had to do to support his family eventually becoming a barber in a shop in the basement of the famous Hearst Building near Columbus Circle. A few years later he had the opportunity to go into partnership to build one single-family house in what was then the farmland of Huntington, New York. He asked the advice of one of his successful clients who told him, 'the barber chair will be here if it doesn't work out.' Founding Ripley Associates and Forest Green Ruby and his longtime business partner, Victor Cynamon, built many homes, developed much property, at one time becoming a large landowner in Huntington. Moving to Roslyn, New York then Aventura, Florida Ruby was always active in his community whether planning cantorial concerts, doing what was needed at his synagogues, or participating in Holocaust remembrance. Throughout his life Ruby was a proud 'Vilner', to him a very special identity. Vilna was an important center of Jewish life, a center of Jewish learning, a nexus of Yiddishkeit. Ruby was one of the publishers of 'Vilna in Pictures' a highly regarded pictorial history by Lazar Ran, the longtime editor of 'The Daily Forward', a project on which he and his colleagues worked for many years. From his youth an aficionado of soccer, Ruby came to love the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Mets. He loved his weekly poker games, vacations in the Catskills; he loved happy occasions, Chivas, and any food that starts with the letter 'a' (as in 'a shtikkele cake, a drink', etc.). Finally, Ruby deeply loved the country that gave him and his extended family the opportunity to rebuild their lives and flourish from the horrors that they had survived. HOROWITZ--Jodi Fisher, loving mother of Elizabeth, Jared and Tate, beloved wife of Paul, devoted daughter of Joy Fisher and Jerome and Anne Fisher, sister of Jeffrey and Marc Fisher and a caring aunt and friend passed away after a courageous battle with leukemia on March 4, 2009. Jodi's kindness, selflessness and dedication to her family and friends made her a remarkable woman who brought laughter and life to those who surrounded her. She was a graduate of Boston University's School of Communication. As Vice President of Public Relations and Media Planning for Nine West Group and later Jones Apparel Group for 15 years, Jodi left a legacy of greatness that serves as an inspiration to all. Her compassion for others allowed her to contribute immensely to the world around her. Jodi was honored by the footwear industry as the founder of Shoes on Sale, one of the leading breast cancer events in the country, which has raised over $30 million dollars for breast cancer research and educational programs. But Jodi's greatest passion was her role as a mother. She loved her children and her enthusiasm for their pursuits in life made her their greatest advocate. Her accomplishments are abundant, but above all the unique and special relationships Jodi forged with her children, family and close friends will be forever missed. Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth El in Stamford, CT at 1 pm on Sunday March 8, 2009. The family will be sitting Shiva on Sunday and Monday from 6-9pm at 96 Indian Head Road, Riverside CT. Contributions can be made to Jodi Horowitz Leukemia Research Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, New York, NY 10065.

The Room for Debate blog on nytimes.com invited readers last week to comment on sports records that will be hard, and maybe impossible, to break. The responses ranged from baseball and basketball to cricket, from squash to Charlie Brown. HANDS DOWN the greatest record in any sport is the 99.94 lifetime batting average posted by Sir Donald Bradman in cricket from 1928 to 1948. Bradman's record at 4.4 standard deviations above the mean tops Pelé, whose record for goals per game is only 3.7 standard deviations above the mean, Ty Cobb's batting average at 3.6, Jack Nicklaus's major golf titles at 3.5 and Michael Jordan in points per game at 3.4. In order to post a similarly dominant career statistic as Bradman's, a baseball batter would need a career batting average of .392, and a basketball player would need to score an average of 43 points per game. Mike B
Art Carol Vogel

KITCHEN--Robert W.,59, died in his home in New York City on February 28, 2009. Graduate of the Tyler School of Art in Philadelphia, he went on to become a painter and art collector, as well as designer in the home furnishing and jewelry industry. His family and friends miss him dearly. A memorial service will be held at Soka Gakkai International-USA in the near future. Memorial contributions can be made to Friends in Deed.

Gunmen opened fire outside a military barracks Saturday night, killing two men and injuring four others in the first attack of its kind in more than a decade, the police in Northern Ireland said. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the shootings, which took place at Massereene Barracks northwest of Belfast, but suspicion is likely to center on dissident republican groups opposed to the Irish Republican Army's cease-fire.

It was a typical workday on Friday for President Obama -- who went to Columbus, Ohio, to make his case, yet again, for his economic recovery bill -- except that much of the business was conducted at high altitude aboard Air Force One. A retinue of senior White House advisers and aides traveled with the president, who began his day with the morning briefing with his staff. Mr. Obama also spent time during the four-hour trip wooing members of the Ohio Congressional delegation, who flew with him from Washington to Columbus.

Contributions to the Pinelands Preservation Alliance, 17 Pemberton Road, Southampton, NJ 08088.

SYMINGTON--Charles H.,Jr."Charlie" "Soapy" Harrison Symington, Jr., 78, of Spring Island, South Carolina, husband of Bailey Walker Symington, died Wednesday morning, March 4, 2009. Born in Baltimore, Maryland on February 2nd, 1931, he was a son of the late Charles Harrison Symington, Sr. and the late Mary Towers Symington. Before retirement Charlie had been an investment banker in New York City with G.H. Walker; Warburg, Paribas, Becker; and S. G. Warburg. He was a graduate of Deerfield Academy ('49), Williams College ('53), and Harvard Law School ('56). He served on the Board of Governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers. He commuted to Wall Street for many years from Tuxedo Park, New York, and then from Princeton, New Jersey, before moving to New York City. He and his wife, Bailey, have lived in Spring Island, South Carolina for the past ten years. Throughout his adult life, Charlie contributed a unique blend of fiscal conservativism, social justice and laughter to school and civic boards. Tennis, golf and grandchildren kept him quick on his feet. His love of history, baseball and politics served as an extension of his unique way of observing and interacting with the people around him. His humor often won him the friendship of those whose politics and sports allegiances differed from his, even family members. Surviving are his wife, Bailey; his children Gaye Symington and her husband, Chuck Lacy, of Jericho, Vermont; Robin Ramos and her husband, Freddy Ramos, of Los Angeles, California; and Randolph Walker Symington and his wife, Megan King Symington, of Old Greenwich, Connecticut, and five grandchildren, Samuel, Mary and Tom Symington Lacy and Maya Anita and Bailey Rosa Ramos. He was well loved by his extended family of nieces, nephews, in-laws and cousins. A Celebration of Life service will be held in early April in New York City. In lieu of flowers, a gift may be made in his memory to The Spring Island Trust - 40 Mobley Oaks Lane, Okatie, South Carolina 29909.

COHN--J. Gunther March 6, 1911- March 24,2008 Happy Birthday Dad. You were so very devoted, caring, kind, patient and generous with your wife Catherine, daughter Vicki, family and friends. As a scientist, beginning in the 50s, you researched and invented technology, including the catalytic converter to reduce air pollutants. These achievements are still the basis for technology used today, worldwide. Your concern was always for our environment, not fame or fortune. I miss you, every day. Love, Vicki

WHITNEY--Donald Howard of Statesboro, Georgia. Donald Howard Whitney, 99, died on March 3 in Statesboro, Georgia. He was born on April 25, 1909 in New York City. He attended Horace Mann School at 120th St. and Broadway and the Horace Mann Boys School in Riverdale, NY, graduating in 1926. He graduated from Princeton University, cum laude in Economics, in 1930. He attended the training school and worked at Chase Securities/Chase Harris Forbes. In 1932, the Glass-Steagall Act prohibited banks from having securities affiliates thus ending Chase Harris Forbes. For the next ten years he worked for Phelps Fenn & Co., a leading house in the municipal bond business. After volunteering and being rated 4F, he was Chief Price Economist for the State of New Jersey. He later joined the Todd Shipyards in Brooklyn NY where he became Director of Training. He married Phoebe Jane Strickland of Stilson, Georgia in 1942. In June 1945, he joined Commercial Union Insurance Group in New York where he worked for 29 years and became Chief Financial Officer. After retiring from Commercial Union in 1974, he first became Director and Financial Officer of the United Mutual Savings Bank and then joined Brown Brothers Harriman & Co. where he served in various capacities until 1986, when he retired. In addition, for 57 years, through 2002, he managed investments for the F.A. Ayer Estate and 26 years for the Wilmar Corporation through 2000. He was a member and officer of the New York Society of Security Analysts, First Congregational Church of Chappaqua NY, and the New Castle Historical Society. He was a member of the Bond Club of New York, Mount Kisco Country Club and the Forest Heights Country Club of Statesboro, GA. He worked with little league basketball and baseball and the boy scouts. He and his wife lived in Chappaqua, NY from 1950 to 1998, when they moved to Statesboro GA, where Phoebe died in 2001. He is survived by Peter Donald Whitney of McLean and Mary Neville Hoch of Amherst MA; by grandchildren Tyson and Vanna Whitney and Katrina Hoch, Sarah Morris and Natalie Hoch Krauser; and by great-grandchildren Eva and Mireia Whitney and Ella Morris. Visitation and Funeral Services were on Saturday, March 7 at the Joiner-Anderson Funeral Home, in Statesboro, GA. Graveside services and burial will be held on Tuesday at 11:00am in the Fair Ridge Cemetery in Chappaqua, New York. Friends may sign the online register book at www.joineranderson.com. Joiner-Anderson Funeral Home of Statesboro is in charge of the services.

MANY New Yorkers will tell you that the town hasn't been the same since the Checker cab disappeared in 1999. Faced with the gradual loss of their own classic taxicab, the residents of Mumbai are proving much less sentimental. Last year, government legislation banned cabs more than 25 years old from the city's streets. The intention is to phase out Mumbai's fleet of Premier Padmini taxicabs in favor of modern alternatives.

Kind, smart and funny, Jean was sincerely dedicated to THIRTEEN and generous in her support. She will be missed by her many friends here. We send our condolences to her husband Bob and join her family in mourning the loss of this lovely woman. We wish them comfort in this time of sorrow. James S. THE Phantom Corsair, one of the boldest custom cars of the 1930s, will be making a sojourn from its home at the National Automobile Museum in Reno, Nev., to star at the Amelia Island Concours d'Élégance. The event will take place March 13-15 at the Golf Club of Amelia Island, Fla. Created by the condiment heir Rust Heinz, the Corsair was built on a Cord 810 chassis by the coachbuilder Bohman & Schwartz. Heinz hoped to begin small-scale production of the car, which resembles a cross between a Cord 810 and a killer whale.

Spitzer; her grandson, Michael Feuer and his wife Karen; her son-in-law, Bernard Feuer; her niece, Helene Spitzer; her nephew, Stephen Spitzer and his wife Eila; her nephew, Michael Becker. She was predeceased by her husband, Hyman Becker, and her daughter, Judith Feuer. A graveside service was privately held.

Heather Cari Goldberg and Daniel Brian Mendelow are to be married Sunday at Beth Tfiloh Congregation in Baltimore. Rabbi Mitchell Wohlberg is to officiate and Cantor Avi Albrecht is to take part in the ceremony. The bride, 35, is a lawyer at Pfizer, the pharmaceutical company, in New York. She graduated from Duke and received a law degree from New York University. She is a daughter of Myrna Goldberg and Dr. Joel Goldberg of Owings Mills, Md. Her father is a dentist in Baltimore, and her mother is the manager of his office.

THE NEWS The Obama administration announced details of a plan to help as many as four million people avoid foreclosure on their homes, at a cost to taxpayers of about $75 billion, by allowing some with little or no equity in their homes to refinance them and others, who cannot afford their mortgage payments, to get their loans modified. BEHIND THE NEWS The plan works mainly by lowering interest costs, not forgiving principal, a feature that drew criticism as too generous to lenders and insufficient to solve the problem. People with big mortgages or big income shortfalls would not be helped. Conservatives questioned why taxpayers should help struggling borrowers at all.

General Motors Corporation said it would no longer provide financial support for the documentary filmmaker Ken Burns as the automobile maker seeks to rein in spending, The Detroit News reported. Mr. Burns, the director of PBS films like “Jazz,” “Baseball” and “The Civil War,” has had a 22-year relationship with G.M.; under the terms of a 10-year deal that was struck in 1999, G.M. paid for 35 percent of Mr. Burns’s documentaries and provided financing for educational programs related to the films. G.M., which has asked for billions of dollars in federal aid, recently ended its endorsement deal with Tiger Woods, and did not advertise on major television events like the Super Bowl or the Academy Awards. The last of Mr. Burns’s films that G.M. helped to finance, “The National Parks: America’s Best Idea,” is scheduled to run on PBS this fall.

Sun worshipers who bought their tickets to the Coachella music festival in April for the express purpose of seeing Amy Winehouse‘s performance will have to content themselves with the dozens of other bands on the lineup. After being charged with assault last week, Ms. Winehouse, the British soul singer, will not be able to obtain her work visa in time to attend the Indio, Calif., festival, at which she was scheduled to sing on April 18, Reuters reported. The assault charge stems from a Sept. 26 incident when a fan named Sherene Flash said Ms. Winehouse struck her after Ms. Flash asked to take her picture. Ms. Winehouse is scheduled to appear in a British court on March 17 to answer the charge. Coachella, whose headliners include Paul McCartney, the Killers and the Cure, runs from April 17 through 19.

New films by Conor McPherson and Marshall Curry and a documentary about the rock club CBGB are among the features that the Tribeca Film Festival announced for its 2009 World Narrative, World Documentary Feature and Discovery categories. Mr. McPherson, the playwright of “The Seafarer” and “Shining City,” is the writer and director of “The Eclipse,” a film about a widower who notices strange phenomena in his house. Mr. Curry, whose documentary “Street Fight,” about Cory Booker’s run for mayor of Newark, was nominated for an Academy Award in 2005, is the director of “Racing Dreams,” about the national championship of go-kart racing. Also on the lineup is “Burning Down the House: The Story of CBGB,” about the East Village performance space and its battle to remain open. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 22 to May 3.

A Brazilian actor who has previously dubbed Sean Penn‘s voice in Portuguese-language films has said he will not take a job re-recording Mr. Penn’s dialogue for the film “Milk,” Variety reported. Marco Ribeiro, a performer who supplied Mr. Penn’s voice in dubbed versions of the movies “All the King’s Men” and “21 Grams,” is also a pastor at the Assembly of God church in Rio de Janeiro. “I did not feel comfortable with the job,” Mr. Ribeiro said, according to Variety. “My voice is involved with other causes, and for the same reason I have refused to work on certain types of advertising.” “Milk,” directed by Gus Van Sant, won Mr. Penn an Academy Award for his performance as Harvey Milk, the openly gay politician. The film, which has already been playing in Brazilian theaters with Portuguese subtitles, is expected to reach a wider audience when a dubbed version is broadcast on television.

Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese will be retiring after this academic year, ending at 19-year reign atop one of the première conferences in college sports. Tranghese sat down in his office for a recent interview to reflect on his career, delivering answers in the same blunt and effusive style that defined his stint as commissioner. He began as the Big East's first employee, just he and a secretary in a three-room suite. (Dave Gavitt, the first commissioner, also served as the athletic director at Providence when the league was formed.) During the interview, Tranghese touched on everything from Patrick Ewing's influence on the Big East to the league's vote to not take Penn State as a member to receiving a head butt from Jim Boeheim. He reflected on his favorite year, his favorite Big East tournament moment, the league's relationship with ESPN and what challenges he thinks face his successor, John Marinatto. And he made one final plea: Please, don't ask him for anymore tickets.

About an hour before the Saint Laurent show, I dropped into Chanel to see Karl Lagerfeld. He was chatting with Anna Wintour behind his big, paper-filled desk when I entered the fourth-floor studio. A model in a black boater, her blond curls streaming over her black tweed jacket and frilly white collar, stood more or less at attention at the other end of the room, waiting. I said hey to Anna and as she got up and was saying her goodbyes to Lagerfeld, the studio suddenly filled with people, about 20. Freida Pinto, the star of "Slumdog Millionaire," had arrived. She looked lovely in a black Chanel jacket and skinny jeans. She and Anna talked for a moment, and then she seemed to talk to everyone. The actress is in Paris to attend the Chanel show tomorrow-her first-and then, she said, she'll return to India to organize some things. In July, she starts work in London on a Woody Allen film, with Antonio Banderas and Anthony Hopkins.

Politics | Still more on the renewed popularity of Ayn Rand and "Atlas Shrugged": Conservatives think the recession will be deepened by people "going John Galt" -- curbing their entrepreneurial spirit or otherwise changing their economic behavior in response to Obama's policies. John Galt is the novel's hero, who moves with followers to a mountain redoubt to watch the crumbling of a bureaucracy-stifled society that penalizes innovators. Meantime, this article sees a strong Objectivist strain in the vigilante hero of the new film "Watchmen." [Washington Independent, Reason]

It's been a rough year for SC Bern coach John Van Boxmeer. After finishing first in the Swiss NLA last season, Bern got knocked out in the first round of the playoffs by No. 8 seed Fribourg. In August he had a heart attack, only to return to the bench in time for Bern's thrashing by the visiting New York Rangers, 8-1, in a Victoria Cup tuneup match.

PARIS - The shows here are making it clear that if a fashion house wants to survive these difficult times, it must stick to its core and reach those customers able to afford its clothes. Judging from what was shown at Comme des Garçons, Dries Van Noten and Lanvin (and at Prada and Armani in Milan last week), designers want to dress women and not young girls: women who are paying for their clothes with their own money.The most successful collections address females with great respect, accepting them in their totality, acknowledging the emotional complexity of their desire to seduce and be seduced. A central theme of this season is what it means to be a woman in a post-feminist, post-consumerist, post-political society: independent of what men want and think.

President Obama today today announced the signing of a memorandum instructing the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy to "develop a strategy for restoring scientific integrity to government decision-making." He promised to "base our public policies on the soundest science" and to "appoint scientific advisors based on their credentials and experience, not their politics or ideology."

Energy | Ever since its wide adoption during World War I (actually since Benjamin Franklin thought of it), daylight saving has been thought to save energy because the extra sunlight later in the day reduces the need for manmade lighting. But two professors at the University of California at Santa Barbara calculate that today it actually results in more energy use. That's because in the summer, people spend more to cool their homes late in the day, while in the colder months they spend more to heat them in the morning. [Yglesias, National Bureau of Economic Research]

This week, the Paris food writer Alexander Lobrano, the author of Hungry for Paris and the European correspondent for Gourmet magazine, joins the T table to share his thoughts (and tips) on dining.In culinary terms, the French and the Americans are each other's yin and yang. When they sit down for a meal, they generally meet in politely inchoate but entirely mutual gastronomic incomprehension. As someone with a foot in both camps, I'd have to say the results are often pretty funny. Consider the "American" restaurants in Paris, a sorry roster of bogus riffs on American coffee shops, New York Theater District restaurants and diners. Is it any surprise that the French just so don't get our food? For most of them, the U.S. still exists in a sort of pre-Alice Waters time warp where "grease" really is the word.

Representative Anthony D. Weiner on Monday released his version of a rescue plan for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, in which tolls on the East River and Harlem River bridges that would be paid only by people who do not live in New York City.

The artist Marc André Robinson, who created the "T" in our new men's fashion issue, currently occupies a corner office in Lower Manhattan. He's there not because his day job is as a finance titan but rather as a part of a residency program established by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council that turns disused office space into art studios. There is bland carpeting, a drop ceiling, '80s-era frosted glass and shiny fixtures - just about everything an artist would choose not to have in his studio. But free space is free space, and Robinson, whose work balances cleverness and craftsmanship, relishes not only the L.M.C.C.'s support but also the idea of artists taking over for bankers.

Rest easy, fans of sophomoric movie title double entendres. There's still a decent chance that Warner Brothers will release its Bruce Willis detective comedy under its original title, "A Couple of Dicks."
In hard times, New Yorkers ask psychic readers not about love, but about money.
Scenes from the photographer Jacques Habbah's exclusive fashion week diary.

Update | 2:24 p.m. A judge in Delaware Chancery Court has given Dow Chemical and Rohm & Haas until 5 p.m. on Monday to reach a settlement over their disputed merger. Otherwise, he said, a trial will begin on Tuesday morning.

FAIRFAX, Va. -- George Mason Coach Jim Larranaga has a picture in his office of himself with President Obama. The picture sits on a small table, in front of a picture of Larranaga with Michael Jordan.
Eight months after announcing the release of the NYTimes iPhone Application, we're delighted to announce the release of version 2.0.
Deb answers the age-old "prune or poppy?" question rather assertively and offers a slightly modified and beautifully detailed version of the classic early-Spring pastry. --MB

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- One of the pleasures of roaming the back fields here is that you never know what you're going to see. On Monday morning I stumbled upon a spirited hitting competition among the pitchers. Divided into two teams -- starters and relievers -- they faced a pitching machine manned by Al Jackson, and points were awarded based on their success in game situations called out by the pitching coach Dan Warthen.

It's generally been a slow year for deal-makers, as the economic crisis has put a damper on mergers and acquisitions. But for many bankers that specialize in the pharmaceuticals industry, business is booming.

At a White House ceremony today, President Obama lifted the Bush administration's strict limits on human embryonic stem cell research. The audience included several people in wheelchairs, reflecting the hope that stem cell research may one day lead to a cure for spinal cord paralysis.

Lawyers for the financier J. Ezra Merkin have asked a judge to modify a temporary restraining order that is restricting Mr. Merkin's Ariel Fund from recouping losses it suffered from its investment with Bernard L. Madoff, who is accused of running a $50 billion Ponzi scheme.

TORONTO - After Chipper Jones strained his right oblique muscle Sunday, United States Manager Davey Johnson all but ruled him out of the rest of the World Baseball Classic. Turns out Jones will stay on the roster and plans to take part in the second round, which starts Saturday in Miami.

Said to be charming, attentive and with a touching air of sadness about him, a Swiss man named Helg Sgarbi evidently wended his way through European society, skillfully winning the hearts of wealthy women - and then blackmailing them for cash.
Millburn -- The weekly Millburn police blotter, provided by Capt. James Miller, public information officer, Millburn Police Department, edited and condensed by The Local.

The well-anticipated revamping of the old-time Village favorite, the Minetta Tavern, from Keith McNally, Riad Nasr and Lee Hanson, is set to open on Tuesday, a bit earlier than planned. 113 MacDougal Street (Minetta Lane), (212) 475-3850.

In the four weeks between the announcement of this year's win-a-trip contest in January and its deadline last month, we received close to 900 applications. In reading and viewing the submissions (which I, as Nicholas Kristof's assistant, have had a chance to do), one thing has become eminently clear: "Young people nowadays" give grounds for optimism for our collective future. The number of bright, talented, impassioned college students among the applicants was truly heartening, and some of the things they've accomplished, and the causes they've taken on, inspire endless admiration. Whittling down the list of applicants to a list of finalists proved very tough, but it's been done, with help from the great team at the International Committee of the Red Cross. We hope to have a winner by the end of this week.

One of the more interesting N.H.L. general managers meetings in many years begins today in Naples, Fla., with the highly publicized issues of fighting and head shots prominently featured topics of conversation. In previous years, this meeting occurred prior to the trade deadline, and the business of the league's rules had to share the G.M.'s attention with their negotiation of deals to improve their teams. With the trade deadline now past, these and other competitive issues should get more focus.
Congratulations to our first winners of last week's caption contest, Ken O, Georgeann, and Read Sherman!

A coalition of New York historic-preservation and community groups has filed a lawsuit against the Landmarks Preservation Commission and St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, seeking to block the destruction of its Edward and Theresa O'Toole Medical Services Building. The distinctive 44-year-old structure is crucial to the hospital's much-debated $1.63 billion plan to build a medical tower and condominium in the Greenwich Village Historic District.
Antipathy toward a "cow tax" is apparently bipartisan.
In hard times people turn to psychic readers and ask for advice on jobs and finances.

Pledging that his administration will "make scientific decisions based on facts, not ideology," President Obama on Monday lifted the Bush administration's strict limits on human embryonic stem cell research.
Laurie Strongin and Allen Goldberg were among the guests on hand to watch President Obama as he lifted the Bush administration's strict limits on human embryonic stem cell research today.
The red heart symbol in the “I ♥ NY” logo is being remade into a red cross in a campaign to encourage New Yorkers to volunteer for the Red Cross Reserves, whose members respond to disasters.
Editor's note: Carter Dougherty, European economic correspondent for The International Herald Tribune and The New York Times, writes with the view from Europe on protectionism.
Citigroup, the beleaguered and bailed-out banking giant, is again drawing attention for its corporate perks.
Q & A with Stuart Elliott.

Webdenda.

MILLBURN - A citizen's revolt, complete with YouTube campaigning, helped quash plans for a $100 million downtown redevelopment in December 2008.

Following through on what he said he would do, Attorney General Andrew Cuomo of New York on Monday sent a letter to Bank of America seeking information on bonuses paid out to its employees and those of Merrill Lynch.

Economy | Penury as the mother of invention: To improve on the cardboard-box dwellings of the homeless, design students backed by a philanthropist have modified the shopping cart into a mobile, single-person shelter. It "carries belongings and facilitates recycling during the day" and "unfolds into a special, framed tent-like sleeping enclosure with a bed at night." Behold the EDAR ('Everyone Deserves a Roof"), rolling out in L.A. But given the state of the economy and the Big Three, shouldn't this idea be rolling out of Detroit? [Architecture Week, EDAR]

PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. -- There have been plenty of open seats for the Mets' games at Tradition Field, which is good news for anyone in town Thursday wanting to see Johan Santana pitch. No official announcement has been made, but the next step for Santana, who threw a bullpen session Monday morning, will be a game. And considering he usually throws his bullpen sessions three days before he starts, well, you can do the math.

The Lanvin showroom, at the Musée de l'Homme, was a hive the other morning, with store buyers writing orders. I met Alber Elbaz there around 11:30, to have closer look at the clothes and see how they fit. I love this part of the job, finding out what's on the inside. With Lanvin, there's usually a minor revelation or two. The black wool dress that opened the show actually has a simple twist of fabric over the left shoulder; the fabric is smooth and lightweight, with seams cross-stitched like a scuba suit. The dress will cost about $2,300.
On Monday in London, Stanley Wells, the chairman of the Shakespeare Birthplace Trust, unveiled what he claims is the only picture of William Shakespeare painted during the playwright's lifetime.
Pat Healy, the New York Times theater reporter, talks with Jane Fonda and Moises Kaufman about the Broadway production of the play "33 Variations."
What we're looking at on the Web today ...

The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Paris Fashion Week. Here, the model Kasia Struss of Women Management before (above, left) and after makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Orlando Pita. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

F.B.I. agents and Suffolk County police officers resumed their search Monday morning for the makeshift graves of two men killed by the Colombo crime family more than a decade ago, digging near an industrial park in Farmingdale, N.Y., an F.B.I. spokesman said. The search was temporarily halted in December, after agents and the police found the body of William Cutolo, a Colombo family underboss who had disappeared in 1999, and were unable to locate the bodies of the other men, said the spokesman, James Margolin.

Fear not, Scorecard is back. Today, we bring you a weekend recap of reviews of Ann Demeulemeester, Christian Dior, Issey Miyake, Jean Paul Gaultier, Junya Watanabe, Lanvin, Maison Martin Margiela, Nina Ricci and Yohji Yamamoto. The aura of sensual sobriety evoked by Alber Elbaz at Lanvin was a veritable fashion moment; meanwhile over at Martin Margiela, where the namesake designer seems to be M.I.A., critics didn't know whom to blame.
Images from the Jean Paul Gaultier, Yohji Yamamoto, Junya Watanabe, Issey Miyake, Ann Demeulemeester and Karl Lagerfeld shows.

It was an impressive hat trick for the London Knights' John Tavares on Sunday. His first goal tied the Ontario Hockey League career goals record of 213 set by Peter Lee of the Ottawa 67s, his second goal established a new mark and his third one was the game-winner, as London beat the top-ranked Windsor Spitfires, 4-3, at Windsor. Knights Coach Dale Hunter was impressed with Tavares's poise.
Thousands of fans greeted Phish at the Hampton Coliseum in Virginia for its first public concert since 2004.

In an interview with the British newspaper The Mail on Sunday, Binyam Mohamed, who was recently released from the United States detention camp in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, discussed his treatment while in American custody and renewed his claim that he was tortured.

I make double backups, one on an external hard disk and a second on a high-capacity thumb drive. As the thumb drive has no moving parts, why does it take 4 to 5 times longer to write to it than to the hard drive?
Now showing on our virtual refrigerator is a wood sculpture by Micah, a fourth grader at Tuscan Elementary School.
Health news from around the Web.

No. 4 Northeastern spent the entire year atop the Hockey East standings, and the Huskies controlled their own destiny going into the final weekend of the regular season. But No. 1 Boston University entered the final two games trailing by one point, ready to pounce if the Huskies slipped up.

In its struggle to stay afloat, General Motors has been pushing the United Auto Workers for concessions on financing its retiree health care plan - a burden that adds up to $50 billion. But any resolution may depend on the Obama administration, as it figures out how to keep G.M. from falling apart. The U.A.W. hopes that the president and the Democratic Congress will protect the auto workers' benefits, either through a bailout or with some kind of protections in the event of a bankruptcy. But the union is in a bull's-eye, with critics pointing out that most Americans don't have retiree health benefits, let alone at a level as generous as the U.A.W.'s.

Twitter -- the social text service -- is all the rage, and while almost 70 percent of Twitterers tweet from their computers (I am not making these words up), the next largest group, about 18 percent, tweet from their phones.

Drivers of alternative-fuels vehicles cruising down Interstate 5 on the West Coast will not need to worry about finding a place to fill up, if the vision of several green-minded governors comes to pass.

I don't know if it's just nostalgia, but for someone who doesn't much care to play games on my phone, I've found it hard to put down Touch Hockey, a free iPhone app that simulates the old air hockey table game.
CF Industries on Monday rejected an unsolicited bid from a rival fertilizer maker, Agrium, even at it pressed ahead with its own uninvited takeover offer for Terra Industries.

On the Well blog, Michael Pollan asks readers for words of wisdom they've learned over the years on how to eat better. "I want to create a compendium of such rules, across cultures and also time,'' he says.
Three months -- almost to the day -- after Honda pulled out of Formula One, the team has a new name and a new car, which was on the track on Monday.

The sweetness of apricot jam adds an element of flavor not often found in savory dishes, and its sugar encourages browning. This produces a dish that is almost no work and has great flavor -- but the result is often too sweet. Enter applesauce, which doesn't overwhelm the meat with sugar.

Writer Michael Pollan, author of the best-seller "In Defense of Food,'' has gained a passionate following by encouraging us to change the way we think about food. But for his next project, he wants your help.

How can a single fertilized egg turn into a full-fledged organism? The two rappers at Stanford University provide the answer in the above video: "Regulatin' Genes." I'm happy to present it there, both because it's so well done and because it's yet another in our collection of songs whose lyrics include "polymerase." (Although this one doesn't include "polymerase chain reaction," as Lab readers managed to do in response to "The P.C.R. Song.")

The New York Times Company said Monday that it had raised $225 million through a sale-leaseback of part of its headquarters building, one in a series of moves to pay down its debts and increase its cash cushion during a drastic slump for the newspaper industry, The Times's Richard Perez-Pena writes.
Nickname given to Goldman Sachs for weathering the financial crisis relatively unscathed, thus far.
