At the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on Sunday, a mob of potential buyers convened for an auction of foreclosed homes, a fast-paced and somewhat unusual happening in a place more used to trade shows and corporate events.

A former New York City police officer who is suspected of fatally shooting his 28-year-old former companion and wounding another woman in Brooklyn turned himself in about 3 a.m. Monday on Staten Island, the police said.
Images from the Comme des Garçons, Dries Van Noten, Givenchy, Stella McCartney, Haider Ackermann, Hussein Chalayan and Tao fall 2009 collections.
Good morning!

Kurt Busch led 234 of 330 laps on Sunday to win Nascar's Kobalt Tools 500 at Atlanta Motor Speedway. That's more laps than he led all of last season. A yellow flag with four laps to go brought the leaders into the pits for new tires. Busch and Jeff Gordon came out in second and third behind Carl Edwards but blew by him to finish one-two.
A comment from a reader who has followed the Bills since their days at War Memorial Stadium:
The Carlyle Group said Monday that it has raised $500 million for its first Middle East and North Africa private equity fund.
Discussion of carbon cap-and-trade systems usually focuses on whether such schemes can set a workable price for permits, given the volatility that has characterized the system in Europe.
Dow Chemical said on Sunday that settlement talks with Rohm and Haas were going "quite well" on the eve of a scheduled court hearing on their soured $15 billion merger, Reuters reports.
Update | 10:59 a.m. Dow Chemical and Rohm and Haas have asked for a delay for Monday's hearing in Delaware's Court of Chancery while the two sides continue settlement talks.
Rarely have so few people had so little time to prop up so many pillars of the economy as those in the Treasury Department under Timothy F. Geithner.

Royal Bank of Scotland is retrenching to its core businesses and plans to leave as many as 36 countries, but undoing a decade of deals in the eye of a financial storm will be a long process, Reuters writes.

Environment | The recession's "green lining": It's shutting down dirty factories in the developing world, from China to Mexico, where much of manufacturing has moved precisely because of more permissive pollution standards. But will the smokestack clouds return when the economic clouds lift? Insuring that they don't is the challenge. [Newsweek]
Congratulations to Alan B. Krueger, a former Daily Economist here at Economix. He has been tapped to become assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department.
Despite a healthy dose of speculation that Google might buy Twitter, the search giant's chief, Eric Schmidt, reiterated Friday that it was unlikely to happen any time soon.
BackType, a comment-tracking tool for blogs, has received $300,000 in seed funding from True Ventures, TechCrunch reports.
Bank of America has become the first U.S. bank to withdraw job offers made to foreign M.B.A. students graduating from U.S. business schools this summer, according to The Financial Times.
TongXue, a Chinese social networking site whose name literally translates into "classmates", has nabbed $6 million in a new round of funding.
Marc Duchesne, the British hedge fund manager accused of cheating investors out of 15 million pounds ($20.8 million), was sentenced to four and half years in prison by a London court on Friday.

Mall giant General Growth Properties intends on Monday to begin formally soliciting holders of $2.3 billion of its bonds to grant it another nine months of breathing room as it juggles its debts and strives to avoid bankruptcy, The Wall Street Journal reported.

GE Capital, the finance arm of U.S. conglomerate General Electric, plans to sell bonds under the U.S. Temporary Liquidity Guarantee program, Reuters reported, citing a source with direct knowledge of the deal.
Is Cisco Systems getting ready to snap up Pure Digital, the maker of the popular Flip Video camera?
Credit Suisse and Swiss Re both announced the appointment of new chairmen on Monday, shifting executives in an effort to limit the impact of the financial crisis, Reuters writes.
Laughter, the old saw goes, is the best medicine. So perhaps the scheduling of two new comedy show pilots whose essences flow from the financial crisis is meant to be a tonic.

The debate over whether some struggling banks should be nationalized is based on misinformation, says Kenneth D. Lewis, chief executive of Bank of America, the bank that has been cited as candidate for just such a move.

India's Sterlite Industries has inked a new deal to buy Asarco, the bankrupt United States-based copper miner, for $1.7 billion, down from an original agreed offer of $2.6 billion. Sterlite reduced its original offer, agreed to in May 2008, by $900 million to account for falling copper prices.
A little more has been revealed about Mark Thomas, the virtually unknown investor who took control of Sumner Redstone's Midway Games.

Istithmar World Capital, the Dubai sovereign wealth fund which has been shedding holdings to raise cash, is looking to unload more assets, although its chief says it won't let go of Barneys New York for less than $825 million.
British hedge fund Lansdowne Partners has banked almost 13 million pounds by shorting insurer Aviva, and could increase that amount if Aviva announces a rights issue.

Japan will extend limits on the short-selling of stocks beyond the end of this month, Reuters reported, citing two sources. The move comes as the Japanese economy, the second-largest in the world after the United States, struggles to prop up its tumbling stock market.
The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation's trust has sold 36,056 of its Class B shares of Warren E. Buffet's Berkshire Hathaway so far in 2009 to comply with tax laws, The Associated Press said.
Lazard said Monday that it has appointed Antonio Weiss, an investment banker based in Paris, as its newly created global head of mergers and acquisitions.
Japan's Nikkei stock index lost 1.2 percent on Monday, closing at its lowest level since the first week of October 1982, The New York Times's Mark McDonald reports.
From Miguel Helft at Bits:
Merck, the American pharmaceutical giant, will pay $41 billion to acquire its rival Schering-Plough, the two companies said Monday.

They are larger-than-life figures at home and abroad, men who saw themselves as the Carnegies or Rockefellers of Russia. They are known as oligarchs, and they may soon be thrown into the dustbin of history by the economic crisis, The New York Times's Andrew E. Kramer writes.

Goldman Sachs' chief executive said he opposed the full nationalization of banks, but thought government stakes could be sensible in extreme situations, in an interview with German weekly Welt am Sonntag.
The Dubai developer that bought the QE2 says it remains committed to renovating the British cruise ship.

U.S. and Bahrain prosecutors are probing about $4.6 million in alleged payments made by employees of Glencore International to bank accounts controlled by then-employees of Aluminum Bahrain, The Wall Street Journal reported.
India's Satyam Computer Services said on Monday it was commencing a competitive bidding process to select an investor to acquire 51 percent stake in the fraud-tainted outsourcer, Reuters reports.

Chief executives of leading Japanese, European and U.S. banks will meet in London to discuss the future of the financial system, the Nikkei newspaper reported, as the global financial crisis prompts a barrage of new regulatory proposals for the sector.
The Senate will try to complete work on the stalled $410 billion spending bill this week, but not before Democrats are forced to navigate a series of politically charged Republican amendments.

Talk of "Gone With the Wind," that guiltiest of guilty pleasures, book or movie, usually boils down to race or "romance." So it's near exhilarating to read Molly Haskell's "Frankly, My Dear" (reviewed by Armond White in the March 1 Book Review), a revisitation that explores the reverberating complexities of the Margaret Mitchell franchise.
At a forum in New York last week, experts on carbon-capture and sequestration, or C.C.S., mostly agreed that the technology was already available, but that the main obstacle was cost.

Economy | Sure, the job market's tough. But employees can still get companies to pay them extra just for agreeing to work in hardship posts, according to a consultancy. The worst place (or best place in this dubious regard?) is Lagos, Nigeria, followed by Jakarta and Riyadh, not counting trouble spots like Baghdad and Harare. [Business Week]

"Derivatives are dangerous."

This week, Joel Kotkin, co-author of "Reviving the City of Aspiration," a study of the challenges facing the city's middle class for the Center for an Urban Future, answered readers' questions about the importance of the city's upwardly mobile class and what can be done to revive this troubled population.
So this is what it has come to. General Electric appears to be in trouble.

Monday, 6:30 p.m. A cynic might suggest that an inventors' conference at a Holiday Inn is about as incongruous as a superhero forum at a truck stop - a noble enterprise diminished by location. Then again, all cannot be wrong with the world if tomorrow's Edisons are actually meeting. The Inventors Association of Manhattan claims to be the city's premier group of innovators, with 320 members in good standing. Bring a gizmo that can fix the credit crisis and you will be flush enough to hold the next meeting at your private suite in the Pierre. 440 West 57th Street, Manhattan.
Whole Foods Market said Friday that it would sell 13 stores to resolve the Federal Trade Commission's challenge of its $565 million purchase of Wild Oats Markets.

The financial crisis grows weirder by the day. When philosophical conservatives like Alan Greenspan start talking about nationalizing banks, you know you've passed into some kind of parallel universe. Why are so many people entertaining an idea that sounds vaguely Marxian, asks Alan S. Blinder in The New York Times's Economic View column.

An influential adviser urged shareholders on Sunday not to support the latest offer for Fortis, the Belgian financial services company, by the French bank BNP Paribas, even as executives at the two companies expressed confidence that the deal would succeed.

A court-appointed receiver notified 1,000 employees of the Stanford Financial Group on Friday that their jobs were terminated in an effort to preserve the value of whatever resources were left in the company, The New York Times's Clifford Krauss reports.

Your Jokes | Send via the comment link below:Alex Rodriguez will undergo surgery for a hip injury. The good news for him is that he now qualifies for the $6.99 early dinner special at many South Florida restaurants. -- Marv Kaminsky
Struggling U.S. carmaker General Motors denied a weekend newspaper report its German unit Opel was preparing for insolvency.

Switzerland rejects U.S. demands that the country's largest bank UBS should hand over the data of 52,000 U.S. clients, Swiss newspaper Berner Zeitung quoted the Swiss justice minister as saying on Saturday, according to Reuters.
Greece reached a deal to sell its ailing Olympic Airlines to the Marfin Investment Group, despite a bid from a private rival, Aegean Airlines.
Regulators shut down Freedom Bank of Georgia, making it the 17th failure this year of a federally insured bank.
Redcorp Ventures, a Canadian gold-and-silver mining company, filed for bankruptcy in the United States and Canada, citing cost overruns and a lack of financing.

Wall Street ended a week of battering sell-offs on an mildly positive note as stock markets closed mostly higher despite a report showing that unemployment had surged to its highest level in 25 years, The New York Times's Jack Healy writes.
Why do so many Twitterers seem to be aspiring stand-up comics?
MIPIM, the annual property show, opens in Cannes on Tuesday, with fewer yacht parties on the agenda and the industry eager for any whisper of positive news.
Reviews of the Jean Paul Gaultier, Yohji Yamamoto, Junya Watanabe, Issey Miyake, Ann Demeulemeester and Karl Lagerfeld shows.

The cost of renting an apartment in Manhattan has been falling since last summer. But at Liz Claiborne, the cost of providing Chief Executive William McComb a place to live increased last year, according to the preliminary proxy the company filed late Friday.
View Larger MapFashion Week Agenda tracks every stilettoed step our style editors take.

Alberto Contador of Spain won the first stage of the Paris-Nice race in pouring rain. Contador, who won the Tour of Algarve in Portugal last month, completed the 5.8-mile time trial around Amilly, France, seven seconds faster than Bradley Wiggins.

Everton rallied past Middlesbrough, 2-1, on Sunday to set up an F.A. Cup semifinal against Manchester United in April at Wembley. Arsenal defeated the lower-tier club Burnley, 3-0, to reach the quarterfinals. Held up by postponements and replays, Arsenal will face Hull in a quarterfinal. The winner will play Chelsea in the semifinals.

Maria Sharapova, a three-time Grand Slam champion who has not played a competitive match since July because of a shoulder injury, will return to the women’s tour this week in Indian Wells, Calif. Sharapova, 21, will not compete in the singles competition but will compete in the doubles tournament with Elena Vesnina, according to a statement on her Web site.

J. R. Celski of the United States won the 3,000-meter title and finished third in the 1,000 at the short-track speedskating world championships in Vienna. Lee Ho-suk of South Korea won the 1,000 in 1 minute 33.06 seconds, ahead of Apolo Anton Ohno, who finished in 1:33.26.

The Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race has begun, with 67 teams entered in this year’s 1,100-mile race from Anchorage to Nome. The restart, where the real racing begins, was held Sunday in Willow, about 50 miles from Anchorage, where the ceremonial start was held a day earlier. The two-time defending champion, Lance Mackey, is looking for his third consecutive win.

The South Korean star Jiyai Shin won the HSBC Women’s Champions in Singapore for her fourth L.P.G.A. Tour title in eight months, shooting her second straight six-under-par 66 for a two-stroke victory over Katherine Hull of Australia. The 20-year-old Shin was five strokes behind Hull at the start of the round and four back with nine holes to play. ¶Eduardo Romero shot a three-under 68 to win the Toshiba Classic by one stroke over Joey Sindelar and Mark O’Meara in Newport Beach, Calif. Romero finished at 11-under 202 for his fifth career Champions Tour victory. (AP).

Dwain Chambers won the 60 meters at the European indoor championships in Turin, Italy, securing his first international title since coming back from a doping suspension. Chambers’s winning time, 6.46 seconds, fell short of the European indoor record of 6.42 he set Saturday.
Americans took nearly 10.7 billion rides on public transportation in 2008, according to an American Public Transportation Association report.
Even when superstar pitchers decline invitations to play in the W.B.C., there are plenty of sturdy arms to go around for the United States. The same cannot be said for Venezuela.

By now, much of corporate America is humbled and hunkered down, hoping to survive an economic crisis that seems to become worse day by day. That is certainly not the posture at I.B.M.'s headquarters in Armonk, N.Y.
A crowd twice the size of last year’s attended a foreclosure auction at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on Sunday.
A former New York City police officer who resigned after being arrested on corruption charges is suspected of fatally shooting his ex-girlfriend and wounding another woman.

An obituary on Thursday about the screenwriter and playwright Tom Cole referred imprecisely to the medal named in the title of his play about a Vietnam War veteran, “Medal of Honor Rag.” Although the medal is awarded “in the name of Congress,” it is the Medal of Honor, not the Congressional Medal of Honor.

The Well column on Tuesday, about the role that doctors and patients play in health care reform, referred incorrectly to data from a study published in 2004. The researchers, analyzing mortality data from the 1990s, showed that only about 1 in 16,000 Americans per year had their lives extended or saved as a result of recent improvements in health care technology, not 1 in 16,000 over the entire study period.

A picture caption on Friday with a film review of “Frontier of Dawn,” using information provided by IFC Films, which released the movie, misidentified the actress shown with Louis Garrel. She is Clémentine Poidatz — not Laura Smet, who has the leading female role in the film.
Illegal immigrants do not qualify for federal financial aid, and those living in Rhode Island, as in 39 other states, do not qualify for in-state tuition at public universities.

A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Friday about Brandeis University’s announcement that it would form a committee to consider the future of the university’s Rose Art Museum referred incorrectly to Brandeis’s provost, who said the faculty senate council would be consulted on the committee’s formation. The provost, Marty Wyngaarden Krauss, is a woman.

A subheading on Wednesday with an article about the A.F.L.-C.I.O. executive council’s call for nationalization of problem banks described the organization incorrectly. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is a labor organization representing 10 million workers; it is not a lobbying group, though it is considered politically powerful in Washington.

An article on Thursday about an unexplained death in San Francisco misattributed two quotations. The quotations — “Live as if you were to die tomorrow; learn as if you were to live forever” (usually rendered as a single phrase) — are derived from a Latin saying in common use since ancient times. They were not originated by Gandhi.

An article on Feb. 27 about prison sentences handed down by a United Nations court for five senior officials in the government of the former Serbian strongman Slobodan Milosevic misstated the name of the court. It is the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, not the United Nations War Crimes Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia.

WEINBERG--Edith (Bunny), died Friday, March 6, at age 78, beloved wife of James for 57 years. Blessed with wonderful and devoted children, Adam, Jed and Nina, son-in-law Bruce, daughter-in-law Lorraine, grandchildren Daniel, Zoe and Kira, daughter of the late Harry and Helen Zickerman and beloved daughter-in-law of the late Harold and Anna Weinberg. Graduate of the Little Red Schoolhouse, Dalton, University of Michigan, and Teacher's College. A beautiful, wise, loving, charming, tasteful person with a sense of humor and captivating warmth. A lover of music, the arts, a talented pianist and singer, for many years she was a member of numerous choruses including The Robert Shaw Chorale. She was a generous supporter of scholarships at the University of Michigan School of Music. Donations may be made in her name to the school of music. Funeral Wednesday March 11 at 11:30am at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison 100 Union Avenue Harrison, NY.

MADELEINE PEYROUX ''Bare Bones'' (Rounder) On each of her previous three solo albums Madeleine Peyroux kept the focus on her voice: a small, distinctive thing with all the weathered charm of a flea-market antique. Her new album, ''Bare Bones,'' features her singing no less purposefully than the others, but it presents her as more of a songwriter than before. Each of its 11 tracks has her name in the credits, and together they add up to a declaration of selfhood.

THOMAS--William, passed away peacefully in his home on January 31. His many beloved friends of all ages send love and prayers. Equally at home in Santa Fe and Bridgewater, Conn., Bill lived in New York City, and was born in Ohio. His cherished wife, (Bobby) Madeleine Thomas preceded him in death. All are most welcome to join a service in Bill's honour and memory on Thursday, March 12 at 6pm at the Fifth Ave. Presbyterian Church at 7 West 55 St.

CHAPIN--Schuyler G. The Board of Trustees of The Bagby Foundation For The Musical Arts mourns the passing of our great friend and esteemed Trustee, Schuyler G. Chapin. Schuyler served on our Board for nearly 52 years, including many years as President and Chairman. His extraordinary wisdom, charm and wit enlivened our meetings over those many years, and his care and compassion for the recipients of our grants was an inspiration to us all. We will always revere his memory and leadership. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, and are grateful to have his son Henry on the Bagby's board. F.Malcolm Graff, Jr., Chairman Blanche Lark Christerson, President J.Andrew Lark, Executive Director

CHRIS CORNELL ''Scream'' (Mosley Music/Interscope) Rockers feeling stale can always jump genres. Darius Rucker of Hootie and the Blowfish went country last year; now the rocker Chris Cornell introduces electrogrunge on ''Scream,'' his third solo album. Mr. Cornell, a grunge pioneer with Soundgarden in the 1980s and 1990s, wrote all the songs on ''Scream,'' but most of the music sets aside big guitar chords to embrace the synthetic pulse and programmed hooks produced by the hip-hop and R&B hit maker Tim Mosley, a k a Timbaland.

Classical albums from three artists, the tenor Plácido Domingo, the soprano Sarah Brightman and Mark O'Connor, above, a violinist, will be released on Tuesday. Mr. O'Connor, originally a bluegrass musician, is releasing ''Americana Symphony,'' his first symphony. Classical music was third in popularity after alternative and Christian/gospel albums in 2008. This year, top sellers include Yo-Yo Ma (''Songs of Joy & Peace'') and Josh Groban (''Closer''), but also Beethoven and ''essential'' music, which have been released only as downloads and have topped charts worldwide. BYAHATTI--Veerappa G.,M.D. of Watchung, NJ died on March 5, 2009 at age 72. A devoted husband, father, and physician he is survived by his wife, daughter, twin grandsons, and seven siblings. We will miss his smile, laugh, generosity, kindheartedness and relaxed manner. Memorial services on Sunday March 15 from 11-3 at Mirage, 1655-150 Oak Tree Road, Edison, NJ.

HAMBLETON John A. Lt. Col. USAF (retired) died on March 6 when an airplane he was piloting crashed near Ocala, FL. Col. Hambleton devoted his entire life to aviation, both military and civil. A graduate of Saint Paul's School he took a degree in aeronautical engineering from MIT and then joined the Air Force. In the fallowing years he completed two combat tours in Korea, and later flew lengthy combat tours in Viet Nam and Cambodia operating out of Thailand. He also served a series of test pilot assignments, both in the Air Force and later as a civilian. He retired in Ocala, FL where he devoted himself to civil aviation. He was killed piloting an F51 Mustang replica which he had constructed himself. The cause of the crash is thought to be engine failure. Col. Hambleton was the son of the late Col. John A. Hambleton, fighter pilot in WWI, Baltimore banker, aviation pioneer and co-founder of Pan American Airways. He also died in the crash of a private airplane in 1929. Col. Hambleton leaves his wife of 52 years, Sarah Hambleton, a daughter Elizabeth Grace, two sons, John A. and George C. Hambleton, eight grandchildren and two brothers.

SCHONFELD--Miriam, known all her life to her family and friends as "Mickey", passed away on March 7, 2009 in Port St. Lucie, FL. Her family was at her bedside. WEINBERG--Edith. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with great sadness the loss of Edith Weinberg. Schuyler G. Chapin, the patrician New Yorker and impresario who glided through society and held a string of jobs in the arts -- including general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, cultural affairs commissioner of New York City and dean of the school of the arts at Columbia University -- died on Saturday. He was 86. His son Theodore said Mr. Chapin died at his home in Manhattan. He had been in ill health since suffering cardiac arrest in 2005.

SYMINGTON--Charles H.,Jr."Charlie" "Soapy" Harrison Symington, Jr., 78, of Spring Island, South Carolina, husband of Bailey Walker Symington, died Wednesday morning, March 4, 2009. Born in Baltimore, Maryland on February 2nd, 1931, he was a son of the late Charles Harrison Symington, Sr. and the late Mary Towers Symington. Before retirement Charlie had been an investment banker in New York City with G.H. Walker; Warburg, Paribas, Becker; and S. G. Warburg. He was a graduate of Deerfield Academy ('49), Williams College ('53), and Harvard Law School ('56). He served on the Board of Governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers. He commuted to Wall Street for many years from Tuxedo Park, New York, and then from Princeton, New Jersey, before moving to New York City. He and his wife, Bailey, have lived in Spring Island, South Carolina for the past ten years. Throughout his adult life, Charlie contributed a unique blend of fiscal conservativism, social justice and laughter to school and civic boards. Tennis, golf and grandchildren kept him quick on his feet. His love of history, baseball and politics served as an extension of his unique way of observing and interacting with the people around him. His humor often won him the friendship of those whose politics and sports allegiances differed from his, even family members. Surviving are his wife, Bailey; his children Gaye Symington and her husband, Chuck Lacy, of Jericho, Vermont; Robin Ramos and her husband, Freddy Ramos, of Los Angeles, California; and Randolph Walker Symington and his wife, Megan King Symington, of Old Greenwich, Connecticut, and five grandchildren, Samuel, Mary and Tom Symington Lacy and Maya Anita and Bailey Rosa Ramos. He was well loved by his extended family of nieces, nephews, in-laws and cousins. A Celebration of Life service will be held in early April in New York City. In lieu of flowers, a gift may be made in his memory to The Spring Island Trust - 40 Mobley Oaks Lane, Okatie, South Carolina 29909.

DUNNING--Robert Duncan died peacefully at home, March 6th. A longtime resident of Summit, New Jersey, former art director, photographer and artist, he is survived by his wife, Deanne Torbert Dunning; son, Thomas; daughters, Catherine, Sally, Martha, Julia and five grandchildren: Tobias Moser, Carson Parris, Ramona and Josie Dunning, Daisy Boyd. Memorial service on Tuesday, March 10th, 2pm, at the Grand Summit Hotel, Summit, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the Wildlife Conservation Society, Bronx, New York.

WORRIES IN DOLLAR'S RISE As the global economy grapples with a lack of confidence and capital, money is flowing to United States government bonds, a condition that appears to be worsening the crisis elsewhere. SIX WEEKS AT TREASURY In the six weeks since Timothy F. Geithner took over as Treasury secretary, he and a skeleton crew of unofficial senior advisers have been racing to shape the country's financial future. [B1.]

FERTEL-METZ--Bernyce (Bunny), peacefully after a long illness. She joins her dear husband, Bernie and her loving parents, Ann and Irving. She leaves behind her beloved daughter, Charlene Bina Metz, her sisters Diane Fertel and Maxine dellaBadia Simon, brother-in-law Elliot, cherished nieces, nephews and great-nieces and nephews. May her love of art and beautiful colors keep her always present in our memory. Donations in her memory may be made to Temple Beth Sholom, 171-39 Northern Blvd, Flushing, NY 11358.

Adding another chapter to the legal history of “Sahara,” the 2005 action movie adapted from Clive Cussler‘s novel, a judge ruled Monday that Mr. Cussler must pay $13.9 million in legal fees to the production company that made the film, The Associated Press reported. In 2004, Mr. Cussler sued Crusader Entertainment, the company owned by the billionaire entrepreneur Philip F. Anschutz, saying that he was not permitted final approval on the script as his contract mandated, which resulted in the box-office failure of the film. Crusader countersued, saying that it had overpaid for the rights to Mr. Cussler’s work because he had overstated the sales of his novels. In 2007, a jury delivered a split decision. On Monday, Judge John P. Shook of Los Angeles Superior Court ruled that Mr. Cussler had violated a contract that mandated the payment of legal fees if either side breached the agreement.
What we’re reading (and watching) on Tuesday morning.

When Phish played its first shows in nearly five years over the weekend, more than a few concertgoers took the song “You Enjoy Myself” as a mandate rather than a suggestion: the police said that they arrested 194 fans during Phish’s performances in Hampton, Va., from March 6 through 8, The Associated Press reported. Most of the arrests, law enforcement officials said, were for drug possession, use and distribution. They said that they had also confiscated more than $68,000 from fans as well as large quantities of illegal drugs. Some 75,000 people were expected to come to Hampton for the concerts, the first that Phish had played since a weekend-long festival in Coventry, Vt., that was attended by about 65,000 fans in August 2004. Phish is scheduled to begin a summer tour in Wantagh, N.Y., on June 4.

Manuscripts discovered in Spain may be unpublished novels left behind by the Chilean author Roberto Bolaño, The Guardian reported, citing the Spanish newspaper La Vanguardia. The works discovered when papers of Mr. Bolaño, who died in 2003, were being sorted include two novels titled “Diorama” and “The Troubles of the Real Police Officer”; also found were documents that may comprise an additional volume of “2666,” an epic, 898-page novel by Mr. Bolaño that was released in the United States last year. New works by Mr. Bolaño have continued to be unearthed since his death; a previously unpublished novel, called “The Third Reich,” was acquired at the Frankfurt Book Fair in October. The literary agency that represents the Bolaño estate declined to comment to The Guardian.

Jay Leno, a man whose appreciation for cars and motorcycles spans multiple garages, said he would try to lift the spirits of unemployed autoworkers by performing a free show in Michigan, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Leno, the comedian and host of NBC’s “Tonight” show, said on Monday’s broadcast that he would perform a free show on April 7 at the Palace of Auburn Hills for “anybody out of work in Detroit,” according to The A.P. Tickets for the show, called “Jay’s Comedy Stimulus Plan,” will be available starting Monday at 10 a.m. at the Palace box office, according to the NBC.com Web site. Participants must bring a photo ID, and only four tickets will be allowed per person.

“Wishful Drinking,” Carrie Fisher’s one-woman show that is also the title of her recent best-selling memoir, may yet come to Broadway this season – if only she and her producer can come to terms on potential profits, both sides say.

Fans of David Alan Grier, the comedian and “In Living Color” alumnus, will have to sate themselves with his performances on “Dancing With the Stars” for now: his Comedy Central series, “Chocolate News,” has not been renewed, a representative for the network said, confirming a report that appeared on the Web site of The Baltimore Sun. Despite its title, “Chocolate News” was less a news parody that a sketch comedy show that featured Mr. Grier playing characters, from fictitious rappers to the poet Maya Angelou, and delivering satirical commentaries on the subject of race. The series, which made its debut on Oct. 15 in advance of the presidential election, ran for one 10-episode season.

Second Stage Theater is postponing its summer production of “Mr. & Mrs. Fitch,” a new play by Douglas Carter Beane (“The Little Dog Laughed,” “Xanadu”), because of a scheduling conflict with the project’s director, Scott Ellis, the theater planned to announce.
“Race,” a new play by David Mamet, will have its premiere on Broadway at the end of this year, one of its producers, Jeffrey Richards, said on Tuesday.

For those who, like us, tried and failed to snare a ticket to the recent, critically acclaimed production of “Othello,” by Theater for a New Audience, there’s hope yet: It’s returning for an unusually limited engagement — 12 performances in mid-April — with an eye toward an eventual commercial run.
Goya's "Black Paintings" recently installed in a ground floor gallery of the Prado Museum. (Andrew Ferren)

After I'd been sober a year and the haze of recovery began to lift - that is, when I began to widen my daily travels to broader spheres than the short distance between the video store and my apartment - I noticed that, outside of B-movies, I had no appreciable interests at all. Years before, in graduate school, I had been forced to fill out a little get-to-know-you questionnaire to break the ice with my fellow students. Having no hobbies or any discernable extra-curricular interests to speak of (save drinking, of course), I winged it - which is to say, I lied - and wrote: "skeet shooting" and "rapping on the mic." Imagine the disappointment of my classmates when they discovered I had neither a talent for weaponry nor hip-hop.
Caleb Madison isn't old enough to drink but I guess he has somehow read up on the subject.

Inter Milan Manager José Mourinho is special. He'll tell you so. And so too will those who work with him, play for him and compete against him. The Portuguese coach has had great success in a relatively short managerial career. Now, after almost eight months in charge of Inter, he has the team on track for a fourth consecutive Serie A title and is locked in a do-or-die struggle with Manchester United in the European Champions League.

José Mourinho, the supremely confident manager of Inter Milan, is fantastic. So, too, is the Special One, a boisterous and impertinent puppet who borrows Mourinho's likeness. And both are equally as likely to tell you so in clipped but pointed English.
On the 50th anniversary of the failed Tibetan uprising against Chinese rule, a former political prisoner reflects on her experience.

“The Chopping Block,” a cooking reality show starring the British chef Marco Pierre White, has its premiere on NBC on Wednesday.
The new president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, William C. Dudley, is reassuring the nation's big banks that they will get as much capital as they need to survive and thrive.

Staff cuts, having hit nearly everywhere in Hollywood, have finally struck Sony Pictures. In a letter sent to the studio staff on Tuesday afternoon, Michael Lynton and Amy Pascal, who oversee the studio, said the company's worldwide work force was in for a 3-and-a-half percent reduction.

SAN JUAN, P.R. -- David Ortiz did not play one game at first base for the Boston Red Sox last season. When Ortiz was asked last week if he might play the position for the Dominican Republic in the World Baseball Classic, he laughed as if five people were tickling him.

For months, two of Hollywood's biggest talent agencies, Endeavor and William Morris, have quietly been talking merger. Endeavor has momentum, William Morris has depth and a combined entity would challenge a leadership position long held by the Creative Artists Agency.

The New York Times's Adam B. Ellick visits a former college professor who now lives and works on an organic farm that produces its own power and, for the most part, avoids the whims of the wider economy.

Just came from a party at Chanel, given by Karl Lagerfeld and Jefferson Hack for the publication of "Another Fashion Book." But who needs an excuse to have a party? So strange to see Stefano Pilati dancing in the middle of the Chanel couture salon I saw Jefferson but no sign of Karl. Already out of Champagne when I got there, so I happily settled on a Bud. Also saw Olivier Zahm, Tallulah Ormsby Gore, and Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte. A few moments later, down the street, I ran into Nicholas Kirkwood and Louise Gray. So it goes.

A financial rescue plan for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority stalled in the State Senate on Tuesday, as the chamber's majority leader, Malcolm A. Smith, cast doubt on whether the Legislature in fact must meet a March 25 deadline for passing the measure. Advocates of the rescue plan have warned that missing the deadline will lead to steep fare increases and severe service cuts.

Those Pinkertons of the Oscar world, the attorneys at Quinn Emanuel Urquhart Oliver & Hedges, have apparently been doing well while doing right by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. For years, the Quinn Emanuel lawyers have been known for their relentless pursuit of anyone who violates the rights and privileges of the academy, including, in the last year, some would be scalpers who thought they could get away with selling tickets to the show, and a collection of heirs who wanted to sell a Mary Pickford Oscar for charity.

For Sattar Attiya the American invasion of Iraq helped his bodybuilding career in an unexpected way. The chaos and open borders meant he could get proteins and nutritional supplements which were not available under Saddam Hussein's regime.
When Oklahoma is mentioned in conjunction with June's N.B.A. draft, it is usually in a conversation about the Sooners sophomore forward Blake Griffin.

ALBANY - Scratch those plans for the first casino on a subway line. Plans to build a casino at the Aqueduct racetrack have collapsed, the latest victim of the financial turmoil that has stilled the credit markets. Delaware North, the Buffalo Company that was contracted to build and operate the casino, has not been able to get the financing to raise $370 million it was due to pay the state.That leaves the state with yet another hole to plug in its ever leakier budget.

It may well be a sign of how desperate everyone is for money these days that a herd of hundreds of people in dark suits lined up under Washington's overcast skies this morning to get into a meeting at the Commerce Department. The topic was how to get a share of the $7 billion Congress wants sprinkled around the country over the next two years to expand access to high-speed Internet.

Seven New York City employees will be presented with the 2009 Sloan Public Service Awards in recognition of their service to the city government. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is to present the awards Wednesday in a ceremony in the Great Hall of the Cooper Union. The awards, created in 1973, are administered by the Fund for the City of New York and financed by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation."At a time when the press daily uncovers stories of corporate incompetence and financial mismanagement, the 2009 Sloan Public Service Award winners are a powerful reminder of real accomplishments achieved by dedicated public servants," Mary McCormick, the president of the fund, said in a statement.

There it was, buried in a video montage that kicked off the Walt Disney Company's annual meeting Tuesday: the first true glimpse of Johnny Depp as the Mad Hatter in Tim Burton's upcoming "Alice in Wonderland." Victorian top hat, crimped hair that sticks straight out, and swirl of brightly colored make-up on his eyes, cheeks and lips that resembled the blur of a pinwheel blowing in the breeze.

Real estate prices in Colombia have increased steadily because of political stability and a growing economy.
Honda has advanced the on-sale date of its new 2010 Insight gas-electric hybrid to March 24 and announced a starting price for the base LX model of $19,800.
Dozens of letters from victims of Bernard L. Madoff have poured into federal district court in lower Manhattan before his expected guilty plea on Thursday.

In a victory for St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan after a yearlong battle with preservationists, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted Tuesday to approve a slightly smaller version of a planned $830-million medical tower, a key component of the hospital's $1.63-billion, two-tower plan to modernize its facilities.

A Senate committee approved on Tuesday a bill that would in effect block Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's bid to seek a third term by requiring a referendum in any city that wanted to revise its term limits laws. Though approval by the Senate Elections Committee is a significant step forward for a bill that just a few months ago seemed to have little chance of getting anywhere in Albany, the bill's sponsors have an uphill battle ahead of them. Passage is far from certain on the floor of Senate or the Assembly, where the bill passed through a legislative committee late last month.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's fortune is getting some new management. The Quadrangle Group, the firm picked by Mr. Bloomberg last year to invest his billions in a blind trust while he is New York's mayor, announced Monday that it had hired three heavy-hitting money managers.
The U.S. ambassador's residence in Dublin, built in 1776, is one of two estates in Phoenix Park -- the other is the home of the Irish president.

Former comedian Al Franken of Minnesota does not have a seat yet in the Senate chamber - the election results showing him ahead of Norm Coleman, the Republican, have yet to be certified and the outcome remains in dispute. But Mr. Franken did have a place today at the Senate Democrats' weekly lunch in the Capitol, and party officials said he was in town "preparing for his transition."

The name recalls another anti-hero, but as the new T Men's Fashion Spring 2009 issue reveals, the sartorially bold artist/filmmaker Steve McQueen is the real deal. McQueen's eye-popping get-up - red suede shoes, an off-the-shoulder kaffiyeh and an ankle-length Yohji Yamamoto skirt - mirrors his work's envelope-smashing aesthetic. We're guessing he didn't wear a motorcycle jacket to shoot his award-winning film about an I.R.A. prisoner's hunger strike, but you still might mistake him for the new King of Cool.

My first post today looked at one of the less offensive recent instances of guerrilla marketing. The second examined what seemed to be a bad accident in the Ladies' Mile Historic District. This third post combines a bit of both.John Weiser, who lives in the neighborhood, was plagued by a street-level billboard for Western Union, newly slathered upon the corner storefront at Broadway and 22nd Street; a building that once served as the Brooks Brothers headquarters but was more recently a home furnishing store. The sign heralds the company's educational fundraising campaign: "Can one word change the world? Yes!" He sent the photo to City Room, pointing to what appeared to be graffiti on the poster. "It's beginning to look like the '70s around here," he said, not intending this as a compliment.

Sooner rather than later, was the answer given today by Representative Steny Hoyer, the Democratic majority leader in the House, when asked about a vote on the bill that would give residents in the nation's capital a full-voting representative. But while he offered up other matters as possible items on the agenda for the next few weeks, including stem cell research, he didn't want to be pinned down on a firm timeline for the D.C. action, citing negotiations that continue to prevent the bill from getting to the floor.

PARIS - There is a show in town that everybody should see. "Voids, a Retrospective," which runs through March 23 at the Centre Pompidou, is not listed in the official exhibition program and is as hard to find as it is mesmerizing. For the record, it's on the fourth floor.

TORONTO - It had been almost 20 years since I saw Mike Schmidt swing a bat. To a kid growing up near Philadelphia in the 1980s, the anticipation of the Phillies slugger's stepping to the plate was extraordinary. Every time Schmidt swung, there was a chance for a home run. He was the greatest power hitter of his time. But Schmidt did not hit moon shots; he hit line drives to all fields that carried farther than everybody else's.

Rob Tanis-Evon could not quite believe his eyes on Monday, as he came around the corner from the ABC Carpet and Home store at Broadway and 18th Street to encounter this shocking wreckage. He photographed it and shared it with friends on Facebook, sending shivers through more people on Monday night. What could possibly have landed on the car to cause such damage? What happened to the people inside? And what was going to fall next?Yet the thing that really stood out, he said, was "the casual interest of those in the area." (You can even make it out in the picture. No one has stopped to gape.) Mr. Tanis-Evon lives and works in Manhattan, so he is familiar with the phenomenon of pedestrian nonchalance. But it seemed almost inexplicable in this case. "I wasn't alarmed because the rest of the 'pack' wasn't," he recalled in an e-mail message on Tuesday morning. "A bit concerning, now that I think of it."

Yesterday at Balkinization, Andrew Koppelman published a lengthy post on the issue of whether Barack Obama is a socialist, the charge that many are now hurling at him. Via a long historical review of left political responses to capitalism, Koppelman argues that "Obama properly belongs in a specific anti-socialist movement on the left, Social Democracy, which accepts a capitalist economy but demands a strong state to moderate its failures and excesses."

We're past the midpoint of Paris fashion week, and the shows go on (and on). How the critics are still writing is beyond us. But they are, so Scorecard is keeping tabs of who they're loving and who they're not. Today, we've brought together choice sound bites from reviews of Christian Lacroix, Comme des Garçons, Dries Van Noten, Emanuel Ungaro, Givenchy, Haider Ackermann, Hussein Chalayan, Karl Lagerfeld, Sonia Rykiel, Stella McCartney, Tao, Veronique Branquinho and Undercover. Rei Kawakubo's archetypal riff at Comme des Garçons kept the critics on their toes, while the back-to-the-future aesthetic of Karl Lagerfeld left them feeling that the designer shouldn't quit his day job at Chanel just yet.

Karl Lagerfeld selects from all the Chanel motifs the ruffled white collar seen on Coco Chanel in a famous photograph. He drills down on this flourish, adding white petal cuffs and big boutonnieres (all removable), and gives a solid foundation of impeccable tailoring with almost invisible geometric seams in the black tweed jackets.

Ever wonder what it was like at the meeting when a classic film was being born? If so, check out the Mystery Man on Film blog, which has posted what is says it a link to the 125-page transcript of the story conference for "Raiders of the Los Ark" that included producer George Lucas, director Steven Spielberg and screenwriter Lawrence Kasdan.

For a literary honor that didn't exist before 2004, the Story Prize - which recognizes the best story collection to be published each year - has quickly established itself as a nifty jewel in a writer's crown. Its top award ($20,000 and an engraved silver bowl) is the richest available for a single book of fiction, and the prize ceremony is a congenial, clubby affair reminiscent of "Inside the Actor's Studio": the three finalists read from their work, then cross the stage to sit in leather armchairs and take questions from the prize's director, Larry Dark. That all of this happens in celebration of the short story can seem almost wondrous; as Lorrie Moore, who knows something about short stories, writes in the current New York Review of Books, this is "a genre that since the invention of television has been continually pronounced both moribund and in a condition of renaissance (recovering from moribund.)"

Jean Manas, Deutsche Bank's chief deal-maker in the Americas, is leaving the firm "to pursue entrepreneurial opportunities," a spokesman for the bank confirmed Tuesday. The move was announced Monday in an internal company memo and was previously reported in The Deal.

The Acadie-Bathurst Titan of the Quebec Major Junior Hockey League is not going anywhere. The Titan had petitioned the league for a relocation request and had talks with the city of St. John's, Newfoundland. Last week, the Titan was granted a one-week extension in its relocation request but ultimately decided to remain in its present location of Bathurst, New Brunswick. Leo-Guy Morrissette, who has owned the Titan for 25 years, also announced yesterday that his children would be buying into the team.

President Obama's decision on Monday to expand embryonic stem cell research has again exposed divisions along ideological and religious lines. Although Mr. Obama's executive order to roll back this Bush policy had been anticipated, the timing of the announcement, several weeks into his presidency, suggested an effort to try to avoid having this charged issue derail other initiatives the administration pursued early on.

The last-minute settlement between Dow Chemical and Rohm & Haas ultimately shows the weakness of Dow's case. Dow is paying the full price of $78 a share and a ticking fee that works out to another 99 cents a share. In exchange, there will be a rollover by Rohm's two biggest shareholders, Paulson & Company and the Haas Family Trusts, of $2.5 billion of the consideration into Dow perpetual preferred shares.

Here's a quick break from the tussle over what's driving climate change and what to do about it. As Richard McCammon, a student from Oklahoma said overnight, there is plenty of agreement on steps to improve the environment and boost the world's non-polluting energy choices. It's time to step back and marvel at the turn of the seasons -- in this case the advent of spring in the Northern Hemisphere.

General Manager Omar Minaya said this morning that the Mets had released reliever Duaner Sanchez. His diminished velocity and spotty command this spring stood out among a crowded pack in the bullpen. After returning last season, Sanchez never truly recovered from the two shoulder operations that interrupted a once-promising career.
The Federal Reserve chairman Ben S. Bernanke on Tuesday called for a broad reworking of how the government regulates the financial system to prevent future financial meltdowns.

The state is banning most smoking in restaurants and bars. Gov. Tim Kaine signed a bill that generally restricts smoking to separate rooms that have their own ventilation. It takes effect Dec. 1. Mr. Kaine had been working for years for a total ban on smoking in all restaurants, but compromised with lawmakers in the bill that passed last month. The measure also exempts private clubs and open-air outdoor areas of bars.

A man was charged with murder in the fatal shooting of a pastor during Sunday services in Maryville. The man, Terry J. Sedlacek, 27, of Troy, was charged with first-degree murder and aggravated battery, said a spokeswoman for the Madison County Prosecutor’s Office. The gunman strode into First Baptist Church, exchanged words with the Rev. Fred Winters, then fired a .45-caliber semiautomatic pistol until it jammed. Mr. Winters, 45, died of a single shot to the heart, the coroner said.

A career criminal whose escape with his gun-toting wife from an East Tennessee courthouse left one guard dead and another wounded entered a guilty plea in Kingston and was sentenced to life without parole. The man, George Hyatte, 37, pleaded guilty to first-degree murder in the 2005 fatal shooting of Wayne Morgan; attempted first-degree murder in the wounding of another guard, Larry Harris; and felony escape. His wife, Jennifer Hyatte, a former prison nurse who met and married him behind bars, received the same sentence in 2007.

A federal judge has turned down a request from the impeached former governor, Rod R. Blagojevich, to have Chicago’s top federal prosecutor and his staff thrown off the corruption case against him. Mr. Blagojevich had argued that removing United States Attorney Patrick J. Fitzgerald from the case was necessary because the prosecutor made inflammatory remarks about him at a news conference after Mr. Blagojevich was arrested on Dec. 9.

The Justice Department may have hoodwinked a defendant in a high-profile terrorism case into thinking his plea bargain would protect him from further prosecutions, a federal judge said. A hearing in Federal District Court in Alexandria was the latest in which the judge, Leonie M. Brinkema, questioned the Justice Department’s tactics in pursuing a criminal contempt case against the defendant, Sami Al-Arian, a former professor at the University of South Florida accused of being a leading Palestinian terrorist. Judge Brinkema gave Mr. Al-Arian’s lawyers 10 days to file papers seeking dismissal of the case on the grounds that prosecutors failed to keep promises made under the plea bargain.

Nathan Lee Murphy, an amateur paleontologist charged with taking a fossil of a rare turkey-size dinosaur predator from private land near Malta, pleaded guilty to a state charge of felony theft. Mr. Murphy, once a highly regarded paleontologist, led teams that found other unusual dinosaur fossils in north-central Montana, including a rare mummified dinosaur named Leonardo. Federal authorities have also charged Mr. Murphy with a felony for the alleged theft of dinosaur fossils from public land. Those charges are pending.

Robert Gallucci, dean of the Georgetown University School of Foreign Service, will become the fourth president of the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation in July. He takes over the foundation, one of the country’s largest, at a time when its assets, like those of most other foundations, have fallen while demands for its help are increasing. Before joining Georgetown in 1996, Mr. Gallucci held a variety of posts at the State Department, including serving as chief negotiator during the North Korean nuclear crisis in 1994 and as deputy executive chairman of the United Nations commission overseeing disarmament in Iraq after the first gulf war. He will replace Jonathan Fanton, MacArthur’s president since 1999.

About 500 people were evacuated from National Jewish Health in Denver when a maintenance worker mistakenly mixed two chemicals used to maintain a swimming pool, setting off toxic fumes. Forty-four people, including at least two children, were sent to area hospitals with nausea and respiratory distress after the mixture of sodium hypochlorite and hydrochloric acid sent fumes through underground tunnels that connect the hospital’s campus. None of the injuries appeared to be serious, said William Allstetter, a hospital spokesman. Among those evacuated were 90 children who attend a special school for students with respiratory problems at National Jewish. The maintenance worker was preparing the chemicals to put in the school’s swimming pool, Mr. Allstetter said, and “he probably picked up the wrong bucket.”.

Guy Carbonneau was fired as the coach of the struggling Montreal Canadiens, hockey’s most historic franchise that is in danger of missing the playoffs in its 100th season. The timing of Monday’s move was a bit surprising because the Canadiens were in the playoff race with 16 games left in the regular season. General Manager Bob Gainey, who preceded Carbonneau as the coach three years ago, will return behind the bench when Montreal plays Edmonton at home Tuesday.

United States immigration officials have agreed to let foreign athletes keep playing in the country as long as they leave after 10 years and apply for a new visa. The change came in a new policy memo issued by United States Citizenship and Immigration Services, after months of lobbying by sports leagues and lawyers for foreign athletes.

After poor results with free agency last year, the Jacksonville Jaguars vowed to revamp their aging roster through the draft. They made an exception for the three-time Pro Bowl left tackle Tra Thomas, who signed a three-year contract Monday, filling the team’s most glaring need. Thomas, 34, who allowed just two sacks in 658 pass attempts last season with Philadelphia, is expected to step into a starting role in place of the free agent Khalif Barnes and provide leadership on a team that finished 5-11 last season, then parted ways with three captains. A Hillsborough County Sheriff’s spokeswoman said Hayes was taken to a hospital by a friend Saturday. Hayes, 21, was treated and released. Deputies arrested 19-year-old Shevelle Bagley on Saturday afternoon. The sheriff’s spokeswoman says Hayes and Bagley got into an argument, which led to Bagley grabbing a pair of scissors and stabbing Hayes in the head. He managed to get the scissors away from her, but authorities say she then grabbed a knife and stabbed him in the neck. Bagley was charged with aggravated battery with a deadly weapon. stab (AP).

The Brawn team made its Formula One testing debut, with Jenson Button setting the fourth-fastest time at the Circuit de Catalunya in Barcelona, Spain. It marked the team’s first full test since Ross Brawn announced last week he bought out the former Honda team, clearing the way for a full lineup of 20 cars at the Australian Grand Prix this month. Button showed the new BGP 001 car will be competitive, clocking his best time of 1 minute 21.140 seconds after 82 laps. BMW Sauber’s Nick Heidfeld was fastest in 1:20.338, with Ferrari’s Kimi Raikkonen and Toyota’s Jarno Trulli also topping the Brawn car. brawn.

Sun worshipers who bought their tickets to the Coachella music festival in April for the express purpose of seeing Amy Winehouse’s performance will have to content themselves with the dozens of other bands in the lineup. Her representatives told Reuters that since she was charged with assault in London last week, Ms. Winehouse, the British soul singer, will not be able to obtain her work visa in time to attend the festival, in Indio, Calif., where she was scheduled to sing on April 18. The assault charge stems from a Sept. 26 incident when a fan named Sherene Flash said Ms. Winehouse struck her after Ms. Flash asked to take her picture. Ms. Winehouse is scheduled to appear in a British court on March 17 to answer the charge. Coachella, whose headliners include Paul McCartney, the Killers and the Cure, runs from April 17 through 19. ... In other summer festival news, the promoters of the Glastonbury Festival in Britain announced that its headliners would include Blur and Neil Young; they join Bruce Springsteen, who was previously announced. The festival runs from June 24 through 28.

A Brazilian actor who has dubbed Sean Penn’s voice into Portuguese in the past says he will not take a job re-recording Mr. Penn’s dialogue for the film “Milk,” Variety reported. Marco Ribeiro, a performer who supplied Mr. Penn’s voice in dubbed versions of the movies “All the King’s Men” and “21 Grams,” is also a pastor at the Assembly of God church in Rio de Janeiro. “I did not feel comfortable with the job,” Mr. Ribeiro said, according to Variety. “My voice is involved with other causes, and for the same reason I have refused to work on certain types of advertising.” “Milk,” directed by Gus Van Sant, won Mr. Penn an Academy Award for his performance as Harvey Milk, the pioneering gay politician. The film, which has already been playing in Brazilian theaters with Portuguese subtitles, is expected to reach a wider audience when a dubbed version is broadcast on television.
Ken Burns’s 12-hour history of the national parks, which will be shown by PBS in September, will be his last documentary with financing from General Motors.

The Public Art Fund, a New York-based organization that helps to produce temporary art installations throughout the city, announced that its director, Rochelle Steiner, had resigned. Perhaps the best-known work produced by the fund under Ms. Steiner’s direction was Olafur Eliasson’s “New York City Waterfalls” last year. The Public Art Fund said that Ms. Steiner would leave her post on April 15 to pursue other projects; a committee has been formed to find a successor.

A roster of productions already familiar to New York theatergoers took top honors Sunday at the Laurence Olivier Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Tonys. “Black Watch,” above, Gregory Burke’s play about a Scottish army regiment’s deployment to Iraq, took four awards, the most of any show, including best new play and director (John Tiffany); a Stateside production ran at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn last year. The West End production of “Jersey Boys,” the musical about Frankie Valli and the Four Seasons (which has played at Broadway’s August Wilson Theater since 2005), won for new musical. And Yasmina Reza’s domestic comedy “God of Carnage” won best new comedy; a Broadway production is scheduled to open at the Bernard Jacobs Theater on March 22. Derek Jacobi was named best actor for his portrayal of Malvolio in “Twelfth Night,” and Elena Roger won best actress as Édith Piaf in “Piaf.”.

U2 announced that it would play Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on Sept. 24 as part of its tour to promote its new album, “No Line on the Horizon.” The band said it would also perform in Chicago on Sept. 12, Toronto on Sept. 16 and Boston on Sept. 20. The tour begins in Barcelona on June 30 and continues in Europe in July and August. More American dates for fall are expected. ... The Juilliard School has created a special chair for Alan Gilbert, who begins as music director of the New York Philharmonic in September. Juilliard said this was the most extensive connection yet between the conservatory and a music director of the orchestra, its Lincoln Center neighbor. Mr. Gilbert is expected to coach singers and chamber groups, work with conducting students, serve as a guest teacher in some classes and occasionally lead the Juilliard Orchestra.

Performance Space 122 has announced that the third annual Spalding Gray Award has been given to Radiohole, an experimental theater troupe in Williamsburg, Brooklyn; the group recently produced the well-received piece “Anger/Nation” at the Kitchen. The award is administered by P.S. 122, the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis and relatives of Mr. Gray, the monologist and performance artist, who died in 2004. This year, the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh is also participating as a member of the consortium. The award provides for a full production of a Radiohole piece that will be performed at P.S. 122, the Walker and the Warhol Museum during the 2009-10 season; an unspecified cash stipend is included. The two previous recipients of the award were Heather Woodbury, the writer and performer, in 2006, and another independent theater troupe, the National Theater of the United States of America, in 2007.

New films by Conor McPherson and Marshall Curry and a documentary about the New York rock club CBGB are among the features that the 2009 Tribeca Film Festival announced for its World Narrative, World Documentary Feature and Discovery categories. Mr. McPherson, the playwright of “The Seafarer” and “Shining City,” is the writer and director of “The Eclipse,” a film about a widower who notices strange phenomena in his house. Mr. Curry, whose documentary “Street Fight,” about Cory Booker’s run for mayor of Newark, was nominated for an Academy Award in 2005, is the director of “Racing Dreams,” about the national go-kart racing championships. Also on the lineup is “Burning Down the House: The Story of CBGB,” about the famous East Village performance space and its battle to remain open. The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 22 to May 3.

ESSEX--Winfield Scott Jr.,known to his friends as "Skip", was the first trader to have seats on both the New York and London Stock Exchanges. He was also a professional white hunter in East Africa, a partner in Hunters Africa and had a coffee farm in Rhodesia, before independence. He died suddenly February 20th at his home in Wellington, FL where he lived with his fiancee, Helene Jackson ("Danny") Magill. He was 66. Mr. Essex was an honorary member of the East African Professional Hunters' Association, an organization in Kenya that governs big game hunting and a partner in Philadelphia Investors in Pennsylvania. He was a member of the Brook Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club, and the Holland Lodge all in New York City and also the Racquet Club and Philadelphia Club in Philadelphia, PA. Mr. Essex was admired for his impeccable dress, gourmet cooking, wit, intelligence, and eye for the fairer sex. Mr. Essex grew up in Columbus, Ohio. He attended Washington and Lee University and received his BA degree from the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. Three children survive him from his first marriage to Brenda Teagle Callaway: Lee Essex Doyle of Boston; Amanda Teagle Essex of New York; and Winfield Scott III of Westport, Conn. He has a fourth son, William David Scott Essex, of Dublin, Ireland, from his second marriage to Victoria Thompson Essex. Survivors also include his brother Richard Essex and his daughters Helena and Isabella of London and five grandchildren: India Lee Doyle, Wyatt Addison Doyle, Hunter Scott Essex, Sydney Essex and Campbell Essex. A toast to Mr. Essex will be held at the Brook Club in New York City on April 16th at 6 pm. His ashes will be scattered over the plains of his beloved Botswana by his family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust, PO Box 15555, Nairobi, Kenya.

GANOE-FRANCES--Sue Williams, beloved wife of Charles S. Ganoe, died of heart failure on March 3 in Princeton. Born in Philadelphia, Susie was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Norris Williams II. Her father, a survivor of the Titanic, was twice U.S. tennis singles champion, held five U.S. and one Wimbledon doubles title, won a gold medal at the 1924 Olympics and played on seven winning Davis Cup teams. Susie graduated from Oldfields School. An avid gardener, she was a member of the Garden Clubs of Princeton and Philadelphia. She was an accredited Judge for the Garden Club of America, and won many blue ribbons exhibiting at Philadelphia and other flower shows. She was also a member of the Ausable Club, St. Huberts, NY. In addition to her husband, she is survived by two daughters, Hemsley Hughes of Glendale, NY and Alice Ryden of Larchmont, NY, three grandchildren and three brothers. Burial in the Adirondacks will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to SAVE, 200 Herrontown Road, Princeton, NJ 08540 or North Country SPCA, 23 Lake Shore Drive, Westport, NY 12993.

HASKIN--Marvin Edward, M.D.,F.A.C.R., F.A.C.P., died unexpectedly at Bryn Mawr Hospital at the age of 78. He was Professor and Chairman of the Department of Diagnostic Radiology at Hahnemann University for 22 years. Dr. Haskin graduated from Central High School, received a BA from Temple University in 1951, and earned his Medical Degree from Temple University Medical School in 1955; he was inducted into AOA, the National Medical Honor Society, in his junior year. Internship and residency in Diagnostic Radiology were completed at Philadelphia General Hospital, during which he also served in the United States Air Force as Chief of Radiology at Andrews Air Force Base in Washington, DC. He became a Diplomat of the American Board of Radiology in 1961. From 1961 to 1969, he served as Chief, Diagnostic Radiology at Philadelphia General Hospital, Associate Radiologist at Hahnemann Medical College and Hospital, and Research Assistant Professor of Physiology and Biophysics, also at Hahnemann, pursuing his many research interests especially those involving cardiac modeling, nosocomial infection, and the physics necessary for the continued evolution of diagnostic radiology technology. From 1969 until 1991 Dr. Haskin was as Professor and Chairman of Diagnostic Radiology at Hahnemann University in Philadelphia, PA. During his tenure at Hahnemann, he mentored innumerable radiology residents and fellows. He delighted in designing the then-new radiology department, which included one of the first digital imaging rooms in this region, a new technology at that time. He continued to avidly pursued his interests in the physics of newer radiologic technology, and was a pioneer in the development and use of computer transmission of image and medical information systems. He was responsible for bringing the CT scanner to Hahnemann, the first located in the City of Philadelphia. Dr. Haskin is an author or editor of 15 books, most prominently Roentgenologic Diagnosis, the several editions of which have been translated into multiple languages including Japanese, Italian, Spanish, and Serbo-Croatian. The three-volume edition of Surgical Radiology followed and was equally successful. He has published nine book chapters and 84 peer-reviewed papers in scientific journals, and had presented over 100 papers at national and international scientific meetings. He was a founding member of the Society for Computer Applications in Radiology, on the Editorial Board of The Journal of Digital Imaging, appointed to the Executive Committee for the Medical Devices Standard Management Board (ANSI), and was a reviewer for The American Journal of Roentgenology, The Annals of Internal Medicine, and The Journal of Digital Imaging... He was a member of numerous local and national medical societies, including the American Association of University Radiologists, The Society of Magnetic Resonance Imaging, and the New York Academy of Sciences. He was a Fellow of The American College of Physicians, The American College of Radiology, The Philadelphia College of Physicians, and a member of the Royal College of Physicians and the Royal College of Medicine. He retired in 1991 to pursue, with typical enthusiasm, his interests in teleradiology and antifomitic technology. He currently holds multiple patents in these areas. He immensely enjoyed his retirement in the company of his wife of over 35 years, Pamela Herr Haskin, M.D., a relationship grounded in mutual adoration. He delighted in the antics of his beloved Newfoundland dogs. This kind and gentle man will also be very sorely missed by his son, Kenneth Geoffrey, an architect in Wynnwood, PA, his sister Lillian Siegel, and his nephew Dr. Everett Siegel, both of Baltimore, M.D. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, March 14, 12 Noon, at the Haverford Friends Meeting, 855 Buck Lane, Haverford, PA (directions: 610-649-3445, or www.Haverford friendsmeeting.org). A Reminiscence Luncheon for friends and family will follow at the Cynwyd Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his honor may be made to the Newfoundland Club of America Rescue Fund, 1004 Hwy 78 So., Mt. Horeb, WI 53572; or to Francisvale Home for Smaller Animals, 328 Upper Gulph Road, Radnor, PA 19087. Services handled by - Auer Cremation Services of Pennsylvania, Inc. - Harrisburg, PA.

CHAPIN--Schuyler. The Board of Trustees and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague Schuyler Chapin. Schuyler spent literally his entire life in support of Carnegie Hall, attending concerts here throughout his childhood and teenage years; stewarding Steinway & Sons as a young executive; making recordings at Carnegie Hall while at CBS Records; serving as a Trustee and Honorary Trustee of Carnegie Hall; and aiding in City support during his period as Commissioner of the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, when he served as an Ex-Officio Trustee of Carnegie Hall. His knowledge of Carnegie Hall's acoustics, musical and performance history, finances, and institutional plans was unparalleled. Schuyler was a true ambassador for Carnegie Hall, and he straddled its historic mix of artists, audiences, and philanthropists with aplomb. We extend our deep condolences to Catia, his sons Henry, Theodore, Samuel, and Miles, and their families. Sanford I. Weill, Chairman Clive Gillinson, Executive and Artistic Director

Updated | 9:56 a.m. An episode of “Big Love,” the HBO series about a polygamous Mormon family, has courted controversy with the Mormon church and prompted an apology from the network — but not edits — before the show has aired, The Associated Press reported. The episode of “Big Love” scheduled for Sunday will show a character portrayed by the actress Jeanne Tripplehorn undergoing an endowment ceremony, a religious rite in which members recite religious teachings and reenact scenes from the Bible in preparation for their places in heaven. The church considers the rite sacred, and only members in good standing may participate in or view it. In a statement, the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints said, “Certainly church members are offended when their most sacred practices are misrepresented or presented without context or understanding,” according to the A.P. HBO said that it did not intend to cause offense to the church and apologized, but that the ceremony was an important part of the episode. In a statement, the show’s creators, Mark V. Olsen and Will Scheffer, said they “took great pains to depict the ceremony with the dignity and reverence it is due,” according to The A.P.

U2‘s new album, “No Line on the Horizon” (Interscope), is No. 1 on this week’s Billboard chart, with 484,000 in sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That is the biggest opening week of any album so far this year, but it is significantly lower than the band’s last album, “How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb,” took in, 840,000 sold in late 2004. Overall album sales have fallen more than 35 percent over the last five years, but U2 was also hurt when “No Line on the Horizon” leaked on the Internet almost two weeks early. According to the media measurement company BigChampagne, more than 445,000 people downloaded it illegally before the official release date. Also this week, Taylor Swift‘s “Fearless” (Big Machine) dropped one spot to No. 2, with 52,000 sales, and the indie-rock-slash-alt-country singer Neko Case reached No. 3 with 44,000 sales of her new album, “Middle Cyclone” (Anti-). Lady GaGa‘s “Fame” (Interscope), which was released last summer but has lately been shooting up the chart, rose three spots to No. 4 with 42,000 sales, and Nickelback‘s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) held at No. 5 with 36,000.

What began as a humble farewell from Michael Jackson to 200,000 or so of his fondest fans has somehow metamorphosed into a spectacle. The concert promoter AEG Live announced that it would add 13 dates to Mr. Jackson’s “This Is It” concert series, which begins on July 8 at London’s O2 Arena. The king of pop’s first 10 shows sold out quickly on Wednesday morning, The Associated Press reported, and his new dates, also at the O2 Arena, will take him through Sept. 10, with more concerts expected to be announced. In a news conference on March 5 to announce the first 10 shows, Mr. Jackson described them as a “final curtain call,” adding, “When I say this is it, I mean this is it.”

A new movie written by Adrienne Shelly will make its debut at the Tribeca Film Festival, which announced its remaining feature selections on Wednesday. “Serious Moonlight,” written by Ms. Shelly, who was killed by a worker in her apartment building in 2006, stars Meg Ryan as an attorney who discovers her husband (Timothy Hutton) is having an affair with a younger woman (Kristen Bell); it is directed by Cheryl Hines (of “Curb Your Enthusiasm”) who starred in Ms. Shelly’s film, “Waitress.” Other films announced include the documentary “Love the Beast,” directed by the actor Eric Bana, about his obsession with his Ford XB Falcon Coupe; “The Girlfriend Experience,” a new feature by Steven Soderbergh; and “Rudo y cursi,” a film by Carlos Cuarón, which reunites the actors Gael García Bernal and Diego Luna, of “Y Tu Mamá También.” The Tribeca Film Festival runs from April 22 to May 3.

Sotheby’s cut the pay package of its chief executive, William F. Ruprecht, for 2008, though Mr. Ruprecht earned at least $2.1 million last year, Bloomberg News reported, citing financial filings from the auction company. The previous year, Mr. Ruprecht earned an annual salary of $700,000, as well as $6.3 million in stock awards and $2.6 million in other compensation from a cash incentive plan as Sotheby’s earned a record profit of $213 million, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and cited by Bloomberg. The art market is believed to have peaked in 2007, and Sotheby’s profit in 2008 was $28.3 million, the worst year the company had seen since a $20.7 million loss in 2003. The publicly traded auction house is seeking to cut $100 million in costs this year and has estimated that 250 employees will lose their jobs.

After 24 years on display just outside the Security Council Chamber at the United Nations, a 1955 tapestry version of Picasso’s 1937 antiwar painting “Guernica” was pulled down on Wednesday and flown to London. A moving crew wore white gloves while peeling the 22-foot-long wool weaving from its Velcro mounts and then rolled it snugly in tissue paper, cotton batting and waterproof polyethylene. Overseeing and photographing the process was Cynthia Bronson Altman, the curator for the tapestry’s owner, Happy Rockefeller, who is lending it for a year to the Whitechapel Art Gallery in London.

The Associated Press has filed a countersuit against the artist Shepard Fairey, who created the famous “Hope” poster of Barack Obama, The A.P. said in a statement. Mr. Fairey, whose poster is based on an A.P. photograph taken by Mannie Garcia in 2006, filed suit in February, seeking a declaratory judgment that would rule that the poster does not infringe on The A.P.’s copyrights, and enjoining The A.P. from asserting its copyrights against Mr. Fairey or his company, Obey Giant. In its counterclaim, filed Wednesday in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York, The A.P. said that Mr. Fairey was “fully aware” that his poster was based on a copyrighted image, and that he “misappropriated The A.P.’s rights in that image”; The A.P. said that it made “every effort amicably to enter into a license and avoid litigation” with Mr. Fairey. In its countersuit, The A.P. seeks damages and injunctive relief on claims of copyright infringement.

Chris Brown, the R&B performer who was charged with two felonies after being accused of attacking his companion, the pop star Rihanna, has removed his name from the ballot of the Nickelodeon Kids’ Choice Awards, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown was nominated in the categories of favorite male singer and favorite song (for “Kiss Kiss”). The nominations were announced before a Feb. 8 incident in which Mr. Brown fought with Rihanna in his car. On March 5, he was charged with assault likely to cause bodily injury and making criminal threats; his arraignment is scheduled for April 6. The Kids’ Choice Awards are to be broadcast on Nickelodeon on March 28.

But one of the journalistic challenges here is that we don't know a lot about MRSA, and so the challenge in my Thursday column was how to raise public concern about a legitimate public health issue without becoming alarmist and exaggerating the danger. It's a very fine line, especially when we journalists tackle issues in science or public health, and I trust you'll let me know if you think I tumbled off this tightrope.
