CHAPIN--Schuyler. Citizens Committee for New York City sends condolences to the family of Schuyler Chapin, a great friend and champion since our founding. Henry Cornell, Chairman Peter H. Kostmayer, President

SMITH--R. Leigh Jr.,died March 10 at age 82 at New York State Veterans Home, St. Albans, New York. He was a former journalist and longtime public-relations executive for Gulf+Western Industries, Hertz, Renault, the Dodge division of Chrysler Corp. and the Saturday Evening Post. He enlisted in the U.S. Navy during World War II and served as a quartermaster aboard submarines in the Pacific including the USS Piranha and USS Bonita. He graduated in 1949 from Washington & Lee University, where he edited the college newspaper Ring Tum Phi. As a journalist he was a newscaster for WSLS radio in Roanoke and a reporter at the wire service INS. He also did freelance work for the late financial journalist Sylvia Porter. He was an avid media watcher who got home delivery of five New York City newspapers in the 1950s and 1960s, and later in life turned to Fox News on TV. He was a member of U.S. Submarine Veterans of World War II, Sigma Delta Ch news fraternity, and Public Relations Society of America. Husband of Miraed Peake Smith, father of Randy Smith of New York and Wilson Smith of Memphis, TN, and grandfather of Will and Jack Smith.

ABC's ''Dancing With the Stars'' attracted its largest season premiere to date as the debut episode of its eighth season garnered 22.5 million viewers on Monday night, according to Nielsen's estimates. That's roughly a million more than the debuts of its last two editions, in the fall and spring of 2008, attracted. The premiere of ABC's new show ''Castle'' drew 11.6 million viewers at 10, trailing CBS's ''CSI: Miami'' (14.8 million), but ABC still led the night with its most Monday viewers on average in close to three years. Fox was runner-up with ''House'' (12.1 million) and ''24'' (11.3 million), while CBS finished a close third with ''Two and a Half Men'' (13.3 million viewers). NBC ranked a distant fourth with ''Chuck'' (5.7 million), ''Heroes'' (6.6 million) and ''Medium'' (7.1 million).

Thirty pairs of long leather gloves for Beyoncé's number at the Academy Awards. Quick-turnaround envelopes specially designed with extra clear windows or zip-tabs. High-end countertops that look like marble but are in fact recycled glass bonded with cement. These are among the products still manufactured in New York City, by an estimated 7,000 companies. While some larger factories remain, particularly in the garment district, most have just a handful of employees. One, D. S. & Durga perfumers, amounts to David Moltz, a 28-year-old musician who has a lifelong fascination with scent, distilling oils and mixing colognes, and his companion.

CHAPIN--Schuyler. The Trustees and staff of New York City Center express great sadness at the passing of Schuyler Chapin, a great friend of City Center and devoted supporter of the arts. We send our heartfelt condolences to our longtime Board member Theodore Chapin and his entire family.

Just what makes a good lawyer? In trying to answer that question, professors at the University of California, Berkeley, have come up with a test that they say is better at predicting success in the field than the widely used Law School Admission Test.

Even as President Obama floated the idea of negotiating with moderate elements of the Taliban, Afghan and foreign officials here said that preliminary discussions with the Taliban leadership were already under way and could be developed into more formal talks with the support of the United States. The Afghan government has been exploring the potential for negotiations with the Taliban leadership council of Mullah Muhammad Omar and with a renegade mujahedeen leader, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, after receiving overtures from them last year, the officials said. The proposal for talks gained additional momentum from an endorsement by Saudi Arabia and the change to a civilian government in Pakistan, both of which increased political pressure on the Taliban to compromise.

Higher-education experts say the Obama administration has proposed the broadest overhaul of federal college aid programs in decades. But for all the focus on the size of the budget, it has been hard to tell just what this means for students and their families. One problem is that whatever the president proposes, Congress actually holds the purse strings. So there is no way to know just what aid will really be available down the road. But based on what administration officials have said, here is a summary of how the budget as proposed would affect funds available to help pay for college.

EPSTEIN--Sally Spero. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center are profoundly saddened by the passing ofSally Spero Epstein; mother-in-law of our esteemed Board Chairman and friend David A. Tanner and mother of David's wife Peggy. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to Mr. Tanner, his wife and their entire family. Steven M. Safyer, M.D., President, Montefiore Medical Center

Adding another chapter to the legal history of ''Sahara,'' the 2005 action movie adapted from Clive Cussler's novel, below, a judge has ruled that Mr. Cussler must pay $13.9 million in legal fees to the production company that made the film, The Associated Press reported. In 2004 Mr. Cussler sued Crusader Entertainment, the company owned by the billionaire entrepreneur Philip F. Anschutz, saying that he was not permitted final approval on the script as his contract mandated, which resulted in the box office failure of the film. Crusader countersued, saying that it had overpaid for the rights to Mr. Cussler's work because he had overstated the sales of his novels. In 2007 a jury delivered a split decision. On Monday Judge John P. Shook of Los Angeles County Superior Court ruled that Mr. Cussler had violated a contract that mandated the payment of legal fees if either side breached the agreement.

The Dalai Lama delivered one of his harshest attacks on the Chinese government in recent times on Tuesday, saying that the Chinese Communist Party had transformed Tibet into a ''hell on earth'' and that the Chinese authorities regarded Tibetans as ''criminals deserving to be put to death.'' ''Today, the religion, culture, language and identity, which successive generations of Tibetans have considered more precious than their lives, are nearing extinction,'' said the Dalai Lama, 73, the spiritual leader of Tibetans.

EPSTEIN--Sally Spero, adored wife and best friend of Alan, beloved mother of Elizabeth and Peggy and their husbands, Richard Kadin and David Tanner, devoted grandmother and admirer of Allison and Peter Kadin, Eric, Mark and Robbie Tanner, died on March 10, 2009. She will be remembered as a wife, mother, grandmother and friend who was dedicated to her family, her many friends and the friends of her children and grandchildren. Sally loved her family unequivocally and her enthusiasm for their pursuits made her their biggest fan. Alan was the love of her life and their model marriage of 55 years was infused with a joy and mutual affection that is unrivaled. She will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester in Rye, NY at 2pm on Thursday, March 12, 2009. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Sally's memory can be made to The Summer Camp, 8 Church St., Bridgton, ME 04009.

When Libya gave up its nuclear and chemical weapons programs in late 2003, President George W. Bush pointed to the decision as a victory in Washington's so-called war on terror and as a potential model for pressing Iran and North Korea to give up their weapons programs, too. But now Libyan officials say they are dissatisfied with the way the deal worked out, insisting that the United States has done too little to reward Libya's concessions. Officials here say they believe that Libya's limited payoff undermines the credibility of the United States as it presses other nations to abandon weapons programs.

Fishing olives out of a jar is often an involuntary catch-and-release program. Count on a sleek, new stainless-steel olive spoon to facilitate the task, even from a narrow container or an opaque pottery one. It is also effective for scooping gherkins and cornichons from their containers, as it has an opening that allows the juice to drain.

PETERSON--Richard W.,on February 23rd, 2009 at age 84. Beloved husband of Marie L., loved father of Christine Peterson, Ph.D., Karen L. Aaro and her husband Thomas, grandfather of David Aaro. Also survived by his sisters Ethel Kidwell, Eleanor Asher, brother Wilbur, the late Walter, and many nieces and nephews. He was a proud veteran of WWII serving the Navy during the Pacific Theater, and retired VP of the Bank of NY. Reposing Thursday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Flower Funeral home 714 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers. Mass Friday 10am Church of St. Anthony (Nepera Park). Cremation private. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Methodist Church Home For The Aged, 4499 Manhattan College Pkwy Bronx, NY 10471 will be appreciated.

Most economists still do not expect the Chinese economy to suffer a broad decline in prices this year, but statistics released on Tuesday did provide disturbing whiffs of possible deflation. Consumer prices were 1.6 percent lower last month than a year earlier, the first decline since December 2002, the National Bureau of Statistics announced in Beijing. February's result represented a precipitous drop from an inflation rate of 8.7 percent in February of last year, when rising prices were a top priority for the Chinese government.

Highlighting continued internal divisions at the Screen Actors Guild, the board of the union's Hollywood division, its largest unit, urged the union's national board on Monday to allow members to vote on the ''last, best and final offer'' presented to the union last month by a coalition of Hollywood studios. The national board, which recently ousted the union's executive director and chief negotiator, previously voted to reject that offer. The Hollywood board does not want to accept the offer; its majority, which supported the ousted negotiator, hopes a rejection by the full membership will lead to a strike-authorization vote, which is opposed by the national board majority. The actors' union has been working without a contract since the end of June. The Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents the studios, said on Feb. 19 that it would leave its offer on the table for 60 days.

Gov. David A. Paterson will introduce legislation this week that would roll back the state's tough drug sentencing statues, known as the Rockefeller drug laws, by restoring significant power to judges in sentencing first-time, nonviolent drug offenders, a senior administration official said. But the official said the governor's bill would leave out other measures proposed by Democrats in the Assembly in an effort to reach a compromise with the closely divided Senate.

The Dalai Lama is a man of peace and forbearance. So it is a measure of Tibet's suffering and growing desperation that he accused China's government on Tuesday of turning Tibet into a ''hell on earth.'' We only hope Beijing heeds his warnings before it is too late. The Tibetan spiritual leader still advocates a ''middle way'' of nonviolence. But China stubbornly refuses to pursue serious compromise on Tibet.

Two Brooklyn teenagers and their father were among four people charged with gang assault in a fight that preceded the death of another teenager early Sunday, although it was unclear if the fight caused the death, the police said. The victim, Sharif Abdallah, 17, collapsed while he and others chased at least two of the suspects away from a party in Prospect Park shortly after midnight on Sunday, his friends and the police said. Sharif was pronounced dead at New York Methodist Hospital.
CHINN--Geoffrey. The Jewish Reconstructionist Federation mourns the death of Geoffrey Chinn, board member, Vice President of the NY/NJ Region, a creative thinker and an inspiring leader.

Fans ofDavid Alan Grier, the comedian and ''In Living Color'' alumnus, will have to sate themselves with his performances on ''Dancing With the Stars'' for now: his Comedy Central series, ''Chocolate News,'' has not been renewed, a representative for the network said, confirming a report that appeared on the Web site of The Baltimore Sun, baltimoresun.com. Despite its title, ''Chocolate News'' was less a news parody than a sketch-comedy show that featured Mr. Grier, above left, playing characters, from fictitious rappers to the poet Maya Angelou, and delivering satirical commentaries about race. The series, which made its debut on Oct. 15 before the presidential election, ran for one 10-episode season.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about an armed attack by suspected Irish Republican Army dissidents on a group of British soldiers outside their base in Northern Ireland misstated the location of The Sunday Tribune, the newspaper that received a telephoned claim of responsibility for the attack. It is in Dublin, not Belfast. The article also misstated the timing of what would have been the start of the victims' next assignment, in Afghanistan. It was a matter of hours, not days.

ROTHSCHILD--Fritz A. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the death of Dr. Fritz A. Rothschild, a longtime member of our faculty who received rabbinic ordination and a doctorate from JTS. Dr. Rothschild, formerly the Joseph J. and Dora Abbell Professor of Jewish Philosophy, was one of the world's foremost experts on 19th and 20th Century Jewish philosophy and wrote extensively on the philosophy of Abraham Joshua Heschel. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Lotte, and his son, Jonathan. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Gershon Kelst, Board Chair.

''Are you ready to get on the Purim party bus?'' Rabbi Saadya Notik screamed Tuesday to a group of women, many in costume, standing on a sidewalk at Mount Holyoke College. The women rushed to the charter bus, a virtual nightclub on wheels, where neon lights pulsed, smoke billowed from underneath the seats and music blared.
To the Editor: Re ''The Computer Will See You Now'' (Op-Ed, March 6):

Even as rival Democrats are lining up to challenge to Kirsten E. Gillibrand next year, the new senator is acquiring a major advantage: much of Hillary Rodham Clinton's extensive New York network of campaign operatives, donors and advisers. Since Ms. Gillibrand was appointed in January, top Clinton aides have signed on to her campaign or Senate staff. Others with ties to Mrs. Clinton have worked to help smooth over rifts with groups that are skeptical of Ms. Gillibrand's relatively conservative voting record. Some of Mrs. Clinton's top presidential fund-raisers have joined Ms. Gillibrand's finance team to help her raise the $70 million or more she will need for the 2010 and 2012 elections.

CAMPBELL--John P. The partners of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt & Mosle LLP regret the passing of John P. Campbell, their partner and counsel for many years. John was born on September 1, 1923 in Utica, Oneida County, New York. He always referred to himself as a "bib-overall guy from Oneida County". John was educated at Middlesex School, Concord, Mass.; Harvard College and Columbia Law School. His attendance at Harvard was interrupted by his service in the U.S. Army Air Force in Europe from late 1942-1945. John started his practice with our firm in 1952, was a partner from 1959-1993 and counsel until 2008. He was a member of the Harvard Club and the Links Club in New York, the Metropolitan Club in Washington, DC and the US Saint Andrews Society. He was an outstanding lawyer and a delightful person. He will be sorely missed and fondly remembered. John is survived by his wife Eleanor Saggerman Campbell (whom he married in August, 1949); four children - Samuel R. Campbell, Frederick B. Campbell, Louisa Campbell Travis and Camilla Campbell Platt; and seven grandchil- dren.

ANITA LO, the executive chef at Annisa in Greenwich Village, made a mushroom soup a few years ago that was inspired by the colors of late autumn. It had acorn squash, acorn jelly and warm shades of brown, gold and orange. ''I was working in earth tones,'' she said. For this column, she adapted her recipe for spring, resulting in a clear soup of mushrooms and daikon (or tofu). The broth is gently flavored with garlic, onions, soy sauce, Shaoxing wine and kombu, Japanese seaweed. There's much to chew on.

Nobody is born in a trunk anymore, to use the old expression describing an immersion from early childhood in showbiz. But Lorenzo Pisoni, the star and co-author of the new solo show ''Humor Abuse,'' came pretty darn close. Mr. Pisoni spent a good portion of his early childhood locked in a trunk -- yes, an actual trunk -- strapped to his father's back. Don't worry. Dad was not a monster mixing exercise with a penchant for brutality. He was a professional clown -- white makeup, red rubber nose and all -- and the opening of his act involved having his son pop out of a steamer trunk Dad carried onstage on his back.

Bernard L. Madoff is facing life in prison for operating a vast Ponzi scheme that began at least 20 years ago and consumed billions of dollars of other people's money. While his fate will not be certain until he is sentenced, his lawyer told a federal judge on Tuesday that he intended to plead guilty on Thursday to all the criminal charges that federal prosecutors had filed against him -- a list that could yield a prison sentence of 150 years.

While praised by scientists, President Obama's decision to lift restrictions on federal financing of embryonic stem cell research could cause state governments and philanthropists to pull back on billions of dollars they have pledged for such work. A number of states and philanthropies rushed in to fill the gap after President George W. Bush imposed the restrictions in 2001. California voters alone approved spending $3 billion over 10 years, making the state's taxpayers the nation's largest financial backers of the research.
Opening This Week

The Energy Department made a $500 million math error a year ago when it withdrew its support from a ''near-zero emissions'' coal plant in Illinois, Congressional auditors will say in a report to be released Wednesday. The error led the department to say mistakenly that the project, known as FutureGen, had nearly doubled in cost -- an increase the Bush administration deemed too expensive.

Michael Napolitano speaks to his fifth-grade class in the Morrisania section of the Bronx like a basketball coach. ''You -- let me see you trying!'' he insisted the other day during a math lesson. ''Come on, faster!'' Across the hall, Larita Hudson's scolding is more like a therapist's. ''This is so sloppy, honey,'' she prodded as she reviewed problems in a workbook. ''Remember what I spoke to you about? About being the bright shining star that you are?''

Greg Hayworth, 44, graduated from Syracuse University and made a good living in his home state, California, from real estate and mortgage finance. Then that business crashed, and early last year the bank foreclosed on the house his family was renting, forcing their eviction. Now the Hayworths and their three children represent a new face of homelessness in Orange County: formerly middle income, living week to week in a cramped motel room.

Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner's efforts to flesh out the details of the administration's economic plans referred incorrectly to the American Enterprise Institute, which employs Vincent Reinhart, a senior fellow who commented on the administration's strategy. It is a conservative policy research group -- not a lobbying organization.

CHINN--Geoffrey. Miller Canfield mourns the sudden and tragic loss of our friend and colleague, Geoffrey, an extraordinarily gifted, accomplished and honest attorney. He will be missed both professionally and personally. Our deepest condolences to his wife Carol, his six children and his many grandchildren.

MODELL--Michael S. March 11, 1952-April 28, 2001. Happy Birthday, dear Michael. We will light a candle in your memory. We know that you are with Dad, and we will love you and miss you both forever. Mom, and the Family

Icon Brickell, a new condominium complex in downtown Miami, was intended to be Jorge Perez's answer to the Time Warner Center, the massive mixed-use building developed in Manhattan by his longtime business associate, Stephen M. Ross. Mr. Perez, the chairman of the Related Group (an affiliate of Mr. Ross's New York-based Related Companies) and the undisputed condo king of South Florida, has peppered the waterfront with residential units in recent years, but he has never built anything on the scale of the $1.25 billion Icon Brickell.

ON Jan. 22, President Obama signed an executive order banning torture and establishing a panel to examine America's interrogation methods. The ban on torture is a major step toward reclaiming our heritage as a nation of laws and a people of character. And it will enhance the country's security by undermining Al Qaeda's most effective recruiting theme -- its portrayal of the United States as a dishonorable superpower that sanctions the type of abuses so graphically captured in the images from Abu Ghraib. The challenge now for the panel is to reconsider the ancient practice of interrogation and bring it into the modern age. That will require making an effort to objectively assess which strategies are actually effective.
Ready for Another Run Siena forward Josh Duell leads the country in fat jokes, leg ailments and perspective on how to pull an upset in March.

DUBLIN When the next United States ambassador to Ireland takes office, he or she also will take up residence in one of Dublin's most spectacular houses -- and have the former ambassador, Thomas C. Foley of Connecticut, to thank for its recent restoration.

Alf Pike, one of the last two surviving members of the Rangers' Stanley Cup-winning team of 1940 and later a Rangers coach, died March 1 in Calgary, Alberta. He was 91. His death was confirmed by his family.

Schedule information on Monday with a theater review of ''Blood Type: Ragu,'' at the Actors' Playhouse in Greenwich Village, omitted the last digit of the telephone number to call for tickets. The number is (212) 868-4444.

The Sundance Film Festival has found its new director, and it is an old hand. John Cooper, who was long in charge of programming for the festival, was named to the director's post. That job fell vacant last month when Geoffrey Gilmore resigned to become artistic director of the Tribeca Film Festival. Mr. Cooper has worked with the Sundance Institute, which oversees the festival, since 1989. In a statement announcing the choice, Robert Redford, the institute's president and founder, called Mr. Cooper ''a natural choice.''

A gunman shot and killed at least 10 people, including several members of his family, on Tuesday afternoon in what officials said was the worst shooting in Alabama. The gunman led the police on a chase through Geneva County in southern Alabama, firing at officers before fatally shooting himself at a business where he was once employed, law enforcement officials said.

Chalk it up to lingering drowsiness after the time change on Sunday or the damp chill in the air after an unseasonably mild weekend. Whatever the case, the audience that filled the Metropolitan Opera to capacity on Monday night hardly seemed to muster the kind of unbridled enthusiasm you might have expected for what was, on balance, among the company's finest offerings so far this season. The opera was Dvorak's ''Rusalka,'' a charming, sumptuously scored fairy-tale setting from 1901, presented in a popular 1993 storybook tableau by Otto Schenk and Günter Schneider-Siemssen.

As the military pushed toward what it said would be a final victory over Tamil separatist fighters in the north, a suicide bomber in the south on Tuesday killed 14 people and wounded 46 others, including a government minister, according to official reports. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but such bombings are the earmark of the separatists, and the attack seemed to demonstrate that they were still capable of carrying them out despite the loss of almost all the territory they had once controlled in northern and eastern Sri Lanka.
To the Editor: Re ''Middle East Reality Check'' (column, The New York Times on the Web, March 9):

The City Education Department, working to avoid a possible strike by unionized workers, wants to require companies that win preschool busing contracts this year to hire the drivers and other employees from companies that now hold the contracts. The new contract provision would essentially guarantee the jobs of many of the most senior unionized drivers, matrons and mechanics who could lose their jobs if their employers failed to win or did not bid on the new contracts.

NOTRE DAME 61, RUTGERS 50 Luke Harandogy took the court with a purple bruise under his right eye. He personified the Fighting Irish nickname, and his teammates played with a bravado to match his shiner. The Irish, seeded 10th, held 15th-seeded Rutgers to 33 percent shooting by mixing defenses. ''That's encouraging we didn't have to get 82 to win a game,'' Irish Coach Mike Brey said.
To the Editor: Re ''Turning to Cube Steak, and Back to Childhood'' (March 4):

PELTZ--Faye. The Board of Directors, Store Owners and staff of Key Food Stores Co- Operative, Inc. are saddened by the passing of Faye Peltz, loving wife of our Director Samuel Peltz. Mr. and Mrs. Peltz were honorees of Colel Chabad, to which they gave generously, as well as to UJA Federation and other worthy charities. The Key Food family extends its most heartfelt sympathy to her husband Samuel Peltz, sons Steven and Jay, daughter Helene and five beloved grandchildren. Funeral, March 11, 12pm at Boulevard Chapels, Hewlett. Shiva at Peltz residence.
$3.5 MILLION 32-18 137th Street

They have built their careers on waiting for the right pitch. But Adam Dunn and Bobby Abreu never expected to need that skill in the off-season. The most patient hitters in baseball had their patience tried like never before. Dunn ranks first in the majors in walks since 2004, and Abreu is second. Dunn is all but a lock for 40 home runs a season, Abreu for 20. Both routinely drive in and score 100 runs. Yet both were unemployed a month ago.

After the final whistle, the Inter Milan players traded their sweaty, black-and-blue-striped jerseys for their Manchester United opponents' bold red ones, and the crowd cheered. The postgame ritual provided the perfect cover for José Mourinho to slip away unnoticed by more than 85,000 people at San Siro stadium on Feb. 24. Mourinho, the Inter manager, has done few things quietly since taking over Italy's top club in June. But after the 0-0 draw in the Champions League knockout round, during which he repeatedly jumped from his bench to the sideline to shout instructions to his players and to argue with the referee, Mourinho left the field through a private door without shaking hands with his opposite number, Alex Ferguson.
To the Editor: Re ''So You're Dead? Don't Expect That to Stop the Debt Collector'' (front page, March 4):

THE co-owners of Rockefeller Center have hired a restaurant consultant to find a new tenant for the Rainbow Room after the Cipriani organization's management of the storied space ends on July 31. A spokeswoman for Tishman Speyer said the firm had hired Barry Wine to ''search for another great restaurateur who will operate the Rainbow Room in a manner befitting one of New York's most beloved and iconic institutions.'' The spokeswoman, Suzanne Halpin, said the firm wanted the space to ''house a world-class restaurant.'' She added that it had no intention of converting it to office space, as had been rumored.

Purim was Tuesday, and in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, a 6-year-old boy, dressed as a king, went out with his father. Purim commemorates a time when the Jewish people of Persia were saved from extermination, a story that is told in the Book of Esther.
To the Editor: Re ''Coat-Check Anxiety? Get Over It'' (Feb. 25):

Prosecutors indicted 56 people, including two retired generals, on Tuesday in a continuing investigation into a possible coup plot in Turkey. Another 86 suspects are on trial in the case, and 77 other suspects are awaiting charges.

To the Editor: It is with delight that I came across both Elaine Louie's recipe for chana Punjabi (The Temporary Vegetarian) and Mark Bittman's vegan beet-salad recipe (''A Divorce for Beets and Goat Cheese'') in the same week. My only regret is Ms. Louie's statement that the vegetarian feature was destined for an early retirement. A largely vegan and occasional vegetarian diet has been a fantastic way to manage my weight and avoid high cholesterol and other maladies of middle age. Visiting our local farmers' market and eating the organic seasonal vegetables I find there are among the joys of life.

GOTTLIEB--Louis Leon. Loving husband of Sybil, father of Diane and Robert, Judith and Andrew, grandfather of Joanna, Stewart, Miles, Harry and Leah. Brother of Charlotte Zavon, beloved uncle, cousin and friend. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Chapel, 21 Broad St., Mt. Vernon at 12 noon.

To the Editor: Michelle Obama's well-muscled arms do more than suggest the strength and confidence that it will take to restore America (''Should Michelle Cover Up?,'' by Maureen Dowd, column, March 8).

The space shuttle Discovery is set to lift off Wednesday night on a two-week mission, carrying a replacement part for a water recycler and a final set of solar arrays for the International Space Station. At a news conference on Tuesday, Kathy Winters, NASA's shuttle weather officer, said a forecast of clear skies and light winds provided ''90 percent go weather'' for the launching, scheduled for 9:20 p.m.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Tuesday about the country singer and actor Jimmy Boyd referred incorrectly to the character whose boyfriend he played in the situation comedy ''Bachelor Father.'' She was the bachelor father's niece, not his daughter.

AT dinner with an Italian friend, he began musing about potatoes. He started with a rant about fast food. ''You'd think that peeling and frying a real potato was the equivalent of going to the moon,'' he said. Then he described a childhood comfort food, one that seemed both more rustic and more sophisticated than a similar one I ate: not-bad mashed potatoes integrated with wretched canned peas. His version: mash potatoes with olive oil, incorporate cooked dandelion greens, top with bread crumbs, bake.

Both tenants and landlords seem to be growing afraid of commitment these days. With the economic outlook murky at best, fewer of them want to tie themselves to long leases. In Manhattan, where office leases often last 10 years, there has been a noticeable uptick recently of leases lasting only one to three years. Some prominent landlords have begun playing up the availability of short-term leases in their buildings.

Three of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company's most senior dancers -- and among the most respected artists in contemporary dance -- were told two weeks ago that their contracts would not be renewed at the end of their current period of employment in May. Holley Farmer, Daniel Squire and Koji Mizuta, who have all performed with the company for more than a decade, were informed of the decision by Trevor Carlson, executive director of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company. The action, which was not formally announced to the news media, comes as the company is rehearsing for its season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, which will open on April 16, Mr. Cunningham's 90th birthday.
CANDIDATE A former prime minister of Iran, Mir Hussein Moussavi, announced Tuesday that he would run as a moderate in the June presidential race, the Iranian Student News Agency reported.

The United States Department of Justice opened an investigation into the Maricopa County Sheriff's Office for suspected civil rights violations. The sheriff's office is run by Joe Arpaio, who has gained national attention for ordering deputies to patrol rural highways, raid Latino neighborhoods and storm municipal buildings in the dead of night in search of illegal immigrants. ''Our investigation will focus on alleged patterns or practices of discriminatory police practices and unconstitutional searches and seizures conducted by the M.C.S.O., and on allegations of national origin discrimination,'' Loretta King, acting assistant attorney general, wrote in a letter to Sheriff Arpaio.

Dr. Charles S. Lieber, a clinical nutritionist who upset scientific dogma by showing that alcohol in excess can cause cirrhosis despite an adequate diet, died on March 1. He was 78 and lived in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. The cause was stomach cancer, his daughter Sarah said.
Time: About 45 minutes
Among Ireland's gifts to New York, add chocolates. Lily O'Briens Chocolate Cafe, selling bonbons made in Ireland, has opened on Bryant Park.

It took decades, myriad scandals and a muckraker to change the rules for how senators are chosen. Now leading lawmakers want to close what they see as a lingering century-old loophole in the 17th Amendment's demand that each state's senators be ''elected by the people thereof.'' The calls are being fueled by this year's flurry of tangled appointments to the Senate, which now counts four new members who have yet to face election. There was nearly a fifth until one senator changed his mind about departing.

ASCHENBRENNER--Rudolf, passed on March 8, 2009, after a painful and courageous struggle with a terminal illness. Survived by loving wife Annelie, sons Peter and Alan, stepdaughter Marion, and their respective partners Karen, Nelson and Gary. Born 1915, in Vienna, worked as structural engineer in Austria, Switzerland, Argentina and the U.S. Helped develop structures for Apollo moon shot program. Contributed to theories on thin shell design. We miss you. Wake on Wednesday 2-4, 7-9pm. Funeral on Friday 12:15pm. Contact Schmitt Funeral Home, 516- 785-3380.

PETERSON Jude, Easthampton, MA, 43 of Carillon Circle passed away on February 18, 2009 at his home. Son of Kate (Butler) Peterson of Weston, MA and the late Hall J. Peterson. Brother of Temple Peterson of Brattleboro, VT and Aimee Peterson of Warwick, RI. Uncle to a niece and a nephew. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 21, 2009 at 1:00pm at the Boucher-O'Brien Funeral Home, 7 Pleasant St., Easthampton, MA followed with burial in Main St. Cemetery. Donations may be made to a charity of ones choice.

Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. said Tuesday that the United States was still weighing which candidate to support for NATO's top post, in a sign that Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen of Denmark, who has been viewed as the favorite to become secretary general, may not have sufficient support among NATO's 26 members. After talks in Brussels on Tuesday, Mr. Biden was careful to keep Washington's options open. ''It's a very strong field,'' he said at a news conference at NATO headquarters. ''We don't think as a matter of policy any member nation should be ruled out as being able to provide a secretary general, but we have not taken a position.''

In what may be among the longest-running and widest-ranging cases of academic fraud, one of the most prolific researchers in anesthesiology has admitted that he fabricated much of the data underlying his research, said a spokeswoman for the hospital where he works. The researcher, Dr. Scott S. Reuben, an anesthesiologist in Springfield, Mass., who practiced at Baystate Medical Center, never conducted the clinical trials that he wrote about in 21 journal articles dating from at least 1996, said Jane Albert, a spokeswoman for Baystate Health.

The Your Money column on Jan. 24, about paying employment taxes for nannies and other household workers, misstated the rule for paying federal unemployment taxes. You are liable for the tax if you pay total cash wages of $1,000 or more in aggregate in any quarter of a calendar year -- not $1,000 per employee. (A reader pointed out the error recently, discovered while preparing her taxes.)

After much debate and many mixed feelings, the Big East invited all 16 of its teams to Madison Square Garden for its conference tournament this year. And by the end of the first two games Tuesday, two teams that would not have qualified for the tournament under last year's format had advanced to its second day with upset victories.

''Race,'' a new play by David Mamet, will have its world premiere on Broadway at the end of this year, one of its producers, Jeffrey Richards, said on Tuesday. Mr. Richards declined to say whether the play was comedy or drama, satire or parody. ''I think the title speaks for itself,'' he said. ''It's a great new work by Mamet,'' who won the Pulitzer Prize for ''Glengarry Glen Ross.'' Rehearsals are scheduled to begin Oct. 26, with preview performances starting on Nov. 20 and opening night on Dec. 10. A Broadway theater will be announced later, Mr. Richards said. The production will not have an out-of-town run first. Mr. Richards is producing the play along with Jerry Frankeland Steve Traxler. Mr. Mamet was most recently represented on Broadway with revivals this season of ''Speed-the-Plow'' and ''American Buffalo''; his last new play on Broadway, ''November,'' ran from December 2007 to July 2008. Mr. Mamet could not be reached for comment.

ARMY The army's chief of staff, Gen. Edmond Rasolomahandry, warned Madagascar's feuding political leaders on Tuesday that the military would ''take a crucial decision'' if an agreement was not reached within 72 hours. On Thursday, a conference is scheduled to bring together the island's political, civic and religious leaders.

When John Marinatto arrived at Providence College as a freshman in 1975, he got a job as a basketball manager for Coach Dave Gavitt. The Providence sports information director at the time, Mike Tranghese, passed on a piece of advice that would resonate throughout Marinatto's career. ''Make yourself invaluable,'' Tranghese told him.

The 86 dancers at American Ballet Theater have agreed to accept a proposal by management that would eliminate the company's pension contributions and the dancers' vacation pay in 2009. Management made the request because of the financial crisis. and at the meeting on Monday, the dancers voted unanimously to approve the plan, Rachel S. Moore, the company's executive director, said. ''We are deeply grateful to them,'' she said. ''We are happy that we didn't have to lay off dancers or cut their salaries.'' The administrative staff has not been asked to cede vacation pay, but has also agreed to accept cuts in employer contributions to their pensions and to a sliding scale of salary cuts ranging from 1.5 percent to 10 percent.

Nashville — The invitation indicated only that the party on Wednesday night here was the “grand opening of Third Man Records.” But the 150 fans, friends and members of the media who showed up to the small warehouse in an industrial section of Nashville were given more than a tour of Jack White’s new label offices – they were present for the announcement and the debut of Mr. White’s new band, the Dead Weather.

Announcing plans for their 2009-10 season, leaders of the Goodman Theater in Chicago said they would produce a double-bill next January that is expected to move to Broadway immediately afterward: Eugene O’Neill’s “Hughie” and Samuel Beckett’s “Krapp’s Last Tape,” both starring Brian Dennehy.

At last night’s star-filled tribute to R.E.M. at Carnegie Hall, members of the alternative rock band, including its frontman Michael Stipe, gave a surprise performance with Patti Smith. Were you among the lucky few to catch the show? Send us your reviews.

On this week’s Popcast, Jon Pareles reviews “Scream” by Chris Cornell; Ben Ratliff on Robbie Fulks online offering, “50-Vc. Doberman”; Sia Michel looks at more big releases in March; and the Brooklyn band Bishop Allen performs in our studio.

After an auction that brought three serious bidders to the table, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, the educational and trade publisher that has lately struggled financially, has decided not to sell its trade and reference division, a storied publishing house whose authors include Philip Roth, Gunter Grass and Jonathan Safran Foer.

If you read the Arts section of The New York Times closely on Thursday (and even if not), you probably know that major American symphony orchestras have fallen on hard times financially. (Who hasn’t?)

Eric Simonoff, a star book agent who represents Pulitzer Prize-winning novelists Jhumpa Lahiri and Edward P. Jones as well as the memoirist-turned-novelist James Frey, is leaving the literary agency Janklow & Nesbit and joining William Morris, the global talent agency. Mr. Simonoff, 41, had been at Janklow & Nesbit for 18 years and was promoted to the role of director two years ago. He will take all of his clients with him when he joins William Morris on Friday.

The Chilean author Roberto Bolaño posthumously won the National Book Critics Circle award for fiction for “2666,” (Farrar, Straus & Giroux) a sprawling novel set in Santa Teresa, Mexico, that was published in translation in 2008. Dexter Filkins, a reporter for The New York Times, won the general nonfiction award for “The Forever War” (Alfred A. Knopf). The award for autobiography went to Ariel Sabar for “My Father’s Paradise: A Son’s Search for His Jewish Past in Kurdish Iraq” (Algonquin) and the prize for biography went to Patrick French for “The World Is What It Is: The Authorized Biography of V.S. Naipaul” (Knopf).
A California artist turned his desert property into an art studio, vacation home and mineral spa.
At a Bronx house that up to 30 men call home, cramped quarters are only the beginning.

LUCIE, Fla. -- For those of you who didn't watch Johan Santana pitch tonight and only noticed his pitching line -- two and two-thirds innings, four hits, three runs, two strikeouts, a hit batter -- worry not. Results do not matter, health does, and he left his 47-pitch outing against the Marlins convinced that he will stay on track to pitch the April 6 opener in Cincinnati.
LOS ANGELES -- It's been so long since Arizona has failed to make the N.C.A.A. tournament that Lute Olson's hair was . . . well, it was still white.
ATLANTA -- When Georgia Tech upset Clemson here Thursday, it was just the fifth time in the 56-year history of the A.C.C. tournament that a last place team won an opening-round game.

With golf and second home markets tied at the hips, property experts will be interested in U.K.-based Golf Monthly's selection of top courses in Europe. Few surprises make the list, which include Valderrama, the much-lauded course in Spain, and the Sporting Club in Berlin. Spoiler alert: Vilamoura in Portugal also made the list.

On Nov. 24, 1963, two days after John F. Kennedy's assassination, President Lyndon B. Johnson met with his principal national security advisers to consider the most volatile issue he had inherited: Vietnam. A coup at the beginning of November - approved by the Kennedy administration - had toppled Ngo Dinh Diem's government and taken his life. Concerns about the ability of his untested successors to withstand Vietcong insurgents backed by Ho Chi Minh's North Vietnamese Communist regime gave Johnson a sense of urgency about an issue that could threaten United States interests abroad and undermine his standing at home.

After No. 7 West Virginia's impressive 74-60 victory over No. 2 Pittsburgh in the quarterfinals of the Big East tournament on Thursday night, there was one question percolating in the press room. Could the league get three No. 1 seeds in the N.C.A.A. tournament?
Though “Tokyo Sonata” looks like a family melodrama, there is more than a touch of horror to its story of a downsized salaryman.

Over the course of the past week or so, while I was interviewing child psychiatrists about the exciting new field of developmental neuroscience, the phrase "the best and the brightest" came up twice.

A few minutes into the Louis Vuitton show this afternoon, I glanced over my shoulder at the people standing outside the clear plastic tent in the Cour Carree of the Louvre, and wondered what they must be thinking. Marc Jacobs was serving up a lot of delicious French cake, in the Marie Antoinette sense. The thinking behind the collection was light-hearted, it seemed to me. All those black taffeta rabbit ears, the marvelous stick pins tipped with fat pearls, the messy bouffants, the over-the-top boots laced with black velvet ribbon He was pouring on the French chic but, at the same time, not taking it too seriously. I was also glad to see Jacobs stick with the Paris theme from last season and push it in other directions. Of course, a lot of this ruched and ruffled glamour seems a parody of French high style, which was always over-the-top and not a little vulgar. But Jacobs played with that, too.

With its Insight model, Honda seeks to be the hybrid "for everyone."

So here we are at the World's Most Famous Arena amid what's been billed as one of the best Big East tournaments in the league's 30-year history. So what is everyone talking about today? None other than Dennis Wolff.

H. Rodgin Cohen, the senior partner of the law firm Sullivan & Cromwell and a preeminent adviser to financial firms around the world, is no longer under consideration to become deputy Treasury secretary, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

Inter Milan will not be coming to the United States to play in the Major League Soccer All-Star game. Inter Manager Jose Mourinho enjoyed his time in Los Angeles when he visited with Chelsea in 2006 and has decided to return with the Italian Serie A side.

This post is in honor of Michigan State's Kalin Lucas. He won the Big Ten Player of the Year. Kalin Lucas is a fine basketball player. But the fact that he's the best player in a league that could get eight teams in the N.C.A.A. tournament is an illuminating indictment of the talent level in college basketball this season.

Apparently, the folks behind "Watchmen" aren't too proud to beg. Yesterday, screenwriter David Hayter ("X2," "The Scorpion King") asked the blog Hard Core Nerdity to post an open letter to science fiction fans that pleads for repeat viewings over the coming weekend.

Earlier this week, I was testing Google Voice, which I reviewed in today's paper. One of its key features is managing text messages. They arrive on your Google Voice Web site like e-mail messages; you can search, sort, reply, forward, and, above all, keep them forever - an impossibility until Google Voice came along.

These have been a sad last few years for lovers of The Sporting News Baseball Guide series -- of whom there were tens of thousands -- because when the TSN Guide suspended publication after the 2006 edition, those of us who collected each book dating back decades no longer had a new tome to throw up on the shelf each spring. No longer would crinkled copies of 1950s Guides of Mantle and Mays share space with their Pujols and Jeter successors.

A year ago today, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced that he was resigning from office. His administration's intrigues, however, have long outlived his governorship, even issues not entirely connected to the main reason he resigned.

It has happened again. Not in the U.S. this time - where, gratefully, the spate of school shootings of that crescendoed with Columbine ten years ago next month, has not been the norm more recently. But that is no consolation at all to 12 sets of parents in Germany today, whose children were murdered in one of the places they should feel safest - their schools.

The crowded field to replace Robert M. Morgenthau as district attorney just got a little less crowded. Eric T. Schneiderman, a former trial lawyer who is now a state senator a representing Upper Manhattan and parts of the Bronx, said Thursday that he would not seek Mr. Morgenthau's seat.

The effects of the ailing American auto industry have moved north. Chrysler said that it would close plants in Canada unless it receives a $2.3 billion loan from the Canadian government and quick concessions from the Canadian Auto Workers union, reports Bloomberg.

The news broke this week that a couple of high-profile hotel companies are fiddling around with their brands. (I know branding can be boring, so I'll try and keep this light.) Hilton, which operates everything from Hampton Inns to the Waldorf Astoria, hired the former W hotshot Ross Klein to dream up a new hotel line called Denizen. Judging from the renderings, it's going to look sort of like what W would look like if you launched it now: more quirky, less glossy; more vintage, less mod; more flowers, less wenge wood. "Smart instead of slick" is how Klein put it to me. Hilton plans to open them in Austin, Abu Dhabi, Cancun, London, Mumbai and New York, to name a few places.

Updated, 5:15 p.m. | Bowling Green, the uneven gated ellipse at the foot of Broadway, evokes history more than most spots in New York City. Legend has it -- though historians give the legend almost no credence -- that Indian tribal leaders used the land for meetings and to negotiate the sale of Manhattan to Peter Minuit in 1626. What is known is that the site was a parade ground and cattle market in the Dutch era, which essentially ended with the British conquest of 1664.

Danny Cepero burst on the scene during the 2008 Major League Soccer season when he found himself starting in goal for the New York Red Bulls late in the season. And it was quite a professional debut when the native of Baldwin, N.Y., became the first M.L.S. goalkeeper to score a goal. Cepero went on to backstop the Red Bulls through two rounds of the playoffs before losing to Columbus in M.L.S. Cup '08.

In a footnote to the Ivy League season, Cornell said on Saturday that it erred in reporting the final score of its title-clinching victory over Penn on Friday night, and that the problem wasn't math. It was because the scorekeepers' computer was demolished by Cornell fans rushing the court, a university spokesman told The Associated Press, adding that the final score was 83-59, not 83-58. Marvel Entertainment announced this morning, according to reports in the Hollywood Reporter and the Associated Press, that it was shifting and delaying the release dates on several of its upcoming superhero films, to stop the projects from bunching up on one another and to create a dramatic progression in their storylines. With "Iron Man 2" set for May of 2010 and Sony Pictures' "Spiderman 4" for May of 2011, Marvel's "Thor" will arrive in June of 2011 and "The First Avenger: Captain America" a month later, all of this culminating - once the super-characters have been introduced in their own films - with the multi-character "Avengers" in the summer of 2012.

You have met Anita Tedaldi before on Motherlode. She is a military wife, living in Florida at the moment. It's just one of many places the Air Force has moved Anita, her husband, and their six children. Anita is a journalist. Or was a journalist. Or is trying to keep working as a journalist. But, as she writes in today's guest post, it is hard to maintain any kind of linear career when you are married to the military. Our story begins back in Sacremento, Calif., (or, as Anita describes it "three moves ago") when she was working for the a handful of local newspapers.

Bernard Madoff pleaded guilty this morning to 11 counts of fraud, money laundering, perjury and theft in a 20-year Ponzi scheme whose collapse erased as much as $65 billion supposedly in his customers' accounts. Since the fraud was revealed in December, the case has engendered tremendous public outrage, well beyond the anger of the thousands who lost their savings.

Job Smeets and Nynke Tynagel, the design duo known as Studio Job, defy the logic of contemporary Dutch design whereby objects should be humorous and quirky but functional nonetheless. Smeets and Tynagel's furniture and objects not only err on the side of dysfunction, but they are also distinguished by a distinct dark streak. On the occasion of Studio Job's first major retrospective, at Moss in New York, Felix Burrichter chatted long-distance with Smeets, the duo's mouthpiece, to talk about new projects, cultural DNA and maintaining optimism in times of recession.

The clean energy sector grew by leaps and bounds last year -- despite the global economic downturn and the brutal beating to the stock market. Revenues from the solar photovoltaics, wind power and biofuels sectors increased 53 percent in 2008, to $115.9 billion from $75.8 billion in 2007 - and are predicted to reach $325.1 billion in the next decade, according to a Clean Energy Trends report released this week.

My husband and I took out a private mortgage for four apartments in a co-op in 1998. It was an interest-only loan that was due to be paid off in 2004. In that year, we tried to sell our apartments in order to pay off the loan, but the buyer was unable to get a mortgage. We stopped making payments at that time. The lender has not moved to foreclose. Is there anything to stop us from just walking away?

Heston Blumenthal's restaurant the Fat Duck, in Bray, England, is back in business today two weeks after it was closed because dozens of diners said they'd gotten sick after eating there. Local health authorities allowed him to reopen the restaurant, one of the most acclaimed in the world, even though they have not announced what caused the outbreak and have not completed some tests.

Microsoft founder Bill Gates is the richest man again, overtaking investor Warren E. Buffett, as the global financial meltdown wiped out $2 trillion from the net worth of the world's billionaires, Forbes Magazine said on Wednesday.

Baugur Group, the high-flying Icelandic retail investor that crashed along with its nation's banks, said Wednesday that it would file for bankruptcy after a court called time on its efforts to reorganize.
Roche, the Swiss drugmaker, has struck a deal with Genentech to acquire all outstanding shares in the American biotech group for $46.8 billion, the two companies said Thursday.

John Paulson, the hedge fund veteran who famously earned an estimated $3 billion betting against subprime loans before the market downturn, has now set his sights on British banks, The New York Post reported.

The renowned investor Warren E. Buffett said he sees buying opportunities in the United States for his company, Berkshire Hathaway, as prices decline and competition from rival bidders decreases.

EBay's chief executive, John Donahoe, did nothing Wednesday to dispel ongoing speculation that the company is planning to put Skype, the Internet calling service it bought for $3 billion, on the block.

Bank of America has reportedly put a private bank it inherited from Merrill Lynch on the block, and the largest U.S. bank may try to sell other assets as well.

Trying to smooth out disagreements between American and European policy makers about how to address the economic crisis, President Obama called on foreign governments on Wednesday to increase their domestic spending to stimulate their economies and asked for greater coordination of regulatory oversight, The New York Times's Stephen Labaton reported.

Liechtenstein bowed to international pressure Thursday, saying it would adopt global standards on transparency and information exchange in tax matters, turning up the heat on Switzerland and other tax havens to follow suit, The New York Times's Matthew Saltmarsh reported.

Some 15 financial companies will meet Thursday with New York State's Insurance Superintendent to complain about a decision by MBIA, the world's largest bond insurer, to split its bond insurance unit into two companies, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Jim Ellis and Kevin Taweel used a search fund to acquire a $6 million roadside assistance company with 45 employees that they built into the nation's largest provider of insurance products to cellphone companies.

India's Satyam Computer Services, which has been struck by fraud, closes registrations for potential bidders on Thursday, starting a process to sell a majority stake in the company caught in the country's biggest corporate scandal, Reuters reported.

The Securities and Exchange Commission aims to issue a proposal in April to restore the so-called uptick rule and will look at other ways to address short-selling in the stock market, S.E.C. Chairwoman Mary L. Schapiro confirmed on Wednesday.
Despite tough fund-raising conditions for many start-up companies, those seeking cash in the field of virtual goods, online games or virtual worlds apparently aren't hurting, says GigaOm.

Big Drama, a colt who won five of his six starts as a 2-year-old, is out of the running for the Kentucky Derby after kicking himself in his stall in January. Big Drama turned in a solid workout March 1, but the trainer David Fawkes and the owner-breeder Harold Queen chose not to point toward the Derby, which will be run May 2. drama.

The San Diego Chargers and running back LaDainian Tomlinson agreed to a reworked three-year contract. “The alternative was just unthinkable; he belongs in San Diego,” Dean Spanos, the team president, said.

Despite a lengthy test session with Darren Cahill in Dubai, Roger Federer is still without a full-time coach. Federer, a 13-time Grand Slam singles champion from Switzerland, and Cahill, one of the most successful coaches in tennis, have long been considered a likely match. But Cahill and Federer’s agent, Tony Godsick, confirmed on Wednesday that Cahill and Federer would not be working together, in large part because Cahill was not prepared to travel as extensively as Federer would have required. roger.

Heather Mitts hit a post with her seventh-round shot, and Sweden defeated the United States, 4-3, on penalty kicks after a 1-1 tie in the final of the Algarve Cup women’s tournament in Faro, Portugal. Sweden went ahead on a goal by Lotta Schelin in the 19th minute. But the United States rallied when Shannon Boxx tapped in the equalizer at the back post in the 90th minute. algarve.

Peter Bromby of Bermuda was the winner in the Star Class regatta of the Bacardi Cup in Biscayne Bay. Bromby and Magnus Liljedahl kept the overall lead with two races to go in the regatta. John VanderMolen and Geoff Ewenson finished runner-up to remain second in the overall standings. bacardi.

The ultraniche perfumer Neil Morris works out of a fragrance studio in his Boston home, where he is his own creative director and perfumer. Morris is self-taught - he started composing in 1975 - and you can smell it in his work: this is artisanal, not corporate, perfumery. Lauder, P&G and LVMH, with their creative execs and focus groups, would never put out these scents. Morris's quality varies, but unlike with many of the large-brand perfumes, you can smell someone trying things out: How about this? How about that?

Gov. Bobby Jindal’s administration and the state’s Board of Elementary and Secondary Education have reached an agreement on the financing of Louisiana’s 69 public school districts. The administration is expected to propose a $3.3 billion spending plan for next year that includes no cuts, and the schools board agreed not to request an increase. The board will take a final vote on the matter on Thursday.

The engagement between Gov. Sarah Palin’s daughter Bristol Palin, 18, and Levi Johnston is off. Mr. Johnston, 19, told The Associated Press that he and Bristol Palin mutually decided “a while ago” to end their relationship. Mr. Johnston declined to elaborate. The two are the parents of a boy, Tripp, who was born Dec. 27. Governor Palin revealed her daughter’s pregnancy days after being named as Senator John McCain’s running mate on the Republican presidential ticket.

After years of legal wrangling, 75 white firefighters in Chicago will share a $6 million settlement reached with the city in a reverse discrimination lawsuit filed over a 1986 lieutenants’ examination. Concerned that it discriminated against black firefighters, the city “race normed” the test results. A jury later found the test was fair, a decision the United States Supreme Court upheld on appeal. Linda Friedman, a lawyer for the firefighters, may of whom have retired, said they could expect to receive their checks by this fall.

Highway crews carved through 10-foot snowdrifts from a blizzard as hundreds of stalled motorists waited in bitter cold. The storm was linked to at least four deaths. Interstate 29 was reopened from the Canadian border across North Dakota to Watertown, S.D., a distance of about 280 miles, highway officials said. Interstate 94 was reopened in both directions after hundreds of vehicles lined up to be allowed on the highway west of Fargo.

The space shuttle Discovery will remain on the ground until at least Sunday to repair a hydrogen leak that scrubbed a Wednesday launching. That will shorten what was planned as a 14-day mission, because the Discovery has to undock from the space station before the arrival of a Russian Soyuz spacecraft, scheduled to be launched March 26. If the Discovery is not launched by Tuesday, then the mission will probably be pushed to April, with repercussions to future shuttle missions and the construction of the space station. The hydrogen leak occurred near the connection of a vent line to the shuttle’s external fuel tank. The vent line allows excess pressure to flow away from the tank and away from the spacecraft.

A Superior Court judge in Riverside ruled that the man convicted of murder for setting a 2006 wildfire that killed five firefighters is mentally competent and that the penalty phase of his trial can continue. Judge W. Charles Morgan based his ruling on a 12-page report prepared by a court-appointed psychologist who examined the man, Raymond Lee Oyler. Mr. Oyler, 38, was convicted Friday of five counts of first-degree murder, 20 counts of arson and 17 counts of using an incendiary device. He could face the death penalty for setting an Oct. 26, 2006, blaze that overwhelmed five Forest Service firefighters in mountains 90 miles east of Los Angeles.

The federal Justice Department opened an investigation on Tuesday to determine whether civil rights violations were committed by the Maricopa County Sheriff’s Office. Sheriff Joe Arpaio gained national attention for ordering deputies to patrol rural highways and to raid Latino neighborhoods and municipal buildings in search of illegal immigrants. “Our investigation will focus on alleged patterns or practices of discriminatory police practices and unconstitutional searches and seizures conducted by the M.C.S.O., and on allegations of national origin discrimination,” an acting assistant attorney general, Loretta King, said in a letter to Sheriff Arpaio.
The country told international aviation and maritime authorities that it will launch a satellite in early April, the North’s official news agency and a news agency in the South reported on Thursday.

A news analysis article on Tuesday about President Obama’s decision to allow researchers using federal money to study more embryonic stem cell lines misstated, in some copies, the amount of money in a California initiative for stem cell research. It is $3 billion, not $10 billion.
Davey Johnson, the manager for Team USA in the World Baseball Classic, knows the Dutch take their baseball seriously. He was once their manager.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about new hands-off methods for studying wildlife misattributed one quotation and gave an incomplete attribution for another. It was Michael K. Schwartz, a research ecologist for the United States Forest Service, who said, “I got into the field to watch wild behavior and to hold an animal” — not Chuck Schwartz, leader of the Interagency Grizzly Bear Study Team in Bozeman, Mont., who was quoted later in the article.
Alex Rodriguez is not the only Yankees veteran recovering from surgery. Mariano Rivera, Jorge Posada and Hideki Matsui underwent operations in the off-season.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Wednesday about the appointment of John Cooper as director of the Sundance Film Festival, replacing Geoffrey Gilmore, referred incorrectly to Mr. Gilmore’s new job. He is chief creative officer of Tribeca Enterprises, which runs the Tribeca Film Festival, not artistic director of the festival.

The Critics’ Choice column on Monday, about new CDs including Kelly Clarkson’s “All I Ever Wanted,” misidentified the nationality of the musician and producer Dr. Luke, who worked with the Swedish songwriter and producer Max Martin on Ms. Clarkson’s second album. He is American, not Swedish.

An art review on Saturday about art fairs held in conjunction with the Armory Show misidentified the nationality of the artist Hayv Kahraman, whose paintings were on display at the Thierry Goldberg booth at the Volta fair. She is Iraqi, not Iranian. The review also misidentified the site of the Jonathan LeVine Gallery, whose booth, at the Scope fair, had an installation by Camille Rose Garcia. The gallery is in Chelsea, not Brooklyn.

A music column on Tuesday about the band the Roots misstated the nights the band’s drummer, Ahmir Thompson, better known as ?uestlove, will have a D.J. residency at the nightclub Le Poisson Rouge. It will be Thursday nights, starting March 26, not Tuesday nights.

An article on Wednesday about a series of debates between the liberal comedian Bill Maher and the conservative author Ann Coulter referred incorrectly to Senator John McCain’s daughter Meghan McCain, who wrote a blog post for The Daily Beast criticizing Ms. Coulter. Ms. McCain is the oldest daughter of the senator and his second wife, Cindy; she is not Mr. McCain’s oldest daughter. (His oldest is Sidney McCain, whom he had with his first wife, Carol.).

The Media Equation column on Monday, about possible ways to increase newspapers’ revenue, misstated the name of one newspaper that charges for its Web content. It is The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette, not The Arkansas Gazette. (The name was changed in 1991 when The Arkansas Democrat bought the assets of The Arkansas Gazette from Gannett.).

Chris Brown, right, the R&B performer who was charged with two felonies after being accused of attacking his companion, the pop star Rihanna, removed his name from the ballot of the Nickelodeon Kids’ Choice Awards on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Brown was nominated in the categories of favorite male singer and favorite song (for “Kiss Kiss”). The nominations were announced before a Feb. 8 incident in which Mr. Brown fought with Rihanna in his car. Last Thursday he was charged with assault likely to cause bodily injury and making criminal threats; his arraignment is scheduled for April 6. The Kids’ Choice Awards are to be broadcast on Nickelodeon on March 28.

The new U2 album, “No Line on the Horizon” (Interscope), tops this week’s Billboard chart, with 484,000 in sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan — the biggest opening week of any album so far this year but significantly lower than the band’s last album, “How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb,” which sold 840,000 in its first week in 2004. Overall album sales have fallen more than 35 percent over the last five years, but U2 was also apparently hurt when “No Line on the Horizon” leaked on the Internet almost two weeks early. According to the media measurement company BigChampagne more than 445,000 people downloaded it illegally before the official release date. “Fearless” (Big Machine) by Taylor Swift dropped one spot to No. 2, with 52,000 sales, and the indie-rock/alt-country singer Neko Case reached No. 3 with 44,000 sales of her new album, “Middle Cyclone” (Anti-). Lady GaGa’s “Fame” (Interscope), which was released last summer but has been shooting up the chart lately, rose three spots to No. 4 with 42,000 sales, while Nickelback’s “Dark Horse” (Roadrunner) held at No. 5 with 36,000.

An episode of “Big Love,” the HBO series about a polygamous Mormon family has courted controversy with the Mormon church.
A new movie written by Adrienne Shelly will make its debut at the Tribeca Film Festival, which announced its remaining feature selections on Wednesday.

What began as a humble farewell from Michael Jackson to 200,000 or so of his fondest fans has somehow metamorphosed into a spectacle. The promoter AEG Live said it would add 13 dates to Mr. Jackson’s “This Is It” concert series, which begins on July 8 at the O2 Arena in London. Mr. Jackson’s first 10 shows sold out on Wednesday morning, The Associated Press reported, and his new dates, also at the O2 Arena, will take him through Sept. 10, with still more concerts expected to be announced.

Second Stage Theater is postponing its summer production of “Mr. & Mrs. Fitch,” a new play by Douglas Carter Beane (“The Little Dog Laughed,” “Xanadu”), because of a scheduling conflict with the project’s director, Scott Ellis, the theater announced. “Mr. & Mrs. Fitch,” a comedy about gossip columnists, was to begin previews on June 16 but has been moved until the 2009-10 season. A spokesman for Second Stage said that Mr. Ellis, who directed “The Little Dog Laughed,” could not direct the production because he had been named supervising producer and director of the Showtime series “Weeds.” Second Stage said it would announce a replacement summer production soon.

GEZARI--Temima. Artist, died peacefully March 5, age 103. Memorial festival in June: temimagezari@gmail.com

BERNSTEIN--Sidney, of Coconut Creek, FL died on February 28, 2009, at the age of 70. Beloved of his Beverly. Proud father of Michael and Jamie (Grobman) Bernstein and Evan and Sherry (Bernstein) Schwartz. Adoring "Grandpa Shalom" of Joshua and Jacob Bernstein and Hailey and Alexa Schwartz. A graduate of Columbia and The Cornell Law School, he had a distinguished career as a lawyer and publisher spanning more than 40 years. He is past president of Congregation Beth El of Jolla and a member of the Board of Temple Beth Am, Margate, FL. His life was devoted to his children, his grandchildren, the law and Israel.

GURAL--Aaron. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, a man of great humor and integrity. Our sincerest condolences are extended to Jeff, Jane, Barbara and the entire Gural family. David Yagoda and family

PINCUS--Marion M.,passed away on March 10th, 2009. Adored niece of the late Sophie D. and Leah G., loving granddaughter of the late Adolph and Augusta, daughter of the late Philip and Mabel, niece of the late Joseph Pincus. She resided at 175 East 74th Street, New York City. Service on Friday, March 13th, at 10am at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Avenue and 81st Street. Interment Mt. Neboh Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Temple Emanu-El would be appreciated.

ESSEX--Winfield Scott Jr.,known to his friends as "Skip", was the first trader to have seats on both the New York and London Stock Exchanges. He was also a professional white hunter in East Africa, a partner in Hunters Africa and had a coffee farm in Rhodesia, before independence. He died suddenly February 20th at his home in Wellington, FL where he lived with his fiancee, Helene Jackson ("Danny") Magill. He was 66. Mr. Essex was an honorary member of the East African Professional Hunters' Association, an organization in Kenya that governs big game hunting and a partner in Philadelphia Investors in Pennsylvania. He was a member of the Brook Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club, and the Holland Lodge all in New York City and also the Racquet Club and Philadelphia Club in Philadelphia, PA. Mr. Essex was admired for his impeccable dress, gourmet cooking, wit, intelligence, and eye for the fairer sex. Mr. Essex grew up in Columbus, Ohio. He attended Washington and Lee University and received his BA degree from the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. Three children survive him from his first marriage to Brenda Teagle Callaway: Lee Essex Doyle of Boston; Amanda Teagle Essex of New York; and Winfield Scott III of Westport, Conn. He has a fourth son, William David Scott Essex, of Dublin, Ireland, from his second marriage to Victoria Thompson Essex. Survivors also include his brother Richard Essex and his daughters Helena and Isabella of London and five grandchildren: India Lee Doyle, Wyatt Addison Doyle, Hunter Scott Essex, Sydney Essex and Campbell Essex. A toast to Mr. Essex will be held at the Brook Club in New York City on April 16th at 6 pm. His ashes will be scattered over the plains of his beloved Botswana by his family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust, PO Box 15555, Nairobi, Kenya.

EPSTEIN Sally S. The Trustees, Administration and Staff of Blythedale Children's Hospital are deeply saddened at the passing of Sally Epstein, mother of our dear friend and Trustee, Peggy Epstein Tanner. We also extend our care and affection to her husband Alan, and Sally's other daughter Liz, as well as to her much beloved grandchildren. We know how much Sally cared for the Blythedale Children's Hospital, which she supported enthusiastically both directly and through her daughter, Peggy. John L. Furth, Chair, Board of Trustees Larry Levine, President and CEO Blythedale Children's Hospital, Valhalla, New York

GURAL--Aaron. The Governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Aaron Gural, former governor, Vice-Chairman, Honoray Lifetime Vice-Chairman and a member of REBNY for nearly 68 years. Aaron was one of our industry's most respected individuals and was active in many charitable and philanthropic organizations. Aaron started his career at Spear and Company and eventually became partner and Chairman of Newmark and Company. Throughout his distinguished career, Aaron brokered several billion dollars of real estate and was involved in acquiring major buildings in the New York metropolitan area. We express our sincere condolences to Aaron's son and REBNY Governor Jeffrey Gural, his daughters Jane Gural-Senders and Barbara Gural-Steinmetz, and the entire Gural family. Stephen M. Ross, Chairperson Steven Spinola, President

NASA called off the planned launching of the space shuttle Discovery on Wednesday because of a hydrogen leak in a vent line between the main engines and the external fuel tank. The problem cropped up at about 2:00 p.m. as the shuttle's external fuel tank was being filled with liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen in preparation for a 9:20 p.m. liftoff. Officials decided to drain the tank to troubleshoot the problem, and the launching attempt was called off a few minutes later.

GURAL--Aaron. The Officers and Directors of the Realty Foundation of New York mourn the loss of our dear Aaron. A board member since 1973, Aaron had served as VP since 1980. One of our strongest supporters - he was honored as our "Man of the Year" in 1988 - and a greater man is difficult to find. Aaron brought to each meeting, his great spirit, quick wit and dedication to our causes. His ability to get the job done - legendary. His love for his family was foremost, his zest for life extraordinary and his reaching out to help others greatly respected by all who knew him. Aaron, you shall be dearly missed - but always remembered with smiles. Our heartfelt condolences to his family - Jeff and Paula, Jane and Willie, Barbara and Tom, 10 grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Our hearts are with you. Jerry L. Cohen, Chairman H. Dale Hemmerdinger, President

ROTHSCHILD--Fritz A. The Jewish Theological Seminary mourns the death of Dr. Fritz A. Rothschild, a longtime member of our faculty who received rabbinic ordination and a doctorate from JTS. Dr. Rothschild, formerly the Joseph J. and Dora Abbell Professor of Jewish Philosophy, was one of the world's foremost experts on 19th and 20th Century Jewish philosophy and wrote extensively on the philosophy of Abraham Joshua Heschel. We express our deepest condolences to his wife, Lotte, and his son, Jonathan. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold Eisen, Chancellor Gershon Kelst, Board Chair.

VIERNSTEIN--Lawrence J.,Ph.D., on March 10, 2009, age 90. Beloved husband of Dr. Phyllis Ackman, father of Laura and Karl and their spouses, grandfather of five, great-grandfather of three. He made many original and significant contributions during his long career at the Applied Physics Laboratory at Johns Hopkins University, as a Biomedical Engineer and specialist in many scientific areas. His bass-baritone voice delighted small opera audiences, his family and friends. We will miss him all the days of our lives.

HUGHES--Paul M.,a former broadcasting executive, died Wednesday, March 11, 2009 at the age of 70. He lived in New Canaan, CT and Hyannis Port, MA. Vice President of Tele Rep, Inc. in New York City. Mr. Hughes recently retired from the Cox Radio Board of Directors. His prior community service work included chairing the Greater Hartford MLK Youth Fund, Hartford Urban League and was a former Board member of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, CT and the Doane Stuart School in Albany, NY. Mr. Hughes is survived by his wife, Maureen, three children, Caroleen Mackin, James Hughes and Nancy Hughes, and his sister, Bernardine Hughes, and seven grandchildren. Funeral mass will be 11:00am on Saturday, March 14 at St. Thomas More Catholic church in Darien, CT. Calling hours will be Friday, March 13 from 5-8pm at Hoyt's Funeral Home, 199 Main St. in New Canaan, CT. KEIL--Braden. Beloved husband of Jennifer Gould Keil and devoted father of son Braden Lewis Keil, Jr., and daughters Kaitlin Rose Keil and Kourtney Lee Keil died on March 10th, 2009, in Manhattan. Born in LaGrange and raised in Hinsdale, IL, Braden was the son of Herbert and Marilyn Keil of Potomac, MD. He is also survived by a brother and three sisters. Braden was the consummate professional journalist, writing for the New York Post for more than a decade. He chronicled the luxury real estate market with great insight, providing in-depth views of an ever-changing residential landscape. Braden's writing produced newsbreaking stories featured in the Upfront section and on the front page of the New York Post. Considered by many to be a Renaissance man, he had varied and diverse interests and in his twenties, ran for a seat in the Maryland House of Delegates. Throughout his life, he was a gourmet chef, avid tennis player, and recreational pilot. He traded commodities in Chicago, and worked in venture capital prior to joining the New York Post. He was passionate about his Post beat and had many close friends at the paper. He will be missed deeply by his wife and children. Funeral services will be held on Friday, March 13th, at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. Burial services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Braden's memory may be made to Beth Israel Medical Center, Department of Pain, Medicine and Palliative Care, 12 Baird, First Avenue at 15th Street, New York, NY 10003.

EICKMEYER--Bob. The employees of The Estee Lauder Companies deeply mourn the passing of our dear colleague and beloved friend, Bob Eickmeyer.
