Bob retired from the Company in 1999. Our hearts and thoughts are with Bob's nieces, Carol, Ellen and Barbara, his sister-in-law Ann, and his grand nieces Julie and Emily. Box 2227 Santa Fe, New Mexico 87504-2227.

EICKMEYER--Bob. The employees of The Estee Lauder Companies deeply mourn the passing of our dear colleague and beloved friend, Bob Eickmeyer. He was an outstanding innovator with exquisite architectural skill. He was a true visionary who marked a special place with The Estee Lauder Companies. Bob joined our Company in 1968 as a store designer. His career spanned more than thirty years as he rose through the ranks of the Clinique Store Design business to eventually become the Senior Vice President of Store Design for Clinique International. Bob retired from the Company in 1999. Our hearts and thoughts are with Bob's nieces, Carol, Ellen and Barbara, his sister-in-law Ann, and his grand nieces Julie and Emily. His spirit will continue to live on at the Estee Lauder Companies. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival, Attention: Kristen Tidwell. P.O. Box 2227 Santa Fe, New Mexico 87504-2227.

ESSEX--Winfield Scott Jr.,known to his friends as "Skip", was the first trader to have seats on both the New York and London Stock Exchanges. He was also a professional white hunter in East Africa, a partner in Hunters Africa and had a coffee farm in Rhodesia, before independence. He died suddenly February 20th at his home in Wellington, FL where he lived with his fiancee, Helene Jackson ("Danny") Magill. He was 66. Mr. Essex was an honorary member of the East African Professional Hunters' Association, an organization in Kenya that governs big game hunting and a partner in Philadelphia Investors in Pennsylvania. He was a member of the Brook Club, the Racquet and Tennis Club, and the Holland Lodge all in New York City and also the Racquet Club and Philadelphia Club in Philadelphia, PA. Mr. Essex was admired for his impeccable dress, gourmet cooking, wit, intelligence, and eye for the fairer sex. Mr. Essex grew up in Columbus, Ohio. He attended Washington and Lee University and received his BA degree from the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill. Three children survive him from his first marriage to Brenda Teagle Callaway: Lee Essex Doyle of Boston; Amanda Teagle Essex of New York; and Winfield Scott III of Westport, Conn. He has a fourth son, William David Scott Essex, of Dublin, Ireland, from his second marriage to Victoria Thompson Essex. Survivors also include his brother Richard Essex and his daughters Helena and Isabella of London and five grandchildren: India Lee Doyle, Wyatt Addison Doyle, Hunter Scott Essex, Sydney Essex and Campbell Essex. A toast to Mr. Essex will be held at the Brook Club in New York City on April 16th at 6 pm. His ashes will be scattered over the plains of his beloved Botswana by his family. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust, PO Box 15555, Nairobi, Kenya.

KEIL--Braden. Beloved husband of Jennifer Gould Keil and devoted father of son Braden Lewis Keil, Jr., and daughters Kaitlin Rose Keil and Kourtney Lee Keil died on March 10th, 2009, in Manhattan. Born in LaGrange and raised in Hinsdale, IL, Braden was the son of Herbert and Marilyn Keil of Potomac, MD. He is also survived by a brother and three sisters. Braden was the consummate professional journalist, writing for the New York Post for more than a decade. He chronicled the luxury real estate market with great insight, providing in-depth views of an ever-changing residential landscape. Braden's writing produced newsbreaking stories featured in the Upfront section and on the front page of the New York Post. Considered by many to be a Renaissance man, he had varied and diverse interests and in his twenties, ran for a seat in the Maryland House of Delegates. Throughout his life, he was a gourmet chef, avid tennis player, and recreational pilot. He traded commodities in Chicago, and worked in venture capital prior to joining the New York Post. He was passionate about his Post beat and had many close friends at the paper. He will be missed deeply by his wife and children. Funeral services will be held on Friday, March 13th, at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. Burial services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Braden's memory may be made to Beth Israel Medical Center, Department of Pain, Medicine and Palliative Care, 12 Baird, First Avenue at 15th Street, New York, NY 10003.

DESPITE the 1980s pop hit, wearing sunglasses at night was never particularly practical -- nor socially acceptable. But wearing protective eyewear in low-light conditions, such as at dawn or dusk, under cloudy skies or through dappled shade, helps preserve healthy eyesight and youthful appearance. For the outdoor athlete especially, wearing sunglasses no matter the brightness of the sky improves visibility, protects the eyes from particles in the air and limits exposure to the rays of the sun, which can remain surprisingly strong on even the grayest of late-winter days. ''Oftentimes, ultraviolet exposure is more prevalent during low-light conditions and on cloudy, overcast days than it is at high noon or on sunny days,'' said Dr. Kevin Gee, an optometrist and the director of the Sports Vision Performance Center at the University of Houston. ''For this reason, it's important to wear lenses in all low-light situations, which helps athletes tell texture, brings out background objects more quickly and shields their eyes from wind, objects in the air and glare due to traffic or snow.''

Workers took down a 1955 tapestry version of Picasso's antiwar ''Guernica'' (1937) on Wednesday from outside the chamber of the United Nations Security Council, where it had hung for 24 years. The owner of the 10-by-22-foot tapestry, Happy Rockefeller, is lending it to the Whitechapel Gallery in London, where it will be part of an exhibition about the response to Picasso's original.

When the Madison Square Garden crowd sarcastically cheered Justin Burrell's basket with less than two minutes remaining in the first half Wednesday, that was not a good sign for St. John's. When those same fans booed as the Red Storm left the court at halftime, the game was essentially over. Burrell's shot pushed the Red Storm to double figures on the scoreboard after more than 18 minutes of play, hence the derogatory cheers. Marquette was not having any such problems, hence the jeers from the New York fans as the Golden Eagles crushed St. John's, 74-45, in the second round of the Big East tournament.

SPRUCING up a problem room doesn't necessarily require a complete makeover; it can sometimes be as simple as dressing a bare bulb, wall, floor or window with a touch of whimsy or a dash of color. And if furniture is needed, one new chair, table or stool might be enough. For those shopping on a tight budget, this season's new offerings include inexpensive pieces that look like classics (perhaps too much so for some design purists), but cost a fraction of the price of the real things.

Just when you thought iPods couldn't get any smaller, they have. The new iPod Shuffle from Apple is half the volume of its postage-stamp predecessor; with no controls or buttons, it looks like a sleek aluminum tie clip. There's just enough room on the back for a mirror-finish spring clip for fastening to your clothes. Playback controls are on the headset cord, and because there's no screen, a synthesized voice narrates as you navigate your songs and playlists. The price is $80 (in silver or black), and the capacity is 1,000 songs (4 gigabytes). How well does it all work? David Pogue has a full review at nytimes.com/pogue.

GURAL--Aaron. With overwhelming sadness, the partners and entire organization of Newmark Knight Frank mourn the loss of our founder and chairman emeritus, Aaron Gural. A salute to this dedicated philanthropist and real estate pioneer with the vision that built our company to greatness, we remember the honorable and accomplished life Aaron lived and the number of lives he impacted in his 92 years. Aaron was an inspiration to our entire organization and we will cherish our memory of him. We extend our sincerest and deepest condolences to his family and friends, including his son and our chairperson, Jeffrey Gural, his daughters, Jane and Barbara, and his ten grandchildren, Aileen, Eric, Roger, Brian, Jennifer, Anny, Nikki, Perri, Lily and Noah and his nine great-grandchildren.

GURAL--Aaron. Our sincere condolences to Jeff, Jane, Eric and the entire Gural family on the passing of Aaron Gural, a long time leader in the NYC real estate industry. He was a man of great character and wisdom and a real estate visionary with the courage to stay the course through good times and bad. A Man's Man, a Broker's Broker and an Owner's Owner. Our industry has lost a great leader and we have lost a great friend. Earle Altman Gregg Schenker Steven Hornstock Jay Caseley Jay Kreisberg Keith Lipstein And the ABS Partners Real Estate Team

The March 2009 issue of The Strand Magazine includes a previously unpublished short story by Mark Twain, “The Undertaker’s Tale.” Andrew Gulli, editor of The Strand, which specializes in mystery and detective fiction, said in a statement that in the story, “Twain uses his razor sharp wit to pen a tongue-in-cheek tale about the funeral industry, which could easily have been written today.” The story will also appear in a new collection of Twain’s previously unpublished stories and essays, “Who Is Mark Twain?”, that HarperStudio is bringing out later this year.Have any ArtsBeat readers checked out the Twain piece? Your reviews are welcome in the comments section!

It is hard to remember a time when Alec Baldwin wasn’t just always funny all the time. You have to go back to go way back to his “I am God!” line in “Malice” and I’m not sure that even counts. Every Saturday in March, Baldwin is co-hosting, “The Essentials,” TCM’s ongoing and invaluable movie series with the network’s in house cinephile, Robert Osbourne, whom I vastly prefer to TCM’s nepotism-tainted, younger, alternate host Ben Mankiewicz. (His biography at TCM.com begins: “Ben Mankiewicz, scion of one of Hollywood’s legendary families…” Mankiewicz is the grandson of writer Herman Mankiewicz and grand nephew of director Joseph L. Mankieicz.)

Despite its ironic proximity to Los Angeles’s Stoner Playground, the office of Judd Apatow is not the zany frat house that his movies (including “Knocked Up” and “The 40-Year-Old Virgin”) might suggest. When we visited him there on Thursday, in the midst of a hectic editing session for his upcoming comedy-drama “Funny People,” we didn’t see a single bong, beer keg or passed-out partygoer (though a couple of his editors looked very tired).

Now that the big-screen version of Watchmen has been realized, the most eagerly awaited adaptation of a comic book is probably “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World.” The film is about a 20something slacker battling the evil exes of his current love, Ramona Flowers, and its cast includes Michael Cera as the titular hero, along with Mary Elizabeth Winstead, Chris Evans and Brandon Routh. The penultimate volume, Scott Pilgrim vs. the Universe, hits our paperback list at no. 10. Check out scottpilgrim.com to sample pages.

It took only five hours for tickets to sell out for all 50 concerts of Michael Jackson’s comeback series in London, which is set to begin July 8, Reuters reported this morning.Mr. Jackson, whose last set of concerts was the “HIStory World Tour” 12 years ago, initially committed to 10 shows at London’s O2 Arena, but he added another 40 that will extend the run to Feb. 24, 2010. “This is it, the final curtain call,” Mr. Jackson said at a news conference this month announcing the shows. “I just wanted to say that these will be my final show performances in London. When I say this is it, it really means this is it.”Mr. Jackson’s last album of new music was “Invincible” in 2001. He all but withdrew from public life after his acquittal on child abuse charges in 2005 and has been struggling with debts that contributed to his loss of his Neverland ranch and miniature amusement park in California.

Updated:James Purdy, whose dark, often savagely comic fiction evoked a psychic American landscape of deluded innocence, sexual obsession, violence and isolation, died on Friday morning at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey. He was 94 and, after a period of declining health, had recently broken his hip, said his close friend and assistant, John Uecker.

Saddle up the horses, Pa: The Ingalls wagon train is leaving the prairie and going national.The new musical “Little House on the Prairie,” based on the books of Laura Ingalls Wilder, will run for five weeks at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., in September and October and then immediately go on tour for performances in more than 30 cities through 2010, including Denver, Toronto, Houston, Tempe and Sacramento. The tour will begin at the Ordway Theater in St. Paul. The musical – which stars Melissa Gilbert (who played Laura on the “Little House” television series) – sold out all 12 weeks of its world-premiere run last summer at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, where it broke box-office records. The project was created and directed by Francesca Zambello (who directed Broadway’s “The Little Mermaid”) and has a book by Rachel Sheinkin (“The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee”) and music by Rachel Portman, who won an Academy Award for best original score for “Emma.”

Making eau de vie is not for the faint of heart. Nor is drinking it. In America, most spirits are consumed as part of a cocktail, and most cocktails are designed to hide the less-than-elegant character of the cheaper spirits commonly used in mixed drinks. My distillations, bottled at 80 proof, and bone dry and containing only the spirit of the fruit, are often shocking to people who have been drinking spirits for decades but have never actually tasted what they are drinking.
Rachel Steward and Peter Lord were wed on March 7 by the Rev. Joseph W. Tolton, a Pentecostal minister, before 98 guests on the yacht Cloud 9, docked at the New York Skyport Marina on the East River.

Earlier this week, the World Chess Federation announced that it has changed the format for the selection of the next challenger for the world championship. The decision came despite the protests of several leading players who had objected to changing the rules in the middle of the cycle.

It's been something of a watershed week for the nation's financial crisis: we've had the one-year anniversary of the serving of the disaster's appetizer course, the collapse of Bear Stearns; the noted philanthropist Bernie Madoff has thrown himself on the mercy of the court, if not the folks he took to the cleaners; the Dow Jones Industrial Average had its biggest one-day percentage gain since all the excitement began (bringing us all the way up to late-'90s levels!); General Electric (remember when it was the bluest of chips) finally lost its triple-A credit rating; the Labor Department informed us that 5.3 million Americans are now receiving unemployment benefits, the most since it began keeping that statistic; and some of the banks you and the Opinionator have graciously helped to stay in business have decided that perhaps we were asking too much of them in return (such as, ahem, making their executives let shareholders have a say before they decide to fork tens of millions over to themselves) and that now they think they'll go back to doing things on their own.
Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Matt Welch of Reason debate whether labor unions build up the middle class.

The landlord at Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the vast apartment complexes on Manhattan's East Side, got a reprieve Friday afternoon when the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court suspended a court decision that it had improperly charged high rents for thousands of apartments. The landlord requested the stay so that it could try to appeal the case. [For a wider look at the implications of the case, see this article published Sunday.]The court ruled unanimously on March 5 that the landlord, Tishman Speyer Properties, had wrongfully deregulated more than 3,000 apartments and hiked rents beyond certain set levels, while receiving property tax breaks from the city.

For decades, the "serious" foreign policy issues were the likes of non-proliferation or trade rules, but a new agenda is emerging and the treatment of women around the world is high on it. We saw that with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee creating a subcommittee dealing with women -- with Barbara Boxer chairing it. And now we see even more of that, with the White House creating a new Council on Women and Girls (in large part dealing with domestic matters) and the State Department naming a new position of special ambassador for global women's issues. That job is going to go to Melanne Verveer, the head of Vital Voices, who has been a pioneer in the area and is passionate about seeing progress. The Washington Post has a good item about all this.

There are few things that get me more excited than going someplace new. As T's travel editor, I'm not on the road quite as often as you'd think -- much of my time is actually spent dreaming up trips for others, namely the great writers we publish in our travel issues (the next one is out on March 22, by the way) -- but I do manage to get out and about pretty often. And today (hooray) I am off to Europe, on a whirlwind road trip through the former Yugoslav republics of Croatia and Slovenia.It's my first time to both places, both of which are not only rich in culture, food and wine, architecture and natural beauty but also interesting to me as post-Communist success stories. I'm traveling with some friends from New York - and meeting up with another who lives in Zagreb, Croatia's capital - which, for reasons I won't bore you with, means that my itinerary is a wee bit roundabout, but we're packing in a lot of compelling places: Istria, Croatia's Italian-inflected peninsula on the Adriatic (for some serious eating); the pretty and fascinating Haloze-Zagorje border region (serious drinking - lots of wine here); some of Slovenia's greatest hits, including Lake Bohinj and Lake Bled, the Soca River Valley and of course the capital, Ljubljana (all seriously beautiful). (You can get a snapshot of the two parts of my trip on the maps below.) As always, I'll be scouting for finds and story ideas for T, so the trip is a mixture of work and play. And for anyone who's interested, I'll be doing a first for me: sending impressions from the road to The Moment's Twitter feed, sharing our exploits and discoveries and photos, which, knowing this part of the world - and the madcap group I'm traveling with - should be entertaining. So follow along!

PARIS -- Sofia Coppola has been working both sides of the camera for LVMH. In a recent Vuitton ad, she sprawls at the feet of her father in Napa, Calif., a book-filled tote nearby. Last week, the filmmaker's vision of a perfect day in Paris was unveiled on French TV in a commercial for the new Miss Dior Chérie L'Eau fragrance. (If it looks familiar, it's because it screened for a microsecond in the United States at the end of last year.) Dressed in a pale pink sleeveless dress, the 21-year-old model Maryna Linchuk rides a bike through the streets of the capital, strolls across the Seine, is fitted in a Dior couture dress, admires roses at a Left Bank florist, nibbles on pastries at a Right Bank patisserie, sprays Miss Dior Chérie on her neck, kisses her boyfriend and is swept into the sky while holding a bouquet of balloons. Coppola set the commercial -- her first -- to Brigitte Bardot singing "Moi Je Joue" ("Me, I Play"). The director has described it as "a charming, catchy melody, a little 'bubble gum.'" Which is probably the last thing you would have called it in the 1960s, had you heard Bardot's squeal. The model-actress-singer-sex kitten starts sweet, then turns edgy -- not unlike Coppola's last cinematic confection, "Marie Antoinette." "I won, too bad / it's what you deserved / you are my toy," goes the second verse. "I will promise you an inferno of claws and fangs," goes the third. The Coppola commercial ends with Bardot's "Oh! oui, oui," omitting her orgasmic cry. Sofia, how could you?

Disney new "Race to Witch Mountain," starring Dwayne Johnson, will attempt to unseat Warner Brothers' "Watchmen" at the top of the weekend box office, with Universal's "Last House on the Left" and Fox Searchlight's "Miss March" as wild cards. Variety tries to divine the tea leaves. In the Los Angeles Times, Claudia Eller digs in a bit deeper and talks about Warner Brothers' efforts to attract fans to the expensive superhero adventure. The Hollywood Reporter speculates about whether "Watchmen," which opened last weekend to a slightly disappointing $55.7 million, will be a one-week wonder. Reuters asks exactly the same question. The Box Office Guru, Gitesh Pandya, guesses that "Witch" will beat "Watch," $27 million to $22 million.

Lawrence Summers, President Obama's top economics adviser, said this morning that he saw early signs that the economic crisis was beginning to ease. But he emphasized that the crisis would not end anytime soon.
During the Q. and A. after Lawrence Summers's speech today, he said his No. 1 aim had been to persuade people that the economy would not necessarily fix itself.

Through four weeks, some 200 shows and who knows how many flutes of free champagne (definitely fewer than last year), Scorecard has read almost every English-language critic's fashion reviews. This morning, with the press on their way to Charles de Gaulle, we bring you our final roundup of Paris fashion week reviews, including Azzedine Alaïa, Chapurin, Hermès, John Galliano, Limi Feu, Louis Vuitton, Miu Miu and RM by Roland Mouret. In a transparent tent (or "hot house") inside a courtyard of the Louvre, Marc Jacobs sent out his parisiennes for Louis Vuitton in all their ruched taffeta, totally-'80s-again glory; meanwhile, in a private showing on the Rue de Moussy, the erstwhile master of the bondage dress, Azzedine Alaïa, didn't cast a backward glance, earning him the polite claps of top critics.

Along with returning robins and budding snowdrops, this time of year brings a bridge table full of girls selling Thin Mints outside the local supermarket. I noticed them there last weekend, a rainy and chilly day, and wondered if that's really what their parents had in mind when they signed their children up for scouting. It seems Kristy S-Y, who writes under that byline for Examiner.com, had much the same thought 3,000 miles away this weekend in Seattle, where it was even colder.

With the State Senate balking on a financial rescue plan that would impose tolls on East River and Harlem River bridges to help close a mounting budget gap, officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority warned on Friday that if Albany does not act by March 25, they will have no choice but to order steep fare increases, impose "painful" service cuts and lay off at least 1,100 employees.

Glenn Reynolds, the law professor and Instapundit blogger, suggests that shift in gerontological research could be the ticket for solving the (perpetually insoluble, it seems) financial woes for Social Security and other pension systems. Writing at Forbes about the "longevity dividend," he notes some of the technological possibilities for slowing the aging process and observes:
Our market-rate lease is up in June. We have no intention of staying for two years - or even one - but it might happen. What are our options? Is it as simple as not signing and seeing what happens?

South by Southwest Interactive, the annual festival that lures the tech-savvy set away from the warm glow of their computers to Austin, Tex., kicks off Friday. I'll be joining the masses who turn out to see the newest and coolest Web innovations and the latest clickable sensations, reporting on what I see along the way.

Just how much of a secret are Merrill Lynch's bonus numbers? As secret as, say, the recipe for Carvel's ice cream?

Windsor Spitfires goalie Andrew Engelage set an Ontario Hockey League record for victories by a goalie with his 46th in Windsor's 5-1 victory over Plymouth on Thursday night. Engelage broke the record of 45 set by Steve Mason in 2006-7.

Americans are finally adopting some of Italy's better customs. Take Jim Lahey's new Co. restaurant in Chelsea, for example. The pizza is good - very good. His flambé pie with béchamel, Parmesan, mozzarella, lardons and caramelized onions will make your head spin. What really caught my attention, though, wasn't Martha Stewart sitting in the corner with a flock of goslings -- it was the $2 Caffé Vita espresso that ended the meal. Two bucks for an espresso or macchiato in a restaurant? That's unheard of these days, where a cup can run $4. Or at least I thought it was.
They may not be multimillion-dollar Bugattis, but around 30 rusty vintage cars were found in a barnyard in Norfolk County in England.
The flavors of chili and orange complement each other nicely in this juicy shrimp dish, essentially a very easy stir-fry.
Major League Soccer Commissioner Don Garber spoke with Douglas B. McIntyre this week about the league's expansion plans and a strategy for soccer moving forward.

Speculating about the fate of AOL is a constant exercise in tea-leaf reading -- and as tea leaves go, this was a big one: Time Warner on Thursday tossed out two top leaders at its AOL unit, and brought in a former Google executive instead.

First Lady Michelle Obama said she was moved by the struggles of the military families that she met during her visit to Fort Bragg on Thursday. She said she was particularly concerned when she heard that some families have to rely on food stamps to get by.

It's about two and a half hours to Tigertown, and the buses left promptly at 8 a.m. They were pulling out of the complex, in fact, when Fernando Martinez (not on the trip) pulled in to drop off Jose Coronado, who slammed the door and bolted toward the door.

Sometimes when you cover wild games like the six-overtime epic between Syracuse and Connecticut that ended Friday morning at Madison Square Garden, you remember the little stuff that happens off the court more than any shot on it. Here are a few little behind-the-scene moments that made this game special.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's comment about the importance of the rich in New York set off a round of charges that he does not get "it" (whatever "it" is). "You know, the yelling and screaming about the rich -- we want rich from around this country to move here," he said a few days ago. "We love the rich people."

Update | 8:31 a.m. American Apparel, the clothing retailer, agreed on Friday to sell a 20 percent stake in the company to Lion Capital, a private equity firm that once owned Jimmy Choo, for about $80 million, The New York Times's Andrew Ross Sorkin reported.

Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway was stripped of its 'AAA' credit rating by Fitch, barely hours after Standard & Poor's cut General Electric's top-tier rating, as the global financial crisis pummels America's corporate titans.

Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, the biggest bank in Japan, said Thursday that it will raise nearly $1 billion by issuing preferred securities, its latest step to shore up a capital base depleted by a tumbling stock market.
Warren E. Buffett said he was approached twice to help American International Group in the final days before the United States government rescued the insurer last September.
Each workday, when the closing bell sounds on Wall Street, the mayor in Charlotte, N.C., the Wall Street of the South, takes stock of this city's fortunes.

Swiss private bank Union Bancaire Privée, one of the largest European hedge-fund investors, offered Thursday to buy back $700 million of its clients' Bernard L. Madoff-related investments at half what they originally paid.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has reached out to Phoenix, the German drug wholesaler owned by Adolf Merckle, the German billionaire who committed suicide in January, about a possible deal, The Financial Times reported.

European private equity returns were 25 percent lower in 2008 as company valuations fell and exits dried up, according to data released on Friday by Thomson Reuters and Europe's private equity trade body.

New York State Attorney General Andrew Cuomo, Representative Barney Frank and other lawmakers are discussing a plan to link executive pay to the long-term performance of companies, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Deutsche Bank is set to ­double the size of its management board by promoting four top executives, thus establishing a clear pool of candidates to succeed Josef Ackermann when he retires as chief executive next year, The Financial Times reported.
Time Warner abruptly fired the two top leaders of its struggling AOL unit Wednesday and replaced them with one of the top executives from Google, The New York Times's Saul Hansell reported.

CNBC "Mad Money" host Jim Cramer appearance on the "Daily Show" last night, the much-anticipated showdown in the feud between the financial network and the fake daily news show. The reviews now pouring onto the net are virtually unanimous: Stewart won.
Nasdaq OMX plans to acquire an alternative trading platform in Europe, the U.S.-based group said on Thursday.

As merger mania sweeps the drug industry, a swath of biotech companies in the San Francisco Bay area may be next on the takeover list, as drug giants look to increase their product line, The San Jose Mercury News said.

Federal lawmakers pressured the top accounting rule maker for new guidance on mark-to-market accounting within three weeks or face legislation to change the rule that has forced banks to record billions of dollars in asset write-downs, Reuters reported.
The global head of Nomura Holdings's investment banking business will be based outside Japan for the first time in the bank's 84-year history, it said on Friday. Hiromi Yamaji is moving to London.

If mark-to-market accounting is to blame for the current financial crisis, The New York Times's Floyd Norris writes, then the National Weather Service is to blame for Hurricane Katrina; if it hadn't told us the hurricane hit New Orleans, the city would never have flooded.

Roche Holding's agreement on Thursday to acquire full ownership of Genentech for $46.8 billion is the third big drug industry merger this year. But, The New York Times's Andrew Pollack writes, it is different from the other two - Pfizer's $68 billion proposal to acquire Wyeth and Merck's $41 billion deal with Schering-Plough - in crucial ways.
A few clues that the economy's downward spiral might be slowing galvanized Wall Street on Thursday and sent world stock markets soaring for the second time this week.

Two small European countries, Andorra and Liechtenstein, agreed to loosen banking secrecy rules on Thursday, a small but significant step for Western governments trying to shut down tax havens.

Analysts appeared divided Thursday on whether Astellas Pharma would come back with a higher bid for CV Therapeutics or abandon its hostile offer, after a United States rival, Gilead Sciences, said it inked a deal to acquire the target for about $1.4 billion.

As the site for New York City's first free-standing wind-power generating turbine, Staten Island is logical enough in its way. The buildings there are relatively low, and it has plenty of unobstructed shoreline and hills from which to grab wind coming off the water.

News America Marketing, a unit of the News Corporation that produces coupon inserts and sells advertising in supermarkets, settled a lawsuit this week with a competitor that had accused it of anticompetitive behavior and corporate spying.

Nortel Networks is still working on a strategy that will see it emerge from bankruptcy protection, even as the beleaguered telecommunications equipment maker mulls which of its assets to sell to narrow its focus, Reuters reported, citing a source familiar with the situation.

Carl C. Icahn, the activist investor, said he had no plans to push for a sale of Lions Gate Entertainment in the current environment, but he criticized the Hollywood studio's expenses for being too high and called its purchase of TV Guide "reckless," Reuters reported.

Tired of squinting at tiny type the screen all day? In Windows Vista, you can bump up the font size - right-click on the desktop, select Personalize and click on "Adjust font size." Once the "DPI Scaling" window comes up (probably after a Vista security alert), select the larger "120 dpi" setting and click OK. Illustrated instructions are here.

There is "an unusual and surprising" number of homes available in Beverly Park, the Beverly Hills neighborhood home to Eddie Murphy, Denzel Washington and Rod Stewart, RealEstalker reports. Covering 250 acres (101 hectares) in the hills above the posh city center, the gated, high security enclave is also home to corporate moguls Sumner Redstone and Avi Arad.
In the second longest game in college basketball history, the Syracuse Orange beat the Connecticut Huskies, advancing to the Big East semifinals.

The Insider is a recurring profile of tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here the artist Jonathan Horowitz shares his essentials. A retrospective of his work, "Jonathan Horowitz: And/Or," is now on view at the P.S.1 Contemporary Art Center until September 14. A new solar-powered video installation, "Apocalypto Now," opens at Museum Ludwig in Cologne, Germany, on April 23; an exhibition featuring his work goes up at Sadie Coles HQ gallery in London on April 30.

Ronaldinho and Kaká, midfielders for A.C. Milan, were selected for Brazil’s roster for World Cup qualifiers at Ecuador (March 26) and against Peru (April 1) despite injuries. Kaká injured a foot on Feb. 7 in a Serie A match against Reggina, and Ronaldinho has had lingering problems with an Achilles’ heel. brazil.

Coach Eric Mangini continued his makeover of Cleveland’s roster by signing the free-agent linebacker David Bowens and releasing right tackle Kevin Shaffer. Bowens, 31, played for Mangini the past two seasons with the Jets. He is the third former Jets player to join Mangini in Cleveland.

The newcomer Andy Campbell of San Diego and crew Mike Nichol of Miami edged out the Olympians Marc Pickel of Germany and crew Steve Mitchell of Britain to win the fifth race of the Bacardi Cup in Biscayne Bay off Miami on Thursday. The two teams had a bow-to-bow duel on the last upwind leg with the Americans managing to keep their speed up through the finish line while the German team slowed a bit as it glided to the finish. The overall leaders Peter Bromby and crew Magnus Liljedhal, both Olympians and Bacardi Cup champions, finished 24th in the 64-boat fleet to keep the No. 1 slot. boats.

Trying to exhale here in Madison Square Garden. I've covered college basketball for 14 years and never seen anything like Syracuse's 127-117 six-overtime victory against Connecticut. To start our coverage, here's a quick run-down of some of the hyperbole and ridiculousness from the Garden tonight.
The Department of Defense has identified 4,251 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war.

The Sears Tower in Chicago will soon have a new name. A global insurance broker, Willis Group Holdings, announced that it would place its name on the 110-story skyscraper. A spokesman for the company, which is based in London, said it was able to negotiate a deal with the building’s owner that included renaming the building Willis Tower, in addition to leasing 140,000 square feet of office space. A spokeswoman for the Sears Holdings Corporation said that officials were “saddened” by the coming name change but that the company had no naming rights to its former headquarters, which was the tallest building in the world when it was built in 1973.

Lawmakers have approved the most sweeping changes to Utah’s liquor laws in 40 years in an effort to increase tourism and make the state appear less odd. The Legislature eliminated the private club system, which requires customers to fill out an application and pay a fee for the right to enter a bar. Bartenders in restaurants will also be allowed to serve cocktails directly over bar counters instead of walking around them. Utah, with a government historically dominated by Mormon church members, is the only state in the country with either law. The state’s D.U.I. laws will become stricter.

The former boyfriend of the model Anna Nicole Smith and two doctors were charged with conspiracy to furnish drugs to her in the years before she died of an overdose in 2007. Prosecutors say Ms. Smith’s former boyfriend and lawyer, Howard K. Stern, and Drs. Sandeep Kapoor and Khristine Eroshevich were charged in Los Angeles Superior Court with three felony conspiracy counts. A spokeswoman for the Los Angeles County district attorney’s office said the defendants were also charged with obtaining fraudulent prescriptions and unlawfully prescribing a controlled substance. Prosecutors said the doctors gave the drugs, including opiates and benzodiazepines, to Mr. Stern, who then gave them to Ms. Smith.

The police have arrested three executives from a Scottsbluff car dealership, where 81 vehicles worth roughly $2.5 million, as well as the executives themselves, recently vanished. The owner of Legacy Auto Sales, Allen Patch, 52, and the controller, Rachel Fait, 37, were arrested in Utah. The general manager, Rick Covello, 53, turned himself in to Scottsbluff police, Capt. Kevin Spencer said. The three were wanted on suspicion of theft. About two dozen vehicles missing from the dealership were traced to Salt Lake City; most of 16 taken to an auction had been sold to about 10 dealerships. Six others were found at the Scottsbluff airport, one was found at a Wal-Mart parking lot in Evanston, Wyo., and the Federal Bureau of Investigation found others in Las Vegas. Legacy Auto Sales has had financial problems, said John Childress, Scotts Bluff County’s chief deputy county attorney.

The government of Chile has filed lawsuits in federal court in Miami against four banks, claiming those institutions were negligent or had deliberately helped the former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet conceal about $26 million in public money allegedly stolen over several decades. The lawsuits name PNC Financial Services Group Inc., based in Pittsburgh; Spain’s Banco Santander; Espirito Santo Bank of Portugal; and the Bank of Chile. A PNC spokesman said the bank would not comment. The other three institutions did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

The Harris County district attorney criticized the police, prosecutors and defense lawyers in the wrongful conviction of a Houston man, Ricardo Rachell, whose DNA was not screened before he spent more than five years in prison. The district attorney, Pat Lykos, said Mr. Rachell’s conviction resulted from “a series of unfortunate events, blunders and omissions.” Ms. Lykos, who was not the district attorney when Mr. Rachell was prosecuted, said the office had no policy of testing forensic evidence before trial, something she said would change. She said she would require DNA tests in all cases where it was available. Mr. Rachell, who was cleared last year of the 2002 sexual assault of an 8-year-old boy, had long said he was innocent and had pointed to another man who continued to assault young boys after Mr. Rachell’s arrest, but his claims were not investigated until recently.

A fleet of mothballed warships rotting in waters near San Francisco Bay is not a major source of environmental contamination, federal scientists reported. A study by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration found that levels of PCBs, toxic metals and other compounds were typically no higher around the Suisun Bay Reserve Fleet than elsewhere in Bay Area waterways. Because of that, the agency said, it is not recommending specific cleanup of sediments near the fleet. The more than 70 old ships were kept afloat in case of war, but many have fallen into disrepair. A 2007 study commissioned by the United States Maritime Administration suggested that the ships were shedding tons of toxic paint into the bay. State water regulators and environmentalists have sued the federal government, seeking the ships’ removal.

A federal appeals court has dismissed a lawsuit by a Georgia gun group that sought to allow firearms in parts of the world’s busiest airport. The group, GeorgiaCarry.org, sued after the City of Atlanta and Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport banned guns from even unsecured areas in the terminals. That was a response to a Georgia law enacted last summer that allowed people with permits to take their guns into restaurants and state parks and on public transportation.

After facing three weeks of headwinds in the Atlantic Coast Conference, Virginia Tech brushed aside No. 9 Miami, 65-47, in the first round of the A.C.C. tournament.
A state-run science council denied Thursday that it had fired the editor of a magazine over an article about Darwin, as had been reported in Turkish news media this week.

Georgia’s main opposition parties agreed Thursday to join forces for an April 9 protest demanding the resignation of Georgia’s president, Mikheil Saakashvili.
